Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 23:19:38 -0500
From: Jon50g@aol.com
Subject: 944S idle problem (stalling out)

While we're on the subject with Jim Ringnalda's 944, I thought I'd chime in
on the 'ol S's status.  I have diconnected the O2 sensor at the prescribed
place (next to the rear of the valve cover in the white clip).  Well, first
of all, it was much easier then going for the connection at the exhaust, how
silly of me.  It didn't make any perceptable difference there either,
however.  The disconnection was performed at start-up plus 1minute, 10
minutes and roughly 17 minutes.  The car was reved up and down durring both
connected and disconnected phases of this test.  Again, no difference in
operation.  The sensor was exactly how Kevin and George described.  It
seperates to three connectors on each wire, one male and two female and
visa-versa.

I need someone to tell me if this means my O2 sensor is bad, or to elaborate
on what these test results show.  The engine performed seemingly fine with
the sensor disconnected.

Before I get more serious about hunting down this potentially temperature
related problem by fully removing the intake and poking around, I want to get
clarification on this O2 test and try some injector cleanor to see if I get
lucky.  I haven't ruled out the idle stabilizer either.

Thanks,
Chris Woodward
944S (53k mi)

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 23:28:56 EST
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>
Subject: Oil and irreverance

Back in the early '60's, I determined that the manufacturer's
normally 'best' oils were significantly inferior to 'premium'
oils in air cooled engines.  This may not apply today, but ...
In a VW, I found that with 'best' oil, the valves started to
stick at about 1500 miles after an oil change.  Putting in the
'super-premium' oils of the day would unstick the valves and
free the engine until I finally would get around to changing
the oil.

This cycle got repeated multiple times because I had cases of
Valvoline oil to use up.

Today, with no reverence, I change my oil in my daily use cars
twice a year .. more or less.  Modern synthetics hold up their
lubrication and viscosity properties pretty well.  They would be
rated 12,000 miles except for the legal liabilities related to
car manufacturer's recommendation of a typical 7500 mile change.

In racing engines, I used Castrol R.  It smells nice.  It also
lubricates well.  It doesn't mix with other oils.  Don't even
think of trying !!!!  .. then I haven't raced for a long time.

The lore in aircraft engines was always that the probability
of failure was highest just after an oil change.  I don't
know if it is true.

Just because your oil looks black doesn't mean that it has
stopped lubricating.

Rick Dill

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 23:43:17 -0500 (EST)
From: RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu
Subject: 944 all better now

	I am in a much better mood now my new(ish) puppy is idling like a pro; 
my express thanks go to George who tripped my memory at the right time 
regarding a loose vacuum hose.  My hand still hurts from getting the line from 
the idle control valve back onto the intake manifold (most easily done from 
underneath the car), and after connecting this I now have a performing 944.  
The computer (which I suspected) has a Hypertech chip in it, which is working 
fine, however has anybody got any details on this particular chip?
	Also I now have a surplus-to-requirements ECU (with standard chip) and 
an alarm unit (which rides piggy-back on the ECU) available at reasonable cost 
to an enthusiast needing such a unit.
	Now where can I get a good quality KKK turbo unit?...
Thanks again George,
	Jan

Date: Tuesday, 28 February 1995 10:25pm MT
From: MARTENS%emc2@ccsvm.stortek.com
Subject: 944 engines, No. 2's

George Beuselinck and pfilers,
       greetings from Down Under and a question for George and any other
interested people.
Of all the motors you have torn down, what percentage roughly have had
problems on the No. 2 bearings ?  Most common failures we have over here
seeems to be no. 2 rod bearing doesn't get enough oil.  Worst failures are
No. 2 rod bolts fail after the bearing; and then usually destroy the case.
One we recently stripped down, due to noise after a track day, had a bent
crank, bad no. 2 bearing, bad water pump bearings and bad oil pump bearing.
Lo and Behold, the crank showed signs of corrosion, again at No. 2.
Peter Fitzgerald, who is a prominent racer over here, his 944 Turbo is
actually a Turbo 3litre, has come up with a fix which can be applied. The
motor has to be out to do it and I dare say we will find it out next week
when we rebuild this motor. He also recommends only Castrol R synthetic or
at worst Mobil 1 Synthetic as the best oils for track and club cars,
regards,
Joe Martens  '86 944.

Porschephiles #1207                         Wed Mar 1 10:22:02 CST 1995
Date: Wed, 1 Mar 1995 03:57:29 -0500 (EST)
From: takaharu@sas.upenn.edu (Takaharu Mizutani)
Subject: Porsche 961 S2 ??? 


Les Kyger wrote:
> Saw this on rec.autos.marketplace.  Seems hokey to me, but I thought
> I'd ask you guys.  Is there a such-a-thing as a 961 S-2?

I don't know about the S2 part, but there definitely was a 961.

> >Very rare Porsche for sale or trade, 1 of only 4 ever made, with this one
> >being the only one left in mint condition.  $2.25 Million Cash or Trade.
> >Photos available upon request.  Serious inquiries only please.
> >The Porsche is a 961 S-2 which is the predecessor of the 959 and is the
> >only one left in existance.  It has a Koenig body, full roll cage, 6
> >cylinder 12 spark plug engine, dual ignition, dual fuel system.

I think the ad is about right. The 961, if I remember correctly, was the 
racing version of the 959- track racing, that is. I remember the 961 
competed at Le Mans sometime in the mid '80s, and at least one of them 
was destroyed in a crash. There was also a rally version of the 959, 
including an off-road type with big knobby tires, which, I believe, won 
the Paris-Dakar race one year.

But US$2.5M?!? That's a lot of money for a car that presumably cannot be 
used- investment purposes only?!? Would the 961 fit in any current 
racing category? I guess you could autocross it. :-)

Subject: Re: 944 idle problem

Hi, Bill,

Yes, your theory is all wet. :-)

Backfiring is usually caused by bad timing (ignition or valve) or a lean
mixture.

Subject: 86 951 Heater Problem

cbt@eduplus.ca (Stephen Davies) complained;

>>The heat in my 951 S has the nasty habit of disappearing when I come to a
>>stop and the revs drop. 

My '84 944 has always done this, and the dealer assured me that it was
normal.  Of course, my temp gauge rarely gets above the 1/3 mark, even
in summer with the A/C on.

Is your temp. gauge showing what you consider to be normal readings?  If
so, just keeping a little throttle on at the light on the real cold 
mornings, like I do, may be the best option.  Otherwise, things may
start to get expensive to solve a minor annoyance that may actually
be normal operation.

Good luck

Ed Gibbs
'84 944, Guards Red, All Mine!

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 95 13:59:43 GMT
From: kevin@mailserver.aixssc.uk.ibm.com
Subject: Re: Failure to signal



Let me share with you the events I was unfortunate to experience
last week.

My SO and I were driving home from a friends place at about 1 in the
morning after the four of us had been out for a meal at pretty good 
Chinese restaurant a few miles away.

We were about a mile away from our house when I noticed a car coming
up rather quickly behind me. The road conditions were pretty poor (ice) 
so I assumed it must be one of the local idiots (Basingstoke is full
of them), and slowed down a little to let them past.
The car behind also slowed and began to follow me. After approx
200 yards the thing lit up like a Christmas tree and pulled me over.

Both I and the Woman PC got out of our vehicles and the conversation
went like this :-

Me:  Hello Officer what seems to be the problem ?
WPC: Tanking it a bit up there weren't we ?
Me:  No (I had been spot on the limit).
WPC: Do you know what the speed limit is on this road ?
Me:  Yes, 40 MPH
WPC: You appear to have a faulty rear light
Me:  Oh, where ? (checking the rear lights)
WPC: That one there is not as bright as the other side. (pointing to lhs)
     Have you been drinking, Sir ?
Me:  I had one glass of wine with a meal about three hours ago.
WPC: In that case Sir, in view of that fact that you have committed
     a moving traffic violation and have admitted to me that you have
     comsumed alcohol I must ask you to provide me with a specimen 
     of breath.

(Long explanation of breathalyzer procedure and half hour stood at
 the roadside ommitted....)

WPC: Well Sir, that looks OK but I must give you a caution about driving
     with defective lights (giving me a caution notice).
     You must take your car to a Ministry of Transport Testing Station
     within 14 days and have the examiner certify that the light has 
     been repaired. You must then return this notice to the address
     on the back.
     You must also produce your documents (Insurance cert etc.) at 
     the local station within 7 days.
Me:  Uh, OK.

2 days after this incident I took my documents into the local Police 
Station to prove that yes, I did have a driving licence, yes, I was
insured and yes, my car did have a current MOT certificate.

The officer on duty was quite friendly and just complained about all 
the paperwork ( he had to fill in three forms for this 'offence').

When I showed him my caution notice he was amazed, his comment was :-
"What ? For THIS ? She must have been bored that night !"
"Don't fix the light yourself, because the testing station will usually
 charge you a fiver just to stamp the notice"
(Too late I'd already done it - I carry spares).

What really pi**es me off is that this b*tch of a WPC has cost me 
at least two lunch breaks and about $5 just because one rear light
was not as bright as the other. I was not given an opportunity 
to change the bulb there and then, nor did I get the usual :-
"Please get it fixed Sir, if it's still broken in a few 
 days time I'll have to book you"
I suspect that she was hoping for a 'Driving under the Influence'
charge and was upset because she didn't get it. A little 
Porsche-Paranoia may also have been involved.


- -- 
Regards,             Inet: kevin@aixssc.uk.ibm.com   Voice: +44-256-343000
Kevin Murrell       UKnet: kevin@aixssc.ibm.co.uk     VNET: NHBVM7(MURREK)
'87 944S (just about to get a new clutch)

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 1995 09:08:19 -0500
From: David944@aol.com
Subject: Some help for a rattle in a 944

Pierre

You write

> I can't give an explanation to that rattling noise but I have exactly the
> same noise with my 85/2 944. If for instance, I'm waiting at a red light,
in
> order to get this annoying sounds off I have to depress the clucth. I
bought
> my car 3 years ago at 60K and it didn't increased nor decreased since that
> time (I changed the clutch when I bought the car).
> 	Like you Timothy my mechanics told me that it was *normal*.

>	Anyone got better answer ??????

I don't know why you think the original note came from Timothy, but Larry
Reynolds from CareCareSp gave me this information and advice.

David.


>Dear Dave:

>I will give you a basic run down on the 944 drive train.  This will rather
detailed.  Please >don't read the word dummy in any of this.  I don't know
how familiar you are with your car, >so I will include the basics.

   I didn't, but yes I drive it, I pay for it, I love it, but boy, I can't
fix it!

>The 944 is a front engine/ rear transmission car.  This how they acheive a
50/50 weight >balance on the car (50% vehicle weight on front wheels/50% on
the rear)  This makes the >car very easy to control in corners.

>The engine is connected to the clutch assembly that drives the torque tube.
 A torque tube >is a drive shaft with no universal joints.  It is a solid
shaft (in a hollow tube) connected to >the transaxle.  The transaxle is a
combination transmission and rear end.  There are two >drive axles (half
shafts) that drive the rear wheels.  There are two Constant Velocity Joints
>(CV Joints are two universal joints put together) that allow the half shafts
to flex up and >down with the rear wheels. 

>The fifth gear idler is a gear in the transmission that is used in
conjuction with the >syncromesh gears so you don't grind the gears when
shifting.  There are several shafts in >the tranny upon which the many gears
slide backward and forward to engage and >disengage.  The fifth gear idler is
at the end of one of these shafts.  It "rattles" back and >forth due to a
slightly larger tolerance (this is normal) than other gears.  This rattling
>movement causes the gear to vibrate the input shaft which is connected to
the torque tube. > The torque tube then amplifies this sound much like a bell
amplifies the small sound of the >clapper.  Thus we get this "rattle" sound
from the rear of the car.  When you push in the >clutch, the torque tube is
loaded to the rear of the car and this takes up some of the >tolerance in the
gear shaft.  The idler has less room to vibrate and the sound quiets down.
>If the sound is anything but a rattling,  I would get a second opinion, as
something else >could be wrong.  I would not spend a lot of money to have the
rattle repaired as Porsche >stopped all warranty repairs for this rattle becau
se there is no repair.  We have to live with >it.  

>Sweptco ( I think this is spelled correctly) is a synthetic gear oil that
coats the shafts a >little better than mineral oils and reduces the rattling
of the gear.  You should be able to >find it at a race shop or independent
Porsche repair facility near you.  I don't stock it.  If >you can't find it,
let me know and I will get it for you and charge you my cost plus shipping.
 >It is not cheap, but in my opinion, is the best gear oil for a 944.

>I noticed that you live in New York City.  There are two independent Porsche
shops who I >would let touch my cars.  I do all of my own work and know the
quality service by these >two people.  One is Tony Henderson of Performace
Plus in Oakland, NJ (201) 201- >337-5678.  He is about 30 minutes from the
City.  Tony is a 944 specialist.  He also >carries Sweptco gear oil and would
be glad to change your gear oil and diagnose the >problem at the same time.
 The other is Bob Kakascik of Euro Perf in Garfield, NJ.  (201) >773-4870 or
europerf@intac.com.  Bob does all of my alignments.  He is a 914 specialist
>but does a lot of work on 944's.  If you call either of them, tell them that
I sent you and to >take good care of you.

>I am a member of NNJR and we hold hands on Tech Workshops where we show you
how >to maintain your car both mechanically and cosmetically.  If you are
interested, I can get >you into these.  I usually do a lot of the instructing.


>I hope that this has answered some of your questions.  If I may be of
further service, >please let me know.

>Larry Reynolds
>Car Care Specialties, Inc.
>Distributors of Quality Porsche Care Products
>Phone (201) 796-8300
>Fax (201) 791-9743
>E-mail carcaresp@aol.com

Hope this is as much help to you as it has been to me, I have an appointment
with Tony Henderson a week from now, and will report back on any progress.

Best of luck

David944@aol.com
1984 944  (In New York City, you can only AFFORD one of these at a time)

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 1995 09:27:39 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: No more shake, rattle and roll on my 944!

Hi gang!
	Here's a follow up on a problem I had with my car (85.1 944):

I was getting a rattling noise from the engine, driver's side any time I
decelerated and the rpms dropped from about 3K to 2K. It sounded like marbles!
It drove me nuts...

I searched around and found that the noise was comming from below the intake
manifold. By placing my hand on top of the upper balance shaft cover, I could
feel the rattling. 

Some people suggested that it might be trans noise. Well, I'm happy to report
that after changing the rear bearing on the bal shaft the noise has gone away!

My theory is that perhaphs the belt could have been overtightened at some
point, applying too much force to the whole shaft and making the bearing fail.
It could also be caused by normal wear (@ 95K miles).

But who knows and who cares! I already ordered the lower shaft bearings.
Do you guys know that it takes 1 week for my local P dealer to get parts from
Reno. I could have it FedEx and have it sooner for about another $16!

Anyway, does any one know (Jim P, George or Kevin) if the bal shafts are tuned
to work at different engine RPMs? I know that 4 cyl engines have second
order vibes that the balance shafts are supposed to counteract. I got rid of 
the 2K vibration. Now I'm chasing one at 4K. (lower shaft?) 
Are 2 and 4K (+/- a few hundred rpm) the 944s resonnant frequencies?

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories     len@library.att.com	   201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa  / '85 Guards Red 944
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo / '88 Silver BMW 325is

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 1995 08:37:21 -0600
From: pfile@tta.com (Porschephiles Mailer)
Subject: Monthly Update for March, 1995

March 1995

Monthly Notices for the Porschephiles mailing list. 
PLEASE READ THIS WHOLE MESSAGE!!

There are five sections: UPDATE, COPYRIGHT, FTP-INFO, CLUB-INFO, RULES. Be sure
that you are current on RULES...

UPDATE

It's been a *LONG* couple of months... I didn't get out an Update in
February, so it's been a while. There have been all sorts of developments.

The old and creaky hardware I'm using has started getting enough load that
it from time to time re-processes messages, showing up as multiple copies
of mail on the list. DON'T WORRY ABOUT THIS. That's why there's a "delete"
key in your mail progam!! And please don't feel the need to tell me about 
it -- I get the first piece of mail delivered by the list software, and the
first digest delivered by the digest software, so I already know. Your note
just adds to the load that's causing the problem... the thought *IS* greatly
appreciated, though!

While on that subject, Bart Chambers  (bartonc@infi.net, bart@tta.com) is
leading the charge to set up the Porschephiles Foundation. It's a non-profit
organization with a single goal: make sure that the finances are available
to keep this list on the air, and free to all. Sort of like Public Television,
but we won't send out notices between the notes for a week once a year... 8{)
If you're interested, send him a note.

There is some progress on affiliating Porschephiles with PCA, which would give
us access to lots of material that we just can't use at this point. Care is
being taken to insure that this affiliation does not damage the character
of the list. Things being what they are, this is moving slowly, and I WILL
keep you informed.

The Who's Who is out of date. There are 68 pending requests to be added or
changed, and there is a good chance that some folks on it now have dropped.
I'll get that fixed soon, in the mean time, what I have follows this note
in a separate message.

Got to run, more later!!

Stan

COPYRIGHT AND FAIR USAGE STATEMENT

The messages sent to this list constitute private correspondence by and between
members of a closed community. As such, the copyright for EVERYTHING that 
ANYONE posts lies with them. PERIOD. This is *NOT* a bulletin board system,
where consent for further redistribution is implied by nature of the the
system; it's PRIVATE.

If you wish to use something written by someone on the list, you must first
seek their permission unless they specifically grant the right in that
specific posting to reprint it at will. And, in general, it is a VERY GOOD
idea to *CREDIT* someone if you use something by permission "copyright xxxx
Joe Gearhead, used by permission" to keep *SOMEONE ELSE* from screwing up
down the line.

You may also solicit articles, comments, notes and expansions of previous
notes. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.

Remember, when you read something on this list: what you are reading belongs
to whoever wrote it. They may have plans to publish it further themselves.
They may want to keep it "private" (i.e. just for list member use). They 
may not care what gets done with it. It's still theirs, and before re-use,
permission must be obtained.

Please respect people's rights, even if they don't make a big deal about it.
I mean it.

FTP-INFO

Archives are available via FTP, compressed, since 4/90. There are no
older archives available. Remember, while it seems like a good idea when 
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before, 
there are OVER 18 MEG of archives. DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE TIME. 
Period!!! And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM CST, or I'll 
have to take access away. We do have to get *SOME* work done around here, 
you know...  Also DO NOT ask me to mail you archives, since it's just too 
much work. Thank you.

Images from a variety of sources are available as well, in /pub/images.
There is an UPLOAD directory there as well, if you have images that you'd
like to upload. Please include a file called "from.<username>", where
<username> is your logon ID that describes the files if possible.

NOTE: To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to use BINARY mode in FTP. 
Then on receipt, you need to use the UNIX "uncompress" program, or equivalent,
to restore to textual format.

SECOND NOTE: if you really, really need to get a full set of archives, 
we have a business services group which could write you a tape for a fee.
Let me know if you really, really need that.

FINAL NOTE: As I noted in a prior mailing, the FTP restriction above applies 
to major downloading of stuff from the archives, not WWW access. Suggestions 
for improving the WWW pages would be welcomed, as well as experienced help
in doing so.

CLUB-INFO

Some Porsche Club info follows. IF you're not a member, PLEASE join!! 
This info is also on-line in /pub/pca/info, in case you forget to save
this message!

P.O. Box 10402
Alexandria VA 22310

Does take non-US membership. You *MUST* have a Porsche VIN number to join.
+1 703 922-9300, roughly 9:00 to 5:00 EST (GMT - 6).  Dues are $36/year.
Have your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number handy.
Or they'll send you an application which you can mail in with your check.

National membership chairman is Nann Weissenberger who is reachable via
e-mail at nannw@aol.com.   You can ask her for info or get her to send 
you an application as well.

Ayton House
West End
Northleach
Gloucestershire
England GL54 3HG
Telephone : +44 451 860792

Specialty clubs:

356 Registry Inc.
27244 Ryan Rd. 
Warren, MI, 48092

For 356 enthusiasts around the world. $20 per year for US members, $35 for
world-wide members -- and cheap at twice the price!!! (Vic Skirmants' racing 
column is worth that, as are the classifieds...) 
5000 happy members can't be wrong! 

P.S. You *DON'T* have to own a 356 to join, and if you think you want to
own one, this is the best place to buy. No one seems to expect concours
prices for their cars unless they have a real concours car.

914 Owner's Association
100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
Palm Springs CA 92262

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries. Dennis Deeds publishes the club
newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly. Membership is $22 a year.
Again, they don't require you own an 914 to join, but they are interested
in the lowest and highest serial numbers known for each year model.

"S" Registry

Contact Vern Lyle, Box 363,
West Point, PA 19486 (tele (215) 652-7011 (day), (215) 287-5083 (eve). 
Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter. Dedicated to all early
911S models.

RULES

This list is still being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming
mail to the whole list at once. The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  

To send a message to the whole list, mail to

		porschephiles@tta.com

To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other administrative issues,
send mail to

		porschephiles-request@tta.com

If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you feel
moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request" address.

The list is also available as a digest, where you get a compilataion of
the day's messages once per day, rather than getting all of the individual
messages. This seems to be a win for people with slow mail links or who
are just too busy to stay current. If you want to convert to (or from)
the digest, send mail to the porschephiles-request address above.

PLEASE NOTE A FEW ITEMS:

1) There are a lot of  members on the list. It's small enough to be effective,
   and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and sets of
   experience. Remember that before you decide to not ask a question, or
   if you get flamed for asking an "obvious" question. Diversity -- it's
   a *feature*....

2) The list is maintained more regularly than it used to be. I have
   routine access and try to handle changes at least once every other
   day.

3) ONLY send administrative mail to the "porschephiles-request"
   address, or to me directly. And, you can also reach me by phone 
   at (713) 661-2084 if you have to.

4) In the same vein, if you use a "pure" System V mail system, please pay
   attention to your replies. The default will send the reply to 
   the "porschephiles-request" address, as it is the UUCP "From "
   address (first actual line of the mail header). 

   PLEASE BE AWARE THAT I ROUTINELY TRASH SUCH MIS-ROUTED MAIL!!!

5) If your mailer starts screwing up *you will be dropped from the list*
   Should you notice that you aren't getting the list any more, send me
   mail and I'll figure out why not...

Enjoy the list! If I can be of assistance, please don't hesitate to drop
me a note.

Regards From Your Moderator,

Stanley P. Hanks
Principal, OMNInet Communications
P.O. Box 2087, Bellaire Texas 77402-2087
e-mail: stan@tta.com    direct voice: (713) 661-2084

'64 356 SC  		(Daily Driver)
'74 914 2.0 		(SCCA ITA/PCA Club Racing)

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 1995 10:26:43 -0500
From: MrBru@aol.com
Subject: Re: Extraordinary...

Hi Bart,

So you're the guy who bought the famous - almost Porschephiles
list sponsored 914 race car!!  It's nice to hear from someone who
also appreciates the finer points of the 914 breed.  I am even
crazy enough to have sold my 911 to get a big six in a 914 - some
would say to have my head examined,  but I like it!

In answer to your questions, my engine was a 3.0 SC.  It has 98mm
piston/cyl kit, the cylinders were cut, pistons pocketed & champhered.  The
SC heads were used and ports enlarged, then
decked to end up with about 11.5:1 compression.  Horsepower
is somewhere around 325.  Some other neat stuff was done, but I won't bore
you with the details.    

I am using carbs, and I don't personally know anyone still using the
DME on the 3.2 in this application.  If I can be of assistance in your
venture let me know.  good luck

Jeff Brubaker

Date: 01 Mar 95 10:26:26 EST
From: Michael Kehr <71324.3010@compuserve.com>
Subject: RE: Motor Mount # 951.375.042.04


Jerry Writes:


>From: Jerry944T@aol.com

>Just received a Technical Bulletin straight from Porsche. 
>Once again they have an UPDATED engine mount for all 944 series cars. They
>include 924S, 944/S/S2/T. all years. 
>The new mount # 951 375 042 04, supersedes the former version, 951 375 042
>05. In a startling reversal it is no longer a hydraulic unit, but is spring
>loaded. It is longer than the old mount thereby eliminating the 4mm spacer
>used in the old model (on the right side). 
>This mount is applicable to either side of the engine. They are also saying
>that you can mix and match so you need not replace both mounts at the same
>time. They are also a bit pricey although I don't have the exact numbers. I
>do know that they are more expensive than the supersceeded part.(surprize)
>BTW you don't have to have a vibration problem to need a new mount. The
>factory would have you replace mounts if the engine oil pan drops below the
>lowest point of the front crossmember. Something about not tearing out your
>oil pan if you encounter an obstacle.

- ---------------------------------------------------
The technical Bulletin (#9011) I have is dated November 13, 1990. It describes
the new mount # 951.375.042.04. This "new" mount came out over 4 years ago!
The new mount does not use fluid for the dampening of engine vibration. This
is the first I have heard about a spring ? The mounts that are on sale now
are the "04" version, that is at least at all the places I called. They can
be found for around $120.00 each (discounted). They are readily available at
this price.

Mike Kehr   '86  951



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 95 10:28:47 -0600
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William C. Marten)
Subject: Lambda (O2) Sensor Testing

Since there seems to be an interest, this is the testing procedure found in 
"How to Tune and Modify Bosch Fuel Injection" by Ben Watson, Motorbooks 
Int., ISBN 0-87938-570-7.  (Hopefully that will keep me out of trouble with 
copyright laws . . .)

1.   Disconnect the connector between the sensor and the computer.
2.   Connect a high-impedance voltmeter between the sensor and ground.
3.   Start the engine and warm up completely (the engine, not you.)
4.   Hold the Lambda lead to the ECU with one hand and touch the positive 
battery terminal with the other hand.  Engine RPM and sensor voltage should 
drop.
5.   If step 4 fails, connect the Lambda lead to ground.  RPM and sensor 
voltage should rise.

If the system passes *either* test, the system is working properly.  If the 
RPM changes but the Lambda voltage does not, replace the Lambda sensor.  If 
neither change, check for continuity on the wire to the ECU.  If the wire 
and connection are good, replace the ECU.

Good luck (and don't shoot the messenger),

     Bill Marten
     wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu

  them, either. I
  routinely see them change lanes without signalling, pass on the right
  (even with an empty

  "off-ramp/on-ramp" game, etc. A
  couple of months ago a cop killed a woman while he was running a stop
  sign. He was
  speeding, with no lights on and was paying more attention to looking for
  street signs
  than controlling his vehicle. He was only going to get a ticket for
  failure to stop, but the
  department decided to get REALLY tough and suspend him for a couple of
  weeks. It's
  really hard not to get cynical about "law enforcement" when you see
  bullsh*t like this on
  a regular basis. I am really starting to become convinced that police are
  no longer public
  servants but tax collectors, as Pete A says. So much for "taxation

Date: Wed, 01 Mar 95 11:49:00 PST
From: Shafer Kirk <ShaferK@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: 944 O2 sensor anomalies


Performed some O2 sensor checks.  Cannot explain some things.

Running open loop, fully hot engine.  Measured volts at O2 sensor while 
applying 1.5V dry cell to DME O2 input.  0.00V (full lean).  This I 
understand since I told the DME the mix is full rich - so it drove mix full 
lean.

Next grounded DME O2 input.  Wanted to see 1.00V at O2 sensor.  Only got 
about 0.85V.  Do not understand.

Next, still open loop, diddled with mix screw in air flow meter.  Discovered 
it was nearly all the way closed (rich rich rich supposedly) but O2 sensor 
sat around 0.75V - only a little rich (0.45V = stoich optimal).

OK, so I began backing out the mix screw to lean out - watching, hoping to 
back things down around 0.45V.  No could do.  After 70 (yes, seventy) 
counter-clockwise turns could only lean it down to about 0.55V.  Am assuming 
that only first N turns actually did anything.  But I know O2 sensor is 
capable of reading 0.00V since it did so during DME test above.  Do not 
understand why unable to lean out enough via mix screw.

Engine runs extremely well now with O2 sensor reconnected.  Stumble under 
accel problem gone.  Have no clue where closed loop mix is really sitting 
now.

Suspecting marginal O2 sensor - drift with age.  Mine is original.  137K 
miles.



========================================================
Questions.......

O2 source suggestions?  Expected $$$?

Tricks to break them loose from exhaust pipe.  I expect great difficulty.

Danger of leaving things as they are?  Runs better than it has in years. 
 Melt cat?  Foul plugs?  Blow up engine?

Why don't shops [w/ gas analysis machines] set mix closed loop - account for 
marginal O2 sensors?  As I understand, they set mix open loop [at idle].
========================================================



Thank you all for any info here.

Kirk
'88 944

------------------------------

Date: 01 Mar 95 12:54:18 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 356 carb

 
Ingemar Sward writes
>my 356 C 65 with Big Bore Kit (1620 cc)... has always idle bad with dark
>spark plug. I have now change the
>piston rings and same problem occur... My carb are standard Zenith are there
>any recommandation before I change them to Weber or is it possible to make
>the engine run good on original carb. I know that I can change to larger air
>jets from 210 to ??? and where can I find those jets. And if I desire to
>buy Webers who can handle this to me in Europe complete with manifold.
 
1) >Is it possible to make the engine run good on original carb?
Yes. The factory did it. Big bore kit (1720 cc, not 1620?) may mean you have to
try some different jets for high speed but probably not for idle.
 
2) First try cleaning and adjusting your carburetors. Thoroughly
disassemble, clean, reassemble, and set idle mixture using 2 idle mixture
screws on each carburetor. This is a sensitive adjustment. Also are your
throttle linkages set up correctly and idle speed of both carbs matched? 90
percent probability that your problem lies in cleaning/adjusting.
 
3) >I know that I can change to larger air jets from 210 to ???
Won't change any idle problems. Air correction jets only do things at high
rpm. My factory shop manual indicates that the Normal used 230 air
correction jets, the Super used 220. You could try taking a jet out and
taking it to a VW parts place, I don't know if the Zenith jets are shared
with VW applications but some Solex jets (main, air correction) are also
shared by VW. If for some reason you are getting more air (big bore kit,
wilder cam) you will need to fool with the air correction jet (smaller) and
main jet (bigger).
 
4) >I have now changed the piston rings and same problem occurs.
When changing rings, did you break the glaze on the cylinder walls? If not,
they may not seat properly. Even if the cylinder looks fine, you have to
give it a slightly rough surface with a cylinder hone to make new rings
seat.
 
5) >And if I decide to buy Webers
If you are having trouble setting up simple Zeniths to run properly on your
engine, you will have 10x as much trouble setting up aftermarket Webers
which weren't designed for your engine in any case. If you want to use
2-barrel carburetors, find some Solexes from 356 S90, 356SC or 912.
 
6) 356s always run rich at idle, dark plugs at idle are normal. Are they
dark after extended high-speed driving? To check, cut the ignition while
still running at higher speed under load (as after extended cruising on
highway, perhaps 100 km/h or above), pull plug, check color.
 
7) Which Zenith do you have? The Normals used 24 mm venturis, the Super used
28 mm. You should have 28 mm on your 1965 C.
 
8) If your big bore kit was combined with a camshaft for more power, you are
probably undercarbureted and will need bigger venturis. The Webers normally
come with 28 mm venturis, not much better than your Zeniths. The Solexes have
32 mm. Webers with larger venturis are possible but hard to find and there
is a problem compared to Solex; see (10).
 
9) I have never seen a Weber retrofit installation that worked worth a damn.
The people who perpetrate these things claim "more power" but what they are
really selling is more bottom end torque with the smaller (smaller than
Solex) venturis, at the expense of top end power and torque. A good Solex
will pull strongly well past 6000 rpm. A 28 mm Weber will fall down well
before that. The customer feels more pull at 2000 or 3000 rpm but doesn't
realize that there is less at 5000 and 6000. These things are very
subjective and the human senses are easily fooled. Without dynamometer or
road test numbers, you really don't know what you're getting. I once played
with velocity stacks on my 356 SC, felt "wow, it's really moving now" and
when I looked at the acceleration numbers and instantaneous acceleration,
the car was actually worse than with ordinary Solex air cleaners. The stacks
will work better than the cleaners, but not without more rejetting and
accurate testing.
 
10) There is something called throttle ratio or throat to throttle ratio of
carburetors. Basically, it says there is an optimum venturi size for a given
inlet size. You can't just keep sticking bigger venturis into a carburetor
and expect it to maintain its drivability. That's the problem with putting
even bigger venturis in the Weber; its drivability goes to hell. Maybe OK
for racing, not OK for street.
 
Pete

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 95 09:56:08 PST
From: "Michael Hodos" <MHODOS@us.oracle.com>
Subject: More on Drivers with Suspended Licenses


- --Boundary-7213877-0-0

Dave: 
 
One technique that I have used very successfully in the Bay Area when being 
followed too closely is to simply use the flat of my hand to signal "Please 
back off" while mouthing the words.  I then follow up with the universal okay 
sign (index finger to thumb) to say, "Thank you!" 
 
This technique actually surprised me with its effectiveness the first few 
times I used it!  This leads me to believe that many tailgatters don't realize 
how closely they're following until it's brought to their attention. 
 
Michael Hodos (mhodos@us.oracle.com) 
1962 356B Super90 Cabriolet 



- --Boundary-7213877-0-0

>The two biggest sins I've been noticing of late: following other cars far to
>closely for the speed and changing lanes/turning without signalling.

No kidding, I see this routinely here in Santa Barbara County where traffic
can generally be considered light to moderate.  Seems that my poor little
911 attracts it's share of tailgaiters.  At 70 mph, I've had people follow
me so closely that I can't even see any space between our two cars!  The
worst violators are drivers of "Sport Utillity Vehicles".  I guess they
figure that if the need to stop rapidly occurs, they'll just launch off the
back of my 911!
>
>The latter is especially onerous given the fact that the CHP recently made it
>known that something like 90% of the accidents on California roads and
>freeways  are the result of drivers failing to signal their intentions!
>
Interesting since I estimate that over 90% of law enforcemnt officers (CHP
included) fail to use their signals at *any* time.  This is particularly
troublesome considering that these people are supposed to be "professional"
drivers.  They set a poor example.

When I was a kid, driving seemed a joy in California.  Drivers were
generally polite and they generally signaled their intentions.  I remember
my dad complaining about lack of signaling and rude drivers on our summer
trips outside of California.  Now the is the norm throughout the country
rather than the exception.

But, what can you do?

Regards,

Dave Sens
Santa Barbara, California
'71 911T Coupe

Date: 01 Mar 95 12:54:50 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 912 parts needed

 
Jeff Baggett writes
>I know about Tweeks and Performance Products. Who else is out there...
>These guys seem really high, especially Tweeks.
 
I don' buy no parts from no Twinks. Sure, they're high priced, but they're
also incompetent, so that makes up for it <g>. You are paying for their
slick catalog. (Not too long ago, I think I got their catalog no. 19 on one
day, and the next day catalog no. 18 arrived. I love it...)
 
For the absolute best service (and high prices, but sometimes you have to
bite the bullet) call Stoddard. They have just about everything, and are
owned by Porsche (that explains the pricing). 1-800-342-1414. You need their
catalog anyway just to see what is available. I think it's $5, refundable on
first order.
 
I think Carlsen Porsche Audi has a deal where if you tell the parts lady
that you are on Porschephiles you get a discount. I think anything Stoddard has
is effectively an official Porsche part available through dealers so maybe you
can go that route. Ask for Linda at Carlsen Porsche Audi, 1-800-523-2408
 
Zims in Texas is sometimes expensive, sometimes has deals. 1-800-356-2964
 
Call Doc & Cy's, 1-800-950-0356, to get their catalog. Haven't dealt with
them but their prices seem OK.
 
There are lots of used parts dealers -- Aase Bros, EASY, Southern California
Import Dismantlers, to name just a few.
 
Pete

Date: 1 Mar 95 13:40:00 EST

Subject: A Porsche man?

From today's (3/1/95) New York Times, Page D5,
An article titled "A Search Across Asia For a Missing Trader."
By Edward A Gargan

"Singapore, Feb. 28 - Police departments across Asia were alerted today to 
look for Nicholas W. Leeson, the English financial trader who was reported 
to have jumped into his PORSCHE and fled this city last Thursday after making 
disastrous futures trades that lost $1 billion and toppled England's oldest 
merchant bank, Barings, PLC."

Does anyone else see the commercial possibilities here?

Smartly dressed young man, briefcase in hand, slips into front seat of 
silver 928, pulls out of underground garage beneath sleek glass office
tower and accelerates into the distance.  As car grows smaller, voices
begin offscreen;

Executive:  "Has anyone seen Leeson?"
Young male voice:  "Hey, where's Nick?"
Angry executive:  "Get Leeson in here now!"
Secretary:  "Something big is up!"
Second secretary: "I know.  Everyone is looking for Nick!"
Shocked executive:  "Oh my God!"
Secretary:  "Mr. Jones, It's London on line 3.  They say it's urgent."
Panicked executive:  "Stall them!  I need time to find Leeson!"

Sound of bricks falling

Car very small now.  Roll slogan across screen.

"Porsche.  There is no substitute."

Nick - if you're reading the list wherever you are, be sure to send a nice 
check to the Porschephiles fund.

Date: Wed, 01 Mar 95 13:56:10 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Cheapest source of manuals ?


> >The absolutely cheapest source for factory service manuals has got to be
> getting them on microfiche from the dealer.
> >My 944 set cost $26 and the Turbo Supplement cost $12, from Stoddard...
> >Large Format Microfiche viewers can be had for around $200...
> >Only way to fly...
> 
> I had actually seriously considered this as an inexpensive way to get the
> manuals (seeing as how I am a student, wanting to save $$ and learn about
> my 914... the old "spend $ to save $")... my big question was how
> inconvenient it would be to have everything on fiche instead of the
> hardcover manuals.  You (apparently) haven't found it a problem.  You
> actually prefer the fiche?  Have you run into any difficulties?  Drawbacks?
> Any basic info would be greatly appreciated.
> 
Good question, so, I'll copy pfiles on the answer...

The drawbacks are:

1) you can't write notes on the fiche.  My old manuals are filled with
corrections, notes, and missing steps.

2) It tends to be tough to have the fiche in the shop when you are trying to
remove a greasy/oily part...Fiche and viewers do not take kindly to grease
spots...

3) You have to plan a bit more with the fiche...What I tend to do is take
notes on what procedure I'm going to do, then do it from the notes...

4) The wiring diagrams are in negative (i.e. white lines on black background
vice black lines on white background.) Not as easy to read.

That's it...
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

I can close the roof but not open it, and if i take the roof off i can
get the clamps to retract but not come back out
to hold the roof on again.

The reason I say its the switch is that I've been able to shine a light on the switch,
and stick a screwdriver in the edge that looks like theres a metal switch contact,
short that and the roof clamps work again.

If I pry the switch voer cover off with a screwdriver, am I likely to break it.
Can I just replace the cover if I do?> WHat is the "correct" labor-intensive
way to replace it. Its not obvious to me what interior panels shpould come off.
It doesnt look easy like the rear roof panels were (I took those off, then
discovered my problem was in the front...).

Is this in a "cheap" manual some where. At Pep Boys the Haynes/Chiltons didnt
have anything about sunroofs in the index.

Tight shot: Desktop.  Scattered financial reports, prospectuses, computer
printouts.  Pull back slightly as <major financial newspaper> falls onto
desktop.  Headline reads "BARINGS DISASTER", column heading "Major UK
bank reports losses of $1 billion".

Cut to: Medium shot, slender white male, suspenders, tie askew, grabs jacket
from coat rack and walks briskly to door.  Opens door, glances around, then
leaves quickly.

Cut to: Garage.  We hear a car start, wheels chirp, then red 911 speedster 
shoots across screen.  Pull back to shot of car rapidly accelerating down
the road.  Pan up slightly to show airplane making final approach.

Cut to: Office.  Smartly-dressed young woman pokes her head inside, asks "Mr.
Leeson?  The partners are asking about you."  Peers behind door, "Mr. Lees-".  
Shot of empty desk, chair still swiveling slightly.

Cut to: Used car lot.  A head-on shot of a slightly-dusty red speedster fills
the screen.  A hand appears from offscreen and places a placard with a hastily-
scrawled price beneath one of the windshield wipers.  An airplane is heard
taking off in the background.

Fade to black and fade in slogan (with voice-over):
	"There are no old Porsches.  Only new owners."

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 95 11:53:59 PST
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  924S/944 Sunroof Switch Removal/Cleaning

Paul,

I've had problems with the same switch on my 944.  Yes, you can pry the
plastic trapizoid off without doing dammage.  

I don't know the "correct" procedure - probably replace the switch,
but I heard that was a big job taking lots of interior apart.  So,
I went the easy route and just cleaned the switch with contact cleaner
and haven't had a problem since.

Good luck,
Pat
pat@ixi.saic.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 01 Mar 95 15:55:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Tire Mounting Advice Sought


Andrew,

To get the old tire off and the new one on, the mounting machine needs
to locate and lock down the rim.  The way the average shop machine
does it is by three or more "feet" which are pressed out and against the
inside of the rim.  Yes, they do leave the dimples you notice, which I am
sure must be a problem for some folks, esp. those who concours.

There is apparently at least one kind of machine which "does not
touch the rim," whatever that means.  I remember that a local tire place
(Direct Tire) used to advertise this feature.  I used them once about
six years ago, and they had idiots running the machine, mooting any
benefit it may have had.

The factory probably has machines dedicated to their particular rim
dimensions and bolt pattern, making it possible to locate the rim the
same way a car's hub does.  A shop has to deal with a ton of different
rim dimensions and lug layouts (count, diameter, and fillet shape).

Kevin

Date: Wed,  1 Mar 95 12:32:20 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: Cheapest source of manuals ?

| From: George Beuselinck  <George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net>
|
| > I had actually seriously considered this as an inexpensive way to get the
| > manuals (seeing as how I am a student, wanting to save $$ and learn about
| > my 914... the old "spend $ to save $")... my big question was how
| > inconvenient it would be to have everything on fiche instead of the
| > hardcover manuals.
|
| The drawbacks are:
|
| 1) you can't write notes on the fiche.  My old manuals are filled with
| corrections, notes, and missing steps.
|
| 2) It tends to be tough to have the fiche in the shop when you are trying to
| remove a greasy/oily part...Fiche and viewers do not take kindly to grease
| spots...
|
| 3) You have to plan a bit more with the fiche...What I tend to do is take
| notes on what procedure I'm going to do, then do it from the notes...
|
| 4) The wiring diagrams are in negative (i.e. white lines on black background
| vice black lines on white background.) Not as easy to read.

Many libraries have fiche viewers that have a built in electrostatic 
(Xerox style)
copier. So, you can print out the germain "pages". In fact, if you can't spring
for a fiche viewer just now, use the library's fiche viewer to locate 
the sections
you need and then print them out. Also, some of these fiche "copiers" have
the ability to print in posative or negative, so you could reverse the coloring
of the wiring diagrams, for example.

I don't have the service manual on fiche, but I do have the parts catalog
for my model and year on fiche. The parts list is almost as valuable an aid
as the service manual because it contains exploded views of all of the car,
along with all of the part numbers. So, if you get the service manual, don't
forget to get the parts list fiche also.

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

Date: Wed,  1 Mar 95 13:10:43 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: Failure to signal

| From: Albert Hsu  <hsu_a@jdola.lanl.gov>
|
| I was once sitting in a left turn only lane in Kingman, Arizona when one of
| the county mounties pulled in behind me.  The green arrow came up and I
| proceeded to turn.  Immediately the cop turns on his lights and pulls me
| over.  He walks up and asks if I knew why he was pulling me over.  I had no
| idea.  He then proceeded to tell me I failed to signal my turn.

Are you saying that your signal *was* on but he pretended it wasn't, or that
it should have been obvious you were turning since you were in a turn lane?
If the latter, well, the law still requires a signal even if it is a 
dedicated turn
lane. I know it seems dumb, but the law tends to be overly broad and does
not allow for judgement calls. This is a double edged sword. While it
makes for some dumb interpretation of the law, it also supposedly
reduces the chance of harrasement since the law is being applied
equally with supposedly minimal interpretation at the level of the
enforcing officer. That is the theory anyway. As someone's sig notes,
systems involving humans are imperfect 'cause humans are imperfect.

And along the same lines, I noticed as I sat in a turn lane this
morning that only about a third of the drivers had their signals on.

And while I am rambling along, I want to relate an incident about
believing turn signals. FWIW, this is from a newspaper account
of an actual incident. Two cars were proceeding in the same
direction on a two lane highway. The front car slows approaching
an intersection and appears to be flashing the left turn signal.
The car in back pulls onto the shoulder to pass on the right.
The car in front turns right rather than left and is broadsided.
What happened? The car in front had a burned out right
rear brake lamp and the driver was pumping the brakes. I
guess the moral here is don't pass on the right and don't
assume the other guy knows what he/she is doing (i.e. drive
defensively). The Porsche you save may be your own!

I wonder if anyone has done any statistical analysis of
injuries/deaths per mile driven on race tracks versus
highways? I bet that racing is safer than driving on the
street! (at least with modern race cars anyway)

    Eric

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 95 14:18:17 PST
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert H. Albrecht)
Subject: Re: Tensioner Upgrade/ other options for 911

At 12:56 PM 3/1/95 -0700, Jonn Kim wrote:


> I have been reading a lot about the need for Carrera tensioner upgrade. I
>would love to keep my car for a long time, and would like experts' opinion.
>Is this upgrage that critical? Can I get similar protection by installing
>chain guards (sold at Automotion and Performance Products) for about $25?
>What is the reason that these guards cannot be used with Carrera tensioner?
Don't know

>I also notices the variation in prices: 350 to 500 on tensioners. Are they
>all the same? 

Yes.  The only possible difference is replacing the tensioner sprockets 
rather than using the spacers in the kit, but this does not apply to your 
'83.  It already has the newer sprockets.

Also is there a good and cheap manual that shows how to
>upgrade the tensioner? 

I could mail you a few xeroxed pages if nothing comes with your kit (when 
you buy it).

I did this on my '83 SC a couple of years ago.  First, the REAL danger isn't 
failed tensioners per se, it's the broken pieces of chain rail (broken by 
the slapping loose chain) that are caught between the chain and sprocket, 
breaking the chain.  This is less of a risk in our '83s than in earlier cars 
because of improved chain rails which are less prone to become brittle and 
break.

I bought my SC with about the mileage as yours, drove it about 30k mi. 
before doing the tensioners.  There was no indication of failure.  When I 
removed the old tensioners, one required a vise to compress, the other I 
could work like a joystick with my thumb.  I also replaced the chain rails 
(another $30 for the set).  The job took all day.

Bob     '83SC, '65SC, Mouse the cat.

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 1995 16:20:57 -0600
From: wpcostel@aud.alcatel.com (William Costello)
Subject: Re: More on Drivers with Suspended Licenses

In Dallas TX, the freeways are like a NASCAR race with people following 1
car length, or less, at speeds up to 100 mph. This is when the freeways are
not being used as parking lots durring rush hours. The drivers that really
piss people off are slow movers in the left lane. The left lane is where
the NASCAR race is run most of the time. Driving is generally OK, except
for the drivers that like to snake through traffic by cutting between lanes
with no warning. These are the real danger to most drivers.

If you come to Dallas and signal people to stop tailgateing, they will signal
you to get the hell out of their way. People can get real hostile when they
get into their cars. The worst drivers use Honda Accords as their weapon
for the road. They tend to be the ones whipping lanes all the time.

W.P. Costello

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 1995 19:16:16 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: Interior photos

Scott:

Regarding your dashboard question, I don't know for sure but I believe the 68
911L had the same dash as a 67 except instead of the stainless steel trim it
used a basket weave vinyl.  
A good source of trim question solutions would be Brett Johnson's book, "The
911 & 912 Porsche-A Restorers Guide To Authenticity."
A good source for Porsche books old and new is Frank Barrett's "Toad Hall
Motorbooks"
His phone # is 303-235-0116
As far as your flasher relay, try under the drivers floorboard.
on your door panels, I believe the one you describe as your passenger side is
correct.  They didn't change to the door pocket style until 1969.  (This
would also be answered in Dr. Johnson's book)

Regards
pm9146@aol.com (Pat Moyle)

Greetings:

A couple of years ago I found out firsthand why Dallas drivers don't signal
lane changes.
I was towing a 46 foot race car trailer from Roebling Road to Denver and
since it was November, took the southern route.  (The trailer had 2 Porsche
vintage racers in it.  Subject requirement satisfied, I hope)
I discovered when I finally had a hole big enough to change lanes into,
(trailer and dually about 60 feet total length), if I signalled my intention
either the car at the rear would speed up to fill the hole, or someone in an
adjacent lane would dive into it.  The only possible way to do it was to find
the hole and take it VERY aggressively without signal one.  I don't know if
this was just "Big D's" way of greeting a Colorado driver or if they are just
as hard on their own.

from Sante Fe, NM to Albuquerque on I-25 at a steady 80 mph, (this was in the
days of 55 mph even on interstates)  the only things passing me were native
americans in pickup trucks and high school age girls in VW Rabbits.

Rick Dill (dill1@watson.ibm.com) wrote: 

>The lore in aircraft engines was always that the probability
>of failure was highest just after an oil change.  I don't
>know if it is true.

	Of course it is.  This phenomenon manifests itself in all sorts 
	of places... I'm most familiar with the "When you fix the last 
	bug in a computer program, two more appear" corollary.

>Just because your oil looks black doesn't mean that it has
>stopped lubricating.

	True, but it MAY mean that your filter has stopped filtering.  
	If you use synthetics to stretch the oil-change intervals, you 	
	should still change the filter every 3000 miles or whatever.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 95 19:49:21 -0600
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William C. Marten)
Subject: More O2 stuff

Correct me if I'm wrong but . . .

The Lambda sensor measures the difference between O2 in the exhaust gas and 
O2 in the ambient air, therefore, there is no way that a functioning sensor 
could yield a *zero* voltage.  No voltage would mean no oxygen was consumed.

The "normal" operating range for a Lambda sensor (again, from "How to Tune 
and Modify Bosch Fuel Injection" by Ben Watson) is 0.1v - 0.9v.

Since the 944 that is having problems (forgive me, I didn't write down 
whose) has a Lambda sensor that is showing a constant rich running, the 
computer should try to lean the mixture.  If it succeeds and adjusts the mix 
excessively lean, the engine could be damaged.  (does the temp gauge run hot?)

OTOH, if the sensor is correct and the ECU/DME/computer is at fault (not 
responding to the sensor voltage) the rich running will cause excessive fuel 
consumption and could (long term) cause the cat to meltdown.

Determining which part -- the sensor, the DME orthe harness linking them -- 
is at fault is left as an exercise for the reader.

     Bill Marten
     wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu


------------------------------

because they always seems to perform some stupid maneuver, like making a fast
right turn from the left lane, and I make a point of noting the car they
drive.

On the other hand, I've been stuck behind drivers who, upon seeing my 911,
slow down deliberately to "conform" to the posted limit, and they seem to be
invariably driving Volvo station wagons with "Save the Whales" stickers<g>.

Date: 01 Mar 95 20:55:41 EST
From: Nancy.O.Broadhead@Dartmouth.EDU (Nancy O. Broadhead)
Subject: Re: cam sprocket shims

- --- Fred L Hess wrote:
When measuring for sprocket alignment on cyl 1-3 one has to calculate the
difference in the layshaft sprocket for cyl 4-6. ... Anyone have the spec on
this for a 66 911 motor?
- --- EOQ

Our early 911 shop manual says: "When checking alignment of camshaft sprocket
for Cyl 1-3, add to the previously determined distance (A) (straightedge front
to drive sprocket near flank) the mechanically fixed distance of 54.8 mm (2.157
in.) between the front and rear drive sprockets on the intermediate shaft,
measured between the near flanks of the two sprockets."

Is 54.8 the magic number you wanted?

- --N
nancy.broadhead@dartmouth.edu

Funny, I frequently see just the opposite.  If I'm driving 60 people will
go 65 to pass my 911, if I drive 70, people will go 75 and so on.  Maybe
they're jealous or maybe the just want to get a look at a Porsche or maybe
they want to race.  Who knows.

Drivers of whale saving Volvos seem to move to the beat of a different
drummer regardless of surrounding traffic, but generally they're pretty
slow.

These days, I just try to stay out of everyone else's way.  So far, so good.

Regards,

Dave Sens
Santa Barbara, California
'71 911T Coupe
"I'm not sure we understand everything we know about this".

dropped the dash in my lap for free, and the dealer provided installation for
$50.

Not bad - gripe, complain, cry, and threaten.  There's no excuse for paltry
quality problems on these cars - NONE!

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 1995 23:10:16 -0500
From: Zunknown@aol.com
Subject: More 944 Motor Mounts

The latest update:

Porsche has long since superceded all 944 motor mounts to "04", which is the
only mount still in the price book ($197.00 as of the March 1, 1994 book).

There is an "07" mount, but that appears to be only for 968s with automatic
transmissions (!?).

As the supercession to "04" occured almost 5 years ago, there are probably
none left anywhere. The mounts currently on special were part of a special
purchase from the manufacturer by certain importers.

No one seems to have actually sawed one in half, so the question still
remains...is there a spring? Are they solid? Does it matter?

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 1995 20:16:59 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: 914 tire sizes

>        Depends on what you want.  It sounds as if the appearance
>of the 50-series tires just ain't cuttin it for you--so go bigger.
>195/60 is not too bad, and is usually a little less expensive than

It's not so much the appearance... Well, I guess that's a bit of it. It's 
also the way-off gear ratios and the speedo (well, the speedometer is 
not working right now, when it DOES work it'll be way off), plus the 
thing is SO dang low... From comparing the 165/15s that WERE on it, 
it dropped the car about 1.25". I'm NOT a "low-rider" fan, but it does 
look kinda neat on the 914.

>the 205s.  If you've got *STOCK* wheels (most aftermarket alloys
>were made for Bugs and don't have the right offset for it) you can
>put a 205/60-15 on the car, but I think the speedo may read high.

I have the stock steelies now, but I really want to move into alloys. I 
just don't like steel wheels, plus one or two of them got bent (from an 
EXTREMELY nasty pothole - the same hole bent the same wheel 
twice). I had them sandblasted and painted, so they look good, but the 
hammer marks don't help. :)

>        I put A-509s on my 914(s).  I just couldn't scrape up the
>$$ for the AVS-I's, and I'm not sure about Comp T/A ZRs.  I haven't
>heard anything bad--just not sure yet.  I went from a 195/60-15 to

I have Comp T/A ZRs on my Shelby, and I loved 'em when the car was 
on the road. Certainly much more than the Gatorbacks that I had on 
before. But I haven't driven enough different tires to know for sure.

>a 195/50-15 and the difference was astouding.  The ride got notice-
>ably worse, and the adhesion and gearing slightly better, and the
>difference in feedback was astounding!  I would not go back--at

Well, the only 914 I've ever driven is my own, and I put the 50-series 
on it before it went on the road (the dry-rotted 165s just didn't cut it), 
so I don't know how a "normal" one would handle. My car has no 
sway bars (waah!) and the springs are probably worn a bit, but it still 
handled very well, just with too much body roll. And the ride always 
seemed surprisingly good, all things considered - but I was used to the 
Shelby, which was hard as a brick. (Which is the way I like it - I like 
to feel the road.)

Basically, the pluses for the 50-series are better handling, 
responsiveness, plus they're actually cheaper for ZR tires.
Minuses are sitting too low, throwing off the gear and speedo 
readings, making the wheel-wells look oversized, etc...

Plus, when it sits that low, it's a serious pain in the butt to get a floor 
jack underneath it! :)

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 95 23:33:43 EST
From: weltyc@cs.vassar.edu (Chris Welty)
Subject: March Porsching Column


Permission is given to use this material in any publication as long
as my name and affiliation are left intact.  If you can, send me the
issue.  Previous Porsching columns are available at
http://www.cs.vassar.edu/faculty/welty/porsching

PORSCHING  by Chris Welty
Hudson-Champlain Region

When You Wish Upon A Star - Part III

It was a late Wednesday afternoon in LA, and we - our lungs slowly
becoming acclimated to the abundance of carbon based molecules in the
air - realized we didn't have a plan.  We were expected at the
apartment of a friend of John and mine from college, but we had no
idea how to get there.

"A car.  We need to rent a car," John said.  "And a map.  We
also need to buy a map." 

As if enough miracles hadn't already occurred, we actually found a
payphone with a yellow pages still in it (OK, look, I admit I
embellish this story in a few places, but this one is true.  No,
really, we actually found a payphone, in LA, with a Yellow Pages still
in it.  I swear, this one I didn't make up) I opened it up to Auto
Rental, and let my fingers do the walking.  It didn't take long to
find a place that not only promised cheap prices, but could send a van
over to pick us up.  After waiting about twenty minutes, I noticed a
white van cruising very slowly along the passenger pickup area.  I
immediately yelled, "Drive by!!" and threw myself to the ground,
anticipating the stocatto of automatic weapon fire.  John and Karl
ignored my warning, however, and were squinting at the van. 

"Did you say `Rocket' was the name of the place?" asked John.

"Er, yes," I responded from the sidewalk.  It was then I noticed
the words `Rocket Rent-a-car' spray painted on the side of the
van.  "I ummmm... thought it said `Rockets', the name of a
notorious street gang in East LA, " I said as I got up and brushed
myself off. 

We flagged down the van, loaded our stuff on board, and headed out for
Rocket Headquarters.  Despite a tendency to veer in the direction of
scantily clad women, our driver was able to get us to our destination,
which we mistook at first for a junkyard.  We hadn't actually
mistaken it, since it was a junkyard, but they also rented out a few
cars. After some interesting confusions about age limits and credit
card bills, we set off in our midget car in search of Porsches - 911s
to be exact. 

According to the "Illustrated Porsche Buyers Guide," a quarter of all
the Porsches ever sold were sold in Southern California.  When
combined with the generally dry air, the lack of snow and resulting
lack of salt on roads, that meant there were an extraordinary number
of prime 911s packed into the smog filled area around LA, and that
meant prices were low and some people were ready to make deals.  We
were excited.  We were lost. 

"Where are we?"

"Where's the map?"

"What map?"

"I think we're on Venturi Blvd."

"Never mind where we are, look!"

Soon it became obvious that the Buyer's Guide was right on
target. There were zillions of Porsches in LA.   Beautiful ones.
Black ones, red ones, blue ones, yellow ones, pink and orange ones
(well, one), a feast for the eyes (with a few exceptions).  We stopped
four or five times to look at cars, practising our ability to
determine the model year.  The problem is that very few californian
cars are original, so tell-tale signs like the bumpers or flares
don't easily distinguish the year.  John or Karl, however, usually
found some way to convince me they knew the year, though I was still
struggling with `T' not standing for `Targa.' 

We were looking at a black 1972 911E (the E, I learned, is for
eenjection) in a closed-for-the-day used car lot when I was suddenly
struck with memory. 

"Oh wait!  Last time I was here, I noticed a huge Porsche
dealership with a 917 in the window.  It might have been a model, but
it's worth checking it out.  It was on a big street - Sepulchura, I
think.  Let's ask someone." 

We found it pretty quickly, since it wasn't too far from the
airport. What I had seen was Vasek Polak Porsche, one of the larger
Porsche dealerships you'll find, on Sepulveda Ave.  I had actually
copied down the address on my last visit, so there was no magic
involved in finding it. There wasn't much there for us, we were
looking for deals, we wanted cars that needed some work and love, but
didn't need too much money.  Polak was not the place for such
people, but the displays were worth the trip.  That day there was a
917 and a beautiful RSR in the showroom. The salesman realized quickly
we weren't going to be buying anything, but since there were no
prospective actual buyers around, and since we were clearly fanatics,
he was more than happy to give us the tour and let us poke our noses
into and under the cars.  

There was a cutaway of a 911 engine with a sportomatic transmission,
and Karl pointed out  that the sump cover was rotated 90 degrees from
its correct position.  I had already learned to feign understanding
when there were others around, and a quick mental leap off the word
"sump" (which I recognized from experiences with failed pumps in my
basement), lead my gaze to the bottom of the engine where I noticed a
round peice of metal that could very well have been on wrong. I shook
my head knowlingly with that, "I hate when people do that" expression
on my face, and glared at the salesman.

"Only you would notice," he said to Karl. Funny how salesmen
like to pretend they know you well enough to be your best buddy.  The
guy probably didn't even know what a "sump cover" was!  I was just
about to suggest this possibility when some potential customers walked
through the door and we were forgotten.  It was probably a good thing,
the guy had been nice to us, and anyway we had promised to be at
Steve's apartment two hours earlier.

By this time we had somehow acquired a map, and we proceeded to the
UCLA area where Steve lived.  We were tempted many times to stop, but
instead we made mental notes of those places and managed to reach our
destination.  Steve lived in a nice sized one bedroom apartment, with
a kitchen, living room and dining room.  When we arrived, we found
that dinner was waiting for us in the form of tacos.  Steve's
girlfriend had taken the liberty of making them for us, even though he
had warned her it might not be a good idea.  We were pretty excited,
were just becoming aware of the fact that we hadn't eaten since the
plane (if that could actually be called eating) and didn't realize
until too late that we were eating faster than she could make new
food.

After we had devoured everything edible in the place, we headed out
for some pizza, leaving Steve (who had to get up early) with his
astonished girlfriend just gaping at the scene of destruction.  On our
way out we heard him laugh, "I warned you they eat like cows -
that's why I said we should go out for dinner."  We decided not
to eat at Steve's anymore.

The pizza was terrible, but we hardly noticed it.  The excitement had
built to a crescendo within me.  It was very late, and we were tired
from our trip, but there was no sleepiness in any of us.  We had
little choice but to drive around and visit the used car lots in the
local area, Porsches were all we could think about.  Along Santa
Monica Blvd there were a number of lots, all of which were closed, but
many had cars outside and unprotected by fence or other obstruction.

To an outside observer, we might have looked like some special FBI
used car investigative squad.  As soon as we noticed a lot with a 911
in it, we would pull over hard and come to a quick stop at the curb,
the three of us would jump out and converge on the car like
ants. Skirting the very limits of tolerence for any of the alarms
installed on the cars, we found fiberglass, welds, bondo, and other
surprises.  Even I was able to spot most of it.  Just about everything
in these lots were not what they appeared to be.   This was a sort of
"sauce for the goose" from my perspective.  At first glance, I had
about as much of a chance as identifying a car as John or Karl did.

Perhaps the FBI should have a special used car force, some of these
cars were being sold as what they looked like, but not what they were.
California, or at the very least L.A., has a reputation for being a
place where looks are everything, perhaps it was all that mattered to
most people here.  It did matter to us, though.  I was continually
thanking my lucky stars that I hadn't come alone, I might very well
have ended up with the first place car in the "wannabe" category: a
turbo-look 912.

Our first day in LA, then, ended on a rather dour note.   I had become
consumed with the fear that my fillings would fall out that night and
choke me.  More relevant to the story, I also had become obsessed with
the belief that all cars in LA were going to be like what we saw that
night: overpriced, butchered, and completely undesireable.  I had just
launched into a very heart-felt rendition of "O Solo Meo" when all the
car alarms in the neighborhood started to go off.  John and Karl
pulled me into the car and requested instead my version of "tubular
bells."

On the way back to Steve's apartment, John sensed that both Karl and I
had been disheartened by the night's experiences.  He reminded us
several times that he had come to LA and bought a Porsche earlier in
the year, and assured us that we had nothing to worry about.  By the
time we were inside, whispering in Steve's living room, he had
lifted our morale sufficiently enough that we went through the papers
we had and made lists of prospects to call in the morning.  I rolled
out my sleeping bag on the floor of the living room and prepared
myself for sleep.  The night had curbed my excitement enough for me to
reasonably expect rest.  Hope and the promise of a new day contented
me.  As I fell asleep, I gazed from the floor out the window at the
sky, but some clouds had obscured the summer stars.

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1210                         Thu Mar 2 02:00:06 CST 1995
Date: Wed, 1 Mar 1995 23:38:23 -0500
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: Washing/Drying Porsche

Scott Kelley asked what to use to wash / dry a Porsche.  I will try to pour a
little water on the subject.

What is the best product to use as a car wash?  The correct answer is use
what you like best.  There are some drawbacks to certain products and
advantages to others.  Dish detergent (Ivory Liquid, etc) may be used, but rea
lize that this product is designed to remove animal or vegetable fat / grease
from fired ceramic dishes.  It looks at your Porsche's nice coat of wax with
the same hungry eyes.  If you enjoy washing and rewaxing weekly, then this is
for you.  Wax retailers love people who use dish detergent (they send the
Ivory Company Christmas cards every year)

If you prefer to have your wax last a little longer, you may consider using a
product that is specifically designed for automotive use.   The quality
products are based upon detergents instead of soaps.  Soaps are manufactured
from rendered animal byproducts (the stuff the dog food people reject).  They
contain trace elements that can actually damage your paint.  These trace
elements are the same goodies that leave a ring in your bath tub.  (Ring
around the Porsche)

Quality car wash/shampoos (same thing - most cars don't have hair) are usually
 pH controlled, contain gloss enhancers and some even have a small amount of
water soluable wax for good measure.  Use only enough car wash to break the
electrostatic/ionic bond between dirt and your Porsche.  Start with a clean
large bucket (preferably plastic - if you kick the metal bucket, Mr. paint
chip rears his ugly head), add a small amount of the car wash and fill the
bucket with cool water.  Avoid hot water as it will soften the wax.  Read the
directions on the car wash bottle and try reducing the recommended amount by
half.  I use less than a half a cap full in 5 gallons.  The more car wash,
the more wax you remove. Try to avoid powder car washes, as the undissolved
granules can get on your sponge or towel and scratch the paint surface.

Make sure that your Porsche is in the shade and the paint surface is
relatively cool.  Rule of thumb # 1: If you can comfortably hold you hand on
the hood, you can wash/wax the car.

Spray the car with a gentle spray to thoroughly wet the surface.  Don't use a
200 P.S.I. fire hydrant spray, it isn't needed and may grind the surface
grime into the paint and cause scratches.  Some of the concour purists will
not use a nozzle on the hose at all.  Start at the top of the car and work
down.  Rewet the top, gently wash the top and then rinse.  Move onto another
section, such as trunk or hood.  Rewet this area, wash and rinse.  Continue
on down the car, completing a section at a time.  This way, the car wash does
not dry on the paint.

You may use a wash mitt, towel, or sponge to wash the car.  I prefer a wash
mitt as the grit tends to work up into the long fibers and not scratch the
paint,  When I redip the mitt into the wash bucket, I give it a swirl to
release the grit.  The flat surface of a sponge can sometimes catch dirt and
act like a sandpaper.  The purist will use two wash mitts.  One for the top
half of the car (the cleanest) and one for below the trim line and
wheels/wheel wells.

Your Porsche should be dried as soon as possible.  There are several methods
to accomplish this.  Lots of towels are a great drying medium.  They should
be 100% cotton (some of the blends contain polymer fibers that scratch).
 Start at the top, lay the towel on the top and then **gently** drag the
towel across the surface of the paint to pull the water from the surface.
Change to a dry towel and blot any remaining water.  Move to the hood or
trunk and repeat. Dry the sides last as the water will usually take care of
itself on these surfaces.  Another method is to use a chamois.  There are two
types, natural and synthetic.  The natural leather chamois contain acids,
primarily tannic, that strips wax.  Most synthetic chamois don't seem to do a
satisfactory job.  One exception is the P21S Super Absorbing Drying Towel.  I
have stopped using towels after trying this goodie.  I used to be a "dyed in
the wool" towel man. 
Driving the car to dry it may be fun, but you are redepositing dirt on the
wet surface and allowing the resulting "mud" to dry on the paint.

I hope that the above brief synopsis rinses away some popular myths.  If
there are any questions, please give me a shout.

Larry Reynolds
Car Care Specialties, Inc.
Distributors of Quality Porsche Care Products
Post Office Box 535
Saddle Brook,  NJ  07663-0535
Phone (201) 796-8300
Fax (201) 791-9743
E-mail carcaresp@aol.com

P.S.  I'm one of the people that sends the Ivory Company a thank you card
every year.

Ergonomics" and "Does Slick-50 Really Work?".

Suspended Licenses" discussion there?

find them by wading through all the "I'm the best driver on the road and 
everyone else is an idiot" messages.

Thanks, and I hope I haven't offended anyone...

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 1995 22:52:55 -0800

Subject: 911 motor in a VW transporter

>california offer a kit with motor and all.

Wolfgang:

transporters.  I saw one rip off an 11-second quarter mile.

Owners?  Something like that...).  I don't have their address here, but 
you can probably find it in any of the VW magazines ("Hot VWs", etc.).

If you can't find it, let me know in e-mail and I'll get the info for 
you.
