------------------------------

Date: Wed, 1 Mar 1995 23:16:52 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: Quest. about washing/drying car.

Scott Kelly (scokelly@netcom.com) wrote:

>What is the best solution to use when washing your car?  Is dish
>washing detergent ok or is something like Turtle Wax Car Wash a 
>better thing to use?  Or should you skip the soap and just use
>a lot of water and soft cloth/sponge?

	You definitely need the soap.  Some dishwashing detergents will 
	strip the wax off your car, so the automotive soaps are probably 
	better.  I use Armor All Car Wash, but if you have money to 
	burn, Zymol and Griot's Garage make good products, too.

>What is the best way to dry a newly washed car?  I usually take it
>for a quick spin to get the majority of the water off and then
>use a terry cloth towel.  I have a chamois - but it never seemed
>to work well for me.  I was told to get it (the chammy) wet first.

	The terrycloth towel is better for your paint than the chamois, 
	although if you do use a chamois, you should get it wet first 	
	(the chamois acts more like a squeegee than an absorbent cloth). 
	After you use one a few times, in fact, it'll be impossible to 	
	use dry, since it'll be very stiff (it IS leather, after all).

	Driving the car wet is a bad idea; the water will pick up a lot 
	of dirt during your "quick spin", and you'll then grind it into 
	the paint when you dry the car.

	By the way, you should wash and dry in straight lines parallel 	
	to the direction of travel (nose-to-tail).  Circular rubbing 	
	will leave swirl marks in the paint.

	General tips:

	Get a lot of water on the car first, then wash from the bottom 	
	up.  Don't use the same sponge (or brush, or whatever) for both 
	the car and the wheels.  Speaking of wheels, don't treat 	
	them any differently than you treat the paint; the finish on 	
	those expensive Fuchs is fragile.  Also, be careful of tire 	
	cleaners; some may discolor your wheels.  Rinse from the top 	
	down, then dry the car immediately.  If possible, wash the car 	
	on a cool, cloudy day to cut down on water spots.

	Don't wax the car if the paint is warm to the touch, and don't 	
	use an orbital waxer that spins faster than 1500 RPM.

	Oh, yeah... One more thing:

	Don't obsess about all this; it's only a car.

	-Andy


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1211                         Thu Mar 2 13:10:34 CST 1995
Date: 02 Mar 95 01:28:58 EST
From: Richard Kovach <76253.1567@compuserve.com>
Subject: 944 Power Steering Details

My recently-acquired 1984 944 seems to have an intermittent or variable leak.
When I was getting the car checked over prior to purchase, the shop pointed out
that there was supposedly no PS assist being provided by the pump.  I don't know
how they assessed this.  They didn't mention any leak.  This seemed a little
odd, and I noticed when test-driving (and since) that most of the time the power
steering seemed OK, but once in a while seems weak.  I've also noticed a very
small amount of leaking fluid around the pump under the hood and under the car,
but not enough for the level to be dropping much in the reservoir.  It's been
too cold out to do much serious poking around (ie. removing the skid plate to
get a clear look).

But it's got me real curious as to how the power steering works on these models.
Is there any danger of serious damage to any components from using the car with
the pump not fully functional?  Is it possible to continue use if the pump fails
completely?  

Are there parts/kits available to rebuild the pump if it's just a case of some
seal(s) going bad, and is this a job for a generally capable non-expert?  Is it
covered in the factory manuals (which I'll be getting soon)?

Many thanks, 
Richard Kovach
1984 944

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 09:53:19 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)

Larry, you wrote:

<Story of Damon Hill busted and banned for 100MPH+ on the motorway>

and asked

| Tsk, tsk. Just warmin' up for the first F-1 race. Ben, is this what 
| you guys do on the "motorways?"

I prefere to stay off the motorways in daylight, in the UK you can 
get faster point-to-point on the A-roads, given a 911 of course :-) 
On the motorway it is just a turkey shoot for the cops, besides they 
are so dull that I prefer to avoid them. Rolling along in a convoy with
lots of fat blokes in company cars is a prima facie case of Porsche
Abuse IMHO.

I do like to use the motorways late at night. All the traffic travels
in scattered bunches which you can see for miles, so it is possible to
pile on the power, haul in each group, slow to a reasonable 85 MPH
while doing a visual on each car. Once you have a positive view on
cop-or-not you can mash the throttle and really wind it up
while hauling in the next group. One clearly needs to maintain a
high level of situational awareness, probably a good idea at all
times in a Porsche.

Regards

Ben "bandits! 12 o'clock high" Evans

Date: Thu, 02 Mar 95 07:20:32 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Power Steering Details


> But it's got me real curious as to how the power steering works on these mode
> Is there any danger of serious damage to any components from using the car wi
> the pump not fully functional?  Is it possible to continue use if the pump fa
> completely?  

No probability of damage to the rack if the pump fails. It just gets very
hard to steer at low speeds. At higher speeds the effect is not so
pronounced. There are several racers on the net who run the power steering
rack without the ps pump, to eliminate the drag on the engine...

> 
> Are there parts/kits available to rebuild the pump if it's just a case of som
> seal(s) going bad, and is this a job for a generally capable non-expert?  Is 
> covered in the factory manuals (which I'll be getting soon)?

No pump rebuild kits generally available. There are used pumps available in
the $140-$160 range, depending on condition.

Of course, you have not definitely completed the diagnosis. You could have a
leaking hose that is allowing air into the system. Or you could have a rack
with a worn spot. Both of those are common failures also...

- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

clear it up.

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 10:12:04 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: preparing 914 for autocross

> Also, is there a FAQ or archive for the 914 that I could
>pass along to him...

        There's an FAQ, but it isn't very helpful on these subjects.

>Also, what is the (or, is there a) recommended wheel alignment.  He has some
>more questions, but thought this was a start.

        Step 1 when preparing for *ANY* racing endeavor--READ the RULES!
Particular alignments can put you out of some classes in some organizations.
I guess alignments are "free" in SCCA, but that's just another beef I've
got with them...
        Zone 7 PCA Stock classes are limited to -1 degree front camber,
 -1.5 degree rear camber.  Toe and castor are free, as the "stock" numbers
are fine for just about any application.
        Basically, a 914 on "street" tires will hook up better with more
negative camber.  (There *are* exceptions!)  However, tires start wearing
more quickly with more than about -0.5 to -1.0 degrees negative camber.
The problem is that, when driving on the street, you're putting more of
the car's weight on the inside of the tires, which wears them faster.
        Corner balancing, at "race weight" (e.g., no spare tire, tools,
coolers full of beer, etc., but *with* the weight of the driver) comes
highly recommended.
        Figure this whole thing is about 2-5 hours of labor ($$) on a 914.
Two hours would be unusual.  Mine took 4.  If you're in the Bay Area, try
Ken's SporTech down in Campbell.

- --DD

"No cones, no cones..."    ____--/~|___\_____.      _____
                          (  _             _  >    |_____|___|__/____|_
Dave Darling               ~' `~~~~~~~~~~~' `~      _____|   |       |
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov `~'           `~'

>The heat in my 951 S has the nasty habit of disappearing when I come to a stop

>core...)

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 12:07:19 -0500
From: Kuma77@aol.com
Subject: 944 Dies or Doesn't Start

I have a 84 944.  I was driving one day and it just cut out, no sputtering or
anything it just cut out.  I tried to restart it and it didn't.  After about
30 minutes it started and ran for 30 minutes and died.
After several attemps to start it a few days later it started, ran for 90
minutes and died. I checked the coil for spark and had none.  I replaced the
coil with a spare good one I had, no luck.  I then took the Computer out and
took it apart.  It looked good inside,ie no bad soldering, and put it back
in.  I also cleaned the contacts on the computer.  This time the car started
right up and ran for 7 minutes before stopping again.  No Spark again.  It
started again an hour later and ran several minutes.  I thought it was a
loose sensor so I was wiggling them around and I touched one at the rear of
the engine above the bell housing and the car died.  I could not restart it
since.
    The computer was replaced in 89 after the previous one failed( I jump
started another car) and only has 35,000 miles on it.
Does any one have a suggestion or similar experience?
Also is there available a schematic for the computer since the chips are not
labeled and  my hand book doesn't cover it.  I think I could test the
computer if I knew what the checks needed to be but haven't found any sources
of info to do this?
Again any help would be appreciated.
Joe

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 18:14:33 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 944 Dies or Doesn't Start


On Thu, 2 Mar 1995 Kuma77@aol.com wrote:

> 
> I have a 84 944.  I was driving one day and it just cut out, no sputtering or
> anything it just cut out.  I tried to restart it and it didn't.  After about
> 30 minutes it started and ran for 30 minutes and died.
> After several attemps to start it a few days later it started, ran for 90

I had a saga with the same problem a few weeks ago. The symptoms are 
identical.

We had quite a conversation on the net about it, it took we around a week 
to track down the problem.

It was very difficult to diagnose because of the fact that it kept 
clearing up.

Eventually in my case, I noticed that when ever I lost the spark, I also
lost my rear wiper - this was the clue, I figured that it must be a common
electrical wire. I did not actually find the problem, but I dropped down
the fuse panel, you know how it sort of hooks in under the glove box.
After I waggled a few wires, it wiper burst into life, and then I was able
to restart the engine. 

Looking at the wiring diag in Haynes, it is not clear if the wiper and 
ignition box are on the same wiring run, it kinda loops all around the 
back of the fuse panel, so I never found a loose connection, but since 
then I have done around 6k miles with no further problems.

Suffice to say I was very relieved, because there had been talk about 
components breaking down in the spark box, fuel pumps etc etc, someone else 
suggested water in the dizzy cap!!

So I suggest keep a x-head screw driver and some pliers in the car, and next 
time it happens drop down the fuse box and give all the red wires a 
gentle waggle.

In the mean time stay out of the fast lane on the interstate, 3 times 
before I found the problem, the car had cut whilst I was doing > 70 mph 
in the outside lane.

Good luck

Pete


+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 13:24:37 -0500
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: Re: Car Covers

Barry,

Using a car cover outside is well worth the trade-off of any  microscopic
scratches your car might get.  This, compared to the sun and pollution damage
is a good trade-off.

Never use a dirty (inside) cover or cover a dirty car.

I use a cover everyday in dry weather.  After 5 years my paint looks as new. 

As for covering your car in the garage, I used to do that but I don't think
it necessary or important unless storing your car.  Plus, you can not look at
your pretty car in the garage if it is covered.

 -Allen Henderson-
'72S, '59A (still) Coupes

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 15:10:26 -0800
From: audacity@halcyon.com

Scott Banister
President
Audacity, Inc.

Hi fellow Porschephiles,

A few days ago, we at Audacity, placed an e-mail release out on the 
Porschephiles list about our Exceeding the Limit service.

I was pleasantly surprised by the response; we saw quite a few "Cool, sign me 
up."  However, we received a few that said "you have the Audacity to do this!"

To all those who showed a positive interest in our service, I would like to 
thank you for your interest and assure you that the information you requested 
is on the way.  In addition, I would like to apologize on behalf of Audacity 
for any bad blood it might have caused with the Porschephiles membership.  I 
think some of the consternation we have caused can be cleared up with a little 
explanation...

I think some of the confusion stems in that we are NOT an internet list or 
home page and some people thought we are.  I could certainly see why people 
would wonder why they should pay for a service they get now for free.  We 
apologize for not making  that more clear in the release.  Our service is 
similar to what is available through the Porschephile list, but certainly not 
identical.

So, What are We?

What we are in terms of technology is the equivalent of an "American On-line" 
for Porsche owners.  We do not use the Internet for access to our system 
although in the future we may do so.  What we do is we have specialized 
Windows on-line software that is used to connect Porsche people to our server 
over normal phone lines.  We are geared up to tap into the 99% of Porsche 
owner who do not have the technical know how or the desire to get themselves 
on to the internet at this time.  We may not be right for all the Porschephile 
list's membership, however, we thatought this group would generally like to 
know about it.

I hope that should calm some agner in regards to us advertising in "another 
list", since we are in fact, not a list.

If you are unclear about our service, please call us and speak with us 
personally.  We can clear up any confusion you might have.  

Come check us out, we are growing every day.  See you on the info-bahn!


Scott Banister
President
Audacity, Inc.

(206)455-0314 voice
(206)455-2760 fax
audacity@halcyon.com

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 95 11:25:32 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: 912 Questions


Scott wrote:

2)  I would like to get the seats redone.  The springs/foam are shot and I'd like to get new covers installed.  Anyone know a cheap way to do this (remember I am a 912 owner!)


You might consider doing it yourself, Scott.  Re-doing seats isn't
all that hard.  The springs can usually be stiffened up by binding
them together with hog rings or hardware store wire.  You can also
stuff some stiff foam in them to make them stiffer.  Beats the
price of new ones by a mile.  New foam is easy.  You can usually
buy what you need at an upholstery supply store, or even at 
a big sewing center.  It can be shaped by trimming with a sharp
blade, like a razor blade, and also by filing it with a Surefoam
file.  One technique is to build up a rough shape by gluing 
appropriately cut pieces together, and then smoothing with a blad
or file.  

As for the covers themselves, that's a bit harder to do from
scratch, although if cost really is the biggest problem you can do it.  
One way is to take apart your present covers, use the pieces as 
patterns, and cut new ones.  Vinyl, by the way, is very cheap, and
is available at all sewing centers.  If you can afford a bit more,
I'd but seat covers already made up from any of the outfits that
advertise in Pano or Excellence.  There are some companies that
specialize in interior trim, but almost all the parts suppliers
also sell seat cover kits.

One more thing.  If you decide to cut and sew the vinyl, you'll
probably have to rent a heavy duty sewing machine.  Last time
I looked, about six months ago, the cost was about $60 for
a month.  Ought to be able to sew a bunch of stuff in a month...

Have fun.

Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa

------------------------------

Date: Thu,  2 Mar 95 13:51:04 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: Driving in England

[...]
> I do like to use the motorways late at night. All the traffic travels
> in scattered bunches which you can see for miles, so it is possible to
> pile on the power, haul in each group, slow to a reasonable 85 MPH
> while doing a visual on each car. Once you have a positive view on
> cop-or-not you can mash the throttle and really wind it up
> while hauling in the next group. One clearly needs to maintain a
> high level of situational awareness, probably a good idea at all
> times in a Porsche.
>
> Regards
>
> Ben "bandits! 12 o'clock high" Evans

Ben, this is nearly identical to the 'states.  Packs of animals, er, I 
mean cars & drivers, clustered together increasing their probability of 
an accident.  For some reason probably deeply rooted in human behavior, 
drivers cling in groups according to the least common denominator.  
Those whose minds are still functional like to drive fast & often 
alone, breaking through these groups of people in a technique I call 
"pack jumping".

This becomes very clear from the air - if you ever get a chance, study 
a road for a while and you'll see packs come & go.  Pretty amusing.

Say, do you have toll roads in England?  If so, do you find people 
following each other blindly into toll booth lanes, ignoring open & 
empty lanes?  This is another chapter in my "Lemming Theory" of driver 
behavior.

I lift my glass to those with the minds to enjoy life in their own lane!

		Jim

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 95 10:42:18 CST
From: husain@zeus1.issc.com (Afsar Husain (N3564))
Subject: Re: BORLA MUFFLER FOR AN '87' 944

Tim,

I had Borla muffler installed  on my 85/2 944 last August. I purchased it
for around $480 form EuroProduct (800-962-0911). My actual invoice price
was less than the price they quoted to me on the phone, which again was
less than their 944 Special Excellence Ad price. But I wasn't going to 
complain about that ;-)

As far as the muffler is concerned it does sounds good and I do feel like
a have gained some ponies since the car has a better kick then before. The
kit comes complete including stainless clamps and fits perfectly. I did
had to replace the rubber hanger.  I took it to a local shop and they
charged me $30 for complete installation. 

I think it is worth the investment. The amount of water vapor 
exiting the exhausts on cold Chicago morning and the angle of the
installed muffler was enough to convenience me.  The thing that helped me
justify such an investment was the fact that I had convinced myself for 
keeping the car for a duration longer than the average life of normal
muffler. I also think that it is worth some money when you go and sell 
the car, as I have seen many used Porsche Ads that specify Borla muffler.

Hope this helps, My $0.02 worth is;  Go For It 

Afsar Husain

> I have been considering purchasing a Borla stainless muffler for my "87' 944. I
> would appreciate some advice on wether it is worth the $500+ investment. Does
> anyone have any experience with this device?

Date: 02 Mar 95 14:44:49 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Racing safer than public highway?

 
If you look at the fatality statistics for Formula One, it doesn't look
nearly as safe as the public road. Never mind testing accidents; if you have
200 mile races, 15 times a year or whatever, with 26 cars in the grid,
that's only 78,000 driver-miles/year. If you kill one F1 driver every 4
years, that's a fatality rate of one per 312,000 miles. Not too good;
assuming 20K miles per year for the average public motorist, this is
equivalent to one fatality for every 15.6 driver-years.
 
Pete

Date: Thu, 02 Mar 1995 15:53:49 -0500 (EST)
From: RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu
Subject: Re: 944 Dies or Doesn't Start

Joe,
	The Bosch Motronic system is quite well described in believe it or not 
the Chilton's BMW 5 series manual.  I think there is also a Bosch fuel 
injection system manual around.
	Check your fuel relays also, these things can be easily checked 
according to the chilton's manual.  (Ground terminal 20 (I think-check!!) on 
the computer to ground (through an amp-meter) and you should be able to hear 
the pumps run) The only thing to remember is that the idle control valve 
resistances are different for Porsches, otherwise the computer connector 
values should be the same.
	Happy hunting,  Jan

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 16:11:06 -0500
From: Skaterj@aol.com
Subject: How fast is TOO fast?

Does anyone know when the flashing lights in your rearview mirror represent
more than your standard speeding ticket?  Do the police follow a procedure
that would warrant a 'reckless driving' arrest for driving WAY too fast. Like
going double or triple the speed limit? Or does an officer always have
discretion as to what is considered EXCESSIVE? 

I know that here in Texas, if you are caught going more than 25 mph over the
speed limit, you are not permitted to take a Defensive Driving course to have
the ticket removed from your record. (You can only take a Def. Driv. course
once every 12 months to dismiss a ticket.) I was just curious if there is a
fine line between a minor traffic offense and some jail time.


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 95 16:44 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: How fast is TOO fast?

Skaterj@aol.com wandered by and idly asked:
   Does anyone know when the flashing lights in your rearview mirror represent
   more than your standard speeding ticket?  Do the police follow a procedure
   that would warrant a 'reckless driving' arrest for driving WAY too fast. Like
   going double or triple the speed limit? Or does an officer always have
   discretion as to what is considered EXCESSIVE? 

I would imagine that's largely up to the office, and whatever s/he feels will
hold up in court.  I imagine that if you were driving 80 in a 55 during rush
hour, weaving and obviously endangering yourself and other drivers, then you
could be ticketed for reckless driving.  OTOH, I was once pulled over for 132
in a 55, but since it was 2:30 in the morning, I wasn't drunk and the road was 
empty, I just got an *extremely* harsh chewing-out and I was on my way again.
Much more slowly, to be sure!

- -- Tracy Nelson

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 95 16:45:39 EST
From: sdandeka@chipcom.com (Shirish Dandekar)
Subject: Clutch confusion

I'm getting conflicting information about the clutch and transmission problems
for the 87-88 911. Most of the advise I have received has led me to believe 
that the G50 transmission with the hydraulic clutch was a better choice 
that the earlier transmission (915) with the cable activated clutch. Most of
the earlier cars I test drove were more difficult to shift than the latter models.

However, the mechanics I've talked to (three) have all indicated that the 87 & 88
model years had problems with the throw out bearing. One mechanic sighted a repair
bulletin referencing this problem. For most cars this would just be an annoying 
squeaking coming from the clutch assembly. In worst case this could lead to 
seized throw out bearing. This was changed in 89 to a thicker part. 

This is what I have been told. It may be incorrect. Any information that might
help clarify my confusion would be appriciated. Thanks.

	-RISH- 

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 13:57:46 -0800
From: davesens@rain.org (Dave Sens)
Subject: Re: How fast is TOO fast?

>Does anyone know when the flashing lights in your rearview mirror represent
>more than your standard speeding ticket?  Do the police follow a procedure
>that would warrant a 'reckless driving' arrest for driving WAY too fast. Like
>going double or triple the speed limit? Or does an officer always have
>discretion as to what is considered EXCESSIVE?

I think the officer's discretion plays a significant role.  For example,
several years ago while living in Washingon I was driving on a freeway just
east of Seattle.  It was early morning rush hour on the southbound side but
my 6 northbound lanes were free and clear.

I was *very* late for a rather important appointment so I pushed my GTI up
to around 110 or so.  Mind you, there was not another car on the northbound
side.  About 30 seconds after reaching terminal velocity I blew past 6
motorcycle cops who were monitoring southbound traffic.

Before the officer could get his bike started and on the road I was
probably a mile ahead of him. When he came out, I immediately and carefully
slowed down, signaled all my lane changes and got off the freeway at the
first exit and pulled over to the side of the road.  Still, it took the cop
another 30 seconds or so to catch up.

I waited patiently with my license and registration ready.  The officer
came up to the car with a big grin repeating "I otta run you in".  He
questioned me regarding my speed (I was right on) and my hurry.  I knew
that I was going to jail!

Without further lecture, still with a big grin, the officer proceded to
write a ticket for 70+ (saving a reckless driving charge), admonished me in
a friendly way to watch my speed and bid me a nice day.

I suspect to this day that he probably *really* enjoyed the chase as I gave
every indication that I wasn't fleeing his "custody" when he came out after
me.  He never stopped grinning!

So, with this anectdote in mind, I suspect that any citation the officer
issues is completely at his or her discretion.  I'll never forget that
discretionary act and to this day, I remember his kindness whenever I'm
pulled over.

Sometimes you win and sometimes you lose.

Regards,

Dave Sens
Santa Barbara, California
'71 911T Coupe
"I'm not sure we understand everything we know about this".

------------------------------

Date:         Thu, 02 Mar 95 16:56:06 EST
From: Archie <SOASMITH@ECUVM.CIS.ECU.EDU>
Subject:      How fast is too fast?

Skatterj asked... How fast is too fast in relation to getting a reckless
driving citation.

I would think it varies from state to state.  As a former state trooper in
North Carolina, the reckless driving statute was not used in driving fast
situations without other violations.  The NC statute requires some proof
of negligence to substantiate "reckless driving" and that is difficult to
prove in court without some "gross or glaring" violation of the safety of
self or others.

Here, reckless driving is not frequently used in speeding cases.

Archie T. Smith
East Carolina University
Department of Sociology, Brewster A-412
Greenville, NC 27858 (919) 328-6147
Bitnet: SOASMITH@ECUVM1 Internet: SOASMITH@ECUVM.CIS.ECU.EDU

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 13:54:37 -0800 (PST)
From: Clark Wallace <SAVE@CPVA.SAIC.COM>
Subject: Performance Tips?!!

> Since the word Porsche is 
> normally associated with high performance vehicles a lot of other vehicle 
> drivers like to race away from the lights to beat the expensive sportscar.  It 
> is nice to be able to put them in their place once in a while; and this 
> morning I could not succeed.  Therefore I need to either meet this guy on a 
> twisty road, or bring out the 6 cylinder 24 valve bike! (yes AIRCOOLED)

I like to think that the word Porsche is also normally associated with above
average intelligence <g>

Here's my recommendation.  Whenever I find myself in a "Gee, look's
like some knucklehead wants to play drag race" situation I do the following:
 - Make eye contact with aforementioned knucklehead, then turn away.
 - Let your car, uhhh, I mean Porsche, roll forward just slightly indicating 
  intent to kick some serious butt.
 - Allow light to change green.
 - Proceed through intersection at safe speed.
 - Watch aforementioned knucklehead disappear in cloud of white smoke with
  clutch abaze and engine revving to beat all hell.
 - Sit back in smug satisfaction that you're keeping your maintenance costs
  in check.

I like to think that after the moron realizes what happened (regardless of 
what he's going to tell his other moron buddies) he feels, well, kinda stupid .
. . .

Clark

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 17:05:27 -0500
From: Phyl346@aol.com
Subject: 944 Engine Noise Dianosis

Hy, just to let you know, I'm new to this e-mail stuff so bear with me I'll
get it eventually.

I'm hoping to get the benefit of experience here on an engine noise I've been
hearing.

Upon full warm-up my '83 944 w/ 103K miles begins to make a light but very
noticeable and disconcerting metallic tapping noise which, although I've not
100% confirmed, appears to eminate from underneath the intake runners in the
general location of the upper balance shafts' rear bearing.  The noise's
frequency is roughly proportional to the engine's speed.  Oil pressure
remains in the 3.5 - 4.5 bar range even on extended driving.

It seems to me that the rear bearings for those purposely-out-of-balance
shafts take quite a beating and based on the April '95 issue of Excellenc mag
which shows them to be the last bearings to receive oil flow I suspect they
are asking for my attention.  Since I perform all the maintainence on this
car including belt changes (the last of which was some 20k miles ago) yet am
not formally trained in this, I fear this is what manuals vaguely caution
about when the topic of belt changes and correct tensioning comes up.

Anyone ever had or heard of this problem?  and are my suspicions accurate?

Other than that,  I love my 944 and will probably purchase another for my
wife as the beautiful concept of supply and demand have made these cars one
of the absolute best bargains around.

Date: Thu, 02 Mar 95 14:29:20 pst
From: GFORCE@cccpp.com (GFORCE)
Subject: Re: How fast is TOO fast?

Does anyone know when the flashing lights in your rearview mirror represent 
more than your standard speeding ticket?  Do the police follow a procedure 
that would warrant a 'reckless driving' arrest for driving WAY too fast. Like 
going double or triple the speed limit? Or does an officer always have 
discretion as to what is considered EXCESSIVE? 

I know that here in Texas, if you are caught going more than 25 mph over the 
speed limit, you are not permitted to take a Defensive Driving course to have 
the ticket removed from your record. (You can only take a Def. Driv. course 
once every 12 months to dismiss a ticket.) I was just curious if there is a 
fine line between a minor traffic offense and some jail time.

Here in CA, I believe if you are caught driving 15 mph over the speed limit, El 
mandoe (ie, tax collector) can also write you up for reckless driving.

G.E.
78 911 SC

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 14:27:12 -0800
From: winders@support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: Clutch confusion

>I'm getting conflicting information about the clutch and transmission problems
>for the 87-88 911. Most of the advise I have received has led me to believe
>that the G50 transmission with the hydraulic clutch was a better choice
>that the earlier transmission (915) with the cable activated clutch. Most of
>the earlier cars I test drove were more difficult to shift than the latter
>models.
>
>However, the mechanics I've talked to (three) have all indicated that the
>87 & 88
>model years had problems with the throw out bearing. One mechanic sighted
>a repair
>bulletin referencing this problem. For most cars this would just be an
>annoying
>squeaking coming from the clutch assembly. In worst case this could lead to
>seized throw out bearing. This was changed in 89 to a thicker part.
>
>This is what I have been told. It may be incorrect. Any information that might
>help clarify my confusion would be appriciated. Thanks.

Rish,

I guess I am one of the people that does not like the G50. Sure, the
hydraulic clutch is easier and the more "modern" syncro systems is
easier to shift.

I like the feel of the 915. It "talks" to me more clearly and I get
a better sense of what gear I am going into. Plus, it is MUCH cheaper
to rebuild and modify. Go price a ring & pinion or gears for a G50
and prepare to pass out. Some people say the 915 is not as strong as
the G50. While this may be true, I know of 915's pumping 500+ HP and
500+ ft-lbs of torque to the ground with out problem. Yes, you have to
modify the 915 to handle this, but not extensively.

Fixing a badly damaged G50 costs as much as new Yugo!!

Scott Winders
winders@support.apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 95 17:32:29 EST
From: RON OLSON  02-Mar-1995 1729 <olson_r@cho000.dnet.ge.com>
Subject: Notes from recent factory tour

Two weeks ago (Feb 14), I was fortunate to get a chance to tour the
Porsche factory in Zuffenhausen.  I took a few notes along the way,
so, I'll pass them on for anyone interested.  I wish I could include
some pictures, but pictures were STRICTLY VERBOTEN.

My trip to Germany was set only the Thursday before a Sunday
departure, so I had one full day in the states to try to get a tour
confirmation.  Reno tried, but couldn't pull it off.  Not willing to
give up, after I arrived in Frankfort on Monday, I called the factory
directly, and, since I had come all the way from the U.S., they agreed
to slip me into the already-full tour the following day.

The factory is easily accessible by the excellent Stuttgart subway,
although I almost mistakenly got off at the Zuffenhausen stop rather
than the closer Neuwirtshaus stop.  From there, the factory is right
across the street.

Before the tour, I had 45 minutes to spend in the museum.  In addition
to 20 or so older Porsches, some of racing fame, the museum has a
small gift shop, a movie to watch, and a video game.  I even plunked
down the 2 marks to play the video game, which was a typical race car
game, but in this case the display was a large-screen on the wall, and
the game control was ... you guessed it ... an actual 911.  The 911
steering and accelerator were wired up to take the place of the joy-
stick (some-how this seems turned around).  Come to think of it, I
didn't think to try the brakes to see if they worked, too.  All-in-
all, the museum was interesting, but it's not large, and I found 45
minutes was plenty of time.

The tour included about 20-30 people, and was split into three groups
(one English-speaking, and 2 German-speaking).  We saw three shops -
engine assembly, final assembly, and upholstery.  All were highly
interesting, and all gave the image of careful, well organized,
quality work, although with a very manual slant compared to today's
most automated plants.

Our first stop was the engine shop.  Every engine worker can build an
entire 911 engine, but in practice each of the 24 workers on the
engine assembly line carefully dedicates themselves to one specific
task for 1/24th of the engine.  The climax is at the end of the engine
assembly line, when each engine is taken to a test chamber, and tested
at high RPM for problems and for proper power output.  They are proud
that only 3% are rejected and have to go back for rework.  That's down
from 5% in the past.

Our second stop was the final assembly shop, where the body is joined
to the chassis.  The line moves VERY slowly, with maybe 30 or so 911
bodies being slowly carried by an overhead conveyor system, and with
the corresponding chassis moving along on an underneath conveyer
system.  Then at one point - presto - one more body and chassis come
together and look like a car.  This sight was impressive, and I
pleaded with the guide to let me take just one picture.  I could have
made a great poster.  But, not a chance!

This assembly line moves at .6 meter/minute, whereas a highly
automated line might move at 10 times that rate.  Porsche wants to
speed things up, but taking it all the way to the Toyota or Nissan
level isn't justified at the Porsche volumes.  The line is flexible in
that different car types (911, 968, ...) can be intermixed.  But, I
saw only 911's.  With the low volume of the others, you'd have to hit
it just right to spot anything else.

Our last stop was the upholstery shop, which was more interesting than
I had expected.  We saw 50-100 people, mostly women, carefully, and
slowly, cutting, gluing, and stitching leather dashes, arm pieces,
etc.  No automation here, unless you count the few sewing machines.
The presence of these women contrasted sharply with the other shops
where there was hardly a woman to be found.  The completed pieces were
a real work of craftsmanship, and this operation, maybe more than any
other I saw that day, really brought home to me one reason a Porsche
costs more.  At one point the guide picked up a small piece (an arm
rest?), perhaps a foot long, and said `each worker produces 8 pieces
like this per day'.

The remaining notes don't line up specifically with any of the three
shops, but come from various comments the guide made throughout the
morning.
  
 . The Per-day production is now 86 911s, 2 928s, and 2 968s  (I know
   - that's slightly above the 60 per day that the Porsche sales
   video claims)
 . Manufacturing of 968 parts is now over, and they will keep making
   968's until the parts stock runs out.  This should take
   approximately 2 months.
 . The top three markets for Porsches are:  U.S. 6000, Germany 5700,
   and Japan 1500.
 . The guide said there are NO plans to build a U.S. Porsche plant -
   `Porsches have long been built in Germany;  when a customer buys a
   Porsche they expect it to be built in Germany;  and, that's the
   way it will continue to be.'  (Of course, a tour guide, who meets
   with the public daily, might be the LAST in the company to be told
   of such plans)
 . One 911 takes 12-17 days to produce.  Those who arrange for
   factory pick-up of a new 911 can enter the factory to watch their
   car's production at any point during that time.  The major parts
   (e.g. engine) are ticketed with the car's ID, so the owner-to-be
   can find their car parts and follow them around.  (This amazed me
   - that their manufacturing organization would bend so far for the
   customer)
 . I had known that the 924 had high Audi content, but I was
   surprised to learn that both the 924 and the 944 were manufactured
   by Audi in an Audi plant.  Only with the evolution to the 968 did
   production actually move to the Porsche plant.  Even so, the 924
   and 944 were two of the biggest money-makers for Porsche.
 . Improved productivity is a consistent theme throughout the plant,
   and is one of the current president's greatest contributions.  He
   even contracted Toyota to advise Porsche on manufacturing methods.
   A few examples of the changes:
     . Total human labor in a 911 is now 80 hours, down from 120
       hours two years ago.  And, it will drop further.
     . For 1995, the goal is an additional 6% productivity increase.
       Signs throughout the shops remind the workers of this.
     . Each worker is required to submit 12 improvement suggestions
       per year.  Awards, such as dinner in Paris, are given for the
       best suggestions.
     . The number of suppliers to Porsche has been reduced from 900
       to 300.  And, suppliers who don't meet their delivery
       deadlines get some unwelcome publicity - their names are
       posted conspicuously in the plant, for all to see.
 . Early orders for Boxters look good - 6000 so far.


The tour was well worth the time.  The quality you find in your
Porsche car can also be found everywhere at the factory.  And even
though Porsche is clearly watching productivity and production costs,
I never felt that the workers were being hurried at the expense of
quality.

If any of you are in the Stuttgart area, be sure to set aside some
time for (and don't forget to prearrange) the tour.  If you can't get
on the tour, the museum might be worth visiting if you're already in
Stuttgart, but whether further travel for the museum is worth it to
you depends on how badly you want to see some older Porsches.  I'd
like to go back, myself, and I'm sure I'd take in more a second time.
Better yet, anyone know how to get into Weissach!

Ron Olson  (olson_r@cho.ge.com)
84 944
86 Audi 4000

------------------------------

Date: Thu,  2 Mar 95 13:56:52 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: traffic waves (was: RE: Driving in England)

| From: Jim Selders <jimseld>
|
| [...]
| > I do like to use the motorways late at night. All the traffic travels
| > in scattered bunches which you can see for miles
| >
| > Ben "bandits! 12 o'clock high" Evans
|
| Ben, this is nearly identical to the 'states.  Packs of
| animals, er, I mean cars & drivers, clustered together
| increasing their probability of an accident.  For some reason
| probably deeply rooted in human behavior, drivers cling in
| groups according to the least common denominator.  Those whose
| minds are still functional like to drive fast & often alone,
| breaking through these groups of people in a technique I call
| "pack jumping".
|
| This becomes very clear from the air - if you ever get a
| chance, study a road for a while and you'll see packs come &
| go.  Pretty amusing.

This phenomena has been studied and various theories have
been advanced as to the cause. In fact, some applied
mathematicians have even tried modelling these "traffice waves."
The fatal flaw with these theories is that they assume some sort
of cognition by the drivers. ;-) Actually, that is not true; cognition
is not an assumption. If I remember correctly from my
applied math class, the only assumptions that became
coefficients in the discrete-step (non-linear) differential equation
was the density, speed, and average braking reaction time.

In fact, I think the traffic wave theory can be blamed for the
on-ramp metering systems that have been foisted on many
of us. I wonder how much of this can be attributed to traffic
"engineers" in the public employ trying to justify their jobs.
(I know, traffic metering supposedly actually increases the
overall throughput of a section of highway, but I find that little
consolation while waiting several minutes in the on-ramp line
before I can get on the freeway. Do the traffic engineers know
how many folks actually take an alternate route rather than wait
to use a particular on-ramp and factor that into their analysis?
That probably wouldn't be taken into consideration since they
have met their goal of increasing the average speed of
that particular stretch of roadway.)

    Eric

------------------------------

Date: Thu,  2 Mar 95 14:18:04 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Racing safer than public highway?

| From: Peter Albrecht  <76416.167@compuserve.com>
|
| If you look at the fatality statistics for Formula One, it doesn't look
| nearly as safe as the public road. Never mind testing accidents; if you have
| 200 mile races, 15 times a year or whatever, with 26 cars in the grid,
| that's only 78,000 driver-miles/year. If you kill one F1 driver every 4
| years, that's a fatality rate of one per 312,000 miles. Not too good;
| assuming 20K miles per year for the average public motorist, this is
| equivalent to one fatality for every 15.6 driver-years.

How many race drivers hold super licenses? 28 or 30? That is an
insignificantly small percentage of all racing drivers, amateur and
professional, around the world. I was talking more about the types of
racing one of the list members might be likely to attempt: PCA,
PCGB, SCCA, and so on. I think even karting is more dangerous
than club racing.

Doesn't F1 hold the dubious distinction of the most people killed in
any one race (I believe it was a Mercedes-Benz F1 car that flew
into the stands at Le Mans in the early '50s; something like 82
people were killed)?

The point was that for most of us, racing is probably safer than driving the
highways and byways.

Speaking of F1 and karting, I understand that Michael Schumaker
just won a major kart race in Paris. Truely a gifted driver. 'Course
he started out driving karts.

    Eric

> 
I do like to use the motorways late at night. All the traffic travels > 
in scattered bunches which you can see for miles, so it is possible to > 
pile on the power, haul in each group, slow to a reasonable 85 MPH
> 
while doing a visual on each car. Once you have a positive view on > 
cop-or-not you can mash the throttle and really wind it up
> 
while hauling in the next group. One clearly needs to maintain a > 
high level of situational awareness, probably a good idea at all > 
times in a Porsche.

> Regards

> Ben "bandits! 12 o'clock high" Evans
     
Ben, this is nearly identical to the 'states.  Packs of animals, er, I 
mean cars & drivers, clustered together increasing their probability of 
an accident.  For some reason probably deeply rooted in human behavior, 
drivers cling in groups according to the least common denominator.  
Those whose minds are still functional like to drive fast & often 
alone, breaking through these groups of people in a technique I call 
"pack jumping".
     
This becomes very clear from the air - if you ever get a chance, study 
a road for a while and you'll see packs come & go.  Pretty amusing.
     
Say, do you have toll roads in England?  If so, do you find people 
following each other blindly into toll booth lanes, ignoring open & 
empty lanes?  This is another chapter in my "Lemming Theory" of driver 
behavior.
     
I lift my glass to those with the minds to enjoy life in their own lane!
     
  Jim

From: 	Shirish Dandekar
Sent: 	Thursday, March 02, 1995 1:45 PM
To: 	porschephiles@tta.com
Subject: 	Clutch confusion

I'm getting conflicting information about the clutch and transmission problems
for the 87-88 911. Most of the advise I have received has led me to believe 
that the G50 transmission with the hydraulic clutch was a better choice 
that the earlier transmission (915) with the cable activated clutch. Most of
the earlier cars I test drove were more difficult to shift than the
latter models.

However, the mechanics I've talked to (three) have all indicated that
the 87 & 88
model years had problems with the throw out bearing. One mechanic
sighted a repair
bulletin referencing this problem. For most cars this would just be an
annoying 
squeaking coming from the clutch assembly. In worst case this could lead to 
seized throw out bearing. This was changed in 89 to a thicker part. 

This is what I have been told. It may be incorrect. Any information that might
help clarify my confusion would be appriciated. Thanks.

	-RISH-

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 17:27:53 -0600
From: ourios@zeus.wustl.edu
Subject: Outline of entry-level ICE class at Washington Univ.

Dear Porschephiles: As promised here is the outline of the ICE class 
at Washington University. This is meant to be an entry level class for 
incoming freshmen and freshwomen, and I have made an effort to make 
these students like mechanical engineering (I have succeeded).  
Lectures are once per week, and the class is divided into 5 lab groups,
so that during lab weeks one of the groups is in the lab each day.

ME 147 The Internal Combustion Engine 
Approximate weekly outline:
Month & Date   & Day   & Topic \\
      &        &       & \\
Jan   & 20     & F     & Introduction  (videos to perk up interest) \\
      & 27     & F     & Classification of ICEs/examples  \\
Feb   & 03     & F     & 2-stroke and 4-stroke piston engines \\
      & 10     & F     & Gasoline and diesel piston engines \\
      & 17     & F     & Thermal efficiency, emissions \\
      & 20-24  & Daily & Lab 1: Piston engine measurements\\
Feb   & ??-    &       & \\
Mar   & -03    & Daily & Lab 2: Types of Dynamometers\\
      & 05-10  &       & Spring Recess \\
      & 17     & F     & Gas Turbine Engines  \\
      & 24     & F     & Gas Turbine cycles    \\
      & 27-31  & Daily & Lab 3: Thermal efficiency measurements \\
Apr   & 04-07  & Daily & Lab 4: Friction measurement \\
      & 10-14  & Daily & Lab 5: Turbomachinery experiment \\
      & 17-21  & Daily & Lab 6: Injection/emissions \\
      & 28     & F     & Concluding review / energy systems \\
May   & ??-??  & TBA   & Final Exam \\

Grading is based on: \\
60\% short laboratory reports (10\% each) \\
40\% A final examination (multiple choice, I'm searching for "easy" questions,
     none of this "what locked up that 356 engine?")


Notes to porschephiles:  
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ 

1. Lab 1 was taking apart a small Briggs and Stratton engine, measuring
compression ratio and valve timing, and reassemble. My technician insisted that
we add a sentence  "Loosen the head bolts by turning the rachet
counterclockwise". He said  it was required because of 
past experience(!!) with entry-level engineering  students <sigh>. 

2. Lab 2 was a review of principles of operation and preliminary measurements
in a water brake, an eddy-current, a magnetic clutch dynamometer, and a 
compressed air driven turbocharger in which the compressor acts as the power
absorber and the turbine (use your imagination) acts as the "engine delivering
power to the dyno". 
Maximum turbo speed is 150,000 rpm, so this could be used to test 
T*d's special high-speed low-power autocross engines. (Come to think of it, 
150K rpm isn't fast enough. This is a power-to-weight ratio argument, 
so most post-T*d porschephiles will not understand this anyway. Apologies for
the digression).  

3. Lab 3 will be thermal efficiency measurements using a Ford Ranger engine
mounted on the water-brake dyno. That engine has been equipped with a special
controllable fuel-injection system. I will try to obtain the full fuel map, ie
as much as I can from idle to max speed and low to max power (see earlier
posting on why one needs to change gears occasionally). 

4. Lab 4 will be friction measurements on the same engine by comparing the
output of all cylinders running versus all minus one running with spark plug
removed. I will try to do this at various speeds and equivalent powers and see
if friction is directly proportional to engine speed. Place your bets early.

5. Lab 5 will obtain the compressor and turbine operating maps, again from min
to max speeds, and see how often you can surge the compressor   ==8-0.   

6. Lab 6 is play with the injection while measuring efficiency and emissions on
the Ford engine running on regular gasoline and on M85 (a mix of 85% methanol
and 15% gasoline). 

7. In examples (lectures 1 and 2) I showed them pictures of slow speed marine
diesels, in which the bore is about 0.9 m (1 yard) in diameter, and the stroke
is 2.5 to 3 m. You should see their eyes pop...

8. I got a chance to make a comment about "rice burners who aspire to be
exotics". By now they have found out about Ginger (Blutorange 911 SC) and
Blondie (yellow 911 Carrera), so in response I got a few feigned-shock remarks
with all-knowing smiles. Little rascals, after spring break I will show them
the article about the twin-turbo 930 in European car.

9. I am having *A LOT* of fun with this class, and so do the students.

10. I am still looking for a 911 engine to mount on the eddy-current dyno. For
now I have a Mitsubishi engine on that dyno, and an SM student checking the
effect of 3 different turbochargers on engine performance.

Regards
(Theo)
Theodosios Korakianitis

1987 911 Targa, in-your-eye summer yellow over full black leather
(deceased: 1982 911 Targa, ticket-me (they did) btutorange over full black leather) 


------------------------------

Date: Thu,  2 Mar 95 15:20:58 PST
From: Scott=D=Berry%MfgEng%GPID@banyan.BV.TEK.COM
Subject: Weber 40 IDF Float level adjustment - HELP!

I just purchased a Hanes Weber manual that tells me to adjust the flat level by 
the following method:  Use a micrometer (or good steel ruler) and bend the tabs 
that hit the needle valve assembly so that when the needle valve is closed the 
floats are 0.394 inches from the carb body top and when the floats are 
positioned so the valve is fully opened the floats are 1.2 inches from the carb 
top.  I have seen these expensive float level gauges and have also been told 
that the float level is adjusted when the car is idling.  I currently have 
the carbs out for a rebuild and I'm about to put them all back together.  What's 
up?

Thanx!

Scott

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 18:27:11 -0600
From: ourios@zeus.wustl.edu
Subject: Driving in UK/USA


I remember driving like Ben a few years ago in the Northeast of England.
Past midnight, returning on the M? from Morpeth (where my then girlfriend 
and now better half lived) to Gosforth. Doing well over 100 mph in a 
yellow Ford Cortina (my first car). I came up at high speed to the 
car in front - all dark. I pulled over to overtake at a safe distance,
and ***SH*T**, I saw it was a jam sandwich! 

Explanation to our US friends: A jam sandwich is basically a white
car with a red or blue stripe about mid height all around it, 
with two policemen inside. It your regular police cruiser. 

So I slammed the brakes and did not overtake. I slowed down to legal speed
and followed the jam sandwich to the Gosforth exit. I thin I did see the 
jam sandwich rock a few times as the constables inside were rolling in 
laugher at my reaction.

Two weeks later the rusted cross member of the Cortina fell off in a 
busy city street, and got towed to a gas station, lopsided. 
I was leaving the UK in a week, and the garage mechanic gave me 
50 pounds (sterling) for the roadkill. I'm glad the cross member 
didn't fall off in an M-something or A-something, or I might have been 
history.

Two years ago on I-64 from Washington University to home in 
a rallye yellow 924: Clear road ahead, and I am trying to see
if the rattle is engine-speed dependent (it's a 4-gear 1987).
60 mph and 3000 rpm (in 4th) - clear road, some rattle.
Step a little on it, 70 mph, about 3500 rpm, TOO MUCH RATTLE.
A little more, 80 rpm, about 4000 rpm, still clear ahead, less rattle!
Digress a little, think about that problem on the latest research 
paper....
Clear road ahead, mash it, over 85 mph, over 4500 rpm, no rattle!
But the radar detector goes nuts, so I slamm the brakes, where the 
hell is he, glance over the mirror **SH*T** - 
A JAM SANDWICH FROM THE LOCAL TOWN 1/2 MILE BEHIND ME.

This was over 85 mph in a 55 zone. I tried to explain about the rattle 
and the research paper, to no avail. The policeman was very polite, 
and kind too. He said he clocked me once "well over 80 mph" and 
immediately afterwards at 75 mph (they need two counts). He said 
that my detector (which was still going nuts) worked. 
And he gave me a ticket for going 70 mph in a 55 mph zone.
He greeted me "slow down a bit, Doc" (he had asked where I work and 
what I do).

The next day my lawyer got a bonus to convert the traffic ticket
to a parking ticket, and the local City of Town and Country 
collected a parking ticket more expensive than the traffic ticket.

Life goes on...

Theo
Theodosios Korakianitis
1987 Targa 911, summer yellow over full black leather (I *LIKE* yellow cars)

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 95 19:05 CST
From: dnimtz@mill2.millcomm.com (Dan Nimtz)
Subject: Re: Quest. about washing/drying car.

>	General tips:
>
>	Get a lot of water on the car first, then wash from the bottom 	
>	up.  Don't use the same sponge (or brush, or whatever) for both 

I don't agree with washing from the bottom up for the following reasons:

1) You end up washing the top dirt down unto the (already) clean bottom
2) There is typically more dirt and grime on the bottom, that will end
   up on the top to some degree.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 02 Mar 95 18:45:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Clutch confusion


Rish,

I don't know about the throw-out bearing.  I do know that Porsche
increased the diameter of the release lever pivot as well as
the needle bearings that ride on it.

Older G50's can be updated.  There is a tool they sell, believe
it's number 9292, which is used to widen the bores in the case
for the release pivot.  I believe you need to purchase a new release
arm and pivot.  The tool costs about $90.  PCNA used to rent or
lend such low-use tools out, but appear to have discontinued
doing so.

Unless you have a problem with the clutch, and until you drop
the engine to replace it, I wouldn't worry about this.  To my
limited knowledge, the pivot has not been a huge problem for
people.

You may have had a harder time shifting 915's than G50's
because the ones you drove were older and so had tired
synchros.  The G50 is, by all accounts, a stronger part.  However,
both it and the 915 are fine and beautiful things.

Kevin

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 21:47:52 -0500
From: Zunknown@aol.com
Subject: G50 Throw Out Bearing Problems

Someone referred to a problem with the throw our bearings on early G50
transmissions.

What happened was there was a problem with noise and non-smooth operation of
the clutch release mechanism. There are two "repairs".

One is the late throw out bearing (950 116 080 07), which has a sleeve of
slippery material on the inner surface where it slides on the guide tube.
Because this sleeve effectively makes the inside diameter smaller, a
different guide tube must also be installed.

The other fix is to remove the transmission (!), ream out the bushings where
the cross shaft resides, and replace them with new, better ones.

There are factory bulletins on both fixes.

Date: Thu, 02 Mar 1995 19:17:27 PST
From: Greg DesBrisay <gd@kuma>
Subject: Re: Weber 40 IDF Float level adjustment - HELP! 


Scott,

I've adjusted my 40IDF carbs following the procedure in the Haynes
manual.  I used a straight edge and a set of calipers to measure the
clearances.  There is no need for special float level gauges and there
is no need to adjust the float level while the car is idling.  In
fact, I can't imagine how one could possibly do that!

Greg DesBrisay
'67 912



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 22:16:13 -0500
From: Mrmojo911@aol.com
Subject: G50 Transmission

Shirish Dandekar expressed concern about a throwout bearing problem on G50s.
I think the problem he's talking about is actually with the bearing release
fork, and the consequence is typically just an overly stiff clutch action
(which admittedly defeats the purpose of the hydraulics). Over time my G50
911 developed a pedal at least as stiff as my former 915 car with the
mechanical clutch. When I did a clutch replacement, I had the mechanic also
do the factory update on the bearing fork (extra $100 or so). Result: very
smooth, easy clutch.
Of course it would be rather expensive to do this if you weren't replacing
the clutch anyway. 

Apart from the clutch, I don't think you'll notice much difference between
the 915 and the G50. 

Now ... (unrelated matter) ... any of you bright boys or girls know how 
to fortify the swaybar brackets so the damned things don't keep breaking?

Charles Broome <Mr mojo911@aol.com>

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 21:04:24 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Unsubscribe

>      No! Noone EVER leaves the list....alive.
>      
>      You're doomed to receive 50+ msgs per day for the rest of your life.

You know, back in the Old Days, one of my compatriots got DAMNED tired
of all these "please take me off the list" messages to the list, so
set up a "braindead newbie" list that you could *ONLY* get off of by
sendind a note to the "-request" address. Offered to many of us that if
we had people that sent such notes to our lists that we could just
bounce that note to a private address he'd set up, and they'd automaticly
get added, no charge, no fuss. From then until they figured out how to get
off, they'd get *tons* of mail from other people that consisted primarily
of "how do I get off this list" and "could someone please take me off this 
list" with a weekly recording welcoming them to the braindead newbie list...

I hear that it took some people close to a year to get off...

Stan

Date: 2 Mar 95 18:09:29 -0800
From: Daryl Savage (Exchange) <daryls@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: How fast is TOO fast?

here in Washington State they can and often times will throw a 
Reckless Driving at you if u are going 20 or more mph over posted.

i've never had the luck of "running into" an officer whilst said officer
was in a good mood.

my first experience with this was at about 120mph in my old
mx6 turbo.  ended up face down in the back of the police cruiser
(can't stop yourself from falling when your hands are restrained
behind yo back and you are pushed in with no regard as too
your safety) with a bloody nose.  the guy also bent my glasses
whilst he was rolling me down the side of my car (yes, scratching
the paint) and pushing my face into the back windshield.

mind you, this was my first run-in with the law and i was too frightened
and stunned to be resisting or abusive.

then the guy wanted to know what kind of firearms i like best.  hmm...

my second experience was at 3 am on my way back from northern cal
having just picked up my '89 930S Targa.  they thought i was racing
some mazda pickup.  really...

the cop never got an accurate reading on me but the attorney i have
on retainer (same one Bill uses BTW) mentioned that
a police cruiser at full throttle is well known to be going faster then
65 mph.  i might point out that even a stock 930S at full throttle is well
known to be going faster then 160 on the flat.  but anyone who's 
driven a targa knows that full throttle runs tend to be short due to
limitations of the human ear.  so, noone really knows how fast it
was...

this officer had more of a sense of humor though.  he mentions in
his affidavit that whilst sitting on an overpass on nb i5 "when
defendant passed underneath the overpass shook..."

also, this particular officer used the word "nemesis" in a complete
sentence.  extra points :):)

however since i steadfastly refused to discuss any aspects of
the case with him he told me that "it was ok to talk now.  he wasn't
going to ask about the incident" and then proceeded to make
small talk ("where'd you get the car.  what do you do.  etc.").
of course he quoted me in the affidavit in an attempt to bias
the judge against me (how relevant to the supposed crime is 
the purchase price of the car? answer: not.  its relevant only
in calculating max fine (ie: taxation)).  reduced to negligent,
write check, go home, write check to insurance agent,
repeat last...

having someone else in the car helps.  then you will be less
likely to get bloodied by over zeallous law inforcement
officials and if you do you'd have a witness.  also, if
the cop isn't too mad (in either definition) (s)he may
just let your friend take posession of the car instead
of impounding it.  this greatly simplifies matters once
you get out of, err, umm, that unplanned rest stop...

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 21:33:17 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: GT Racing and AIR products

> Anybody have first hand experience with fiberglass replacement ...

Fiberglass replacement X, for all X, don't fit. They have to be hand fitted
to your car, for the given piece. Not even the same piece from the same
place is the same from one piece to another.

Adding fiberglass parts is *NOT* a simple bolt on job, normal hand tools
required. Not if you want it to fit well, look good, and last.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 22:57:42 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Performance Tips?!!

Jan says, " ...I BADLY wanted performance there and then 
which is why I placed the comment in the philes.  Since the word Porsche is 
normally associated with high performance vehicles a lot of other vehicle 
drivers like to race away from the lights to beat the expensive sportscar.
 It 
is nice to be able to put them in their place once in a while; and this 
morning I could not succeed...."

Jan, if you bought a 944 expecting to outdrag everything on the street, you
need a serious lesson in the basics.  What you (and I) have is a
well-balanced sports car that's a lot of fun for the knowledgable enthusiast
to drive.  One visit to a race track during an SCCA or PCA event will show
that there are numerous cars that outclass the 944 (pick your parameter:
acceleration, top speed, even handling).  Street racing is for the immature;
however, since you own a car that the immature don't normally buy, I'll
assume you don't fit that category.  Responsible Porsche drivers carry a
large enough burden on the street without the immature adding to it with such
antics.  Do your racing on the track, where it belongs and where the rest of
us will be glad to give you your chance at being a winner.

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 23:14:41 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: Turbo S Question

Gregory Scott said:

>How does one know if they have a Turbo Cup car? I have an '89 951 Turbo S
>and
>am curious if it is a Turbo Cup car. I saw someplace that they had such an
>animal in '89.

No Turbo Cup cars were brought to the US by Porsche in 89. Porshce DID bring
some Turbo Cup like cars to the US in 86 and 87 for the Escort Series. These
cars had more mods than the Turbo Cup cars since they had to race against
Corvettes, etc.  The Turbo Cup Series were run in Canada, Germany and South
Africa.  Turbo Cups had cross ventilated brake rotors, suspension mods with
coil overs at all four corners, roll cage, no power steering, no sunroof, no
air conditioning, 8 and 9 inch magnesium phone dial pearlescent white wheels,
hard or solid bushings in the suspension, larger front and rear sway bars,
fibreglass hood, welded in brakets for a front suspension cross brace, no
radio, no sound deadening, and they ride like a truck, but are GREAT fun on a
track!

Jon Lowe
'87 Escort 944T


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 23:49:37 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Traffic Waves

Eric says, "This phenomena has been studied and various theories have
been advanced as to the cause. In fact, some applied
mathematicians have even tried modelling these "traffice waves.""

Yes, Eric, even before mathematicians discovered this phenomena it was part
of the required curriculum in the particular engineering school I attended.
 The models we used worked quite well (just as I suspect those used by
highway engineers responsible for traffic metering today work reasonably
well).  It's not that complicated if you simply model the mechanics (which
are remarkably consistent, as posts on this subject have implied) and ignore
the social causes.

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper

Date: Sat, 11 Feb 95 00:31:51 PST

when i was younger and stupider, (funny how often they go together)
i was riding my kz400 motorcycle in brooklyn ny, of course i didn't have
a license, but thats another story..
anyway i was speeding, about 45 in a 20 when i see a police cars lights
come on, i start to slow down, then remember the license thing, so i
speed up!  well they chased me for about a mile, i went thru stopsigns
lights, crossed double lines, but finally at a major intersection the
light was red, and i had to stop.
the cops jumped out pushed the bike down, and took my keys.  first
thing they said was 'you better have a license for this thing'
so i went thru the motions of looking for my license, and made up a 
story about leaving it at my girlfriends house.  so they asked me for id
i gave them a credit card, they went to the squad car and called it in,
so they leave me, (sans keys) and go to the station to check my name; BUT GOT 
NOTHING, evidently in ny when your license is revoked, you just
disapear, so they asked me if my license had been revoked, i said no
but that i did have a plates problem at one time.  well 5 tickets later
they let me go, but did joke that if i had a bigger bike i couldv out 
run em.  i tore up the tickets and went home.
ps i wound up getting a license from another state, had to take the road
test and everything. oh well.
rz

Sand by hand do not use the sander. You may have trouble if the paint is 
old. Use the 2000 grit if you just trying to "level" out the paint. I 
know on my Carrera hood I tried to "fix" it up by sanding and I really 
didn't work. But I also had some good rock chip holes and never got it 
to work right and ended up repainting it.  Good luck give it a shot!!!

Subject: Re: Police officers

Speaking of police officers' atrocious driving ... in California, police
officers are exempt from the "rules of the road" spelled out in the Vehicle
Code.  It's probably true elsewhere, too.

Two years ago I missed sudden death by _three seconds_ (I later timed it)
because of a Palo Alto cop who ran a red light in broad daylight at an
intersection near my house -- no siren, no lights, doing at least 60mph in
a 35 zone. For no apparent reason, either.

Date: Thu, 2 Mar 1995 21:57:59 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Color Sanding

Hi Bev:

Re: Color Sanding:

I recently attended a "workshop" that covered color sanding on a yellow Jag
E-type hood.  Here was their method:

        1) hand-sand w/lots-o-water at 1000 grit
        2)  "    "   "      "       "  1500 grit
        3)  "    "   "      "       "  2000 grit (optional)
        
    then, using an 8"-10" orbital polisher/buffer (low speed),        
        4) buff with synthetic chemical buffing cream using sheepskin pad
        5)  "    "   3M Finesse-It II using lambswool pad
        6)  "    "   3M Perfect-It using a waffled foam pad
        
The results were pretty impressive.  The above is not meant to be a blatant
advertisement for 3M products, etc., it's just that this is what they use
and they feel pretty strongly about their choice.        

Their buffer was electric and vari-speed, and they did this all outside in
broad and bright daylight. The foam pad is particularly improtant as it
avoids heat-build-up, and Perfect-It is designed for use with this type of
pad.

 ________________________________________
|  Andrew E. Kalman     aek@netcom.com   |
|       standard disclaimers apply       |
 ________________________________________


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 3 Mar 1995 02:17:16 -0500
From: Mdch01@aol.com
Subject: Re: 931 Variable Cam sprocket

These cam sprockets are available.  The problem is that the distributor is
also driven off the camshaft.  Any adjustment in the cam timing will affect
the ignition timing as well which is not a very desirable consequence.
European Car had an article on these devices a few years ago.
Cheers  -  MIKE

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 3 Mar 95 09:18 EST

	>I was once pulled over for 132 in a 55...
	
	You were on a final approach pattern, coming in for a landing???
	
	I expect to see this story in Der Gasser soon!

Nothing so fun as that...  I was late getting home from a date, I was driving
my *Mom's* car (1981 Pontiac Catalina, 455 4bbl V8), and I'd had the thing
floored for about ten miles.  This was in Iowa, so the road was flat, straight
and empty at that time of night.  It helped (probably a lot) that I had been
a weekend radio dispatcher for the sherrif's department the previous summer, so
the deputy that pulled me over knew me.  No ticket, no bloody nose, just
hellfire and brimstone in the cruiser and more of the same when Mom found out
a couple days later.  Ah, to be young and stupid again...

- -- Tracy Nelson

Date: Fri, 3 Mar 1995 09:45:05 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: 944 engine noise (LONG)

Phyl says: 
> Upon full warm-up my '83 944 w/ 103K miles begins to make a light but very
> noticeable and disconcerting metallic tapping noise which, although I've not
> 100% confirmed, appears to eminate from underneath the intake runners in the
> general location of the upper balance shafts' rear bearing.  The noise's
> frequency is roughly proportional to the engine's speed.  Oil pressure
> remains in the 3.5 - 4.5 bar range even on extended driving.
> 
Funny you should ask! I just posted this a couple of days ago:
Hi gang!
	Here's a follow up on a problem I had with my car (85.1 944):

I was getting a rattling noise from the engine, driver's side any time I
decelerated and the rpms dropped from about 3K to 2K. It sounded like marbles!
It drove me nuts...

I searched around and found that the noise was comming from below the intake
manifold. By placing my hand on top of the upper balance shaft cover, I could
feel the rattling. 

Some people suggested that it might be trans noise. Well, I'm happy to report
that after changing the rear bearing on the bal shaft the noise has gone away!

My theory is that perhaphs the belt could have been overtightened at some
point, applying too much force to the whole shaft and making the bearing fail.
It could also be caused by normal wear (@ 95K miles).
=================================

Here's what I did to change it...
Remove air cleaner, belt covers, belts, etc. Make sure that you lock the 
engine at TDC on #1 cyl. I have a factory tool that that makes this a one person
operation. You must loosen up the crankshaft pulley, about 250ft#. It helps to
have the tool.

Since you are going to go through the hassle of taking the front of the eng
apart, might pay to do belts, rollers and oil seals for the balance shafts.
You will need the tool to adjust the belts. Or eyeball them and have them 
done shortly afterwards... You will need a pin spanner to loosen up the
sprockets for the BS.

Now for the cam bearings. In order to get to all the bolts that hold the cover
in place, the intake manifold must be loosend up. I just did this last week,
here's my procedure...

Loosen up the intake manifold bolts (8), loosen up two bolts that hold the fuel
rail to the valve cover (10mm wrench). By doing this, you will not have to 
remove the fuel rail from the IM and get new injector seals. THen again is your
call. I just did this a few months ago, so I was not going to get new inj. seals

Remove the bolt that holds the oil dipstic support from the IM, also one bolt
that supports the IM from the engine mount. Remove acc cable from IM support.

Loosen up the big air hose at the front of engine, there is one hose that
connects to the bottom of the IM (all the way in the back) using a long screw
driver. I also loosened one of the hoses by the head temp sensor.

There is enough slack on the FI hoses to allow you to lift the IM about 2-3".
Just enough to get to all the bolts for the BS cover. I used twine to lift it
from my garage ceiling. Connected to the front and back of the IM. I also used
a short piece of wood by the valve cover to hold that side of the IM up. It
looked pretty funny :) THere were 4 or 5 strings going up to the ceiling.
I felt like Repetto with my Pinoccio 944 :)

Remove the front nose piece (holds the F oil seal) from the BS (13mm socket x3)
Loosen all bolts on the BS cover. Do it on an alternating pattern, you don't
want to warp it. Some of them take a little to get to them, different wrenches
and or sockets. Nothing major. Once lossened, remove the cover.

The shaft is held in place by the front bearing (in F cover) and a single
rear bearing. I used original size on my car (95K miles). Two bolts allow you
to get to bearings. Coat them with grease during assembly. I paid like $19
from Porsche. There was noticeble up/down play on my shaft!

During reassembly, i coated the BS cover with Form-a-gasket. There is a rear
circular cover that uses a rubber oil seal. I reused it coating the mating 
surfaces with goo. I'm cheap. Torque as per specs following cross wise pattern.

Reassembly is the reverse. Make sure all your hoses are back in place and
tight. Oh yeah, there are two small hoses that go to the FI presure damper,
and a vacuum valve that should come off from the FI body. They have curved
connctors.

I spent about 6 hrs doing the whole thing. My engine is much quieter now. Still
getting some vibes at about 4K. Just ordered LBS bearings. Will do them next 
week.

Also, I found a snapped bolt in the front A/C mounting bracket about 1 month
ago while checking for the noise. It added to the vibration problem...

Hope this helps!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories     len@library.att.com	   201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa  / '85 Guards Red 944
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo / '88 Silver BMW 325is

        I am going to my first PCA Drivers Ed event on March 12, at Summit
Point, and have some questions for anyone who is going to this event or
has participated in Potomac PCA events.
 
        I will have my 911 tuned up, and have the alignment checked before
the event.  I have new pressure feed chain tensioners installed, and will
be installing new brake pads (street type), and bleeding the brakes with
street type brake fluid.  I feel for my first event I do not need to worry
about purchasing speciality pads or high temp brake fluid (am I wrong?).
Anything else to check before the event.  I have not received the
confirmation paperwork back from Potomac PCA yet, I guess that will answer
some of my questions.
 
        As for the organization of the event, and time schedule.  I will
need to mount my track/autox tires on the car after I drive the 3 hours to
Summit.  How early does the track/registration open in the morning, do I
have time in the morning to swap tires before the beginner program starts?
Or should I plan to swap the tires the night before in the hotel parking
lot?
 
        What should I expect as a beginner for my first event?  I expect
there will be some classroom, and possibly an instructor drive session to
point out the line, then several track sessions with the instructor.
 
 
 
Todd Cohen
