Date: Fri, 3 Mar 1995 08:46:34 -0800
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Porschephiles FAQ for March

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
+             PORSCHEPHILES - FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS              +
+                   (last revised March 3, 1995)                      +
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

This is the FAQ for the Porschephiles list.  It is posted regularly,
once a month at or near the start of the month.  There are undoubtedly
additions, changes, etc., needed.  Your input is solicited in improving
the FAQ.  Send any comments to the address at the end of the FAQ.

Changes this month are additions to the list of recommended reference 
materials courtesy primarily of Bob Joyce, and some additional World 
Wide Web (WWW) Porsche links.

=======================================================================

Questions answered in this FAQ:
  What is Porschephiles?
  How does Porschephiles work?
  Who is the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?
  What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?
  Are there any suggestions on how I should submit to the list?
  How do I submit administrative requests?
  Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?
  What else is available in the tta.com archives?
  Is there WWW access to the Porschephiles archives?
  What about other Porsche-related WWW links?
  What about splitting the list?
  What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?
  Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?
  I want to join the Porsche Club of America; what do I have to do?
  How can I find out more about the car I own?
  What are the model numbers of cars related to the Porsche name?
  What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
  What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?
  What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?
  What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?
  What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?
  What references are available for information about Porsches?
  Should I use an oil additive in my Porsche engine?
  Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other renowned Porsche people) here?
  Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?
  Who maintains this FAQ?

=======================================================================

What is Porschephiles?

     Porschephiles is an Internet mailing list centering on the Porsche
automobile in all of its incarnations.

=======================================================================

How does Porschephiles work?

     This list is being run as a mail reflector, which sends incoming 
mail to the whole list at once.  The participants include people with a 
variety of backgrounds, some technical, some race/autocross/performance 
drivers, some owners, some just admirers.  To send a message to the 
whole list, mail to

                porschephiles@tta.com

     To send mail regarding distribution problems, or other 
administrative issues, send mail to

                porschephiles-request@tta.com

     If you have a friend who would like to get on this list, or if you
feel moved to tell other people about it, ONLY GIVE OUT THE "-request"
address.  The list is also available as a digest, where you get a
compilation of the day's messages once per day, rather than getting all
of the individual messages. This seems to be a win for people with slow
mail links or who are just too busy to stay current. If you want to
convert to (or from) the digest, send mail to the "porschephiles-
request" address above.

=======================================================================

Who is the Moderator of the Porschephiles list?

     The moderator is:
          Stanley P. Hanks
          Principal, 
          Technology Tranfer Associates
          P.O. Box 2087
          Bellaire TX 77402-2087

          e-mail: stan@tta.com, 
          voice:  (713) 661-2084 

     His Porsches currently include:  
          '64 356 SC (daily driver)

=======================================================================

What kinds of questions can be asked on the list?

     There are a lot of members on the list.  It's small enough to be 
effective, and large enough to have a number of diverse opinions and
sets of experience.  You ought to be able to ask any question you like,
although it's probably a good idea to look it up yourself if you can and
save the net bandwidth.  Keep the diversity of the list in mind before 
you decide to not ask a question, or if you get flamed for asking an 
"obvious" question.  Diversity -- it's a *feature*...

=======================================================================

Are there any suggestions on how I should submit to the list?

     Beyond using normal good sense and discretion, you can submit
whatever you like that is relevant to Porsches.  You might want to use
descriptive "Subject" lines, including the model number when it is
relevant (e.g., "944 S2 Fuel leak query").  Your submissions would be 
easier for others to read if you make sure that your mailer wraps 
lines of text at 80 characters or less.

=======================================================================

How do I submit administrative requests?

     Send them, and ONLY them, to the "porschephiles-request" address 
(porschephiles-request@tta.com), or to Stan directly.  

=======================================================================

Are archives of the list available?  If so, how can they be obtained?

     Archives are available at ftp://tta.com/pub/porschephiles/archives.
Archives in six subdirectories (90, 91, 92, 93, 94, 95) each of which 
has the archives for that year, in UNIX compress format.  There are no
older archives available.  While it might seem like a good idea when
you're first starting out on the list to know what has gone on before,
there are OVER 13 MEG of archives.  DO NOT TRY TO FTP THEM ALL AT ONE
TIME.  And PLEASE DO NOT FTP between 8:00 AM and 7:00 PM CST, or Stan
may have to take access away.  Also, DO NOT ask Stan to mail you
archives.  To FTP the compressed archives, you will have to use BINARY
mode in FTP.  On receipt you need to use the UNIX "uncompress" program,
or equivalent, to restore to textual format.  Mac and Windows versions
of "uncompress" are available via FTP from /pub/porschephiles/programs.

=======================================================================

What else is available in the tta.com archives?

     FAQs: In the FAQs directory there is this FAQ and there are FAQs 
for specific Porsche models (so far there's one for 914s and one for 
the Carrera models -- feel free to contribute one on YOUR favorite 
Porsche).  These are available at ftp://tta.com/pub/porschephiles/FAQs.
 
     Images: All sorts of Porsche images for your viewing pleasure,
mostly in .gif format.  There's also a directory called "UPLOAD" where 
you can deposit your own images for inclusion in the collection.  If 
you add any images, please include a file called "from.<username>", 
where <username> is your login ID, that describes the files if possible.

     PCA racing info: The PCA Club Racing Newsletter is now on-line,
thanks to the tireless efforts of the editor.  This is available by FTP 
in the directory tta.com:/pub/porschephiles/PCA/ClubRacing.  The 
newsletters are available both in PostScript and in Windows Write 
format.  If this is useful to you, send your thanks to the editor, Tom,
at "tt911@ibm.net".
 
     MiscInfo: Various other interesting bits of information potentially
useful to Porschephiles.
 
     Survey: The questionaire and results (when compiled) of the 
membership survey.

     Logo contest: Several Porschephiles logos have been submitted;
check them out and choose one you like, or develop your own candidate.
Someday maybe we'll decide on a winner, and then we can have T-shirts,
coffee mugs, stationery, etc., made up.

     And as usual, Monthly-Update, RULES, and Whos-Who, which get 
updated on a monthly basis.

=======================================================================
 
Is there WWW access to the Porschephiles archives?
 
     Yes, WWW access is through http://tta.com/Porschephiles/home.html.
The FTP restriction above applies to major downloading of stuff from the
archives, not WWW access.  Suggestions for improving the WWW pages
would be welcomed, as well as experienced help in doing so.

=======================================================================

What about other Porsche-related WWW links?

     There are several WWW home pages related to Porsches, and more will
undoubtedly appear (if you know of any others, please submit them):  

     http://192.253.114.31/Stuttgart/Porsche/Porsche_contents.html -- 
     Porsche Museum (courtesy of an American High School in Stuttgart)

     http://warthog.cns.udel.edu/porsches.html -- "Delaware PCA Mosaic 
     Home Page"

     http://www.research.digital.com/CRL/personal/hawe/pca-ner.html --
     PCA Northeast Region home page

     http://tta.com/PCA/Carolinas/homepage.html -- PCA Carolinas Region
     home page

     http://www.vpm.com/pca-svr/ -- PCA Sacramento Valley Region home
     page

=======================================================================

What about splitting the list? 

     Various proposals surface now and then about splitting the list 
into components based on car model, activity types, or other divisions?  
Stan's reply to these suggestions is as follows:  

     "I just want all you Faithful Readers to understand: there are only 
two votes that count. Mine, and anyone who's willing to pay me to change 
my mind or operation or whatever.
 
     "Posted rates around here are $75/hr for automotive engineering 
projects, $125/hr for information technology consulting, and $2k/day for 
expert witness engagements.  Just so you know where the bidding starts..."

     In other words, the list *WILL* **NOT** be split.

=======================================================================

What is the Porschephiles Who's Who?

     The Who's Who is a listing of those who receive Porschephiles and 
who have responded to the offer to be listed.  It lists the owners, 
their state/country of residence, their car's year and model, and
their net address.  The list is updated when people send Stan the
information, and when he has time to update the list.  He sends it out
on a monthly basis to the list.  Only Porsches are listed, so don't
send your Alfa Zagato or your Buick GN in to be included.  Send
submissions or changes to "porschephiles-request@tta.com."

=======================================================================

Which clubs are there for Porsche owners?

     Several different clubs are available, depending on your interests
and location:

          Porsche Club of America.
          P.O. Box 10402
          Alexandria VA 22310
          Telephone: +1 703 922-9300

The main US Porsche club; see below for more information.

          Porsche Club Great Britain
          Ayton House
          West End
          Northleach
          Gloucestershire
          England GL54 3HG
          Telephone: +44 451 860792
          FAX: +44 451 860011

The Porsche club in Great Britain, obviously.

          Porsche Owners Club
          P.O. Box 9000-277
          Seal Beach, CA  90740
          +1 310 784-5653.

Based in Southern California, the focus of POC is time trialing and 
racing.

          356 Registry Inc.
          27244 Ryan Rd.
          Warren, MI, 48092
          Telephone +1 313 558-3692

For 356 enthusiasts around the world.  $20 per year and cheap at twice
the price (The 356 Registry Magazine with Vic Skirmants' racing column 
is worth that, as are the classifieds).  5000 happy members can't be 
wrong!

          914 Owner's Association
          100 South Sunrise Way, Suite 116
          Palm Springs CA 92262
          Telephone: +1 619 325-6583

Over 2000 members in over 20 countries.  Dennis Deeds published the 
club newsletter, Mid-Engined Views, quarterly.  Membership is $22 a 
year.

          Early 911S Registry
          PO Box 363
          West Point, PA 19486
          Telephone: +1 215 652-701 (day), +1-215-287-5083 (evening)

Contact Vern Lyle.  Dues are $20/yr with a quarterly newsletter.  
Dedicated to all early 911S models.

     A more complete list of Porsche US regional and other special 
interest groups, from the January 1994 Porsche Panorama, is on tta.com,
in /pub/MiscInfo/sigs.

=======================================================================

I want to join the Porsche Club of America; what do I have to do?

     The Club affiliates you with a local region based on where your
ZIP code falls on their territory map.  You *CAN* request to join a
specific region, and you can specify an affilate region or dual
membership in another region.  The local regions put on many different
events, some social, some educational, some driving or compeition
oriented.  The annual gathering of the whole membership, the Porsche
Parade, features competition for the national championships in many
events, seminars, a GREAT goodie store, and one of the most fun weeks
you'll experience.

     To join, you need to have a Porsche VIN number and be able to claim 
you're an owner, a co-owner, or hold a lease on a Porsche.  That may
seem restrictive, particularly if you want to join the club to get
access to Panorama, the club magazine, for purposes of FINDING a car...
In such case, it's suggested that you purchase a modest fraction of a
friend's car for say $5 or so, hence becoming a co-owner.  Just don't
tell them you did that or where you got the idea...

     Once you have a VIN number, there are four ways to join:

     1) Send a letter to the national office saying that you want to 
join, with your name, address, car info and a check for $36 to:

	Porsche Club of Americia.
	P.O. Box 10402
	Alexandria VA 22310

     2) Call them up at +1 703 922-9300, roughly between 9:00 to 5:00
EST (GMT - 6).  If you have your Visa/MC number *AND* your VIN number
handy, you can do it over the phone.  (Otherwise, they'll send you an
application which you can mail in with your check.)  This is the FASTEST
way, and if you need to be a member *RIGHT NOW* to go to an event that
is members only, this is your best bet.  Don't count on using this
method the week of or before Parade...

     3) find someone active in your local region.  *MANY* of the regions
are represented on the Porschephiles list, so that's a good place to
start.  Once you have found someone, get them to put you in touch with
the local region membership chair, they can give you the form, and off 
you go.

     4) National membership chair Nann Weissenberger is also on the
list, and is reachable via e-mail at "nannw@aol.com".  She'd be more 
than happy to help you out.

=======================================================================

How can I find out more about the car I own?

     If you own a North American Porsche, Porsche Cars North America 
will, for a fee of $20, research the original bill of sale for your car
and give you a Certificate of Authenticity stating the facts and 
figures for the car as it was delivered to the dealer.  If you're 
interested, contact: 
          Howard Adams
          PCNA
          P.O. Box 30911
          Reno Nevada 89520-3911
Include a copy of your title or registration as proof of ownership.
It takes 2-3 weeks depending on backlog.  A similar service is
available in Great Britain from Porsche Cars Great Britain, for about
30 pounds Sterling.  Porsche AG can also perform a similar search.

     It's also possible to get dealers to run a search for warranty and
other repairs for your car.  Some authorized dealers will search PCNA 
files for warranty and other maintenance records on specific cars.  
This data base apparently only goes back to sometime in the mid-1980s.  
It's not known how widespread this practice is among dealers; some will 
search only for warranty work done, while others also provide 
information about routine maintenance and repairs.  Ask your dealer.

=======================================================================

What are the model numbers of cars related to the Porsche name?

     The following list was extracted from _Illustrated_Porsche_Buyers_
Guide_, _Porsche_Specials_, _Cars_Are_My_Life_, _We_At_Porsche_, and
the article "Project Porsche, The Early Years" in the June '83 issue of
_Thoroughbred_&_Classic_Car_.  It includes only more or less complete 
automobiles designed by Ferdinand Porsche or by the Porsche factory.  
Components (engines, transmissions, etc.) have not been included.  
The list is incomplete, in part because there has apparently been 
imperfect record keeping at the factory.  In addition, the nature of the
list has changed over the years from an in-house listing of project 
numbers to a market-driven listing.  Additions and corrections are 
welcomed:

      "1" - Lohner-Porsche electric car, 1900; Ferdinand's first design,
            but not part of the "official" model sequence.
       7  - Wanderer passenger car, 1.7-liter, 6-cylinder engine, 1930; 
            the first official model, chosen to convey impression of 
            prior experience.
       8  - Wanderer 8-cylinder saloon design, 3.5-liter engine, 1931.
       9  - Second Wanderer 8-cylinder prototype, supercharged, 1931.
      12  - Zundapp small car, 5-cylinder radial rear-engined, 3 built.
      22  - Auto Union P-Wagen Grand Prix car, 4.3-liter, V16 engine, 
            1932-1937.
      24  - Zundapp three-wheel vehicle.
      27  - Mathis-Ford Saloon.
      32  - NSU prototype (Volkswagen forerunner).
      52  - Auto Union sports car based on P-Wagen GP car, 1934.
      60  - Original Volkswagen prototype, renamed KdF (Kraft durch 
            Freude, or strength through joy, by Adolf Hitler), basis 
            for the postwar Volkswagen, 1934-1941; the 60K10, a variation 
            of the 60, was a sports coupe built for the later cancelled 
            Berlin-Rome race, 1939. 
      61  - Another Volkswagen prototype, a narrower version of the 60.
      62  - Volkswagen-Kubelwagen (bucket car) cross-country prototype.
      64  - KdF-based sports car, 3 built, 1937-1938.
      65  - Volkswagen for driving schools.
      66  - Volkswagen for export, right-hand drive.
      67  - Volkswagen for invalids with steering column gear change.
      68  - Volkswagen Post office delivery van, model A, 1939.
      80  - Mercedes-Benz land speed record car, 44.7-liter V12
            Daimler-Benz engine, 1938-1939.
      81  - Volkswagen Medium Van, 1939.
      82  - KdF-based military Kubelwagen, 1939-1940.
      86  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen with 4wd, 6 built.
      87  - 4-wheel-drive version of Kubelwagen, 1939-1941.
      88  - Volkswagen delivery van on Kubelwagen chassis, model B, 1939.
      90 -  V12 rear-engined racing car for Daimler-Benz, 1937.
      94 -  V12 rear-engined racing car for Daimler-Benz, 1937.
      97  - Daimler-Benz heavy lorry.
      98  - Volkswagen amphibious car.
     100  - Panzer Leopard tank, 2 prototypes, 1939.
     110  - Volkspflug Small Tractor.
     111  - Small Tractor (2-cylinder engine).
     112  - Further development of 111 above.
     113  - Further development of 111 above.
     114  - F-wagen, 1.5-liter sports car prototype, 1.5-liter V10
            twin-ohc water cooled mid-engined coupe, 1938-9.
     115 -  1.1-liter supercharged Volkswagen mid-engined coupe, 1938.
     116 -  1.5-liter Volkswagen mid-engined coupe.
     128  - KdF-based amphibian Schwimmwagen, 1940-1941.
     130  - Tiger Tank (Jagpanzer) "Ferdinand".
     138  - Volkswagen Amphibious Car (version 2).
     155  - Half Track version of Kubelwagen.
     164  - Six-wheel lorry.
     166  - Volkswagen amphibious car (production version).
     182  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen (production version).
     187  - Volkswagen Kubelwagen 4wd (production version).
     205  - 180-ton Maus tank, 1942; two built, never saw action.
     245  - 18-ton multipurpose tank, 1942.
     293  - Caterpillar tractor.
     312  - Tractor with petrol engine.
     323  - 11-hp diesel tractor, 1946.
     328  - Tractor, 28 hp. engine.
     340  - Wheelbarrow.
     355  - Volkswagen delivery van.
     356  - The original Porsche sports car, the first to wear the
            Porsche name, 1948-1965; various engine and drivetrain 
            components and numerous styling variations existed.
     360  - Cisitalia 4-wheel-drive Grand Prix car, 1947-1948.
     370  - Cisitalia 1.5-liter sports/touring car, 1947.
     425  - 20 bhp diesel tractor.
     514  - LeMans car, also called 356SL, 1951.
     524  - Improved 356 prototype with mechanical injection, 1951;
            not economically feasible to take to production.
     530  - Experimental 4-passenger Porsche, 1951-1952.
     534  - Volkswagen Small sports car.
     540  - Porsche America Roadster.
     541  - Special sports version of 356.
     542  - Studebaker Saloon 1952-1954.
     550  - Mid-engine, 2-seat sports/racing car, the car that James 
            Dean died in, 1954; the 550A was a redesigned 550 with a
            tubular space frame, 1956.
     597  - Jagdwagen (Hunter) 4-wheel-drive vehicle, 1954-1955.
     621  - Porsche single-cylinder tractor (allgaier).
     622  - 2-cylinder tractor.
     623  - 3-cylinder tractor.
     624  - 4-cylinder tractor.
     633  - Studebaker saloon prototype.
     645  - Sports/racing car, "Mickey Mouse," 1956.
     675  - Small Volkswagen 1955-1959.
     691  - Porsche 550 RS (1956)
     695  - Porsche predevelopment (T7) for 911.
     702  - One man Helicopter.
     718  - Bergspyder sports/racing car (RSK), 1957; the 718/2 was a 
            1.5-liter single-seat racing car (F-2), 1959.
     726  - Volkswagen Saloon 1958.
     728  - Small Volkswagen 1957-1961.
     737  - Porsche outboard motor.
     753  - Porsche 1.5-liter 8-cylinder Formula 1.
     764  - Volkswagen 6-cylinder saloon.
     787  - Grand Prix car, 1961.
     804  - Grand Prix car, 1962.
     806  - Leopard Tank.
     814  - Leopard Tank.
     901  - Prototype 6-cylinder sports car, basis for 911, 1963; 
            changed to 911 for production because of conflict with 
            Peugeot numbering scheme.  6 prototypes built.
     904  - Mid-engine competition GT coupe, with various engines in 
            1963-1964, 100+ built, some for street use. 
     906  - Competition sports coupe (space frame), 1966-1967.
     907  - Sports/racing coupe, various iterations, 1967-1968.
     908  - 3-liter, 8-cylinder competition car, various bodies,
            1968-1970.
     909  - 2-liter hill climb spyder, 1968.
     910  - Sports racing coupe, different configurations, 1966-1968.
     911  - Porsche's flagship.  Built from 1964 (excluding the '63
            901 prototype) in numerous variations through the 993.  
            Rear-engined, air-cooled, boxer six-cylinder engine.
            Many engine variations have existed through its long life, 
            from the original 2-liter car to the 3.8-liter RS.
     912  - The 911 with the four-cylinder engine from the 356 inserted
            in place of the flat six-cylinder.  Built from 1966 through
            1969; 912E in '76 was a revival with engine from the 914.
     914  - The mid-engined car co-developed with Volkswagen between
            1970 and 1976; a popular autocross/slalom car.  The 914/6
            was a Porsche-built variant with a two-liter 911 engine
            inserted in place of the four-cylinder engine and other
            refinements.
     916  - Projected 2.4-liter version of 914/6, 1971.  Was apparently
            used in competition by the factory.  Also, a few examples 
            of an 8-cylinder (908-based) version supposedly exist.
     917  - 12-cylinder competition car, famous for Le Mans and CanAm
            victories; various iterations, 1969-1973.
     924  - The first of the water-cooled front-engine cars, built from
            1976 to 1988.  Originally with a four-cylinder, Audi-derived
            engine; updated in mid-86 as the 924S with the 944 drivetrain;
            has the best aerodynamic shape of any street Porsche.
     928  - The high-end car produced from 1978 to present, V8 in the
            front, water-cooled, has grown from an original 4.5-liter
            to 5.4 today.
     930  - Turbocharged 911, homologation and street version of the
            racing 934.
     931  - Turbocharged 924, sold in 1980-1982.
     934  - Group 4 racing 930 turbo coupe, 1975-1976.
     935  - Group 5 racing 930 turbo coupe, 1976.
     936  - Group 6 turbocharged spyder, 1976.
     937  - 924 Carrera GT.
     939  - 924 Carrera GT Le Mans.
     944  - Front-engined, water-cooled inline four-cylinder car, with
            nearly perfect 50/50 weight bias.  Sixteen-valve and
            turbocharged versions were produced.  Produced from 1982
            through 1991. 2.5-liter displacement, except for a 2.7-liter
            eight-valve 944 model in 1989 and the 3-liter 944S2.
     951  - The turbo version of the 944.  Built from 1985 to 1991.
     956  - GT racing car, loosely based on 911; 1982-1983.
     959  - Supercar 911 derivative; 2.85-liter, four-valve, twin cam,
            dual turbochargers, all-wheel drive; not street-legal in US.
     961  - Racing version of the 959.
     962  - GT racing car based loosely on 911; used in endurance racing 
            and IMSA GTP; 1984.
     964  - The 911 Carrera 2 and Carrera 4, introduced in 1989.
     968  - Rebirth of the 944 series in 1992 with revised styling.  A 
            noteworthy feature is variable valve timing.
     986  - The Boxster, due in Sept. '96, the newest hope for Porsche's 
            future.
     993  - The latest iteration of the 911, introduced in 1994.

    1764  - Volkswagen vehicle.
    1834  - Volkswagen vehicle.
    1866  - Volkswagen successor.
    1906  - Leopard tank.
    1966  - Volkswagen small car prototype.
    2539  - "Save" ambulance.
    2567  - "Orbit" fire fighting system.
    2708  - Cart.

=======================================================================

What Porsche model/year/variant should I buy?
 
     General answer:  Buy the latest one you can afford of the model you
like.  Within models, there are certain years that are generally thought
of as more reliable or otherwise desirable, and others that have proved
troublesome over the years.  If you have questions about a particular
model, ask the list.  (We are looking for contributors to write about 
specific models.  Contributions, which may be too lengthy to include 
here, will be stored at tta.com and available via FTP.  Dave Darling has
gotten the ball rolling with a summary for the 914.  Feel free to 
contribute regarding your favorite model.)

=======================================================================

What kinds of racing events can I run my car in?

     There are several kinds of events organized and run by Porsche
clubs and organizations:

     Autocrosses.  These normally occur in a large parking lot or other 
relatively flat, open area.  The lot is filled with traffic cones that 
define a course.  Only 2 or 3 cars are on the course at the same time, 
and never at the same location on the course.  You race against the 
clock, and your times are compared to others in your class.  Classes 
are organized so that you compete against similarly-configured cars of 
about equal capability, ranging from box-stock to extensively modified.
Autocrossing is probably the safest and cheapest way to go fast in your 
Porsche (or any other car for that matter).  In some parts of the 
country, autocrosses are called slaloms.

     Time Trials.  These are also timed events, but they usually take
place on an actual race course.  They are often held in conjunction
with Track Events.  The time trial, like the autocross, is not against
other cars at the same time but against a clock.

     Driver's Education.  These events are held at a race track (but not
during a formal race meeting).  Multiple cars are on the track at the 
same time.  Instructors ride with the students, who are taught to drive 
at speed safely.  The US PCA has a basic set of rules and various PCA 
regions have their own rules which don't differ much from each other.  
Usually, the only modification to the car is a fire extinguisher that is
mounted metal to metal.  Students and instructors must wear an approved 
helmet.  

     PCA Club Racing.  This is racing in the traditional sense, in that
there's a full complement of cars, a definite start and finish, and
head-to-head racing.  The concept is similar to the various vintage
racing events that are becoming so popular; the idea is to preserve your
car and those of others while racing against each other.  If you don't 
race responsibly, you are not allowed to race.  There's a policy
governing this that is referred to as the 13/13 rule.  Under this rule,
if a driver is judged to be at fault in an incident that results in
damage to his car or another (no matter how small), he's out of that
particular event  and on probation for the next 13 months.  If in that
probation period that driver is again determined to be at fault in
another incident with damage, he's out of club racing for the next 13
months.  Equipment requirements include the fire extinguisher, a cut
off switch, an approved roll bar, and a five point seat belt harness.
There are several of these around the country.  You should have 
experience with autocross and driver's education events under your 
belt before you jump into this kind of racing.  Contact your local
club racing officials to get copies of rules, needed equipment, etc.

=======================================================================

What are the meanings of terms and acronyms I've seen in the list?

     BTDT = Been there, done that
      BTW = By the way
      EFI = Electronic fuel injection
      FAQ = Frequently asked questions (but you knew that)
      FTP = File transfer program
     FWIW = For what it's worth
     IMHO = In my humble opinion
      IMO = In my opinion
      IOW = In other words
      LWB = Long wheelbase
      MFI = Mechanical fuel injection
      PAG = Porsche AG, the mother company back in Stuttgart; "AG"
            stands for "Aktiengesselschaft," which means that the 
            company has publicly traded stock
     PANO = Not an acronym; this stands for Porsche Panorama, the PCA 
            national monthly magazine
      PCA = Porsche Club of America, the major US/Canada Porsche
            enthusiasts organization
     PCGB = Porsche Club Great Britain OR Porsche Cars, Great Britain
     PCNA = Porsche Cars North America (Reno, NV), the US importer
     PMJI = Pardon me for jumping in
      POC = Porsche Owner's Club, the *other* US Porsche owner's group;
            in the past they have been more competition-oriented than 
            PCA, which has many interest groups participating
     ROFL = Rolling on the floor laughing
  ROFL,PP = Rolling on the floor laughing, peeing in my pants (!)
     RTFM = Read the f**king manual (for some, "read the Ford manual")
      SWB = Short wheelbase
      TIA = Thanks in advance
     TTFN = Tata for now
     TTYL = Talk to you later
      WWW = World Wide Web
     YMMV = Your mileage may vary
      <g> = Grin
     <bg> = Big grin
    <vbg> = Very big grin
      :-) = Smiley face (turn your head 90 degrees to the left to 
            "read" it); various iterations exist using different ASCII 
            characters
    
=======================================================================

What are the major Porsche periodicals besides Porsche Panorama?


     Excellence -
       Independent magazine devoted to Porsches.  Many of the same
       authors you see in Panorama, less jingoistic in their praise
       for everything PCNA brings to market.

       US rates: $20 one year, $35 two years, $49 three years
       foreign (incl. Canada): US$27 one, $49 two, $69 three years

       Excellence
       Circulation Dept.
       P.O. Box 1529
       Ross, CA  94957
       telephone: 415-382-0580


     Christophorus -
       Porsche AG's official magazine.  Very good source of some
       technical information about their cars and technology.
       Beautiful magazine.

       US rates: US$28 surface mail, US$40 air mail

       Porsche AG
       Editors, Christophorus
       Porschestrasse 42
       D-70435 Stuttgart
       Germany
       FAX: D-711/827-6245


     European Car -
       Formerly "VW & Porsche", now devotes some bandwidth to other
       European cars, esp. BMW.  Lots of technical how-to's, but
       biased by "placed" articles from advertisers - beware!

       US rates: $18.80 one year, $28.20 two years
       Canada: $26.80 one year, $44.20 two years, includes GST
       foreign: $28.80 one year, $48.20 two years

       Argus Publishers Corp.
       P.O. Box 454
       Mt. Morris, IL  61054-0454
       telephone: 800-877-5602


     911 and Porsche World -
       British independent magazine devoted to Porsches.  Coverage
       of UK club racing, tech Q&A, owner's reports, and so forth.

       US, Canada, Mexico:
         US rates: $37 one year, $72 two years
         Canada, Mexico: US$43 one year, US$83 two years

       1 year subscription $55 for 12 issues includes Dean Batchelor's
         book, "Illustrated Porsche Buyers Guide,"  6 month subscripton 
         $27.50 for 6 issues, no book included.

         PMLetter@aol.com

What are some of the major Porsche aftermarket suppliers?

     Be aware when buying a part in the aftermarket that it may or may
not be the same part you would get from Porsche.  This holds true even
when the part carries the "correct" Porsche part number, and when it
carries Porsche's parts trademark.  The following suppliers, listed
alphabetically, have been praised by various Porschephiles:


     Andial
     3203-3207 S. Shannon St.
     Santa Ana, CA  92704
     telephone: 714-957-3900
     FAX:       714-957-9332

     Porsche's official agent for competition parts and products in 
     the US.  Catalog $6.00.


     Automobile Atlanta
     505A South Marietta Highway
     Marietta, GA 30060
     telephone: 404-427-2844
 
     The most comprehensive catalog of 914 parts.  Higher-than-average
     prices.  Catalog $5.00.  (Also a 924 catalog?)

     sister company to Weltmeister, whose suspension kits they carry.
     Free catalog.

     FAX:       703-323-7325

=======================================================================

What references are available for information about Porsches?

     There are many books and manuals available, and the right one for 
you depends a lot on your interests and your particular car.  Porsche
publishes a Workshop Manual for all late model cars, as well as
various Technical Specification booklets.  Your local dealership's
parts manager can show you a catalog of technical literature
available from PCNA.

     The Porsche Club of America periodically assembles all of the 
technical articles which have appeared in Panorama into a new volume of 
their Upfixin der Porsche series.  These are available from PCA's 
executive office.

     What follows is a list of some of the more popular and often-cited
books.  This list is not exhaustive, but provides a starting point.  If 
you want information about other books, ask the list.  (Note: there's 
not much information about water-cooled cars; those with favorites 
should submit them to the name at the end of this FAQ.)

     Aichele, Tobias
     Porsche 911, Forever Young
     (translated by our own Pete Albrecht)

     There are also Haynes manuals available for most models.  While 
the Haynes manuals tend to be very weak on specifics having to do with
different model years and variations, they are good at teaching how-to
procedures for different maintenance and repair tasks.

     The following sources for books and publications were provided by 
Bob Joyce (Bob356@aol.com):

=======================================================================

Should I use an oil additive in my Porsche engine?

     This is Stan's response:  "Duralube, Slick-50, and *EVERYTHING ELSE 
THAT ISN'T JUST PLAIN OIL* is, to be blunt, snake oil.  Or as Bruce 
Anderson commented about something else, "a cash flow device."  Slick-50
is *evil* if you have an engine with an aluminium case.  Guess what we 
all have, eh?  There is a bit of info on it via anonymous FTP in tta.com
in /pub/porschephiles/MiscInfo.  Additionally, many of these additives 
use teflon.  DuPont (the inventors of Teflon) have stated categorically 
that teflon is useless in such applications."
 
=======================================================================

Can I reach Bruce Anderson (or other renowned Porsche people) here?
 
     Yes. There are many luminaries in the Porsche world on this list.
If something is relevant to them, they'll typically respond to you
privately.  Their participation is greatly valued, so respect their
privacy and don't try to draw them out in the open.  If they want to
say something to the list as a whole, they'll do so.

=======================================================================

Where can I get a copy of the latest version of this FAQ?

     The FAQ is stored on tta.com in the /pub/porschephiles/FAQs 
directory, filename general-FAQ.  The version stored there will be 
the same one sent out monthly.  (There's also a FAQ that's specific to
the 914; other specific FAQs are welcomed, if anyone wants to contribute
to the archives.)

=======================================================================

Who maintains this FAQ?

     The FAQ is maintained by Walt Thode (thode@nprdc.navy.mil).  I have
a 1972 911T as my daily driver.  Anyone who wants to contribute should 
do so.  Contributions, revisions, and suggestions for new items are 
always welcomed.  I peruse the list for potential additions, but I don't
promise to find everything you might want in the FAQ.  Don't be shy 
about sending suggestions directly to me.

=======================================================================

Porschephiles #1216                         Sat Mar 4 00:12:19 CST 1995
Date: Fri, 3 Mar 95 13:02:11 EST
From: "Jeffrey A. Shorey" <js@ee.duke.edu>
Subject: Re: 912 Question (redoing seats)

I'd like to second Bob's comment about redoing the seats yourself.  I'm not
sure what the construction of your particular seat is like, but I know all
about the '73 Recaro seats (I assume they are original).

First off, if you want to redo them in vinyl, the vinyl you find at sewing
places (at least the ones around here) will not cut it.  You need to find
some heavy, reinforced vinyl suitable for seats, not for dust covers.  In
fact, because the existing vinyl on your seats has been stretched and warped,
it will be difficult to create a correctly fitting replacement by yourself - I
would go for one of those kits.  Last time I looked, they were about $300 for
the pair of seat covers from Twinks.

The foam in my seats was reasonably intact and wasn't disintegrating, but it
was kind of mashed, particularly the seat inserts.

The metal frame that made up the driver's side seat had broken at some point
and been rewelded.  Unfortunately, they didn't make sure it was straight before
fixing it and thus the seat back had a really noticable twist in it.  First
order of business was to cut their old weld out and weld it back in the
correct position.

I ended up redoing my seats in fabric (actually sofa fabric remnants) for a
total cost of around $20.  The fabric has a nice water-proof rubber backing,
and its beige color blends pretty well with my sun-bleached brown carpet.  It's
not original, but it feels a hell of a lot better on your legs during the
summer than vinyl and the price is right.  I was also able to sew it on a
standard sewing machine - didn't include the piping though.  It was also easier
to go back and modify the fit, since the stretched vinyl templates didn't give
that great of an initial fit.  Bob's right - to sew vinyl you need an
industrial sewing machine.  Don't try it on a regular sewing machine or you
will break it ($$$).  Figure with piping, you've got 4 layers of vinyl
to go through.

The seat bottom of my seats consisted of a tightly stretched elastic mesh, not
springs, upon which the seat insert rested.  The mesh was totally rotted, so I
strung tightly stretched elastic waistbands across the frame ;-).  This worked
pretty well, but you have to find another way to fasten the fabric/vinyl along
the edges.  Originally upholstery staples were used (like the kind used to
fasten springs to the interwoven "belts" in furniture) and the edges were
stapled to the mesh - I used the plastic cable ties like those used in
electronics work.   All of the fabric edges that need tied down have metal
rods in them - just cut a little bit of the fabric at the tie down point and
slip the cable tie around the internal rod.  Works great.  It's also easy to
take apart, and they don't rust ;-).

In retrospect, my second seat definitely looks better than the first.  Sort
of a learning curve kind of thing.  One thing you might want to do if you use
fabric is to scotch-guard the seats.  I've noticed a blue tinge on the driver's
seat, probably from my blue jeans and some blue shorts that I wear.  Also, you
should tie the ends of each line of stitching that you use, otherwise it will
start to pull out after time.  This is particularly important for the cross-
stitching on the seat inserts.  I did that on the second seat, but not the
first.

 - Jeff Shorey  js@ee.duke.edu
  '73 911S Coupe (His)
  '85 535i Coupe (Hers)
  '88 Beretta V6 (Somebody please buy this car!)

          In  regards to Skatterj's question, I agree that it'll depends on 
          the officer.  I had to very different experiences (albeit in 
          different states).  A number of years ago I was clocked by an 
          officer doing a 168 mph on the Massachusetts Turnpike in a 
          Ferrari 512 Boxer (not my car, belonged to a friend who was with 
          me, geezzzz, talk about no need for a stereo!).  It was 3:30 am 
          and the only way he caught up with me was at a toll booth.  After 
          finding out the car wasn't stolen, that I was sober, and after a 
          severe tongue lashing about how this was grounds for jail time, 
          and, of course, several minutes of apologizing profusely, he let 
          me off with a warning!  Needless to say, I donated $$$ to the 
          annual police fundraiser.......
          My second experience was in Maryland a couple of years later.  I 
          was clocked doing 71 mph in a 55 at 2:30 am.  This time I was 
          slapped with "reckless driving".  I was the only one on the 
          highway, no weaving, sober, etc, etc.  Why reckless driving?  He 
          wouldn't tell me.  I guess it had to do with the $50 for speeding 
          vs. $255 for reckless driving, and probably a slow night.  Go 
          figure?
          
          
          ciao mi amice,

Date: Fri, 3 Mar 95 11:41:07 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: Color Sanding


Bev-

You never quite said what was wrong with the "couple of areas 
on the hood," making it hard to give definitive advice.  I'm 
assuming they are slightly off color due to oxidation, or slightly 
rough due to dust, or something like that.  Here's what I'd do.

I'd start with the 1500 grit and the rubber pad.  Soak the paper 
in water for a few minutes before using it, and add a little 
detergent to the water.  The detergent helps keep bits of sanded 
off paint out of the sandpaper.  The 2000 grit is too fine to do 
anything, and the 600 grit may be unnecessarily coarse.  If the 
1500 doesn't get you anywhere in a reasonabl;e time, go back to 
the 600, and follow that with the 1500.  Keep it wet too.  (Use 
separate containers for soaking the different grits, or clean 
thoroughly between uses.  You don't want 600 grit particles in 
your 1500 grit paper.)  Keep the surface nice and wet.  Don't 
scrimp on water.  You can keep the pressure even enough with 
your hand.  It should only take a few minutes to sand off the 
top surface.  Check it by drying it with a towel.  When it's 'done' 
it will look dullish.

When you have that nice, even, dull sheen, it's time to use 
polishing compound.  I'm afraid that guys might jump all over 
me for this one, but you don't have to go through all the hoopla 
about wool pads, or sheepskin pads, or this polish or that 
polish, if you're just doing a bit of patching up.  Just use a nice 
clean cotton rag.  Believe it or not, you can even get by with a 
paper towel, but don't tell anyone I told you that.  Any good 
polish will do.  The 3M Finesse is fine, PPG makes stuff called 
DRX-10, I think, and I'm sure one of the Meguiars polishes will 
work as well too, although I haven't used them myself.  I tend 
to stick with the 'professional' products, like 3M and PPG.  I 
figure that they have to satisfy folks who make a living 
polishing cars, not just some hobbyists.  

Don't use a power polisher.  You don't need it for a small 
section (and you can actually screw things up with it if you're 
not experienced).  You also don't have to worry about using 
coarse polish, then a finer polish, and so on.  You do that if 
you're doing a whole car.  It saves time.  But if you're just doing 
a spot here and there, you can use fine polish to begin with and 
just rub a little longer.  It'll take ten minutes instead of five.  

There's not a whole lot of magic to it, and not a whole lot to 
worry about.  It's hard to ruin a finish by polishing it!

Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa

Date: Fri, 3 Mar 95 15:54:34 EST
From: sdandeka@chipcom.com (Shirish Dandekar)
Subject: DME modifications

I noticed that the 911 Carrera increased HP from 207 to 217 (202 to 214 depending
on the source) from the 84-86 to 87-89 model years. The specs list both 3.2l engines
with the same compression ratio and the same fuel injection system (DME). Was the 
incease in HP due to differences in the DME or was the valves/head design modified?
If if was due to the DME was it simply a software change or something more 
significant? Can the earlier Carreras (84-86) DME be upgraded to this level of
performance without major expense?

	-RISH-

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 3 Mar 1995 13:11:20 -0800
From: winders@support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: DME modifications

>I noticed that the 911 Carrera increased HP from 207 to 217 (202 to 214
>depending
>on the source) from the 84-86 to 87-89 model years. The specs list both
>3.2l engines
>with the same compression ratio and the same fuel injection system (DME).
>Was the
>incease in HP due to differences in the DME or was the valves/head design
>modified?
>If if was due to the DME was it simply a software change or something more
>significant? Can the earlier Carreras (84-86) DME be upgraded to this level of
>performance without major expense?
>
>        -RISH-


A change was made in '87 to the DME program (i.e. chip) to assume Super
Unleaded was being used instead of regular unleaded. This assumption
allowed them to get the extra 10 hp....

Scott Winders
winders@support.apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Subject: Re: DME modifications

    A change was made in '87 to the DME program (i.e. chip) to assume Super
    Unleaded was being used instead of regular unleaded. This assumption
    allowed them to get the extra 10 hp....

Was this also accompanied by the inclusion of anti-knock sensors to detect
detonation if super unleaded *wasn't* used?  If so, then "upgrading" a pre-87
DME (w/o the knock sensors) to the new chip might be a bad move.

Just junk food for thought!

>    allowed them to get the extra 10 hp....
>
>Was this also accompanied by the inclusion of anti-knock sensors to detect

Tracy,

No, no knock sensors until '89 with the 3.6 and it's 11.3:1 compression
ratio. Of course, the twin-plugs makes it more like 10.3:1, but that is
still awful high.

Scott

Robert,
An interesting story.  I've been stoped a number of times for speeding in my 
younger days. I remember going to court on one of these occations and being 
asked by the judge "I see you are a student, what college do you attend?"  I 
replied "Illinois Institute of Technology".  I didn't think that this had any 
bearing on my "need for speed" but the judge must have and replied "Not that 
this has any thing to do with the issue at hand, Case dissmissed !"  Just like 
that. I was stuned that being a college student could possibly count for 
something (specialy in a court of law). Well this was a Chicago traffic court 
and I was in no way going to look a gift hourse in the mouth, so I graciously 
removed my self <BG> from the court room, free to speed again.

Date: Fri, 03 Mar 95 18:28:55      
From: hora001@ibm.net
Subject: Weber 40 IDF Float level adjustment - HELP!



Scott...wrote                                                                                                                                                       
Subject: Weber 40 IDF Float level adjustment - HELP!                                                                                                       
"I just purchased a Hanes Weber manual that tells me to 
adjust the flat level b"..

The manual was fine for my 914s 40IDF..the float is adjusted
when it is apart and done by holding the top 1/2 with the
float open and closed to check both measurements 10.00mm
32.5mm respectively...covered on pgs 170 & 171.. only a good
ruler and eyeball are needed.
There is a float gauge with a little glass tube that is for
the Weber IDAs and Zeniths used on 911s 

John Hora
73 914 1.7
74 914 1.?

Date: Fri, 3 Mar 1995 16:48:27 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: Performance Tips?!!

That's one of the things I love about my Shelby Charger (turbo, of course). I 
paid about $2000 for it and could outperform (acceleration AND handling) 
the majority of other cars on the road, easily. I recall reading somewhere 
that one of the goal of Carroll Shelby's Charger was to outperform the 944 
at 1/3 (or less) of the cost. :)

But, then I bought the 914, and eventually the turbo died, and now I 
tearfully have to sell the Shelby... :(

Hopefully, next winter I'll get to do some motor work and get the 914 up to 
at least close to the acceleration power of the Charger... I miss power! :)

Date: 03 Mar 95 20:44:41 EST
From: Clinton Owen <74547.3121@compuserve.com>
Subject: O2 Sensor Failure

It is very obvious when your O2 sensor fails (or the connector cracks in half as
happened to me), your gas mileage will get unbelievably bad.  

While I was away under the ocean working for Uncle Sam on a Submarine my wife
took the 944 in for it's Smog check, naturally they sold her a new O2 sensor.
When I started driving the car again I noticed that the range was down to about
150 miles per tank, something like 10 to 12 miles per gallon.  There were no
other symptoms of abnormal operation.  

Once I replaced the connector on the firewall everything returned to normal.

Clint Owen

83 944, 145K miles

Jim:

This is a very good price, or at least it would be in the Chicago area. I
took delivery tonight of a factory ordered 993 C4 Cabriolet; they had given
me 5% off the sticker. This is from a dealership that, between myself and my
partners, we've purchased approximately a dozen cars. I had taken their deal
to a rival Porsche dealer, where I had purchased a different vehicle and thus
was a customer there, also. They would only give me approximately 2 - 3% off
the sticker, even knowing what the rival dealership would do.

8% off seems good to me. Demand is still high on these cars.

Date: Fri, 03 Mar 95 23:58:09 +0000
From: Ray@arkay.MV.COM
Subject: Re: Turbos and Water Injection

The following message was returned to me as "undeliverable". I 
thought I had successfully posted it to Porschephiles, but evidently
there must have been a problem. Here is my second attempt. Sorry if
you are getting a duplicate.

//-----------------------------------------------------------------
> Hi all,
> Someone recently asked about pros /cons of injection systems for
> turbos. While I don't have any firsthand knowledge, I have been
> following a discussion about this in the internet newsgroup
> rec.autos.sport.tech. Basically, it was mentioned that water 
> injection reduces probability of destructive detonation, helps
> absorbe excess heat, and in the process the generated steam adds
> torque due to the additional pressure exerted onto the piston by
> the expanding steam.
> 
> Of the disadvantages that were noted, the danger of internal engine
> corrosion was the one that alarmed me most. In fact the idea of an
> engine rusting inside out bothered me so much that I forgot any
> other problems they mentioned.
> 
> Re-reading Bruce Anderson's book ("Porsche 911 Performance 
Handbook")
> I noticed that he mentioned another way to increase safe boost 
limits
> is the use of an additional fuel injection system to enrich the
> mixture at high boost levels. Unfortunately, the company mentioned
> in the book no longer makes any such devices, but EBS Engine 
Builders
> Supply mentioned on the phone that they have something like that. I
> asked them for specifics but probably didn't sound ready to plunk
> down tremendous amounts of cash so they haven't sent me anything 
yet.
> 
> While I realize that I have a lot to learn before I attempt such
> performance improvements, I am very curious about anything that 
> makes higher turbo boost safe or at least less dangerous. Larger
> intercoolers are also of interest.
> 
> My 930 has adjustable turbo boost, all the way up to 1.5 bar, but   
> Bruce's picture of the melted piston is very vividly in my mind
> anytime I am tempted to reach behind the driver's seat to touch the
> forbidden tap of instant pleasure. 
> 
> Another thing that is very much on my mind is the previous owner's
> repair bill totalling $7000 in parts, labor, and machine shop costs
> for rebuilding the engine after a "mysterious loss of power".
> 
> Ray (Former Boston city dweller transplanted to NH boonies)
> '82 Euro 930 		(the primary subject of my attention)
> '92 Harley		(hibernating)
> '83 and '88 Toyotas 	(soaking up road salt)

Date: Sat, 4 Mar 1995 01:28:55 -0500
From: KMyers8519@aol.com
Subject: Re: Subject: Roll Cages

Greetings:

This is in response to Pat Moyle's letter of 95-02-22. His blasting of
Autopower cages is based on mis-information, mis-communication, and
mis-understanding. There are several false statements that libel Autopower
and all Autopower dealers such as myself.

First, Pat Moyle is WRONG in claiming that an Autopower cage was involved in
the accident at the 1993 runoffs. THIS IS FALSE! The cage that failed was
made by another manufacturer. The name of the manufacturer is not pertenant,
I will supply this information to anyone who really cares. Call me at the 800
number below.

Second, in racing, there will always be accidents that far exceed the design
limitations of the safety equipment of the car. Third, Autopower DOES make a
cage for the 914 that mounts to the door sills using welded mounting plates
with nuts on the back side. Forth, any Autopower cage may be custom
fabricated to mount to welding plates attached to the door sills.

It is the responsibility of the race car owner to determine what is the
safest and most cost-effective choice. Although Race-Tech, Mattar and Safety
Devices all make cages that will hold up to most accidents, I will bet that
their failure rate per cages-made is no better or worse than anyone elses.

In the specific accident at the 1993 runoffs that was referred to, the car
hit head-on into a tire barrier at excessive speed and was flipped
approximately 10 feet in the air before crashing down on the roof of the car
with tremendous force. Many things happened to cause the driver to be hurt in
that accident, only one of which was that the cage punched through the floor
of the car. AGAIN, THE CAGE INVOLVED WAS NOT MADE BY AUTOPOWER. It is not
certain that a cage using welded in mounting plates would not have failed
also. SCCA has since reviewed their rules and made changes to roll cage
tubing diameters and allowed aftermarket seats in Showroom Stock cars.
However, Showroom Stock cars must still use bolt-in roll cages.

Bottom line...Pat Moyle was right in one thought...don't scrimp on your
personal safety. I don't know Mr. Moyle, but "Judge not lest ye be judged";
but if you are going to judge, at least get your facts right.

Tens of thousands of Autopower cages have been installed in race cars over
the years. Autopower would not still be in business if there were truly a
safety problem.

Ken Myers
Owner, I/O Port Racing Supplies
800-949-5712

Porschephiles #1218                         Sun Mar 5 02:00:05 CST 1995
Date: Sat, 4 Mar 1995 00:35:12 -0800
From: Harry Pellow <maestro@well.sf.ca.us>
Subject: 912 Carburetor Questions

To: Porschephiles
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Weber/Solex/Zenith Carbs on a 356/912

        Recently, there has been a discussion here concerning the use of
Weber Carburetors vs. Solex/Zenith carbs on a 356 or 912 Porsche.
        Having personally installed & adjusted HUNDREDS of carburetors
of all the above types on 356/912's, I think you might like to hear the
results.
        Result 1: IF Zenith or Solex Carbs have been rebuilt properly-
with all surfaces machined flat, the bodies ultrasonically cleaned and
in the case of Solexes, bronze throttle shafts bushings installed
(along with oversize butterflies, if needed), then they work well!
        Result 2: The 40 IDF Webers (and even the 44IDF Webers),
work well on 356's or 912 too! Don't let others steer you toward a wrong
decision with their personal prejudices and half-truths. A good carburetor 
is a good carburetor, and Webers are good carburetors.
        It's more a matter of personal choice- like do you want to be 
Original, or do you want Ball Bearings supporting your throttle shaft?
   As far as Weber carburetors, I like both the 40 and 44IDF- which one you
select depends on the application. The 40's are a good choice for a 
street engine, they're more tractable around town and give better gas
mileage. 
     The 44's produce more high-end power (at the cost of low-end
driveability)
and give you the sound of the Ferrari at less than 1% of the cost.
     The 40's, having a 40mm bore are best used with the Solex manifold and
the Adapto-plate. (This also eliminates interference with the sheet metal
and spring plate bolts on late-model fan shrouds.) The 44's, having a 44mm
bore, should be used with the Weber manifold as it too has a 44mm bore and
things then match. The Weber manifold, however, requires some trimming of
the
Side Vertical shrouds to provide clearance. (Also, if you use the Weber
manifold on late-model Fan Shrouds, then you should watch out for
interference
between bolts holding the Spring Plate on the Fan Shroud and the
screws holding the block-off plate on the Weber.)
     The biggest problem with Solexes is that the steel throttle shaft wears
its bore in the carburetor body (there being no bushings in the
early Solexes). Eventually, the wear gets so bad that the butterflies
start digging into the throttle body, opening up gaps around the butterfly,
allowing more air than necessary to pass through. This causes the high RPM
idle condition characteristic of worn Solexes. Adjusting the mixture screws
either has little or no effect or makes things worse. It's time to rebuild
the Solexes, which to do properly, costs almost as much as a set of NEW
Webers!
     Webers don't NEED the throttle shaft bore rebored or rebushed
since Webers have ball bearings supporting the throttle shaft and do not
suffer from throttle shaft wear like the Solexes do. THAT'S a big advantage.
     With Solexes, changing a main jet means that the entire 
contents of the float bowl pouand it's a joy to adjust the idle mixture
screws- they're
like micrometers and repeatable. A sign of a good carburetor.)
      Just my $.02.

KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
The Maestro


 secothe float chamber flowing all over
your spark plug wires.
       Having the Main Jet, Air Correction Jet and Emulsion Tube
on a single, easily-removed Jet Stack is a Better Idea.
      The big disadvantage of Webers is that they are not Original. If you
want only original parts on your car, you're stuck with Solexes or Zeniths.
      Speaking of Zeniths- though not a "performance" carburetor, when 
properly rebuilt they run Very Well, thank you. (I just fired up a rebuilt
356C today- and it's a joy to adjust the idle mixture  screws- they're
like micrometers and repeatable. A sign of a good carburetor.)
      Just my $.02.

KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
The Maestro

Date: 04 Mar 95 11:24:47 EST
From: Michael Kehr <71324.3010@compuserve.com>
Subject: RE: Looking For 944 Turbo ?

Darren,

Hope this helps.

The latest model 944 Turbo (951), would be a 944 Turbo S 1989. This was the
only 944 turbo model available in the U.S for 1989. This model was also
produced in 1988 as a limited edition in a special color, silver rose metallic
with matching plaid interior. Aprox. 700 car were shipped to PCNA. As demand
exceeded supply, along with complaints about the color, other colors were 
produced. 

The 944 turbo was first introduced in this country as an '86 model. The early
VIN #'s had some problems.(exhaust manifolds cracking, fuel line coupling
leaking, a change in the exhaust system in '87 I think, a change in the
crossover pipe, which takes off 5 hours of labor when changing the clutch.)

In '87, ABS brakes and dual air bags were offered as options. There were
changes to the front wheel geometry to accomadate the ABS, wheel offset
changed. Also remember the problems were addressed and the updates were fitted
in this model year, not that this car didn't have it's problems (waterpumps,
etc.) A self adjusting belt tensioner was also added.

In 1988 a special edition model was produced as a direct result from
the Porsche turbo cup. The new model came equipped with 928 S4 brakes
a engine with 247 bhp, new vanes in turbocharger and DME remapping. Minor 
changes were made to the fender area to accomadate the larger tires and 
wheels. Sport suspension (M 030), stronger manual transmission and LSD, clutch
modifications, along with other changes. This car was loaded with all options.

In 1988 the standard turbo was also available. In 1989 this special
edition model was the only turbo available. Of course it came in all
color combinations and options included.

Be aware that these Turbo S cars produce almost 65 hp per cylinder! These
cars exibit more problems, because of the higher performance. Also people in 
general run these cars harder. If you plan to purchase one of these expect 
higher repair bills. I feel that this is the best 944, but there are trade 
offs. The 1988 non S is a great buy, alot of bugs were worked out buy this 
time. Of course these S models will demand the higest price of the Turbo's, 
get a pre inspectionby someone who "knows" these cars, it will be well worth 
it.
Good luck, I hope this helps a bit.

Mike Kehr  '86 951

Date: Sat, 4 Mar 1995 08:37:01 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: Car Lift Questions

You wrote: 

>

>garage.
>

>
>Any help or advise would be greatly appreciated.

>NPIBob@aol.com
>1980 SC Triple Black
>1978 SC Petrol Blue
>1994 Jeep Grand Cherokee
>
>
I looked at a lot of lifts. I was not able to get one as the Ceiling in 
my garage is to low. The lift would fit but could not get the 914 high 
enought to park to 911 under it. Call the manufactures and get there 
brochures that include the installation measurements. Then you will have 
a better idea if you can fit it in the garage.

I personally like the lifts where you put the car on the ramps and it is 
open in the middle great for engine drop oil change etc.

Be prepare to spend about $3,000 for a good one.


					mike

Date: Sat, 04 Mar 1995 12:31:47 -0500 (EST)
From: RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu
Subject: Performance tips 2

Oh thank you morally correct people who have shown me the light.  I will never 
road race again, definitly wear a seat belt, and always wear a condom.
	
	Come on people, why did you buy a Porsche? don't give me this BS that 
it's the fine German Engineering because Volkswagen/Audis, BMW's and Mercedes 
are engineered just as well.  I also don't believe that most of the Porsches 
sold are sold because of the (yes I will say it) sex-appeal of the driver - be 
that male or female.

	These cars are pure-breds built for safe fast (& lets not forget FUN) 
performance motoring, and unless you have NEVER broken the speed limit don't 
give me a hard time about a previous experience.  After all I was there to 
evaluate road conditions, visibility of other vehicles etc.etc.  By the way if 
someone has an autox organized in the Ohio area then please challenge me, this 
944 is bringing back all sorts of pleasant memories of when I used to race 
karts!

	I also realize that the 944 is never going to be a dragster, otherwise 
I would have bought an AC Cobra.  In the meantime the bike will suffice...

	However there still remains the quest for more performance from the 
vehicle at hand.  Even though it already is a fearful autox tool, it could 
undoubtedly be better.  THAT's why I asked about 'bang for the buck' and 
details about my hypertech chip.  I have no details for this chip, but was 
told by a friend that these chips are sold with some other components (much 
like a kit) to upgrade performance.  Is this correct?  I have also heard of a 
high flow catalytic convertor sold by the dreaded JC Whitney but which 
supposedly increases exhaust flow.  I have already purchased the K&N air-
filter which made a satisfying difference over the partly-clogged standard 
filter.  Any other cheap mods available?  Is a change to a Dinan or 
Autothority chip worthwhile?  
	
	Cheers, Jan

'86.5 944 (latest fun)				>

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 04 Mar 95 12:52:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re: Subject: Roll Cages


Hi Ken,

I think I read Pat's posting a little differently than you, and took a
different message away.  To my thinking, the issue at hand is not
Autopower vs. other manufacturers.  The issue is cages (and for
that matter roll bars) which mount to a floor pan vs. those which
mount to structurally stronger points, like the frame rails.

In this matter, no one has convinced me that mounting a cage to
a floor pan is as safe as mounting it to frame rails.  I probably should
look at the Run-Offs incident as a single data point, and I am not
a mechanical engineer.  But it seems pretty clear to me that, to
create the best survival cell for the driver, it ought to be connected
at all eight corners of the cube.

You say "Forth, any Autopower cage may be custom
fabricated to mount to welding plates attached to the door sills."
This is certainly true on the surface.  But for an equipment vendor
to market an a priori inferior or inadequate design, with the "out"
that its buyer is free to correct that design, is absurd.  I can
think of a lot of analogies, but the nearest to hand is a new car
warranty.  How would you feel if, after buying a new car and a
defect arose, the dealer's response was "Hey no problem,
feel free to fix it on you own nickel, Ken"?

I have seen AutoPower cages modified to mount to the frames,
for example, in a friend's 930.  That involved a bunch of work
on the part of the guy who installed it.  Too bad those front legs
weren't shaped properly in the first place.

Moreover, you presume that the buyer or his mechanic a) recognizes
the problem, and b) knows how to properly fix it.  Go to any PCA
Club Race or track event, and I can walk you around the paddock
and point out any number of counterexamples.  I have been told
that the same can be said for SCCA and IMSA.

You also say "It is the responsibility of the race car owner to determine
 what is the safest and most cost-effective choice."  Unfortunately,
most of the owners are pretty good at the latter and kind of lost
when dealing with the former.  Most folks assume that AutoPower, Race
Tec, and the rest have done their homework and produced a safe,
high quality part which will install in a car correctly.  This certainly
should be the case, but it isn't always.

Your points about SCCA's changes to cage material thickness and
their rules regaring bolt-in (vs welded in) parts don't seem to have
any bearing on the matter of floor mounts and the Run Offs incident.

Finally, you say "Tens of thousands of Autopower cages have been
installed in race cars over the years. Autopower would not still be
in business if there were truly a safety problem."  Unfortunately, as
Hunter and Stoff point out in their book "Motorsports Medicine", it
is damn hard to get any statistics on injury rates and component
failure rates from manufacturers and racing organizations.  There
is no organization which certifies, eg, Autopower's equipment and
decides whether they may sell it or not.  Your statement could just
as easily have been made of any number of product, technologies,
and companies which no longer exist.  There are hundreds of millions
of people who smoke cigarettes, after all.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 04 Mar 95 16:42:23 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Performance tips 2

OK, Jan,

Since you insist on knowing whether or not reprogrammed chips will help the
performance of your car, I will relate my experience.

I came across a free copy of the Autothority chip for my 83 944. (Don't ask, 
it was just one of the side-benefits of being in the business...) I installed
it, drove it on the street for a month or so, drove it at Lime Rock a couple
of days in driver education.

Bottom line:

1) Most noticeable difference: Rev limiter kicked in at @ 7000 rpm vice 6500.

2) Difference in power: my assessment: slight increase in torque from 1000 
   rpm to 2000 rpm (10 lb-ft??). My guess at increased horsepower was 5 bhp.
   
3) Difference in lap times at Lime Rock: none

4) Other observations: My wife observed, as passenger, "The car sounds funny.
   What did you do to it?" After she pointed it out to me, I did become aware
   of a different pitch to the sound of the motor. I attributed it to the
   timing being advanced to a point much closer to detonation that normal.

Final disposition:

A track junkie friend said he really wanted the chip, so I sold it to him.
Never missed it.

My advice to you: Don't buy a chip (no matter what brand) unless you first 
get a written assurance from the seller that you can have your money back in 
full within a reasonable timeframe (say 30 days).

And, of course, if you haven't learned to drive your car at the limit, by
way of driver education, don't waste the money in the first place.

In my opinion, the $500 spent on a chip is better spent on some good BFG Comp
TA R1 tires (which is exactly what I did with the money from my track junkie 
friend.)  :-)

Of course, Your mileage may vary...


- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 4 Mar 1995 21:34:37 -0500
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: Summit Point & Potomac

Subj:	Summit Point & Potomac
Date:	95-03-03 10:20:43 EST
From:	TODD.COHEN@rrd.com
To:	porschephiles@tta.com

>SUBJECT:   Summit Point & Potomac
 
 
>        I am going to my first PCA Drivers Ed event on March 12, at Summit
>Point, and have some questions for anyone who is going to this event or
>has participated in Potomac PCA events.
 
Todd...Relax.  Many first timers make a much bigger deal of this than it is.
It would seem that you have taken the trouble to make sure that you have a
very safe car, and that is probably the most important thing.  As a rookie,
you will get class training, and have an instructor with you for most of the
weekend.  They will be able to ansewr most of your questions.  As far as more
mods to the car, you do not need it.  You will NOT be going all that fast at
your first event, and as you come out to these, you will naturally drive
harder, and learn what is needed to keep your car working "properly" and
safely.  Finally, you should arrive at the track at 7 am, and you will have
at least 1 1/2 hours to clean out and prep your car.  Hope that helps.

 
Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

Date: Sat, 4 Mar 1995 23:27:10 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Roll Cages

Greetings:

Evidently in stating the roll cage involved in the 1993 runoffs incident was
an Autopower product, I was in error.  If this is  in fact true, I apologize
to the list for this misinformation.  

I did not, however state that the cage failed.  What I said was, "keep in
mind the cage itself did not fail, the mounting system was inadequate and the
roll over protection system failed."

My intent was not to blast Autopower, but was meant as a discussion on mass
produced roll cages in general and the merits (or defeciencies) of the
designs available.  The fact that the runoffs cage was not an Autopower does
not erase the fact that the cage in question, which was bolted to the
floorboard of the car, in your words, "punched through the floor of the car,"
This, if nothing else illustrates the very point I was trying to make.

I spent the day mentally composing what I thought would be a thoughtful
response to Mr. Myers post of this morning.  When I got home this evening, I
found Kevin Gross had already composed and posted it for me.  Thanks Kevin, I
couldn't have said it nearly as well myself.

Bottom line for me is, I will never have a cage in MY car which bolts to the
floorboard, regardless of who makes it.

Regards,

Pat Moyle (pm9146@aol.com)

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 5 Mar 1995 08:28:18 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944TurboS brake proportio...

<Don writes:
<I have heard it is possible to change the brake proportioning on
<my 89 944TurboS in order to let the rear do more work. Supposedly
<there is a sleve above the ABS computer (wherever that is) that if
<replaced  by one from a (things get fuzzy here) 928 or 968 then it
<will proportion more to the rear. Does anyone know the facts on <his?

Don,
I am investigating that very problem as we speak. It is apparent that the
rear brakes are along for the ride. Consider that I, and probably you, wear
out 3 or 4 front brakes for every set of rears. This is in racing situations,
I can't speak for the street.
When I was at the Club Race at Sebring I talked to from the guys at
Kelly-Moss racing and they told me that the proportioning valve could be
changed so the rears take some of the burden from the fronts. They also said
that they could supply the part but first they wanted to know the numbers
that were written on my old part. Apparently there is a ratio written on the
valve body. I have not done this as of today but it will happen in the
future.(the Kelly-Moss people claim that they use brakes in a 2:1 ration and
their cars are really good under braking)
I do have some concerns with this because of the ABS system. I need to know
how this will be effected by the changes, etc, etc, so I'm not going to
plunge into this lightly.
BTW the proportioning valve is in back of the right front plastic fender
inner liner. Pull off the wheel, unbolt the plastic liner and you will see
the proportioning valve sitting on top of the ABS pump. It is a cylindrical
device that is in line with the pump and the rear brake line.
Let me know how you make out.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
8:08 am

Date: Sun, 5 Mar 1995 09:36:35 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re : Gas mileage for a 83 SC

>Well, I finially got to drive the 911 that I bought last fall for
>more than one day...but I found it gobbles the gas up. My 
>calculations show it about 13 MPR oops MPG in the city...with only
>tye occasionaly stomping..

>Is this expected, or do I need my fuel injection to be tuned?

Mike,

I would think you should see alot more than 13mpg.  My '76 gets
low-to-mid 20s in the mpg department (same injection system
as yours, slightly smaller engine at 2.7L) no matter how I drive
it.  You don't mention any running problems, but I would guess that
your mileage indicates something is amiss?

Just a data point...

Mike  


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 5 Mar 1995 09:36:43 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: 83 SC engine and tranny $?

>What is an 83 SC engine w/ tranny worth?  It is in storage, but the owner
says
>that the engine had a broken head stud when he took it out of the car.
>The CIS is included.  Is this a no lose situation if the price is around
>$2k?  The number on the case should be 930_____3.0 correct? What else
>should I check for?  I guess the only way to tell the shape with it not
>being in the car would be a leakdown huh?  Any other advice is appreciated.

Sean,

First off, the engine type (which can be found down near the bottom
of the fan housing on the passenger's side) should be 930/16 for a
US car, 930/10 for an '83 R.o.W. car.  $2k isn't too bad.  A friend of
mine offered to sell me his 3.0L engine (sans gearbox) for $2.5k and
it has ZERO compression in one cylinder and the others are averaging
about 50 psi - I passed.

Unfortunately, the broken head stud is a given.  Not a real big deal, but
it is expensive to get fixed (if for no other reason than the fact that
once your in there, you might as well do other stuff too - I wouldn't
tear the whole engine down and just replace the one stud).

My opinion?  If you're planning on buying this for your own use, it might
be worth considering.  If you plan on buying it with the intent of re-selling
it for a profit, you might want to evaluate how many $$$ *might* have to
be put into it prior to resale.

HTH,

Mike

>

Rich
AOL in its software files has a program called paint shop you can 
download this and use it to open the clip art.

						mike
