Date: Sun,  5 Mar 95 15:01:11 -0600
From: Mike Selner <mike@is.com>
Subject: 944TurboS brake proportioning valve

> Date: Sat, 4 Mar 1995 17:36:02 -0500 (EST)
> From: Don Rubin <rubin@moe.setinc.com>
> Subject: 944TurboS brake proportioning

>  I have heard it is possible to change the brake proportioning on
>  my 89 944TurboS in order to let the rear do more work. Supposedly
>  there is a sleve above the ABS computer (wherever that is) that if
>  replaced  by one from a (things get fuzzy here) 928 or 968 then it
>  will proportion more to the rear. Does anyone know the facts on
>  this?
>

Yes, I replaced the proportioning valve on my 89-951.  The stock
valve is an "5/18" and I used a "5/33". I think the number 5
refers to the rate of the reduction in pressure to the rear
brakes, and the 18 or 33 refers to the pressure, in bar, of the
point where the valve starts to modulate the rear brake pressure.
Hence the 33 would allow up to 33 bar of pressure to the rear
brakes before reducing the hydraulic pressure.  (List, please
correct me if I am wrong here). Check the service manual to
confirm this.  The installation is simple - remove the RF fender
liner, remove the brake line, remove the old valve (about the
size of a "C" battery)...installation is the reverse of
disassembly.  Bleed the brakes and go.  The valve is about $70 -
and not much to it.  You could change the spring in your valve if
you knew what spring to use.  E-mail if you want the part number.

Results:

I don't have enough track time with this setup to give a
quantitative answer.  The fronts will still (attempt to) lock
before the rears.  I feel that there is a bit less nose dive with
this setup.  The rear brakes are doing more work than stock.  My
rear brake pads (Blue Cool Carbon) have worn a bit more than
before - maybe 25% over 3 track events (200 mi avg/event). Two
other 89's in the club have done this modification and are happy.
One car, an '86 951, had a lot of rear lockup and re-installed
the original valve.

>  BTW I am NOT interested in a discussion about the merits of doing
>  this just the technical facts. Thanks...

Disclaimer:
The service manual says that you must retain the stock valve.
No reason is given.  I assume it is because of potential rear
brake lockup.

> Don Rubin                             Voice: 301-588-8010
> Systems Engineering Technology Inc.   Fax:   301-588-0154
> 9703 Forest Glen Court                rubin@setinc.com
> Silver Spring, MD 20910-1121          http://www.setinc.com
>                                      finger for PGP public key

- --
Mike Selner	mike@is.com	951.89.41.41

Date: Sun, 5 Mar 1995 19:53:31 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Brake bias

Chris writes
>I'm very interested in how you two make out.  I have an '87 944S
>which wears its rears out at a ratio of approx. 20/1 (I've gone >through
>three sets of front pads for 3mm of rear pad wear).  I know the 944s >and
>turbo have brake regulators installed which apportion less bias to the
>rear once a certain pressure is reached in the brake lines.

Will be glad to let you know when we have some answers. In the meantime you
certainly DON'T want cool carbons on the rear as they are much harder then
factory pads. Try the cool carbons on the front and soft (factory) pads on
the rear. That should help your situation somewhat. 
BTW does your car have ABS? If it does not be real careful with the bias.
What you (and the factory) don't want is the rears locking up first, in which
case you will have the joy of watching the rear of the car pass the front!

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
4:13 pm

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 5 Mar 1995 17:34:15 -0800
From: cjk50g@ix.netcom.com (Christopher Woodward)
Subject: RE: brake proportioning valve

Hi Mike, Jerry, Rubin, + all,

I wanted to finish the discussion and raise a question regarding
the brake proportioning valve.  Mike was on the right track.  The
numbers on these valves appearing on 944S's, Turbo's and,
presumably S2's, refer to a reduction rate and bar pressure
respectively.  S's have a 5/33, Turbo's a 5/18.  The first number
means the rate at which all marginal increases in pedal pressure
above a cetain bar, 18/33 in this case, are reduced by during
their trip to the rear.  This number 5 refers to a factor of .46
(factory manual in hand).  Stated another way, when you brake hard
enough to activate this regulator, you start getting more front
brake bias.

In my 944S I definitly experience this.  I've gone through more
than three sets of front pads for 3.5mm of rear pad wear.  I've 
tried cross-sanding the rotors with emory cloth and lightly 
sanding the pads in hopes of bringing them back to life.  The
fluid is regularly bled.  But to no avail.  I can go down a sandy,
steep, hill hit the brakes and still lock only the fronts.

My question is whether, upon experiencing this, any list member
has gone the route of installing a bias adjustor and removing the
regulator on their 944.  Comments from those mixing pads would 
also be appreciated.

Chris Woodward
944S

Date: Sun, 5 Mar 1995 18:49:58 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Mounting A Tire w/out Marking Wheel - Update

A week or so ago I asked folks on the net about how to have a tire mounted
on an aluminum wheel without leaving any "little dimple marks" on the
inside of the wheel...

To make a long story short(er), I went down to Dinan (the BMW tuning place)
in Mtn. View, CA and had a talk with them.  They showed me their machine -
pretty typical euro-car garage tire mounting machine.  These machine have
four hydraulicaly-operated wheel "gripper jaws" which move radially outward
to grip the (aluminum) wheel from the inside and hold it tight when the
tire's mounted. These "tables" are a lot like a lathe's 4-jaw chuck, but
the whole thing faces upwards instead of sideways.

Using these gripper jaws one cannot avoid the little dimples that are left
on the wheel.  BUT the jaws are double-acting -- they can also grip the
wheel from the outside, i.e. over the rim / inner bead, and they act upon
the "back side" of the bead, not on the rim itself.  These "outside-grip"
jaws don't have teeth, and they're radiused to approximate the curvature of
some particular wheel size, so the net effect is that it's somewhat more
likely that they may slip when the tire's being mounted.  Also, these jaws
have to be retracted (outwards) once the operator is ready to inflate the
tire and set it on the bead.  

Anyway, I said I wanted the tire mounted using this non-standard method,
and they felt they could do it (the service manager said he's put his "best
man on it"), and the net result is that it worked out fine -- the only
marks, if there are any, are now hidden by the tire. Plus, they did it for
free.

I presume the reason why many shops do it leaving the dimples is that it's
faster and it's less likely to slip since the jaws are actually digging
into the wheel.

My thanks to those of you who replied to my initial query.  

 ________________________________________
|  Andrew E. Kalman     aek@netcom.com   |
|       standard disclaimers apply       |
 ________________________________________

Date: Sun, 5 Mar 1995 22:40:21 -0500
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: Repairing Porsche Wheels

Pierre Vezina has a problem with a cloudy finish on his phone dial wheels.
 "The wheels show whitish dicoloration....and small streaks on the wheel".  

This problem is not unusual and may be the result of several factors. The
most common cause is your friendly local car wash.  Many automated car washes
use an acid to clean the wheels and tires.  This acid cleaner will rapidly
remove dirt, but may also attack the clear coat on Porsche wheels.  The
result is a cloudy, whitish or dull appearance.  

Many times, this may be cleared up by using a paint glaze such as 3M Hand
Glaze or Meguiar #09 or One Grand Omega Glaze to clean the affected paint.
 The OEM finish on many Porsche wheels is simply a silver paint with a clear
top coat.  This combination is not too different from the paint on the body.

Clean the wheel throughly with a quality wheel cleaner and dry completely.
Apply your choice of glaze to a soft cloth and rub out the clouding.  If this
does not do the trick, put a generous amount of 3M on your cloth and add a
small amount (about the size of your pinkie nail) of Blue Magic Metal Polish.
  Rub out the clouding with this combination.  The Blue Magic /3M combination
will usually get the job done.  If it has, follow up with a coat of quality
wax.  I use Sonax Spray Hard Wax on the wheels.  It doesn't chalk and
requires only light buffing.

Some painted/clear coated wheels will "yellow" under hard use applications.
 This is fairly common with track wheels that are subject to hard braking.
 The tremendous heat generated affects the clear coat and causes it to turn
yellow.  The 3M/Blue Magic trick will help to some degree, but not usually
restore them to original appearance.  

If the finish has not improved at this point, you may consider using a more
abrassive cleaner such as Meguiar #02 Fine Cut Cleaner or Meguiar #01 Medium
Cut Cleaner.  Apply either one to a soft cloth and *GENTLY* rub into the
wheel. Use carefully as you may put hairline scratches if you rub too hard.
 When the desired finish has been achieved, follow up with 3M Hand Glaze to
"finish out" the surface and then wax.   
 
A wheel that has resisted all of the above, may require repainting.  If the
existing paint is in good condition, other than discolored, slighly rough up
the paint with a 1200 grit sandpaper.  Wash thoroughly with a Prepsol type
product to remove all grease.  Spray the wheel with a quality primer such as
Wurth Rustop Primer and several *LIGHT* coats of Wurth Gloss Silver Wheel
Paint, allowing each coat to dry for two hours, prior to the next coat.
 Allow to dry for a few days, clean thoroughly and spray several *LIGHT*
coats of Wurth Gloss Clear Wheel Paint.  The Wurth products match the OEM
finish.  The Wurth Gloss Gold Wheel Paint matches the BBS gold finish.

If the surface of the wheel is pitted, or the paint has flaked off in
patches, all paint should be removed prior to repainting,  The easiest and in
my opinion, the only way,  is to have them blasted with a plastic media.
 Most blasting shops have the plastic media, but don't like to use it because
it is relatively slow (time=$).  Some people use glass bead.   Other blasting
media will dimple the wheels. Aluminum oxide leaves a distinct texture to the
surface.  Once all the old paint has been removed, clean the wheel with
Prepsol, prime and then paint.

One of the keys to maintaining your wheels is a coat of wax.  The wax acts as
a sacrificial protectant.  The damaging effects of red hot brake dust,  brake
dust acids, pollution and ozone are unleashed upon the wax and not your
wheel.

If there are any questions, or areas that need amplification, please do not
hesitate to contact me.

Larry Reynolds
Car Care Specialties, Inc.
Distributors of Quality Porsche Care Products
Post Office Box 535
Saddle Brook,  NJ  07663-0535
Phone (201) 796-8300
Fax (201) 791-9743
E-mail carcaresp@aol.com

Date: Sun, 5 Mar 1995 21:15:42 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: Quest. about washing/drying car.

Dan Nimtz (dnimtz@mill2.millcomm.com) quoted me:

>	Get a lot of water on the car first, then wash from the bottom 	
>	up.  Don't use the same sponge (or brush, or whatever) for both 

.. Than made the following points:

>I don't agree with washing from the bottom up for the following 
>reasons:
>
>1) You end up washing the top dirt down unto the (already) clean bottom
>2) There is typically more dirt and grime on the bottom, that will end
>   up on the top to some degree.

Dan:

Good points.  However, frequent rinsing of the sponge (or using two 
sponges, as suggested in an earlier post) will keep the dirt-transfer to 
a minimum.

I only wash from the bottom up so that I don't miss any parts of the 
car. When I start at the top, the soap runs down and I can't 
differentiate between the areas that have actually been touched by the 
sponge and those that are just soapy.

If you, like most people, have a better memory than I do, this won't be 
a problem.

 -Andy


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Sun, 05 Mar 95 22:30:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944TurboS brake proportioning valve


Mike,

You are correct in your description of the numbers on the brake
proportioning valve.  The "5" corresponds to a 0.46 drop in
marginal pressure.

The 5/18 valve used on the 944 Turbo is in fact superseded by
Porsche to the 5/33 valve first used on the 944S.  There have
been multiple supersessions in getting there, but the correct
current part is 928.355.305.02, list price $69.05 (at least it was in
August).

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Mon,  6 Mar 1995 02:40:48 -0500 (EST)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: 914 brakes. upgrade/replacement questions

    I have heard that you could get good results by upgrading to 911

your money, the 911 calipers or the drilled rotors...  If you switch to
the 911 stuff and you want to go junkyarding, I believe the 911 front
end parts from the struts out are a bolt-on, that way you can run cool
5-blot rims as well.
    Then again, I don't have the $ to have any personal experience with
this, so YMMV.  Comments, anyone?

Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 12:19:45 +0200
From: famland@ra.abo.fi
Subject: 924 cooling failiure and subsequent cracking of top

Gentlemen,

I am new to this list so please correct me if this entry is too untechnical
or otherwise inappropriate, but I believe the following experience may be
of interest to at least owners of older 924s.  Also, I apologize for my
imprecise technical English - this is a foreign language to me.


I drive a 1982 924 which has a quiet life in a garage most of the year, it
was bought with a cracked top (block is steel, top is aluminium) which was
replaced.

Unfortuantely, I never changed the original 12-year old cooling water
rubber tubes, and one of these burst open after driving the car at top
speed for about 40 minutes (this was in a European country with liberal
policies on traffic).

The symptoms arose over about two-three minutes:
The engine lost a little power, and the speed dropped from about 210 to 190
km/h while full pedal-to-metal (by speed indicator, more or less accurate),
I lost oil pressure, going from a healthy 3-4 to about 2-1 1/2 bars, and
the engine temp indicator dropped and then started fluctuating wildly.  The
smell of oil, obviously boiling in the engine, appeared, and I pulled over
at a petrol station about 20 secs after the smell of oil appeared.

Too late.

After the steam subsided, I found the burst tube (a sort of L-shaped with
different diametres in entry and exit, right side of engine when viewed
from front).

I improvised a repairing of the tube, refilled water in the cooling
curcuit, and tried to get the engine started, but it cranked very slowly,
as if the battery was flat.  By towing it and cranking the engine, we got
it started.  It was running unevenly and would not idle without stopping.

We towed it home and it would not start again.

This turned out to be hydrostatic locking: cooling water in one or more
cylindres due to burst top gasket.  This was apparent as it was towed
upwards onto a tow truck and water was seeping out of the exhaust pipe.  A
sorry sight in deed.

Epilogue:  The top turned out cracked (2nd time!) and it has now been replac=
ed.

Advice: Replace cooling curcuit components even when they still function.
I have heard elsewhere that the cooling of the otherwise reliable
Volkswagen LT engine is a weak point.

The old rule about not fixing something that works soes not apply in this ca=
se.

=46redrik Amland (famland@aton.abo.fi)

Vidistine nuper imagines moventes bonas?
Altsaa: Har du sett noen gode filmer i det siste?


=46redrik Amland
L=F8itnant av Guds naade og Kongens vilje
sivil=F8konom NHH, tusenkunstner, fusentast, pedagog og blindgjenger
extraordin=E1ire,
samt s=F8vngjenger og fattig og lat student

Adresse:
=C5landgatan 2/47
=46IN-020540 =C5bo
=46inland (the Funland with Finlandia)

Mobiltelefon:   (990) +47 920 48560
=46ax:            (990) +47 921 72805

Ave Professor!  Dormatori te salutant!
Take care of the luxuries, and the necessities will take care of themselves.
Problemet med =E5 bli sitert, er alle de dumme standpunkt man blir tatt til
inntekt for, selv flere =E5rhundreder efter sin d=F8d.

Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 08:17:39 -0500 (EST)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: Is a 2.4 liter 911 engine with 2.7 pistons okay?

On Sun, 5 Mar 1995, wade guthrie wrote:
> a 2.7 liter on the original 2.4 liter crankcase.  I've been steering
> away from 2.7 because of the reliability problems; am I going to have

I would not have said 2.7 for reliability as much as the E and S of 
72-73. The compression of the E and S (using the otherwise same engine 
as T) is quite a bit higher than a T... Supposedly this causes certain 
parts and pieces of the engines to go *kaboom* You'd be best to ask if 
this happened...
 -Derek
73 911T

Date: Mon, 06 Mar 1995 09:12:39 -0500 (EST)
From: RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu
Subject: More 944 quirks

Well since I went for a long(er) drive this weekend in my new rebuilt puppy, I 
thought I'd tried out the cruise control.  Well it should'nt be called cruise 
control, at present it functions more like 'launch control' since as soon as I 
activate it, the car takes off.  Since my wonderful Haynes manual doesn't go 
into any detail on many electronic systems, and also on some issues is PLAIN 
WRONG (like the computer being on the kickpanel under the left hand side of the 
steering column) I wonder if any of you guys & gals have come across the same 
problem.
	Oh, BTW if your central locking konks out but you can still hear the 
soleniod trip when activated, there is a $2.00 (yes TWO bucks) plastic linkage 
that transmits the action from the solenoid to the lock.  Mine had broken at 
the end.  30 minutes to get to, 1 minute to fix, 30 minutes to put everything 
back on AT THE LONGEST.
	Also my alarm switch is stuck, is there an easier way to get to this 
other than having my three year old boy get his arm through the vent in the 
doorshut? How does this ?!?@?! switch come out?  Oh yes I've already discovered 
that taking the electrical connector off sets the alarm off, much to the 
delight of my neighbours...
	Cheers, Jan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 06 Mar 1995 09:24:53 -0500 (EST)
From: RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu
Subject: Re: Oil pressure problems

I used to have an '83 944 which had the same problem, sometimes the oilpressure 
would take ages to come up, but when it came up the pressure was fine.  In some 
extreme cases the pressure wouldn't come up for so long that the hydraulic 
lifters would start clicking.  After much searching around it was found that 
the oilpressure relief valve (essentially a ball bearing with a spring) was 
getting stuck in the open position.  Take the thing apart, clean it and try and 
try again...
	Cheers,   Jan

Date: 06 Mar 1995 09:58:09 GMT
From: cbennet@lmcorp.com (Chris Bennet)
Subject: Re: 911 Pre-Purchase Sanity Check

Greg,
 As a data point;  I bought my white '86 Carrera w/67K miles for $18,300
last fall ('94).  It was owned by an authorized Porsche mechanic
for the last 5 yrs. It had been upgraded to '87 style headlights (H5's), the
tires have lots of tread wear left.  Records are only complete for the last
5 yrs.  Both doors had been painted to fix dings.  A decent car but not
great car.  ($18,300 is what the owner  was paid, I payed my broker another 
$1100 on top of that.)
$19,000 for an '83 SC does seem kind of high considering you could
get a nice '84 Carrera or a decent '86.  I'd keep shopping, that car isn't 
going anywhere (at that price).
  vroom,

Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 10:52:50 -0500
From: X400459@aol.com
Subject: how to download faqs etc on aol

After  getting onto AOL--you get the welcome screen.
1) Click Main Menu
2) on Main Menu, click "Internet Connection"
3) On Internet Connection, click  "FTP" box
4) On FTP (anonomous FTP), click "other Site" box
5) On other site, type in TTA.Com and click "connect box"
6) on TTA.Com click "public"
7) on Public, click "porschephiles

Now you should be in the menu for the various Porschephiles files. They can
be 
downloaded by choosing the file desired, highlighting it with a click, and
clicking the 
"download now" box. Afterwards, the AOL Download Manager will ask you to
select 
a directory in your pc--I always use the AOL2.0 directory, Download
subdirectory. 
The download will proceed. Next, get off AOL and use a wordprocessor to load
the 
text files for saving or printing. If you download a image, use your paint
program or 
download a program from AOL to handle the .gif file. Hollar if you need added

assistance. NOTE that Porschephiles DO NOT want you to "FTP" between 8:00 AM 
and 7:00 PM CST.

Rich Brown  X400459j@aol.com

Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 16:22:07 GMT

Pcar people, I for one am amazed at the the huge number of posts
expressing discontent about the number of posts that have no
Porsche specific content, If you don't like it don't read it! It
is so easy as to be beyond belief. I also note that the complaining
articles contained nothing about Porsche, nothing about driving
Porsche, nothing about the Porsche asthetic, nothing about speed,
or hot metal, nothing glorious, nothing about the smell of hot oil,
nothing about the "tink-tink" sound of a cooling down air-cooled engine,
nope. Just a single complaint. Oh dear.

However, I am willing to listen to whatever anyone has to say, and in 
deference to the apparent opinion that only geeky discussion of the relative
merits of various brake pads and oils is suitable for the list, I won't 
be posting my 3000+ word article that discusses my first ever flight in a
classic 1940s North American T6, with a 600 HP Pratt and Whitney,
the glory of hot metal, hot oil, air-cooling and how I got there and back
in the 911 and the glorious parallel between warplanes and Porsches. I won't
thrill you with the story of how I took the stick, flew it for an hour
and a half, and performed aerobatics, even though it was the first time
I had ever flown any plane or even been in anything smaller than a 747.

Only some parts are about Porsche, so tough shit I won't post it. It is not 
directly about Porsche, but it celebrates the thrill of hot engines, 
and power, and engineering and machines and the people who make and use them. And 
if those are not the things that Porschephiles is about then I'm a banana, but 
since it is not directly a Porsche related article, and <gasp> is about people 
and machines I shall censor it. 

Suffice to say I drove my 911 down to Shoreham and <xxxxxxx3000 words 
deletedxxxxx> drove it back again. There, and now back to the brake pad 
discussion, are Cool Carbons OK for the street, or can I just use some old 
ones from my VW? How do I buy a used Porsche? Why is my 944 vibrating
in a funny way at idle? why can't I get my pre `87 911 into first while
it is moving? etc. etc. ad infinitum....

There, that's done it, the netcops will be on to me now, YOU'LL NEVER TAKE
ME ALIVE COPPERS, TOP OF THE WORLD MA! HAHAHAHAHAHAHA!

Regards (and apologies to anyone that I might have offended)

ben

Date: Mon,  6 Mar 95 09:36:42 PST
From: Scott=D=Berry%MfgEng%GPID@banyan.BV.TEK.COM
Subject: 912 backfiring problem

I have just spent the last couple of weeks rebuilding the Weber 40 IDF carbs on 
my 66 912.  The problem I am having is no matter what I do I can't get the car 
to stop backfiring.  These were the first carbs I have ever rebuilt and my 
experience with carb adjustment is limited.  The backfiring was occurring 
before I rebuilt the carbs.  The backfiring is actually coming through the carb 
throats.  Occasionally it comes from the exhaust.  I have followed the 
recommendations for tuning that I have read in one of "The Maestro's" books and 
also in the Haynes Weber manual.  I do not have a air volume gauge so I have 
been using a piece of silicon tube as recommended in the Haynes manual.  One 
thing I found out is that my Webers do not have starter jets.  Both of the carbs 
have a cover plate where the starter jet assembly typically should be.  
(According to the Haynes manual).  The backfiring is worse when the engine is 
cold, but is always there.  Any info would be appreciated!

Scott
66 912

Date: 6 Mar 95 10:57:00 EST
From: GIBBS@vaxa.acdnj.itt.com
Subject: 944 grounding/AM radio noise

I'm looking to get a little more performance out of my '84 944.

No, not the motor, the AM radio.

I have a bi-amplified alpine CD player with electronic crossover, subwoofers, and 
equalizer (all alpine).  The problem is that the range on the AM radio sucks, due
to monster ignition noise.  It seems to be a grounding problem, as any change in the
electrical situation in the car will affect the amount and tone of the noise (i.e.
turn on lights, operate power window, etc. will change interference).  It has gotten
so bad that I have on occasion driven with the lights on in the daytime in order 
to be able to hear a station that I wanted to listen to.

The battery connections are clean and corrosion free.  So are the ground connections
to the firewall for the battery and engine (although they connect to different points).

I have heard that there is a "grounding mod" for early 944s that removes a ground
loop and creates a single point ground, but I do not have any details on it.

If anyone could shed some light on this I would appreciate it.  I am fairly literate
electrically, but grounding (especially on an automobile) has always seemed like a
black art to me.  I know that what looks right and sensible can often be exactly 
wrong, so I would welcome the advice of anyone who really understands the problem.

Ed Gibbs
gibbs@avionics.itt.com
'84 944, Guards Red, All Mine

Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 13:18:44 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@ilab.mitre.org>
Subject: Powerless 914


I got the following from my brother. Any helpful suggestions as to what the
trouble is likely to be?

{
I think I've got a buyer for the 914, if I can get it running properly.  The 
last time I had it out about 2 years ago  as I was pulling away from a light 
there was a sort of backfire, the engine note became more gutteral and it 
had no power but would rev freely.  No great clunkings, rattles, bangs,etc.  
Yesterday I got it started without too much difficulty (cleaned the plugs, a 
real bear to get two of them out but did not take the threads out with them, 
and a squirt of ether), but it didn't heal itself over the 2 yr vacation.  
Compression is 120 to 130 in 3 and 90 in the 4th cylinder.  Timing appears 
to be ok and advances with revs.  Replaced a couple of suspicious vacuum 
hoses.  Still no power.  Looking in the manual it implies that a faulty 
pressure (vacuum) sensor or a blocked exhaust can cause lack of power under 
load.  I've got an old sensor that I replaced when it became waterlogged.  
It has dried out over the ensuing 3 years.  Iopened it, and cleaned it up, 
so will try that first.   If that doesn't do it I'll take off the muffler 
and give it a try.  It will at least sound powerful.
}

I will forward any helpful suggestions back to him. Unfortunately, I don't
know what year it is, if that matters.

 -John White-
'84 928S

Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 12:57:49 -0600
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: 911 rebuild update EOF

  My 66 is now roadbound!! Instalation went great and the motor sounds
super! Unfortunatly the weather conditions here haven't been quite
as good. I have been working from 6:00 am till 10:00 pm for the past 10 days
to finish this project. Not too bad considering that on 2-24-95 my pistons
and cylindars were in a box:-) To those that shared their experiences and
advice I thank and salute you! To the one who told me to get a real mechanic
(you KNOW who you are) SHAME on you.  
 
 Another item I renewed was the bushings on the front and rear coupling
for the shifter. What an improvement. The bushing on the front shifter ball
was compleatly gone. It realy makes it nicer to drive and easier to find gears. 

Awaiting the sunshine....

Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1974 914 2.0 (for sale)
1966 911 cpe (DONE!!)

Yep....911 brakes on the front of a 914 are incredible.  I'd *NEVER* own
a 914 with the stock binders ever again.  I've been spoiled!!!  :-)

Since this is for an autox car, you must do as Stan and numerous others
have said in the past....

     Read The Rules!!!!

I don't think cross-drilled or slotted rotors, nevermind 911 upgrades, would
be allowed in SP class.  You'd go farther up the competetive ladder.  If you
don't mind losing all the time this is OK.....but it might frustrate you 
until

done exceptionally well in S class with his 914 - listen to what he may have
to say.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 11:47:07 -0800 (PST)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: Which performance street tires for 914?

Dear Chip,

My apologies to the group for the at-large posting:  for my own
reference I would want someone to correct me if I'm wrong.

Your situation is not that different from mine, with 6-inch wheels on
a '75 911 that also came with 185/70 as OE.

You are fine with 195/60 x 15, and there are a lot of tires still
available in that size, including (I think) the Comp T/A, or something
similar.  I would *think* (and I have no experience with this size, so
I'd like some confirmation) that the 195/65 would be OK also--indeed,
that they would come closest to 185/70.

On 6-inch rims on a 911, you can go to 205/60 for some brands (there
are variations despite the standard size), and to that size in general
if you have your front fender lips rolled.  With competition alignment
settings your rear camber is sufficient to prevent rubbing.

In short, the 195/60 would give you the widest choice, and you'd be
safe with them.  Some people use 195/50 for competition, but that
would be too low for the street, IMHO.

There is a speedometer error that goes along with a change in tire
size.  I had 195/60's on my 911 before I went to the 205's and it
showed at least 10% faster than I was driving.  With narrower rims the
difference will be less, probably something you could live with
without recalibration.

Hope this helps.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu
>I've decided to replace the 8 year old (!) 185VR70 Michelin XWX tires on my 
> 914, which has the Fuchs 15x5.5 alloy wheels. I would like to hear from 
> fellow 914 types what a good tire would be? I already called a BFG store, 
> they don't make the COMP/TA in a size I can use. This is a stock 914/2.0, no 
> wheel flares, and a street car only, though sometime I would like to get 
> some autocross instruction.
> 
> Suggestions, anyone?
> Chip Stratton
> Tulsa, Oklahoma

Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 13:17:34 -0800
From: "jim gregory" <jimg@porsche.trevose.sgi.com>
Subject: Re: brake proportioning valve

I (and several others--> this turned out to be a high interest subject at the
driver's ed events I have attended in last year or so) have had success in
replacing the proportioning valve on our non-ABS 944 turbos with one from a
928S4.

There have been several "technical" explanations, I can however offer some
subjective data. It DOES make a difference. I would suggest that if one changes
this valve or starts mixing brake pad compounds that this should be done with a
great deal of caution. Gradually see how it works. I have found it to be
particularly valuable in eliminating a tendancy for the nose to "dive" under
hard braking, thus making it easier to manage the balance of the car as you set
up for the corner. (my car is 90% used for track events). I have found a need
to mix the pad compounds to adapt to my driving style and skill level. Initial
tests with PFC 85 compound at all corners was starting to cause the REARS to
warp- I had to switch to PFC 83 fro the rear. What a change to only feel your
weight pressing against the harnesses instead of the whole car pitching
forward!

FYI, I saved this as one of the LAST changes I made to my brakes. I generally
follow the adage of "if it ain't broke don't fix it". Unless you are having
real braking problems there are other things to try first, ie: CoolBrake kit,
harder brake pad compounds, steel brake lines, alter your driving style, etc.

Then go for the gusto and upgrade your brakes to the Brembo 928S4 setup. Now
those are REAL stoppers!.

 -jim

Porschephiles #1221                         Tue Mar 7 02:00:05 CST 1995
Date: Mon,  6 Mar 95 12:44:18 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: What size is 914 rear axle nut?

| From:  <radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil>
|
|           I am attempting to remove the halfshafts from the 914 and I
|           need to buy a monster-sized  socket for the castle nut that
|           attaches the half-shaft to the hub.  Does anyone know off
|           hand what size it is?  (I think it's around 54mm, but I need
|           to know for sure before I go buy one.) Speaking of buying
|           one, does snap-on, mac, etc make one this size?  I know
|           Sears says they stop at 36mm.

If the 914 is the same as VW and my 944, then a 1-7/16" socket will
do the trick (this is from memory, I hope that is correct). I think this
socket size is only available in 3/4" drive. I used to use a 3/4 to 1/2"
reducer and my 1/2" breaker bar, but I recently bought a 3/4"
breaker bar. No more worrying about breaking the breaker bar!
BTW, you also need a 4 foot long piece of 1-1/2" iron pipe to use
as a "cheater" over the breaker bar. Leave the car on the ground,
emergency brakes on, and tires blocked before applying your
weight to the cheater pipe.

BTW, John Lupien wrote:
>    Where are you? I have the tool you need, and it isn't a socket!
> Tried for days to get those suckers off with a socket, impact wrench,
> etc. No luck. Paid $8 for a "Ubangi" from Johnny's Speed and Chrome,
> took the nut off in 2 minutes flat.

This sounds like the John Muir method: a large chisel and a hammer.
While that does work, the correct tools won't bugger up the nut. And using
a socket and handle, it is possible to estimate a tightening torque. If, for
example, it needs to be 300 ft-lbs and you weigh 200 lbs, then apply
all of your weight a foot and a half out on the handle when the handle
is horizontal. Like they say, close enough for government work!

    Eric

Date: 6 Mar 1995 13:30:33 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@Baynetworks.COM>
Subject: 993 prices, oil change

                      Subject:                              Time:  1:08 PM
  OFFICE MEMO         993 prices, oil change                Date:  3/6/95


From: "Jim Bauman  jbauman@btr.com" <jbauman@btr.btr.com>
Subject: Advice needed for NEW 911 purchase

A friend of mine (wish it was me!) is negotiating to buy a
1995 911 coupe with limited slip, sport seats, rear wiper,
17 inch wheels, metallic paint....

The dealer started off by offering him 8 percent of the sticker.
========
Jim,

Re 993 prices (and 993 oil changes)
I arranged a purchase through my credit union and a San Jose
dealer for a built-to-order 993.  I got a 2.5% discount.  While
I waited in frustration for this dealer to process the
paperwork and get the factory build going I called and visited
all the bay area dealers.  I ended up in Oakland at Negherbon
Auto where I saw the car optioned as I ordered it but in a
different color.  The dealer gave me 10% off sticker (he
referred to it as the "European delivery price"), and then
offered me my asking price on the 89 911 I was selling
privately.  And this was before Porsche raised prices 2%
recently.  Yes, demand is still high for these cars but if you
look around you can do pretty well.  8% is not bad at all
based on what I've heard.

BTW, I just changed the oil at 4k miles (actually my 911
guru mechanic did it).  Had to remove one body panel below
the rockers to access one of the drain plugs (you can no
longer get to this from the wheel well), the right rear
wheel, four miscellaneous undercarriage panels, and one
heater duct.  Only then can you get to *both* oil filters.
This guy clearly knew what he was doing, and got it done in
90 minutes.  I stayed with expensive Synthetic (Amsoil
racing oil), bought factory filters (and saved the box tops),
and took a couple of extras qts under the hood.  Total price?
$230!

The factoy recommends 15k oil changes.  Hmm...maybe I'll
stretch the interval to 6k.

Regards,
Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara)
95 993 coupe, guards red
85 535i, everyday grey
PCA# 91049838

Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 16:02:56 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: 914 muffler (primary?) replacement question

>  Lost quite a bit of my primary muffler's "muffling" ability yesterday...
>  haven't had a chance to crawl under and confirm, but I believe it's just
>  the primary and not secondary ('75 914 2.0).  So, should I just look to
>  replace that (have a coupla' catalogs open), or while I'm at it, replace
>  the whole thing?  If so, it looks like I can get a Bursch (complete) for
>  less $$ than just ordering a primary (or secondary)...  main concern is
>  getting most "bang for the buck " (i.e., value).  All suggestions
>  welcome, and thanks again for everyone's help.

Another option is to switch to an earlier year's exhaust system. The 1975 
used a different system to allow use ofa catalytic converter for California. 
The non-California cars use a "connexion" tube in place of the CC. (The 
misspelling is from Porsche's "914 Service and Training Information, 
Model 75". I recommend picking it up from your local dealer - I guarantee 
it'll be a special order,  however the price is a scant $1.00! Part number is: 
"WKD 454 321". It shows everything that changed for the 1975 model year 
914.)
ANYways... Someone who owned my car before me replaced the exhaust 
with the '73-'74 style, which is a bit simpler, and perhaps more 
free-flowing?
BTW, I must give a quick plug to German Parts & Restoration here - I 
bought the '75 style, only to find that I had the earlier style. The box had 
gotten somewhat mangled on the way in, so I had to rebox it to ship it back 
 - they sent me a new one with no problems, no complaints, no charges, 
nothing. I've been very happy with the various dealing I've had with them 
and recommend 'em highly.

> -Greg, enjoying the fact that his car's exhaust noise
>  is setting off car alarms, but is hoping it doesn't last TOO long...

I can do that with mine, but I AM going to put new heat exhangers on it 
before spring! (I drove it most of last summer with the exchangers not 
quite reaching my nice new muffler - in other words, unmuffled. Got a 
couple pull-overs, but the muffler usually got me off with a warning.) I'm 
supposedly gonna buy a set of unused SS heat exchangers from an 
acquitance, unless someone on here has a nice set they want to let go 
cheap? '73-'74 style?

Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 16:16:22 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: Which performance street tires for 914?

>I've decided to replace the 8 year old (!) 185VR70 Michelin XWX tires on my 
>914, which has the Fuchs 15x5.5 alloy wheels. I would like to hear from 
>fellow 914 types what a good tire would be? I already called a BFG store, 
>they don't make the COMP/TA in a size I can use. This is a stock 914/2.0, no 
>wheel flares, and a street car only, though sometime I would like to get 
>some autocross instruction.

I asked the same question not a week ago, methinks. I have 195/50/15s on my 
car now, and they seem to perform very well (despite being Phoenix 
Stahlflexes, made in the late '70s/early '80s), and after some deliberation and 
feedback, have decided to go with Dr914's suggestion of 205/55/15s... I hadn't 
thought about 55-series before, but it should give me some more height and 
put more rubber on the road, yet still be low-profile enough for real 
performance. Tire of choice is, of course, the BF Goodrich Comp T/A 3 
unidirection ZR tire.

I've heard different results from 205/60/15s, some people say they rub, some 
say they don't, I think it depends upon your wheel choice - the alloys seem to 
have a lot more offset than the steel ones. (I have the stock steel wheels, and 
they're well into the wheelwell. Not the look I like, but no danger of rubbing!)

So, for what it's worth, I'd going with Comp T/A ZR 205/55/ZR15 tires. (I hate 
the idea of putting anything less than ultra-high-performance tires on my 
summer sports car! :)

Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 19:09:04 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 944TurboS brake proportio...

On Sun, 5 Mar 1995 Jerry944T@aol.com wrote:

> Don,
> I am investigating that very problem as we speak. It is apparent that the
> rear brakes are along for the ride. Consider that I, and probably you, wear
> out 3 or 4 front brakes for every set of rears. This is in racing situations,
> I can't speak for the street.

Just a thought about why cars are set up with the fronts doing most of 
the work.

If you have ideal brake balance, and all 4 wheels lock at the same 
instance, then the ABS cannot tell that the wheels have locked, it 
assumes all 4 wheels stopped - car is stopped.

personally I would prefer the ABS to do it's job, than lock all four
wheels. I have seen it happen, its quite scarey, I had to break quite hard
to avoid a prang, I looked in the rear mirror to see an ABS equiped UK
ford granada smoking all 4 tyres as he headed for my rear, luckily I was
able to lift the brakes and drive out of his path.

Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 20:02:39 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: proportioning valve 951

Thank you everyone who related experiences with the 951 brake proportioning
valve. It seems that the consensus is that the valve from a 928S4 is the one
to use for racing applications. 
It also seems that non ABS drivers need to take this step with a great deal
of caution as the ABS acts as a great safety valve.(pun?)
What I need now is the part number for that prop valve.
(Sorry Kevin I know you sent it but I deleted your post in my haste to delete
all the trash that's been showing up lately).
As for the fellow who pointed out the 99% of your braking does not involve
the ABS remember that we are discussing racing (track) situations. In this
environment the ABS comes into play at almost every corner. Especially if you
are late braking. The problem is that the ABS is multichannel so even though
the fronts are evoking the ABS it doesn't mean that the rears are at max
grab. I know that once I feel the ABS activating I don't bother pushing the
pedal any harder and this is probably the reason the rears are not being used
as much as they could.
Threshold braking is the way to go and the ABS certainly is a great crutch.
My personal tests show that my stopping distances are higher with the ABS
disconnected no matter how good a job I am doing with non ABS threshold
braking. Anyone concur?

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
7:58 pm

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 95 09:31:19 +1100
From: michael@sydney.idtours.com.au (Michael Mannington)

unsubscribe Michael Mannington

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 20:24:14 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944TurboS brake proportio...

Pete writes..
>Just a thought about why cars are set up with the fronts doing most >of the
work.
>If you have ideal brake balance, and all 4 wheels lock at the same 
>instance, then the ABS cannot tell that the wheels have locked, it 
>assumes all 4 wheels stopped - car is stopped.

Pete,
This can't happen with multi channel ABS since the coefficient of friction at
all wheels is never going to be the same no matter how well balanced the car
or the system. Hence one wheel will always be more prone to lockup no matter
which braking system is involved. If your theory is correct then even with a
prop valve in place if you STAND on the brakes hard enough all will tend to
lock up. I've tried this and no matter what I do the ABS always works
perfectly

Regards,

Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 20:25:52 -0500
From: PKgolf@aol.com
Subject: Finally

I posted a message about a a possible '78 911SC  targa purchase a couple of
weeks ago.  I am happy to say that the car is mine and I couldn't be
happier<g>.  My sincere thanks to all who responded with helpful and
encouraging words.  Special thanks to x400459 for his especially thorough and
practical advices, I'm glad he stuck around inspite of his initial misgivings
about the porschephile list.  

I've already noticed that people react differently to Porsches than other
cars I've owned.  For the most part they are pleasant but some are bizzare.  

Ture story without embellishments:  The day after I bought the car, a buddy
who was in the market for a new car wanted to go price some cars.  We drove
to the local auto mall in my new baby (looks as good as the day it was
bought, by the way, no kidding <g>) and as our last stop, we stopped at the
BMW dealer.  It was getting late and we wanted to make a quick stop to check
out the M3.  As we drove into the lot, we were met by a rather aggressive
saleslady who seemed eager to get us into a car for a test drive.  The M3 was
in the showroom but they had a 540 6 speed sitting on the lot and my friend
coudn't refuse a test drive.  We both drove the car and the car was solid and
we were impressed.  However, the nice saleslady had something to prove,
perhaps us driving into the lot in the Porsche had something to do with it.
 She got behind this 55k dollar machine and said something to the effect "let
me show you what this baby can do" and proceeded to go berserk.  She took us
back to the back roads where we had just finished our test drive and started
taking corners at almost twice the speed that a reasonable persons like
myself had taken just a few minutes ago.  Inevitably she lost control and
slid off the road and slammed us into a telephone pole, totalling the car and
scaring the beejuice out of my friend and me as well as herself.  There's a
bit more to the story but suffice to say that I found out very quickly how
strongly people can react to a pcar.

Cheers

Paul
'78 911 SC targa (guards red)
couple of other uh.... who cares cars.

    Is anyone out there a Porsche art collector?  If so, I recently bought a
    piece that I have to tell others about.

    I bought a wire shoulette of a 962, made by Mike Wessner of Diversified
    Fabricators.  This is a mighty fine piece, and is quite happy on the wall
    over my desk.

    I saw his C2/C4, and it is just as fine.  He apparently also makes a 356
    and 550 Spyder.  Each is signed, numbered and limited to 50.  He will also
    paint it any color (my is satin black, and looks quite spectacular).

    Mike will be advertising in the Pano next month.  For those interested,
    his number is (215) 598-8002.

    He will also probably make a one off car for those interested in other
    models.

Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 22:28:34 -0600
From: eley@sccsi.com (Bill Eley)
Subject: My first driving event - the results

I've completed my first driving event at Texas World Speedway this weekend.  
It was a PCA Driver Education event.  I appreciate everyone's advice - all 
of it came in handy!

My impressions:

There is no substitute for a good instructor.  I was fortunate enough to try 
three different ones (including our own Scott Jessen - thanks Scott!), and 
they were all *extremely* helpful.  There is *no* way I could have driven 
that track correctly without good instruction.  You may think you can 
intuitively pick where the line should be on a new track, but you can't.

Don't be afraid to ask questions.  A lot of people at the track are busy 
running the event, or concentrating on their own driving.  Information is 
not always volunteered (except during instruction).  

Stay out of the way of macho Corvette and Mustang drivers.

The 968 is an incredible car.  It's so easy to drive.  It seemed to correct 
my mistakes for me (not that I made any!).  The car was a lot less agitated 
by the drive than I was.

Yes, I'm hooked.  No, I can't afford the tires or the wear and tear to do 
this often.  No, I don't know what I'll do about it.  Yes, I will do it again.

Bill Eley
'95 968

wheels painted or powder coated.  This may sound silly, but I sprayed
my phone dials with Rustoleum from the local hardware store about a
year ago.  They came out absolutely beautiful, and have stayed that
way.  Many other P-car people (and others) have commented on how much
better they look than stock.

Date: Mon, 6 Mar 1995 23:00:34 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: My first driving event - the results

Glad you enjoyed it!!! That first track day is alwasy the toughest.

Now, do the math: 

you drove *how many* miles on the track?? 100? *MAYBE*?? 

Let's then be really hard on ourselves and say that it was 3x tougher 
on the car than "street traffic" -- despite the fact that it's just not 
true and track miles *MAY* be better due to no stop and go. OK, great --
you penalize the life of the car by what? 300 miles, tops?

You are, however, correct on tire wear. I found that on my 911, doing
4 track days a year *PLUS* about a dozen autoxes cost me maybe 3000 
miles in tire life. Let's say it's a 50/50 deal, half the wear is due to
track days. At $768 a set, and about 15k miles to the set,
that was what? about $75 in tire wear. Which is what? 3.5 autox 
entry fees, 0.75 track day entry fees, etc.

I think you see the point I'm trying to make here...

Go to the track. DO NOT pass Go. Do not spend $200 on unnecessary 
go-fast crap. Go directly to the track...

Stan

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 11:20:55 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 944TurboS brake proportio...

On Mon, 6 Mar 1995 Jerry944T@aol.com wrote: 
> Pete, 
> 
>This can't happen with multi channel ABS since the coefficient of friction
>at all wheels is never going to be the same no matter how well balanced
>the car or the system. Hence one wheel will always be more prone to
>lockup no matter which braking system is involved. If your theory is
>correct then even with a prop valve in place if you STAND on the brakes
>hard enough all will tend to lock up. I've tried this and no matter what
>I do the ABS always works perfectly 

Believe we I have seen it happen, and this was on a dry road, the car
behind we was completely enveloped in tyre smoke - all 4 wheels locked!!
Now this car had a lot less rubber than a 944T, on a dry road it is 
pretty well impossible to lock all 4 wheels on a 944 without ABS - just 
try standing on the brakes in the wet!!

The Fords use the Bosch ABS, so it is probably very similar to that 
fitted to our Porsches.

If you fit a larger slave cylinder on the back wheels, then you will tend 
to get the backs locking later, ie close to the point where the fronts 
lock, now this isn't an instantaneous thing, if it was there would be no 
problem. 

From my observations and investigations of the behaviour of the ABS system
on my wifes Ford, the cycle rate of the system is around 8 cycles per sec,
ie when a wheel locks, it is switched in and out at around 8 times per
sec.

The wheel sensors obviously have some sort of averaging electronics built 
in, this is probably done so that the ABS doesnt cut in if for example a 
wheel gets airborne for a few millisecs (pot hole etc) during that few 
msecs, all 4 wheels can and occasionally do lock. I can certainly manage 
it in the wet in my wifes car.

When you brake hard and lock all the wheels, as I stated yesterday, when 
all 4 wheels are locked, the abs thinks the car is at rest!!

Brake bias to the front is a certain way to overcome the problem of 4 
wheel lock, I would have thought that porsche would have studied this 
problem in some detail, and if they fit a certain size of slave 
cylinders, they probably have done the sums correctly. There are lots of 
things to put into the equation, number of passengers, how much fuel in 
the tank, size and make of the tyres and road surface condition.

Of course you may be absolutely correct in what you say - and you cannot 
lock all 4 wheels, its your dime - and your fender, front suspension and 
insurance premeium!!!



+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 11:47:40 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 944 grounding/AM radio noise

The important ground connection is the one from the radio case to ground, 
the co-ax shield should also be grounded at the radio, ie make sure it is 
plugged fully home into the radio (hope you have 18 inch fingers )

Normally the antenna body is also earthed to the bodywork on stick 
arials, but it is a matter of dispute whether this is really desireable, 
because you now have a wire from the radio to car body, and this can pick 
up induced engine noise. In digital electronic systems such as telephone 
exchanges, it is conventional to connect only one end of a screen wire to 
earth.

The other possible noise source is the 12v supply, you can try fitting 
one of the many available noise filters. In fact from your description 
this sounds like the probable cause - arcing alternator brushes perhaps.

If you think you have problems, try getting a radio to work in a GRP car 

Peter Diffey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 08:17:47 -0500 (EST)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: GM flaming!

On Mon, 6 Mar 1995, Wilson Luther wrote:

Well, we've not had one GM make it to 150,000 (even with engine rebuilds 
and all) and even the current (and last of our) GM product is giving 
signs of death at 135,000 miles... now, before you say, that's a lot for 
an engine, it's been only 10,000 miles since rebuild (of the whole 
engine, transmission, and all), and never has one single electical 
component worked right (excepting those we have replaced ourselves, like 
windshield washer pump, air conditioner, and power window switches... oh 
and the power windows for that matter!) Never once has GM even remotely 
offered us any help in these areas after hours of nagging them...

Now, for you people who love Porsche-talk.... The Porsche (a 73) has gone 
140,000 miles, and yet, it still goes strong and could easily be used the 
way it was for its first year (where it put 50k miles on as a daily driver)

UAW (doing it their own damn way, no matter what the books say) or 
Stuttgart (following exactly the technical specs of EVERYTHING)... I'll 
take the Porsche any day...
 -Derek

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 09:08:20 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 brakes. upgrade/replacement questions


Dear Josh and Nate and all,

To get great 914 brakes and avoid expense, assuming you have good equipment,
upgrade in the following progression:

     1. Carbon Kevlar brakes pads:  higher coefficient of friction, great
braking increase
     2. 19mm master cylinder:  firmer pedal, less travel, more foot pressure
required
     3. Stainless steel brake lines:  less restrictive (than old deposited
lines), less flex, more positive pedal feel
     4. larger 911T front calipers:  larger piston for better grip, lightens
the feel of the 19mm master cylinder.
     
As one of the cross drilling companies told me, drilled rotors are hype
except in extreme racing conditions. Vent cool air on your rotors before
drilling them. "We drill the rotors because they make us good money."

George Hussey


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 09:08:09 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Looking for original Riviera wheel


Dear Richard,

<I'm looking to buy one original Riviera wheel for a 914.  I've looked 
<everywhere and have been unable to locate anything but the imitation wheels.
I 
<would appreciate any help I could get in tracking down one of these wheels.


Riviera wheels are junk and there is no such thing as an original. They were
all cheap imitations.

Originally intended to fit a VW Bug, these wheels have an offset towards the
outside (since Bugs have fenders that hang on to the body). When fitted to a
914, they stick out so far that the widest tire becomes only a 195x60x15 and
even this tire rubs one fender lip. Throw these wheels away and buy a set of
factory Fuchs for your car or at least a set of the cheap American Eagle
Fuchs reproduction wheels.

However, if you are on a budget and have broken one of you currently
installed Rivieras, they are available in three varieties:
     5" 3-1/8" center hole (used)
     5-1/2" 3-1/8" center hole (used), your choice!
     5-1/2" 2-1/2" center hole (new or used)

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 09:08:46 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 2.4 engine for a 914?


<I might have a chance to get my hands on a 2.4 liter engine from a '73 911T.
<This engine would be installed in my 914 in place of the tired 1.8L
currently
<pushing it around.  The engine is supposed to have the original injection
system
<and is supposed to have updated chain tensioners.  I have a couple questions
<to ask the 911 folks:

<Is the '73 2.4 "T" mechanically injected or does it use the CIS?
<Any problem areas to be aware of with this engine?
<What is a typical life expectancy of this engine?

<I think this engine is already out of the car.  Are there any tests I can do
at this
<point to determine the general health of the engine before buying it?  About
all I
<can think of might be to hook a battery up to the starter and perform a
<compression test.  Is this safe to do on an engine not bolted down?  Come to
<think of it, it probably won't even have oil in it.  Nevermind.  Other
ideas?


Dear Pete,

Most "73 911T engines had mechanical fuel injectin while 1973-1/2 USA 911Ts
had CIS injection. Both had 140 HP, but the CIS car had 8.0:1 compression
while the mechanically injected car was 7.5:1. The mechanically injected car
could be recognized by its roundish six fuel-lined connected fuel distributor
head and rectangular air cleaner cover as well as its ribbed tall mounted air
intake boot. Mechanical injection had a left front mounted belt driven fuel
injection pump and a massive left to right connected air filter with an
intake snout attached. Both engines will work well in a 914. The CIS engine
will need the intake boot modified to clear the rear engine lid latch
receiver while the mechanically injected engine needs the fuel pump changed
and a tube welded onto the heat exchanger chamber to provide hot air to the
injection pump for warmup.

The best way to check the engine is with a leakdown check (cylinder
differential pressure test). This test will tell you the condition of the
valves, head gaskets and piston rings. Also change the oil and check the sump
screen for debris.

George Hussey

Date: 7 Mar 95 09:05:00 EST
From: "LOGISX::GIBBS" <GIBBS%LOGISX.decnet@vaxa.acdnj.itt.com>
Subject: Flaming George

This is sort of non-P car content, so I apologize in advance to anyone who's mail
reader is overloaded, but I just couldn't let it pass.

The other day someone flamed George Buselinck for selling a 944 chip to a friend, 
even though George apparently didn't pay for the chip, but got it through his 
contacts in the industry.  Since no one else has leapt to George's defense, I will.

It seems to me that George does this for a living, and has every right to charge
a fair market price for anything that he disposes of.  This is how he puts food 
on his family's table folks!

Besides - If he got the chip through contacts, then he performed work (i.e. phone
calls, lunches, etc.) in exchange for the chip, and he deserves to be paid for that 
work.  He may have spent many times the value of the chip to cultivate the relation-
ship that got him the chip.

IMHO, it would have been wrong for his friend to expect to get the chip for free,
and if he is a friend, I'm sure he never asked.  His friend just probably assumed 
that he would pay fair market value, and I'm sure that's what he paid.  

George contributes his knowledge and experience to this list every day,and doesn't 
charge a cent for it (although he does get some well deserved good will and free 
advertising).

Just my $.02

Ed Gibbs
gibbs@avionics.itt.com
'84 944, Guards Red, All Mine!

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 10:05:01 -0500
From: Andre Rotchel <lmcanro@LMC.Ericsson.SE>
Subject: Real cause of Senna's accident UNCOVERED


Hi,

the real cause of Senna's accident has been uncovered
according to an Italian racing magazine:

The steering column had been shortened to accomodate 
Senna's driving position. The soldering was not thick 
enough to withstand the rigorous conditions of the race 
and just gave away on the curve, leaving Senna with a useless
steering wheel in his hand. That is why, the car went straight
off the track as if there was no one steering it.

There was no driver error. Only not enough soldering.

Regards,
Andre Rotchel.

   From: porschephiles-request
   To: porschephiles
   Subject: Real cause of Senna's accident UNCOVERED
   Date: Tuesday, March 7, 1995 10:05AM


   Hi,

   the real cause of Senna's accident has been uncovered
   according to an Italian racing magazine:

   The steering column had been shortened to accomodate
   Senna's driving position. The soldering was not thick
   enough to withstand the rigorous conditions of the race
   and just gave away on the curve, leaving Senna with a useless
   steering wheel in his hand. That is why, the car went straight
   off the track as if there was no one steering it.

   There was no driver error. Only not enough soldering.

   Regards,
   Andre Rotchel.

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 95 11:26:34 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: RE: 914 Hub nut (ubangi)

Robert, William, and Porsche nuts all over the world...

> > > i have never had a problem with a rear axle nut, but just out of
> > > curiosity what the hell is a ubangi, and what the number to get one?
> > 
> > It's a 1/2" thick steel plate with a hex hole in it, and a 1/2" socket
> > drive hole, and some flats to hit with a sledge hammer. It looks like this:
> > 
> > 
> > 
> >                   ____________
> > ___________      /            \
> > |          \    /    ____      \
> > |   ____    \__/    /    \      \
> > |   |   |          /      \      \
> > |   |___|    __    \      /      /
> > |           /  \    \____/      /
> > |__________/    \              /
> >                  \____________/
> > 
> > 
> > You put the hex hole over the hub nut, the 1/2" drive breaker bar into the
> > 1/2" square hole, stand on the breaker bar, and hit the flat of the part
> > the square hole is in with a sledgehammer. The nut turns.
> > 
> > As far as a phone number is concerned, I'll have to look it up.
> > Send me a reminder if you haven't heard by Wednesday.

I looked it up - Johnny's Speed & Chrome: 1-800-222-8982

They do mostly Bug stuff, but a lot of it works for Porsches.

GM/Chevrolet Astro van has been pulling my 914 race car and trailer (yes,
over 4500 pounds) for over four years now.  Just this weekend on the way
back to the San Francisco area from the SCCA San Diego National Tour the
speedo rolled over to 250,000 miles.  Never a problem if the engine is
taken care of properly.  I've replaced the a/c compressor and water pump
once each and most recently the fuel pump.  Other than frequent oil and
oil filter changes (3K miles) and the tranny oil, filter change (every
season) and other regular maintenance all runs fine.  And this vehicle is
used every day in my contracting business.  I have noticed a slight drop
in pulling power up some of the grades so instead of doing 50 I know have
to be happy at 40.  I have installed a tranny cooler to help with the 
towing.  I just think it helps to maintain the vehicle we all drive 
wether it's a Porsche or a GM/Chevrolet product.

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 08:22:36 -0800
From: gblanche@qntm.com
Subject: 944 AM radio reception and engine noise

>RE: Engine noise on the AM radio, or stereo in general

I'll post this for the benefit of the entire group.  I have answered 
this questions privately a couple of times already so this time it goes 
out to all:

Unless the engine noise just appeared after replacing spark plug wires 
or a coil or something engine related, the odds are very good that the 
problem is in the stereo installation.  It's sort of a good news/bad 
news scenario.  The good news is that it can be fixed, the bad news is 
that there's no "quick fix".  First a quick backgrounder...

Your car has enormous amounts of wire running through it, most of those 
wires are connected to the + side of the battery, the grounding for 
these circuits is handled by the metal chassis of the car.  That 
explains why there is a big braided strap from the - side of your 
battery directly to the chassis on your car.  By doing it this way, the 
manufacturer is spared the trouble of running a seperate ground wire 
back to the negative post of the battery for each circuit....saves wire, 
saves money, saves weight.  This is the way virtually every car on the 
road is built.  The problem with it is that the path that the 
electricity takes through your car to get back to the battery is not 
predictable.  It will follow the "least resistive" path and this path 
will vary depending on what other accessories happen to be turned on 
(headlights, brake lights, fans, etc.)  For each ground path, there is 
an electrical field and that can induce noise into things like the RCA 
cables of a stereo system.  When this tiny electrical noise is fed 
through an amplifier, it becomes audible as "engine noise".

There are a few things you can do to help reduce the chances of getting 
inducted noise in your stereo.

1.  Make sure that when the stereo is installed, that the person keeps 
the power wires for amplifiers as far away from the signal wires (RCA 
cables) as possible.  A typical power wire puts out 14.4V whereas the 
RCA cables are sending mere millivolts of power.  It is very easy to 
induce noise into an RCA cable because the original signal is so much 
smaller.

2.  Make sure that the grounds from all the various components are tied 
to a single point on the car's chassis.  DO NOT RUN THESE GROUNDS TO THE 
NEGATIVE BATTERY POST!  The battery post is the single noisiest 
grounding point in any car, due to alternator "ripple" when the engine 
is running.  Many novices make this mistake.  Doing it the right way 
actually takes less time and wire.  Find a convenient place, get all of 
your wires consolidated into a "ring-type" connector, then use a grinder 
or sandpaper to clean the chassis to bare, shiny metal.  Secure your 
grounds to the chassis using a bolt with star washers to keep it tight.  
Then spray the area with paint or something waterproof to keep moisture 
out of your connection.  This will prevent an eventual problem with bad 
grounding.  Remember that there are many paths the electricity will take 
through your chassis to get back to the battery.  You may not find the 
perfect grounding spot on your first try.  Sometimes finding a "clean" 
spot takes a couple tries.  Once you think you have one, be sure to run 
the engine, turn on the headlights, push the brake pedal, etc. to check 
for noise or "pops" through the stereo.  This will help you determine if 
you've selected a good grounding point.

3.  Use components with high undistorted output voltage.  This one's 
tougher, especially if you already have equipment that you're not 
willing to replace.  High voltage output means that you will be sending 
a higher voltage signal through your RCA wires which will be much less 
suseptible to picking up inducted noise.  Most consumer grade decks put 
out maybe 1 volt of output.  There are decks however that put out 3 to 4 
volts, and the difference in clarity is amazing!  Keep in mind that the 
more power you can send from the "front-end" of your system, the less 
"gain" you'll need to use on your amplifiers.  This will make a dramatic  
difference in the amount of engine noise you hear.


The lesson in all of this is to take the time to carefully plan the 
selection of your components, and have a good grasp of the factors that 
are working against you in the car environment.  If this is beyond what 
you want to tackle yourself, find a professional to help you.  This 
response has gotten really long, but there's quite a bit more to say on 
the topic.  If people are interested I can answer more here or you can 
ask me questions off-line.  I'll be doing a complete high-end system in 
a 911 soon, (I still need the car) so I'd be happy to explain the steps 
I go through during that installation.


Greg Blanchette
gblanche@qntm.com

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 10:23:42 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 2.4 engine for a 914?

> Both engines will work well in a 914. The CIS engine
> will need the intake boot modified to clear the rear engine lid latch
> receiver while the mechanically injected engine needs the fuel pump changed
> and a tube welded onto the heat exchanger chamber to provide hot air to the
> injection pump for warmup.

You also need to cut access hatches so you can set the injection. On
the MFI, it's in the seat-back firewall; on the CIS, it's in the trunk.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 10:14:45 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 brakes. upgrade/replacement questions

"I've said this before, I'll said it again: vendors are predictable,
100%." 

	From "Hanks Hears a Hype", by Dr. Stan

Time to debunk the latest round of horse puckey....

> To get great 914 brakes and avoid expense, assuming you have good equipment,
> upgrade in the following progression:

By any reasonable standard at all, none of these "avoid expense" relative
to stock parts correctly applied.

>      1. Carbon Kevlar brakes pads:  higher coefficient of friction, great
> braking increase

Cool Carbon pads, or equivalent, are just about a requirement for full-time
track cars. If you pick the wrong compound, or if you don't follow the
break-in proceedure to the exact letter, they are a disaster waiting to
happen on the street. I use street pads on the street on all of my cars.

>      2. 19mm master cylinder:  firmer pedal, less travel, more foot pressure
> required

If you need a master cylinder, it's foolish not to make this upgrade. Unless
you run in a class where it matters. Like any of the stock classes. Then
it's another of those silly upgrades that has you running with the Big Boys.
Know what your terminal application is before you buy *ANYTHING*.

>      3. Stainless steel brake lines:  less restrictive (than old deposited
> lines), less flex, more positive pedal feel

This is just plain stupid and dangerous. You use braided lines on race cars
where you need the greater strength and where everything is made of braided
line anyway. You take them off and throw them away at the end of the  season.
EVERY YEAR. If you do much endurance racing, you do it sooner.

Why? The inner hose abrades on the braided cover. You can't see it. Then,
typically when you most need it, the line blows out *FROM THE INSIDE* due
to overpressure on the weakened spot. Even the full time major league racers
are starting to re-think this one, reasoning being that if you are just 
going to throw the damned things away anyway, why not use something that you
can actually inspect for problems....

And I haven't even begun to talk about the rash of badly assembled units that
popped up a few years ago where the ends would pull off the hose....

>      4. larger 911T front calipers:  larger piston for better grip, lightens
> the feel of the 19mm master cylinder.

Yeah, if you want to spend a few $K.... Figure $650-$1k for the 911 front
end (and it really doesn't matter which one). Figure another few $x00 to
fix the rear end so it now has 5-lug wheels to keep you from looking 
stupid. Figure at least $150 a wheel for some 15x6 911 wheels. Sure, cheap,
effective. My ass. 

And you don't even want to contemplate what that does to you, class-wise,
if you drive the car competitively.

> As one of the cross drilling companies told me, drilled rotors are hype
> except in extreme racing conditions. Vent cool air on your rotors before
> drilling them. "We drill the rotors because they make us good money."

Truth!!

But here's the other half: for real racing applications, you use rotors with
holes cast into the rotors. If you drill the rotors, you break the crystalline
structure of the metal and induce stress risers; if you cast the holes in,
you get lighter rotors, some cooling function, and all that jazz. So if
you are in the racing biz, you probably already know this, if you aren't
you don't need the holed rotors anyway. Needless to say, the drilled rotors
are unsafe, will *break* and can hurt you as a result.


Moral:  Just because something is good for racing doesn't mean *ANYTHING*
        about how good it is for *YOUR* car on the street. Magazines are
	in business to sell copies so they can sell advertising. You 
	simply *CAN* *NOT* believe everything you read in them. Even Pano.
Stan

------------------------------

>>think
>>its a 73 or 74 model.

>>W.P. Costello
>>
>>
>There are no factory 914-6's in 73/74

Correct, but not only that, there was only one size engine used on fatory
914/6s. A 2.0L six was the only engine used on the factory sixes.
I don't know the proper numbers as far as engine cases and all, but serial
numbers for all 914/6s should start with 914xxx...

Date: Tue, 07 Mar 1995 13:03:00 -0500 (EST)
From: PAUL SOUZA 202-260-6061 <SOUZA.PAUL@epamail.epa.gov>
Subject: frozen pilot bearing


          Hi all,
          
          A friend, who is without access to the net, purchased an 83 944 
          which needed much head work, among other things.  The car has 
          about 120,000 on the odo.  After about 10 months of work on it, 
          we finally got it running 2 weeks ago (lack of time and money to 
          get it done faster, as well as many mistakes- wish I had 
          subscribed to the list when we started).  The motor runs great.  
          Now here is the problem:   
          
          The car was on jacks the whole time, and last weekend we took it 
          off, to test drive the car.  When the ignition is off, the trans 
          has no problem getting into gear, but once the car is started, it 
          will not go in gear.  When started in 1st, the car lurches 
          forward, even with the clutch depressed.  We bled the clutch line 
          (found lots of air n nasty stuff...), the clutch feels better, 
          but still does not engage.  I called the local Porsche dealer and 
          they said that, because the car was inactive for a long time, the 
          pilot bearing had frozen (rusted) to the input shaft, and that 
          this happens often in areas of high humidity (like Washington, 
          DC).  
          Their solution is this:  find a spot, like a deserted parking 
          lot, start the car and warm it up.  Then shut it off, put it in 
          1st, start it again and accelerate hard and jam it into 2nd!  
          They say that they have a 95% success rate in unfreezing the 
          bearing that way.  Has anyone had a similar experience?  Does 
          this actually work?  We'd like to get another opinion before we 
          try this.  We not against taking the trans off, just don't have 
          the funds for a new clutch, etc right now.
          
          TIA
          Paul Souza
          '57 356A
          
           


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 13:22:13 -0600 (CST)
From: Menelaos Karamichalis <mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu>
Subject: Re: Stickers and Racing

In response to the message by Darren Foo:
Buy some of the magnetic material you see on the back of refridgerator 
magnets (the brown stuff).  Put your stickers on the magnetic stuff.  
Then put the magnets on your car.  Even better, apply a couple of coats 
of wax over the area where the stickers/magnets will be.  Thus you will 
be able to remove the stickers easily and will not scratch (or it will be 
harder to scratch) the paint with the magnets.  You could put a bit of 
tape that leaves very little residue when removed on the leading edge of 
the stickers/magnets if you experience ...lift!  Even Scotch tape may be 
adequate.  (I have not needed the tape yet).

'85 Burgundy Ice Mazda 626LX			mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu
'87 Guard's Red Porsche 944S
'93 Red-White Miyata Five-12
