Date: Tue, 07 Mar 95 14:23:41 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: frozen pilot bearing

> 
>           Hi all,
>           
>           A friend, who is without access to the net, purchased an 83 944 
>           which needed much head work, among other things.  The car has 
>           about 120,000 on the odo.  After about 10 months of work on it, 
>           we finally got it running 2 weeks ago (lack of time and money to 
>           get it done faster, as well as many mistakes- wish I had 
>           subscribed to the list when we started).  The motor runs great.  
>           Now here is the problem:   
>           
>           The car was on jacks the whole time, and last weekend we took it 
>           off, to test drive the car.  When the ignition is off, the trans 
>           has no problem getting into gear, but once the car is started, it 
>           will not go in gear.  When started in 1st, the car lurches 
>           forward, even with the clutch depressed.  We bled the clutch line 
>           (found lots of air n nasty stuff...), the clutch feels better, 
>           but still does not engage.  I called the local Porsche dealer and 
>           they said that, because the car was inactive for a long time, the 
>           pilot bearing had frozen (rusted) to the input shaft, and that 
>           this happens often in areas of high humidity (like Washington, 
>           DC).  

Note that the pilot bearing is separated from the input shaft by the torque 
tube and drive shaft...  I would think that the pilot bearing itself is 
seized.....

>           Their solution is this:  find a spot, like a deserted parking 
>           lot, start the car and warm it up.  Then shut it off, put it in 
>           1st, start it again and accelerate hard and jam it into 2nd!  

I wouldn't jam it into 2nd, but rather depress the clutch and stand on the
brakes at the same time.  If it doesn't kill the motor, it might just work.
Jamming it into 2nd will just crash the gears...


>           They say that they have a 95% success rate in unfreezing the 
>           bearing that way.  Has anyone had a similar experience?  Does 

Well, a 95% success rate also implies a 5% failure rate.  If the failure
rate includes hitting something or breaking a gearbox, then the odds are not
quite in your favor.  The proper way to fix it is to disassemble the drive
line and figure out what the problem is.

New pilot bearings only cost about $20. Clutch parts are fairly expensive,
but PAR automotive in Yonkers is advertising a complete set for $440. I'll
sell you used, but serviceable parts for much less than that...

(Keep in mind I got them for free, but after all, I'm a Porsche-owning
capitalist these days... :-)  )

>           this actually work?  We'd like to get another opinion before we 
>           try this.  We not against taking the trans off, just don't have 
>           the funds for a new clutch, etc right now.
>           

Good luck, GB
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 11:59:04 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: BUYING VERY LIMITED-EDITION FROM DEALER - NEED ADVICE

I've never bought a new car before, but it looks like I will shortly.  I
would appreciate any advice netters have on negotiating a price on a very
limited-edition car ...

The car in question is the BMW M3 Lightweight - only 70 cars will be made,
21 of which will be on the West Coast, where I live.  It's basically a
stripped / lightened version of the M3 with some race-oriented performance
enhancements. The cars are sold by special order only, and are allocated to
individuals and dealers on a first-come, first-served basis, but if you're
already on the list, the actual time of order is not important (or so I'm
told). Due to some correspondence I had with BMWNA last September, it
appears that I am "way up at the top of the list" in terms of guaranteeing
a unit in my name. 

My question is pretty simple - how does one go about negiotiating price
(there are a few options available (adjustable suspension, adjustable
camber plates, etc.) on this car?  Is there really any room to manouver in
such a situation, where demand may very well outstrip supply, but to an
extent the car is reserved for the prospective buyer (me)?  Am I naive to
assume that this is a bit different from the case where a dealer orders the
car and then holds out for the highest bidder?

BMWNA says the cars will only be made available to dealers, and the dealer
I spoke with (so far I'm on good terms with them) is asking for a small,
non-refundable deposit / downpayment. I presume brokers cannot "get in" on
this sort of deal.

Thanks for any insight / advice you may have on this matter.

 ________________________________________

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 12:06:51 -0800 (PST)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Lacquer paint jobs

Lacquer used to be the medium of choice for spot repairs, since you
could experiment with tinting and quickly redo mistakes, so there are
a whole bunch of cars out on the road with spot and panel repairs in
lacquer.  Also, most touch-up paint is lacquer.  It dries quickly, and
even cured lacquer will come off with lacquer thinner.

Body shops have been forced to change due to environmental
restrictions--one of the few environmentally-induced changes that have
been for the better.  Now they use urethanes and/or water-based
paints.  The same goes for most factories.

In the past, Porsche and the other German cars all used enamels;
these, in recent years, have gone over to urethanes.  GM was the only
American carmaker to use lacquer.  Rolls-Royce used lacquer, I think
Jaguar also.  Anytime you hear someone brag about the number of coats
in a paint job, you can bet it's lacquer, since enamels are a one-shot
deal.

Lacquer was popular for high-end repaints in the 70s.  In the case of
a Rolls or a Cadillac it made sense, since that was how the factory
did it.  But it was used for other cars as well.  The advantages are
relatively few, as I see them:  the material is harder, but less
resilient.  Since it gets its shine from buffing to begin with, it
will respond better to rubbing out scrapes and such.  Other than the
non-originality factor, a major disadvantage is that you cannot
use lacquer thinner for leveling or correcting touch-ups.

A recent lacquer repaint would be unusual, since most body shops have
stopped using it.  

My ex-wife's 66 Mustang had an acrylic enamel repaint in '83.  When I
was in charge of its maintenance the car looked great; now it's gone
downhill :-).  But it was enamel over a lacquer primer.  Try to touch
up a chip, and the enamel will lift.  IOW, lacquer never dies:  it
will always succumb to solvent.  

To put some closure on this, my own impulse would be to stay away from
a lacquer job on a Porsche.  But if the car is otherwise straight and
well-priced, and if you have a source for lacquer repairs, and if
you're not a purist, you might still consider it.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

------------------------------

Date: 07 Mar 95 12:03:11 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Axle nut

 
>If the 914 is the same as VW and my 944, then a 1 7/16" socket will do...
 
356, and I guess VW and 924/944 axle nuts are 36 mm. I have a Snap-on
1/2" drive socket for this, Sears has one too, don't know if 1/2 or 3/4.
 
>Leave the car on the ground, emergency brakes on, and tires blocked before
>applying your weight to the cheater pipe.
 
Even better is to make a bar that bolts down over 3 lugnuts and braces
against the ground (like factory used to install these things). Parking
brake et al may not hold against the 400 ft-lbs or whatever.
 
Pete

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 15:27:18 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: frozen pilot bearing

I did this on an old plymouth wagon, so-

start in gear, let it roll, then apply the brakes. If it doesn't break
loose before the engine is about to stall, get it back up to speed and try
again, harder.

this technique has two advantages:
1. you can generate more negative load using the brakes than positive load
using the accelerator. And, as we all know, ots the absolute value of the
load that matters, not the sign.
2. you have more control and can apply the load over a longer time.

anyway, it woiked fine on da wagon.

doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

Date: 07 Mar 95 12:03:19 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Finally

 
Just so the Porschegeeks don't get all upset about bandwidth (and waste more
of it whining) here is a tidbit of Porsche info they would NEVER find
elsewhere: The chrome plated sheet metal screws used for interior trim on
356s are B 3.5 x 9.5 DIN 7983, chrome plated, or B 3.9 x 13 DIN 7982, chrome
plated. You can cheat with #6 and #8 oval head phillips sheet metal screws.
There, having said that...
 
Paul writes about being taken for a test drive by a berserk female BMW
salesperson (now THERE'S a new minority for you...almost as good as having
an HIV positive one-legged lesbian native American biker babe up for a new
cabinet post, it covers all the bases.)
 
This accident leaves you wide open for all sorts of things. Beginning with
the obvious "Thank you for the demonstration, miss. GOOD handling, but not
GREAT handling." Or "Does this have the optional sport suspension?" Or "OK,
that was nice. Now can you show us what the M3 does?" And goes right up to
"Uh, I think my neck hurts" and having your lawyer/backlash specialist get
that M3 for your friend for FREE. (Hey, it's the 'Murikan Way.)
 
>There's a bit more to the story...
 
So tellustellusTELL US!
 
Pete

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 95 14:54:27 EST
From: Paul Moruzzi <pmoruzzi@hpwarhw.an.hp.com>
Subject: Re: frozen pilot bearing

snip

>           off, to test drive the car.  When the ignition is off, the trans 
>           has no problem getting into gear, but once the car is started, it 
>           will not go in gear.  When started in 1st, the car lurches 
>           forward, even with the clutch depressed.  We bled the clutch line 
>           (found lots of air n nasty stuff...), the clutch feels better, 
>           but still does not engage.  I called the local Porsche dealer and 
>           they said that, because the car was inactive for a long time, the 
>           pilot bearing had frozen (rusted) to the input shaft, and that 
>           this happens often in areas of high humidity (like Washington, 
>           DC).  
snip
>           
>           TIA
>           Paul Souza
>           '57 356

There is another possibility.  The clutch plate may be corroded to the
flywheel.  I had this happen several times on old Saab 96's.  Engine
would run fine in nutral but you couldnt get into gear.  Pulled engine
and found that the clutch plate was frozen to the flywheel,  pried it
off with a screwdriver (came off real easy once the engine was out;-). 
Same thing happened a second time after the car had a extended period of
inactivity.  Since I knew what the likely problem was and I didn't want
to pull the engine, I sepped on the clutch and rammed it into gear -
broke free with no other problems.  Since the whole 96 cost less than
the clutch parts for a 944 I wouldnt use this method.

hope this helps, and let me know what it turns out to be.

PVM

>> 1/2" drive socket for this, Sears has one too, don't know if 1/2 or 3/4.

one up, they get to replace it.  The Proto version works much better.

stand on the brakes inside.

Date: Tue, 07 Mar 95 14:29:20 EST
From: Neil NW Walker at EVEN_2100B <smtplink%Neil_NW_Walker_at_EVEN__2100B@ccmail.ae.ge.com>
Subject: Prep for Drivers Ed


Text item: Text_1

86 911 Turbo
Finally got round to starting prep for Drivers Ed in April. As several of you 
advised last year (advice received with thanks) aligning go fast and go slow 
pedals for heel and toe turned out to be easy. Removed seat, carpet and floor 
board (yep they are called floor boards becos they used to be boards, have 
driven many a mile watching the black top pass below), pulled back accelerator 
pedal and extended rod to limit then adjusted brake pedal to master cylinder rod
for final alignment. Perfect, no blocks, no add on pedal, no grunge. Also fitted
Weltmeister short shift kit, almost as easy but broke shift knob trying to 
remove it for transfer, still needs final adjustment but looks good in garage 
need final road test before claiming complete success.
Now I really need HELP! Have removed intercooler and intake plenum and can 
actually see and reach plugs, injectors and valve cover nuts on right bank of 
cylinders and have found several items I didn't know existed, one of which is 
air (smog) pump. Still cannot even see never mind get to plugs, injectors and 
valve covers of left hand bank.
Question(s), what else needs to come off and how, to get to left bank of 
cylinders so I can do plugs, check injectors etc.? Cannot get drive belt to the 
air pump adjusted either, runs out of travel on the adjuster, how do I get it 
off and back on? should I even bother? what happens if I don't? this is a CA car
now in OH and EPA inspection here is about a 10 second look under the 
|hood|trunk|lid|bonnet|cover (delete as required).
Will continue with jobs requiring only three universal joints per limb until 
words of wisdom arrive, such as replacing deck lid struts, fuel filter, coil, 
distributor cap etc.
Thanks in advance.

neil_nw_walker@ae.ge.com

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 16:55:35 -0600
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: BUYING VERY LIMITED-EDITION FROM DEALER - NEED ADVICE

 Andrew said (talking about a sellers market)....

>My question is pretty simple - how does one go about negiotiating price
>(there are a few options available (adjustable suspension, adjustable
>camber plates, etc.) on this car?  Is there really any room to manouver in
>such a situation, where demand may very well outstrip supply, but to an
>extent the car is reserved for the prospective buyer (me)?  Am I naive to
>assume that this is a bit different from the case where a dealer orders the
>car and then holds out for the highest bidder?

  I think that you answered your own question. Where demand is higher
than supply (in a free market economy) if ya wana play.....you *will*
pay. Why would you ask the dealer to take less of a profit from
selling it to you when Mr. X will pay more? Sounds like the only
negotiation you have is if you *can* buy the car. If you have a bill of sale
stating the VIN# and the agreed price, for the dealer to sell (that car) to
anyone else would be a breach. The same thing happened to a friend of mine
with the new Corvettes. He had a bill of sale without a vin # but an agreed
upon price. Guess what? His car didn't "arive" until the market stoppped
rallying (sp). I guess I would try to get a bill of sale with a VIN# on it.


  On a more topical note :-0  ..

    Who was looking for pictures of a 911 rebuild?

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 18:05:12 -0500
From: SteveDoing@aol.com
Subject: Re: RE: 914/6 engine #'s

914-6 engine numbers are as follows:

1970--6410011-6410268 type 901/36
and      6414001-6414163 type 901/38

1971--6420001-6420270 type 901/38

from official factory publications

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 18:26:59 -0500
From: SLR944@aol.com
Subject: re;goodwill claims

Randy;

      Porsche has been known to give consideration beyond the factory
warranty, and even to 2nd owners, but if it is driveline related you must
have an excellent service history to start with.  In addition you must
present the car to an authorized dealer who will then contact PCNA for you.
 The big problem comes if you have an internal problem say in the engine or
trans. then you pay for teardown with no promise as to what Porsche will do,
so you take you chances, but it may be worth it.  What exactly are you
looking to have PCNA assist you with.

                        Steve
                         slr944@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 07 Mar 95 15:22:00 PST
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Re: 914 brakes. upgrade/replacement questions


Stan mentioned this about cross-drilling your rotors:

>But here's the other half: for real racing applications, you use rotors 
with
>holes cast into the rotors. If you drill the rotors, you break the 
crystalline
>structure of the metal and induce stress risers; ...[snip]... the drilled 
rotors
>are unsafe, will *break* and can hurt you as a result.

Yup....this can happen even if you are careful and do everything you can
to avoid this problem.  A racer friend of mine drilled a pair of NEW 911 
front
rotors and was careful about hole placement and brake pad break-in.
He followed the correct warm-up and cool-down procedure for the brakes
on his race car and BOTH of the front rotors cracked.  Now he sticks with
a good air ducting system and doesn't have any brake fade problems.

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

I've always hated the flimsy plastic handles in my '83... talk about a
disconnect between the solid feel of the car and the cheesy feel of the
handle!  But I've also hated PP's price (several dozen dollars I recall)
enough to live with the plastic.  Thus when the most recent *Automashin'*
sale rolled around with "Metal Latch Handles" for about $20, I fell for
it.  In spite of some, uh, misgivings.

Wrong move.  First there was the $8.95 "shipping and handling" charge (I
live about 70 miles from them).  Then I opened the box and examined my
prizes.  Can you say Pot Metal?  Heavy, shoddily-molded, flaking-black-
paint Pot Metal?  Dr. Fuhrmann would spin in his grave if I put these on
a Porsche... they'd look like sh*t on a Yugo.

Anyway that's it for me and *Automashin'*, I have bought one shoddy-part-
at-Porsche-prices too many from them.  Just looking at all the useless
crap they hawk in their catalog makes my blood pressure rise now...
Bart! Help!  More of the little blue ones!

So good luck with your door-handle quest.  If anyone finds a well made
reasonably priced item that fits an '83 I'd love to hear about it...

 -Ed Mellinger
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 19:12:58 -0500
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: Re: ABS Brake Bias

This is hearsay and not first hand knowlege.  Please douse all flame
throwers.  

I was told by a Chrysler design engineer that they design ABS brake systems
with deliberate bias to allow the rear brakes to lock up long before the
fronts.  This will allow the ABS system to operate properly. If one or more
wheel locks up, the computer kicks in the system.  If all four corners lock
up at the same time with the clutch in, the computer thinks that the car is
at rest and will not activate. I do not know if this is true of the Porsche
system.  

At the Northern New Jersey Region PCA Track Instructors Meeting, we spent
quite a bit of time discussing the pros/cons of ABS on the track.  There are
rumors that certain PCA regions are going to request? or demand? that
entrants in drivers ed track events disconnect the their ABS.  If anyone is
certain this is true, please let me know the particulars.  NNJR is not
entertaining this idea, but we are trying to gather factual information.

There is another rumor that  Porsche ABS and/or the braking system may fail
to operate properly when a car is spinning backwards.  This does not make
sense, but is the suppossed basis for the region(s) disconnecting the ABS.
 Any FACTS on this subject would also be appreciated.

The point that was discussed at length concerned the teaching of "in a spin,
both feet in, wheel straight" .  Our 60+ instructors don't have ABS and/or
have little or no experience spinning backwards.  As we all know, the ABS
cars will at some point hook up and launch in unpredictable directions when
spinning, but that is about as far as any of us go.  

Thank you,

Larry Reynolds
Car Care Specialties, Inc.
Post Office Box 535
Saddle Brook,  NJ  07663
Phone (201) 796-8300
Fax (201) 791-9743
E-mail carcaresp@aol.com




There is also a discussion as to what happens during a track spin and the car
is travelling backwards with the ABS on.

Date: Tue, 07 Mar 1995 17:49:02 -0700
From: Drew Spencer <Drew_Spencer@Novell.COM>
Subject:  Re: ABS Brake Bias -Reply


Regarding ABS and spins on the track:
Since I just happen to have some experience with both, I'll 
give my $.02.

I've found the ABS on the RS America to be quite effective
on the track so far.  In one respect, it is nice to be able to 
squish (not smash) the pedal without having to worry as much
about modulation.  This is particularly of benefit in braking
zones that are bumpy.  On the other hand, I'm still not 
completely at ease knowing that some piece of software 
is always going to guess correctly in all circumstances.  

In spin conditions I unfortunately don't recall whether there
were any problems with the ABS disabling while not going
forwards, as I was busy planting my feet on the floor while
being taken in by the 360 degree panoramic view of my 
surroundings.  One incident that did strike me as interesting,
in this regard, was a Euro Carrera cup race last year.  I don't
remember the venue (possibly Jerez) where the 1st and 2nd
place cars came through the last turn for the check(qu)ered flag.
The guy in the 2 spot early apexed the corner and collected
the leader causing both of them to lose it.  The leader (Alzen?)
proceeded to back into the pit wall (rear tires turning as if in
reverse) and managed to crunch the engine to a 4cyl  :-(.
What struck me was that you would think that when the car
began to spin, he'd have the brakes on.  If the Cup cars do
employ ABS, and he had it on, what you say might very well
be correct.  If not, then he had his brain disabled...

Drew
Drew_Spencer@novell.com
'93 RS America (ready for the new 1.8m Vegas track...!)
'82 911 SC (Soon to be track car begrudgingly giving up it's
old tired parts, but not without inflicting pain and suffering on
its keeper...)

real info and exercise is good for the goose and the gander.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 20:49:12 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 brakes. upgrade/replacement questions

To soften the blow somewhat from Stan, let me offer the following:

He said:
>Cool Carbon pads, or equivalent, are just about a requirement for >full-time
track cars. If you pick the wrong compound, or if you don't >follow the
break-in proceedure to the exact letter, they are a disaster >waiting to
happen on the street. I use street pads on the street on all of >my cars.

I used Cool Carbons very successfully on our street/track 911E for several
years.  Never had a break in problem; not to say that you can't, but we did
not.  Also use Cool Carbons on my wife's Audi 200 Quattro.  The ONLY pad for
that car that offers good fade resistance. One lap at a Quattro Club school
would fade the stock pads.  Offered much better feel on the street also.

>If you need a master cylinder, it's foolish not to make this >upgrade.Unless
you run in a class where it matters. Like any of the stock >classes. Then
it's another of those silly upgrades that has you running >with the Big Boys.
Know what your terminal application is before you buy >*ANYTHING*.

The larger master is a must for any street driven 914 in my opinion.  The
SCCA  protest gestapo may make an issue of it at a national event, if anyone
thought to protest.  It is not visible once the installation is made. It is
legal for PCA Parade, and many PCA regions use Parade rules for their events.
Frequently, these 19 mm masters are cheaper than the stock 17mm master. Pedal
feel is much improved over the best stock 914.

Talking braided lines:
>This is just plain stupid and dangerous. You use braided lines on race >cars
where you need the greater strength and where everything is made of >braided
line anyway. You take them off and throw them away at the end of >the
 season. EVERY YEAR. If you do much endurance racing, you do it >sooner.

Stan has a point here.  My mileage and experience was excellent on street
cars; no failures.  I was VERY careful on installation. But good new stock
lines are infinitely better that old swollen lines.  Difference between new
stock lines and new braided lines is very small.

On 911 brakes for 914's.  I agree that this is not a cheap mod.  For the
street, don't bother.  For the track, probably worth it for drivers schools.
 914 brakes are marginal at best. But competitively, CHECK THE RULES.  Again
legal for PCA Parade.

One mod no one brought up: replace the stock proportioning valve with
adjustable one from the many advertisers.  The stock design IMHO sucked.  Too
large, too much volume, and it significantly to soft pedal.  I would NEVER
replace one with a new stock one. But adjust it carefully according to the
instructions that come with it.

Of course, YMMV.

Jon Lowe
Several 914's, etc.





------------------------------

Date: Tue, 07 Mar 1995 21:00:14 -0500 (EST)
From: RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu
Subject: Re: Frozen pilot bearing

Regarding the frozen pilot bearing, this has got to be another dealer trying to 
wrench some good cash from an unsuspecting owner.  Good job you're on the net!  
There is NO WAY it'll be a frozen pilot bearing, since the transmission is 
obviously turning.  
	The clutch plate has stuck to the flywheel my friend, and this is a normal 
problem for cars that have been standing for a while.  The "Ringo's patented 
technique" for freeing said item is to indeed find a clear bit of tarmac, start 
the car up in first gear and keep your foot oscillating on the clutch pedal ALL 
the time, whilst alternating oscillations on the gas pedal and brake pedal to keep 
engine from over-revving or stalling.  This is worth a couple of laps around the 
car park, and it *SHOULD* release the plate.  If not, it's tranny off, unbolt 
clutch cover plate, release friction plate, inspect (put at least new throw 
bearing in) and rebuild.
	Happy hopping,   Jan

Date: Tue, 07 Mar 1995 21:07:46 -0500 (EST)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: 66 912 weber backfiring problem


Scott,

I just recently solved the same problem with my 66 912 so I may be able to
help but need more information.  You say the carbs have just been rebuilt. 
Did you 
map out the jets (numbers for idle, main, air correcttion, idle, emulsion
tube, and venturi size) on all four circuits?  Without "as founds" it is
difficult to get to "as lefts".  You are REALLY going to need an air flow
indicator (they are not all that expensive) and an accurate tachomteter (I use 
 a  Fluke 88 automotive voltmeter with the RPM 80 attachment.  REALLY

expensive).  I've never seen the starter 
jet circuits except in books so I doubt if they are all that necessary.  You
also need to set the throttle linkages precisely.  I've developed a novel
approach for this and will include this my next mail along with jet maps etc
(after I dig them out, the problem with extensive documentation).  Are you
running the stock air filters or K&N's (or, god forbid, velocity stacks)?  Big 
 bore kit or standard p&c's?  Fuel pressure regulator?  Got the valve

adjustment and timing spot on?  As we used to say to VW customers, "When the
problem HAS to be the carb, it probably isn't". 


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com

Date: Tue, 07 Mar 1995 21:22:36 -0500
From: NG_COLE@ACAD.FANDM.EDU (Nicholas Cole)
Subject: 914 brakes

I have to chime in here about the 911T brakes on a 914. This is what I did
with auto atlanta advice. 911 front calipiers on the 914 struts and discs,
and 19mm master cylinder. I had to replace both. Calipers up front sucked
so bad I couldn't rebuild them. The 911 ones were cheaper and fit using the
914 pads. The master cylinder was also cheaper.
Nick

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 95 19:20:32 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: Which performance tires for 914


Steve-

I read your reply to Chip, and noticed you said speedometer
error goes along with a change in tire size, and that your
speedometer showed at least 10% error (faster) when you
changed from 195/60's to 205/60's, on 15" rims.  I might
be all screwed up (It certainly wouldn't be the first time.), but
I don't think a 10% error is possible, and further, I think any
error would be in the other direction.  The 195/60 tire on a 15"
rim has a nominal diameter of 24.21 inches.  The 205/60 has
a diameter of 24.68.  The difference is 1.9%, nowhere near 10%.
The 205's, with their larger diameter will make fewer turns
per unit diatance, and hence tend to give a lower reading
on the speedometer (by about 1.9%). 

I calculated diameter as follows:

195/60    Tire height is 195 x .6 = 117mm x (25.4mm/in) = 4.61"
          
          Diameter is 15" + 2 x 4.61" = 24.21"

205/60    Tire height is 205 x .6 = 123mm x (25.4mm/in) = 4.84"

           Diameter is 15" + 2 x 4.84 = 24.68"

These are nominal diameters, because when the tire is loaded down the
actual diameter is less.  But it'll be close to this.  I don't think it'll
be off be much.  Can some tire expert out there correct me if I'm wrong?  
All this tire stuff is new to me.  

 -Bob Spindel
 '72 911E Targe

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 95 19:22:15 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)

 -Bob Spindel

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 19:48:36 -0800 (PST)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: Which performance tires for 914

Dear Bob,

The speedo error was when I went from 185/70 (Chip's current size) to
195/60.  That's been mitigated somewhat by going to the 205's, but
it's still on the fast side.  His rims are 5.5; mine are 6, so the
change won't be exactly the same.  Basically, he's gone from the
stock 165/80 to the now-outdated 185/70, so he's already running a bit
fast; going to 195/60 will make the error worse, but unavoidable.
Having the speedo recalibrated is the only permanent fix--that is,
provided 60-series tires don't go out of production!

Sorry for the confusion and thanks for responding.

Steve Gilbert
steveng@csufresno.edu

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 23:06:56 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: frozen pilot bearing

Paul quotes, " ...Then shut it off, put it in 1st, start it again and
accelerate hard and jam it into 2nd!  They say that they have a 95% success
rate in unfreezing the bearing that way...."

And,100% success in tearing up a perfectly good transmission!

The proper approach to solving this not-uncommon problem is to find that
deserted stretch of road, put the car in first gear and start the engine WITH
THE CLUTCH DEPRESSED.  If you're fortunate, you'll motor away immediately
with a slight stumble (clutch still depressed...feels strange doesn't it?).
 Keep the clutch on the floor, one hand on the ignition key, watch where
you're going, and alternately accelerate and quickly back off the throttle.
 Just a few cycles of accelerating up to 3000-4000 rpm and backing off the
throttle (clutch still on the floor) will usually break it loose.  Maybe it
will take more than a few cycles, but it will eventually come loose (100% -
not 95% - guaranteed).  Also, works quicker if you can find a hill to climb
while doing it.  Don't let the engine over-rev when the clutch breaks loose,
and keep your eyes on the road!  This doesn't damage anything, it's cheap,
and the clutch will behave in a perfectly normal fashion afterward.

I have done this at least a couple of times straight out of the garage, in
reverse, but I do NOT recommend that.

To keep it from happening again, lower the humidity in your garage or drive
the car periodically to exercise the clutch (and all the other mechanical
goodies).

Good luck,

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 23:46:27 -0600
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Re: COLOR GAUGE FACES

Does anyone have these on their car ??? Are they cool or no?

I have an '84 944 and I hated the yellow on black gauges soooo much that I
replaced the faces with a set from a trashed '79 924 euro car (basically
the same except for a different scale on the oil pres. (10 bar instead of
5, wow now I can actually read it when the car is cold, and the lack of an
mpg gauge with the tach). I also changed the plastic "conehead" lenses with
proper, flat instrument glass. A little more glare in the day, but the
gauges now look real pro.

The reason I did the above as opposed to going with the colour gauge faces
is that I wanted to keep the gauges looking somewhat stock in appearance
(ie. - vdo logo, etc.)

In any case, do the colour guys look cool or not ????

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 23:01:26 -0700
From: jungmann@swcp.com (Kit Jungmann)
Subject: Re: Keep junk mail short!

>>they're about to post before pressing the send key and broadcasting it to 
>YESSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSSS!  I agree too.

Folks,

In this continuing series we've compounded the problem by replying to a 
message while including the complete text and adding "I agree" to the end.

There is no need to waste bandwidth when quite often the message header will 
suffice as subject matter. Let's keep the junk mail short and sweet!

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 23:25:07 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: Stickers and Racing

Darren Foo (badkarma@unix.infoserve.net) asked:

>Do all cars in a racing event have to have stickers all over them?

	Only if their owners want to get contingency/sponsorship money 	
	from the companies whose names are on the decals.  Contingency 	
	awards are based on your finishing position vs. the number of 	
	cars starting the event; if you don't have the required decals 	
	in the appropriate places when you finish the race, you don't 	
	get the money.

>How do you get them off afterwards when street driving?

	Why would you want to?  Don't you want the whole world to know 	
	you're a macho racer?

	Seriously, they come off pretty easily, since they're just 	
	decals, not adhesive "stickers".

	-Andy
	

- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 23:58:03 -0800
From: richlu@uclink.berkeley.edu (Richard Hsiang Lu)
Subject: 944: firewall repair

	When the free-play in my clutch pedal increased rather
noticably, i suspected the clutch slave and/or master cylinder(s)
had finally worn out after 10+ years of service ('83 944). Upon
inspection, the cylinders showed no sign of leakage, but instead,
the firewall was seriously cracked at the point where the master
cylinder meets it.  I'm thinking the failure in the firewall has
allowed the master cylinder to move forward, thus affecting the
linkage to the pedal, resulting in more free-play.

My mechanic intends to weld a patch over the fractured portion
of the firewall with a MIG welder.  So my question is:  what kind
of material is the firewall in an '83 944 made of?  I heard Porsche
used carbon-fibered composite steel way back in those days, so if my
firewall is indeed made of this material, wouldn't it need to be TIG
welded, rather than MIG welded?  Or is MIG welding sufficient?

The fracture is located between between the booster (which will be
removed to get at the hole) and the harness (which will remain in
place, but covered by wet rags during the welding). I'm not at all
sure about the differences b/t MIG and TIG welding procedures, but
just by eyeballing the crack, it looks like a nasty, difficult task
to just to get at the fissure, let alone WELD it with all those 
components near it.  Has anyone else experienced something like this?
I still can't understand why the firewall would fatigue like this...
afterall the clutch is hydraulically actuated rather than having a
the tension of a clutch cable pull at it...?  Comments welcomed! Thanks

 -rich

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 23:56:55 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: 911 engine number

Robert M Zampardi (us000812@interramp.com) wrote:

>I recently acuired another nine one four, (yes another) in the pass 
?compartment was a 911 engine with webers. the engine number is
>901 106 101 5R
>could anyone shed some light on this?

Robert:

Shed some light on the engine, or on your apparent 914-buying addiction?

As far as I can tell, the number you gave is the crankcase part number. 
If you look on the vertical surface of the fan-housing support, you'll 
find the engine serial number, and you'll find the engine type number on 
the horizontal surface behind it (look closely... it's hard to see).

If you can post those two numbers, it'll be easier to tell you exactly 
what you've got.  You may be disappointed, though... the "5R" cases 
aren't nearly as desirable as the "7R"s.

 -Andy

P.S.  Why not just sell all your 914s and buy one REAL car?  You can
      have mine for $35K...


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 00:11:41 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: 914/6 engines

William Costello (wpcostel@porsche.aud.alcatel.com) wrote:

>Could someone post the engine sizes available in a 914/6 (factory). I 
>have a friend looking at one and he is trying to determine if its 
>original. I think its a 73 or 74 model.

William:

If it ain't a '70 or '71, it ain't an original 914/6.

On the other hand, a '73 conversion is a much nicer car (as long as you 
don't care whether it's "factory").  The '73s had a MUCH better 
sideshift transmission, a movable passenger seat, and numerous other 
niceties that were missing from the early 914s.

Also, if it's a conversion, it's likely to have a larger, more powerful, 
and (probably) more reliable engine.  The original 914/6s came with 
2-liter engines that developed only 110 horsepower.  For comparison, my 
car (a 1973 914/6 conversion) has a 2.7-liter Euro Carrera RS motor with 
about 260 horsepower... A big difference.  With the Carrera chain 
tensioners, oil-squirters, turbo valve covers, 930 oil pump, etc., it's 
a lot more reliable than the original 914/6 engines.

Before your friend buys this car, he should definitely consult with 
someone who knows 914s.  Your local Porsche Club of America region would 
be a good place to find such a person.

 -Andy


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Porschephiles #1225                         Wed Mar 8 11:12:20 CST 1995
Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 00:40:04 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: 914 brakes. upgrade/replacement questions

Stan Hanks (stan@tta.com) wrote:

>[Using stainless steel braided brake lines] is just plain stupid and 
>dangerous.
>....
>Why? The inner hose abrades on the braided cover. You can't see it. 
>Then, typically when you most need it, the line blows out *FROM THE 
>INSIDE* due to overpressure on the weakened spot.
>....
>And I haven't even begun to talk about the rash of badly assembled 
>units that popped up a few years ago where the ends would pull off the 
>hose....

	At the risk of offending the Keeper of the List, here's my two 	
	cents:

	I don't know where you buy your brake lines, Stan, but REAL 
	lines (Aeroquip "Super Gem" and Earl's "Fluor-O-Seal") use an 	
	inner hose made of Teflon that will last nearly forever if 
	installed properly (i.e., without tightly bending or twisting 
	the hose).

	If you're worried about badly-assembled hoses, you can always 
	put the ends on yourself... It only takes a fine hacksaw or 
	Dremel tool, a vise, and a wrench.

>Yeah, if you want to spend a few $K [on 911 calipers].... Figure 
>$650-$1k for the 911 front end (and it really doesn't matter which 
>one). Figure another few $x00 to fix the rear end so it now has 5-lug 
>wheels to keep you from looking stupid. Figure at least $150 a wheel 
>for some 15x6 911 wheels. Sure, cheap, effective. My ass. 

	I'd agree with "Cheap, my ass," but they ARE effective.  914 
	brakes positively SUCK, and, as you've pointed out, the other 	
	suggested mods (19mm master cylinder, steel brake lines, 	
	cross-drilled rotors) don't do a whole lot to correct the 	
	situation.  Replacing the calipers is about the only way 	
	to improve the car's braking.

	If front-end expense is a problem, you can mount 911 brakes 	
	simply by replacing the struts with 911 units; there's really no 
	need to replace the crossmember, etc.  Also, you can usually 	
	find a pair of the $2800 (factory price) "S" calipers for a 	
	couple hundred dollars.

	-Andy


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 01:06:15 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: Real Fuchs Alloys vs. Cheap-Ass Replicas

Mark W kuefel (mkuefel@delphi.com) wrote:

>What is the skinny on telling real forged fuchs 5 spoke alloys from the 
>cast fakes?  Should they have a p/n on them or not?  The kid said 
>"They're the real thing.  Bought them at a swap and shop".  (He also 
>said they had never been used which I doubt, unless there are people 
>out there in the habit of putting balance weights on wheels without 
>mounting tires.)

Mark:

The Fuchs alloys do indeed have part numbers on them.  Since I'm too 
lazy to go downstairs and check the numbers on my wheels, I'll just 
suggest that you call Robert W. Wood, Inc. at 310 473-6649 and ask them.

The forged wheels have a very smooth finish; most cast replicas are 
rougher, although if you don't have access to a set of real wheels for 
comparison, this may not be useful information.

Also, if the wheels are being advertised as 7's and 8's, they're 
almost certainly 6's and 7's... Get the numbers from Robert Wood to be 
sure.

 -Andy

Date: Tue, 7 Mar 1995 09:05:40 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: intake valve cleaning, car lifts

Mikr Todd's message asks:

>running for one block - perhaps due to intake valve deposits.  Can that be
>cleaned without removing head?  I heard one person say it can be done if
>manifold is removed but the local dealers never heard of that.


Mike, based on my experience, I guess you could clean up the intake valves
after you remove the intake manifold. If I remember correctly, you can actually
see them. Two questions come to mind:

1st, I don't know if you can get to the
back of the valves. I remember seeing one part of them, but how will you rotate
them to get to the other side?

2nd, how to ensure that you remove all of the crap out? Vacuum it out?  Is the
stuff hard enough to damage the cylinder walls?

I openend my engine a few months ago, and much to my surprise, there were no
deposits on either the intake or exhaust valves. My car had 93K miles at the
time. I was impressed. 

Why not try some Techron in your car? Also, have you looked for any vacuum 
leaks and or leaking injector seals? The seals are easy to change and the
kits are about $4 from Porsche.

Here's some info on car lifts:

Parking Solutions, 800-359-5021

Autolifts of America, 800-759-0700 $2500 and up

Imparts, 800-325-9043 $3300

Date: Wed, 08 Mar 95 07:32:56 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944: firewall repair


> My mechanic intends to weld a patch over the fractured portion
> of the firewall with a MIG welder.  So my question is:  what kind
> of material is the firewall in an '83 944 made of?  I heard Porsche
> used carbon-fibered composite steel way back in those days, so if my
> firewall is indeed made of this material, wouldn't it need to be TIG
> welded, rather than MIG welded?  Or is MIG welding sufficient?

The firewall in any 944 is good old sheet steel. No carbon fiber or anything
else exotic. MIG welding should be sufficient.

> 
> The fracture is located between between the booster (which will be
> removed to get at the hole) and the harness (which will remain in
> place, but covered by wet rags during the welding). I'm not at all
> sure about the differences b/t MIG and TIG welding procedures, but
> just by eyeballing the crack, it looks like a nasty, difficult task
> to just to get at the fissure, let alone WELD it with all those 
> components near it.  Has anyone else experienced something like this?
> I still can't understand why the firewall would fatigue like this...
> afterall the clutch is hydraulically actuated rather than having a
> the tension of a clutch cable pull at it...?  Comments welcomed! Thanks

You're right, it is a tight spot, but with the proper precautions, your
experienced welder should be able to strengthen it.

I have seen another 944 with this particular symptom, probably caused by
some sort of accident or abuse.

Keep in mind that using the clutch pedal does stress the clutch master
cylinder (at the mounting points to the firewall) in the same direction
every time you use it. A bit of fatigue might be expected...

Good luck, GB
- --

Date:     Wed, 8 Mar 95 8:24:04 EST
From: "Hugh A. Huntzinger" (CCAC-LAD) <huntzing@PICA.ARMY.MIL>
Subject:  Re: Porsche 911 Carrrera Targa 1985

Howard...congrats on the purchase from a fellow '85er.

Now for the bad news:

> ...The car was short its' owners manual & keys to the factory installed
> alarm system.  Any sugestions on how to obtain the keys & manual...

If you have NO key, pragmatically, your only alternative will be to buy
and install a whole new lock (it comes with 2 keys).  Around $100.

I got only one factory alarm key with my '85.  I inquired as high as PNA
and everyone kept confirming the same story:  the security system key
blanks are factory controlled and are *NOT* available, period.

But...at a local locksmith we found a blank that COULD be made to work 
(a SAAB key?)  The ID# for this key blank is in the <Pfile> archives as
well as on my keychain at home if anyone needs it...cost = $10 for 3 keys.


 -hugh

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 08:26:13 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 brakes. upgrade/replacement questions


<"I've said this before, I'll said it again: vendors are predictable,
<100%." 

 <From "Hanks Hears a Hype", by Dr. Stan

<Time to debunk the latest round of horse puckey....

<Moral:  Just because something is good for racing doesn't mean *ANYTHING*
        <about how good it is for *YOUR* car on the street. Magazines are
 <in business to sell copies so they can sell advertising. You 
 <simply *CAN* *NOT* believe everything you read in them. Even Pano.



1. Carbon Kevlar brake pads work *great*  for the street and are sold in the
proper compound when in the 914 configuration. We have tested them with the
manufacturer for hundreds of hours both hot and cold and they are the best
thing that has happened to 914 brakes in this century.

2. The 19mm cylinder, standard on the 914-6 is a stock upgrade and a very
worthwhile one.

3. Stainless steel lines made today are of the highest quality and we notice
a real difference in pedal sponge compared to stock lines. In the last 16
years and thousands of sold sets, we have had two bad lines. We have had no
abrasion problems on any of our racing 914s even after years of use.

4. 911T front calipers work great, can be purchased for $115.00 each and bolt
directly to the 914-4 strut assembly. This is a cheap and effective brake
upgrade.

Moral:  Just because something is good for racing doesn't mean *anything*
about how good it is for *your* car on the street. Ask the guys who have
tried it *all* on 914s for millions of miles. Magazines are in business to
sell copies so they can sell advertising. You simply cannot believe
everything you read in them.

George

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 08:26:25 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914/6 engines


<Could someone post the engine sizes available in a 914/6 (factory). I have a
<friend looking at one and he is trying to determine if its original. I think
<its a 73 or 74 model.



Dear William,

914-6 models were made as 1970, 1971 and 1972 year models. One 1975 model was
made for a fellow in Germany by the factory and the 260 1972 models were
never exported.

Therefore, we are dealing virtually with only 1970 and 1971 model cars. All
of these 914-6s had 2.0 litre 911T engines, but with a 914-6 serial numer
640_ _ _ _ 1970 models
                   641_ _ _ _ 1971 models
                   642_ _ _ _ 1972 models

This number was located on the top back of the engine block and easily read
from under the engine lid. Good Luck!

George Hussey

Date: 8 Mar 95 08:55:00 EST
From: "LOGISX::GIBBS" <GIBBS%LOGISX.decnet@vaxa.acdnj.itt.com>
Subject: 944 stuck clutch (or T/O bearing)

Date: Tue, 07 Mar 1995 13:03:00 -0500 (EST)
>>From: PAUL SOUZA 202-260-6061 <SOUZA.PAUL@epamail.epa.gov>

>>          The car was on jacks the whole time, and last weekend we took it 
>>         off, to test drive the car.  When the ignition is off, the trans 
>>          has no problem getting into gear, but once the car is started, it 
>>          will not go in gear.  When started in 1st, the car lurches 
>>          forward, even with the clutch depressed.  We bled the clutch line 

Had the same thing happen to me on my '84 944.  Washed the car, put it away
without driving it.  Next morning, step on clutch, start car, car tries to
go through rear wall of garage.  Put in neutral, starts fine, won't go into
first.

After calling a tow truck, decide to roll it out of garage to make easier for
tow operator when he gets there.  As car is rolling down driveway (backwards 
in neutral), get brilliant idea, step on clutch, jam gearshift into reverse.

BANG!  Car bucks, then starts rolling again (in reverse with clutch in).  

BIG SMILE!  Put car in neutral, start motor, push in clutch, slip into first,
(works fine now!) pull back into garage, call and cancel tow truck, start planning 
for how to spend the $600 I just saved.

This was several years ago, and no adverse aftereffects have shown up yet.

Good luck!

Ed Gibbs
gibbs@avionics.itt.com
'84 944, Guards Red, All Mine!

------------------------------

Date: Wed,  8 Mar 95 09:58:40 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: ABS Brake Bias -Reply

Drew, responses embedded below:

[...]
> This is particularly of benefit in braking
> zones that are bumpy.  On the other hand, I'm still not
> completely at ease knowing that some piece of software
> is always going to guess correctly in all circumstances.
ABS gets its primary inputs from wheel motion sensors right next to the 
brake rotors (advanced ABS systems may get other inputs, but wheel 
movement is the key ingredient).  Software interpretation of relative 
wheel motion is how ABS systems decide when to reduce pressure to a 
brake channel.  All of this is derived from actual sensor input, not 
any "guess".

However, there are some design variables that affect ABS decisions.  
One such variable would include the threshold at which the ABS 
considers the tire to be skidding versus just having a high slip angle, 
or turning at a different speed going around a tight bend.  These 
legitimate wheel speed differences must not trigger the ABS.  Also, 
different tire compounds (stickiness really) come into play here too, 
especially if a different compound or size (read: total effective 
braking energy throught the tire/road interface during braking) is used 
on the front vs. back axle.

ABS considers all the above things (and possibly more), and adjusts 
brake line pressure in either 2 channels (cheap), 3 (most common - both 
rears on 1 circuit), or 4 (most expensive, most rare) channels.  It 
does this is dozens of times per second.  These 2 major abilities 
(reaction speed and individual channel control) are something no human 
can do, which is why a well-tuned ABS system will *always* beat any 
human's relatively slow, single-channel braking abilities.  This is 
most acutely obvious under bumpy braking, or when 1/2 the car is on 
sand/grass/etc. and the other half's on asphalt.

All that said, there's no requirement that every car manufacturer use 
the best ABS system on their cars, so...  "Your mileage may vary"

In contrast to the above, in loose surfaces like deep snow, sand, or 
gravel, you'll actually stop faster by locking the wheels, letting them 
dig-in and build a berm in front of themselves.  In this situation ABS 
actually impedes deceleration not because of any technological problem, 
but because its whole design principle is not correct in that braking 
situation.  But when you consider what percent of time you'll be doing 
emergency braking in these conditions vs. "regular" hard-packed roads, 
you'll see that overall, ABS is a *big* win.

[...]
> One incident that did strike me as interesting,
> in this regard, was a Euro Carrera cup race last year.  I don't
> remember the venue (possibly Jerez) where the 1st and 2nd
> place cars came through the last turn for the check(qu)ered flag.
> The guy in the 2 spot early apexed the corner and collected
> the leader causing both of them to lose it.  The leader (Alzen?)
> proceeded to back into the pit wall (rear tires turning as if in
> reverse) and managed to crunch the engine to a 4cyl  :-(.
> What struck me was that you would think that when the car
> began to spin, he'd have the brakes on.  If the Cup cars do
> employ ABS, and he had it on, what you say might very well
> be correct.  If not, then he had his brain disabled...
I too saw this accident on ESPN several times, in slow-mo (I taped it). 
 That guy who hit the wall pulled a really stupid racing move with 
typical consequences.  I couldn't understand why he didn't brake before 
hitting the barrier and causing huge rear-end damage.  But it's 
possible, as you suggest, that the ABS system went wacky and he lost 
braking power while in reverse.  I've heard incidental reports of 
exactly this on 2 occasions, once from a [now forgotten name] 
professional racer who ran Lime Rock backwards in a 928.  He completed 
the lap in something around 1:30, then tried to stop but couldn't, and 
lightly tapped a guardrail.  I heard directly from him, that he had no 
brakes whatsoever at the end of his run.

This was several years ago, on an earlier generation of Bosch ABS than 
is now used by Porsche.

I've also heard reports that Carrera Cup racers a couple years ago 
wanted their ABS disabled.  They accomplished this by whacking a few 
curbs really hard as the race started; this upset the wheel sensors 
and/or ABS brain, so it self-shutdown, leaving 'regular" braking intact.

		Jim

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 10:23:19 -0500
From: DRIVERSEDG@aol.com
Subject: Re: COLOR GAUGE FACES

Well, we'de like to think they look preety cool.   At least they do on our
cars.

It really depends on what type you get.  There was a company out there making
peel-and-stick decals that went on the front of the oe face plate and they
kind of gave a bad name to color gauge faces.  But these have nothing to do
with those.  They are made from aluminum and are laser die-cut.  Once
installed, they look pretty awesome and give a much needed lift to an
otherwise bland black interior.  

If you look at the old classic race cars from the 50's and 60's you'll see
they came with white gauges as well.  They are simply easier to read.  You
never pick up a magazine with black pages and white letters, so why should
gauges be any different?

> entrants in drivers ed track events disconnect the their ABS.  If anyone is
> certain this is true, please let me know the particulars.  NNJR is not
> entertaining this idea, but we are trying to gather factual information.
Well, if any PCA regions go asking people to disable their ABS then 
that region, it's directors, and national PCA will have a *huge* 
liability on their hands.  I'd suggest *very strongly* to anyone 
involved with PCA that they NOT do this!

Where else in the car does PCA suggest/require removal of new 
technology that's safety related?  Nowhere, of course.  This is a 
really, really bad idea.

Dave Weber, any knowledge of this in PCA National?

> There is another rumor that  Porsche ABS and/or the braking system may fail
> to operate properly when a car is spinning backwards.  This does not make
> sense, but is the supposed basis for the region(s) disconnecting the ABS.
>  Any FACTS on this subject would also be appreciated.
I've heard of this too.  See my other message (just sent) with the 
story.  Sorry, no facts beyond those surrounding 1 driver's experience. 
 Maybe we should get a Bosch ABS rep. at Tech Tactics or the annual 
Parade to give a technology presentation and Q&A.

> The point that was discussed at length concerned the teaching of "in a spin,
> both feet in, wheel straight" .  Our 60+ instructors don't have ABS and/or
> have little or no experience spinning backwards.  As we all know, the ABS
> cars will at some point hook up and launch in unpredictable directions when
> spinning, but that is about as far as any of us go.
Gee, our instructors are much more experienced than yours in 
controlling backwards spins...  :-)

I feel that our teaching should continue with only _slight_ 
modification, since the physics of vehicles in motion remains the same 
with or w/o ABS.  We do need to add a section on ABS brake systems, how 
they operate, and how to use them effectively.

By way of background, I'm a PCA instructor, previously region track 
chair, I teach our region's annual track school, and I have an 
engineering background.

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 95 10:33 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: ABS Brake Bias -Reply

Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>, with his usual thouroughness, said:
    ABS gets its primary inputs from wheel motion sensors right next to the 
    brake rotors (advanced ABS systems may get other inputs, but wheel 
    movement is the key ingredient).  Software interpretation of relative 
    wheel motion is how ABS systems decide when to reduce pressure to a 
    brake channel.  All of this is derived from actual sensor input, not 
    any "guess".
[ Discussion of ABS design variables deleted ]
    ABS considers all the above things (and possibly more), and adjusts 
    brake line pressure in either 2 channels (cheap), 3 (most common - both 
    rears on 1 circuit), or 4 (most expensive, most rare) channels.  It 

So how does the new 5-channel ABS work?  Is there some sort of "Uberchannel"
that monitors the system as a whole?  Some sort of direct brain interconnect
that makes the driver slow down?

[ More interesting stuff sacrificed to the Gods of Bandwidth ]
    hitting the barrier and causing huge rear-end damage.  But it's 
    possible, as you suggest, that the ABS system went wacky and he lost 
    braking power while in reverse.  I've heard incidental reports of 
    exactly this on 2 occasions, once from a [now forgotten name] 
    professional racer who ran Lime Rock backwards in a 928.  He completed 
    the lap in something around 1:30, then tried to stop but couldn't, and 
    lightly tapped a guardrail.  I heard directly from him, that he had no 
    brakes whatsoever at the end of his run.

Anyone have any idea why ABS wouldn't function in reverse?  I would think that
the sensors would just count pulses as some specially-marked section(s) of the
wheel rotated past, and these would be counted no matter the direction of the
rotation.   Hmmm, unless there were two staggered sensors, such that one 
expected to trigger a microsecond after the other, hmmmm.....

Anyone with a *real* clue?

- -- Tracy Nelson
'87 944S w/o ABS or air bags

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 11:01:55 -0500
From: David944@aol.com
Subject: $ saving tip for AOL users

Just a quick idea, for those of you, who like me, seem to spend to much time
and $ reading and responding to mail through America On Line.

If you have not discovered the FlashSession feature(I just did), look into it.
  By using it, you only stay connected long enough to pick-up and drop off
files (at 14.4 less than 5 min a day)

To use:
Under MAIL select FlashSessions... Pick the "Walk me through it" option (You
need to at least configure it to Pick-up and Send mail)  Again under MAIL
select Activate FlashSession Now.  After it is set up the first time, it
dials into AOL, drops off any mail you have created off-line (under MAIL,
select COMPOSE MAIL without connection to AOL to create off-line) and picks
up all your new mail, then logs off.  You can then take all the time in the
world to browse through your mail (using the Read Incoming Mail option under
MAIL) without burning through money better spent on the important things,
like your car.

Hope this helps,

David944@aol.com
84 944 (You can only own ONE of these at a time if you live in NYC)

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 12:27:08 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Powerless 914


Dear John,

The year and engine size of your 914 matters! We assume that it is still
fuel-injected. Two things:

1. The backfire and "gutteral" sound could be the 1.8 Air Flow Meter flap
sticking and loading the engine.
2. 90 lbs compression is not good!
3. Usually lack of power is because the engine is running on less than four
cylinders. While the engine is idling, pull one spark plug wire at a time
from the distributor cap. This will localize the cylinder.

George Hussey

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 12:27:19 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Value of a 914

<I have a 75 914 in my shop and the owner would
<like a value of the car. The car is clean it has a rebuilt
<motor, a new transaxle\transmission, interior needs
<work and some odds and ends. It starts and runs
<excellent since I worked on it, repairing all the fuel
<injection systems. Also the car is for sale seems the owner
<lost interest. Any help would be appreciated.


Dear Wolfgang,

We certainly can value the car if you can answer the following: (in general)

1. Original paint?
2. Ever wrecked?
3. Miles known?
4. 1.8 or 2.0 engine?
5. Where is the rust? Is the battery standing tall?
6. Exterior hardware condition?
7. Interior condition? Dash cracked?
8. Factory options?
9. Air conditioning?
10. Clean and shiny paint under trunks?
11. Stock fuel injection?
12. Condition of power plant?

This is a good start!


George Hussey

Date: 07 Mar 95 22:44:26 EST
From: "Alan S. Watkins" <76030.40@compuserve.com>
Subject: AM Radio Wiring

Pierre Vezina wrote:

"Alongside the antenna wire there is a little black wire coming/going to/from
the antenna pre-amp.

	1 - Is this wire the power to the pre-amp coming from the radio? (on my
car this wire as been cut flush to the antenna wire sleeve).
	2 - If so, is it the usual +12V? (some odd model exist requiring +5V)"

My '86 928 has a radio antenna embedded in the windshield, and has a black wire
just as you describe running along the antenna coaxial cable.  Connecting that
wire to 12V allowed my Blaupunkt, which otherwise worked fine, to also receive
AM signals.  I connected it to the 12V output of the radio which is normally
used to turn on power amplifiers, etc.  That way the antenna amplifier is
powered only when the radio is turned on.

The wiring diagram in the 928 shop manual indicates this wire is white ("ws")
but it's not.  It's definitely black.


Alan Watkins

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 15:29:39 -0500
From: wise@db.erau.edu (John Wise)
Subject: Re: COLOR GAUGE FACES

DRIVERSEDG@aol.com said:

>>If you look at the old classic race cars from the 50's and 60's you'll see
>>they came with white gauges as well.  They are simply easier to read.  You
>>never pick up a magazine with black pages and white letters, so why should
>>gauges be any different?
______________________________

There is no empirical evidence in perceptual research that indicates that
positive or negative contrast is superior in term of reading speed,
accuracy, or difficulty.  The real issues are related to basic design
criteria (e.g., amount of contrast, visual angle, stroke width, height to
width ratio ...)  A designer can make either perfectly readable or
unreadable.  Also a design that is great in one environment (e.g., low
luminance) may be terrible in another (e.g., high luminance).  

My guess as to the issue of magazines using black on white has to do with
economics rather than any empirical studies in perception.  

Class dismissed.  

John A. Wise, Ph.D., CHFP
Associate Professor & Lead Research Associate


John A. Wise                                    Tel: (+1) (904) 226-6384
Center for Aviation/Aerospace Research          Fax: (+1) (904) 226-7050
Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University            E-mail: wise@db.erau.edu
600 South Clyde Morris Blvd.
Daytona Beach, FL 32114-3900   USA

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 14:38:45 -0600
From: ourios@zeus.wustl.edu
Subject: Non-factory keys for P-car alarms


My 911 also came with one alarm key, so I went to the local locksmith
and he found a "U.S. Lock Corp" key that fits perfectly and made two  
copies. The other side of the key says "S.LOCK" and U.S.A. and C & R.
I can not read the rest because the (round?) bigger head of the key
was ground by the same locksmith so that the key fits nicely on the 
just open door to activate/deactivate the alarm without scratching
the paint....

But you still need one good key to make the copies from.

(Theo)
Theodosios Korakianitis

Date: Wed, 08 Mar 95 16:32:15 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 roof

> Hello All:
> The roof on my 85 944 just went to pot.  I raised it and wouldnt
> lower, so I got the wretched srench out from the case on the motor
> and lowered it manually (not a pleasant experience) and put the
> adjusting screw back in place.  Now when I press the rais button I
> hear the motor whirring (thank god, not a burnt motor) but no dice
> it wont rais the roof, and when press down roof nothing.  I am
> figuring a busted realy, I know of 2 right by the roof motor in
> the hatch, which one would it be and how can u tell which one is
> busted (if any)? Any other relays in this circuit?

Hello, Babak,

The two relays that you see in the rear quarter are identical. If you 
swap them, and the symptom changes, then you might suspect that one of the
two is bad. Final determination of which one is bad is left as an exercise...

There is another relay located in the fuse block. It can be identified by
the raised letters spelling "Hedebach".

On the other hand, the symptom that you describe (motor whir, no roof
movement) tells me that you more likely have a drive problem. I would start 
by checking that the gear on the motor is not broken or that the retainer
clip has not allowed the gear on the motor to come loose.  

Most likely, you only have one problem which is causing the several
different symptoms...

good luck, 


- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ mhv.net
E-Mail: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Wed,  8 Mar 95 16:01:13 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: ABS Brake Bias -Reply

> From: Tracy M Nelson  <tnelson@telesciences.com>
> Subject: Re: ABS Brake Bias -Reply
> Date: Wednesday, March 8, 1995 10:33AM
>
[...]
> So how does the new 5-channel ABS work?  Is there some sort of "Uberchannel"
> that monitors the system as a whole?  Some sort of direct brain interconnect
> that makes the driver slow down?

Do you mean ABS 5?  If so, the "5" just means fifth generation, not 5 
channel.  Unless there's a new jargon out there, the word "channel" 
means a braking circuit that the ABS controls.

ABS wheel control is always equal in the front/rear sense, i.e. you'd 
never find diagonal ABS, though you can find diagonal hydraulic lines 
(sorry if this isn't clear).  So the valid combinations of ABS channel 
control are:

Channels	Wheels controlled
- --------	-----------------
1		Rear axle (pickup trucks, etc.)
2		Front axle, rear axle
3		Front left, front right, rear axle
4		Each wheel individually controlled (ideal but most expensive)

I forgot to mention 1 channel systems in my last posting.

So in a perfect system, a car with 4 individually controllable brake 
calipers could have at most, 4 channels.  The fifth channel, if there 
is even such a thing, likely just twits the driver's head via hydraulic 
action, as if to say "Come on dummy, watch it!".

		Jim

Date: 08 Mar 95 10:02:24 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Value of 356 speedster

 
$5500 for a serial number seems high, because that's what you're buying.
$2000 is about right for a parts coupe with a salvageable engine and trans
and maybe some suspension bits.
 
Unless you have lots of time and/or money, run away. This thing will be a
sinkhole for both. Better to buy one that is at least complete. If the
floor and longitudinals are gone, you need somebody who knows what they're
doing to put those in, or you're going to get a car that looks like somebody
put a floor and longitudinals in it.
 
Also consider all the time you're going to have to spend to find all the
missing hardware. Not worth it.
 
I've seen more complete Roadsters going in the mid-teens (also project cars
but at least most of the pieces were there.)
 
Pete

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 16:16:19 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: 914 steering wheels, or more mindless meanderings

>    All right, on to the subject of this post.  I have a stock
>slick'n'shiny 914 steering wheel.  I have no money to do anything about
(snip)

First option: Beg, beg, beg for a Momo steering wheel for your birthday.

If that doesn't work, whatever you don't, do NOT let yourself come into 
contact with one.
At the IMSA race at Watkins Glen last year, I made the mistake of going to 
the Momo display (in the paddock only, not open to the unwashed masses 
who don't buy paddock passes), and laying my hands upon a Momo Corse 
wheel, and I fell in love. To make a long story short, I now have a Corse 
wheel awaiting installation upon my 914 when spring breaks. (Black 
leather, red stitching to match the TRW Sabelt harnesses... Oo! Oo! Oo!) 
EXTREMELY nice.
And, for what it's worth, you can get one for less than you might think - 
some places in European Car, etc, sell the cheapie Momo wheel, the Monte 
Carlo, for only $130 or so, plus another... $50? maybe less for the mounting 
kit. It's worth it.

I never bothered trying to fix the non-functional horn in my 914 last 
summer, using that as an incentive to buy a new wheel. ("I'll fix it when I 
put the new wheel on!") Now I have to take the Fiamm air horns out of my 
Shelby... (With trumpets off an old Ferrari Dino... Ahhh! Beautiful noise.)

If you're really tight on a budget, perhaps you might want to look around the 
swap shows for a decent, grippy aftermarket Beetle steering wheel... I'm 
90% sure they are compatable. (Anyone know for sure?)


- --

| "General Lido" '85 Dodge Shelby Charger                   -Groucho Marx |

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 16:51:37 -0800
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: 914/6 Engine to 2.2E specs


I am rebuilding my "real" 914/6 motor to 2.2E specs.  I have some good "E"
cams, but since they were on a mechanically injected motor, the cam on the
right side (in a 914/6) is longer and requires some sort of seal on the cam
tower on that end.  The cam tower I have is tapped on the correct end. 

What I need is the retainer or bracket for capturing the seal required on that
end of the cam.  I haven't yet called the dealer since they probably want too
much.  Is anyone out there have a 69-73 motor in parts that has this piece and
would be willing to part with it for a modest sum?  I am in the Bay area.

Dan

Dswiger@qntm.com
Dswiger180@aol.com

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 17:34:25 -0800 (PST)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: Re: 944 roof

On Wed, 8 Mar 1995, babak marefat wrote:

> The roof on my 85 944 just went to pot.  I raised it and wouldnt
> lower, so I got the wretched srench out from the case on the motor
> and lowered it manually (not a pleasant experience) and put the
> adjusting screw back in place.  Now when I press the rais button I
> hear the motor whirring (thank god, not a burnt motor) but no dice
> it wont rais the roof, and when press down roof nothing.

I removed the screw once to raise the roof manually so I could remove it. 
When I put the screw back, I found that the motor whirled without moving
the roof. After much frustration and even removing the motor (made in US I
believe) I finally discovered that it was very critical how you tightened
the screw. After making sure the screw was very tight and secure, the roof
worked again. 

My only problem now is that SOMETIMES, the motor will keep whirling even 
when then roof is fully raised (when the switch is depressed). The motor 
always shuts off properly when the roof is lowered. How can this be adjusted?

Joe '86 944

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 21:15:53 -0500
From: DRIVERSEDG@aol.com
Subject: Re: COLOR GAUGE FACES

Thanks for your message.

You're right, the standard factory gauge lighting is pretty bad.  It's not
Porshe's main fault as VDO makes the instruments, but the buck stops with the
manufacturer for OKing it.

To get an idea if the white gauges are easier to read at night compared with
the black ones:  Shut the lights off in a room so there is very little
illumination, then try to read a white paper with black lettering and a
 black paper with white lettering.  See the difference?

Rick

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 19:58:02 -0700
From: cbardeen@csn.net (Charles Bardeen)
Subject: Roll Cages, Car Value, ...

I have a reasonable low milage (35K) 89 944 S2, that is in pretty good
condition. I would like to start autocrossing it and also be able to get
some driving time on a track (drivers schools, time trials, ...), but
haven't done either before.

I assume that PCA requires roll cages for track events. What other safety
equipement is required (besides a helmet)? How does installing a roll cage
effect the resale value of the car?  Does a it affect the available head
room? Can the cage be removed without marring the appearance of the car? Is
there much sheet metal work when installing a roll cage, and do you have to
be careful so that you don't provide a spot for rust to develop?

Would I be better off getting an older car for track stuff, and use my
current car only for personal use or autocrossing?

                                        Thanks for any opinions,

                                                Chuck

P.S. I assume that my initial practicing would best be done in
autocrossing, and then I can work my way up to track events.



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 19:27:13 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: 914 steering wheels, or more mindless meanderings

I put a Wheelskin leather steering wheel cover on my 914's steering wheel. 
But before I did, I lined the inside of the Wheelskin with 1/16" thick
dense black neoprene-like foam, with an adhesive backing. The result is
really very nice - not quite like a Momo wheel (like the one on my wife's
car), but still nice and grippy.  And cheap - $30 or so, plus a couple
hours in front of the TV or something while doing the near-mindless lacing.

 ________________________________________
|  Andrew E. Kalman     aek@netcom.com   |

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 21:33:32 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: Roll Cages, Car Value, ...

For autocrossing you do not need a roll bar(cage). For time trials in 
Northern Calif. you do not need a roll bar or cage if you stay in the 
"stock" class. For time trial you will need five point belts in both 
driver and passenger seats.

Like any other "racing" you need to get a set of the rules for where and 
what you want to run. The rules are the bibles for all this racing 
stuff.

				mike

Date: Wed, 8 Mar 1995 22:30:18 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: 914 steering wheels, or more mindless meanderings

Hi Nate. You asked:

>    Another happy pfiler has informed me that there is enough material
>on a wheelskin to attempt to cover the spokes... so that may be an
>option for me.  Where did you get your foam from?  Did you use the
>wheelskin for the 914 wheel or one with a thicker grip (because of the
>foam?)
    
I got my foam ages ago - I think it was from the local "House of Foam"
(Yes, it exists, it's on Hamilton Ave in Palo Alto).  Note: if you choose
to use foam under the Wheelskin, _make sure you use only one piece_.  If
you use more than one piece (i.e. there's a butt joint between two pieces
of foam), it's bound to show up as a "valley" on the surface of the
wheelskin.

I ordered the standard one for the 914 (either from Zim's or GPR), and with
(or without) the foam it's a very snug slipover fit, but it works.
Wheelskins is at 800-755-2128 and they are very helpful. I think their
proposed method of lacing is poor, though, and you should experiment with
some better ones. Some pfile addressed this at length a while back.

HTH,

 ____________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman   aek@netcom.com  | 
|____________________________________         
| "Responsibility, not process, is   |
|   the key ingredient to action."   |  
|                                    |
| Phillip K. Howard in               |
|  "The Death of Common Sense"       |
 ____________________________________

Porschephiles #1227                         Thu Mar 9 14:41:31 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 9 Mar 1995 08:50:19 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@ilab.mitre.org>
Subject: Re: Powerless 914


The problem with my brother's 914 has evidently been solved - his last
email follows. Thanks for the various suggestions. What I want to know
is, where do you get mufflers that last 24.5 years?

- ----

A few more clues.  When I removed the sparkplugs in order to check the 
compression (I had cleaned them earlier) they were sooty black.  Seems the 
mixture was much too rich.  It occurred to me that maybe there was some 
obstruction to intake air flow in the oil bath  air cleaner, so I took the 
aircleaner off and tried the car again.  No improvement in power but the 
low, gutteral engine note was much louder.  When I put my ear near the 
intake and revved the engine it sounded almost like an exhaust note.
On the basis of the informatin you sent yesterday I disconnected the hose 
from the intake manifold to the pressure sensor and sucked on it (nice clean 
tubeing,  I'd replaced it the day before).  It seemed to hold a vacuum fine. 
 When I started the engine it ran much worse than yesterday.  It wouldn't 
idle and would hardly rev at all.  So I took off the muffler.  Voila! 
Instant power.  Problem solved.  That lettle backfire must have been 
something letting loose in the  25 year old muffler.  In the 914 all of the 
exhaust is eventually channeled into a single approx 24 inch long fairly 
small pipe.  Something, a baffle or ? must have broken loose with near 
complete obstruction of the entire exhaust.  I guess the loud noise from the 
intake was exhaust coming out the intake valves.  Wierd.  I banged on the 
muffler but nothing fell out or rattled around.  Boy is it loud.


- -----

 -John White-
'84 928S
