Date: Thu, 9 Mar 1995 08:30:05 -0700
From: clandt@lib.nmsu.edu (Christopher Landt)
Subject: RE: 959s


I believe that Bill Gates of Microsoft has one. It is not certain if it is
still in a warehouse or he has snuk it out. Maybe if your real lucky and
living in Seattle you'll get a glimps.

Also there are hundereds of replicas in the Los Angeles area alone. I
travel there quite often and they are like flies. Some are real nice
replicas... I had to take a second look once or twice. Haven't seen a real
one in America yet myself.

Though in 1987 I took a trip to The Homeland and visited Zuffenhausen. Boy
what a treat. I counted 24 at the factory alone. They had them staked up
like bricks. Parked all over the place. 

There is nothing quite like a 959.

Christopher A. Landt
1986 944 turbo
1988 FURD P-UP
"I will own a 959..."

Date: Thu, 9 Mar 1995 11:20:16 -0500
From: StreakN@aol.com
Subject: Re: 959s


> Question, does anyone have a good idea how many 959s are on >the road in
the
>country - both legit and otherwise?
> Ran into a guy that told me he just bought Ralph Lauren's and >there are
>plenty out there.  Last I knew there were supposed to be 3.
 
>Bill O'Connell - Riesentoter Region, PCA

In the process of securing a street title for my HD XR-750TT, I got into a
fairly interesting discussion with a man who claims to have done the
- --legal-- documentation for 4 959's. He claims that these are the only 959's
that are street legal and has the mountains of legal work to prove it. He
also said that in the next few months, we would see magazine articles about
the cars and one is currently offered for a princely $2 million. We agreed
that a used 956 or 962, at less than a tenth of that, is a much better value
and that the current owner was out of his mind asking that much. Supposedly
Jerry Seinfeld was interested but was balking at the price. 
Now I don't know if this is true, but I didn't want the facts to get in the
way of a good story.

seven spoke forged alloys which were standard on my car are painted/clearcoat, 
polished/clearcoat or anodized/clearcoat as delivered from the factory.  The 
finish makes a difference on the repair cost with the anodized/clearcoat being 
the most expensive.

Borbet from the Tire Rack.  Anyone have a comments or suggestions or know of 
wheels for sale.  Please reply directly to me to save bandwidth.  Any comments

sunroof, etc. for $7750 here in Southern California. It needed a clutch cable
and minor tuning, but he looked at several in the $7500-10000 price range.
Granted, it's not a Carrera 3.0, but it's not twice the price, either.

with the first two months of '94.  Porsche sales are up 119%.  Across the
industry, U.S. car and light truck sales are down 3.1%  With this surge in

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Mar 95 09:47:53 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 914 brakes and ABS


The 914 brake system has a proportioning valve located on the lower firewall
(below the engine sheetmetal) accessable from the bottom of the car on the
driver's side. Historically, this little gem has been known to trap a large 
amount of air. If you are replacing a master cylinder or any  rear brake 
hoses or the calipers, you must bleed the proportioning valve also.

This is accomplished by first bleeding all the calipers and getting pedal. 
Then you must (as the valve has no bleeder) break the connecting nuts on the 
lines to bleed the valve. First do the line leaving the valve, then the input 
line. I highly recommend this be done MANUALLY to get enough pressure to make 
the valve move. 

If you are having problems with the rear brakes working correctly, the 914/4
rear calipers MUST BE manually adjusted to have about .008" (.2mm) clearance
between the brake pad and the rotor. The hex adjustment bolts are under a 
plastic cap for the outer pad and a special hex cap for the inner, accessable 
through the trailing arm. This information is available in the old Clymer's
914 manual which is being reprinted by another firm.


ABS. Not all systems are equal, even with the Bosch systems. The issue is 
the sampling rate of the computer. The Porsche unit will work fine in almost
all conditions. It is possible to brake at a rate hard enough cause the 
airbag to deploy. This has occured on the track, probably the reason the early
944 Escort cars didn't have them (Yeah, they add a lot of weight, too). I have
abused a system or two and have found no ill effects or defects when using
all of the brakes. The ABS made virtually no difference in the handling
and did make the car (a 928) feel much more stable in some corners where the 
weight transfer made things dicey.

Most of us aren't able to get the extra tenth (the eleventh? per G. Hill) out
of our driving so we will never be able to subjectively tell the difference.
Pete Albrecht does enough testing of cars to know the difference, I'd trust 
his opinion on the subject.

Why ABS? ABS is an easy way to mask the problems associated with excessive 
weight transfer of a front engined car. ESPECIALLY front wheel drive cars. 
The weight bias is near 60% on many US and Japanese cars with FWD. This makes 
the rears virtually useless when nailing the brakes hard. Couple this with
icy or inclimate weather and you have some big lawsuits on the horizon. The
added benefit of the ABS electronics is the so-called traction control 
feature. FWD cars have a big problem putting more than 225 HP through the 
front wheels. The traction control feature allows the manufacturers to put more
horsepower in and then tailor a curve to prevent Joe Average from exceeding 
the performance envelope, maybe damaging himself in the process. 

Ralph Nader and his minions are still alive and insideously foisting 
electronic monitoring into motor vehicles. ABS really works, a torson 
differential provides better traction control at a far lower price (when 
installed on the production line).

Jim Pasha

details.  Included, of course, was the requisite picture of me
standing in front of the thing so I could prove to my car-nut buddies
I had really seen a "live" 959.

Date: Thu, 9 Mar 1995 13:21:50 -0600
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Fat Fingers *AGAIN*...

I didn't watch what directory I was in, and oooops, managed to delete a
ton of files inadvertently. Not to worry, they're on backup, right?
Well, no. They're not. I'd moved them to a part of the file system that
had previously been static and as a result "didn't need to be backed up".

So, having spent some time finding and fixing all that, it's now time to
give you the really bad news: 

If you had sent me comments on the Porschephiles Foundation idea, or requests 
to be listed at a charter member of the Electronic Frontier Region, I no 
longer have your mail. **DON'T RESEND THIS DIRCTLY TO ME, READ ON!!**

If you had responded to any of the "for sale" notices I've posted, and 
we have any business transactions pending (i.e. you're inquired, and I
haven't responded or you said you want it and I haven't shipped it)
then I no longer have your mail.

If you find that there's something "hanging" with me, in particular if
I'm supposed to get back to you about something, I probably no longer
have your mail.

So, if you fall into any of those groups, or if you just want to harrass me,
you'll need to resend it.

For comments or suggestions on the EFR or Porschephiles Foundation, send
your notes to "comments@tta.com".

To indicate your interest in the EFR, send your notes to "efr@tta.com".

For anything else, I guess send it to me...

Stan
s.

Date: Thu, 09 Mar 1995 13:59:00 -0500 (EST)
From: PAUL SOUZA 202-260-6061 <SOUZA.PAUL@epamail.epa.gov>
Subject: Frozen pilot bearing-result


          A couple of days ago I asked about a frozen pilot bearing on a 
          clutch of an 83 944 (not mine unfortunately :( ).  Here's the 
          result:
          
          The original plan was to start the car in 1st and then "slam it"
          into 2nd (dealer's words).  All of you wrote back with your 
          experiences and most added an important fact - Keep The Clutch 
          In!  The dealer forgot to add that little bit of info......it 
          probably saved the trans.
          Man!
          It worked!  It really worked!  Many thanks to all of you who 
          responded with their suggestions and experiences.   And here was 
          the picture I was presented with when we tried it yesterday 
          morning:
          
          After a little gas on gas off, the bearing unfroze with little 
          effort.  I got out of the drivers seat and my friend jumped in.  
          He sort of had that evil/gleeful look in his eyes (reminded me of 
          Damien when he got on his tricycle in "The Omen").  He took off 
          out of the parking lot and turned off out of sight.  It started 
          to rain.  Hard.  I walked to the edge of the parking lot and 
          peered down the street.......I see the Guards red 944 driving 
          towards me and I notice the window is rolled down.  The car is 
          not slowing down.   Then I hear:  "YES! YES! YES! HAHAHAHAHA 
          HAHAHAHAAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA" and then the car flies by me.  It's 
          still raining.  Still hard.  Boy, just wait until mine is 
          finished, I'll show him...............(fade to black)
          
          Damien thanks you.
          
          Ciao,  Cello
          '57 356A

I haven't seen the ad... Was it a 959 or one of the new 911's.  They look
almost the same from a front end shot. Those carpet ads that use a 911
throw me every time. I think the car is a 959 at first.

If it was a 959 I would almost bet it was a replica. I know he is an advid
Porsche fan. A real nice replica is better than none at all. One 959 rep. I
saw was in the long beach area. I had to look twice. Eveything was perfect,
just like I remembered from the factory when I visited. The final clue to
me was the stearing wheel. No 959 logo. And it was missing the important
dials on the console. Underneath is also a giveaway. I can tell a 911 turbo
from the bottom anytime. But the rest of this car was spactacular. Not one
flaw.

I don't think I have ever seem or heard of a "Original" 959 anywhere free
roaming America. Though now that I remember it There was an add for a 959
for sale from Santa Fe New Mexico, Very close to where I live. Never seen
it though. There are a lot of movie stars that have places there. Robert
Reddford owns a place and drives a 911 turbo convertable. Midnight blue.
When I saw it in a parking lot near a studio he was in I noticed that the
guy did not even lock it.

So who's to tell what is hidden in those mountains near Santa Fe.

Christopher A. Landt

1988 FURD P-UP

Date: Thu, 9 Mar 95 15:47:14 EST
From: sdandeka@chipcom.com (Shirish Dandekar)
Subject: DME Software

A few weeks back I had a question about the HP differences between the 84-86
carrera and 87-89 carrera. Most of the responses I got indicated it was due
to a software (prom) change/upgrade for the DME. The HP gain was attributed
to the assumption that Super unleaded gas was being used. 

Looking at some 911 performance catalogs I noticed that all of the companies 
list different chips for software "upgrades" for those model years. I would 
assume that if the DME electronics were the same and only the software was 
different then there would be only one common part number for the software 
upgrades. Most company would perfer to stock only one part if they were 
compatible and an had equal level of performance. Since this isn't the case 
I'm not convinced that the software was the only difference.

Has anyone tried to simply "plug in" a later mode carrera's prom into the
earlier 911's DME? Have they noticed any horse power gains?

If anyone could shed some light on this subject please let me know.

Thanks.

	-RISH-

<sdandeka@chipcom.com>

------------------------------

Porschephiles #1228                         Thu Mar 9 20:32:54 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 9 Mar 1995 16:27:42 -0500
From: JohnT26@aol.com
Subject: 911 Front hub dust cap removal??

Porschephiles:
I'm replacing the front discs on my 1984 911.  I can't get the axle hub/dust

Date: Thu,  9 Mar 95 13:18:29 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: paint codes for 944 Turbo S

| From: stephen davies  <cbt@eduplus.ca>
|
| I recently bought a 1988 944 Turbo S. It requires some minor touch ups
| around the fender wells. Nobody around here seems to know the paint code
| for the silver rose metalic paint. Can anyone help ?

There should be a paint code sticker on the back of the hatch area,
under the carpeting between the hatch latches. Unsnap the carpet and
look above the spare tire.

    Eric, '84 944

P.S. looking for a used 944 harness bar, used TRW or Simpson harness,
and perhaps a used Recaro A-8 or similar sports seat.

Date: Thu, 9 Mar 1995 17:04:07 -0500
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Track Driving Question

Hello Fellow Track Drivers:

I am getting prepared to drive at the Connecticut Valley Region Driver Ed even
t at Lime Rock Park on 4/14. I was re-reading parts of the Watt's (Let's not
start another 'who's Henry Watts' thing) book, and I have a question about
one of his statements.

In one part of the book he says that on a race track you should either be on
the throttle hard, or on the brake hard. How are you supposed to do that in
Big Bend at Lime Rock, or the hairpin at Bridgehampton, or other relatively
long, tight turns? In my car (86 844, normally aspirated), after getting the
braking done for Big Bend, and starting the turn in (with a little trail braki
ng), when I start to accelerate, if I accelerate hard, I run out of track
before the esses. Instead of heavy throttle coming out of big bend, I have to
modulate the throttle, and I can only put it down about 1/2 way out of the
turn. What should I be doing? Should I brake longer before accelerating? Not
accelerate as hard? Would a car that was more set up for the track, as far as
tires, springs, shocks, brakes, etc, be more "on throttle, or on brakes" than
my completely stock car?. 

Thanks for your advice

Barry Lenoble
BLenoble

Date: Thu, 9 Mar 1995 17:36:11 -0500 (EST)
From: "Gerald G. MacDonald - Thomas Cooley Law School" <macdonag@mlc.lib.mi.us>
Subject: Re: 1984 911 Targa


Rish,

I bought an 84 Targa last summer (with 51k miles on it) (with the 
substantial help of this collective group of experts).  Problems I had to 
resolve included a seeping left cam tower line (no big deal); a burned 
out a/c switch (still not fixed because I prefer the top off which is why 
I bought a Targa to begin with); a burned out antenna motor (my next 
posting to the list - for help in acquiring and replacing this); and a 
top that is beginning to show its age and useage (tears forming along the 
folds).  I did have a leak in heavy rain (with the car parked) aound the 
drivers side window (top of the "fin" window) but I assume when I have the 
top redone this will disappear.  The car is great fun.  I know the clutch 
had just been replaced 1000 miles before my purchase so you might want to 
look at that. 

glad to see so many folks on the list with the 84 Carreras!

Good luck.  Be careful and have a good pre-ourchase inspection done - 
it's well worth the money.

Jerry Mac
84 911 Carrera Targa (Cognac Brown)[in hibernation . . . still :-(]

Date: Thu, 09 Mar 95 18:07:16 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Track Driving Question

> Hello Fellow Track Drivers:
> 
> I am getting prepared to drive at the Connecticut Valley Region Driver Ed eve
> t at Lime Rock Park on 4/14. I was re-reading parts of the Watt's (Let's not
> start another 'who's Henry Watts' thing) book, and I have a question about
> one of his statements.
> 
> In one part of the book he says that on a race track you should either be on
> the throttle hard, or on the brake hard. How are you supposed to do that in
> Big Bend at Lime Rock, or the hairpin at Bridgehampton, or other relatively
> long, tight turns? In my car (86 844, normally aspirated), after getting the
> braking done for Big Bend, and starting the turn in (with a little trail brak
> ng), when I start to accelerate, if I accelerate hard, I run out of track
> before the esses. Instead of heavy throttle coming out of big bend, I have to
> modulate the throttle, and I can only put it down about 1/2 way out of the
> turn. What should I be doing? 

Sounds like you're going fast enough to experience the dreaded understeer of
a stock 944.  What you're going to have to do is ask your instructor how to
get your car to turn in a bit better at the second part of Big Bend, so that
you can hit the apex properly. (Hint: you have to transfer the weight of the
car to the front wheels a bit, typically by throttle management or a bit of
left foot braking while staying on the gas...)

>Should I brake longer before accelerating? 

Probably not. Big Bend requires that you have the car stable during the
turnin. What works for me is getting the car slowed down from the straight,
starting the turnin, then accelerating to the second turnin, braking (I
know, the 911 guys say you can't do that in the middle of a turn) and then
balancing the car through the second part of Big Bend, lifting for a split
second to make the apex, then full acceleration into the braking area for
the left-hander in the esses.

> Not accelerate as hard? 

In a 944, the key is maintaining as much momentum as you can. Inasmuch as
the power is limited, you have to accelerate as hard as you can, as long as
you can, and as often as you can.

> Would a car that was more set up for the track, as far as
> tires, springs, shocks, brakes, etc, be more "on throttle, or on brakes" than
> my completely stock car?. 

You'll have to ask one of the racers that question. Perhaps some of the ITS
racers in the audience... (Nathan, Kevin???)  I will say, though, that if
you want to be faster, you're going to have to upgrade your brakes from
stock and invest in some good race rubber.

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ mhv.net
E-Mail: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net

> for $6k, and a concourse car for $20k.  Pretty wild prices.
> 
> Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara)

I'd bump these numbers a couple of grand each.  This is a very rare beastie,
both an S model, and a soft window'd targa.

IFF the paint is nice and the interior is not ratty, AND the heater works,
AND there are no tranny or engine problems;  This car could be worth $17-25K.

If it needs some work, take the rough price of the work needed to be done,
multiply it by 1.2 and subtract that from $17500.

IE: needs new paint ($5000*1.2==$6000) -> $11,500
  & needs new synchros 1st & 2nd ($1300*1.2==$1560) -> 9940
  & needs new interior ($800*1.2==$9600 -> $8980

     Except for, oh, a Ferrari F-40 or something....I'd have a hard time

  for as little as $225k used. Rant and rave about whose best, but the
  F40 has sold over 800 copies. Porsche could have made a killing in
  the late 80's if they'd federalized the 959. Ferrari is all grins over the
  money they made on the F40....

     My 2 brushes with 959s in the US are;
    1. Seeing one from afar in the Houston Ferrari dealership showroom.
       Those rich folks who get 330P3s, Barchettas and the like need
       somewhere to show them off, the Ferrari dealer usually has something
       on display only. That 959 was surely on temporary visa to the US....

    2. I met Arnold, the guy who designed the Getty 959 copy. He was best
       man at Mike H's wedding. Mike drove away in his 3.2l twin plug,
       webered, GE-80'd and Lockheed-stopped 914 Chalon. I always cry at
       weddings...

Date: Thu, 9 Mar 1995 19:01:28 -0500
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Braided Brake Lines

Stan,

I read your warning on stainless braided brake lines with great interest.
 Since these lines are used in aircraft, and now are standard in the
refrigeration industry, are we getting inferior quality?  The lines used in
refrigeration must withstand significant vibration, heat, dirt, and pressure
in excess of 200 psi, 24 hours a day for at least 10 years.  Is automotive
use more severe than this?  From your warning, I take it that we should
replace our brake lines every year.  Better still to not use them?  What
about the seldom used Street/Track car?  Thanks for any more information you
can provide.

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

 

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Mar 1995 19:01:33 -0500
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: Bust brake bleed niples


From: kh@wg.icl.co.uk (Kevin Hughes)
To: porschephiles@tta.com

>HELP!

>In my infinite wisdom I decided to change the fluid in my 911 Turbo. I found
>one of the rear bleed nipples had sheered - not me, a previous owner. On
>checking the rest it looks like I will end up with 3 sheered out of 8. So
how
>do you get the little ******s out? New nipples are expensive(!) new calipers
>are rediculously expensive. All suggestions much appreciated.

>Kevin

Kevin,

They do make "ez-out" drills that you can use to unscrew the broken nipple.
 You have to drill a small hole in the fitting, and then the ez-out has a
reverse flute that will grab the inside of the hole and back out the fitting.
 If that doesn't work, you will have to carefully drill out the fitting.  Use
increasing size drill bits to drill down the center of the fitting, past the
threads.  BE CAREFULL NOT TO DRILL INTO WHERE THE FITTING SEATS IN THE
CALIPER. Eventually, you will get to the thread diameter, and then you can
pick out the rest of the fitting with a dentist's pick. GOOD LUCK!

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer


------------------------------

Date: Thursday, 9 March 1995 5:25pm MT
From: MARTENS%emc2@ccsvm.stortek.com
Subject: RE:959 sightings

Pfellow Pfiles,
               last year at the Porsche Car Clubs of Australia National
meeting Easter (similar to Porsche Parade) Peter Bartells, boss of
Coles-Myer brought along 2 cars. One was his 959 with tourist plates,
from Switzerland.  He had it out here for 16 months and was due to ship
it back to the Swiss shortly thereafter.  We too have funny laws about
ADR's (Aust. Design Rules = DOT ) and the car would comply, but, there
is always a BUTT, the Aussie government only want approx $2,000,000
import duties and sales taxes for him to have the privilege of
driving it here.  He prefers to do a quarterly visit to Europe and
drive it on the limitless autobahns.
The other car was an early 356 GS 1600 Carrera fully restored, this
was his entered car in the Nationals.  The 959 was to use his exact words
"the support vehicle".  I thouroughly enjoyed drooling over it like
every other afficianado there,
Joe Martens
'86 944

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Mar 1995 19:53:43 -0500
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: Track Driving Questn (long)

From: BLenoble@aol.com
To: porschephiles@tta.com

>Hello Fellow Track Drivers:

>I am getting prepared to drive at the Connecticut Valley Region Driver Ed
event at Lime 
>Rock Park on 4/14. In one part of the book he says that on a race track you
should either 
>be on the throttle hard, or on the brake hard. How are you supposed to do
that in Big Bend 
>at Lime Rock, or the hairpin at Bridgehampton, or other relatively long,
tight turns? 

Barry,

     I have to agree with what George says, and I wanted to add a few
comments of my own. I have found that any car not setup with terminal
oversteer, 911's included, can be balanced on the brakes.  The line that I
preferred to use in Big Bend was to brake and turn-in early at the first
apex, and accelerate at full throttle across the track towards the outside
edge.  Then brake again while turning the car into the second apex.  As soon
as the car turns in (and before the rear gets loose) feed in full throttle
and accelerate across the second apex up to the left hander.  Brake hard,
turn-in and feed in full throttle through the right hander and down no-name
straight!  This technique worked in both my 914 and my 911.  I set several
track records there during Time Trials in the late 80's and early 90's. Trust
me, it works.  I also found that if you trail brake way into the hairpin at
Bridgehampton, you can get the rear to start to drift, and then give it full
power all the way around.

     As far as having a setup car better able to handle full throttle, the
answer is YES.  If your car is adjusted to be fairly neutral, then it can be
driven "flat out" in most turns.  By this I mean, brake up to the turn (and
maybe into it *trail brake*), turn-in while lifting off of the brakes, and as
soon as the rear of your car starts to get "nervous", plant the tail by
feeding in full throttle, and shoot past the apex, out to the trackout point,
and down the next straightaway.  If you can't do this on 90% of the turns,
either your car has too much understeer, has unbelievable horsepower (350+),
or you are apexing way too early!  What a stiffer suspension will do is to
make the transition (weight shift) from braking to throttle happen much
faster, and it will also make the car much quicker on side to side
transitions.  Finally, a stiffer suspension will keep the tires planted better
, and reduce unwanted camber change to help improve the overall grip of your
car.  Hope that helped!

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Mar 1995 20:31:19 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914/6 Engine to 2.2E specs

Dan,

You said:
>What I need is the retainer or bracket for capturing the seal required on
>that end of the cam.

There is no retainer for the seal. It simply is driven into place and is
retained by press fit. The screwholes are for the sheetmetal that surrounded
the pulley for the fuel injection pump drive.

I've seen people simply cut off the drive end of the cam. You don't need it
with carbs, and you'd eliminate a potential for leaks. Hacksaw works great!

Jon Lowe

Date: 09 Mar 95 21:28:22 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 959s

 
The 959 is interesting and rare and all that, but I suspect the price will
be coming down somewhat from the (claimed) 2 million. OK, so you get snob
appeal, but Porsche introduced a better car just this past Tuesday -- the
new Turbo. 405 horsepower, sequential twin turbocharging, all wheel drive,
(sound familiar?), plus the more modern, more capable suspension of the 993,
and priced I think a bit above 100K. And US legal. It would be interesting to
see which is faster on the track, but I would place my bets on the new Turbo
and not on the 8 or 10 year old design. Tuners are probably already planning
3.8 liter versions etc. I would like to see what Alois Ruf can do with this
one.
 
Pete

Date: Thu, 09 Mar 1995 14:33:05 -0500
From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: Broken 944 Sunroof

Babek writes:
>adjusting screw back in place.  Now when I press the rais button I
>hear the motor whirring (thank god, not a burnt motor) but no dice
>it wont rais the roof, and when press down roof nothing.  I am
>figuring a busted realy, I know of 2 right by the roof motor in

ruling out the switch, narrowed it down to the plastic gears which move the
forks up and down.

procedure I wrote to do this.

RickSH sez:
>I have an '87 951 and it has ABS (standard), dual air bags (standard), 
>and a limited slip differential (optional). 

ABS was definitely an option, at least in the US, I don't know about ROW cars.
Check the option list in your spare wheelwell, you should find '593' listed.
Option Code 593 is ABS, it listed for 2,135 big ones (US$) in May 1987.

Date: Thu, 09 Mar 1995 19:13:37 -0800
From: emn@llnl.gov
Subject:  re: 959s

Another 959 story:

About six years ago, I was having my 912 aligned at the famous-but-now-closed Garretson's in
Mountain View, California.  Since I was a newbie and wanted to learn, I had struck a deal with
friend/mechanic Gordon Ledbetter,  who agreed to stay late to let me watch and help.   

Way in the back of the shop, on the last hydraulic lift, next to Gordon's 935 project engine, was a 
*gasp* REAL 959!!   Needless to say, I was astonished.  Gordon was very low-key about it, as was
everybody else in the shop, including Jerry Woods, who was servicing the silver jewel.  Seems that
they were trying to avoid attracting attention to it.  Gordon explained that it was a quasi-legal import
that had been brought into the States before the EPA/DOT embargo.  Although they wouldn't
identify the owner, I later heard speculation from some PCA folks that it may have belonged to a
Hewlett or a Packard.  

I got a good close look at it, and it had evidence of being driven hard:  road grit on the
undercarriage, significant tire wear, etc.  It was explained to me that Jerry Woods was one of the
only people in the Bay Area "qualified" to service the beast, having experience working on 956 /
962's.  I was gushing about what it must be like to drive such a car,  when Gordon calmly
interjected "Oh, it drives OK".  Turns out that they had all taken turns test-driving the car! 
Unfortunately, no offers to drive the car were extended to me.  Sigh.

If any Bay-Area porschephiles can add details to this story, please feel free.

Eric Nichols
1967 912 Light Ivory
1992 Honda Civic Si

Date: Thu, 9 Mar 1995 23:32:40 -0500
From: Nineleven@aol.com
Subject: Broken cruise control 

Someone recently requested info on a cruise control problem which caused it
to stick in the full throttle or "Cruise Missle Mode". I had the same problem
with my' 87 Carerra and would like to offer my $.02. The first time it
happened to me I was heading up the New Jersey turnpike on the way to my
first track event. Traffic was thick and annoying so I decided to use the
cruise control and go with the flow. Imagine my surprise when upon activation
my car took off in dense traffic under full throttle! What was also a little
spooky was the feeling of the gas pedal being sucked to the floor as if by
some demonic spirit. Fortunately just stepping on the brake deactivates the
cruise mode. Later upon investigation I discovered that the cruise control
system is composed of two parts. The first is a brushed aluminum box slightly
smaller than a VHS videocassette which is mounted under the dash near the
radio with an electrical connector attached to it. The second part of the
system is a cylindrical aluminum unit in the engine compartment which the
throttle line passes thru. In my case just changing the electrical component
in the car's interior solved the problem. I was lucky enough to find one at a
swap meet for $15 whole dollars. A great bargain IMHO, especially since a new
one costs around a couple of hundred$. As always YMMV, I hope that this works
for you.

Alan Halpern- nineleven@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 09 Mar 1995 23:42:42 -0400 (EDT)
From: GLOPEZ@miavx1.acs.muohio.edu
Subject: Re: 959


Since the list seems to be on a 959 roll, I just like to add my own experience,
my girlfriend's father and soon to be my father in law, bought a 959 from the
factory when it was presented at the IAA in Germany, I got to drive in it a
couple of times, and even to steer it while it was pushed into a garage (hey I
was only 17 and dreaming), I remember that the first time I saw the car I was
in awe, but when I took a look at the interior I was disappointed, it looked
almost like a regular Carrera xecept for the blueish-green color and of course
the speedometer!!! What an acceleration! That car was awesome, since then my
my girl-friends father has gone over to the ennemies going from a Countach to a
Ferrari 512 TR, but in his opinion no other exotic ever was as driveable as the
959, and he regrets to have sold it. By the way I think that there are more
than 10 959's in the country, although not all might be legal. 


                                Gerard. 

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 10 Mar 1995 00:05:37 -0500
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: 67S Softwindow Targa

I think I may have missed the original message on this, but for what it's
worth, I agree with Miq on pricing, but I also have the same concerns Lance
has concerning rust - if there is no documentation of a past restoration, I
find it hard to believe a CT car w/98k miles is really rust free.  Check it
very closely!  Great car to own though, if all the original stuff is there
and in good condition! Also, while this may be restating the obvious, make
sure the serial number of the car shows it to be an S Targa (500 001S -
500718S), that the trans & engine have an internal designation stamping of
901/02, that the carbs are Weber 40IDS, that front and rear brakes are early
vented, and that the car has front and rear factory sway bars.
Good Luck,
PhilVB
66 911, 67 911S Coupe

Date: Fri, 10 Mar 1995 07:47:13 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Fat-tired 951

Steve writes,
>You mentioned success with 275/40ZR17. Can you 'feel' that you have more
grip?
>Did you have to roll fender, did it rub only at 9'0 clock position?  I'm 
>running 245/45 and 255/40 D40M2 now but will be going to 235/45 and 275/40
BFG
>on Gotti 8" and 9" wheels.  I don't think BFG has 245 size in 17".  Did you 
>post sometime ago that they're coming out with this size. 

Steve,
I had no trouble with rubbing in the rear what so ever. My fenders, however
are factory rolled as all the Turbo S models. Some people have reported
rubbing with my setup but it seems to be a function of ride height more than
anything,
My only outing with this arrangement was at Sebring, a track that was new to
me, so my frame of reference as far as stick is concerned is subjective. I
also put some real swaybars (30mm and 22mm) on over the winter so I had to
deal with oversteer. I eliminated that by stiffening the front shocks, since
I have the luxury of them being easily adjustable.
All and all the car hooked up great and inspired confidence. As soon as I get
to a track that I am familiar with I can give you something quantitative.
BFG is coming out with 245 x 40 x 17 tires. I don't know if they are
available yet. I am inclined to try the 255's.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
7:36 am

Date: Fri, 10 Mar 1995 07:53:24 -0500
From: PerryS7342@aol.com
Subject: RE: 959's....

Shortly after the Porsche announcement on availability of customer cars, I
received a letter from the Porsche AG offering a new 959.  Why I got the
letter I don't know, perhaps as a long time owner,
Christophorus subscriber, or a discussion I'd had in Werks 1 looking at them
after the Frankfurt IAA.  ( I got about the same type followup a few years
before on  the 924 GTR).

As I remember, the letter offered the car in the choice of three colors (Red,
Black, Pearl White) for approximately $449,000 US (variable with exchange
rate) FOB Stuttgart.  It also indicated there was no intent to export the car
and any subsequent use, licensing, and customs fees outside of Germany were
the responsibility of the buyer.  It asked for a $50,000 nonrefundable
deposit with the order.  Further it indicated that delivery times were 12-18
months, but in the interim, the buyer would receive a 1/43 Scale 959 model
"handcrafted by an Italian master-modeler".  It also indicated that if you
wanted the model but did not want the real car, it was available for a mere
$4500, "6 months delivery".

Needless to say, I have neither....

Perry

  '87 911 Targa [Guards-Red/Black]  | RedAcorn@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 10 Mar 1995 09:26:12 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: 944 valve job

>From talking to the mechanicn, he claims that only the
intake valves are bent , the valve guides o are ok, but
the valve guide seals will be replaced. 

He couldn't see any extra work he could do for me. Thats
a good sign I suppose . The claim is that most of the stuff one 
might want to have a look at is in the other 75% of teh engine that
is not apart. 

Now I know why I dont do my own engine work :-)
===================================
Paul, having bent a couple of valves myself, I would say that if the car
was running fine before the incident, and was not burning oil, then the
minimun work for him would be to replace the bent valves and replace the seals.

The seals are part of the head gasket kit. 

Some things to check while you have the head out (including the intake manifold)are the idle control valve under the IM. It usually gets gunked.
Also it is impossible to replace the oil cooled seals without removing the
head/exhaust manifold. I don't recall the year of your car. But I know that
some years (86 & 87?) had cooler seal problems.

Finally, do any of your cam seals leak? It is a realtively easy job to do
once you have the engine apart. And you have to take it apart to get to
the valves. How are your belts and rollers and water pump? 

My 944 is almost all apart (head will come out tonight). I had some balance
shaft bearing noises. And guess what? The lower BS cover has one bolt
that will not come out unless you remove the exhaust manifold or EM/head
combination. 

Hope this helps...

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories     len@library.att.com	   201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa  / '85 Guards Red 944
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo / '88 Silver BMW 325is

driving (for how long?) and then a rest period of 24hrs considered a heat cycle?

If not, how do you obtain optimal temp for heat cycle to begin?

2. The article also talks about asymmetrical construction (stiffer inner side
wall). Do you know if their street Comp t/as also have this type of 
construction? I just bought a set and I noticed that they require that they be
mounted with a specific side out (directional tread). And maybe stiffer side
wall on the inside?

Thanks!

remember there being any other hoses coming out of the blower. Is there
supposed to be a 'Y' somewhere?

brake calipers if the master brake cylinder has been rebuilt?

Any help is appreciated.

Date: 10 Mar 95 11:43:28 EST
From: "Alan S. Watkins" <76030.40@compuserve.com>
Subject: Turn disk rotors?

If this is covered in a FAQ or something, please tell me so we can save the net
bandwidth.

If not, here goes:  30,000 or so miles after replacing my 928's rotors and pads,
it needs new pads.  The surface of the rotors are shiny and smooth, although
there is of course a millimeter or so lip at the outer periphery.  So my
quandary is, do I have the rotors turned, or do I just slap another set of pads
in there and keep on motoring? If I should have them turned, what's the
rationale?  And what's the best way to do it?  Take them off and hand them to my
local automotive brake or machine shop, or should it be done "on car"?  I've had
no problem with rotor warping so far, and I'd sure hate to do something to
change that.

Thanks for the help.

Alan Watkins ('86 928)

Date:          Fri, 10 Mar 1995 09:15:56 +0000
From: "Dirk Bergstrom" <krid@unix.sri.com>
Subject:       Windshield replacement

The time has come, the Walrus said, to talk of replacing the
windshield on my '75 911S coupe.  Not only is the thing pitted and
scratched, but the seals leak like crazy.  I'm tired of being blind
at night and finding puddles in the footwells after every rain.  So
here's my questions:

1) How much should I expect to pay to have a new one installed?

2) Is there anything else I should get done while the glass is out?
	I'd like to get a look at the frame, see if there's any rust.  If 
there is, what should I do?

3) Does anyone have a good glass shop to recommend in the SF Bay 
area?

Dirk Bergstrom
'75 911S, wet inside and out.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 10 Mar 95 09:36:05 PST
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert H. Albrecht)
Subject: Re: Windshield replacement

At 09:15 AM 3/10/95 +0000, Dirk Bergstrom wrote:
>The time has come, the Walrus said, to talk of replacing the
>windshield on my '75 911S coupe.  Not only is the thing pitted and
>scratched, but the seals leak like crazy.  I'm tired of being blind
>at night and finding puddles in the footwells after every rain.  So
>here's my questions:
>
>1) How much should I expect to pay to have a new one installed?

$150 to $300 depending...   I suggest you have an understanding with the 
shop re the aluminum trim strip that goes in the gasket.  It's easy to bend 
the strip, and once bent, it can be "sort of straightened"  but probably not 
restored to a perfect shape with no waves in it.  Surly a good shop can do 
it w/o bending it, but your average price leader will probably tell you 
"they all come out that way".

>
>2) Is there anything else I should get done while the glass is out?
>	I'd like to get a look at the frame, see if there's any rust.  If 
>there is, what should I do?

If you want to replace the dash, having the windshield out makes it trivial.

Bob

Date: Fri, 10 Mar 95 12:58:00 PST
From: Shafer Kirk <ShaferK@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: Turn disk rotors?


A data point:  I have original factory front rotors at 137K miles.  Never 
turned.  Replaced pads several times.  No ill effects.  Yes, mine also have 
a peripheral lip - doesn't bother me much - it should be there, the pads 
don't touch that outer most periphery.  Did a track event last summer - 
heavy brake use - no problems.

However, checked rotor thickness recently and they are just now a hair 
thinner than spec [as stamped on rotor] so I do plan to replace them soon.

My brake rotor philosophy has always been if they are wearing evenly [as 
they should] then why have them turned.  As I see it, needless rotor turning 
only shortens their useful life by shaving off even more metal than the pads 
alone would.  Also, what's to keep an unscrupulous dealer from just shaving 
off a wee bit extra so he can sell you new rotors sooner?  I am also quite 
interested in any rotor advice from the list.

Kirk S
'88 944




>If not, here goes:  30,000 or so miles after replacing my 928's rotors and
>pads,
>it needs new pads.  The surface of the rotors are shiny and smooth, 
although
>there is of course a millimeter or so lip at the outer periphery.  So my
>quandary is, do I have the rotors turned, or do I just slap another set of
>pads
>in there and keep on motoring? If I should have them turned, what's the
>rationale?  And what's the best way to do it?  Take them off and hand them 
to
>my
>local automotive brake or machine shop, or should it be done "on car"? 
 I've
>had
>no problem with rotor warping so far, and I'd sure hate to do something to
>change that.
>
>Thanks for the help.
>
>Alan Watkins ('86 928)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 10 Mar 95 12:34:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Turn disk rotors?


Alan,

No, don't waste money turning them.  Have them checked for minimum
thickness and replace if they are too thin.  The min. thickness is
stamped on the rotor hat.  A pronounced lip is a reliable sign that
you are likely approaching minimum thickness.

Kevin

Date: Fri, 10 Mar 1995 11:19:34 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: RE: Turn disk rotors?

I have not turned rotors on my porsches when changing pads. Only reason 
to turn is if rotors have scoring. or a little warped.

Otherwise replace the rotors.

				mike

          I too have an '84 Carrera and have experienced similar
          problems with the antenna motor, clutch (replaced at
          46,000) and Targa top with leaks and cracks.  Mine also had
          very weak 1st gear synchro's so I rebuilt the transmission--
          but mine was used as a leased vehicle for a couple of years
          so its wear might be due to abuse.

          Otherwise, I find the Carrera to be so darn reliable and fun
          to drive that I almost treat it like a Hondatoy--gas it and
          drive it rain or shine.

Date: Fri, 10 Mar 95 13:53:42 PST
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: re: 914 brakes etc

>From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
>To: porschephiles@tta.com
>Subject: Re: 914 brakes and ABS
>
>    Oh shit.  Looks like I'm in a world o'hurt (tm)... the rear brakes
>on my 914 are completely nonfunctional (as in, I took my car for a spin
>and the fronts were hot and the rears were still rusty...) but I just
>assumed that it was because the master cyl. since it was spewing brake
>fluind all over the pedal assembly.... so I procured meself a new master
>cyl. which I will be installing over spring break.
>    What else am I gonna have to do?
>    Will it hurt?
>    Will it cost money (even worse)?
>
>later,
>
>Nate

As I recall, this is the same car that had rusted out cables, floor
and frame.  And the top didn't fit because the frame was sagging.

If it were me, I would find me a less-rusted chassis, and make one
good car out of two.

You're going to find your "world o' hurt" after you've put all of
your nifty parts on the car, so nifty you can't bear to part with
it, and find out you need a frame rail replaced.

Just my two cents worth...........

gary@superior.ucsf.edu

Date: Fri, 10 Mar 1995 14:38:04 -0800
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: Re[2]: 914 brakes etc

>From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>

>Subject: Re: 914 brakes and ABS
>
>    Oh shit.  Looks like I'm in a world o'hurt (tm)... the rear brakes
>on my 914 are completely nonfunctional (as in, I took my car for a spin
>and the fronts were hot and the rears were still rusty...) but I just
>assumed that it was because the master cyl. since it was spewing brake
>fluind all over the pedal assembly.... so I procured meself a new master
>cyl. which I will be installing over spring break.
>    What else am I gonna have to do?
>    Will it hurt?
>    Will it cost money (even worse)?

>Nate

As I recall, this is the same car that had rusted out cables, floor
and frame.  And the top didn't fit because the frame was sagging.

If it were me, I would find me a less-rusted chassis, and make one
good car out of two.

You're going to find your "world o' hurt" after you've put all of
your nifty parts on the car, so nifty you can't bear to part with
it, and find out you need a frame rail replaced.

Just my two cents worth...........

gary@superior.ucsf.edu

Nate

As an one who is experienced in the trials, frustrations and dissapointments
of restoration, I agree with Gary.  I am just finishing a real 914/6 that was
too near to the grave to start with, but I persisted.  It was only marginally
justified because it was a 914/6.  Rust is the worst thing to deal with when
restoring a car as it can be so pervasive.  I have owned 914s for over 20 years
and I would not touch a car with major rust again.  I know of too many people
who have been sucked into buying a car because it had a nice paint job.

Take Gary's advice and get a not-rusted 914 with a blown engine or some other
form of body damage.  I regularly see cars like this for $500 to $1000 out here
in the S.F. Bay Area.

Dan

Dswiger@qntm.com

------------------------------

Signal red/black vinyl seats, S instruments w/ teak dash and steering wheel.
5 speed trans, Koni shocks and steering damper at 60,000 miles.  6" alloys w/
Goodyear NCT's + original wheels and Michelin tires.  Body 75% original
finish
left front fender, and door repainted as is rear deck lid.  Finish is still
like new.
Engine stock with solex carbs, needs CD unit for ignition. Runs good on
highway but not in town.
Im trying to decide if I should sell or keep.  Too many other cars in my
garage.

thanks 

Chuck Copeland
home phone 303-484-12346

I didn't know all 951S came from the factory with rolled fenders.  They must 
have anticipated our desire for wider rubber :).  BTW, I called BFG today and 
they will be making the 245/45ZR17 as OEM for the 1996 Ford Mustang but 
production starts in May and they will not be available until a month or 2 
later.  So, I guess I'll have to stick with 235/45 for now.  Let me know if 
you do try 255s in front.

program starts 4/1 thru 11/30. You need to be a Team T/A member to get a 
rebate of $25 per tire for 17"/18", (I think $10-$15 for 15"/16"), valid even 
when purchased thru the mail-order places.

Date: Fri, 10 Mar 95 15:51:55 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Rotor Turning


Alan-

If they're not warped, that is if they don't pulse
when you apply the brakes.  Don't bother having them
turned.  They don't need it.

The 'professional' brake guys always turn the rotors
when you change the pads (at least most of them do) on
the theory that they want you to leave the shop with
every possible thing perfect, and they don't know if the
brakes pulse or not.  You know why?  They don't ask.

 -Bob Spindel
'72 911E

Date: Thu, 09 Mar 95 21:33:11 +0000
From: Ray@arkay.MV.COM
Subject: 959 and euro import regulations

Hi all,
A fellow porschephile said:

>In the process of securing a street title for my HD XR-750TT, 
>I got into a fairly interesting discussion with a man who claims to 
>have done the ---legal-- documentation for 4 959's. He claims that 
>these are the only 959's that are street legal and has the mountains 
>of legal work to prove it. He also said that in the next few months,
>we would see magazine articles about the cars and one is currently 
>offered for a princely $2 million.

Yes, the ads for this car have already been showing up in the duPont
Registry, an ads-only magazine that's available at major newsstands 
and lists many cars at vastly inflated prices. (even the ads are 
expensive at $500 for a 1/8th page.) 

The full page ad claims this is one of 4 street legal 959s in the US, 
because supposedly US regulations prohibit the federalization of any 
more 959s. (Notice they did not say one of *only* four, perhaps this 
gives them a way out if a lot more real 959 models show up).

Anybody know if it is true that the 959 is now categorized as a car
that *cannot* be federalized ? Or does their sneaky ad language 
really only state that they cannot be federalized *as is*, and that
it certainly could be done with the normal modifications.

Having recently acquired a euro 930, I am constantly wondering about
the idiotic inconsistencies in the import laws. For example, I
cannot figure out why US model Porsches must have red taillight 
lenses. For a while I had the theory that our lawmakers intended to
eliminate any possible confusion about the direction a car is facing
by having all taillight lenses on all cars red colored. But my Toyota 
and my sister's Saab 900 were both bought new here from regular 
dealers and have yellow & red taillights. 

Also, you see so much trash on four wheels with legal inspection 
stickers that I really wonder why a 959 would be blacklisted.

Speaking of which, does anybody know where to get the definitive
answer on what modifications need to be done in order to have a
legal euro import ? I suppose it varies somewhat depending on model
year but I have no idea where to look. Fortunately, I had no trouble
registering the car. I was actually armed with the right paperwork,
but no one cared to ask to see the car or any paperwork besides the
title.

By the way, I am glad to see another Porsche geek interested in 
Harleys! 

Ray (former Boston city boy now living in New Hampshire)
'82 930 with adjustable turbo boost (I have restrained myself so far)
'92 Harley 1200	(which I converted from an 883)
no pets but a few racoons are running around outside (so who cares?)

//----------------------------------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 10 Mar 1995 22:23:18 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 Turbo S Questions

Rob, 
You said:
rv> He's looking at a 1989 944 Turbo S Cup Car. Here are the questions:
rv> 1) How does a Turbo S differ from a regular Turbo? 2) What is a Cup
rv> Car? The listing said 1 of 200 imported. 3) Is a Cup Car the Club
rv> Sport model, and if so, what is a Club Sport? 4) What type of
rv> performance is he looking at in a Turbo S (0-60, braking, hand
rv> ling) as compared to similar Porsche models? 5) What would you
rv> expect to pay for a low-mileage, clean, Turbo S Cup Car?

No such thing as a Turbo S Cup car. There is no such thing as a 1989 Turbo S.
 There are Turbo S's and there are Turbo Cup cars.  Turbo S's are for the
street.  Turbo Cup cars were for the track in Canada, Germany and South
Africa, and were lightened, had full roll cages, no power steering,
doorlocks, windows, or mirrors, stiffer suspension (read truck like ride),
Recaro racing seat, etc.

Turbo S's used some pieces proved out on the Cup cars, such as a larger
turbo, larger intake manifold, larger, 928 S4 front brakes, etc. They were
offered in 1988 in addition to normal Turbos.  The 1989 Turbo is essentially
the same as an 88 Turbo S, but was not called an S.

Someone is trying to play up what he has at the expense of truth.  A goo 88
Turbo S or an 89 Turbo are EXCELLENT cars though.

Jon Lowe
87 944 T Escort Series    

------------------------------

Date: 10 Mar 95 22:31:12 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 911 front hub dust cap removal

 
Some 911 front hub dust caps have a threaded nut welded on. This makes
pulling them off easy; just thread a slide hammer onto the nut and yank it
straight off.
 
If your cap doesn't have such a nut, it's easy enough to weld or braze one
on (or have a local welding shop do it, cost should be minimal). Check for
adequate clearance between nut and backside of decorative hubcap in center
of your wheels, though. There should be plenty of space but YMMV etc.
 
Pete

Date: Fri, 10 Mar 1995 22:12:01 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 959 and euro import regulations

> Anybody know if it is true that the 959 is now categorized as a car
> that *cannot* be federalized ? 

Current rules prohibit the import of any model for which there is not
an existing federalized US model, unless the importer wishes to do the
whole federalization processs, including all paperwork, bonding and 
any destructive testing necessary. Damn near no  one does this, but there's
a guy in Arizona that did all this nonsense so he can import, federalize,
and sell Mercedes G-wagens.

Given that, unless someone wants to spend about a megabuck on the legal
aspects, and crash at least two 959s to satisfy the testing (note: that's
*AT LEAST* -- they can require you to do it again. And again. And ...)
I'd guess that it won't happen.

> Speaking of which, does anybody know where to get the definitive
> answer on what modifications need to be done in order to have a
> legal euro import ? I suppose it varies somewhat depending on model
> year but I have no idea where to look. Fortunately, I had no trouble
> registering the car. I was actually armed with the right paperwork,
> but no one cared to ask to see the car or any paperwork besides the
> title.

Call the DOT. You have to be compliant with all relevant US DOT regs, plus
the relevant EPA regs. If you have paperwork saying that it's legal,
and you have a clear US title, you're probably OK. Unless the car was "done"
by a known perpetrator of fraudulent conversions, in which case they would
have probably already found you by now...

> By the way, I am glad to see another Porsche geek interested in 
> Harleys! 

Harleys? Feh. Beemers!

Stan

------------------------------

Date: 10 Mar 95 09:45:48 -0800
From: Raman Sarin (Exchange) <ramans@microsoft.com>
Subject: re: 959's in this country...


Someone commented that Bill Gates bought 2 959's and one of them
failed a crash test. As far as I know this is totally false. There
were in fact 2 959's in Seattle at one point, one was Bill Gates' the
other belonged to MS cofounder Paul Allen. A friend of mine has a very
nice picture of Bill's 959 crossing the 520 floating bridge followed
by another friend's F-40.  

When I was an intern many years ago they threw a summer intern party
at Bill's place with all the head honcho's so you could meet them. I
asked Bill what he though of his Lexus LS400 , if they were as good as
everyone said. He replied enthusiaticly that it was a beautiful car. I
then asked him what other cars he currently had, and he said a 911
cab, a '60-s something 'stang and a "959 on the dock somewhere in
california," with a note of sadness. The story on this as I heard it
from another person, who although not Bill is pretty reliable. Is that
both 959's came in liscensed in Germany to an MS of Germany employee
who was here working, they were therefore legal to drive with German
plates. After a year they had to renew the registration so they
shipped them back over to Germany to re-register, and then were
bringing them back in when they were stopped. 

Someone else told me they tried to sneak one in through canada and got
caught there too, but this has never been confirmed.

Anyway, there is at least one 959 in this country legally, as I last
saw it at the Meadowbrook Concours in Michigan, I think at that time
the GM proving grounds had it to play with. Also there were rumours of
being able to ship one in legally for track use only, kinda like the
Ford RS-200 that I would so much love to own one day.

 -R

Date: Fri, 10 Mar 1995 22:25:48 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Braided Brake Lines

>  Since these lines are used in aircraft, 

OK, please GET THIS: use in aircraft is roughly similar to use in race
cars. Parts have a "life" rating -- when they are so old, measured in 
racing hours, flight hours, or just plain wall clock time, they're 
removed, discarded, and replaced. In the time interval between the
time they're installed and the time that they're junked, there are
regular inspection intervals called out by the maintenece schedule for
that part. If it doesn't pass inspection, it gets pulled early. If you
see enough of that, the part either gets its "useful life" rating shortened,
or it gets de-rated for use. Period.

Now: when someone can show me that they really do this on their STREET CAR,
I'll tell them to go ahead and use the braided lines. But most people 
don't even *THINK* about such parts. It'll get installed and that's
the last anyone will think about it until there's some other compelling
reason to crawl into that part of the car. Hence the recommendation to
not use them.

Once again, fitness for use is *NOT* **EVER** to be imputed from use in
an analogous situation. FOR ANYTHING!!! 

Stan

------------------------------

Porschephiles #1232                         Sun Mar 12 02:00:06 CST 1995
Date: Sat, 11 Mar 1995 04:22:36 -0500 (EST)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: 912 Weber backfiring problem

Scott,

Warm engine.  Disconnect the throttle linkages to both
carbs.  Ensure all idle mixture screws are adjusted out the
same amount and use your newly purchased (I hope:) airflow
meter to measure each circuit.  Balance between the front
and back throats by opening the air bypass screw on the
lowest reading throat.  Work this on one carb at a time
then go to the other carb.  Now balance the carbs to each
other by turning in the idle speed screw on the lowest
reading carb.  At this point all throats should indicate
the same air flow.  Set idle to desired rpm by turning the
idle speed screws equal amounts.  Check the airflow again.
Use an accurate tachometer to adjust the idle mixture
screws evenly until best idle is attained.  This part is
nearly impossible without an accurate tach.  Some may have
the feel for adjusting four mixture screws 1/8th turn and
and telling if the idle is up or down 25 rpm.  I don't.
Most books say about 2 1/2 turns out but I have mine
running at 1 1/4 turns.  Too lean mixture often results in
the popping and backfiring you mention.  

My car has a big bore kit, K&N's, fuel pressure regulator
set to 1 1/2 -- ?pounds? (never checked it with a pressure
gauge, have to do that this weekend).  I have a cheepie
in-line fuel filter before the fuel pump (I know I'll be
jumped for this but I have no cavitation problems.  Better
than splitting the line in that busy space above the
distributor).  An important point, Webers must be perfectly
clean.  Some neighbor kids peed in my tank when my mover
was down for paint and I'm still changing filters every
other tank and pulling the carbs every 1K.  Thank God for
the spares.  I still pop a little bit when I first start up
on cold mornings.  It gets kinda cold here sometimes in
Missouri and this puppy ain't no driveway daisy (but it's a
long way from being stretcher bait). 

You've made the right move in getting (only?) one of "The
Maestro's" books and the Haynes manual.  If you got the
hair to pull those babies down and rebuild them, I know you
have the skill and perseverane to make them run properly.
There's no mystery to the Webers.  As a matter of fact, the
40 IDFs are my second favorite carbs.  Ease of dissasembly
(notice how the main jet stack can be removed with carbs on
vehicle? ).  adjustability, commonality of parts (Fast
Freddy's in CA can get you just about any jets you want).
Hell, they even put them on Yugo's (progressive Weber 2
barrel).  My personal favorite, however, is still the
hydraulically dampened variable venturi SU's found on
earlier Volvo's.  (Motorcyle meets car!)

My setup:

Main Jet     115
Air Correction     200
Idle Jet      50
Idle Air     Not mapped (where is "idle air" anyway?)
Venturi           28
Venturi Booster   4.5
Emulsion Tube     F11

Standard Settings:
HPBooks Weber Carburetors by Pat Braden

Main Jet     120
Air Jet          175
Idle Jet      50
Venturi          Not listed
Venturi Booster     Not listed
Emulsion Tube     F11

The promised method of setting the carb linkages:

First, make the tools (2 needed)

              |---|
   |----------|___|       ___________
   |----------|   |      _|_o       |
           |  |---|     | |_________|
           |____________|
     Bolt     String        Shim Stock

I used a couple of SAE Grade 5 5/8-11 X 3.5" bolts (the
purist would only consider using original rear engine mount
through bolts for April 1966 and on, p/n 900.082.031.02 
M 12x1 5x115, per Spare Parts Manual pg 1/13a A, available at
your local Porsche dealer at only $??.?? a copy).  Cut a
rectagular piece of shim stock and punch a hole in it (I
used brass .005" 'cause it punches so easy).  Tie the
string through the hole and then around the head of the
bolt.  Viola!  You know, in retrospect I guess you could
use lead wheel weights (as long as you weighed them for
balance) to protect the sheet metal a little more.  The
powder coating on mine seems tuff enough to shed 00 buck.

Put the shim stock under the Idle Speed Screw (no. 27 pg.
166 Haynes Weber Carburetors manual, no. 36 pg. 50 Bob
Tomlinsons Original Weber Tech Manual) on both sides.  Have
a friend with a steady foot SLOOOOWLY depress the
accelerator.  See which one drops first.  Shorten that
linkage leg (or lengthen the other one).  If you're real
anal (and what Porsche owner isn't?) you'll keep on going
'till they both drop at EXACTLY the same time.  Repeat
procedure three times (or until your eyes cross).  Sure
beats the hell out of trying to eyeball two linkages two feet
apart with too much of your arm wrapped behind the engine
pushing on a greasy bellcrank!

For Chris,

You know what the trouble with E-Mail is?  You can shoot
first and ask questions later.  I should have known SOMEONE
out there had made velocity stacks work on 40 IDF's with
K&Ns and call me on it.  Guilty as charged.  My experience
came after I had just rebuilt my "spare" set and noticed
the stacks that came with them.  No p/n but 39mm throat X
44mm high, about typical from what I've seen.  I had just
bead blasted them and they looked sooooo cool (as if
someone is going to look under your air cleaners to check
out your stacks).  The performance was great from about
4-6K rpm but the bottom end was gutted.  It got to where I
was embarrassed driving around town.  After messing with
every adjustment known to carb and engine I finally
remembered about the velocity stacks I had installed.  I
removed them and drivability returned.  The moral of this
story is that even <I> can't see velocity stacks underneath
the filters.  My theory is insufficient clearance between
the top of the stacks and the top plate of the filter would
not allow the stacks to do their job (and who wants to run
unfiltered stacks on the street?  You can see what that
crap they put on the roads does to the body, can you
imagine it inside your engine?) 

Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com

cheapest part of the deal. There are bunches od aluminium parts in the 86
turbo, not to mention a myriad of wiring, hoses, sensors,paint work etc. Cars
that have had fires, especially complicated cars, are a NIGHTMARE. Right up
there with flood damage.

and it will) you will want to put a gun to your head.

patient, you can find one with a documented maintenance history that will fit
in your budget,

Date: Sat, 11 Mar 95 11:04:53 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; 911 windshield replacement



>>The time has come, the Walrus said, to talk of replacing the
>>windshield on my '75 911S coupe...(snip)

>...I suggest you have an understanding with the shop re the aluminum trim 
> strip that goes in the gasket.  It's easy to bend the strip, and once bent, 
> it can be "sort of straightened"  but probably not restored to a perfect 
> shape with no waves in it.  Surely a good shop can do it w/o bending it, 
> but your average price leader will probably tell you "they all come out 
> that way".

>Bob

     Maybe your shop will know this, but you must remove and install the
 aluminum trim -only- when the  is out of the car. Don't try and remove it 
 while it is in the car; correct procedure is to remove the windshield and
 gasket,  always replace any gasket older than 5 years (these are cheap, one
 of Porsche's real bargains), then install the trim before trying to place
 the windshield. If you try and remove or install the trim at any other time
 it will become hopelessly mangled.

      In case the anodizing is worn off the trim, or its buggered already,
  Porsches' price for the trim is also very reasonable (i.e., similar trim
  for a Ferrari 308 runs about $800...on top of the $1300 windshield...
  replacing a windshield in a Testarossa is a $4000 venture !). The trim is 
  very soft, it shouldn't be "formed" unless it has already got a kink in it.
  Then just flatten it between 2 boards, don't do this in your hands. Also
  don't try to polish the aluminum, you'll risk removing the anodizing and
  it will look splotchy.

     The hard thing on the 2 911s I've done seems to be getting a good
  fit around the upper corners of the glass. There always seems to be
  something of a gap on the upper corners that you have to fill with Silicone.
  Both mine were the original windshields in undamaged frames, so I have
  to wonder if it isn't a 911 characteristic....

            -Lee A.

and though they were great.  The 2.2T seems to go on forever like a 3.0 SC
and would make a great combo driver/autox car.  I like these cars because
they're carbureted - if you don't mind FI, both 2.0 and 2.2 AND 2.4E would
again be good combination cars.  The S cars from all 69 -73 would be great at
the track, but you'll spend more to buy one and it probably wouldn't be as
reasonable to drive on a daily basis.

Date: Sat, 11 Mar 1995 16:37:47 -0500 (EST)

Subject: 924 Cold starting Problems

Hi All...
Some of you may remmember me writing the same things about 1 year ago...
Well I'm finally back on this continent and have had time to mess with
the car...
The car is a '79 924 that will start fine warm but takes either
multiple crankings or dowsing the air-filter in carb cleaner/starting
fluid to get it to crank over on the first try cold.
I have replaced the fuel pump relay, cleaned all fuel lines and systems,
The air sensor plate doesn't sit perfect, but this was a problem 
when I got the car and it started then fine cold...
I also replaced the ignition switch, tumbler and all...
I also verified the cold start valve isn't leaking or anything..

WHAT I HAVE DISCOVERED! is the the cold start valve isn't getting
any juice, when I branched it directly to the battery one day, out
came a nice conical spray.  (I made sure the coolant was cool)
So why isn't it getting any juice? I hate electrics, and have a limited
knowledge.. I have HAYNES wiring diagrams but I find them confusing :-/
If anyone has the patience to try to follow through with me on this
I would very much appreciate it!
Thanks tons in advance!

Date: Sat, 11 Mar 95 17:01:53 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 951

>         I just looked at a '89 944 Turbo. It's got 53k kms and in perfect
> condition. The problem IS that the store does not have all the records,
> actually no records at all. All they say is that it never was in an
> accident. Is there any suggestions? This is my exact car I'm looking for but
> without a history, I may be looking at a lot of maintenance troubles.
> 

Yes, in fact, you may be looking at a lot of trouble.

On the other hand, this car may be a creampuff.

I noticed that your userid is badkarma... It reminds me of a quote from the
John Muir book "How to Keep Your Volkswagen Alive" (before the days of the
H2O cooled VWs.  He said that when you're looking to buy a car, sit down and
try to understand the karma of the vehicle you're looking at. Just try to
absorb the aura of the car...

So, to paraphrase: If you're good at this sort of thing, take a good,
critical look at things like the seats (for wear), and engine oil (smell it
for a burned smell) and the engine compartment (dirty, clean, in between?)
and brake rotors (burned, scored, rusty?) and the transmission (oily, etc.)

You get the idea.

If you're not good at this sort of thing, have a good Porsche mechanic that
you trust (kind of a strange juxtaposition of words in this sentence...)
take a good long look at this car for you...

Also, keep in mind that it is *very easy* to adjust the mileage on a VDO
odometer (Not that *I* would ever do such a thing, but it has been known to 
happen...)

Good luck,

- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ mhv.net
E-Mail: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net

> knowledge.. I have HAYNES wiring diagrams but I find them confusing :-/

Most likely problem is the thermoswitch.  If it is like Audis, this is 
on the rear of the motor, near the firewall.  They go bad all the time and 
keep the cold start valve from releasing fuel...

Date: Sat, 11 Mar 1995 19:06:34 -0500
From: Zunknown@aol.com
Subject: Considering 944 purchase

I read that Naresh has $5000 to spend and is considering a 944.

Naresh (and anyone else with similar finances), be careful! 

You mentioned that you are a student, so I will assume you don't have huge
income. So before you sign on the dotted line, check out some things very
carefully.

944s have a lot of Achiles Heels; the motor mounts go bad (over and over),
the water pumps go bad (over and over), the rubber centered clutch disc goes
bad (you need to remove the entire driveshaft and rear-end/transaxle to
replace the stupid thing), if you don't take good care of the timing belt, it
will break and cause all the valves to bend.... These parts are very
expensive, with the labor to replace them being astronomical.

A lot of people selling used 944s are doing so because they got in over their
heads (they had $5000 budgets, with none left over for upkeep and no huge
income for unforseen failures) and are having to cut their losses-so the cars
they're selling may have hidden, serious, expensive problems.

Call some reputable shops (not gas stations or "bargain" one-man shows) and
ask for some quotes on common things like tuneups, etc. Ask how much parts
cost (stay away from mail order...few professional shops will install
owner-supplied parts).

If you plan to spend $5000 to purchase a 944, plan to have $2000 or more set
aside, just in case. Also, when shopping for a car, take it to a good shop
first...make sure you don't buy someone else's problems.

>Subj:	Re: Braided Brake Lines
>Date:	95-03-09 19:46:33 EST

>I would not recommend using them on anything but an out and out racing car

them over the

I rebuild my braking system. However, if there were other problems with these
lines, or there was a problem of inferior quality which you raised, where it
concerns what is available to the automotive industry, then I wanted to know.
 If I cannot determine what is a decent and SAFE brand of braided brake line,
and it seems like that is a VERY REAL PROBLEM, then I will remove them from
my car, and go back to factory PORSCHE rubber lines, which I will still
replace on a periodic basis.  Anything else would be pretty stupid, agreed?

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 12 Mar 1995 00:19:48 -0500
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: Heat cycling new tires...

>Subj:	Heat cycling new tires...
>Date:	95-03-10 09:49:01 EST
>From:	len@library.mt.att.com
>To:	porschephiles@tta.com
>
>I have two questions for all:
>
>1. The article talks about "heat cycling" a new tire to settle its compound.
>What is the right procedure to follow when breaking in new tires? Is regular
>driving (for how long?) and then a rest period of 24hrs considered a heat
cycle?
>
>If not, how do you obtain optimal temp for heat cycle to begin?
>
>2. The article also talks about asymmetrical construction (stiffer inner
side
>wall). Do you know if their street Comp t/as also have this type of 
>construction? I just bought a set and I noticed that they require that they
be
>mounted with a specific side out (directional tread). And maybe stiffer side
>wall on the inside?
>
>Thanks!
>
>Lou Nicotra

Lou,

Question #1 - Heat cycling tires is done by bringing them up to TRACK
operating temperature ~ 200 degrees fahrenheit, then allowing them to cool.
 But this is not something that is done to "break in" the tires, like you
would do with brakes.  It is something that happens when you use them.  BTW,
most tires work the best right out of the box, and thier performance
deteriorates with each heat cycle.  That is why most race teams use "sticker
tires", that is new tires, when they need the most speed, or they will run
new tires for a few laps to test them, and save them for when they are
needed.

Question #2 - I'm not a whole lot of help here.  R1's definately have the
stiffer inner sidewall, if the street Comps look similar to the R1's, then
they should have the stiffer inner sidewall as well.

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

Date: Sun, 12 Mar 1995 07:23:33 -0500
From: PJZabo@aol.com
Subject: Re: Turning brake rotors

Having read the flurry of postings on this subject, I figured I'd add my .02c
worth.  I've had luck merely replacing the pads on several cars (911 P cars
included) when the rotors were in good shape (no scoring or warps).

Problem is "bedding" the new brake pads to the shiny rotor surface.  The
marraige of slicked up rotor to fresh pads is like any other (ie. some work,
some don't).  I think it depends on the pad material to a great extent
(metal, semi-met, organic, compounds).

I've simply thrown new pads on without turning the rotors without problem and
have sometimes just roughed up the rotors with a pad sander to give the new
pads something to bite.  Usually, however, I have the rotors turned just
enough to break the glaze.  If you go to a reputable machine shop they'll
honor your request and take off just enough to clean em' up.  Cheap
insurance.  Who wants to go back and do the job again?

Pete Zaborowsky

77' 3.0 Carerra (complete resto underway)
70' 911T (first love-next in line for resto)
61' Ducati Diana 250 (nicer to look at than ride)
89' Kawasaki ZX-10 (ludicrous speed)
Understanding wife (sometimes)
1 yr old Son (first word was car, 2nd tools - no lie)
Various boring expendable cars and animals to feed

Date: Sun, 12 Mar 95 10:07:03 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 951 Steering Rack Replacement

Ideally, you'd flush it after removing the failing rack so as not to 
bring more junk into the system.  But you don't want to circulate 
remaining debris into the new rack either.  Net: you're hosed.

In reality, there should be extremely little or no debris in the system 
unless you had a really bad failure, or dumped something in the 
resevoir.  You should be fine just installing the new rack and doing 
the normal flush.

I've lost 2 racks on my '86 951, and a friend lost 1 on his '86.  Seems 
like another one of those expensive German parts that ought to be made 
in Japan.

		Jim

- ----------
> From:  <JamesD1415@aol.com>

Date: Sun, 12 Mar 1995 10:52:05 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: 17 vs 18-in. track tires

Not in my opinion.

Here's what I just put on my SC3.4

F:  9.5x17 -w- 275-40-17  BFG Comp T/A R:  11.0x17 -w- 315-35-17

I'm out $1650 for NEW forged 3 peice wheels AND tires.  $620 (approx)
for the tires.

That's for 10.2 + 11.9 " of rubber on what is apparently the optimal
rims.

From my calculation, (315mm * .35 / 25.4 mm/in) the sidewalls are  4.3:
total, but only about 3.75" measurable above the rim. This is confirmed by the BFG tire
charts

That's pretty low.  Interetingly enough, there is actually slightly  more
sidewall on these tires than on 245-45-16" because they are so damn
wide, even 35 aspect doesn't offset it.


The sidewalls are VERY stiff and and it should yeild a nice contat patch. 

Lookng at the sizes listed in Tire Rack, (pano) rears are 265-35-18, with 3.75" sidewall so there is a significant difference, with almost identical diameter (25.6")  The question is - is 256 adequate for the rears?  Also - what othetr sizes are available?

I would think Goodyear would make some slicks in 18".

If money is no object - great!  Personally I see 2 sets minimum a year
being $2400 I can throw at the car elsewhere.  Guess it depends on your
budget.

Thoughts?

Date: Sun, 12 Mar 1995 14:23:25 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: 911 T  front brakes

Hi Pat:

On stuck brake calipers - In the past I've taken really bad one-piece
calipers and "baked" them in an oven for 30 minutes at some reasonable
temperature (200-250 F).

This made a big difference, and I was able to release the pistons on short
order thereafter.  KEEP IN MIND, HOWEVER, that calipers that have "halves"
and therefore O-rings between the halves may be adversely affected by the
heat - I don't know what maximum temperature caliper sealing O-rings can
take.

Also, 60 psi is probably too little to do much good - I typically use a
Presta-valve bike pump, and it exceeds 100psi before the pistons come out. 

I've always been able to rebuild my calipers, so I can't advise on a source
of rebuilt ones.

 ____________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman   aek@netcom.com  | 
|____________________________________         
| "Responsibility, not process, is   |
|   the key ingredient to action."   |  
|                                    |
| Phillip K. Howard in               |
|  "The Death of Common Sense"       |
 ____________________________________

entering the oil (no foamy brown gunge or other traces of water).
