water cooler seal problem) so I'm wondering, is oil getting into the water
via the oil cooler or via the head gasket. I suppose that where ever it is
leaking into the water it happened on one of those mid winter cold starts
where the oil pressure was insanely high and it just made a seal give way.
What are the chances that high oil pressure could cause a leak to start in
the oil cooler itself (as opposed to just a seal)?


Any help would really be welcome, I want to try to correct this problem as
quickly as possible. My suspicions are that it is the oil cooler seal and
not the head gasket as the oil cooler seal seems to be a weak point on the
car. Could I be wrong?

Date: Sun, 12 Mar 95 16:51:18 PST
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: re: 914 heater

>From: "tim (t.j.) murphy" <tmurphy@bnr.ca>
>To: porschephiles@tta.com
>Subject:  914 Heater Blower & Bleeding Master Cylinder 
>
>Okay, I have 2 questions about reassembling my stock '74 914 1.8L.
>
>My heater blower only has one hose coming out of it and it is connected
>to the driver side J-pipe towards the heat exchangers.  The passenger
>side J-pipe has a cap on it (inside engine compartment) and looks very
>factoryish.  Was it an option to get passenger side heat? I don't
>remember there being any other hoses coming out of the blower. Is there
>supposed to be a 'Y' somewhere?
>
>My other question is about bleeding the master brake cylinder.  Is there
>something special that needs to be done besides bleeding each of the 4
>brake calipers if the master brake cylinder has been rebuilt?
>
>Any help is appreciated.
>
>                 Thanks...Tim Murphy (tmurphy@bnr.ca)

Your heater blower is stock.  Some smog "mechanics" with less than
perfect Porsche knowledge will try to connect the capped over tube
to your air cleaner some how.  Every time I get my 914 smogged I
forget that fact, and have to go buy a new cap.

There was a thread not too long ago about 914 brake bleeding.  
Basically, you should bleed the master cylinder, the front brakes,
the proportioning valve, and the rear brakes, in (somewhat) that
order.

What you want to do is start at the master cylinder, and move the
air out to the end, and bleed it off.  Hitting every possible
point in between.

Glad to help (if this did help).

gary@superior.ucsf.edu

Barton...I will take your flaming as a friendly reminder about manners and
protocol. If it was not intended to be "friendly", please let me know so that
I can generate the appropriate feelings towards you!  In fairness, you should
also chastize Stan, as HE did not include my questions in his response to me,
and he flamed me first, so there!

Seriously, there are probably thousands of Porsche drivers out there running
around with these braided brake lines, and if it is as big a problem as you
say, a small amount of rhetoric from Stan is not really sufficient to make an
impact on this subject.  This list seems to generate tons of responses to
banal subjects like paint polishes and motor oils, but not much to something
important like this.  We are talking about the potential for serious injury
or death, and so I will re-issue my questions with a few more so that
everyone can benefit!

It has been stated that Braided Brake Lines are for racing and must be
inspected (monthly?) and replaced (probably?) on an annual basis.  Fair
enough!  For those who wish to continue to run them:

1) There is a concern about differing quality of these lines, how can you
tell which ones are good?
2) Braided lines like these are made for the refrigeration industry as a
replacement for metal tubing, and rubber hosing.  The environment that they
operate under is harsher, and they are expected to last 10 years.  How long
should the automotive ones last?
3) What should you look for as far as a potential defect in these lines,
besides the obvious rubbing or leaking.
4) When they fail, do they burst immediately, leaving no brakes, or will they
give some warning, like a soft pedal before they fail?

For those of use who will probably go back to factory rubber lines:

1) What is the life expectancy on these?
2) The obvious inspection is for cracks or leaks...anything else?
3) If the rubber line fails, what kind of warning will IT give?

NO FLAMES, JUST FACTS!

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

Date: Sun, 12 Mar 1995 21:38:26 -0700
From: Drew Spencer <Drew_Spencer@Novell.COM>
Subject:  SweepCo 201 Synthetic??? -Reply

Thus spake Ed...

>Should I put the SweepCo  201 synthetic gear oil in my 1986 911 Carrera or is the regular
>better/worse?

>TIA,
>Ed

>1986 Carrera Cab
>1988 944 Turbo S (for sale)
>5 cats

Hi Ed,

I think you'll have a hard time finding Swepco 201 synthetic because I don't think it
exists.   $wepco 201 is a non-synthetic primo dino juice with some special chemical 
additives that give a nice blue hue.  The general concensus is that, for the Porsche 915
transmission, $wepco is the "right stuff".  I place a similar query before p-philes a 
couple of weeks ago and was generally convinced by the masses that I should use 
this stuff in my newly rebuilt tranny.  In fact, I was so convinced that I bought a whole 
case of the stuff and have sold two of the surplus gallons to local Porsche
clubbers for their cars.  Granted, I have no first hand knowledge of its effectiveness
since the car I have put it in is currently suffering from horsepower deficit disorder.
As such, I have no emperical evidence to back up the claims.  YMMV...

Drew
Drew_Spencer@novell.com
'82 911 SC track car (Looking for a heart transplant...)
'93 RS America (Hit the pavement today for the first time in 4 months and damn
it felt good!)

Date: Sun, 12 Mar 95 23:19:00 EST

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 12 Mar 95 23:31:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Installing a rear wiper


Armagan,

There is a pipe along the left edge of the rear glass, which carries the 
three
wires to the rear wiper.  Check out a friend's car which is equipped.  If 
yours
does not have the pipe, I'm not sure what the best improvisation would be.

If you decide to go ahead with the project, get the hardware bits from a
reputable dismantler (such as the list's beloved George B.).  The prices 
from
Porsche are a bit painful.  My own rear wiper motor went to its reward last
year, due to what turned out to be water entering at the armature.  For the
(in)frequency of its use, the recycled motor is the way to go.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 12 Mar 95 23:18:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944S slow starting


Bdale,

Check for vacuum leaks, most likely problem.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 12 Mar 95 23:26:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 oil and water ...


Trev,

Almost certainly the oil/water heat exchanger seals.  Per your question,
the cooler itself can fail, and there is a factory tool to pressure test it,
out of the car.  Looks like a big C-clamp.

Head gasket failure is really very uncommon on aspiros.  Anything is
possible, but I'd start with the exchanger.  BTW, Porsche recommends
you drop the oil pan and check the rod bearings for water damage.
This is a bunch more work, not to mention the cost of the ingenious but
pricey pan gasket.  If you see absolutely no coolant in the oil, when you
drain the oil, perhaps you can get away without dropping the pan.

With respect to it being a weak spot, there was a run of bad seal kits
in MY87.  Since then, Porsche has had problems getting mechanics to
shim the cooler properly on re-installation.  You should be OK once
both have been taken care of.

Kevin

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1234                         Mon Mar 13 11:29:53 CST 1995

safe?

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 09:37:04 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: braided brake lines


The common wisdom in the UK car tuning world, is that braided lines are 
better than rubber.

They have two main benefits -
	they are a lot stronger ie they do not expand under pressure, and 
hence give a firmer pedal.
	They are less susceptable to abrasion.

WRT check intervals, on an aircraft (UK) they would be checked every 50 
hours or yearly - 50 aircraft hours probably equates to every 3000 miles 
for a car.

I for one would normally expect to check my hoses every 10k miles, and 
have yet to see any more problems with steel braided than with rubber 
clad hoses. UK cars get a yearly thorough MOT check and brake hoses and 
lines are one of the most common failures. The rubber hoses usually fail 
for perish cracks, the lines for rust - poor quality material ( not P 
cars ) rarely does a brake hose of any type fail the test at less than 5 
years of age

Refrigorators - when did a fridge get cornered thru rocks at 80 mph at an 
ambient of 110 deg f with red hot brake particles being thrown on to it's 
hoses - I think that is a spurious comparison. In the general scheme of 
things, it is acknowledged that motor car usage puts a more severe test 
on components than any other type of environment.



+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 13:18:53 +0100
From: Christopher Hegarty <chh@esec.ch>
Subject: New 911 Turbo / Porsche 4WD

I was at the Geneva motor show last weekend and saw the new 911 turbo.
It's certainly am impressive looking beast, considerably wider track
than the standard carrera.  Very wide rear tyres (285/30, 18").
There are quite a number of not-so-subtle styling clues so that the
car looks much more potent than a standard 911.

"Auto Motor und Sport" a few weeks ago had a comparison between a
number of 4WD cars to see how they perform in snow.  The 911 C4 did
very badly in these tests (the conclusion was basically that the car
is pretty lousy in snow.  They often had the situation where the car
was stuck with the rear tyres spinning in the snow and the front tyres
stationary ).  This week AMuS report that Porsche now claims they've
tightened the spec on the minimum amount of torque the visco coupling
must transmit to the front axle under worst-case conditions.
Previously it used to be 40% +/- 6%, the spec has now been tightened
to 40% - 0%, + 6%.  Porsche claims they have no plans to replace the
visco couplings on already-delivered 911 C4's.  In the article they
also recommended particular brands of snow tyres for use on the C4.
AMuS reports that a test drive with a C4 with the tighter-spec'ed
coupling was better, although still not great.  Mind you, hopefully
nobody buys a 911 to drive in the snow.  That's why Subarus were
created.

Chris Hegarty (hegarty@al.esec.ch)

From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: "AmsOil" recomendations???



On Sun, 12 Mar 1995 Por944Trbo@aol.com wrote:

As I'm about to start selling AmsOil myself, I'll tell ya what I know 
(and no, it isn't biased)... First, AmsOil is some good stuff, and 
because it is full synthetic based, you can go 15k miles without changing 
it. HOWEVER, it is pretty stupid to go that long if you know what goes 
through your engine in just 3k miles (which is why he's reommending 
changing the filter every 3k miles.

Now, the answer about how good it is... It's great oil, smooth running 
and such, but not for $8. He's really hosing you on this one. The 
seller's manual recommends $4.95 be the selling price (which isn't too 
much more than say Mobil 1 or Slick 50). Tell him you know he should sell 
it for $4.95 per quart, maybe he'll break.

BTW, I'm working on starting up a small business called Vintage 
VW/Porsche Partshaus (Vintage VW and Vintage Porsche, sorry 9x4/9x8 
owners) I'm interested in knowing what I should stock. This business 
willhopefully be up and running (in some form) by early summer at

on VW copyrights (interesting story there: "Hm, well, VW doesn't have a 
legal department, I can ask PR though... hold on") as Porsche very easily 
pounces people about their name (remember Porsche Magazine?) I really 
want to settle that... any clues where to call?

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 09:04:33 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 2 Liter Engine ID


<I am going to look at a 914 engine that is being represented as a 2 liter.
<THe car that is was in is in the crusher. How do I ID the engine as being a
<2 liter? The heads are different on the 2 liter, so I want to be able to
<identify the case and heads as being the correct ones. Any help would be
<appreciated.


Dear Tom,

It is very easy to identify a 2.0 engine. Since, however, many call their 914
a 2.0 when it is really a 1.7 or 1.8 with a 96mm piston cylinder kit
installed (1911 CC) Caviot Emptor!

If fuel injected, a 2.0 can be identified by:
     1. Large steel ribbed rectangular air cleaner mostly on the left side of
the engine
     2. Green (not tourquoise) injectors
     3. 3 bolt intake to head runners (NOT 4. four bolts bolting the intake
runner tubes to the head is a 1.7 or 1.8).
     4. Spark plug holes are in the side of the cylinder covers, NOT the top.
     5. The engine ID number is in front of the oil filler, down in the
canyon between the filler and the impellor housing with the round timing hole
plug. It will begin with GA, GB or GC and then the consecutive number.
However, beware! It is easy to build a 1.7 or 1.8 with a 2.0 IDed case!

If the car is carburated or the fuel injection is missing, ignore numbers 1
and 2!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 95 09:04 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: 944 sunroofs

    How the heck does the power roof on the 944 S come off?   The directions
    simply say to raise the roof via the rocker switch, undo the two front
    switches, and pull up. I tried this but it seemed like I'd break the plastic
    arms that raise the back of the roof before it would come free.  What step(s)
    am I missing?

I just checked the 924/944/951 FAQ and, sure enough, it's not in there. I don't
have my manuals handy, but the trick is to shut the car off, then turn the key
to the (second?) detent.  Then, hit the down side of the switch.  The forks
will retract, and the roof can then be lifted right off (after you unfasten the
latches in the front, of course!).  Assembly, as they say, is the reverse of
disassembly -- fit the air deflector into the leading edge of the sunroof, then
lower the panel until it's almost flush with the roof, then shove it forward to
make sure it's positioned properly.  Pull your fingers out the let it drop into
place.  Get back into the car, turn the key to the third detent and open the
sunroof, then close it.  This will move the forks into their normal position
and lock the sunroof down so it won't lift at speed.

This is all documented in the owner's manual, but that didn't help me until
I'd read it about a dozen times...

"Happy motoring, and we'll see you out on the freeway, which is already in
progress!" -- Ralph Spoilsport (The Firesign Theatre)

- -- Tracy Nelson
'87 944S

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 09:04:49 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Heater Blower & Bleeding Master Cylinder 


<Okay, I have 2 questions about reassembling my stock '74 914 1.8L.

<My heater blower only has one hose coming out of it and it is connected
<to the driver side J-pipe towards the heat exchangers.  The passenger
<side J-pipe has a cap on it (inside engine compartment) and looks very
<factoryish.  Was it an option to get passenger side heat? I don't
<remember there being any other hoses coming out of the blower. Is there
<supposed to be a 'Y' somewhere?

<My other question is about bleeding the master brake cylinder.  Is there
<something special that needs to be done besides bleeding each of the 4
<brake calipers if the master brake cylinder has been rebuilt?

<Any help is appreciated.


Dear Tim,

All 73-74 and early 1975 914s had only a single short supplementary heater
blower hose. Since the engine fan blew most of the heat through the heat
exchangers, Porsche thought they could save money by using only one hose.
However, they found this solution unacceptable and in  the middle of the 75
production run, connected a Y and a long heater hose to the passenger J pipe.
All 75-1/2 - 76 modles have a Y connection and passenger side hose. 70-72
models have a dual port blower mounted on the left side of the impellor
housing and also dual blower hoses. I'm sorry they made us 73-74 914 owners
suffer heater output (you don't need to suffer, though, because DR. 914 had
an update made to retrofit to the 73-74 cars!).

Master cylinders are best bench bled before installation. Make sure before
bolting the cylinder to the bulkhead that you force the supply lines from the
resevoir into the cylinder. It is almost impossible after mounting, and loose
supply lines suck air. Bleed right rear, left rear, righ front and finally
left front.

A good trick is to crack all 8 73-76 brake caliper bleeders and fill the
resevoir letting the lines drip for an hour. This helps prebleed the brakes
and makes the job easier.

George Hussey

> in his response to me, and he flamed me first, so there!

Let me dissect this and offer a threefer:  

First:  Stan is a *very* busy man, to whom we *all* owe an inestimable
debt of gratitude!  He *created* and runs Porschephiles for us on the
equipment and bandwidth that is his means of earning his daily bread.

We have discussed here recently how this is starting to have a
*significant* impact upon his income-genreating resources.  Those of us
who appreciate the *enormoous* benefits we have derived from Stan's
generosity over the years (year plus, in my case), have started a fund to
purchase new equipment to be devoted exclusively to keeping Porschephiles
going and allowing Stan to have the full use of his hardware resources.

This does not address the impact that Porschephiles message traffic has
upon Stan's T-1 line.  If we can raise enough money to address that, we
will.  We ought to.  (see my custodian's report later this morning - we
still have less than 100 contributors, and have only raised $4,100 to
date.  Considering that we have 1200 members deriving benefit, that's an
underwhelming response rate).

So here's part one of the threefer *Clue*:  Flaming *Stan* is not *ever*
an action that a person with a grip, or a modicum of comity, would do.

Part two of the threefer follows part one.  You feel that Stan should be
chastized because he did not include all of your question when
responding. (Larry, here is where a grip would have been *ever* so
useful...) Memorize this:  Stan does *not* *owe* any of us *anything*!
Further, his response was a model of clarity in making his point, which
you do seem to have grasped.  That you still have some unanswered
questions is unfortunate, but a simple, *courteous* mention of that fact
would have been the appropriate response.  You will always get more help
when you demonstrate your grasp of the concept that those offering *any*
response are doing you a courtesly.  One who flames another for failing
to respond to one's full and complete satisfaction, is likely to be
percieved as an ill-mannered child, and receive a response appropos to
that perception.

The third part of the threefer, Part C., is that I did *not* flame you, I
*gently* chided you, as I have done again in this.  I used to live with a
*great* old cat, named (very appropriately) "Spike."  Spike had been born
and lived the first nine or so years of his life, wild.  He was large,
and possed *awesome* claws and fangs.  A true gentleman, Spike would, on
occasion, feel the need to communicate the message that some behavior of
mine was inappropriate.  He'd grab my arm in his paws (that most closely
resembeled Catcher's-Mitts equipped with meat-hooks), then look up
directly into my eyes; when he had my complete attention (which, may
I assure you, he *assuredly* did have), "Poink!" he'd give me a touch,
the merest *hint* of his claw-tips.  This, my friend, has been such a 
message.  I trust you'll take it in the same spirit; recognize the error
of your ways, and go forth and sin no more...(he said with a more good 
natured grin, as he ambled off into the growing sunlight...)

(Kindkly old) Father Bart

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 09:27:13 -0500 (EST)
From: Richard Hollander <ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us>
Subject: Re: New 911 Turbo / Porsche 4WD

What's this nonsense about not driving a 911--or any other Porsche--in 
the snow? A truly great car is made to be driven year-round and an ideal 
car is one that can serve as transport no matter what the conditions. A 
Porsche is a great car, yes?

Also, you may know that all Porsches have a 10-year warranty on rust 
perforation due to their galvanized sheet metal. This isn't because the 
factory wants us to leave our steeds in the garage every time the weather 
gets lousy.

When I lived up north, I used my 951 in the snow and found it to be 
superior to my other German car in the white stuff--a M-B SL. The 951 has 
perfect weight distribution, LSD, and ABS (which is beneficial in snow, 
contrary to what some believe). 

No Subarus for this man!


RickSH
ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 09:37:49 -0500
From: MrBru@aol.com
Subject: Braided Brake Lines

I don't wish to generate flames for posting another "opinion" on these
brake lines.  PLEASE remember that this list primarily contains only
opinions of others.  Two years ago I had a failure on my auto-x 914,
it blew quite suddenly & made a loud cracking sound, not to mention
covering nearly all of the bottom of my car with brake fluid.

The brakes failed completely,  fortunately it happened while I was on
the auto-x course and noone or no property was damaged.  It did
however illustrate the problem that is being discussed here on the 
list.  I still use these lines on my auto-x and track cars, and I do
inspect them regularly.  I don't feel that they are more dangerous 
because at least they are being replaced -- I've seen some pretty old
rubber hoses being used on street cars.  They may be of a lesser
quality but then again some may be better.  The importang point is 
to be CAREFUL with your brakes no matter what lines you use; 
inspect them often and replace if there is ANY doubt.


Jeff Brubaker

about 4 914's one of which is REALLY fast.

Date:         13 Mar 95 09:30:43 EDT
From: KEHRLICH@lawlib.law.vill.edu
Subject:      Gates 959 and others

    I finally went to my semi-authorized Gates biography for the semi-
approved scoop on the 959, etc.  The book was reviewed and ok'd by
Gates, but not co-written.  The bottom line is this is the most
reliable info I have on the subject.

    Gates and Allen bought two 959s together at the end of 1988.
Gates got a silver one and Allen a white one.  They paid $380,000
each and were able to drive them for a year as has been previously
noted.  When the foreign exemption ran out in Jan 90, the cars got
stored.  It would have cost $30,000 to ship the cars to Germany and
go through that process.  The cars were stored in a Free Trade Zone
warehouse in Oakland while Gates and Allen tried to argue with the
feds about certification.  In the meantime, an Allen employee flies
down every few weeks to start the engines and makes sure they are
roadworthy.

    That's the most recent info I have, but the book is two years
old.  The rumors about putting the car in a trailer in Washington and
trying to sneak it in through Canada are intriguing.

    Other Gates info:  his FIRST car was a used dark green 911 which
he drove quite hard.  In addition to the Lexus daily driver, he has a
Mustang, Porsche C4 cabriolet, and a Ferrari 348.  On the record he
only has one ticket since 1988, but I'm sure there are several others
that the legal staff have dealt with.

kevin

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 15:49:48 +0100

>

>gets lousy.
>
No complaints there.  But driving a 911 in snow is (IMHO) a whole bunch
of no fun.  My 911 is my daily driver, but daily driving for me has
to include a large dose of enjoyment.  Driving in snow simply isn't
enjoyable.  It's even less enjoyable when you're worried about being
run into by idiots who haven't even bothered to mount winter tyres,
which in Switzerland is always a problem when the first snow comes,
even if it comes as late as December.

Furthermore, even when there's no snow or ice on the roads in winter,
there's still salt left on the road, so even if you don't drive in
snow, you still need the galvanization, unless you put your car in the
garage until summer.

On top of all that, a sports car wearing snow tyres is only half a
sports car.
>
>No Subarus for this man!
>
Nor for me, but I find my old trusty-and-rusty VW Golf Synchro to be
the preferred form of transport when it's snowy/icy.  I frankly don't
care what happens to that car, so long as I survive the accident.

Chris

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 10:17:10 -0500 (EST)
From: "David I Johnson" <johnso76@pilot.msu.edu>
Subject: Florida Porsches

Howdy Philers,

I just got back from from 3000 miles in my Volvo Wagon. It turned 225,000 on
the trip. During the trip several things of interest(maybe) are worth sharing.

I saw the 993 that was driven to Daytona, run for 24 hours and driven back. The
car was owned by a dealer on Fairbanks Street in Orlando. He had the car on
display on his lot. I saw it with the engine cover up and except for the roll
bar looked pretty stock to me. The body took a little abuse in the race so that
it looked like a sightly bloodied solder. He 10 or 12 used Porsches on his lot
all the way from 930's to 356's. One was of special interest for the story and
the opportunity. Nord Nordstrom the owner had a white 1986 Cab. slant nose
metal conversion that has all the right stuff but was well used. Interior
needed redoing, stereo had been stolen etc. It had about 80,000 miles on it. It
was on consignment because the son had been killed in a motorcycle accident
according to the salesperson.  He thought it could be bought in the mid to low
twenties. If you go to Orlando visit Nord's and the dealers across the street
who deal in unusual and older american cars.

The other car of interest was a 1987 944 turbo at the Lincoln Mercury Dealer in
Cocoa Beach. It had been repainted, 102,000 miles by a local Doctor. They were
asking $8,400 but were down to $7000 before I had to leave.

Dave Johnson
85.5 944
89 Volvo
86 Ford SVO
85 Ford SVO
75 Cosworth Vega

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 09:44:12 -0700
From: Drew Spencer <Drew_Spencer@Novell.COM>
Subject:  Re: Heat cycling new tires... -Reply

> Larry Says...
Question #1 - Heat cycling tires is done by bringing them up to
TRACK operating temperature ~ 200 degrees fahrenheit, then
allowing them to cool.
 But this is not something that is done to "break in" the tires, like
you would do with brakes.  It is something that happens when
you use them.  BTW, most tires work the best right out of the
box, and thier performance deteriorates with each heat cycle. 
That is why most race teams use "sticker tires", that is new tires,
when they need the most speed, or they will run new tires for a
few laps to test them, and save them for when they are needed.
> End included text

WRT: The performance of "green" tires.
On the autox list, there's an engineer from BFG who has
been helping those of us who use his product to get the
most out of the R1's.  The word from BFG is that the tires
will work best if they're heat cycled once, then allowed to
cure for 24 hours or so.  I don't know all the details, but
is consistent with my experience.  It's rather easy to wear
a race tire to the cord if you don't cure them first.  I understand
this is even more acute in slicks. 

In addition, if you watch Indycar, Nascar, or F1, you'll notice 
that they typically "scrub-in" all their tire sets in practice 
before raceday so they have a chance to cure.  Qualifiers are 
a different beast since they only have to last a couple of laps. 

Of course, this is all IMHO....

Drew
Drew_Spencer@novell.com
'82 911 SC
'93 RS America (Headed to Vegas to try out the new track
this weekend!!!!!)

core in exchange?????????????????????????

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 95 09:55:35 PST

Text item:

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Gates 959 and others
Author:  porschephiles-request@tta.com at SMTPGATE
Date:    3/13/95 6:45 AM


    I finally went to my semi-authorized Gates biography for the semi-
approved scoop on the 959, etc.  The book was reviewed and ok'd by 
Gates, but not co-written.  The bottom line is this is the most 
reliable info I have on the subject.
     
    Gates and Allen bought two 959s together at the end of 1988.
Gates got a silver one and Allen a white one.  They paid $380,000 
each and were able to drive them for a year as has been previously 
noted.  When the foreign exemption ran out in Jan 90, the cars got 
stored.  It would have cost $30,000 to ship the cars to Germany and 
go through that process.  The cars were stored in a Free Trade Zone 
warehouse in Oakland while Gates and Allen tried to argue with the 
feds about certification.  In the meantime, an Allen employee flies 
down every few weeks to start the engines and makes sure they are 
roadworthy.
     
    That's the most recent info I have, but the book is two years
old.  The rumors about putting the car in a trailer in Washington and 
trying to sneak it in through Canada are intriguing.
     
    Other Gates info:  his FIRST car was a used dark green 911 which
he drove quite hard.  In addition to the Lexus daily driver, he has a 
Mustang, Porsche C4 cabriolet, and a Ferrari 348.  On the record he 
only has one ticket since 1988, but I'm sure there are several others 
that the legal staff have dealt with.
     
kevin

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 95 10:08:39 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Braided Steel Lines



Okay, Here goes on the subject. 

Like any other type of hose, there are specific braided lines for a 
particular function or liquid. Brake fluid will attack any non-compatable
hose, whether braided or not. I have seen non-compatable lines used 
in SCCA because the owner didn't know hat he was being sold. Fortunately,
the failure was gradual and we were able to help him figure the problem 
out. 

When ordering any hose, whether plain or braided, know the pressure, 
specific application (water, gasoline, oil brake fluid, etc) when 
you order. There will be substancial cost differences in many cases.
Oh yeah, we shouldn't forget whether the line will be under pressure or
suction.

Some of the performance warehouses are stating in their ads that some
braided line is NOT compatable with brake fluid.

As the ends are assembled, have someone that is knowledgable show you
how to assemble and dissassemble the ends from the lines. Purchase
any special tools required.

Braided lines can still be damaged (as can rubber) by friction created
by chassis flex, engine movement, vibration and plain poor installation.
I have a friend that installed a remote oil filter, thermostat and 
oil cooler on his tow vehicle. I notice an oil leak after a club
breakfast, decided to see what could be leaking on a two-month old 
4-wheel drive Blazer. My friend had neatly tie-wrapped the lines to the 
cooler to the front torsion bars. Each time the bar moved, it pulled on 
the lines. The fittings were now loose at the hose, but hadn't pulled 
apart yet. 

Use adele clamps to hold any lines like these in place. Internal pressure
can also make the lines move. These clamps have a single mount point and
securely hold the line in place. ALWAYS use the aluminum with rubber
overlay. Plastic breaks and plain metal will rub and chafe the hose.

Jim Pasha

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 95 10:49:52 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Freeing Brake Pistons



Pat-

If you can't blow out the piston with compressed air
(And as someone else noted, 60 psi isn't very much.
Try 100.) then a sure-fire way to get the piston out
is to reconnect the caliper to the brake line and
step on the brake pedal.  I've never had that fail.

I'd try to repair the units rather than buy rebuilts.
It's unlikely that there's anything wrong with them, and
a repair kit only costs about $5.  Also, you might not
really have to replace the pistons with stainless ones.
Remember, the piston itself doesn't touch the cylinder
wall, only the rubber seal does, so a piston can get
to looking pretty ugly and still do a perfectly good
job.  I'd be willing to bet that the inside of your
pistons (the side you haven't seen yet...) is clean, and
only the outside is rusted.  Wire brush off the rust,
and you should be in good shape.

 -Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 14:03:44 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: 944 oil leaks (aka "Lou's experience...)

Ok folks, here's the poop. I cannot stand leaks! These observations are
based on my own experience with my 85.1 944. I figure I pass this info to you
since Trev and Clint had questions on oil leaks. YMMV

First, lest do the oil cooler. I had a leak comming from the bottom of the oil
cooler. It masked itself by dripping on top on the lower balance shaft assmbly.
I thought I had a LBS seal going. Took it apart, replaced seals, put the whole
thing bacK together. Still leaked. 

I thought I could try to put some gook around the perimeter and put the whole
thing back together. Well, that was a great idea! After starting the engine,
it look like Niagara Falls. As it turns out, there are 2 oil seals (orings)
that did not go where they were supposed to go. I thought I could remove
and fix my leak with the exhaust manifold in place. Well, the
OC cover wont come out!

I ended up taking the head off to replace the oil seals around the oil cooler
cover. The good news is that there is an improved seal that has the orings
mounted to a thin aluminum carrier. So it goes in nice and easy. Got it from
Zims. Also, there are improved (Viton?) seals for the oil cooler.(green)

While I was there, I also replaced the two orings that actually seal the oil
cooler to the engine. Any way, If your oil cooler seals are bad, the head
or at least the exhaust manifold must come out. The nuts on the EM looked
like they were not going to come out. So I took the easy way out and removed
the head/EM in one piece. So I put in a new head gasket.

Watch out for a hanging oil pressure relief valve. I hear there is a tool
to center it while you tighten the OC cover. I used my pinkie to make sure therewas free movement. I've done about 2K with no problems.

What I'm trying to say, is that if the oil cooler seals are bad, you might 
have to do the HG anyway to get to it.

Next, the oil seals. I too, replaced the oil seal on all 3 cams. Watch out for
the lower BS. The shaft rotates in the opposite direction of the other two.
There is a special lower seal (they have little arrows showing rotation).

I was given a tip by a professional P mechanic. It seams that on 928s they
use an inner oring that acts a third oil barrier. The way it works is this.
The shaft has a step down, there is an onion skin plastic gasket that goes
over the shaft and lays against the internal front bearing. In my car,
one of them was missing! 

There is also a part that looks like a top hat. The CS seal rides on the surface. I think you can actually wear a grove on it. If you change the seal, you 
might be ok for a while. I think this might be Clint's problem. Zims sell the
kit that includes the running surfaces (top hats). Any way, the oil seal that
I referred to before, goes inside this top hat. There is an actual grove cut
out for it. The mechanic suggested to get it installed (probably a few cents)
They do it onn all their cars by default. 
It looks like 928s use it but Porsche does not include it on a 944. It has 
a 928 part number.

Seal here->     |        |==============
           _____|        |
	     |    -------|
	     |
	     |      
 928 oring > |      
	     |    -------|
	   -----|        |  
		|        |============ SHAFT
             ^
         Top hat         ^
                         |
                         Paper thin gasket                         

Pardon the ASCII graphics!

While you have the head/EM out you might want to check the LBS cover for leaks.
The bugger will not come off. You can get all bolts off except one that hits
the EM. How do I know? Guess what I did this weekend?

Hope this helps!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories     len@library.att.com	   201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa  / '85 Guards Red 944
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo / '88 Silver BMW 325is

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 14:15:32 -0500
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: Armour-All et al

Keep away form that nasty greasy goop! 

For interiors (plastic, vinyl, rubber)  use Meguiars Mirrorglaze 40. Works
much better and does not leave a film of grease on everything.

I use it on my exterior rubber (Spoiler, bumpers etc) My car has lived ten
years in the Arizona sun and the rubber looks almost new.

> that can lead to a quick thinning of the species. We lost some
> B-52s early in the 'Nam goat-rope just because of that. They
> then developed the trail formation that got away from the

Two Items, Herb.  First, this is a *Porsche* list.  Accordingly, please remember
that Goat-ropers need love too!  Second, Damn Straight on that wing-tip
vortex business:  When I was (pretending to be) working for Continental Air
Services in Saigon back during that earlier Phun Phest, we lost a Beech Baron
to wing-tip vorticies from a C-130 that had landed about 5 minutes earlier!

About 150 feet above the Strip on short final, sudden wing-over and *splat*
Your basic non habit-forming error.  Them WTVs are *persistent* little 
varmints; not to meantion, deadly...Moral: Never follow a C-130 too closely
in your 911 (928s are ok, being heavy and front-engined water-pumpers...)

Bart

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 11:39:58 -0800 (PST)
From: scokelly@netcom.com (Scott Kelly)
Subject: Buying 1989 911 C4 - Questions...

I have found a 911 C4 (1989) that I am ready to purchase (pending
my mechanics okay-dokay).  I'm looking for any last minute things
that I have overlooked that possibly a current C4 owner (or previous
owner) can think of to avoid any expensive mistakes.

The Car:
Red w/ black, 1989 911 C4; asking $34,900; 21k miles; Original owner; All 
records; No wrecks; New tires; Flawless exterior/interior; No leaks from 
engine or differentials.  I just can not find anything wrong with the 
car.  It has had two modifications: higher performance exhaust (not sure 
which manufacturer) and a performance chip ( I forgot manufacturer).

Me:
I've been looking for 9 months.  I have found two other cars that I was 
ready to buy but my mechanic said that they were leaking or had been in 
accidents.  I have a 1985.5 944 that I will sell soon.  I do all the work 
on the car except clutches, timing belts, that kinda things.  I do all 
oil changes; interior work; motor mounts; plugs; basic engine components; 
brake work (rotors & pads); etc.  I know the 911 is a different animal, 
but if any shade tree mechanics would like to comment on their 
experiences - I'll listen.

I guess I'm looking for things like: "I know there was a recall on the 
engine to head seals - you may want to make sure it has been taken care 
of".  Things like that.  Or typical problems of a 1989 C4 that I can 
expect to have to deal with.  Of if any one knows of any possible 
problems with a performance chip (passing emmisions. idling problems, 
cold weather problems; hot weather problems, do I need to retain the old 
chip, etc) I would be interested to hear them.

Thanks for any info.
Scott Kelly
scokelly@netcom.com

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 14:54:53 -0500

Subject: Re: 3.2 For Sale

AutoBahn reports:

<I have a good customer who is looking to sell a 3.2 that I sold to him about
<3 years ago. He put a 3.6 in and is looking to sell his 3.2 . 
<It has 44k on the ticker. 

I can see why he is a GOOD customer.

<Will sell this nice motor for: $7,000.00 with a core 3.0 or 3.2
<in exchange.

WHAT ??? $7,000 for a 44K 3.2. Look around, I know of at least TWO 3.6s with
brain and harness that are for sale for less. Average 3.2 sales in Pano are
around $4750 to $5500 for premium examples. And you want a core ???

Bart D

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 14:22:48 -0500 (EST)

well, after nearly 100k & 8 years of rust-belt abuse, my muffler is 
finally ready to be buried.

The dealer says that the stock '87 944 exhaust is about $500.. thumbing 
through Excellence, i see that "OEM style" ansa is $200... 
Performance Products has an "aluminized steel" OEM style muffler for 
$224... am I correct in assuming that the original exhaust was aluminized?

Any experiences/horror stories about these OEM style exhausts would be 
appreciated.

As for driving 944's in the snow... 
Indeed, it ain't like my old subaru. Still not as bad as other RWD cars 
i've driven, particularly since  i've jettisoned the Pirelli P6 deathtraps.

The galvanization process seems to have rendered the hull totally 
impenetrable... The body looks virtually as good as when the car was 
new.. I wonder what drives most 944's to their graves? it ain't rust.

adam

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 95 15:21:00 PST
From: "Golden, Arthur" <agolden@pepsi.com>
Subject: RE: replacement 944 exhaust?


Adam writes

>well, after nearly 100k & 8 years of rust-belt abuse, my muffler is
>finally ready to be buried.
>The dealer says that the stock '87 944 exhaust is about $500.. thumbing
>through Excellence, i see that "OEM style" ansa is $200...
>Performance Products has an "aluminized steel" OEM style muffler for
>$224... am I correct in assuming that the original exhaust was aluminized?

After 90k mine went on my '88 44S. Although it's a different exhaust, it's 
similiar enough to comment. Over the years, different people have commented 
that the stock exhaust is engineered to complement the car so well that it's 
one of the stock items that you would normally not want to change. I can't 
recall the exact dollars but a new exhaust was about $700 and no one made a 
"OEM style" for the S because of it's limited production. I found a salvage 
(I forget where but can check) for about $250. I now have 120k on the car 
and it's working fine (I'm right at the break even point so if it fails and 
I need to get another $250 salvage, it's still cheaper than buying a new 
one).

BTW, I used the existing rubber hangers and they're still OK but I did 
change the ring between the exhaust and cat (~$12 for the OEM ring)

* replace all I's with mechanic


Arthur E. Golden
AGolden@Pepsi.com
1988 944S

Date:          Mon, 13 Mar 1995 13:42:13 +700
From: JBUTLER@park.admin.utah.edu
Subject:       022 Distributor

I'm getting ready to freshen up the 022 cast iron distributor for my 
912. The shim kit from Stoddards has a few parts that were NOT in 
the distributor when I took it apart. 

One 1 inch OD (outside diameter) brown fiber washer

One 3/4 inch OD green fiber washer

Four felt disks, two 1/3 inch, two slightly larger

Two small C-clips

One larger C-clip

I'm also wondering how to use the shims. I assume that I should shim 
between the drive gear and the drive shaft bushing to keep the 
contact plate from bearing any load from below, correct?

aluminized?
>>

>> appreciated.

My experience with Ansa on a couple cars (not Porsche) in New England is 
that they rust about twice as fast as stock exhaust systems. And that is 
compared to systems which were not stainless as some Porsche and Audi ones 
are. I would stay away from Ansa particularly in the rust-belt.

Peter

Date: 13 Mar 95 16:00:27 -0500
From: mvmas@mvujc.att.com
Subject: Re: 914 brakes and ABS

>The 914 brake system has a proportioning valve located on the lower firewall
>(below the engine sheetmetal) accessable from the bottom of the car on the
>driver's side. Historically, this little gem has been known to trap a large 
>amount of air. If you are replacing a master cylinder or any  rear brake 
>hoses or the calipers, you must bleed the proportioning valve also.
>
>This is accomplished by first bleeding all the calipers and getting pedal. 
>Then you must (as the valve has no bleeder) break the connecting nuts on the 
>lines to bleed the valve. First do the line leaving the valve, then the input 
>line. I highly recommend this be done MANUALLY to get enough pressure to make 
>the valve move. 
>[ABS deleted]
>
> Jim Pasha

Could you elaborate on this procedure?  I know you had posted a similar
message last year, and I did attempt to bleed the proportioning valve,
although I'm not clear on what you mean by making the valve move.  I
would think that it would be hard to get that amount of pressure with
a loose nut, and even if you did you would spray fluid at ridiculous
speed.  They should make a bleeder you could insert inline.  Anybody
know what the inside of one of these valves looks like?  

Thanks,
Mark Skala
mvmas@mvujc.att.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 95 15:57:00 EST
From: Peter Tracy <pgt@novelmail.keps.com>
Subject: RE: Open(?!) or closed CV boots?



 ----------
>> From: porschephiles-request
>> To: "porschephiles@tta.com"
>> Subject: Open(?!) or closed CV boots?
>> Date: Monday, March 13, 1995 2:07PM
>>
>> 
 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------  
 --
>>
>> I would never do this to my P-car, but this question is about my
>> 87 VW Jetta, which is the daily driver. However, others may think of
>> it for any car.
>>
>> I just noticed the front left CV boot is torn. Do I need to take
>> everything apart to put the new boots, or do I just buy the split-type
>> advertised in JC Whitney and slip it over the shaft?
>>
>> If the net wisdom is that the split shaft is not a good idea, then what 
is
>> the process from removing the wheel to getting to the boots? Any
>> particular pitfalls?
>>

I have had mixed success with the split boots. The difference in effort is 
not so great that I would just do it right. You just need to remove the 
drive shaft by taking off the axle nut and the six hex screws which hold the 
end at the transaxle. You should loosen the axle nut before jacking up the 
car because it is large and on tight. Also, don't put the car back down on 
the wheels without the axle in because you can damage the wheel bearings. 
The CV joint can be removed by taking off a circlip and hitting the end of 
the axle with a mallet as I recall. The Bentley manual gives a good diagram 
on how to get it apart. (The only problem I had was that some of the 
bearings inside the joint came out when I was cleaning out the old grease 
and rolled under my workbench!) Good luck!

Peter

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 16:23:54 -0500
From: AutoBahn1@aol.com
Subject: Parts buying.

I see the price for the 3.2 that my customer has for sale is causing a little
bit of angry replies.
No 1. Yes I know you can buy used motors out of Pana for $4,500.00-5,000.00.
But let me ask you this: Are you getting a good motor or is it stolen???? Are
you getting good paperwork to go with it. Who are you buying from? Where did
they get the engine from. Do they have a reciept?  For you uninformed
P-people, there is alot of stolen parts out there!!!! What happens if you are
caught with a stolen motor? ( Well, it was a good deal, but???? I didn't know
it was stolen.) The new scam is the chop shops are paying people not to
report cars stolen and selling the parts. When you run the #'s they come
clean, then about 3-4 months later, the car is reported stolen.
Guess what, your good deal is now the property of the insurance company. You
are out the motor,(or whatever), and your cash. At least you will not go to
jail. Or, what about motors that come from overseas? How do you run their
numbers? Unless you can get verification from InterPol how do you know it
wasn't stolen overseas.
Regarding 3.6 motors for $7,000.00. What are you going to put it in?
That is why they are so inexpensive. It cost alot of money to put them in an
early car. Most of the C-2, C-4's that come through the auctions are not
getting rebuilt. With a salvage title,  it is getting harder and harder to
get a loan on these cars.  Before anyone else e-mails me back saying that
$7,000.00 is crazy, please think about what is going on in the market. When
it sounds to good to be true, it usally is. I run a salvage yard for a
living. I have seen and heard it all. 
I hope my little message keeps someone out of trouble. 
Matt Safranski
65 911

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 95 16:15:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 oil leaks (aka "Lou's experience...)


Hi Lou,

>What I'm trying to say, is that if the oil cooler seals are bad, you might
>have to do the HG anyway to get to it.

You don't need to remove the exhuast header or the engine head to
reseal the oil/water heat exchanger.  It's icky, and you do it from under
the car, but there you go.  (I assume by HG you are referring to the
head gasket.)

If you're going to do the work yourself, treat yourself to the special
line-up tool for the oil pressure relief valve.  Through MY86, it's
p/n 000.721.921.50 and lists for $22.35.  From MY87 on, it's 000.721.926.21
and lists for $18.85.  Also consider replacing the rear o-ring on the
relief valve while you have it out.

>Next, the oil seals. I too, replaced the oil seal on all 3 cams. Watch out 
for
>the lower BS. The shaft rotates in the opposite direction of the other two.
>There is a special lower seal (they have little arrows showing rotation).

These radial oil seals come in two sizes, depending on the application.
For the lower balance shaft, you want the 30 x 48 mm part, 999.113.281.40.
For the upper balance shaft, it's the 30 x 47 mm part, 999.113.282.40.
There is of course a special tool for tamping them into place.  However,
if you lube the edges and work *slowly* with a drift, you should be OK.

>I was given a tip by a professional P mechanic. It seams that on 928s they
>use an inner oring that acts a third oil barrier. The way it works is this.
>The shaft has a step down, there is an onion skin plastic gasket that goes
>over the shaft and lays against the internal front bearing. In my car,
>one of them was missing!

This is correct for the eight-valve 944's.  There is an inner gasket, some
sort of clear material, 944.105.321.00.  On it rides what Porsche calls a
spacer but some folks call a "slinger" (don't have p/n handy).  And the
radial seal rides on the slinger.  The slinger itself is a wear item -- as 
it
turns within the oil seal,the inner lip of the seal wears a groove in the
slinger.  If you have an oil leak, and on removal you can catch your
thumbnail in the groove, replace it.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 14:26:29 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Freeing Brake Pistons

Bob Spindel wrote:

>I'd be willing to bet that the inside of your
>pistons (the side you haven't seen yet...) is clean, and
>only the outside is rusted.  Wire brush off the rust,
>and you should be in good shape.

I'll second the first sentence, but instead of using a wire brush I would
recommend a metal polish (like Flitz).  If you use the polish, though, be
100% sure that it's all gone when you're finished (I wash things off with
warm, soapy water) to avoid any problems due to polish that remains. 

I've overhauled 22 calipers of various makes, age and condition, and I've
never been unable to "bring one back from the dead" -- it's really pretty
straightforward, just timeconsuming.

 ____________________________________

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 95 14:54:30 PST
From: Miq Millman <mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com>
Subject: Armor All

It's not the use of AA that causes cracks per se, it is the lack of use.

Like addictive drugs, once you start using Armor All, be prepared to continue
its monthly dosage ad infinitum.  If you ever stop for more than two months
(like a winter storage) enjoy the numerous cracks that appear in your P-car.

Protectant 303 makes a product that replaces the stuff AA causes to dry out
and it doesn't require many regular reapplications.


Besides those two red headed twins with the mustangs are really goofy
looking.

- -- 
Miq Millman   mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com	  503 642 6139   (Aloha site)
AL4-55  Intel, 5200 NE Elam Young Parkway, Hillsboro, OR 97124-6497
See also miq@teleport.com

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 08:57:02 -0800
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: Re[2]: Braided Brake Lines

Stan and others

It should be noted that the ZR1 Corvette used braided line even where it could
have used rigid steel line.  The reasoning may have been the could fab the steel
lines in time to meet production schedules.  But they sold the cars that way.
Maybe we should have somebody who really knows about these lines comment on 
there life expectancy, especially in automotive use.

Dan
Dswiger@qntm.com


>  Since these lines are used in aircraft, 

>cars. Parts have a "life" rating -- when they are so old, measured in 
>racing hours, flight hours, or just plain wall clock time, they're 
>removed, discarded, and replaced. In the time interval between the
>time they're installed and the time that they're junked, there are
>regular inspection intervals called out by the maintenece schedule for
>that part. If it doesn't pass inspection, it gets pulled early. If you
>see enough of that, the part either gets its "useful life" rating shortened,
>or it gets de-rated for use. Period.

>Now: when someone can show me that they really do this on their STREET CAR,
>I'll tell them to go ahead and use the braided lines. But most people 
>don't even *THINK* about such parts. It'll get installed and that's
>the last anyone will think about it until there's some other compelling
>reason to crawl into that part of the car. Hence the recommendation to
>not use them.



Once again, fitness for use is *NOT* **EVER** to be imputed from use in
an analogous situation. FOR ANYTHING!!! 

Stan

for 18 consequtive years.                    Tax Credits for prior programs

excellent return!

full ten-year credit period.                   They do not vary with changes 
in interest rates or fluctuations in the stock and bond                      
markets.
        3.  Tax Credits reduce your tax bill, dollar-for-dollar.  Every 
dollar of Credit provides a full dollar                 of additional 
spendable after-tax income.
        4.  The only alternative to Tax Credits is tax payment.

Dear Porschephiles,

This is hard, but needs doing.  I apologize to Larry Herman, and to Tony;
and to you all for my childish Public responses to Larry and Tony.

These responses of mine did not set the kind of example I am proud of, rather
th opposite, I'm afraid.  My public responses were a childish public ego display
entirely inappropriate to this excellent group, and I am ashamed and sorry.

Stan is my friend, and I am proud of that.  Childish displays in defense of
a friend do not honor such friendship, and Stan, of all people, needs no defense
before this group. 

The appropriate response to Larry and Tony would have been Private.  
Furthermore, simple statements of the fact that the messages  were rude and 
inappropriate, along with a dispassionate explanation of why, would have been 
appropriate Public responses, and might have borne fruit.  As it is, I'm afraid
that all I accomplished was embarass and further alienate good people who
merely needed some leadership.

Larry and Tony, I'm sorry for any embarassment I may have caused.  If you need 
an example of how to modify your behavior on this group, (and you do)  please 
take this, and not my earlier childish display, as an example of Porschephile 
behavior.

Bart Chambers

Hi again,
	Well even though the infamous 944 is now being taken out and about, I have 
noticed that the throttle response is not what I think it should be.  When 
cruising, if some acceleration is required the response is distinctly lacking, in 
the sense that the throttle needs to be depressed a long way before the car will 
speed up.  It is almost as if it holds back when the throttle is operated a little 
way.  Could this be an indication of a mass air flow sensor fault?  Changing the 
air filter has made no effect, and I am just about to replace the Bosch platinum 
plugs with splitfires, which I have been told are much better.
	Any way of checking for vacuum leaks using the mpg indicator?  Any other 
ideas/comments?

joints stronger still?

seem to be aquired in very large quantities by a handful of "racing" shops
and/or parts suppliers.

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 23:44:15 -0500
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: Re: Armour All et Al

Dave queried the advisibilty of using Armour All ( or other silicone based
products)

The problems associated  with silicone based products may be broken down into
the two catagories of usage,  tires and vinyl:

1. Tires/Rubber Trim:  There are two main degrading agents that attack tires.
 They are UV light waves and ozone.  Both of these attack the long
hydrocarbon chains of the rubber and by breaking these chemical bonds,
shorten the molecules with resulting loss of elasticity and other problems.
 Tire manufacturers add two primary sacrificial protectants to the rubber.
 To protect against UV, they add carbon black.  This is why tires don't come
in designer colors to match your paint. The carbon black will turn white/gray
as it absorbs the UV and dissipates the energy as heat. Thus the basis of
rubber parts turning gray as they age.  To protect against ozone, tire
manufacturers add a wax based sacrificial protectant.  The ozone
attacks the wax and depletes it.  As the tire rolls, additional wax is forced
to the surface of the tire.  This is referred to as "blooming".  This
blooming refreshes the surface wax protectant.  A tire that has not been
flexed will have the wax depleted by the ozone and thus begin to degrade and
suffer  "dry rot". The silicone oil in Armour All et Al may actually dissolve
the wax and be the cause of premature tire side wall cracking/failure.  It is
rumored that some tire manufacturers will not honor warranties on failures
caused by silicone based products.  I am in the process of checking with the
major tire manufacturers to determine the validity of this rumor.   In
conclusion, any tire dressing should contain a UV protectant to bolster the
efforts of the carbon black and preferably not contain any silicone.

Plastics/Vinyls:  The dash, door panels, seat backs, and numerous other
interior/exterior trim pieces are usually vinyl.  Vinyl may be viewed as raw
semi-liquid vinyls that are held in place by a solid vinyl "skin" (this
description is for illustration only and not a PhD chemical dissertation ).
 The dash and other vinyl parts of your P car are constantly bombarded by UV
that breaks down the molecules of the skin, allowing the raw vinyls to escape
(off-gassing).  These vinyls then may deposit themselves on the glass,
forming a haze that is difficult to remove.  If you have such a haze, it is
probably your dash that has decided to pick up stakes and migrate(back to
Germany?).  Silicone based products do not usually contain UV protectants,
and the silicone may act as a magnifying glass, intensifying the UV
degradation.  Silicone oil may also dissolve the essential oils in the vinyl
skin, hastening the premature formation of cracks in the vinyl skin.  A
quality vinyl protectant will contain a UV protectant and essential oils to
replace lost oils from the vinyl.  These protectants are expensive, so the
K-Mart specials may do more harm than good. Silicone also has very strong
electrostatic attraction which may be considered beneficial in that it will
tend to stay where it is placed, but will also attract every dust particle in
the surrounding three counties.

There are numerous quality products on the market.  If anyone wishes a
partial list,  or there  are any questions, or areas that need amplification,
please contact me.

Larry Reynolds
Car Care Specialties, Inc.
"We will sell no silicone... except for Yugos"
Post Office Box 535
Saddle Brook,  NJ  07663-0535
Phone (201) 796-8300
Fax (201) 791-9743
E-mail carcaresp@aol.com

1990 944S2 Cabrio Waxer
1986 944 Turbo Tracker
19__ Wifer
1989 Dumb as Dirt Granddog

Date: Mon, 13 Mar 1995 23:36:15 -0600
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Re: 944 oil leaks (aka "Lou's experience...)

Thanks very much for the advice, but I'm wondering about your following point:


At 2:03 pm 3/13/95, len@library.mt.att.com wrote:

(lots of cool stuff deleted ...)

>cooler to the engine. Any way, If your oil cooler seals are bad, the head
>or at least the exhaust manifold must come out. The nuts on the EM looked
>like they were not going to come out. So I took the easy way out and removed
>the head/EM in one piece. So I put in a new head gasket.

>What I'm trying to say, is that if the oil cooler seals are bad, you might
>have to do the HG anyway to get to it.

Oh man, take off the head? I would say the easy way out would be to dump
some penetrating oil on the exaust man. studs/nuts, walk away for a couple
of hours, come back and ease those puppies off real slow (heck, there's
only 8 of them I think). Then, clean the threads with the proper size
metric die, and a little anti-seize before re-assembly with new nuts. I
really wouldn't want to deal with taking off the whole intake side of
things, then the head, just so I wouldn't have to deal with some rusty
nuts!

But hey, to each his own !!

regards (and thanks again for the info)
trev.

Date: Tue, 14 Mar 95 04:42:00 UTC
From: w.oconnell4@genie.geis.com
Subject: Gremlin

  OK, now that we are done pounding Larry for having the nerve to ask for a
reason not to use stainless steel lines, I have a strange problem with my
'81 SC turn signal s/4 way flashers.  They die for some reason every now and
again. The only constant factor I have been able to determine is, the
working/non working is for the entire ride, that is, if they work they will
continue to work until the car is parked and if they don't work its the same
deal.  IE, took ol' blue to work today and on the way in, they were just
fine but coming home tonight - zip.  Turn the car off and on - no
difference. Push the 4 way button and nothing.  They have been know not to
work for days and then, as if by magic, start working again and stay that
way for a long period.  Other times it's work today, not tomorrow, and ok
the next.
  Thanks
 
Bill O'Connell - Riesentoter Region, PCA

Porschephiles #1238                         Tue Mar 14 11:13:10 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 9 Mar 95 21:45:14 MST
From: hrubin@nyx10.cs.du.edu (Howard Rubin)
Subject: Non-factory keys for P-car alarms

My 911 came without an alarm key so I took the lock out
and dropped it off at the local locksmith for a bit.
The key he made says 'Italy' and has the inscription
WT 10 on one side and a large S on the other side.
In order to drive the car I put a resistor in instead
of the key alarm switch, 4700 ohms as I recall.
If you're having trouble getting keys made, drop me a
line and I'll get you the phone number of the locksmith
I used.

Howard Rubin - 82 SC - hrubin@nyx.cs.du.edu

Date: Tue, 14 Mar 95 07:39:36 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 smooth acceleration.

Hi, Jan,

> Hi again,
> 	Well even though the infamous 944 is now being taken out and about, I have 
> the sense that the throttle needs to be depressed a long way before the car w
> speed up.  It is almost as if it holds back when the throttle is operated a l
> way.  Could this be an indication of a mass air flow sensor fault?  Changing 
> air filter has made no effect, and I am just about to replace the Bosch plati
> plugs with splitfires, which I have been told are much better.

Friends don't let friends do Splitfires...Just say no.

Stay with the platinum plugs...they are not your problem...

Check the length of your throttle cable. Is there too much slack there?
Have you changed your fuel filter yet?  What are your fuel system pressure
readings? Do you have any other symptoms other than a lack of power?
What's compression look like? Is your valve timing *exactly* right?
Is there a possibility that your catalyst/exhaust system is clogged?

The answers to the above questions will get you started on the road to
recovery...

Good luck...

> 	Any way of checking for vacuum leaks using the mpg indicator?  Any o

No.

Date: Tue, 14 Mar 1995 07:55:52 -0600
From: TODD.COHEN@rrd.com
Subject: Track Info Thanks and Oil Leaks

RR DONNELLEY & SONS COMPANY
 
          TO:        OAS     -00000001 *porschephiles@tta.com
 
          FROM:      TODD.COHEN
 
          DATE:      03/14/95
          SUBJECT:   Track Info Thanks and Oil Leaks
 
 
I wanted to thank everyone who sent me information and advice for
preparing for my first track event at Summit Point.  I was able to have
the car inspected locally and then breeze through inspection at the track.
It was a wonderful and enjoyable experience, and I could not have spent
the day with people any nicer.  My instructor was great, and we spent alot
of time after each session analyzing and talking though my mistakes, and
the correct points that I did.  It certainly does take a different
approach and control of the car, than autocrossing, but I can also see
some items that I can work on to improve my autocrossing skills, being
smoooooth, and being careful about following the line.
 
Now that I have been able to drive the car for more than about a hour at a
time, 3 hours round trip to the track, then 80 minutes of track time.  I
am able to determine were all my oil leaks are, and why I went through
about a quart and a half of oil at the track.  It seems my oil tank is
leaking.  I thought that the leak was from the short length of rubber hose
that leads off the bottom of the tank.  But, I think it is from the
backside where the wire for the oil level sender connect, since there
seems to be oil all around the tank.  After I round up a 36mm wrench, I
can get the oil tank off the car.
 
Would the sender be the problem?  The top oil line, and breather hoses
don't have any oil around them, and the oil outlet on the bottom does not
seem to have enough oil around it to soak the tank, and I doubt it would
soak the tank at a level higher than the outlet.
 
I know that a previous owner had a shop replace the tank about 6 years ago
for the same reason.  Do oil tanks have problems with the seams leaking,
or getting damaged?  Being a 1972, the oil tank is in front of the rear
wheel, so it should be better protected, that was one of the reasons for
putting it there in the first place.
 
 
Todd Cohen
1972 911T (Leaf Green)

Date: Tue, 14 Mar 95 08:46:00 PST
From: "Goodman, John" <Goodmjo@hvsmtp1.mdc.com>
Subject: brake lines


With all the commotion over SS braided brake lines lately, I thought I'd go 
ahead and throw this in.  Eurasian Parts Select offers DOT APPROVED "Kevlar 
stainless steel brake lines with 10x's less expansion than Aeroquip-3 hose" 
for most models of BMWs.  It's a safe bet that they carry them for Porsches. 
 Price is $75 a set, but it should be noted that most BMWs take six hoses 
rather than the "usual" four.  So, if someone is looking for an economical 
replacement of their factory lines with the high-tech look of the SS lines 
and the peace of mind that comes with the blessing of the almighty DOT, 
these lines may be the ticket.  I don't have these lines on any of my cars, 
but I have dealt with EPS in the past and was more than satisfied with their 
service.  Of course, YMMV.

John Goodman
'85 911
'88 M3

------------------------------

Date: 14 Mar 95 09:53:44 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Freeing brake pistons

 
Bob Spindel says that brake pistons can look pretty grungy and still work.
 
Yes, but only to a point. If the hard chrome plating on the piston is
flaking, especially in the area where it slides past the seal, it will
destroy the new seals in no time at all. Clean piston with
fine crocus cloth (this doesn't take off any metal to speak of), maybe clean
the bore likewise if it looks bad, rinse very thoroughly, inspect, and
re-use or trashcan as required. I make a simple arbor by wrapping tape
around a suitable shaft, jamming the piston over the tape, chucking this
into a drill press, and using just enough crocus cloth to clean up the
surface.
 
If the plating is flaking in the critical area, the piston is junk, get the
new stainless ones. Flaking at the bottom of the piston, deep inside the
caliper where it never slides against the seal, is still acceptable.
 
Pete

A little note re: the Uniform Commercial Code.

Based on my experience and the experience of a number of people in
the salvage business that I trade with......

If you buy that used part  from an entity that is or presents itself
as being in the business of selling used parts and you are buying it 
to use (paying the sales and use tax is good proof of this) then it is
your part regardless of its origin. 

If you are in the business of buying and selling used parts and the 
part turns out to be stolen then you'll have to give it up.

I trade in used UNIX workstations, test equipment, electronic parts, 
and whatever other stuff I can make a buck on. (wanna buy a used cray
XMP28300 ?)


> living. I have seen and heard it all. 
 No you haven't! There's always a new scam ;-)
 From the present owner of a thrice stolen DeLorean.

 -bob

Date: Tue, 14 Mar 1995 07:17 -0800 (PST)
From: Robert_Yasek@NOTES.YMP.GOV
Subject: Re: Track Info Thanks and Oil Leaks


  Hey Todd,

  I have a '73 911T that had a fair sized oil leak a few months back.
  I isolated it to the oil tank, and it ended up being the assembly
  that the oil filter is screwed into. There is and O-ring in there and
  mine was very brittle and flattened (yes, I did get a lot of space
  shuttle jokes over this). Replacing the O-ring solved the problem,
  at a cost of a few bucks. It also got me to clean all the gunge that
  had accumulated around the tank.

  Hope this helps.

  Regards,

  Rob Yasek
  '73 911T
  '91 Bixby Noodlehead

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Mar 1995 11:37:57 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 questions


<1. Our 914 has an old tired dashboard, lots of cracks, but we inherited a
<nice new one with the car. With very little to do, (I love to tinker with
<it) -- the car is reunning wonderfully -- I thought I'd put the nice new
<dash in. Well, those 9 bolts are in horrible places. Is changing this as
<timeconsuming as it looks? Anyone know any dashchange trick? 

<2. Fred and I took the odometer zero-reset cable out when we fixed some 
<wiring behind the dash. When we put this cable back in, it does not 
<reset, it just turns. Never goes to zero. I'd like to fix it. No matter 
<how much I push, it does not 'seat' right I guess. Any suggestions?

<thanks in advance.


Dear Mark,

Dash replacement is relatively easy by following these steps:

1. Disconnect the battery and then remove the lower dash knee pad.
2. Remove the ashtray and, if easy, the radio.
3. Pull the three instruments forward. Remove the rubber gasket and push them
back through the cluster.
4. Remove the instrument surround.
5. Pry up slightly on the dash with a screwdriver and remove the two nuts
above the instruments with an open end 13mm wrench.
6. Remove the other nuts with a quarter inch drive ratchet with a 13mm
socket.
7. Installation is in reverse. We hold the two dashnuts up against the stud
with a putty knife and start with the 13mm open end wrench.

If you have pushed the reset cable all of the way into the instrument, it
will turn the numbers. Sometimes you have to turn it in reverse. The odometer
may never set the "tenths" to zero. However, this is typical.

George Hussey

Dear Craig and Rich (and all),

O.K., here is the official appraisal list that we have used for years! It
always works and is accepted by insurance companies. Unfortunately, to do a
proper appraisal, we need to see each car. However, you can all get an idea
of what we judge. The number slots are open because the market valve changes
yearly. Hope this helps!

For those of you unaware of our company allow me to introduce you to
Automobile Atlanta, 914 World Headquarters.

We are a vintage Porsche 914 dealership conducting an international catalog
mail-order business since 1978. Our credentials are as follows:

1) Our President is the Technical Chairman of the 914 Owners Association - a
worldwide club

2) Main contributor and editor of to the 914 Restorers Guide to Authenticity
 - The only book written about restoring the 914

3) Bi-Monthly contributor to the 914 technical column of European Car

4) Author of The 914 Technical Manual and many other 914 technical
publications

5) Contributor to Excellence Magazine and European Magazine and technical
consultant for 914 related inquiries

6) We have bought and sold 914s since 1975 keeping abreast of the market and
daily price changes.   We have sold at least ___  914s since ________ of
19___, most sold out of state.

7) We service most 914s in the Atlanta area, as well as many from out of
state and have a comprehensive restoration facility

8) Our technical staff make weekly calls to call all people selling 914s to
help keep us abreast of the market.

9) Many dealers, insurance companies and banks use our appraisal service to
establish fair market value of these cars

10) We conduct a multimillion dollar 914 mail order business world-wide with
over 35,000 active 914 owners.

Our appraisal of the particular 914 in question must first be prefaced by the
following remarks:




As everyone knows it is easy to determine the value of a car five years old
and newer but likewise very difficult to determine the value of older cars
because the vast differences in condition, i.e. poorly repaired collision
damage, rust out, indeterminable number of miles. Therefore one can only
establish value by directly comparing one vehicle to another and finding what
the market will pay for such a vehicle.

Since we at Automobile Atlanta have actually seen most 914 Porsches for sale
in at least the local market, we can place a value on each as it compares to
the other. The 914 is a part of Porsche history never to be repeated, is
highly regarded by collectors and therefore rapidly appreciating as fewer
nice examples are available. This letter deals with current market value on
the date specified.


The car in question is Customer Name:_____________________ 
Year:197___ Model: Porsche 914 Engine:  ____VIN #_____________ engine
ID#_______________  color: _____________.    The standard condition for
today's 914 is as follows:

1.  Repainted,  but immaculately, with no over spray.

2.  Mechanically excellent, extremely reliable with only slight oil leaks,
verifiable mileage just over 100,000.

3.  No rust whatsoever - even in the notorious battery tray area and never
damaged by collision.

4. Options to include five factory alloy wheels, front and rear
anti-swaybars, bilstein shocks, appearance group center console and chrome
bumpers. Air conditioning is of added value (some early models do not offer
all of these options).

5. Immaculate interior with minor dash cracks - radio inconsequential

6. The engine compartment would have all pieces properly attached and routed
with perfect battery stand and original factory fuel injection in perfect
working order.

7. The front and rear trunks would have original finish and be immaculate,

8. All rubber seals and bolt on trim would be in good condition with only
slight scratches and none would be missing.


Rating this standard car at 100 points, we only need to value each point to
determine the retail value of the 914 in question.  Since certain 914 models
are more popular than other, the per point value would be higher.  This
particular model a Year:____________ 914  Engine:_____________ rates $_____
per point.  Therefore the retail value of the standard 914 of this model is
$____________

Date: Tue, 14 Mar 1995 11:57:06 -0500
From: Beverly514@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1237 Tue M...

> I have a strange problem with my'81 SC turn signal  They die for >some
reason everynow and again

Bill,

Some time ago I had a smilar problem on my '70 911E. The condition was
sporadic and hard to trace. A friend of mine had similar symptoms but thought
it was probably a loose connection. Sometimes blinkers would work, or one
side would not work, or flashers, etc.,  etc.. Not long after discussing the
problem, his 911 had a dash fire. The culprit was the headlight switch.

I took my 911 down to the P shop, I asked them to inspect the headlight switch
. I described the symptoms and then what happened to our friends car. At
first they laughed, it was a one in a thousand chance that the switch could
cause the problem. I insisted that they inspect the switch and any other
electrical relays. 

When I went to pick up my car, the manager said he wanted to apologize. When
I asked for what, he handed me a headlight switch. The switch had already
started to go, he said he was surprised I had not had a dash fire already.
They could not find any other electrical components that needed replacement -
only the headlight switch!

Once the switch was replaced, the symptoms disappeared.

This may not be the problem with your 911 - but do not rule it out! 

Good Luck!!


Bev Frohm
70 911E Tangerine Targa ( show & tour)
74 914 2.0 - Still butt ugly, but soon to be a swan
Freckles the Calico Cat - always has PMS
Elmer the Cat - our six toed tear

Hi All,

My '66 912 is almost done (Finally!) and its time to prepare for a
test drive.  The car hasnt been DRIVEN in 17 years, the motor was
last RUN about 3+ years ago ( used separate gas tank/pump to carbs to
avoid gunk everywhere but in the carbs).

Is there a type of oil I should use to put the first few miles on
since its been so long?  As you can see from my list below, everything
has been touched, taken apart, rebuilt/repainted/repaired.  I guess I'm
worried that having taken virtually everything apart that 
maybe there's a method to checking the car out?  I already plan
on spending a day after driving it a few miles to re-tork everything
just to be sure I didnt miss anything or something came loose.

I'm gonna start the brake bleeding, start engine phase this month.

I'd appreciate any insights/horror stories to avoid....

Ron De Lange
rondl@uscbu.att.com

- -----------what's been done:

Body:
	- Numerous body panels, floor/suspension pans, etc.
	- Restored gas tank 
	- 100% all new gas lines, filter, etc. from gas tank to engine.
	- 100% new brake pads, lines, caliper pistons, everything else rebuilt.
	- Suspension - all new bushings, struts/shocks, everything else R&R'd
	- pedal bushings, clutch/brake cables new
	- wheel bearings/races R&R'd

Engine/Trans:
	- Dismantled all sheetmetal, dipped/repainted
	- Totally degreased everything
	- Plugs, points, rotor, cap, etc. all replaced
	- Fuel pump rebuilt
	- Carbs (Solexes) rebuilt
	- New Bursch exhaust
	- Engine oil Changed, filter cleaned, gasket
	- New valve cover gaskets
	- New trans oil
	- Degreased CVs and new boots/bolts
	- Clutch, throw-out bearing
	- all electrical connections cleaned/repaired
	- generator belt
