Date: Tue, 14 Mar 1995 09:02:43 -0800 (PST)
From: Cherie Woodward <cherie@corp.cirrus.com>
Subject: P-car on WheelofFortune



	I had the misfortune (8-) of being bedridden and instructed
	that mindless entertainment would cure when I spotted a 
	hot red (red hot?) P-car being given away on America's
	game - Wheel of Fortune. It's still up for grabs, at least
	until the end of the week, until it's won, or it's the 
	selected prize and the contestant can't guess the puzzle.

	I was glued to the TV, but it hasn't left the prize list.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Mar 1995 12:02:53 -0500
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: 911 Test Drive

Hi Hal,

Yesterday I test drove an 85 911 Carerra. The place, Power Motors in Rosyln,
had some pretty interesting cars. They are a used car dealership,
specializing in hi-line cars. In the showroom they had a few Ferarri's, and
of course, some Porsches. I wanted to see an 85 911 Targa that was listed in
the paper, so the salesman took me to the back garage, where the car was
located. In there were a lot of very nice cars. One was a Dodge Viper, and
another was 69-70 Dodge Challenger with a 426 Hemi. That car was really cool.
It was Plum Crazy, with white leather interior, and a pistol grip shift
lever. It had the typical Dodge sport wheels, and 60ish tires. I didn't find
out how much they wanted for it.

After waiting for the salesman to move a few cars to get the Porsche out, we
took it for a drive. I have to say that I very dissapointed in the car. I
don't know if there was something wrong with this particular car, or if it
was indicative of 911's in general. This car had 16,500 miles on the odo, and
was very clean. The interior was in very good condition, but certain things
surprised me. The floor mat was worn out under the drivers foot position.
Other parts of the interior looked to be worn more than a 16,500 mileage car
should be. I don't know if the odo was turned back, or that was just the way
it was. 

Anyway, the car was difficult to drive. The clutch was not hydraulic, and had
a very heavy feel. The shift lever had an unbelievably long throw, and it was
difficult to find the gears, third especially. It also ground going into
first if I was not at a dead stop (synchros perhaps?). The car also didn't
seem that fast. The engine never developed the rush of power that I was
expecting. There was no comparison to the 944 Turbo S that I drove. Instead,
the 911 just seemed to pull the same, regardless of the rpm. The engine
pulled just as hard at 2000 as it did at 5000. I guess it was deceptively
quick, because it didn't seem to pull that hard, but I would be going at 70 be
fore I realized it. The handling was nice, not as hard as I imagined, but
very precise and firm. There was no pwer steering, but that didn't bother me
once the car was moving.

The interior also seemed primitive. It was difficult to read the guages from
the sitting position. The footing was also strange in the car. It had a dead
pedal for the right foot, but the clutch was located in sort of a tunnel. 

When I got home I went for a quick drive in my 944. What a difference! The
944 was so much more comfortable. The clutch was easy to press, the gears were
 easy to find, the dash was earier to read. 

If that is the way all 911s are, I don't know if I want one. The car that I
am considering is a Euro model, so it should have 30 more HP. That should
help. I will have to try anoter 911 to make sure. If both 911's are the same,
then I'll have to wait until I find the right 944 Turbo S.

Later
Barry
BLenoble@aol.com

Date: 14 Mar 1995 09:23:21 U
From: "John Lucas (GRC)" <John_Lucas_#l#GRC#r#@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: None

                                                                    9:14 AM
  OFFICE MEMO                                                 Time:
                      Subject:
                      None                                          3/14/95
                                                              Date:


This is in response to the recent thread about oil leaks into the cooling
system.  From what I've seen, the discussion is based on 944's, with some
reference to 928's.

There's an article in the April `95 issue of Excellence ("944 (and 928) Oil
Systems" by Jim Pasha, Pg 109).  His contention is that leaks can develop
between the oil cooler (heat exchanger) and the coolant.  He recommends having
the seals replaced at the shop (2-3 hrs labor and less than $100 parts -- plus
an oil and coolant change).

I've read his article twice now, looked at my Porsche service manuals, and I
still can't determine where the heck the seals he's talking about are on my
928.  

As you may have guessed, I have oil seeping into the coolant.  A brief history
follows:  Changed coolant in December after 12 months use and it was VERY
dark, almost black.  Changed oil also and it looked like slightly used oil
(i.e., no discoloration, no rainbow effect, no slime or anything out of the
ordinary).  Therefore, oil leaking into coolant, no coolant leaking into oil. 
Okay.  Last week the radiator cracked and died so I changed it out ($519 at
Eurasian, for those who may need a similar replacement).  The coolant was
*slightly* discolored after nearly three months service ... therefore, a
slight oil seepage still exists.  This is bugging the heck out of me and I
want to fix it!!

Now, finally, my question to you 928 folk out there .... have any of you
changed the oil seals mentioned in the Excellence article?  I have no idea how
to get access to the seals between the heat exchanger and the coolant.  A
measure of my ignorance is that I don't even know *where* it is (the oil
filter and pressure sender are attached to the oil cooler housing according to
the article, but again this isn't obvious to me in the service manuals and
it's not obvious when laying under the car staring at the filter and sender). 
I think if I knew what I was looking for I could change the seals myself and
save the labor costs.

Next question:  if I change the coolant every six months (every other oil
change) and flush the engine while I'm at it, do I run any risk of damaging
either my engine or my cooling system if I defer fixing the leak?

Practical info:  1984 928S, 5-speed, no oil cooler in radiator.

Thanks for any info on this subject!!

John

Date: Tue, 14 Mar 95 10:14:00 PST
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: RE: info on panel flange tool


>Does anyone have any experience with air-powered panel flanging tools?
>I've just butt-welded panels in the past but this tool looks interesting.
>It puts a 1/2" recess along the edge of the panel so that you can overlap
>the panels when welding. Seems like it would make welding much easier.

My friend and I have just finished welding in 2 large replacement "patches"
in my 914 rear trunk floor.  We used both methods...."butt" and "overlapping
flange with the tool you described" method.  The flange tool made it easier
by a long shot since it was difficult to cut the replacement panels to fit 
the
holes we cut in the trunk floor due to their shape - which made butt welding
"interesting".  Sometimes the gap was 1/8"....oops!  Our "weave-welding"
talents have grown considerably though.  :-)

These 2 methods were discussed briefly last summer and the one concern
raised about the "lap" method was that it was felt it would tend to rust 
easier
than a "butt" joint since moisture could get inbetween the two overlapping
layers of metal.  Whatever you do, just make sure that the weld is complete
(no pin holes for moisture to get in the weld) and that BOTH sides are
covered with high quality primers/paints/undercoating, etc.  Apparently
POR 15 makes good weld/metal prep and rust prevention goop to help
minimize future rust problems.

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

Date: 13 Mar 1995 03:42:50 GMT
From: vezp@eureka.qc.ca (Pierre Vezina)
Subject: AM radio summary


	A couple of weeks ago, I posted a request to this list concerning my problem
with the AM radio reception in my 944. It turned out that my problem was also
the problem of a few other Pfilers.
	To make a long story short here is our findings :

	In order to receive good AM signal into your radio the antenna pre-amp must
be properly powered (most 944s, some 911 and 928). The power to the pre-amp
is coming from a little black wire running in the same sleeve as the antenna
wire (work shop manuals are not too explicit on the subject .. at least the
944 one). Therefore, +12V must be applied to this wire whenever the radio is
switched on (most radio have a "Power Antenna" output that can be used for
this). Direct +12V should not be connected to this pre-amp since it will
slowly drain your battery. 
	For unknown reason the powered pre-amp is absolutely needed for AM reception
but is not required for FM reception (it is probably affecting station with
weaker signal). 
	This problems in most of the cases has been introduced by car stereo
installation shops not being aware of this different wiring in P-cars. When
installing a new radio
they just cut the little wire without thinking too much ....  if it was
connected meant 
it was actually doing something).

	That's the story folks.

	 I would like to thanks the list in general for the bandwidth and Mark Doyle
in particular for his good cooperation (+ other Pfilers who communicate their
ideas on the subject).

	See you soon.

	Pierre Vezina
	vezp@eureka.qc.ca
	85/2 Black 944

Date: Tue, 14 Mar 1995 14:28:13 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: 911S Alignment questions

Howdy,

Neil Kumpers has a '73 911S targa and can not get the
alignment within factory specs.

> Is it not unusual that a 22 year old targa is hard to get within
> spec after years of torsional flexing or do I need to get the car to a
frame
> shop? It's not that far from spec.

It should be possible to get it close enough, even better than
factory specs. It depends upon ride height - a lowered car may have
too much negative camber. But in my opinion this is not a bad thing ;) .
What is the height of your front and rear fenders, and what size tires?

A front strut may be bent if the front camber can not get within specs.
I think the strut can be re-bent on a frame machine but do not know if this
is safe. A 911S strut is not cheap to replace!

>If the car can't be aligned within spec, is there a way to balance  out the
>alignment by putting the left side out of spec but within reasonable limits?

I have been aligning my '72 911S Targa myself for ten years, and am now
doing it again and removing my "street prepared" suspension and installing
new factory parts. I can now do the rear spring plates and re-indexing
not only blindfolded, but in my sleep (~20 times in less than 1 year to 
get it right and get the lousy Automotion adjustable rear spring plates to
finally work, and then removing them!).

There are many settings which will work OK depending on how you intend
to use the car. Let me know the specs that he was able to obtain and
I'll give you my idea of a good compromise setting that you can use.

You basically want the left and right sides to match. The rear camber
and toe can be further adjusted if necessary by slotting the spring
plate holes. You may need to raise the ride height if the camber
is way too negative.

Mike Piera '72 911S Targa  '73 914/2.0   (Connecticut Valley PCA)

P.S. Anyone going to the San Diego Pro Solo this weekend? I'll be
trying to get some Stock-1 points in an MR-2 Turbo.

P.P.S. Anyone interested in a COMPLETE blueprinted, Parade-winning
PCA stock-legal suspension for a pre-78 911????

Date: Tue, 14 Mar 1995 11:37:44 -0800
From: winders@support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: re Tax Break offer

>Ease up techno-nerds!  The guy is just trying to make a living!  I agree this
>was not necessarily the right place to promote himself, but you guys have to
>learn to relax.  I continue to be amazed at how many *angry* people there are
>out there that find it necessary (and apparently satisfying) to vent so
>viciously.
>
>Why not take Bart's example, and deal with him off line - he just needs a
>simple, *gentle* explanation of what the majority prefer to discuss within
>this format.
>
>Get a life!


Before telling us to get a life, you need to understand that there
are proper and improper ways to do things on the Internet. Sending
an advertisment, unsolicited, to a mailing list is not the proper
thing to do.

This guy probably sent to the same message to many other mailing lists
besides ours. The Internet is self policing at this point. There are no
"laws" to be enforced. At the same time, the Internet is not really
an anarchy either. There is a code to operate under and this guy broke
the code.

One of the problems the Internet is facing in its rapid expansion is an
influx of people (from AOL, Compuserve, eWorld, etc.) that have no idea
what is correct behavior.

Scott Winders
winders@support.apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

quoted me something like $300 to replace the seal but they won't guarrantee
that they won't break the windshield in the process. (quoted at $600 :-(
making a possible total bill of $900 to replace a bloody seal).

Can any of you recommend a reputable glass shop (or other) that can do this 
work in the Washington D.C. area? Where should I get the seal? Automotion?
(I don't think I want to install a stock seal, German rubber sucks)

------------------------------

Date: 14 Mar 95 19:19:36 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Info on panel flange tool

 
Reid Zeigler asked about an air driven panel flanger.
 
Yes, I've used them, but almost never for car panel work. They're great for
making boxes and stuff like that. I did make flanged repairs to 2 sides of
my 356 battery box, but now I would butt weld it. I have also used them to
put a step in some hammer formed steel pieces which were later welded
together to make an exhaust resonator for a non-Porsche project. That one
was super easy to MIG weld. Flanged panels are indeed easier to weld (clamp
panels together with Clecos and just draw a bead, virtually no danger of
burn through, then plug the 1/8 Cleco holes when all is done.)
 
The problem with flanges is that they are rust traps somewhere down the
line, no matter how much or how well or with what you try to seal them.
Water is insidious in the ways it creeps into openings and then wicks up and
between sandwiched panels. The factory does use lap joints, and surprise,
that is where the things rust most readily, too.
 
You probably don't want to hear this but the right way is to butt weld
patches. If the factory used a lap joint (and they are unavoidable in
making cars), then you have to use the same kind of joint.
 
With care and practice, and the right kind of clamping, beautiful flat butt
joints are possible.
 
I would get a panel flanger just because it is such a neat tool for everyday
sort of welding jobs. There are times on a car when you just have to use it.
 
Eastwood sells one, I forget the cost, but you should be able to beat there
price just about anywhere.
 
Pete

Date: Tue, 14 Mar 1995 19:35:06 -0500
From: jfoster@rohmhaas.com (Jim Foster)
Subject: RE: 944 oil and water ...

At 11:26 PM 3/12/95 EST, Kevin Gross wrote:
>
>...
>
>Head gasket failure is really very uncommon on aspiros.  Anything is
>possible, but I'd start with the exchanger.  BTW, Porsche recommends
>you drop the oil pan and check the rod bearings for water damage.
>This is a bunch more work, not to mention the cost of the ingenious but
>pricey pan gasket.  If you see absolutely no coolant in the oil, when you
>drain the oil, perhaps you can get away without dropping the pan.
>
Kevin,
Can you give me some documentation on where Porsche recommends dropping the pan?
My dealer had never heard of droppin the pan on a seal replacement.

>With respect to it being a weak spot, there was a run of bad seal kits
>in MY87.  Since then, Porsche has had problems getting mechanics to
>shim the cooler properly on re-installation.  You should be OK once
>both have been taken care of.
>
We had to have the job done twice in the span of a few months when one of the
replacement seals failed and the car started dripping oil all over our
garage floor.  The warranty on the seal paid for the job the second time
around.

Date: Tue, 14 Mar 1995 20:03:46 -0500
From: L8Apexer@aol.com
Subject: Re: Buying 1989 911 C4 - Ques...

Scott, I had a 964 for 5 years and loved it!  The only problem I had was the
chip for the 4 wheel drive went out at about 10k.  It was replaced under
warranty.  No other problems.  If you live in an area with a lot of snow
you'll still need snow tires.  I put in a performance chip and stopwatch runs
0-60 and 60-100 didn't show much difference, but I didn't have any trouble
with it either.  Emissions probably not a problem at idle.  If you love great
sounds, get a K&N air filter and drill a bunch of 3-4" holes in the airbox
cover.  With your foot in it once you hit 4000rpm you'll be in heaven.  Good
luck!  L8Apexer  951TS and 993

Date: Tue, 14 Mar 1995 21:46:09 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: help on 356

> What are the critical parts to double make sure?

If it's metal, it needs to be checked for rust. If it's electrical, it
needs to be checked for function. Find someone that knows these cars --
there's a lot of things to know that need to be checked. Some things that
seem horrible aren't a big deal, some that look fine will make you wish you'd
never been born.

> Do you know a good brand for a 6v to 12v converter? (I'd like to 
> build a 12v stereo into it).

Give it up. You can't pull enough amps out of the generator to do this, and
based on recent findings in the vintage BMW world, the converters may place
a life-threatening load on the generator windings anyway. Besides, you
won't be able to *HEAR* the stereo if you are driving with the windows down
anyway...

> What is a reasonable price, for a car in good conditions?

$9k to $18k, depending. On the car, and how good "good" really is...

Stan

Date: Tue, 14 Mar 1995 23:43:20 -0500
From: awhite@soleil.acomp.usf.edu (Andrew White)
Subject: 911 Test Drive

>Yesterday I test drove an 85 911 Carerra. The place, Power Motors in Rosyln,
              (much was deleted to save space)
>Anyway, the car was difficult to drive. The clutch was not hydraulic, and had
>a very heavy feel. The shift lever had an unbelievably long throw, and it was
>difficult to find the gears, third especially. It also ground going into
>first if I was not at a dead stop (synchros perhaps?

Sorry you had such a miserable time in the 911.  I have the same car that
you test drove (1985 Carrera Targa).  I had some minor modifications done.
The car is now putting out over 240 hp.  I can honestly say, you must have
driven a real dog.  I'v owned many high performance American made muscle
cars as well as european sports cars.  The Porsche 911 definatley rules.  I
would definatly try another 911.  I'm sure you will agree if you connect
with a healthy one.  As for 3rd gear,  I haven't driven a 911 yet that
didn't have a gear box that felt like you were driving a Mack truck.  If
your looking for power shifting, the 911 is not for you.  Good luck in your
hunt.  .  .  Howard

Date: Tue, 14 Mar 1995 23:30:53 -0600
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Re: 944 Oil & Water

Thank you very much for the idea. My car is an '84, and in talking to a
good friend who is a tech at my local Porsche store, and also a very nice
gentleman at PCNA, they both said, "forget it". However, both gave me some
very good advice on fixing the problem, and the guy at PCNA offered to fax
me several tech notices regarding the procedure (which I took him up on
since I have the original factory manuals, but not too many of the
updates).

He told me that to clean the system (after the repair) I should use a water
solution of "Shout" (ie. - like to wash clothes with). Apparently, this is
in a tech note somewhere from Porsche. Anybody have any comments on that?

He also recommended replacement of the coolant hoses.

He also asked me if this seemed to be a big leak (it's not), and have I
seen any hint of water in the oil (I didn't, both at an oil change and in
looking at the dip stick just after I've run the engine). He asked how long
I've had the leak, and I replied, "about 2 weeks" (and I do keep a very
close eye on my coolant on a bi-weekly basis, so I know it hasn't been
longer than that).

So, in any case, he replied, "In that case, I would not worry about
dropping the pan to replace the bearings". He noted that since the oil
pressure is usually higher than coolant pressure, oil usually leaks into
the coolant and not the other way around (unless the problem is not
attended to, then the car will overheat with the oil build up in the
coolant, the pressure in the coolant system will build up (from the
overheating), and the oil will thin out (again, from the overheating) - and
you will get water into the oil).

If any of this advice seems wacky, please let me know ...

trev.

At 8:04 am 3/13/95, Bob356@aol.com wrote:

>and thoroughly cleaning the coolant passages in the engine/radiator).
>
>Good luck.

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 00:13:15 -0600
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Re: 944 smooth acceleration.

At 1:39 am 3/14/95, George Beuselinck wrote:

>Friends don't let friends do Splitfires...Just say no.
>
>Stay with the platinum plugs...they are not your problem...


Oh man, I sure couldn't agree any more !!!

Splitfires == S--tfires !!!!

In any case, up until now I have been using the Bosch plat's with success
(changing every 12k miles or in my case, four months). Last week I was
going to put a new set of Bosch's in, but something possesed me to try
something different! So, (this will sound really weird), I went with a set
of Champion Gold's. (alright, stop throwing food, garbage, and other debris
at me, I can hear all of you laughing)

I love these plugs. My '84 944 seems to really have a lot more response now
(even more so then when I switched over to a new set of Bosch plats). I
attribute this in part to the fact that I have new plugs in the car, part
to the possibility that this brand of plug is working better for me, and
partly (possibly) due to the fact that the electrodes on this set of plugs
might be lined up in the head better (I don't index my plugs, but I am
aware that the orientation of the plug electrode in the head can really
effect things).

In any case, I thought the Champions would suck, but they don't, I think
they work better (in my car, anyways) than the Bosch plugs. In the past I
have always stuck to the following rule:

American car = American plugs
German car = German plugs
Japanese car = Japanese plugs

Where I ever got this idea I don't know, because these Champions are
working great in my 944 !!!


(just my .02 worth)

trev.

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 09:33:50 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: 356s and TV Shows

Dave Darling says, "...Kinda sad to see one end up that way, but I guess
356s were a lot more common (and inexpensive) back then..."

No, not really, Dave.  There were only 76,303 when 356 production offcially
ended in 1965 (plus a handful assembled afterwards for special customers).
 And, the $5500 the 1965 356SC cost made it relatively expensive (putting it
in the highest category, for example, on North Carolina's personal property
tax valuation list for automobiles).  For comparison, the 1965 911 cost about
$5900.

It IS sad to see one end up that way, but there are a remarkable number of
them around today.

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC (original owner)
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 95 08:57:29 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; info on panel flange tool


>Does anyone have any experience with air-powered panel flanging tools?
>I've just butt-welded panels in the past but this tool looks interesting.
>It puts a 1/2" recess along the edge of the panel so that you can overlap
>the panels when welding. Seems like it would make welding much easier.

   Reid, I've used the "Vise grip" type (not the air-powered type). It works
 fairly quickly, really, unless you've got tons of work to do it might work
 fine at about half the cost (not that $60 for the air-powered flanger isn't
 cheap...).

   If I thought I could get away with a butt weld, I would, as this must
 be the best weld to "hide" a seam. As far as the moisture...the factory
 uses blind overlaps everywhere (eg, quarter panel to door jam). I spray
 that "cold galvanizing" Zinc-epoxy where a weld will occur. This helps
 prevent rust and actually promotes a better weld. 
                                                      
    Good luck on your....italian Porsche !
 
          Lee A.

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 10:18:18 -0500 (EST)
From: Richard Hollander <ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us>
Subject: Re: 993 brake light.

The CHMSL (center high-mounted stop light) on the '96 911 Turbo is nicely 
integrated via a horizontal line of LEDs on the upper trim of the rear 
window. From the looks of things, the Euro model may don it too. You'd 
think with Porsche's engineering expertise and the anal-retentive way 
they pay attention to new headlamps and wiper arm mounting points that 
they'd come up with a better way to affix a CHMSL to their cars than that 
darn basket handle. Then again, maybe all 911s will adopt the Turbo's 
CHMSL...


RickSH
ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 09:28:18 -0600
From: wpcostel@porsche.aud.alcatel.com (William Costello)
Subject: Re: Tax Credits can reduce your taxes!

I can not speak for eveyone on this list, but I feel that people who drive
Porsches have a bad reputation as being stuck-up snobs that like to throw
their money around where it will draw the most attention. This is the way
people treat me after they hear that I own a Porsche.

This happend to me last week when a man, that works on a project that
shares lab space with the project that I am on, found out that I drive a
Porsche. I have known him for a few months and we have got along fine. Now
he makes smart remarks about what kind of people drive Porsches. When I tried
to explain to him that my 1986 911 could be purchsed for less that his car
from Japan, it did not make any difference.

People have a sterotype in their mind about Porsche drivers. I can not help
but wonder if people from this group attacking Mr. Hudson about his ad will
add to this sterotype. I find the best way to remove a sterotype is to do
just what people do not expect. For myself as a Porsche driver, it is to
be kind to others on the road, people on the Internet, and anyone who needs
help with their car. People do not expect a Porsche driver to stop and help
change their tire. Atleast not here in Dallas TX. My fellow co-workers did
not expect that I would help them with problems on the cars from Japan.

The point is that a little kindness can go a long way. The kind thing to do
about Mr. Hudson would be for one person (like Stan or Bart) to send a note
explaining the problem and then copy this note to the list so that all will
know that the issue has been delt with in the proper manner.

I no that my views are not held by everone, but I hope some other people out
their feel the same way. This is not a flame, but only a call for reflection
before action.

W.P. Costello

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 07:41:33 -0800 (PST)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: 993 brake light.

Ken -

It is my understanding that the 993 "middle/high" brake light was suppose
to be up top as in the initial pictures.  Porsche had problems with the
attachment of it to the glass late in the production cycle and solve the
problem by putting it on like they did. 

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR
SCCA-SFR/RR

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 10:53:58 -0500

Gold. Stay away from the Bosch platinums with the ceramic-covered tip,
I'm sure the champions are better. Bosch has tried to pull a "BMW"
and use clever marketing to make something seem high performance that
is not. I never understood how BMW got a performance reputation with the
general public when they sold mostly 320i's to rich secretaries...

>I love these plugs. My '84 944 seems to really have a lot more response now

time. These are the WRxDS - work great on my '72 S which is tough on plugs.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 10:53:59 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Re: '73 911S Alignment questions

Neil Kumpers is having problems getting his '73 911 S Targa aligned,
it will not come within specs.

>>What is the height of your front and rear fenders, and what size tires?  
>LF 25 3/4 in         RF 25 3/4 in      LR 24 3/4 in         RR 25 7/8 in
>On Yoko A509 205/60 15 

This ride height does seem fine. This should not cause excessive camber.
But your left rear may be too low, especially with you in the car. Put
your weight in the driver's seat area, roll the car, and measure again.
You probably need your left rear torsion bar re-indexed to raise the
corner to match the right rear. Corner balancing would be nice too!

>Left Front            Right Front         Hunter Range
>-0.1        Camber        -0.7             -0.2 to 0.2 

It seems that your right front has a bit too much negative camber for normal
street use. I have run up to 1.5 degrees negative, but this will wear tires
more quickly. Bent front struts may not be apparent when shocks are
installed.
I would guess that your right front strut is out of spec. Maybe someone
on the list will know if it is safe to bend these on a frame machine?
I have done this on non-Porsches.

Otherwise, you will have to replace the strut. Alternatively, you can
set the left front to -0.7 and have a matching set. In this case, you
will want to adjust the rear camber to about -1.2 negative on both sides.
Otherwise your car could oversteer at the limit. This will handle great!
(Note : Your current left rear is probably close enough for this
alternative!).

>Left Rear            Right Rear
 -1.1        Camber      -0.5                -1.2 to -.08
0.15         Toe       -0.24                 0.00 to 0.33

The left rear camber is a bit too negative, but may be able to be reduced
enough
if you re-index the torsion bar and raise this side. Try to get about .5
degree
more negative in the rear than the fronts.

The right rear seems to be toed-out which is not good. The spring plate
must be adjusted to pull the wheel forward to toe it in. I think they
need to play with the camber and toe eccentric adjusters more. If they
still can not get a little toe-in, then the hole in the spring plate can
be slotted enough to get the desired toe. But this is not nice to do if
you can avoid it. Good Luck!

Regards, Mike Piera  '72 911S

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 95 09:25:39 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: RE: 944 Oil  Cooler/Heat Exchanger



John,

In the article, I was specifically referring to the 944 about the 
oil cooler/heat exchanger leaks. Especially the internal leaks around 
the cooler oil seals. The 944 system seems to be prone to leaks, most 
likely from thermal expansion issues rather than any latent defect. My 
own 944 had a leak, it was at 60,000 miles or so (100,000 Km). The 
present owner reports no problems at over 120,000 miles (200,000 Km). 
Most that are repaired never leak again. On a normal 944, the job can 
be accomplished by the average home mechanic without removing the 
exhaust manifold. The 944S, 944S2 and 968 will require the exhaust 
manifold to be removed in most cases. The power steering pump reduces 
access to the housing in all models. This is the primary reason I 
recommended using a shop do do the job for some models. 

Sorry for the confusion. I have but 4,000 words to get a subject covered
due to layout constraints. I will try to be more concise when defining 
model peculiarities in the future.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 12:33:15 -0500
From: JohnT26@aol.com
Subject: 911 Front dust/hub cap

Thanks to all those who sent me their methods for removing the 911 front hub
dust caps.  I ended up buying the 9165 Porsche dust cap removing tool from
Baum Tools (800/848-6657 USA) for $48.00.  It fits onto a slide hammer with a
10 X 1.5 thread.  It takes about five seconds to get the cap off with it.
 Like I always say, " You have to have the right tool for the job"  If anyone
wants to borrow it for their next bearing adjust/repack or rotor change drop
me a note, it will help me justify the $$.

Thanks Again,

John Turco  JohnT26@AOL.com

'84 911 Targa, on the road again!

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 12:33:17 -0500
From: JohnT26@aol.com
Subject: 911 Caliper rebuild, low pedal?

Pphiles:
After rebuilding my front calipers and installing new rotors, pads and
bleeding the system (fluid change) I have a low pedal on the first
application.  I read in " Up Fixin' " vol VI, page 44 (Roger Chaney), that
after the caliper rebuild:
"You may find that you have a lower pedal at first application after the
brakes are not used for a short period.  Don't worry, this will go away after
a few miles and sometimes does not occur"
Well, I'm worried.  Has anyone had this happen?;  What's " a few miles" 5, 50
,1000?;  Why does it happen?
I think I used my quota of questions and then some, thanks, as always for
your replies.

John Turco  (JohnT26@AOL.com)

'84 911, soft brake pedal, Targa

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 17:49:47 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 911 Caliper rebuild, low pedal?

Low pedal after a re-build

There are two possibilities

1	air left in the system - most probable depending on how much 
fluid you lost, you may need to bleed up to 300cc's before you get all 
the air out.

2	brake knock off - this is caused where you leave excessive play 
in the wheel bearings, as the wheel bounces along, the rotor rocks 
between the pads, and forces them apart, so you have to press further to 
push the pads back in. This can happen after a re-build, because the well 
packed bearings seem quite tight as you turn the wheel. Grab the top of 
the wheel and rock - any clunck play, and you have found the problem.

Good luck

Pete Diffey

+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Subject: 911 seat type and headroom

I have a 1984 911 with standard (non-power, not sport) seats and a sunroof.
In my normal seating position my head just touches the ceiling.  (I am 6'
1" tall.)  At x-cross or driver ed. events when a helmet is required I do
not have enough head room for a comfortable seating position.

I recently sat in a 1986 911 with power seats (but not sport seats) and a
sunroof.  I noticed that there was significantly more head room.  Is this
because the newer seats have a lower seating position?  Or do power seats
have a lower seating position?  If the answer to either of these questions
is yes, what modificatiosn would be required to use them in my car?

Any other suggestions for my head room problem?  Would sport seats or an
after market seat help?

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 14:27:55 -0500
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bartonc@annap.infi.net>
Subject: 'Philes Phund PHAQ

Hi Sanjay, and New members of the Group (who are wondering what all this
talk of money for a free list is all about...)

Porschephiles has steadily grown to a membership of *OVER* 1200 members,
generating traffic of more than 68,000 messages per month. This volume of
traffic is eating a significant chunk of Stan's T-1 service.  Not to put
too fine a point of this, this eats into Stan's livelihood, and, amigos,
that ain't right.  We owe Stan an inestimable debt of gratitude.  The
very least we can do to show it is to take as much of the capital burden
upon ourselves as possible.

We are trying to acquire the funds to build the infastructure to ensure
the survival of Porschephiles independent of any member.  It's not a
type-a personality thing at all. Folks who have pledged $100 are those
who have recognized the high capital cost of accomplishing this, and who
have the means to contribute more.  *Nobody* has to contribute anything.

What is the suggested donation, and why?

$15 for Student; $50, Member; $100, Patron; and  $more, Dieties

So where do the suggested contribution numbers come from?  Can you say
"Rectal Data?"  It is my sense that a Student should be able to afford
$15.  If a poor starving Stoont can cough up $15, it isn't far out of
line for a Working person, who can afford both a love of Porsches and
access to the 'net, to be able to pony up $50.  If you want to do more,
then $100 seemed like a nice, tidy round number.  If you contribute $100,
you become a *Patron*

NOBODY *HAS* TO CONTRIBUTE ANYTHING!

I also know (I've been investigating the costs of becoming a Service
provider on the 'net, and) it's not cheap.  Recently, InfoWorld has a
comparison of two ppackage servers, one from BBN, and the other a Sun
Netra.  We're looking at $7-10K just for the box and software.  I don't
believe that Mailing list Software was in those figures, but I do know
that they do *not* include T-1 service.  As we determine what the blivid
(5 lbs in a 3 lb bag) of stuff totals out to be, you will be advised.

But this is *not* some anal-retentive thing working here (well, that's my
story and I'm stickin' with it...), but an attempt to offer *guidance*
that has been requested.  Frequently.

So what If you don't send anything?  You're *still* a Porschephile, with
all the privilidges and rights pertaining thereto.  As long as the
service survives...

If you want to ensure the survival of this organization, and I sure as
hell do, then send what you can.  Many folks have asked what would be
appropriate to send, and I've tried to offer guidelines.

So What do you get out of this?  How about a nice shiny *Number*,
reflecting the order in which I receive your check?  How about
*Satisfaction* that you've been part of one of the *great* happenings on
the 'net?

Everyone *Can* send a donation; *NOBODY* has to!

Finally, for you good souls who want to contribute, but haven't done so: 
The bank folks would rather that you send the checks to me, made out to

for deposit to "Porschephiles" Acct #3933150532

My address is:

Custodian "Porschephiles" 
c/o Bart Chambers 
1270 Lavall Drive
Davidsonville, MD  21035 (410) 721-2989

If you wish to call me, please do so prior 8:30 PM EST.

***Please send me an Email with your address, ck number and amt.*** This
will be private unless you wish to send it to 'philes yourself:

We are grateful any and all donations.

Cheers

Bart Chambers
Custodian, Porschephiles
Wife, Varmint, Porsche, etc.

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 13:42:18 -0700
From: stephenk@synopsys.com (Stephen Keller)
Subject: Re: mailbomb

Babak writes:

>Several P-philers had the idea of mailbombing people that waste
>our bandwidth with mail like the guy about tax breaks.  How about
>we all make a page buy cutting and pasting "MAIL BOMB" all in caps
>and fill up the page and send multiple copies to these people?

Folks:

Sending mail bombs for any reason, no matter how justified, is bad
netiquette. It burdens not only the intended "victim" but all sites along
the way who have to pass along the extra traffic.  The best response to junk
mail is to ignore it, responding to this tax-break guy only validates that
his message was received.

Peace, Stph

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 95 15:29:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: info on panel flange tool


 I have seen a manual panel flange tool (works like pliers) used and was 
impressed at how much better the seam came out.  For a small job it's very 
useful, but no doubt a chore on any large panels.  No doubt the air powered 
flanger would be welcome on a big job.  The one I saw is sold by the 
Eastwood Company in Malvern, PA.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 95 15:30:09 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Oil Tank Leak


Todd-

From what you say, I'd bet on the sender or a crack in the
tank.  When you take the tank out (which is very simple to do),
you'll find that the sender is mounted in a circular opening
about 2" in diameter, with a gasket, and is held by five or
six small bolts.  My guess is loose bolts or bad gasket.  Could
also be leaking through the electrical feedthrough.

If it's a cracked tank, good luck.  On the other hand, if
it's just a leaky seam, you ought to be able to repair it
with solder.  The tank is copper and should take solder well.

Hope this helps.

 -Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa

P.S.  I don't have a 36mm wrench either.  I used the closest
standard equivalent, which I think is 1 7/16".

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 20:39:48 -0500
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911 Caliper rebuild

From: pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk (Peter Diffey)
To: JohnT26@aol.com
CC: Porschephiles@tta.com

Low pedal after a re-build

There are two possibilities

1	air left in the system - most probable depending on how much 
fluid you lost, you may need to bleed up to 300cc's before you get all 
the air out.

2	brake knock off - this is caused where you leave excessive play 
in the wheel bearings, as the wheel bounces along, the rotor rocks 
between the pads, and forces them apart, so you have to press further to 
push the pads back in. This can happen after a re-build, because the well 
packed bearings seem quite tight as you turn the wheel. Grab the top of 
the wheel and rock - any clunck play, and you have found the problem.

Good luck

Pete Diffey

======================================================

Pete, there is also the fact that the piston seals are new and quite elastic.
 They can "pull" the piston back into the caliper a little after brake
pressure is released, causing them to have to be pressed further out with the
next application, hence the low pedal.  

Also, in your response to my brake question you were perplexed about the
refrigeration application.  I was refering to commercial refrigeration, with
30 hp compressors vibrating enough to shake a concrete slab, operating 24
hours a day, 365 days a year at pressures over 250 psi, and temperatures up
to 200 deg F. Not quite your household Fridge!

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 20:39:55 -0500
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: A/C Questions

Subj:	A/C Questions
Date:	95-03-15 19:15:06 EST
From:	spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu
To:	porschephiles@tta.com
CC:	spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu

Bob writes:

I just spent two weeks tracking down and fixing all the leaks in 
the system.  I called a local dealer to see what it cost. $160 plus tax.
There has to be a better way. 

One more thing, is it really necessary to replace the receiver/dryer as
advised? Couldn't I just run a vacuum pump on the system for 48 hours 
or so to get any accumulated moisture out, perhaps heating the 
receiver/dryer while I do so?  What's in there?  If it's simply an 
hydroscopic compound, the vacuum pump and heat ought to 
do it.  Anyone know?

Thanks a bunch.

Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa (with an empty factory a/c system)

====================================================

Bob, as you are now learning, automotive A/C is going to be very expensive
because of EPA regulations and the Montreal Protocol.  The WORLD is involved
in this, not just the US. Your best bet would be to get the system converted
over to h134A, the new refrigerant found in most auto's today.  They might
have to replace the expansion valve as well, and you will lose a little of
the already insufficient cooling effect, but you will be set until the year
2030.

As far as the receiver/dryer, you are right in that you could possibly
evacuate most of the miosture, however the unit is also works as a filter.
 It is probably full of wax and other byproducts formed by the mixing of air,
moisture and refrigeration oil.  There is a small chance that it may not be
clogged, but to really find that out you must refill the system and try it.
It's not worth the trouble to do that, even though those suckers cost $150.
 Sorry for the bad news.

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 95 14:52:31 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Right way to lower 911 ?

| From: Chris Bennet  <cbennet@lmcorp.com>
|
<some stuff deleted to save the bandwidth that I am about to waste! Note
that there may actually be useful information hidden in this message. See
if you can find it!>
|
| Q: What is the "correct" way to lower a 84-89 Carrera ?  The common
| method of putting in rack spacers seems, well, unPorschelike.
| How did the factory do it ?  I see "RSR" struts sold (some with coilovers)
| but these seem to be sort of racer thing.

Yes, RSR means racing in German. (and lotso money in any language)

For us non-racers, all you need to do is let some air out of each tire.

(Ack! NO, stop mailbombing me! Honest, I am not trying to sell tax-
free Bosnian annuities!) <vbg>

BTW, wrt the recent spamming, flaming, and mailbombing, newcomers to
the net need to realize that oldtimers often revel in the net's anarchy 
and live
by the credo "if you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen!" Folks are
much more brazen sitting in front of a screen than they would be face-to-face.
The net is simply not for the faint-of-heart (and that isn't likely to 
change in
the near future, either). Gee, I feel better having expounded that!

Since I am on a bandwidth wasting roll, I'll relate the procedure I plan
on using on the back of my 944. My car has torsion bars at the rear and
your '86 Carrera has torsion bars at all 4 corners, so the principle, if not
the exact procedure, should apply.

Porsche torsion bars have splines on each end to make the mechanical
connection. My understanding is that there is a different number (courseness)
of splines on each end which allows for differential rotation to give finer
adjustments than would be otherwise possible.

So, put the car on jackstands and remove the wheels. Go to one corner and
place a bottle/floor jack under a wheel lifting point. For the front, 
it would be under
the ball joint on the A-arm. On the rear it would be on the training arm under
the wheel bearing hub. Jack just enough to lift that corner of the car 
off of the
corresponding jack stand. The point is you want to have the A-arm/trailing-
arm at a static ride height angle. Place a dial protractor (the kind 
that have a
built-in spirit level so that you can measure the deviation from level 
in degrees)
on the A/trailing-arm perpendicular to its pivot axis. Then, with a 
little measuring
and trigonometry, you can calculate the angle change you would need to give
the desired lowering. Then, lower the jack and disassemble enough of the
suspension so that the torsion bar can be removed (details omitted because
I don't know them!). I would just remove the torsion bar end cap initially and
rotate it one spline, then reassemble everything (with fasteners just snugged)
so that the angle change can be measured (after rejacking the arm). If 
it is too
great (and it probably will be), then you need to disassemble again and then
pull the torsion bar out of its back spline, rotate it in the opposite 
direction one
spline, reassemble, rejack, and recheck the angle. Continue until the desired
angle is achieved.

Repeat on the other three corners and then realign.

Jeeze, that sounds like a lot of work. Does anyone know of a simpler method?
(Yeah, right, take it to a mechanic!)

I am sure that someone will point out any mistakes I may have made in the
above!

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

IMHO, the new "basket handle" brake light represents an improvement over the
old "ET" version. That sucker cost a lot to replace when it was inadvertently
knocked off my '89 911 twice during washing. It's acceptable cosmetically
(Porsche doesn't make the DOT rules) and much sturdier.

Gary 

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 22:20:08 -0700 (MST)
From: Qassim Moolla <qmoolla@gpu.srv.ualberta.ca>
Subject: Loss of power; 1987 944 S

My 1987 944 S loses power after approx 3500 RPM.  The car has had the 
following work done: 
New belts, timing etc. New plugs including a new wireset. New fuel 
filter,distributor cap, rotor. The timings been checked. I recently 
changed some of the idler rollers and the car appears to have gained some 
power. The tensioner roller is still to be changed because it seems to 
vibrate. My question-  Could the loss of power be caused by vibrations 
set up by the rollers which in turn are picked up by the two knock 
sensors which would theoretically retard the timing. Please contact me at 
qmoolla@gpu.srv.ualberta.ca if you have any thoughts on the subject.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 22:01:27 -0800

Subject: Driver's Door Handle Broken

Hello All,

Well, it finally happened.  The trigger on the driver's outside door handle
has broken.  When it happened I thought that maybe something was stuck (the
recent rains have done strange things around here) but a generous
application of my favorite lubricant did not ease the problem.

So, I figured I'd dump $50.00 or so on a new door handle.  Much to my
surprise, they are going from $250.00 - 350.00!  Given this, I guess I'll
take the old one off and try to fix it myself.

However, if you have a good used handle for my '71 911 that you'd be
willing to part with, please let me know.

Thanks in advance.

Regards,

Dave Sens
Santa Barbara, California
'71 911T Coupe

Date: 16 Mar 95 01:25:10 EST
From: "C.Grayshon-Pedley" <100306.422@compuserve.com>
Subject: Help With Book Research.

To All Group Members.
Hello form England

I am a member of a English Porsche owner/driver/appreciation club.  I am also a
"Hobby Journalist" - not my main occupation. I am looking for research material
for a book I am writing. The book is to be a continuation of the Excellence Was
Expected story but not a copy as I realise the problems with writing such a
masterpiece - everyone wants to say no you got that bit wrong - not to mention
copywrite problems.

I am looking for information, Photocopies of Porsche articles and any
Photographs from the period 1978 to 1988. I am interested in all aspects of
Porsche history - racing and road articles.
As the book is more of a hobby than occupation I can not  pay for the articles
but am willing to pay for postage for interesting material - any material used
will be credited to the supplier/writer/magazine/book.

Any personal memories or thoughts can be e-mailed to myself at Compuserve - My
mailbox address is 100306.422@compuserv.com - I shall be with Compuserve until
April the 12th then I am changing to a new service provider with a better
Internet and WWW connection - PLEASE e-mail before then - I will rejoin the
group from the new service provider after that date.

On a more personal note - I would like to offer any help to anyone interested in
visiting England or Europe on vacation or any Porsche information not available
in the USA.


Yours

C. Grayshon-Pedley.     
28, Rydal Grove, 
Roberttown, 
West Yorkshire. 
WF15 7DN   
England.

Porschephiles #1243                         Thu Mar 16 11:43:00 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 16 Mar 95 06:42:03 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 951 rod bearings

> I have an 89 951 with stage 2 chips and no other significant mods.  I've had
> car since nearly new and it's fed Mobil 1.  Out of 33kmiles there's about 15k

> driver school miles.  Have heard and seen several #2 rod bearing failures due

> to poor lube/oil foaming with sustained high rpm use.  Have heard that this
> can occur on all models and that this only applies  up to 86 models.  Need
>  accurate info.  Thanks

Keep your engine oil level topped up (check between each run) and you should 
have no problem.

Several track 951 owners have their rod bearings checked after 50 track
hours (about twice a season for the serious junkie).

Good luck,
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

On Wed, 15 Mar 1995 HermanHome@aol.com wrote:
> Pete, there is also the fact that the piston seals are new and quite elastic.
>  They can "pull" the piston back into the caliper a little after brake
> pressure is released, causing them to have to be pressed further out with the
> next application, hence the low pedal.  
> 

really - if this was the case, then all new cars would exhibit this 
behaviour, I have never noticed a soft pedal on any new car I have driven

> refrigeration application.  I was refering to commercial refrigeration, with
> 30 hp compressors vibrating enough to shake a concrete slab, operating 24
> hours a day, 365 days a year at pressures over 250 psi, and temperatures up
> to 200 deg F. Not quite your household Fridge!

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 09:29:01 -0500 (EST)
From: "Gerald G. MacDonald - Thomas Cooley Law School" <macdonag@mlc.lib.mi.us>
Subject: Re: porsche not PC?


I can commiserate with Paul's experience.  I received my bill from State 
Farm for the 911 in December.  I had insured the car with them (along 
with all my other cars and house) and had received a pretty good deal 
(for a 911).  Well, in December I get a bill and then a letter the next 
day explaining that a *25%* surcharge was just arbitrarily being tacked 
on to my bill because the 911 is "a high performance vehicle".  I went 
ballistic since they told me last summer they wouldn't cover me if I was 
using the car as a high performance vehicle, i.e. Dirver's Ed or 
autocross or any kind of time trial.  When I pointed this out to them the 
response was "Oh, there's no such exclusion." (Got that in writing!)  
And, allegedly, they are charging the same 25% surcharge on cars like the 
Cadillac with the Norrthstar engine.  They say the surcharge is based on 
the ability of the car to accellerate rapidly.  Hmmm . . . couldn't be 
related to how much the car cost so they figure the owners have money to 
burn?

Anyone else have this "surcharge" experience?  Any suggestions where I 
can get the smae coverage and avoid this "sports car prejudice?"

Jerry Mac
84 911 Carrera Targa (Cognac Brown)

On Wed, 15 Mar 1995, MR PAUL W MURPHY wrote:

> i received an unexpected suprise today while calling for an 
> insurance-quote for my 87 944. after answering the usual
> litany of questions expected; the man asked what make and
> model the car was. after telling him; he informed me that
> the company, worldwide insurance group, does not insure
> porsches. my spotless driving record not withstanding; i was 
> rejected because of my vehicle. i didn't know whether to
> laugh or cry. are there any other cases of
> 'auto-discrimination' out there? BTW, the company's # is 800 
> 325-1487. you might want to give them a call and echo my
> sentiments that people cause accidents, cars don't.

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 08:48:33 -0600
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Fuel Pump Diag

Hello Porschephiles!

  We are experiencing spring feaver in Central PA. 75 degree weather and
it feels GREAT! I have about 300 miles on my 66 rebuilt motor and no
problems or leaks! I think I do have a problem in the fuel pump. The other
day I noticed what seemed like a slow down of fuel while driving on the freeway.
It seemed to go away in about 2 min. After starting the vehicle the next
time I noticed the pump not shut down. So after checking to make sure that
there was no blockage in the feedline I disconnected the side feeding the
carbs and
installed a clear line on the other side (the tank side). If there was a temp
blockage, it is now gone. What I am noticing is the pump creating full
pressure and on the back side, after turning the vehicle off, I see a siphon
start back to the tank. I assume that this is a bad check valve in the fuel
pump. 

  Questions....

 Is my diagnosis correct? Is there "rebuild" kits available for an electrical
pump? Do you know where I can buy a Hardi fuel pump? Stodddard shows no
replacement save for Bosch available. Gotta wait till you guys in Sunny SO
CAL get up before checking my other suppliers.

 TIA!!!!
Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1974 914 2.0 (for sale)
1966 911 cpe (DONE!!)


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 95 08:46:46 CST
From: johnny.miller@platinum.brooks.af.mil
Subject: 71-911T door handle

     In responce to your broken driver's side door handle:
     The same thing happened to me.  The part that broke is the little
     L shaped deal that holds the pin and spring in place.
     
     I was able to take a piece of metal and bend it in a z shape
     like below.
     
              |  
             -+-|
              | |
              | |
              | |
              | |
              | | +
              | --|-
     
        The lower plus is supposed to show the door handle screw which I 
     used to secure the unit in place.  It holds the pin and spring in 
     place.  Use a tie-wrap to hold the pin to the bracket.
     
     If this doesn't make sense, I can send you a bitmap file.
     
                Johnny Miller
                Millerj@platinum.brooks.af.mil

>>Great price!  Do they do mail order?  Can you tell me where is Eurasian and

>Bill Smyth
>'84 928S

  At least my brother's '84 Euro model 928S (4.7l/300hp) has the oil
 cooler built into the radiator. Its just as the cooler would be integrated
 for an auto-tranny cooler, but the lines are bigger (like -12). My '79,
 and my brothers earlier '81 model had no such thing, maybe only the Euro
 model "S" had it. 

   $519 is a steal for a new radiator, used they run over $400. The OEM
 radiators are really crap, one of the few horribly weak points on these cars.
 Nothing should fail as quickly as they do, but there really isn't another   
 choice other than having one made...

     -Lee A.

  I was unable to remove the locks, and after talking to both the 
dealer and a locksmith, made the decision to break off the rear locks.

second and a half per wheel).If you're relying on the factory locks 
you may want to think about something a little more substantial.

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 10:23:14 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Welding sheet metal


Dear Alex,

You wrote:
<I have a question for those of you having welded in replacement body panels
<with a MIG welder.  What is the lowest amperage you have used?  Have you
<ever gone below 30 Amps?  I am deciding between two different machines
<(Daytona vs Miller) and like the Miller more, except that it only goes down
<to 30 Amps, while the Daytona goes down to 20 Amps.  Is this going to be
<a big problem?

<I intend to use the machine to work on my rusted 914s - so being
<able to weld sheet metal is REALLY important!

<Comments?  Suggestions?


To weld a 914 successfully, you have to use 30 AMPS. The latest Miller (the
supercession to the old CRICKET) is the best. Below 30 AMPS we use TIG. It is
slower, but requires less heat and makes a nicer weld. Of course, supplement
the Miller with gas!

George Hussey

Date: 16 Mar 1995 10:30:42 -0500
From: cbennet@lmcorp.com (Chris Bennet)
Subject: Re: 944TS chip

Bob,
  I had the Stage II chip in my '87 944 Turbo and it made
a noticeable difference. I could not verify their claimed
horsepower (270 vs the original 217) but the difference was
more than just imagined.  The downside was the head gasket only 
lasted 10K miles after installation.  Perhaps the '89 is less
prone to this problem.
 Autothority has a 30 day money back guarantee so if you don't 
like it you can send it back.  A less ethical person than yourself
could probably just _steal_ the software using an EPROM programmer.
  vrooom,
    Chris

- -----------------------------------------------------------------
i am looking for information regarding the stage I/II chips and the 
performance/response change to be expected.
<snip>
oh, by the way, are there any samples anyone is willing to let me evaluate. i

actually have the ability to receive the data over the netwrk and download to
a 
ERPOM programmer if anyoine is interested.

regards 
bob

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 08:06:47 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: porsche not PC?

Yes I have limited use polcies on both the 74 Carrera and the 914.

These are through Leland West. This insurance is avail to PCA members. 
Limited use does carry major restrcitions. But if you only dirve a few 
miles are year then IMHO this is the way to go. I pay $400 annaul for 
both Porsches with stated value coverage.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 95 08:30:47 PST
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert H. Albrecht)
Subject: 911 caliper rebuild, low pedal

Date: Wed, 15 Mar 1995 12:33:17 -0500
From: JohnT26@aol.com
Subject: 911 Caliper rebuild, low pedal?

Pphiles:
After rebuilding my front calipers and installing new rotors, pads and
bleeding the system (fluid change) I have a low pedal on the first
application.  I read in " Up Fixin' " vol VI, page 44 (Roger Chaney), that
after the caliper rebuild:
"You may find that you have a lower pedal at first application after the
brakes are not used for a short period.  Don't worry, this will go away after
a few miles and sometimes does not occur"
Well, I'm worried.  Has anyone had this happen?;  What's " a few miles" 5, 50
,1000?;  Why does it happen?

<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

John,

        I experienced the same phenomena on a 356 brake caliper rebuild.
The pedal was hard, but at a lower position in the stroke than before.  In
my case, it was the rear calipers, so wheel bearing adjustment was not a
possible explanation.  After a few hundred miles, I didn't notice it
anymore.  I believe the pedal is now as it was before the caliper work.  My
speculation is that the new caliper seals act as an elastic spring and
retract the caliper pistons somewhat when the brakes are released (same
EFFECT as loose wheel bearings).  This COULD be due to the fact you shove
the pistons way in during installation.  Perhaps it takes some use, and
heat, to position the seal on the piston in what will be it's normal
operating spot.

        Speculation, totally, but the "problem" went away.      Flames, or a
better explanation welcome :)


Bob Albrecht, San Diego Region
'83 SC Targa, Platinum
'65 SC, Battleship (Dolphin) Grey
Cat named "Mouse"


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 95 11:34:34 EST

was 10x1mm.

Date: 16 Mar 95 11:47:12 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 993 brake light.

Hi, Richard Hollander and Ken Rentiers.
 
Apparently the beancounters decided that since the basket handle was needed
for the center high mounted stoplight on the cabrio anyway, they'd save
money by making lots more of them and putting them on coupes too. I agree,
it looks dumb. But oddly enough most non-Porsche people I've talked to like
it.
 
Porsche is quietly phasing in the original roof extension. They don't want
to make a big deal out of it because they don't want customers saying
"Waa... Billy got a neato roof on his toy and all I got was this dumb
baskethandle. Gimme good spoiler NOW!!!"
 
The styling people designed this in for two reasons, one to hold the CHMSL,
the other to make the roof look longer and thereby match the longer/more
massive rear end on the car.
 
BTW, this thinking is also the reason why Turbo digital boost gauges stop at
.7 bar. The car actually develops a bit more than that, but they don't want
customers coming in and saying "I went T*D racing with my buddy Bubba, and
HIS Turbo gets up to .73 bar, but mine only goes to .72, now FIX IT!"
 
Pete

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 11:55:41 -0500

Paul,

Here in Southern California, most insurance companies run, not walk, from
Porsches. This has been the case for a number of years now . 

20 years ago insurance companies were hesitant to take on the Corvette's. You
had to educate them how the car was made. Now Porsches have gotten a bad rap
for "The 80's". You know, the  ill mannered jerk's who could care less about
the car, other than it gave them percieved power and prowess. Most of these
people were weeded out with the close of "The 80's", but there are still a
few lurking out there. Once they tried to tell me that it was the theft rate
for Porsches that prompted the policy. Just for fun, I would quote the latest
auto theft statistics, Porsche was somewhere around 16th.

I have been lucky, I have been insured with AAA for 25 years (boy that makes
me feel old). Occasionally, in the quest for a better rate, I have requested
quotes from other insurance companies. In toll we have seven cars, two are
Porsches. These "other" insurance companies said the would LOVE to insure our
fleet, EXCEPT THE PORSCHES! Well, my reply of course is, "No Porsches, no
policy". 


Good luck!

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 09:13:05 -0800 (PST)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: Freon

> Freon/Air Conditioners.
> My local supplier says that I need a license to buy 1lb. cans of R12 but that I 
> can buy 20lb. cans for about $200 without. I do have a manifold/gauge and 

Friends -

Freon is no longer available to "anyone" unless you have a license to
purchase it.  This became effective on November 14, 1994.  If someone is
selling it to the general public the fines can be heavy.  This is all
regulated by the Federal Clean Air Act.  Unless you are certified pursuant
to sections 608 or 609 of the above act, you can no longer purchase freon. 
The above sections include normal heating, air conditioning and
refrigeration mechanics (including home repairers that do freezers and
refrigerators) and automotive mechanics.  The test involves knowing how
various freons deplete the ozone, compositions of various freons,
different oils used with newer refrigerants (can you say synthetics),
recover/recycling/reclaiming procedures, general refrigeration
procedures/precautions, leak checking procedures, etc.  You are also
required to have at least a recovery machine if not a recovery/recycling
machine on the premises. 

Some of the newer cars have different fittings on the refrigerant lines to
both deter the public from messing with them and to isolate the type of
freons being used (less likely you'll put the wrong freon in if you have
to think about a different fitting).  Though, the freon containers have
the same fittings on them.  Snap-on tools makes a nice conversion kit with
the various fittings needed for cars and quick disconnects that eliminate
the extra freon going into the atmoshpere when you disconnect the hoses. 

Don't blame me for this mess.  I don't agree with it all either.  I think 
the ozone has other problems then just freon.  But because I have a 
heating and air conditioning business that I want to continue to provide 
me the income to play with my Porsche, I've had to get all the bells and 
whistles.  And it hasn't been cheap either.  At least their not messing 
with freon R-22 yet.  It will be here until at least the year 2020 and I 
hope to retire before then.


Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR
SCCA-SFR/RR

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 95 09:51:00 PST
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: RE: Welding sheet metal


>I have a question for those of you having welded in replacement body panels
>with a MIG welder.  What is the lowest amperage you have used?  Have you
>ever gone below 30 Amps?  I am deciding between two different machines
>(Daytona vs Miller) and like the Miller more, except that it only goes down
>to 30 Amps, while the Daytona goes down to 20 Amps.  Is this going to be
>a big problem?

Hi Alex,

My 914 rear trunk repair was done with a 110V - 130 Amp Miller.  I don't 
know
what the amperage was, but we used the lowest (of the four) available heat
settings and set the amperage to around 28 on the dial (whatever that 
"really"
means).  One thing we discovered was that welds done with the provided
"gasless wire" (the machine was new), kinda sucked.  Lots of slag and lots
of burn-through problems.  We stopped after making a mess of a couple of
"weld inches".  After hooking up the gas and using regular thin wire, the 
welds
looked great, penetrated well, no slag, and most importantly - no burn
through!

The local welding shop I deal with has a "demo" area where you can weld
a few beads with a variety of welders.  Bring in a sample of the thinnest 
metal
you'd like to weld and try out the machines.  If your welding talents are 
lacking,
have the guy there do the welding for you to show that at least the machine
is capable of doing the job.  If it works, buy it and practice, practice, 
practice!!!

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

Paul Murphy writes that his insurance company wouldn't insure his 944.

My company, PEMCO is really strange.  When I called and told them I'd like
to insure my just purchased 67 911 they told me they didn't insure 911's,
only 944's.  When I proceeded to tell them they already were insuring my

insure grey market vehicles.  This took two firm but polite letters and 
somehow it also got insured.

and having a decent driving record, which is why I try to take all 
tickets to court, even though it is a real pain.  The National Motorists 
Association helps with the latter (unpaid advt).

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 13:08:52 -0500
From: David944@aol.com
Subject: Lowering your insurance Rates

Like everyone else, insuring my P-Car is not a pleasant experience.

In New York State (I do not know about anywhere else) you can take a
defensive driving course that will reduce your insurance rate by 10%, both
collision and comprehensive for 36 months..  It will also remove up to 4
points from your state driving record.

There are several private companies that offer classes (8 hours, all
classroom, about $45) and I hear that AAA and AARP offer it as well. Check
with your insurance agent before you spend the time and money.

david.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 95 12:45:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 911 caliper rebuild, low pedal


Bob,

Re: the initially lower pedal height which got better.  It is more likely
due to misalignment (for want of a better word) of the pad faces
with the rotor on re-installation.  Perhaps you swapped inner for outer.
The lack of true causes knock-back, which makes for a deeper
pedal travel next time you go for the brakes.

Kevin

  We are experiencing spring feaver in Central PA. 75 degree weather and

day I noticed what seemed like a slow down of fuel while driving on the freeway.
It seemed to go away in about 2 min. After starting the vehicle the next
time I noticed the pump not shut down. So after checking to make sure that
there was no blockage in the feedline I disconnected the side feeding the

pump.

pump? Do you know where I can buy a Hardi fuel pump? Stodddard shows no

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 95 10:42:12 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Freon Replacements (fwd)


Hi Bob -

This came off the BMW mail list sometime early last year.  The tech bits
are interesting, and so is the political news-that-wasn't aspect.  I
suppose you could mail the guy directly for more info...

good luck

Ed

ps: Porschephiles - sorry if this was on our list last year.         

> 
> 
> >  I've got an A/C system for a 2002 sitting in my garage that will probably
> >  never get installed.  The reason is that I don't want to deal with the
> >  R12 thing in the future.  According to a guy here at work that knows a
> >  great deal about refrigeration systems, the older style systems (up to the
> >  mid '70s I think) have an expansion valve setup that won't work with the
> >  new R134.
> 
> This not true.  R-134a works a bit better if the superheat is adjusted
> via the hex screw inside the valve exit port but that isn't absolutely
> necessary.  And if you do decide to change the valve, it is only about $20.
> BFD.  Of vastly more concern for ANY system converted to 134a is the 
> incompatability of the PAG oil with even traces of old refrigerant.
> Supposedly other types of oils that are compatable with traces of old
> refrigerant are under development but the only ones shown to date,
> the esters, are so sensitive to moisture that the moisture typically
> present in the dryer will cause it to break down.  Plus it is a 
> lousy lubricant.  As of now, you MUST change everything that is porous
> and has been in contact with the old refrigerant.  That includes the hoses,
> the dryer, all O-rings and seals and the evaporator if it has any elastomer
> seals.  And as a practical matter, a compressor replacement is in order
> unless you want to take it completely apart to scrub the components and
> replace the gaskets.
> 
> Conversion is really a side issue because R-12 is going to be around for
> a long time.  The Bush admin EPA was shilling for big industry as 
> represented by MACS and SAE.  The Clinton EPA is taking a much more
> pragmatic approach (strangely enough), particularly after the industry
> was caught lying about the ease of conversion and the reliability
> of 134a systems.  They have already pushed back the deadline to stop
> production of R-12 by a year and the feeling is it will be pushed back
> further.  Plus there are alternatives.  R-406a, formerly known as 
> GHG-12, developed by George Goble (ghg@ecn.purdue.edu) is an exact
> drop-in for R-12.  Banned at industry request under the Bush admin,
> it was re-examined under the Clinton administration and given approval
> for everything except mobile use.  The exception is strictly a political
> move in that the EPA doesn't want to admit all at once how bad it screwed
> up so the mobile exclusion will go away within the year.  This blend
> has over 4 years' testing in thousands of vehicles and works fine.
> It even improves the cooling capacity of systems it is used in.  Meanwhile,
> you can buy this blend from People's Welding in Indianapolis (try 800 info
> for the number - I don't have it handy) and once you own it, you can
> use it as you wish, including in your car.
> 
> Another alternative, OZ-12, was banned because MACS stirred up 
> media hysteria because it is flammable (mix of propane and isobutane).
> A rational evaluation of the risks (a pound of this stuff right beside
> a hundred lbs of gasoline) was never considered.  Reliable rumor
> has it that OZ-12 is about to re-appear with a fire supression additive
> that makes it non-flammable.  Like 406a, OZ-12 slightly improves the
> performance of the system and is completely compatable with and can
> be mixed with R-12.
> 
> Finally, if all else fails, you can mix your own refrigerant using 
> isobutane (NOT butane) camp stove fuel (22%) and propane (78%).
> There is simply no way someone with a little ingenuity and motivation
> will ever be without AC.  I assume that if you're clever enough to
> install the system, you can use one of these alternatives. 
> 
> Meanwhile the price of R-12 is down ( about $210 for a 30 lb can) and 
> can be bought by anyone until November so the easiest solution is to
> grab a couple of jugs and stash it away.  If your system doesn't leak,
> 60 lbs will last a lifetime and if production ever does stop, that
> money you invested in the stuff will turn out to be a wise one.
> 
> John
>

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 13:55:38 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: 911 caliper rebuild


I was going to stay out of this one but.....

Wayne said:

>replacement O-ring seals were somewhat thicker from inner diam. to outer diam.
>(approx 1mm) than the old ones.  This was enough that I could not get the
>pistons back in.  I eventually put the old O-rings back in just to get rolling
>again. 

a couple of comments:

The new seals are probably thicker because they don't have any wear. You
need to lubricate everything with either a special brake rebuilding paste
or just clean brake fluid. You will probably have to press the pistons in
with a C-clamp, and it's normal for them to be tight with new seals.

The reason the pedal is low at first is that you have to pump enough brake
fluid through the system to push the pistons back out, take up the slack
from piston-pad-rotor etc. After that's done and you stand on the brake 
pedal a few times, it should be at the proper height.

Be very careful rebuilding brakes, it's one of the few things you do on a
car where a mistake can mean your life, or someone else's.

Reid



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 14:11:25 -0500
From: Triet Le <trietle@pipeline.com>
Subject: 944 Turbo aftermarket mufflers

I noticed that Alan Johnson Racing is now selling ANSA mufflers for the 944
Turbo at the incredible price of $159.95. Incredible, because the original
costs $525.00. Anybody buy one yet? How do they compare to original in
terms of noise, power, quality, and durability. Also, several places
advertise a 3lb carbon fiber muffler. Any net experience with this product?

 
re: query on chipping a 944TS 
Probably the most bang for the buck. I have an Autothority 2.7 on my '86
944T. The boost comes on early and stays on. Definitely reduces lag.
Supposedly gives me more hp and torque than a 944TS. Probably leads to
increased wear and tear and escalates normal maintenance schedules (new
clutch and brakes please!!!) I wouldn't do it again for that reason.
Mentally, the car always feels faster when you throw $ at it, and slower
when you get used to driving with the mod. Plenty of chips out there, some
with better reps than Autothority. Some places even throw your car on a
dyno and spit out a custom chip. No doubt is is possible for you to cut
your own EPROM, but a dyno should cut development time dramatically. I read
that chipping is so popular in Japan, there are drive-thru places to get
your Supra TT chipped. "Jiffy-PROM" anyone. Personally, I think that
Autothority is the most common (ie. proven), is CARB certified (I know you
can get an inspection anyway), and has a 30 day money back warranty if it
doesn't dip your wick.
