------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 95 13:44:14 CST
From: mateckom@ccmail.afmea.af.mil
Subject: Re: Insurance Policies and Stated Value


Like most, I consider insurance a necessary evil.  However in the thread I 
noticed a discussion of limited use insurance and stated value policies.

About two years ago I read (and just went back and re-read) a letter in a local 
JAGUAR Club newsletter (we also ran it in our PCA region's newsletter).  It was 
a dissertation by a gent in Centerville Virginia who had a stated value policy 
on his '65 Mustang ... and the after effects of a major accident.  

After it was totalled, the insurance company told him that their stated value 
policy conformed to ISO Form E167 terms ... and that they were only obligated to
provide the LESSER -  of the stated value - or - of the actual cash value.
(Obviously the actual cash value is much less on a special interest car).

The guy launched a one man campaign against stated value policies.  He conducted
a survey of insurance agents, and found that less than 10% understood the 
provisions of ISO Form E167 (that the insurance was for the lower of two 
values).  I called my insurance company and tried to verify the letter, but they
said that they don't even offer stated value polices anymore -- "too confusing" 
(they offer a "Valued" policy which covers a pre-agreed on appraised value of 
the car.)

I don't know if the person still provides it, but he forwarded a 8 page document
on his experience (and the law) upon request.  If somebody wants his box # for 
personal use or for your club's newsletter - send me a personal note, and I'll 
reply to you.


Mat Matecko

'87 9 ONE 1  Granite Coupe
'62 MGA MK2 Iris Roadster


mateckom@ccmail.afmea.af.mil

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 95 13:41:27 CST
From: wpcostel@porsche.aud.alcatel.com (William Costello)
Subject: Re(2): porsche not PC?

I live in a subburb and commute into Dallas (about 20 miles one way). I have
my insurance thru Nationwide and pay $379 for 6 months with a $500 deductable.
This is for a 1986 911 Carrera with a perfect driving record and driven almost
every day. I had other bids as high as $2500 for 6 months. It pays to shop
around and find someone that looks at your record rather than your car.

W.P. Costello

Date: 16 Mar 1995 08:34:25 U
From: "John Lucas (GRC)" <John_Lucas_#l#GRC#r#@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re: 928 oil in coolant

 Reply to:     RE>>928 oil in coolant

Carlos Sham said
>> I don't think I see an oil cooler in mine... 
and Bill Smyth made a similar comment.

They're both right!  Since I sent the e-mail looking for help, I've talked to
Howard Adam at Porsche North America.  He did some research and called back to
tell me that the 928 does not have a sump/oil cooler such as the 944 (the
Excellence article that gave me the idea probably should have pointed out that
difference).  

Some 928's have an oil cooler built into the radiator, some don't.  Mine
doesn't.  

The PNA rep suggested that I have an analysis run on the coolant before going
any further.   I plan to do that within the next several weeks.  He also
thought that there could be some normal discoloration due to (partly) the type
of driving I do here in the Los Angeles area.  

Thanks to both Carlos and Bill for their responses ....  I'll post a note
regarding the results of the analysis, etc.

John
'84 928S

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 95 12:03:43 PST
From: Miq Millman <mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com>
Subject: Clues sought

I was driving my 66 911S last night when a strange thing happened.

I had just taken it up to about 70 mph and slowed down to about 40 mph all in
3rd gear.  

The dash started making a strange even ticking sound.

I looked at the Speedo, and noticed that it was oscillating between 0 mph and
about 60 mph.  The ticking noise was the needle bouncing off the pin at 0
mph.  

I slowed to about 15 mph and observed no change in funciton or pitch of the
wildly swinging needle.

I sped up to about 65 mph and the needle stopped acting strange and resumed
its normal "slight shimmy" of registering the speed +-5 mph.

So what happened?

What is this a sign of?

(hopefully I get more answers to this than the last request for short
wheelbase suspension setup I sent)

Miq Millman   mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com	  503 642 6139   (Aloha site)

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 12:06:04 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Lowering your insurance Rates

I used to be insured here in CA with AAA (CSAA), but I got tired of their
intrusive questionnaires (this was when I shared a house with a couple
people), so I looked around and found that State Farm and Allstate had the
best rates (about 20% better than AAA).  

I chose State Farm because you can "suspend" and "resume" coverage on each
car if you know you won't be driving it.  Also, there's a (small, say 10%)
multi-car discount.  The "premium" for sports cars (e.g. a BMW M3, or
perhaps a 911) is an additional 25%.  _All_ the 914's are considered "not
sportscars" by State Farm ( :) or :(, depending on your point of view!).
Oddly, none of my cars are considered "sports cars".

Also, all the storied I've heard of people dealing with State Farm when
accidents ocurred were positive.

I pay $156 every six months per car for liability to the hilt but _no_
comprehensive / collision / theft, limited to < 7500 miles annualy.  No
problem if you have more than one car.

And, should it need repeating, I suggest you run screaming from any GEICO
solicitation.

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 12:08:59 -0800
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: Re: Clues sought

I was driving my 66 911S last night when a strange thing happened.

I had just taken it up to about 70 mph and slowed down to about 40 mph all in
3rd gear.  

The dash started making a strange even ticking sound.

I looked at the Speedo, and noticed that it was oscillating between 0 mph and
about 60 mph.  The ticking noise was the needle bouncing off the pin at 0
mph.  

I slowed to about 15 mph and observed no change in funciton or pitch of the
wildly swinging needle.

Sounds like the Speedo cable is your problem.  At low speeds it is oscillating
or wrapping up in the housing.  At High speeds this is abates and things appear
normal.

Dan

I sped up to about 65 mph and the needle stopped acting strange and resumed
its normal "slight shimmy" of registering the speed +-5 mph.

So what happened?

What is this a sign of?

(hopefully I get more answers to this than the last request for short
wheelbase suspension setup I sent)

Subject: 911 alternator quirk?

when the headlights are on.  I have normal 45/65 watt H5 bulbs.

alternator from Vertex.  The rebuilt had a bad voltage regulator which lead to

regulator, new battery as well as several other new electrical components
mostly relays and A/C fans.  So, is this dim charge light normal, or is it an
indication of something sinister?

Bottom line, should I be on the phone to Vertex demanding a replacement?

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 95 15:44:46 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: A/C Questions

> After all, how much could it cost to charge up a 911's 
> small system?  I have previous owner receipts for $8 or $9, so I 
> figured OK, now it might be $20 or $25.  Wrong.  Very wrong.
> There has to be a better way.  Propane?  (Just kidding.)

Why kidding? 22% iso-butane, 78% propane, by weight, is a fine
replacement mix (although not clearly legal). Sure, there have been
those who point out that this is a flamable mix, but then so is
R-12 + oil (there is an impressive photo of a 12' flame of R-12 + oil
on G. Gobel's home page - check it out...). Not to mention the fuel
in the not-nearly-so-well-contained fuel system...

The iso-butane/propane mix actually improves the performance of the system.

John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 16:10:28 -0500
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: Re: Clues sought

Miq,

Make sure your speedo connection at the transaxel is ok.  It is located at
the very front of the tranny and should be surrounded by a rubber boot.

Not taking care of the above cause can vibrate the speedo drive gear out of
its correct postion, thereby requiring one to pull the engine and tranny to
fix.  Don't ask how I know.

 -Allen Henderson-
'72S, '59A coupes.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 16:15:16 -0500
From: Mdch01@aol.com
Subject: Re: AC system problems.


> I just spent two weeks tracking down and fixing all the leaks in 
> the system.  The car's been under restoration for a year, and this 
> is almost the last thing.  (I say almost...is one ever done?)  I 
> called a local dealer to see what it cost. $160 plus tax.  I called 
> AAA Air Conditioning and Radiator Service (Isn't that what 
> they're all called?).  $49 plus $22.50 per pound for freon.  Yikes.  
> That'll be over a hundred too.

Hmmm, sounds a little too much to me!  I have just restored my 1977 924's  AC
system.  Total cost was $230.  This includes $130 for a rebuilt Sankyo AC
compressor (with a lifetime warranty), $18 for a receiver dryer and $64 to
Evacuate and recharge with freon R-12 (gas cost $32).  Note that I purchased,
removed and replaced my compressor and receiver/dryer myself so all the shop
had to do was evacuate (for 1/2 an hour) and then recharge, and leak test the
system.  The technician told me that I could have upgraded to the new gas
(134 or something?) but I would have had to purge the entire system which
would have meant <removing> condenser, evaporator, compressor and running a
solvent through them to remove old oil ($$$!)  Other considerations are that
the rubber o-rings need to be replaced (maybe neoprene replacements?) -
apparently the new gas destroys them.  They will stop making R-12 in late
1995 though - so the price is certainly going to go up!   I suggest you keep
on looking - there are plenty of devious repair shops out there - you will
find a good one though.
Cheers,  MIKE
1977 924
ex 1980 931 sold yesterday  :-(        



------------------------------


Porschephiles #1245                         Thu Mar 16 21:22:14 CST 1995
Date: Thu Mar 16 13:20:08 1995
From: ci.tcpbridge.center2.center1.rae1%smtpgate@ci.berkeley.ca.us (Ralph Elder )
Subject: 914 Fan Shroud Removal  (SMTP Id#: 24560) - Reply

Hi dave,

Sorry to tell you,  but - there are 4 bolts (13mm) behind the fan that go into the
case.  

The good(?) part is that the fan really isn't that hard to take off.   The fan has a
pin on the back that makes is hard to put it back on wrong.  There are three allen
head or (splined head - depending on your originality index) bolts around the
center and a 13mm (14mm?)  in the center, then wiggle and pull.   If it gives you
trouble, try   filling up  the center hole with liquid wrench and leaving it alone for a
day...   

The other bolts that you have to remove are the bolt(s?) holding on the alternator,
AND the ( I always forget this ) bolt on the other end attaching the oil cooler
bracket to the fan shroud.

(you aren't doing this with the engine in the car, are you?  if so - I'm impressed,
it's so much easier when the engine is on a stand.) 

BTW - is there a proper name for those splined head bolts that hold on the fan
and the cv joints?

=============
Ralph Elder  -  RAE1@ci.berkeley.ca.us      510.644.6820
City of Berkeley, CA
NARS Racing, Chief of Shop Woundings 
70, 74, 75 914s
Saturn, Jeep, Datsun......(gotta do something about all these non-P cars)

******** This has nothing to do with the City of Berkeley, CA  **************


------------------------------

Date: 16 Mar 1995 16:36:17 -0500
From: "Elliot Entin" <elliot.entin@alphatech.com>
Subject: Re: 911 alternator quirk?

        Reply to:   RE>911 alternator quirk?

Wayne,
I'm not sure I would be demanding a new alternator, but from my experience,
something is definitely rotten in Denmark.  Check the output to the battery,
if memory serves me, it should be around 13.5 volts, anything above 14 or
below 13 should be view with suspect.  Check grounding strap for corrosion or
looseness.  Check cells of battery, if not maintenance free, for water and
corrosion.   Alternators fail less frequently than voltage regulars in my
experience.
Hope this helps.
Elliot. 

You wrote...
- --------------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 95 17:23:26 PST
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: A/C


After gawking at the high price of freon, I did some investigating
on what you actually need to buy the 1 lb. cans of freon.  It turns
out that all you need is a certification that be obtained by taking
a 20 question open-book exam from the Mobile Air Conditioning
Society.

I did this last year.  I aced the test and received my certificate
and wallet card within a few weeks after returning the test.  The 
fee was $20 or $30, billed to my credit card, and included the
study guide (about 20 pages), the test, and the processing.

Of course now the small cans aren't manufactured anymore, but should
still be available at some places.  As mentioned earlier, you now
need the certification to buy in larger quantities.

I'll get the 800 number this weekend for MACS, if anyone is 
interested.


Matt Carpenter
'88 9000t
'84 928S
E-mail: mwc@lubrizol.com

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 14:29:46 -0800 (PST)
From: JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: Re: 914 Fan Shroud Removal

>Subject: 914 Fan Shroud Removal
>
>       So how the heck do I get the fan shroud off my 914 engine?
>I undid the screws and bots, and the front half came right off.
>But the rear half is still on there tight.  I'd like to get the
>whole thing off so I can clean up the rest of the sheet-metal and
>that side of the cylinders and so forth.
>        Please tell me that I don't have to take the fan off to
>do it!

O.k. I won't tell you that you have to remove the fan......

But there's no other way to remove the inner shroud. Sorry...

Keep this in mind when you re-mount the fan (if you do remove it). Keep a very 
careful eye on the clearance of the bolt ends wrt the fan hub oil seal. 
Otherwise, if you've changed bolts or anything, you could eat up the seal the 
next time you start the engine. Just a caution...


 -Josh

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 17:40:26 -0500
From: Cdaar1@aol.com
Subject: Re: porsche not PC?

> It didn't help me either having a spotless driving record (knock on >wood).
 A woman would probably pay a quarter of what I pay, with >ten accidents on
her record. 

In one of my many reincarnations, I managed the Personal Auto insurance
department for a major insurance company, and this experience gave me contact
and insight into a great many similar insurance companies all over the
country.  Even then, there wasn't a single company making money on personal
auto (several of them have since dropped out of selling personal auto
insurance).The situation hasn't improved, fewer companies available to write
insurance, so the companies can afford to be picky and charge the hell out of
everybody.  

Actual statistical experience showed that unmarried males below 25 had the
worst accident records, regardless of vehicle, so everybody avoided insuring
these.  Also, the category "performance cars" lumped Porsches with Corvettes,
Trans-Ams, Firebirds, etc., and the overall experience was likewise abysmal,
both in terms of serious accidents and thefts.

So, if you get an insurance application from a young, unmarried stud in a
fire-breather, well, you get the picture.

I was surprised to find that most auto underwriters think of cars as
necessary evils, so it was difficult to convince anyone that people who have
a great passion for Porsches, say, would have far better driving records than
the average. I think that the only insurer who recognizes this is the broker
Leland-West in California; unfortunately, this broker is very conservative
and prefer to insure only the so-called "stable" types--married, homeowner,
no daily driver, etc.

The only advice I can give you youngsters is to ride your parents' insurance
coverage if you can, get the highest deductible you can afford, avoid traffic
tickets (they're murder from an underwriting standpoint), don't commute into
 large metro areas if possible. But don't skimp on liability limits,
uninsured/underinsured motorists coverages, ever. 

Fred Castro

BTW, it is now widely recognized that female drivers are no better risks than
the male.

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 15:57:58 -0700 (MST)
From: "Byron D. Short / AFS Inc." <bshort@usa.net>
Subject: Re: 944 Turbo aftermarket mufflers

Triet Le writes...
> I noticed that Alan Johnson Racing is now selling ANSA mufflers for the 944
> Turbo at the incredible price of $159.95. Incredible, because the original
> costs $525.00. Anybody buy one yet? How do they compare to original in 
> terms of noise, power, quality, and durability. Also, several places
> advertise a 3lb carbon fiber muffler. Any net experience with this product?

This may not be the information you want, but I'll tell you my approach. 
On my 87 951 I replaced everything behind the cat with a 3" pipe--no
muffler at all.  The sound is not very loud, which is not uncommon on
turbo cars.  The turbo makes a pretty nifty muffler at full throttle, and
at cruising speeds the car doesn't need much.  Results?  It FELT like less
turbo lag, but this is pretty subjective.  I did not take g-analyst
readings or any other objective measurements.  I've heard some say that
this should increase the amount of boost, but with the factory wastegate
management system, any extra boost is simply regulated out anyway. 
Obviously there's a big weight savings.  I don't for a minute believe the
claims that this could produce less power than the "tuned Porsche" 
muffler.  Less back pressure produces more power in 99% of the street cars
out there according to the dyno jockeys I've talked to.  Any findings to
the contrary would rely upon the computer reacting differently to the
increased flow, which is pretty unlikely.  Oh, and the cost with smooth
compression bends was $70 for the entire pipe, hangers, labor, and all. 
Mandrell bends would have been about $100 higher, but I didn't feel it was
needed with the larger 3" pipe. 

I'll be putting this pipe on my S2, however I'm betting it'll be a bit 
loud there and if so I'll be forced to add a muffler.


- --

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 95 17:14:50 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; finding AC leaks


    If you still plan to do your own AC work, do yourself a favor and
  buy a leak detector. By god it is the only way to really know where 
  the freon is going. At $150, these were expensive when Freon
  was 99 cents a can....but with Freon soon to be a "N.O.S" item it pays
  for itself quickly. The detection range of these is something like 
  1/2 ounce per year....Even on new systems leaks can develop really quickly.

     Lee A. (glad I did...)


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 95 18:53:19 EST
From: mark_salvetti@ABBSMTP.abb.com (mark salvetti)
Subject: Stated Value Insurance

          In Massachusetts, the stated value policy is as described;
          i.e. the company pays the LOWER of the book value or the
          stated value.

          As far as I know, Leland-West is true stated value, but
          they have limitations.  You must be a PCA member, and you
          have mileage limits (2,500 or 5,000) but you also must not
          use the car as regular transportation.  You have to provide
          them with registrations for all your vehicles, so that you
          can prove that each licensed driver in your family has their
          own car and the Porsche is "extra".  You can't drive
          the car to work.  Also, you must usually keep the vehicle
          overnight in a locked garage.  If you only concours your
          vehicle, you can get a cheaper even more restrictive policy
          that only allows you to drive to events, and you must not
          leave the car unattended at any time.

          I carry liability through my Massachusetts company (about
          $800 per year) and collision/theft/fire through Leland-West.
          This costs me another $200 for a $15,000 stated value
          ($500 deductable) and 2,500 miles/year.  All this for a 1979
          911 Targa.

          If Leland-West is not true stated value, please let me know!

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 19:40:31 -0500
From: Drifting11@aol.com
Subject: goofy 911E trans.; parts WTB

Last June I asked P-philes about a problem with my 911E transmission in that
the gap between 2nd and 3rd gear was very large and I wondered what could be
going on.

It turns out a previous owner (it's always their fault) had accidentally
swapped 3rd and 4th gears when reassembling the transission. The transmission
was also misaligned (big suprise seing they couldn't put the gears in right)
which caused excessive wear on other components.  Reid Van (St. Louis) is
rebuilding the unit and I expect to have the car back on the road before
long. 

I am still looking for a single Fuchs 14" wheel. Cosmetics are not important
at all as this is for the spare, but cracks and large bends are deal killers.
I would also like to purchase an original tool kit.  I looking for  Euro
parking lights and tail lights. I need a passenger side front and both rear
lights. These must have the silver trim. Finally, I plan to attend my first
drivers ed. track event and am in the market for a helmet. Any tips about
good mail order sources or model recommendations?

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 16:43:28 -0800
From: Tony Vanacore <tvanacore@wpo.borland.com>
Subject:  re: insurance

How about a "good" insurance co. story:
             Several years ago, i owned a 1971 MBZ 300SEL 6.3.
Wonderful car... I had it insured at  a declared value of $10,000.
After a few years the car was stolen.  I called the State Farm adjuster
after 30 days had passed to inquire about a settlement. I was told that
they were trying to determine the value of the car so as to make me an
offer.  I came unglued and reminded them that I had been paying
premiums based on a replacement value of $10.000.  Their response
was that they thought that the car was worth more, but if I wanted, they
would give me the 10K that day.   "Of course it's worth more than 10K",
came out of my mouth and after some faxing of Hemmings adds for 6.3's,
we agree on $12,500 and they waived the deductible!!!!!    State Farm has
ALL my insurance business.
                                                           Tony

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 20:45:54 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: Weird Brake Problem

Kotchman:

In pondering your brake problem, 3 things come to mind.
1.  If the car has the original brake lines, they could be deteriorating
internally, not allowing adequate return of fluid to the master cyl. when
releasing pressure.  When they get old they start acting like a one way
valve.  Cure-Replace with new factory type rubber lines.  (I'm assuming this
is a street car and I wish to stay as far away from the braided brake line
discussion as possible.)
2.  Possible the venting clearance between the pedal actuated rod and the
master cylinder is inadequate, not allowing the master cylinder to completely
return.  This clearance or "free play" (can anyone really play for free these
days?) should be approximately 1 mm measured at the pedal.  it is adjusted by
removing the floorboard and shortining the rod going from the pedal to the
master cylinder. (it is threaded into the bracket which connects it to the
pedal and secured by a lock nut.)  
3. The pedal bushings are bagged either by rust or brake fluid saturation,
not allowing the pedal to returning all the way causing the same problem as
item 2. If the pedal feels stiff and will not return to it's stop by itself,
(check by pulling on the pedal and seeing if it moves further back) the
bushings are gone.  Cure-remove the pedal assembly, disassemble it and
replace the bushings.  Some people like the bronze bushings, but I prefer the
original nylon type.  We are in a fairly dry climate where rust is not a
major issue.  Here the most common cause of bushing failure is brake fluid
saturation caused by the master cylinder leaking fluid past the rearmost seal
ring indicating the need to rebuild or replace the cylinder.  usually the
loss of fluid is very slow and the tightening of the pedal bushings is a
symptom of this failure which allows you to often detect the problem before
the system runs out of fluid causing total brake failure.  The early cars
such as yours have the fluid reservoir buried in the contraband well and are
sometimes not checked for level as often as they should be, therefore a loss
of fluid might go undetected until it's too late.  The bronze bushings will
not be effected by fluid contamination so you don't have this early warning
possibility.  If you check your fluid level regularly, this shouldn't be an
issue.  If you have the floorboard out, you can see the rubber boot on the
end of the master cylinder.  (The pedal rod goes into it.)  If you pull that
boot back and have brake fluid in that area, or you have brake fluid in the
pedal assembly itself, the master cylinder needs attention soonest.

Hope this helps

Pat moyle (pm9146@aol.com)

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 17:47:30 -0800

Subject: Re: porsche not PC?

maf,

It is true, 911s had the 25% surcharge and some were inadvertently missed.
An upgraded 'puter program enabled them to pick-up on the missed ones. I'm
an agent for the company and had to explain this to several customers, so I
know how you feel.

The surcharge was/is based upon a lbs per hp rating (I'm not sure of the
ratio). Several family type sedans, such as the Cad Northstar are going to
be dropped from the surcharge program at the next renewal. Included are the
Mercedes 400E and 500E/E500 along with the performance Lincoln.

FYI,

...Bill

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 21:42:22 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Insurance Policies and Stated Value

Mat says, "...After it was totalled, the insurance company told him that
their stated value policy conformed to ISO Form E167 terms ... and that they
were only obligated to provide the LESSER -  of the stated value - or - of
the actual cash value...."

For a number of years I carried stated-value insurance on my one-owner,
looks-like-new 356SC with State Farm...until my insurance agent called to
suggest I shop elsewhere.  He had learned that State Farm does, in fact, pay
the lesser of either the stated value or the value they carry on their
adjusters' book, and, in my case, that amounted to a difference of about
$3000.  He said it would be difficult to prove a value higher than their book
without an elaborate appraisal.  With his help (he evaluated the ratings of
the various companies for me), I shopped around and settled on a
stated-value, limited-use policy with J.P. Taylor in Pennsylvania.  It was
half the price of my former State Farm policy, and the insurance is written
by a highly rated Swiss company.  J.P. Taylor specializes in antique auto
insurance, and and is probably most familiar to owners of domestic antiques.

If you have a unique automobile, it will pay you to ask the right questions
when you shop for insurance.

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper

p.s., the last two of these vehicles is still insured with the very honest
State Farm agent.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 23:41:17 -0400
From: cbt@eduplus.ca (stephen davies)
Subject: Need help '95

> OK, I saw this '89 944 Turbo for 23,850 dollars Canadian. It's got 53,000kms
>and it looks immaculate...... Should I buy.

$23,850 is quite a lot considering the red book value (check your local
library) is about 21,500. In December I flew to Montreal (from Halifax) to
look at a 1989 Turbo (80 K Km) and a 1988 Turbo S (125 K Km). Both were at
Porsche dealerships. I negotiated the '89 down to $19,500 but ended up
buying the '88 for $17,500. Both were in good shape and came with a year
warranty. These cars aren't that plentyful (only 40 '88 Turbo S in Canada)
but I would continue to look around. 

If you are interested in quite serious performance continue to seek out a
Turbo S and don't settle for a regular Turbo.The superior suspension and
engine are definately worth it.

Stephen Davies
1988 944 Turbo S

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 23:01:59 -0500
From: DavidKNY@aol.com
Subject: Insurance

I work as a consultant for the insurance industry, and if you have a clean
driving record (i.e., no at-fault accidents or points in past five years)
GEICO is the hands down winner for price. We (31 male & 33 female) live in
NYC and are paying around $3500 per year for a new 993 cab with high BI
limits, a $500 deductable, and no driving restrictions.

Now I know many of you have heard bad things about GEICO, and while it is
true they may be quicker to drop you than other insurers, they are as
reasonable as the next co. when it comes to paying claims.

BTW, you can get a price quote over the phone while you wait.

David K.

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 22:05:26 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914/911 brakes

> I think I recall reading in all the stuff about 914 brakes that
> there were 911 calipers that would bolt right in and improve
> the brakes a bit.

False.  You can bolt in the whole 911 front end, but not just the
brakes.

You can bolt on the brakes from an early 320i (solid rotor)
with a little machining. It's much better, with more pad area
than a 911S,and slightly bigger pistons as well.

Stan

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 95 20:49:00 PST
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: RE: Insurance


>NYC and are paying around $3500 per year for a new 993 cab with high BI
>limits, a $500 deductable, and no driving restrictions.

Hmmm....all this insurance talk makes me really like our (often locally 
thought
to be rather horrible) "socialized" auto insurance in B.C., Canada.

Gender is irrelevant
Marital status is irrelevant
Age is irrelevant

# of tickets ONLY affects things if you get a few IN A YEAR.  You get to pay
a fine on your birthday.  But if you so desire, you can get 1 speeding 
ticket
a year for all 20 years in your driving career and it WILL NOT affect your
insurance rates.  Not one cent.

Accidents will affect you a bit.....often resulting in at least a 30% 
increase in
rates for the next 3 years....a greater increase will result for more than 1
accident in any 3 year period.

Car make and model will only have a bearing on collision and comprehensive
rates - the more expensive the car, the more it'll cost.

For the above example of $3500 (US)/year for a 993, a know a guy who
insured his Lamborghini Diablo up here for about $2000 CDN ($1430 US)/year
for 1 or 2 Million 3rd party liability, collision, pleasure use (drive to 
work up
to 6 days in a calendar month), no mileage restrictions, etc.  He's had a 
few
tickets and no accidents.

On the lower end, my wife pays around $1250 CDN ($900 US) to fully insure
her '91 Toyota Tercel ($2 Million 3rd party, collision, daily driver to 
work, etc).
So our rates have "collapsed" into a smaller range - almost like an average.
They also go up as claims in our province go up too.

Getting a claim resolved up here is usually a hassle though....but that's 
another
story.  But after reading your comments, I'm quite happy with our auto
insurance!  :-)

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 20:57:55 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Actual Cash Value---When or NOT

Lets see when is actual cash value, ACV. 

When you insure your car with a Classic Car insurance company you are 
dealing with Stated Value Insurance.(SUPPORTED BY AN APPRAISAL) You are 
dealing with Policy/USE retrictions. This insurance is not for the 
Porsche which is used as the second car. This insurance is ONLY for the 
Porsche which is STRICKLY limited use and not normally driven to the 
store, work, bank, etc. The Porsche is usually used for some sort of 
club activities.

The same applies to the PCA Leyland West insurance. This ins. was 
specifically designed for the Porsche Club members, and yes, you do have 
to be a member of PCA to get the insurance, and is based on the Porsche 
as the third etc car in the family.  It is stated value with LOTS of 
restrictions.

But, if you do not drive your Porsche a lot and don't use it for everday 
transportation you can save a bunch with classic ( if car old enough) or 
with the Leyland West type of insurance.

The "normal" insurance companies do not write the same Stated Value 
Insurance no matter what they call it. There's is actual cash value.


							mike



- -- 
- --
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Mar 1995 21:13:44 -0800 (PST)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: Freon

Hi all -

Since I'm not a scientist nor a chemist, I'll let others tell you about
the use of isobutane/propane mixtures as a replacement for your freon. 
Personally, I wouldn't touch the stuff with its flammability and un-tested
nature.  Besides, if it was that great plenty of air conditioning
companies would be looking into it and they are not.  Besides,
flammability is a big concern in the industry.  Other things the industry
is looking at while on their hunt for new freons is non-toxic,
non-carcinogenic, non-corrosive and have extremely low boiling points. 
R-12 had all these qualities and was once thought to be the perfect
solution.  BTW, the industry use to use ammonia as a refrigerant, but when
leaks occured plenty of people complained about the smell.  Now if they 
could only get rid of the smell.

With regards to the use of R-134a, the same restrictions apply to it.  You
cannot vent it into the atmosphere, it can only be purchased by a licensed
technician and it must be reclaimed/recycled.  Even though the ozone
depletion is almost zero, they still don't want this stuff in the
atmosphere.  R-134a also requires a new leak detector because it doesn't
contain the chlorine atom.  Old refrigerants could use a small flame with
a smiffer hose attached, but with the newer refrigerants, you have to
purchase an electronic leak detector (yes, around $150).  This one atom is
what causes most of the damage to the ozone.  When chlorofluorocarbon
(CFC/R-12 or other CFC's for that matter) molecules meet up with UV
radiation, the chlorine atom leaves and connects with the ozone molecules
(O3), it then takes away one oxygen atom and becomes a chlorine monoxide
(ClO) molecule.  Then when this meets up with another single oxygen atom,
it leaves the chlorine atom free again because oxygen then becomes O2. 
This chlorine atom then goes to the next ozone molecule and destroys this
molecule and the process keeps repeating itself.  I think that is
chemically right.......any chemists out there?  But let's not turn this
into another what's better in tires discussion.  Correct me simply if
possible. 

One of the problems with automobile air conditioning systems is vibration
and rubber hoses.  In fact, if you use rubber hoses on a R-134a system,
they have to be of higher quality and denser to prevent freon from leaking
or permiating through the hoses.  Vibration is a given, where on regular
a/c systems most refrigerant flows through solid copper tubing that is
brazed at all joints.  Also on automotive systems, because of the use of a
lot of flare hose ends (joints), there are many o-rings that dry out if
not lubricated frequently enough.  This is why it is recommended that you
run the a/c system at least once a month.  This allows some oil from the
compressor to pass through the system with the refrigerant and keeps
o-rings lubricated. 

If your system initially starts off cold but then quickly goes to warm, 
it sounds like you are low on refrigerant.  Better check for leaks, 
repair and then fill with refrigerant.

As far as cost to check out and re-fill your a/c system this varies all
over the country.  The most modern shops can probably do the job in less
than 1 hour and then you have to add the time to replace defective /
leaking hoses etc.  This includes evacuating the system.  I think most
shops hourly rates are around $55-70 per hour.  You figure the math. 
Freon currently has a Federal tax of $3.10 per pound and that is projected
to rise almost 50 cents per year until 1999.  Beyond that, who knows what
the government will do.  Remember, this is only the Federal tax. Then you
have to add the cost to manufacture (or in the case of R-12 end of 1995)
reclaim exisitng refrigerants to proper ARI standard 700-1988.  Now add
the cost of currently looking / experimenting with new refrigerants and
the cost of R-12 is somewhere around $9-10 per pound.  And that's
wholesale cost not the cost to the public.  The mechanic has to make some
profit on his "parts" sales and now you can see why some places sell freon
for over $15 per pound.  Some of the recycle/reclaim equipment can run as
high as $5000.  This cost has to amortized over time by someone, usually
the car owners. 

As far as self-service of your a/c system.  I relate it somewhat like the 
private service shops that can't get the new computerized equipment to 
work on the new cars.  That's the way it is!  But I can sympathize (sp.) 
with you.

Again, as in my original statement, i don't agree with the handling of 
the problem nor do I think that freon is responsible for all of the 
problems.  It is just like the air polution problem, they blamed the cars 
and now with the massive restrictions on these the problem has only been 
solved partially (maybe %20?).

I hope this has answered most of your questions.

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR
SCCA-SFR/RR

heating and air conditioning contractor
Licensed and paying for it!  Now I know why my dad wanted out of the 
business a few years ago.  The government is making it a mess.

------------------------------

inadvertently forgot to charge you this before; it's always applied") 
when I called to complain.  Must have been the same form letter.  But now 
something smells fishy (I never heard of an insurance company doing 
anything "inadvertently" which actually saved customers money).  Are we 
to believe that they had this surcharge all this time and (not 
coincidentally) it's only after they got all our other cars and house 
policies that they discovered this oversight?  Oh, and it happens to be 
on the Porsches.  Oh and it happens to have been discovered for everyone 
at the same time?  Hmmmm . . .

Porschephiles #1247                         Fri Mar 17 13:16:57 CST 1995
Date: Fri, 17 Mar 1995 04:00:18 -0500 (EST)
From: Frequently Frustrated! <quartz@minerva.cis.yale.edu>
Subject: My quirky 914...

Howdy Porschephiles!  Let me tell you about my 1972 914-4 Gretchin. 
Beautiful blazing red and nice on the curves.  But something's strange... 

	I pride myself on doing all the work on my beloved baby, but a few
months ago I had a rather nasty problem.  Zipping down the road as oft I
do, my right axle becomes detached from the transmission, sending the
engine racing and me slowly to the side of the road.  Being dense but
mechanically inclined, I simply put the axle back on, screwed the bolts
down tightly and went on my merry way.  Later I noticed the right rear
tire was rubbing against the fender well, and I then discovered a part of
the suspension was rusting through.  It then made sense to me why the axle
came off, the tire was pulling away constantly.  $600 of welding later,
the wheel is fine and was aligned, but then it happened again, the axle
came off as I was driving.  Unfortunately this time it shattered the axle
and ripped my clutch cable to shreds on the way down.  I replaced the
parts, but the axle bolts/screws still become loose regularly, and I
tighten them down at regular intervals to prevent breakdown.  But why? 
Why I ask?  I put in new roll pins and washers, even new nuts and I tried
Loctite!  What is my problem?  Thanks for any assistance or opinions! 

Rick Shimkets
'72 914-4 "Gretchin"
'87 Subaru GL 4WD "For sale at only $1100, buy me cuz Rick only likes 
Gretchin"

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 1995 10:50:00 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: 944 steering column firewall bearing


My car has just failed it's annual safety inspection, because of 
"excessive play" in the steering, on examination this seems to be caused 
by wear in the firewall bearing.

I have this morning purchased the bearing, but what do I do to fit it - 
it looks like I need to remove the steering column

Any help much appreciated.

Pete Diffey


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 95 07:38:23 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 steering column firewall bearing

> 
> My car has just failed it's annual safety inspection, because of 
> "excessive play" in the steering, on examination this seems to be caused 
> by wear in the firewall bearing.
> 
> I have this morning purchased the bearing, but what do I do to fit it - 
> it looks like I need to remove the steering column
> 
> Any help much appreciated.
> 
> Pete Diffey
> 

Hi, Pete,

I don't recall the year of your car, but you may have a fairly large 
problem here...

In order to replace the firewall bearing, you will indeed have to remove the
steering column and its surrounding tunnel.

Ultimately, you will have to remove two *anti-theft* 
shear bolts (bolts without heads) at the upper support mounting point.
I have been fairly unsuccessful in removing steering columns (probably
due to my impatience more than anything else) without damage, so I 
have taken to leaving them in place when I discard a chassis.

I would find a pretty good mechanic, perhaps a dealer to assess the amount 
of effort involved. I would *not* attempt this on my own, unless I had
a much greater tolerance of frustration...

Good luck,


- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 95 08:19:19 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: Clues sought

>I was driving my 66 911S last night when a strange thing happened.
>
>I had just taken it up to about 70 mph and slowed down to about 40 mph all in
>3rd gear.  
>
>The dash started making a strange even ticking sound.
>
>I looked at the Speedo, and noticed that it was oscillating between 0 mph and
>about 60 mph.  The ticking noise was the needle bouncing off the pin at 0
>mph.  
>
>I slowed to about 15 mph and observed no change in funciton or pitch of the
>wildly swinging needle.
>
>I sped up to about 65 mph and the needle stopped acting strange and resumed
>its normal "slight shimmy" of registering the speed +-5 mph.
>
>So what happened?
>
>What is this a sign of?

I seem to remember (years ago) similar symptoms from my 67 911S. I can
offer two possibilities. The basic effect comes from torsional oscillations
in the speedometer cable (whats that you say? speedometers weren't always
electric? the early 911 had at least moved to an electric tach). These
torsional vibrations might be due to a small kink in the cable somewhere 
(near the speedometer head, where there is significant cable to wind
and unwind). The fact that the effect only happens over a narrow speed
range is, I expect, a resonance effect. The second possibility, if my
memory is accurate, is that the early 911 odometer used a ratchet
mechanism, which imposes cyclic loads on the cable. If it binds, these
cyclic load changes could set up torsional oscillations in the cable.
For fixes, if the cable is kinked, put in a new cable, perhaps just
a new core (which is where a kink causes a problem). If it is the
speedometer itself, get it repaired, or, take it apart yourself and
disable the odometer feed (consult your favorite attorney first :')).

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 1995 09:27:08 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: re:parts washers



I also use SafetyKleen. When it's no longer usable, they
take it back and recycle it, so you don't have to hassle
with disposal.

I use Berkibile Gum Cutter for tough varnish etc., in very
small amounts, with good ventilation. I use CRC Brakleen for
all other spray applications. There are two formulations - 
the old trichloroethylene which is non-flammable, and the new 
"environmentally safe" formulation which is toluene, xylene
and all the other "ene's" that make it toxic for the user 
and a real fire hazard in the garage. I always figured that
one good fire would spew more toxic stuff into the atmosphere
than all the cans of chloroflurocarbons. I always use non-
flammable cleaners if possible in my garage (which is attached
to the house) just to be safe. 

Reid

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 1995 08:20:23 -0700 (MST)
From: "Byron D. Short / AFS Inc." <bshort@usa.net>
Subject: Re: 944 Turbo Aftermarket mufflers

Triet Le responds...

> B. Short mentioned that his catback exhaust system was an unmuffled 
> shot of 3" steel tubing.  COOL!!!
>
> I can't believe that the neighbors aren't setting Fido on you.

Fido makes more noise than my 951 with this pipe does!  Seriously!  As a 
serious autocrosser, I've had many, many louder cars.  For instance, my 
914 2.0 with a Bursch muffler, same car with 1.7 and a small dyna-max 
muffler grafted to a Bursch system, even a Neon with the muffler hacked 
off and a short down pipe installed in it's place.  All were MUCH louder 
than the 951.  As far as weight goes, I just put the pipe in the back of 
my S2 this morning, as it's going to be installed on it today.  The pipe 
weighs, I would say, about 10-12 pounds total, including all hardware.

As I mentioned, the S2 will probably need a muffler, unfortunately.  I'll
know more in a few hours.  Without a turbo in the system, it DOES get
loud.  A good example of this is shown by accelerating hard in the 951,
then lifting about halfway very suddenly.  The computer opens the
wastegate, venting the exhaust around the turbo.  This produces a brief
pulse of LOUDness.  But it goes away right away since you're not standing
on it anymore.

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 95 10:27:23 EST

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Actual Cash Value---When or NOT
Author:  mswillis%ix.netcom.com@interlock.mgh.com (Michael Willis) at ccnode
Date:    3/16/95 08:57 PM


Lets see when is actual cash value, ACV.
     
When you insure your car with a Classic Car insurance company you are 
dealing with Stated Value Insurance.(SUPPORTED BY AN APPRAISAL) You are 
dealing with Policy/USE retrictions. This insurance is not for the 
Porsche which is used as the second car. This insurance is ONLY for the 
Porsche which is STRICKLY limited use and not normally driven to the 
store, work, bank, etc. The Porsche is usually used for some sort of 
club activities.
     
The same applies to the PCA Leyland West insurance. This ins. was 
specifically designed for the Porsche Club members, and yes, you do have 
to be a member of PCA to get the insurance, and is based on the Porsche 
as the third etc car in the family.  It is stated value with LOTS of 
restrictions.
     
But, if you do not drive your Porsche a lot and don't use it for everday 
transportation you can save a bunch with classic ( if car old enough) or 
with the Leyland West type of insurance.
     
The "normal" insurance companies do not write the same Stated Value 
Insurance no matter what they call it. There's is actual cash value.
     
     
							mike
     
     
     
- --
- --
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com


------------------------------

Date: 17 Mar 95 10:26:13 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Clues sought (speedo bounces)

 
Miq Millman asked about a bouncing speedo needle in his 66 911.
 
Probable cause: kinked or worn speedo cable. Replace. Be careful not to kink
new one.
 
The fact that the needle bounces 5 mph even under the best conditions is a
giveaway that something's binding the flexible shaft in the cable. It grabs,
winds up, breaks loose, grabs again, etc.
 
Pete

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 1995 08:04:19 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: My quirky 914...

If you are using new cv ridged washers and good cv bolts the axle should 
stay put. Torque the bolts to 35lbs. Make sure that nothing else is 
loose and causing vibrations etc. I would also retorque the bolts after 
about 1000 miles to see is any loosned up.

Keep the grease out of the threads.


anyway my $$.02 worth.


				mike

- -- 
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 95 11:28 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: If you've got a $10 head, get a $10 helmet...

Can anybody recommend a good place (either mail-order or in the greater Delaware
Valley) to get a good helmet?  I'm gearing up for my first track event, and I
figure I'll go all-out and get a Snell 95 SA-rated helmet (if the Snell 95

Date: 17 Mar 95 11:14:14 -0600
From: Craig_Zaplatynsky-CCZ001@email.mot.com
Subject: RE: If you've got a $10 head, get a $10 helmet...


>Can anybody recommend a good place (either mail-order or in the greater 
>Delaware Valley) to get a good helmet?

Tracy,
You can benifit from my motorcycle knowledge of helmets.  Mail-order is the 
least expensive way to go, but you do need to try on a few to be sure of a 
propper fit.  You can do this by going to a local cycle shop and try a few on.
Denis Kirk Mail order provides  a good selection of helemts for a good price.
I do not recomend the polycarbonate helments.  They do not provide good 
protection as compared to the Kevlar fiber helmets ( I own a kevlar helmet mfg. 
by BEIFFE and am very pleased with the style, fit and light weight)  You may 
also need to check the regulation at the track that you will be running at.  
Some only require a Snell rated helmet while others insist you purchase a Bell 
Helmet.  I previously owned a Bell and found the design to be heavy and 
cumbersome.
The best way to decide is look around, try some on and keep your eye on the 
saftey rating.

Craig Z.
'74 914 2.0L
Algonquin IL

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 95 12:24:43 EST
From: Lee Walczak <lwalc@mcgraw-hill.com>
Subject: Re: If you've got a $10 head, get a $10 helmet...

     Tracy:
        I don't think it's a swell idea to buy a helmet by mail-order. The 
     fit is pretty critical in a helmet, and they don't all feel the same. 
     When I purchased mine, I must have tried a dozen different models on 
     before I made my selection. And I made sure to wear the helmet I liked 
     for a good 10 minutes or so to see how it felt. (If you wear glasses, 
     this will help you find out if the helmet has adequate ventillation or 
     tends to fog up with the visor down). The only way I would do this is: 
     Try someone else's in your size, and if you like it, *then* place your 
     order. The two major brands I've seen are Bell and Simpson. (A 
     full-face helmet is advisable unless you want to look like Dale 
     Earnheart). I liked the Bell better, but that was just a personal 
     preference. I think it was something like an MR2, and I believe the 
     price was around $270 from OG Racing, which is in Manassas, VA. Your 
     prices may vary...
        Lee Walczak / Wash., D.C.

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 1995 12:20:40 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Re: Spark Plugs

Hello, 

Mark Doyle asked :

>I saw those "KMART" Bosch platinum plug and almost bought some.  What is 
> wrong with these plug?  Are they different than the Bosch platinums I 
> might buy elsewhere?

No, these are the same ones you would get anywhere, but since
K-Mart started pushing them a few years back, I couldn't resist
calling them that.

These plugs are easy to tell because they have the ceramic covered center
electrode and are the only affordable Bosch platinums.
I'm no Robert Bosch, but I think they are obviously bad, as the
spark is squooshed inside a small area, and they don't work
in many applications (foulm turn black, etc).

The "REAL" Bosch platinums are about $15 each, and specified
for the 911S and Turbos. But I've been happy with the Silver so far
(but never ran on a real race track yet).

Regards, Mike Piera  '72 911S Targa  In San Diego for the Pro Solo.

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 95 10:34:50 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Testing a/c for leaks


Hi All-

Several people have asked me how I made a leak gauge to test 
my a/c system.  There are probably better ways to do it, like buying a 
leak detector as Lee Atkinson did, but FWIW, here's what I did.

First, I used my air compressor to fill the system to about 40 psi, 
and then I went around to all the fittings and slopped on very 
thick,  soapy water.  That's how you find leaks, even slow ones, 
in tires, and it works quite well.  It's surprising how even a 
small pinhole leak that might take a day to reduce the pressure 
from say 40 to 39 psi will show up as a visible, growing bubble.

Then, to be absolutely sure I was leak free (considering the cost 
of R-12, one wants to be absolutely sure) I charged the system 
with air, again to about 40 psi, and let is sit for a few weeks, 
every now and again checking the pressure.  After two weeks 
with no loss, I figured it was leak-free.  

To accomplish all this, I made a little fitting/gauge combination 
that screwed onto the system filling port, which on my car is on 
the compressor.  There are actually two such ports, and I don't 
think it matters which you attach to for the purpose of this test.  
It's a standard fitting, available in hardware/plumbing stores 
for a buck or so. I attached a $10 prerssure gauge to this, and 
then a female quick disconnect.  That way I could connect and 
disconnect the air compressor easily.  But you really don't need 
this little bit of luxury.  With this assembly in place, just open 
valve a bit (clockwise).  If there's pressure in the system, the 
gauge will read it.  Mine was empty, so I added air till the 
gauge read about 40 psi, and then closed the valve (counter-
clockwise).  That way the system is isolated from my little 
assembly and any leakage is from the system itself.  Every few 
days I opened the valve and checked the pressure.  Simple.  Just 
remember the valve rotation is opposite to what comes 
naturally.  I'm not sure all a/c units have valves like this, but on 
mine, its a sort of three way device.  Total counter-clockwise is 
operational.  System sealed and ready to go.  Whe turned in a 
bit (clockwise) it opens the filling port, and when screwed in all 
the way it isolates the compressor.  I assume this is so one can 
replace the compressor without losing system charge.

Bob Spindel (rapidly learning more than I wanted to know 
about air conmditioning)
'72 911E Targa


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 1995 13:40:23 -0500 (EST)

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 1995 11:24:19 -0800 (PST)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: Testing a/c for leaks

Bob -

You have committed two fatal errors.  The first one and most significant
is that you put air into the system and air contains moisture.  That is
the worst possible thing you could have done.  Better install a new
filter/dryer before attempting to fill with freon.  Even after evacuating,
which may remove most of the moisture, the filter will be useless. 

The next thing to remember is that the high side of the a/c system will 
probably operate somewhere in the range of 300-325PSI during a hot day.  
No leaks will be found at 40PSI but at 250 or above watch out or that 
compressor will just blow all the freon out of the system over a period 
of a few uses.

The right way to check the system is to fill with nitrogen and leak check
with a pressure around 120-150PSI.  Then evacuate the system and pull a
vacuum of 30MG (inches of mercury) which should be able to be held for
over 30 minutes.  If you can't pull the vacuum, you have a leak, or if the
vacuum won't hold you have a leak.  The new electronic leak detectors can
check for a leak up to 1/2 oz per year (so they claim). 

Mike

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR
SCCA-SFR/RR

------------------------------

Porschephiles #1248                         Sat Mar 18 02:00:06 CST 1995
Date: Fri, 17 Mar 1995 11:28:09 -0800
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: Re: Motronics Fuel Pressure question (in 944)

Ron,

If the Motronic system uses a manifold reference fuel pressure regulator, then
the fuel pressure will vary according to manifold pressure.  As the manifold 
pressure drops (lighter load on engine,etc), then the fuel pressure will drop.

This is done to keep the pressure drop accross the injector orifice constant so
that the fuel delivery is only a function of how long the injector is open, 
which of course the computer determines. By the way, the delivery, as in gm/sec
is related to the pressure as a square law.  If you doubled the pressure, the 
delivery would only increase by the square root of the change, or about 40%.

Dan

dswiger@qntm.com

>I have a question about fuel pressure behavior with Bosch Motronics.
>Fuel pressure on my car (84 Porsche 944) is dead-on the idle spec
>of 29psi.  But, I expected the pressure to remain 29psi at higher RPMs,
>and found instead that it dropped at higher engine speeds
>(e.g. 25psi at 2200rpm).

>Is this proper, or is it an indication of a problem, such as inadequate
>fuel delivery?

>Thanks,
>Ron Olson  (olson_r@cho.ge.com)

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 95 13:23:39 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 924/944 Turbo Mufflers.


The 924 and 944 mufflers are not real mufflers. They are resonators
which have no baffles. They use length and size to tune the octave 
harmonics to reduce the exhaust noise. They are *very* low restriction.

About the only thing you gain by eliminating the cat back piping is 
weight reduction. By removing the Catalyst, however, you will reduce
restriction and get a slightly better spool-up of the exhaust side of 
the turbo. For the 924, this gives a slight improvement over stock. It 
needs some mixture adjustment for the higher rpm ranges.

If you are working with a 944 Turbo, then you should talk to Jon 
Milledge about a PROM which will take advantage of the lower exhaust 
restriction and the turbo mods/improvemnts you can also use.

The normal 944 uses a reverse-flow muffler. This is applicable to all
non-turbo models. The OEM factory muffler is hard to beat for street 
use. The rest make noise and make your wallet lighter. Even if you are
on the track, you should consider a muffler. I have run gutted catalysts
with a stock muffler and gotten a few more HP. I have used a straight 
pipe in place of the stock catalyst and gotten less power. On any DME-
equipped car, you should consider what the DME is doing and what mods 
to the DME you are allowed before dicking around with the intake or 
exhaust.

Spark Plugs. My absolute best results are with indexed Bosch Silvers in
my 1983 944. The same plugs in friends 944 Turbos and 944S2s indicate 
similar results. There was a reason the Porsche factory specified these
plugs in the owners manual as specified replacement types. In my 1973
911S, the ORIGINAL sytle platinums worked best on the track or in 
extended high speed situations. 


Jim Pasha

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 95 15:42:50 PST
From: Miq Millman <mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com>
Subject: Re: Brake fluid type for a 66 912?

Scott Berry says:
> I want to bleed the brakes on my 66 912 and I have no idea what type of 
> brake fluid is currently in the car.  What type should I use and does it
> matter if I mix a new (and possibly different type) of brake fluid with 
> the old stuff?

To be 100% safe you could flush the system with denatured alcohol after
draining the current old cruft.  Then use new fluid.

I'd recommend ATE Blue, is should be about $16 for enough for a complete
system.  Its DOT4, and has a high boiling point.


- -- 
Miq Millman   mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com	  503 642 6139   (Aloha site)
AL4-55  Intel, 5200 NE Elam Young Parkway, Hillsboro, OR 97124-6497
See also miq@teleport.com

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 1995 17:27:24 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Brake fluid type for a 66 912?

Use a good DOT3, like Castrol LMA GT (use the GT *NOT* the "regular" LMA)

Take a turkey baster and suck out as much of the old fluid as you can, then
re-fill the reservoir. Then hookup your Eezibleed (you *DO* have an Eezibleed,
don't you?) and bleed away.

DOT5 is just plain evil, DOT4 an unnecessary complication.

Stan

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 1995 17:56:44 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Do all '89 911C4's leak oil?

First, yes, almost all Porsche leak oil. The only ones that don't are 
the ones that haven't started yet. Think of it as proof of fine German
craftsmanship.

Second, the oil is *NOT* leaking from the cylinder heads. It could be 
leaking from the valve covers (likely), or something else higher, and 
dripping from the cylinders looking like it's leaking from the cylinder
heads. But it's not leaking oil from there. The leak that Bruce refers
to is that of COMPRESSION. That's a lot worse, and $8k is a cheap fix
if that's the problem.

Stan

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 1995 20:24:45 -0500
From: RobVial@aol.com
Subject: Boxter info

While waiting for an oil change today I flipped through one of the car
magazines.  I can't remember the name but it wasn't Car & Driver or Road &
Track.  They had a drawing of the 1998(?) Corvette.

Anyhow, the had info about cars being introduced in the next few years, one
of which was the Boxter.  Man, I still melt when I see a photo of it.  I
didn't expect anything substantial from the text, but there it was, THE
ENGINE OPTIONS!

They said Porsche is going to offer a 170 bhp 4 cyl and a 210 bhp flat six.
 I believe they said rear engine also.  Something about $40,000.

For $40,000 why not use the 236(?) bhp 968 engines.  170 bhp and $40,000
don't mix (not even 210).

Anyone else seen or heard anything like this?  This car isn't in my price
range, but you never know with Powerball (getting my numbers tomorrow).

Rob

89 944S2 (ready to be Zymoled tomorrow)
93 Camry V6XLE (Zymoled last weekend and loved it)
93 Lumina (company car that has horrible braking)
no critters
no rugrats
just bills

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 95 20:42:38 EST
From: mark_salvetti@ABBSMTP.abb.com (mark salvetti)
Subject: Re: Lowering a 911

          Chris Bennet wondered how to lower his '86 Carrera, and Eric
          Brown offered some advice.  Thought I'd add my 2 cents
          worth (Given how long this has gotten, it's more like $2!).

          First, why lower?  I'm planning to lower my '79 911SC to
          what I think are stock levels for the Carrera.  For
          non-track cars, Bruce Anderson recommends the following ride
          heights: 25 inches from floor to top of rear fender lip, and
          25.5 inches to top of front fender lip.  My understanding is
          much lower than that and you have to go to thicker (i.e.
          stiffer) torsion bars to keep from bottoming the suspension.
          If you just want to lower 0.5", you might be able to do it
          during the alignment, rather than messing with the torsion
          bars.

          In my case, I need to lower the rear about 1.5" and the
          front about 1" to get to these heights.  The SCs for the USA
          were high from the factory due to US bumper height
          requirements.

          To lower the rear, jack up the car and support on jackstands
          under the torsion bar tube.  The method of measuring the
          spring plate angle that Eric described is accurate, except
          you must do this with the spring plate hanging free.  This
          means unbolting it from the control arm.  You have to
          support it with a floor jack and lower it slowly after
          undoing the lower shock absorber bolt and all of the bolts
          holding the spring plate to the control arm.  If not
          supported, the torsion bar tension will cause the arm to
          violently snap downward.  Also, the angle you want to
          measure is the difference between the inclination of the
          jacked up car and the spring plate.

          Next remove the cover over the end of the torsion bar tube.
          I think the outer end of the torsion bar has 40 splines, and
          the inner has 44.  This means that removing the spring plate
          and moving it one spline results in (360 degrees/40)=9
          degree change in spring plate angle.  According to my little
          Spec Book, a 1 degree change should result in a 7 to 9 mm
          change in ride height, so moving one spline could change
          your ride height by 2 to 3 inches!  You have to increment
          the inner and the outer ends of the torsion bar in different
          directions to get the change you want.  I'm planning to
          use this method, rather than dealing with spring plate
          angle.  This assumes that you can easily remove the spring
          plate and the torsion bar, which I've heard may be a big
          assumption.  Make sure you don't mix up left and right side
          bars, and don't nick the protective coating or the bar may
          rust and break.  This has to be done for each side of the
          car.

          This is a compilation of info from the factory manuals, the
          Haynes manual, Bruce Anderson's book, and the Spec Book.
          There was also an article in Excellence last year on doing
          this.

          I'm less clear on how to do the front, although I think
          it's easier.  I'm planning to just feel my way along here,
          or send an Email to Bruce Anderson for advice.  I'll let you
          all know how I make out.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 1995 22:47:05 -0500
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914-6

Keith,
You wrote about a 914-6 w/new paint, orig wheels w/a price of 10k that you
might be able to get to 9k.

If you're looking for value, originality is important.. does it have the
original engine/trans? All original panels, interior, etc? But, most
important, is it rusty? Just because it's had a new paint job does not mean
it doesn't have a rust problem.  Verify this first!  Rust will turn a
reasonable price into a high one very fast when/if you have it fixed!

If it's solid, original and runs ok, 9k would be a good price.  There are
cheaper cars out there, but always it seems, with problems.  There are more
expensive cars out there (good ones and bad ones).  Be careful and consult
with the 914 experts on Pfiles before you spend your money.
Good luck,
Phil VanBuskirk, Porsche Market Letter 619-727-4856 (8-5/m-f CA)

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 1995 23:04:12 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com

 Craig says, "Mail-order is the least expensive way to go, but you do need to

Don't you think this is bad form, Craig?  Local retailers invest money in
inventory specifically to give you this privilege, so don't you think this is
taking advantage of them?  I'm not in the business, and I very often buy
mail-order, but I don't think it's appropriate to try-on-for-size locally and
then buy elsewhere.  Find a good dealer and support him!  The rewards will
make it worthwhile.

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 95 23:05 EST
From: Jay Ellis <0007142347@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: 951 sans muffler

Byron writes...
> A good example of this is shown by accelerating hard in the 951,
>then lifting about halfway very suddenly.  The computer opens the
>wastegate, venting the exhaust around the turbo.  This produces a brief
>pulse of LOUDness.  But it goes away right away since you're not standing
>on it anymore. 
I also have a 3" pipe from the cat back that I put on for the track season.
It's a little loud for my tastes for the street, but it sounds so great at
the track, I leave it on.  Actually, I have it flared to a 4" tip and just
got it 'aluminized' (or something like that) with a white powdery coating to
keep it from rusting out.  From the back, it looks similar to the turbo cup
car exhaust.  Not near as mean a sound though...

Removing the muffler really helps to keep the engine temperature down during
hot summers, and allowed me to keep up with a 951S on nearly all of Summit
Point this past Sunday!  The 247hp S still walks away from me on the long
straight, but I seem to have just as much torque at speeds under 100.

Let us know how the pipe works on your S2...

Jay Ellis
'87 951 (new R1s, rollbar in the mail...)
'89 Feline Tigger
'92 Feline Grisabella
7142347@mcimail.com



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Mar 95 20:32:32 -0800
From: donr@deltanet.com (Don Rutherford)
Subject: Annoying squeak in 78SC

James

Two possibilities. Based on the age, it is quite possible that it is the 
torsion bar rubbing in its tube because the mounting which originally held 
it centered inside the tube has worn. As I understand it, the solution is to 
rebuild the mount which requires a weld.

The other alternative, which is why I am on the verge of replacing mine, is 
the shock itself. Mine are Boge and one of the fronts is driving me with its 
constant squeeking. Easy to check. Jack up the corner so the shock is 
extended and spray WD40 inside the shock tube. Mine goes away, but only for 
a day or so.

Don

>I have a '78 911 SC that has an annoying squeak in the front suspension.  
>.......Does anyone know about this?  Any fixes for this?  Any help is 
>appreciated. 
>thanks 
>James

Date: Sat, 18 Mar 1995 04:52:49 -0800 (PST)
From: scokelly@netcom.com (Scott Kelly)
Subject: Re: Do all '89 911C4's leak oil?

Stan,
 
> First, yes, almost all Porsche leak oil.
From where do all Porsches leak?  Oil return tubes, between the cylinder 
heads and cylinders, cam towers, valve covers ... where?
 
> Second, the oil is *NOT* leaking from the cylinder heads. 
I'm not a mechanic, but it "looked like" it was coming from the seam 
between the cylinder head and the cylinder.  This was easy to view on 
cylinders 4-5-6 (6 was leaking bad), but 2-3 were hard to view. 

> It could be leaking from the valve covers (likely), or something 
> else higher,...
My mechanic said it was also leaking from the cam towers.  Is that
considered the valve covers?

> The leak that Bruce refers to is that of COMPRESSION. 
Who is Bruce & where does oil leak from when it is caused by a 
compression problem?

Stan, 

1) is running a compression leak-down test on a cold engine a "good" 
enough test to see if the oil leak is a problem or is it "normal"?

2) are all oil leaks a sign of bad things to come or are some the sign 
that it is a Porsche?

I appreciate you help. Thanks.
Scott Kelly (scokelly@netcom.com)

Date: Sat, 18 Mar 1995 10:51:27 -0500
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Grease and Torques Settings

Michael Willis wrote "......Keep the grease out of the threads."

This brings up a question.  I've been told by a QC buddy of mine that grease
and anti-sieze compounds have a definite negative effect on torque settings.
 He states that, particularly on higher torqued fasteners, these compounds
can actually cause stretching of the fastener, since higher than spec torque
is actually achieved by the lubricant use.  He also stated that a fastener's
factory rated torque can also be messed up by the use of plated fasteners, if
they are not original.

This makes logical sense to me, but if true, how does one adjust for the use
of anti-sieze compounds - particularly on wheel nuts.  I have used these for
years on my wheel nuts, and exhaust components, but worry if I should make
some sort of torque adjustment or just stop using them.  

How about the group - what are your feelings?

Pat Garvey

wanna-be, mall driving, sports car.  Get something with class."

approximately $12,000.  However, the main reason I am getting rid of my 
1983 toyota celica is the constant headaches with its falling apart, 150K 
miles...Now with the price range I am in, I am relegated to getting a 911 
with mucho miles.  Now, I am getting myself into a nightmare?  I really 
don't want to be working on a car every weekend (even if I could!!).

the local autotrader, and I saw a 1980 911SC Targa, AC, Cruise, 
maintained with org. porsche parts, new top, starter, clutch, water seal, 
fuel relays, and ignition, HIGH FREEWAY MILES (the sellers wife said it 
was under 200,000, but over 150,000), solid trans, and strong engine, all 
for $9500.  Now this seems remarkably low.  Of course, one of my 3 
friends (1973 911) has a really good friend who works on nothing but

check any possible purchase.

previous cars were a 1980 Chevy Citation, and a 1983 Celica.

Date: Sat, 18 Mar 95 12:02:00 PST
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Stainless Steel Valves for 914 2.0L......Stan's right again!!!


Hello 'philes,

Well, Stan has been proven right once again....stainless steel
valves suck in a 914 2.0L engine.  A little while ago, a mechanic
friend of mine was about to rebuild a guy's engine.  I mentioned
to him the warnings I heard here about NOT using SS valves
and he half-believed me.  He gave his customer a choice
and being on a budget, he opted for the SS valves and hoped
they'd be OK.  After the engine was rebuilt, and a happy customer
was driving around, I showed printouts of Stan's warnings to
my friend.

He started to worry....then he called up the customer and told
him what he just found out.  My friend said if the guy wanted to
pay for the new factory valves, he'd install them for free.

Well, 2 days ago the engine was torn apart.  It had 4000 miles
on it since the rebuild.  The SS valves were pitted, and the seats
and guides were worn.  The valves were burning up.  My friend
figures they would have lasted another 4000 miles before
chunks fell into the combustion chamber and done lots of
damage.

He will NEVER use those again.....

Thanks, Stan!!!

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 18 Mar 95 12:51:40 PST
From: John Wright <jpw@hpsadlb.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Local Retailers


>Date: Fri, 17 Mar 1995 23:04:12 -0500
>From: Bob356@aol.com
>Subject:  RE: If you've got a $10 head, get a $10 helmet...

> Craig says, "Mail-order is the least expensive way to go, but you do need to
>try on a few to be sure of a propper fit.  You can do this by going to a
>local cycle shop and try a few on."

>Don't you think this is bad form, Craig?  Local retailers invest money in
>inventory specifically to give you this privilege, so don't you think this is
>taking advantage of them?  I'm not in the business, and I very often buy
>mail-order, but I don't think it's appropriate to try-on-for-size locally and
>then buy elsewhere.  Find a good dealer and support him!  The rewards will
>make it worthwhile.

>Bob Joyce

I'll second Bob's advice.  

Years ago, I had a part time job selling parts in a primarily VW shop.  

It used to drive me "up the wall" when a mail order customer would come in 
and say something like:

   Customer:  I ordered this VW part mail order, it took two weeks to get 
              here, and it's missing a chrome piece.

              Do you stock the missing piece?

   Me:        Only as part of the same blister packed assembly. 

              If I pull the part out of the assembly, the remainder won't be
              saleable.

              You could buy our assembly and return the other.

              Otherwise you'll have to deal with the mail order source.

   Customer:  That $*%# mail order company.

              (gripe, gripe, gripe)

              (customer leaves the store)


From the retailer's perspective,

       1. They don't make a profitable sale.
       2. They are expected to sympathetically listen to complaints about
          a mail order competitor.
       3. There MAY be a residual possibility of future business.

It's hard for a local retailer to compete price-wise with a mail order firm
that may carry almost no inventory, doesn't maintain a retail store, and 
doesn't have retail store overhead.

I'm NOT saying "don't deal mail order", but if you want to keep a local
retailer in business, try to keep whatever business you do with them profitable
to them.

Don't just waste their time.


John Wright   jpw@sr.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 18 Mar 1995 19:34:45 -0500
From: BUBBAUSA@aol.com
Subject: Re: Weird Brake Problem

Try your brake hoses. I had this prob once on an old 356 C Cpe - seems the
hoses swell on the INSIDE from age and water and fluid and heat cycles ete
etc. The Mcyl can push fluid through but there is not enough "oomph" to let
the fluid come back to the Mcyl/Reservoir & so it keeps pressure on the
caliper pistons to keep pads engaged. After replacing all 4 rubber hoses &
bleeding the system, never encountered it again. Dunno, but it may be worth a
look. Good Luck.
George
50 Cpe
57 Carerra S/R Cpe
61 Rdstr
65 C Cab

OK guys, before I forget.  Was rooting through my old philes to see which ones to 
let go, and noticed again this story about aircooling and lack of valves. HAHA 
good joke; I have a couple of CBX's (Yes Honda, Yes Japanese 2 wheeler) with not 
only lots of cylinders (6 each) but even more lots of valves (24 each) and what's 
more *AIRCOOLED* The japanese had this aluminum casting down to a fine art in the 
70's, the cylinder heads on these babies is truly a work of art.
	AND LETS NOT FORGET the Honda NR750, which is a V-Four design and has a 
massive *EIGHT* valves per cylinder, has oval cylinders but is, however, 
watercooled. 
	However, changing the heads on a Porsche engine to accept more valves may 
be a different story..
Cheers,  Jan

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 1995 05:18:39 -0800 (PST)
From: scokelly@netcom.com (Scott Kelly)
Subject: Re: "The Used 911 Story"


> Where did you read "The used 911 story", if I may ask? 
> Thx. Dave

Dave,

'The Used 911 Story' is a small reference book that points out things to 
look for when buying a used 911.  It covers each year and the specifics 
of that year.  I found it helpful because it is one of the few books that 
covers the 1989-93 C2 and C4 models.

Author: Peter Zimmerman
Publisher: PMZ Publications
Lib of Congress Catalog Card #: 81-7003

It's not the type of book you'll find at your local mall.  I purchased 
mine through Moffett's.  They advertise in back of Excellence.

Moffett's; 12 Francis St.; Cocoa Beach, FLA. 32931
     Orderline: 1-800-356-2911
     Infoline :   407-783-1820 (voice & fax)

I paid $18.95 for book plus $3.99 S+H.

Hope that helps,
Scott (scokelly@netcom.com)

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 1995 08:59:57 -0500
From: TimK913781@aol.com
Subject: Re: If you've got a $10 head,...

Pick up a copy of either Cycle World or MotorCyclist.  There are plenty of
good mail order places which advertise in those mags.  

If you're not sure which helmet you want, go to a local bike shop and try on
a few.  Some places will even match the prices of the mail-order joints.
 Personally, I like Shoei and have an RF-200.  I believe these are still
being produced.  Arai (another difficult-to-pronounce helmet company) also
makes some excellent lids.  In my experience, you either have a Shoei head or
an Arai head, so it does pay to try a few on before making a decision.  Brand
is entirely relevant.

Either way, you will be extremely well protected and quite comfortable.

Tim Krone
TimK913781@aol.com
