of my 911.  I have had a problem with chunking of the 
tread at driver's ed events.  By chunking I mean basically
large chunks of tread are coming off at the sidewall-
tread interface.  This has happened twice - yesterday
being the most recent.  Could this be a factor of the
tread design?  My pressures were at 35PSI, alignment
is OK, etc.  The tires do have alot of tread on them (I can't
wear 'em out).

I now have to buy new tires as these are not usable for
any more track events.  I'm leaning towards Yoko AVSs
or Bridgestone RE71s, etc.  Should I expect the same thing
to happen to these?  

What I really need to do is buy a cheap set of wheels and
get some track tires for them but I wouldn't mind the wear
on my new tires - I just don't want to ruin them with one
track event.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Subject: Risk of failure for 944 timing belt 


Records show that the timing belt on my '86 944 was replaced 5 years ago.
Distance driven in those 5 years has been 33,000 km or 20,700 mi. Climate 
driven in is Pacific Northwest, summers only.
 
I know the rule of thumb is 3 yrs or 30,000 mi between replacements.
 
Given the facts, what's the risk of the timing belt breaking? Visually, 
it checks out ok, but this doesn't mean much. Should I be parking it 
right away to have it fixed, or can I still drive it at least until the 
P9201 arrives in the mail?
 
Joe '86 944

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 1995 12:35:36 -0500
From: Leslie Kyger <kyger@expert.cc.purdue.edu>
Subject: Geico Bad, State Farm Good

I had a _lot_ of trouble *CANCELING* a Geico policy on my 72 VW.  
(Porsche Type 60  =)  I bought the policy in Arizona, when I moved to Kentucky 
I switched to State Farm.  Geico sends me a big bill (about twice what my 6 
month rate had been.)  I send it back "cancel".  Geico sends me another bill, 
and a letter telling me I'm past due.  I send it back "Hey!  Cancel!"  Geico
sends me another bill, "You never paid us the first time."  I send them a 
photocopy of the cancelled check with their agent's signature on the back.  
Geico's collections department sends me a letter and a bill.  I call their HQ 
in Atlanta.  They still have no clue, "You owe us."  I send ANOTHER photocopy 
of the canx check, and a irate letter.  Geico's collections department sends
me a bill and a threatening letter.  I call HQ.  "Oh, sorry, must've been a
miscommunication."  Geico's collections department threatens me AGAIN.
I call HQ and LET THEM HAVE IT!  After 3 months of this, it ends.

I slide on some wet leaves in my 89 Mercury and bend a control arm on a curb.  
6 days later, State Farm's check is in my hand.  Geico is much cheaper than 
State Farm, and I think I know why...

- --Les

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 95 15:53:31 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Risk of failure for 944 timing belt 

> 
> Records show that the timing belt on my '86 944 was replaced 5 years ago.
> Distance driven in those 5 years has been 33,000 km or 20,700 mi. Climate 
> driven in is Pacific Northwest, summers only.
>  
> I know the rule of thumb is 3 yrs or 30,000 mi between replacements.
>  
> Given the facts, what's the risk of the timing belt breaking? Visually, 
> it checks out ok, but this doesn't mean much. Should I be parking it 
> right away to have it fixed, or can I still drive it at least until the 
> P9201 arrives in the mail?
>  
> Joe '86 944
> 
> 

Rule of thumb is:
1) Replace Belts.

2) Re-adjust belts at 1500 miles.

3) Re-adjust belts at 15000 miles.

4) Replace belts at 30000 miles.

For me, since I own a belt gauge and track the car extensively, I check 
the belts each couple of months and replace at 10K miles.

I wouldn't be worried about belt problems with 20K miles, but would schedule 
replacement and replacement of any suspect pulleys or idlers...

Good luck, GB
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 95 15:56:20 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 O.E. Alarm Switch

> Hey you fellow Techies!
> 	Still haven't heard from any of the specialists that I know exist on this 
> net about my *?!#! alarm switch situated in the drivers side rear fender.  Ho
w 
> does this switch come out? The switch is totally seized on mine, and I want t
o get 
> it operative again. (George??) 
> 	BTW thanks for the replies on my surging accelerating problem, I have 

Removing the switch is easy.

1) Pry off the black plastic ring on the outside of the switch.
2) Undo the retaining nut.
3) Push the switch into the panel behind the quarterpanel.
4) Remove the air grille in the door post.
5) reach in and retrieve the switch.

Please note that the switch is not repairable.

Replacement switches with keys are available from the dealer.

Good luck...
> found that the mass airflow sensor is responding well to treatment with lots 
of 
> WD40, and the problem seems to have gotten a lot better.  Still not perfect, 
but I 
> have half a can left...
> 	There has been a lot of talk about insurance, how much should I insure my 
> 86.5 944, Arrest-me red, 138k with recently overhauled engine, excellent cond
ition 
> throughout with no paintwork done at any time, totally original for?  I was 
> thinking in the $7500 range, am I way out with that?  
> 	Cheers,   Jan

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 1995 13:04:03 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: Grease and Torque Settings

Pat Garvey (porschefan@aol.com) wrote: 

>I've been told by a QC buddy of mine that grease and anti-sieze 
>compounds have a definite negative effect on torque settings.  He 
>states that, particularly on higher torqued fasteners, these compounds
>can actually cause stretching of the fastener

Pat:

No!  They actually STRETCH?

Why, that would mean that tension would be developed across the bolts, 
and they might -- I know this sounds crazy -- actually hold things 
together.

Duh.

Someone should tell your buddy that all bolts MUST stretch in order to 
do their job.  In fact, bolt-tightening operations are often specified 
by the amount of bolt elongation at the desired tension.

Since bolt-stretch is hard to measure, however, most tightening specs 
show torque settings instead.  These settings invariably assume the use 
of thread lubrication.

Without any lube, the settings are grossly affected by the friction 
between mating threads.  Without thread lube, your torque wrench may 
read 100 pounds, for example, but a good portion of that torque will be 
devoted to overcoming friction.  When you remove the wrench and 
everything relaxes a little, the torsional stress goes away and the 
tension load which remains will be much less than what you want.

 -Andy


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 1995 13:17:14 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re:  Decisions, Decisions

Some guy named Tim (budd@rohan.sdsu.edu) wrote:

>I was all ready to purchase a 92 MR2 Turbo, when my 3 friends, lets 
>call them 1986 911Carrera, 1973 911SC [sic], and 1980 911SC, [asked]
>"Why purchase a wanna-be, mall driving, sports car.  Get something with 
>class."
> .... My $$$ limit is approximately $12,000. .... Now with the price 
>range I am in, I am relegated to getting a 911 with mucho miles.  Now, 
>I am getting myself into a nightmare?  I really don't want to be 
>working on a car every weekend (even if I could!!).
>
>So, basically, with no further ado...what should I do?

Tim:

Buy the MR2 Turbo.  It's faster than any of the 911s your friends own, 
it handles better, and it's orders of magnitude more reliable.  It 
doesn't look as goofy as a 911, either.

For your $12,000, you can get an MR2 Turbo with low miles, leather 
interior (if you like that sort of thing), A/C, power everything, ABS, 
etc.  If you look carefully, you'll find one with a transferable 5-year 
warranty.

I have a feeling that you'll be much less happy with a late-70s or 
early-80s 911.

 -Andy

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 1995 16:36:36 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Placement of 914  Auxilary Oil Cooler

> I purchased a 16-row Earl's oil cooler (4 7/8" H) but am not sure where the
> most efficient placement would be.  If I place it up front I would probably
> have to install a heavy-duty oil pump.

Well, that's too much oil cooler for starters. You should have been just
fine with a 6-row cooler. Anyway, what's done is done.... 

> Has anyone had success with rear placement and, if so, where was it placed?

I always mount up front except on tube-frame race cars. There's just no
good place to hang a cooler in the back that allows it to get any air
flow. Putting on the engine lid is *NOT* an option.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 1995 16:48:05 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: If you've got a $10 head,...

> Pick up a copy of either Cycle World or MotorCyclist.  

Ummmm. The problem with this is that unless you're also a motorcyclist,
and very seldom do the car thing, you're still better off with a Snell
SA-90. Why? Well, it's specific for racing cars. The liner is fireproof.
It's built to a different impact standard. This kind of stuff is important
if you need it.

> In my experience, you either have a Shoei head or
> an Arai head...

Bell maps pretty well onto Shoei, and Simpson onto Arai. Of course,
Arai makes a *WONDERFUL* SA-90 hat that's only about a kilobuck. If
I were doing the pro race thing these days, it would *DEFINITELY* be
under an Arai hat. I"m not, so it's a Simpson.

Check prices in Circle Track, Sports Car (the SCCA mag), etc.

Stan

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 1995 16:54:30 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 911 Tire "chunking"

> I have a set of "cheap" BFG Euro TA tires on the rear
> of my 911.  I have had a problem with chunking of the 
> tread at driver's ed events.  By chunking I mean basically
> large chunks of tread are coming off at the sidewall-
> tread interface.

This is actually pretty common on many tires. It's why the practice
of "shaving" started -- theory is that the tread blocks are too tall,
that they "squirm" under load and that the resultant heat build-up causes
them to separate from the carcass. Shaving reduces the height of the
tread blocks, cutting down on heat, etc. OF course, now days the tires
start to really get sticky at the shave depth, as the manufacturers 
started seeing a way to increase performance *AND* revenue... but I 
digress...

> I now have to buy new tires as these are not usable for
> any more track events.  I'm leaning towards Yoko AVSs
> or Bridgestone RE71s, etc.  Should I expect the same thing
> to happen to these?  

I ran Yoko AVS Intermediates for 6 years on my 911. Street. Track.
Autox. *GREAT* tires. Used to run RE71Rs on the showroom stock
racers, but that's a different tire than the vanilla RE71.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 1995 17:10:28 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Grease and Torques Settings

> This brings up a question.  I've been told by a QC buddy of mine that grease
> and anti-sieze compounds have a definite negative effect on torque settings.

See "Screw to Win" by Carroll Smith (Actual title is "Nuts, Bolts, Fasteners,
and Plumbing Handbook"). If you're racing, you should have two copies of 
this -- on in the bathroom, one in the toolbox. Great stuff.

Slight lubrication -- the spec is *USUALLY* "one or two drops of a light
machine oil" -- is needed to make sure you don't have threat stiction
giving an unrealisticly high reading on the fastener.

Gobs of grease and never-sieze *CAN* also have the same effect. They
add extra goop between the male and female threads, and this can cause
the same sort of binding.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 1995 17:19:36 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Do all '89 911C4's leak oil?

> > First, yes, almost all Porsche leak oil.
> From where do all Porsches leak?  Oil return tubes, between the cylinder 
> heads and cylinders, cam towers, valve covers ... where?

Well, the engine is made of these large pieces of aluminium, and where
they come together, if there's oil pooling behind it, you can pretty much
count on it eventually leaking. Candidates are the case center seam, the
cylinder-case interface, the head-cam carrier interface, the cam towers,
the valve covers. You can also get leaks from the oil sender, the oil
cooler, the thermostat, the various lines that make up the oil system, and
the oil return tubes....

> > Second, the oil is *NOT* leaking from the cylinder heads. 
> I'm not a mechanic, but it "looked like" it was coming from the seam 
> between the cylinder head and the cylinder.  This was easy to view on 
> cylinders 4-5-6 (6 was leaking bad), but 2-3 were hard to view. 

Oil is like any fluid: it seeks the lowest level. So when you have oil
dripping off of the bottom of something, that's *NOT* likely to be where
the oil is coming from unless you're really really lucky. Take the car to
a pressure do it yourself car wash, hose off the bottom of the engine, and
then run it for a while. See if you can figure out the source of the leak
once it's clean. Nothing else works (except radioactive tracers and flurescent
dyes and crap).

> > It could be leaking from the valve covers (likely), or something 
> > else higher,...
> My mechanic said it was also leaking from the cam towers.  Is that
> considered the valve covers?

No. But it's also a possiblity.

> > The leak that Bruce refers to is that of COMPRESSION. 
> Who is Bruce & where does oil leak from when it is caused by a 
> compression problem?

Anderson, Bruce. See "Minor Deity" in the Porsche Dictionary. See also
"The 911 Performance Handbook". If you have or want to have a 911, you should
have this book. Period.

> 1) is running a compression leak-down test on a cold engine a "good" 
> enough test to see if the oil leak is a problem or is it "normal"?

Nope. You have an oil leak. Oil leaks, unless they're pressure leaks (in
which case, believe me, you'd know it) are *NEVER* fatal on any of the 
air cooled cars. Unless of course all your oil leaks out and you don't know
it, and then in my opinion it still wasn't the oil leak, it was pilot
error...

You need a compression test and a leak down test to see if the engine is
any good. Plus having it checked out thoroughly by a competent mechanic.
I would seriously hesitate to use the current mechanic, as they may know
the car well enough to lie successfully, and will likely figure that if
something *IS* broken they might be able to get you to let them fix it down
the line. Then again, I'm cynical and paranoid...

> 2) are all oil leaks a sign of bad things to come or are some the sign 
> that it is a Porsche?

Depends. I've had over a dozen Porsches. All but one leaked, and it didn't
have an engine.

Then again, I've never had a catastrophic problem except in a race car.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 95 18:20:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re: Brake fluid type for a 66 912?


Miq,

>To be 100% safe you could flush the system with denatured alcohol after
>draining the current old cruft.  Then use new fluid.

This is OK if and only if you are going to disassemble the parts and get
all the alcohol out of there too.  It's a good thing to do if you are 
switching
between glycol and silicone.  However, if you're just cleaning out nasty
old glycol, I would rather just flush new glycol through.

I don't think that alcohol has any magic cleansing properties.  If things 
are
really bad enough on the '66, it would be prudent to rebuild the callipers
and MC, replace the rubber hoses, and check all the metal lines for
damage and corrosion.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 95 18:12:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Do all '89 911C4's leak oil?


Scott,

They don't all leak, but a bunch do and PCNA is aware of the problem.
The solution calls for replacing all the cylinders and refacing the
cylinder heads.  See tech bulletin book I, group 1, number 9202,
dated 28 April 1992.  They are warranteeing the work, but to my
knowledge there is no recall or service action campaign.

BTW, Stan, the leaking is indeed apparently showing up at the
cylinder to head interface.  No idea why or what is in fact wrong with
the engines -- I'm curious to know.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 95 18:34:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Grease and Torques Settings


Pat,

This is true -- with lubrication, you need less shear stress (torque) to
establish what you really want, which is tension stress.

However, to my experience torque values are invariably called out
taking into consideration the kind of lubricant being used.  For example,
conn rod bolt torque is spec'ed given that the bolts are coated with
engine oil.  Ditto for lug nuts: your car comes from Porsche with anti-
seize on the lug bolts, and the 96 ftlb spec is correct.

Replating fasteners will affect torque because of the different
interference fit.  Simplest thing is to not use re-plated fasteners on
a car you plan ti actually drive.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 95 19:21:29 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Belt Tension Intervals

>     Rule of thumb is:
>     1) Replace Belts.
>     
>     2) Re-adjust belts at 1500 miles.
>     
>     3) Re-adjust belts at 15000 miles.
> 
> George, what about those of us who own MY87+ cars with the automatic tensione
r?
> Should we at least check the belts at the intervals you give above?
> 

Hi, Tracy,

Let me clear up one thing about the MY87+ cars with the built-in tensioner:

The tensioner does not provide a continuous adjustment.  It is used at the
time of the initial installation of the belt and at further maintenance
activities. Once the timing belt tension is set, the adjustment is locked
down and remains that way until the tensioner is loosened.

In light of that consideration, and in light of the fact that the balance
shaft belt does not have the benefit of an automatic adjuster, I would
follow the above recommendation...

Good luck
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 95 16:44:44 PST

>Full Face

>White
>Large (7 3/8 - 7 1/2)
>
>Purchased three years ago and used only a few times (probably fewer than five
>events). It looks very near new. 
>
>Price: $125 plus shipping.
>
>Bob Pentecost
>bpenteco@aol.com
>Silver Sage Region
>'83 944

Sorry Bob, but I just have to throw my two cents in about this.

Remember the line about buying a $10.00 helmet if you've got a $10.00
head?  The same line of thinking goes for used helmets.

Two problems with used helmets:

  1)	The lining (styrofoam) dries out in a couple of years, making
	the helmet useless.  Three years is about the life span of
	a helmet.

  2)	Helmets are "use once and discard" items.  The very first time
	you say to yourself "Darn, I'm glad I had a helmet on", THROW
	IT AWAY AND GET A NEW ONE!  It now has a gazillion tiny little
	cracks in it, and probably won't work next time.

Helmets are cheap; heads are not.

Gary.

All 2.7 had engine head stud problem unless the engine has been rebuilt 
with the Devailer (spelling)head studs,  then YOU will have to rebuild 
it.

The 2.7 after being rebuilt correctly is OK> Thats what is in my 74 
Carrera. Runs just fine now.

When buying any Porsche ALWAYS have it cked out before you buy it. Have 
this done by a good independent Porsch Mech. It will cost apprx $200 and 
is well worth it. Plus the list of things will give you baraining power.

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 1995 20:26:24 -0500
From: Drive951@aol.com
Subject: 951 brake problem

Knowledgeable enthusiasts,

I am having trouble with the brakes on my 1986 951.  I would describe the
problem as "major brake fade".  Under all types of braking, the car initially
brakes hard, and then seems to continue decelerating at a constant/linear
rate rather than an increasing rate of deceleration.  Actually, it seems as
if the car decelerates less and less.  Eighteen wheelers can brake more
quickly than my car right now!

I have new rotors all around, a new (less than six months) master cylinder,
new brake lines, and meaty Cool Carbon brake pads (I don't mind the
squeaking, so I leave them on for the street...).  

My mechanic has sweated over this and thinks it may be the proportioning
valve.  Could this be it?  Any advice is appreciated!  I have a track event
in less than two weeks and would look forward to it more if my brakes were
100%.

Personal mail to: Drive951@aol.com would be fine, if preferred.

Thanks,
Charlie Boyer
Drive951@aol.com
1986 944 Turbo

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 1995 21:53:18 -0500 (EST)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: Partswashers & fluid

When I worked an outage at WNP2, a BWR nuclear power plant at Hanford
Energy Reservation in Washington state, we used Simple Green to remove
the protective coating on all our OEM replacement parts.  The chemistry
people there were real picky about what we used but finally qualified it
for use outside reactor areas.  I bought it directly from the Washington state
supplier for about $450.00/55g.  We ran it through parts cleaners we rented
through the Safety Kleen people without ill effects.  The Simple Green people
can fix you up with the MSDS and standard promotional blurbs.


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com

- ---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sun, 19 Mar 1995 17:40:38 -0600 (CST)
From: David R. Duffield <dduffiel@ozarks>
To: Mark Hatch <mhatch@utg.org>
Subject: Re: 73.5 911 Seat Interchangability with other porsches(944, etc.)?

Hey Mark,

I tried to reply to you the other nite but got interrupted.  Probably all 
of the 911 seats that bolt flat on the floor will probably interchange.  

I do know that the mid '70s-'80s Accessory recaros used slide mounts that 
replaced the slides that came on the seats as delivered.  My '70 and my 
'74 use the same seat mounting arrangements. That should be a clue to you.
 
I have mounted a set of LX seats in the '70.  The seats came out of a 
Rabbit.  A couple of chunks of angle iron and a little welding got the 
seats in there just right. 

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy

Ok, here's my response:

Dave:

If, by "heresy", you mean "An opinion or doctrine contrary to church 
dogma" [Webster's 9th New Collegiate Dictionary, Unabridged], then I 
agree...  My recommendation was based on fact, not "religious" 
propoganda.

Taka:

I guess I should respond to each of your points.

	1.  Yes, this is Porschephiles.

	2.  Yes, the MR2 was improved in 1993.  '93 MR2 Turbos are 	
	outside Tim's budget.

	3.  If there were a Porsche in his price range that competed 	
	with the MR2 Turbo, I'd recommend it.  Since there isn't, I 	
	recommended the Toyota.  By the way, Bill Gates (who apparently 
	so fascinates you people that you've filled the list with 	
	stories about him) drives a Toyota (well, a Lexus... same thing) 
	every day.

	4.  Yes, 911s look goofy.  The headlights and fenders have 	
	just recently changed after 30 years, the wing windows still 	
	haven't, and that "widow's peak" where the roofline meets the 	
	windshield is just plain bizarre.  The rear end comes to a 	
	point, making the car look a little like a cockroach, and the 	
	new active rear spoilers look ridiculous.

	5.  Yes, new MR2 Turbos do cost about $30K.  Like any car, 	
	though, good examples can be had cheaply if you're willing to 	
	spend some time looking.  Actually, $14K is a more reasonable 	
	estimate for a '92; Tim may have to buy a '91 if he can't swing 
	the extra cash.

	6.  I have no idea what a used 951 costs.  If they can be 	
	purchased for $12K, Tim may want to look into buying one.  	
	However, his original post mentioned that his friends were 	
	recommending against buying a "wanna-be, mall-driving sports 	
	car".

	7.  I should know better than to try reasoning with someone 	
	whose signature looks like a compilation of "Robb Report" 	
	advertisers...

 -Andy

Porsche, Koni, Yokohama, Autopower, TRW, Bell, Valentine, Tektronix, 
AMD, Sony, Counterpoint, NHT, Cardas, Volant, Raichle, Cartier, Armani, 
Zero Halliburton, Ferragamo, Dunhill... and Toyota.  So there.

WHAT?!!!

I think that the 911 is beautiful.  Goofy no, Distinguished yes!  After

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 19 Mar 1995 23:12:32 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: Blind Brand Loyalty (was "Decisions, Decisions")

Jason Jorgenson (ycr418@freenet.mb.ca) read my "goofy 911" message and 
screamed: 

>WHAT?!!!
>
>I think that the 911 is beautiful.  Goofy no, Distinguished yes!  After 
>all where would Porsche be today without the 911?

Jason:

Granted, the 911 is a great car.  If it weren't, I wouldn't have gone to 
all the trouble to transplant $20K of 911 parts onto my 914.

It may even be the best sports car ever; its 30-year life certainly 
makes it the oldest, and that says a lot about the genius of its 
designers.

"Distinguished," though?  I don't think so.  While the car has a 
distinguished history, the design just looks old-fashioned.  If Porsche 
had never built a 911, and Hyundai unveiled a car with the same body 
style today, people would laugh.  It's only the mystique of the Porsche 
flagship, and the association with the long history of 911 racing 
victories, that makes the design even acceptable today.

Don't get me wrong... I wouldn't want Porsche to change the essential 
911 styling cues.  Making the car's styling fit the currently-accepted 
norm would be sorta stupid.  All I'm saying is that the car's styling 
was weird in 1965 (even the famous Fuchs five-spoke alloys were 
ridiculed when they were first introduced -- Bruce Anderson quotes a 
friend of his as likening them to the wheels of a circus bandwagon), and 
it's still just as weird today (and showing its age, besides).

 -Andy


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Porschephiles #1252                         Mon Mar 20 11:41:32 CST 1995
Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 08:42:54 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: 911 hire in europe


Ref hiring a 911 in europe

Hertz definitely do not hire porsches

Other major companies may but it is unlikely

A few years ago a friends wife hired my friend a 911 turbo for the day to 
celebrate his 30th birthday - this was around 1986 and it cost 200 pounds 
for the day.

I think they hired from a small specialist shop - the kind of place that 
hire rollers for weddings etc

The going rate for car hire is around 30 pounds/day in the 
UK/France/germany for the very small cars 50 for a reasonable size 4 seater

Spain is a bit cheaper, Greece and is the most expensive

BTW in the UK we get around 5k car related deaths a year among 15 million 
drivers, in Greece and Portugal they get around 25k deaths a year among 
less than 5 million drivers, so as you can guess the chances of taking a 
dent is very high in these countries - every time I have hired in spain, 
the car has always been scraped. Most of these countries do not offer CDW 
options, a dent is highly likely.



+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 10:01:01 +0100
From: Christopher Hegarty <chh@esec.ch>
Subject: 911 development plans -> 996


The German magazine "Auto Zeitung" has an article in the 11th March
1995 issue about Porsche's development plans for the 911. I have
no idea how accurate this info really is.

The main points they make:

+  The 1996 911 will have 285 HP (instead of 272) thanks to detail
   improvements

+  At the end of 1995 a new turbo-look C4 will appear.

+  At the 1995 IAA Porsche will present a new Targa, "based on the cabriolet
   with an electric glass roof," literally translated from the German.

+  The once-planned entry-level 911 with 240 HP won't be produced

+  The new (996) model of the 911 will be available in August 1997, first
   as C2 coupe, later as C4 and cabriolet.  Main points:

	* The new 911 and the Boxster (boxster is for summer 1996 release)
	  will have an identical chassis (at least the front half of the
	  car) although of course Porsche wants the cars to look
	  very different.

	* The car will be completely freshly designed "from the ground up,"
	  although the suspension of the 996/986 will be based on the 
	  current 993 suspension. Porsche plans to introduce adaptive
	  (active?) damping, and the brakes and tyres should be improved
	  from the 993.

	* The boxer will finally be water cooled, 4 valves per cylinder.
	  This is a completely new engine, smaller and more efficient.
	  Also quieter (alas). Planned is 3.3l, 275 PS. 

	* The car should be somewhat faster that the 993: lighter and
	  less wind resistance.

	* New tiptronic will be offered, with six gears.  Maybe this
	  is a manual box with an automatic clutch?  Tiptronic will
	  also be offered on the C4 and turbo for the first time.

	* The car is flatter, wider and longer that the 993.  More
	  interior and luggage space.  Safety features to include
	  side airbags.

	* The car will be cheaper to produce.  Apparently the Porsche 
	  marketing heinies are debating whether they want to make the
	  base car cheaper or if they want to offer more standard
	  features for the same price.

Chris

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 05:11:01 -0600 (CST)
From: "David J. Christiano" <dchris01@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Factory tour report

It's 4 am and I'm wide awake having returned from Frankfurt yesterday. 
Our trip began in cold, rainy Stuttgart where the US$ is a poor cousin to 
the DM. The exchange rate was down to 1.39 at the numerous (greedy) money 
changers.
Even with a fair knowledge of German, buying an S-Bahn ticket at the 
Stuttgart HBf (train station) is confusing. Find a friendly local to help 
you use the machines and show you how to validate your ticket in the 
punching machine.
The guide spoke excellent English, but was not the best informed on 
Porsche's corporate strategy. Nevertheless, one can glean lots of info by 
observing what's to be seen on the factory floor (recognizing this is the 
production factory, not the Weissach R&D center.) He said 40% of the new 
cars were cabs, though my observation didn't seem to bear this out. 6,000 
Boxter orders have been taken and they are converting the 928 "assembly 
line" into a universal line which will build the Boxters or anything else 
for that matter. The guide said "they" were still making changes to the 
Boxter now, but he was clearly not well informed.
I did spot 2 or 3 flat six twin turbo motors off to one side that seemed 
to be fairly complete. Carefully observing the engine assembly, I noted 
the new twin plug motors have no external tensioner piping, and a welcome 
redesign of the bolting ini of the rocker arm shafts. These are probably 
old hat to those of you who have newer mechanicals than me.
As far as a motorcycle, all I saw were many posters of Harleys and 
several items regarding cooperation between H-D and Porsche on 
engineering issues.
The factory tour is highly recommended with a visit to the small but 
interesting on-site Museum. If you are flying into Frankfurt, you can 
catch a train directly to Stuttgart from the airport, or take the S-Bahn 
(commuter train) from the airport to Frankfurt. From there it's about an 
hour and a half to Stuttgart on an Inter-City-Express that cruises at 250 
kph.
The wife and I EuRailed around Europe (this was my second EuRail pass). 
It's a great way to go and if you take a French TGV you will go faster on 
the ground than any production Porsche (sustained 300 kph). (You can't 
blame the Germans. It's much flatter in France and easier to go faster)
If you have any questions on EuRail passes, write me an E-mail.

Dave Christiano, Springfield, Missouri
1974 914/6 3.0 liter
1976 911S (soon to be for sale)
1986 930 (soon to be on the road)

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 08:28:52 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 951 brake problem

> Knowledgeable enthusiasts,
> 
> I am having trouble with the brakes on my 1986 951.  I would describe the
> problem as "major brake fade".  Under all types of braking, the car initially
> brakes hard, and then seems to continue decelerating at a constant/linear
> rate rather than an increasing rate of deceleration.  Actually, it seems as
> if the car decelerates less and less.  Eighteen wheelers can brake more
> quickly than my car right now!
> 
> I have new rotors all around, a new (less than six months) master cylinder,
> new brake lines, and meaty Cool Carbon brake pads (I don't mind the
> squeaking, so I leave them on for the street...).  
> 
> My mechanic has sweated over this and thinks it may be the proportioning
> valve.  Could this be it?  Any advice is appreciated!  I have a track event
> in less than two weeks and would look forward to it more if my brakes were
> 100%.
> 

Hi, Charlie,

Most likely problem is not the proportioning valve, but if you wish, you can
try installing a new one (see the archives for the more appropriate valve
from the 928) or you can just put in a straight line for no reduction in the
pressure to the rear wheels at all.

I would replace the front pads to see if you have not cured them properly.
After all, you're going to need ones sooner or later, why not buy them now 
and see if that is causing your problem...

That is the most likely cause of your problem. (I know, I almost hit a
semi-trailer when it pulled into my lane on the freeway and I couldn't slow
down...) Badly cured trick pads are worse than well cured stock pads...

Good luck,
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 08:38:16 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; 911 dash in 914

 >Subject: 911 Dash in 914

>P-filers,
>In the last European Car there is a reader's letter regarding a highly
>modified and alas, crashed 914. One of the items mentioned was a Getty-design
>911 dash. Can 911 dashes be modified to fit a 914 ? What is a Getty-design
>dash ?

>Bart D

   Bart, Getty Engineering makes the "911 dash," it is a fiberglass (?)
  model of the 911 pod, meant to replace the 914 layout. It takes the
  standard 911 gauges, and comes available covered in either leather or vinyl.
    Getty also makes 959 copies, apparently they were one of the first
  to get the 959 "right." I think they are in the LA area, maybe even
  Huntington Beach...

   To me, the best things about a 911 are its door handles and its dash....
  No car I've ever been in betters the 911 design...

         -Lee A.

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 09:40:27 -0500 (EST)
From: qhq2227@dcro2.dcro.dla.mil (Larry Dunlap)
Subject: Re: 944 O.E. Alarm Switch

George,

Hey got the lug nuts and the centercaps, thanks!  I will get a check out
today for what I owe you....

As for the alarm switch problem,

The factory alarm switch, is kinda, sorta, repairable.  We had one seized,
on a friends 944.  The key wouldn't turn on his at all.  We didn't know
any better, so we we took the switch out of the car and took the wires
off the switch (good move, trips the alarm) but if you have someone hold
the wires together the alarm shuts off.  Anyway, we took a knife and cut
open the back of the plastic housing, and it was rather easy to get the
lock out.  So we greased up the lock real good, put it back together and
it has worked fine ever since.  (I should point out that there is a small
circuit board inside the thing, so be careful not to damage it.  I also
visually inspected it to make sure nothing was "burned" out on it).  When
we put it together, we superglued the back on, then wrapped it up in some 
electrical tape.  The operation took about 20 minutes.  Hope this helps....

                                                -Larry


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 09:46:12 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: RE: Chrome Cleaning



>From my experience, if Semichrome polish and a little 0000 steel
>wool won't remove your black spots, then they are pits and 
>permanent. JMB

That's Happich Simichrome. There's another metal polish that is
exactly the same as far as I can tell, by Hohn & Hohn GmbH, 
called Wenol. It comes in 100ml tubes and it's quite a bit less
expensive. I don't remember who the distributor was for mine,
but it's imported by SCI, Cuisine International in Camarillo, CA.

Great Stuff!

Reid (reid_zeigler@merck.com)

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 07:12:31 -0800
From: davesens@rain.org (Dave Sens)
Subject: Re: Blind Brand Loyalty (was "Decisions, Decisions")

>If, by "heresy", you mean "An opinion or doctrine contrary to church
>dogma" [Webster's 9th New Collegiate Dictionary, Unabridged], then I
>agree...  My recommendation was based on fact, not "religious"
>propoganda.

On Porschephiles you may truly be regarded as a heretic since many Porsche
owners consider ownership a rather religous experience.  Despite your good
intentions while recommending the MR2 Turbo, you have to expect a strong
response when publicly posting such a recommendation on our list.  This is
particularly true when you disparage the very automobile for which this
list serves.

My recommendation would have been not to purchase a Porsche too.  Anywone
who has to scrimp to buy a Porsche will only regret it in the future.
Porsches *are* expensive to own and maintain and I believe that trying to
buy one on a budget is potentially troublesome.

But (and this begins my "religous dogma"), the 911 is a wonderful car to
own and drive.  It's lines even after 30 years are sexy and seductive, at
least to me and to many others.  It handles well when well driven and it
rewards perfection. It sounds wonderful. When properly maintained, it (at
least mine) is extremely reliable.  I can think of no other car that I'd
rather own. No other marque provides me with this level of satisfaction and
pleasure though there are many that I would own for other reasons.

Yeah, I guess it is a religous experience.

One last thing, your comment:

>By the way, Bill Gates (who apparently so fascinates you people. . .

By refering to the list members as "you people" you have aparently excluded
yourself.

Regards,

Dave Sens
Santa Barbara, California
'71 911T Coupe

Date: 20 Mar 95 11:32:00 EST
From: "LOGISX::GIBBS" <GIBBS%LOGISX.decnet@vaxa.acdnj.itt.com>
Subject: 944 Wheel Bearings

Well, with the early spring we're having, this was the weekend to get baby (an 
'84 944) out of hibernation.  This mainly consisted of doing all the preventive
maintenance that I said I would do over the winter, but didn't.

Among the items on my list, was repacking the front wheel bearings.  I was more
than a little nervous about this, as it was my first time.  It went pretty well, 
but I've got a couple questions for the net.

The biggest problem I had was in getting the seals out.  The Haynes book says to
carefully pry them out with a screwdriver.  Carefully didn't do squat, so I 
did it somewhat less carefully, and did finally get them out.  Is there a tool 
available for this, and if so, where can I get it?

Since I was less than careful, I wound up with some gouges on the inside of the
hub, both where the seal sits and on the chamfered area between the seal and the
actual bearing race (the bearing race itself is fine).  I smoothed them out 
as best as I could with 220 grit sandpaper, so there is no protruding metal, but
there are still some depressions left in the metal (none of which extend past the 
seal).  Is this a problem, as long as it's not on the actual bearing race?  My gut 
feeling is no, but I'd like to get some other opinions.

Finally, I followed the Haynes instructions on tightening the nut until the thrust
washer can just be moved with a screwdriver (what I actually did was to tighten it
until the nut couldn't be moved, then backed off until it could just be moved).  I
am still nervous about the setting though, as I have never seen it done and know this 
is kinda tricky.  Could anyone offer any suggestions to help me determine if I did it 
right (other than drive it and see if the wheels come off).

The wheels do turn smoothly, except for some slight caliper drag.  I took it out for
a short drive, and all seemed well, and I felt the wheels when I got home, and they
didn't seem excessively warm.  I'm probably just worrying too much, but this is the
first time I've done this, and I'm not overly impressed with my own mechanical
ability, so any advice, suggestions, good or bad news would be appreciated.

Ed Gibbs
gibbs@avionics.itt.com
'84 944, Guards Red, All Mine

> washer can just be moved with a screwdriver (what I actually did was to tighten it
> until the nut couldn't be moved, then backed off until it could just be moved).  I
> am still nervous about the setting though, as I have never seen it done and know this 
> is kinda tricky.  Could anyone offer any suggestions to help me determine if I did it 
> right (other than drive it and see if the wheels come off).
> 

I found the Haynes technique gave way too loose a setting. The method I 
used was to bolt on the spare tire when checking for play. It allowed for 
more leverage when pushing/pulling the top and bottom of the wheel when 
checking for free play. Also, the hole in the middle allowed for access 
to adjust the nut with the spare bolted on. One thing I found was that 
you had to be careful not to confuse the bearing play with the play where 
that shock absorber shaft enters the strut.
 
After a high speed test drive, I checked it by feeling the hub through 
the 'phone dial' holes. This time, be careful not to confuse the 
warmth/heat produced by braking with any heat from the bearings.
 
Anyone, correct me if I'm wrong.
 
Joe '86 944

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 9:39:02 PST
From: "David O. Blanchard" <blanch@capella.cup.hp.com>
Subject: Re: Porsche Insurance

After all the venting about the terrible insurance companies, I 
think a bit of balance is due.  I personally know of at least six 
people who have taken their expensive toys to a time trial 
(laughingly described as "drivers education") and turned them into 
ugly little balls of twisted Porsche parts.  They then turned around 
and collected from their insurance agencies for repairs or 
replacement.   Personally, I would like to think I would be too 
ashamed to do something like that, but then I never created one of 
those little balls.

Another factor to consider is that when a Porsche gets pranged, the 
owner often has the audacity to insist that it get fixed up good as 
new.  Well, in the normal repair biz, this is an anomoly.  Most 
folks will accept "good enough for government work" standards.  The 
insurance companies have this factored into their rates and get 
upset at the deviants.  Would you want to insure one of you picky 
perfectionists at the same rate per $1000 value as a Yugo?

It all adds up.  A way to keep you rates low is to accept the risk 
of collision yourself.  That is, only pay for the liability and 
uninsured driver insurance.  This only works if you are not making 
payments.  It can also keep you very attentive to the business at 
hand on the race track.

David O. Blanchard - Hewlett Packard 
                     Odapter Business Development Manager
Phone: (408) 447-7275   Fax: (408) 447-0956
EMail: blanch@cup.hp.com    
- -------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 13:00:09 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)

> Another factor to consider is that when a Porsche gets pranged, the

Then most folks are stupid, but you already knew that.
When somebody prangs my car (happens FAR too often - I live
in Massachusetts, after all) they are responsible for making
the car as good as it was before they hit it. I don't give
a flying **** at a rolling Yoko whether they pay for it or
their insurance pays for it, they have to make good, 100%,
on the damage they did. And if they aren't willing, my atty.
is on retainer. If I damage my own car, I fix it myself or I
pay to get it fixed right. "Good enough", as far as I'm concerned,
means perfect. And it doesn't make any difference if it's my
Porsche (HA! That would be the day, wouldn't it?) or my Toyota.

> The insurance companies have this factored into their rates and get 
> upset at the deviants.

I think you have this backwards. It's the insurance companies that are
deviant, not me... I pay good money for coverage, and I insist on 100%
value for my money.

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 12:35:48 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 944 Wheel Bearings

>I found the Haynes technique gave way too loose a setting.

        I'm not sure on the 944 wheel bearings, but it sounds like
they're adjusted like 914 bearings.
        So the idea is to tighten up the nut until the washer can
*just barely* be moved.  If you can simply push the washer around,
it's too loose.  If you can just barely slide it by (Dave puts Nomex
on) prying with a screwdriver, then it's right.  Now, by "prying"
I mean putting a wide-ish screwdriver blade in and twisting so that
one side of the blade is against a raised part of the hub/whatever
and the other side is against the washer.
        You can check by grabbing the top and bottom of the wheel
or the brake disk and wiggling back and forth.  You should feel a
very slight movement and "clunk".  Very slight is good.  No play may
mean that they're too tight, which can be very bad.  Better a little
loose than a little too tight.  Then you should drive on it for a
while (How long?  Dunno.) and then check the play again.

My $00.02

- --DD

"No cones, no cones..."    ____--/~|___\_____.      _____
                          (  _             _  >    |_____|___|__/____|_
Dave Darling               ~' `~~~~~~~~~~~' `~      _____|   |       |
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov `~'           `~'

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 14:04:34 -0500
From: Dave Hempstead <hempsd@hpangrt.an.hp.com>
Subject: Renting in Europe

I looked into renting a porsche in europe 10 years ago.  (yes, it's
been a long time, but I checked into it).  My 944 here in the states
was 1 year old, and I longed to try a P-car out on the Autobahn.

Also, management at work knew of my longing, and agreed to pay for the
rental on my next trip over (since I didn't have enough lead time to
set it up the first time).  Unfortunately, that was my one and only
trip over with that management team.  

Anyway, I found 2 companies in Panorama which would rent Porsches.  
One was in Frankfurt, and the other was, Ithink, in Munich.

The going rate was ~1200 dollars per week (in 1985).  I don't know
what the price is now.  I think that was for a 911.  That price
was just a little too steep for my bank account (although the
Opel Vectra I rented was nearly 400 dollars for the week).

Sorry I don't have the company name, but they did advertise in Pano

Dave Hempstead
84-944  Platinum

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 12:51:51 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Ideas for hot-rodding my 914-4?

>>       My personal toy is my 1972 Porsche 914-4 l-jet which is in
>>perfect tune.

        A 72 with L-jet?  The flapper-box FI from the 1.8L?  (74-75)
Is that a complete engine transplant, just the FI, or a typo?

>Beef up the suspension with 140 lbs. springs in the back.
>        Any other suggestions out there?  I have VERY firm suspension as
>it is, spine-crunching even!

        You might go to progressive-rate springs.  They go from 100 #
at low excursion to 160 # at high excursion.  Also, try wide low-profile
tires--I love my 195/50-15s.  If you wanna really hang onto the road,
get R compound tires, like A008RS2's or Comp T/A R1s.  (BFGs are the
current "hot ticket".)  Lower and corner-balance the car.  Don't lower
it all the way to the ground, though!
        If you get bigger springs in back, larger front torsion bars may
be a good way to go.
        Try a larger front sway-bar.  Word out at the autoX course is
that the rear bar is not recommended except for a totally-stock setup.
        Headers and/or an SS exhaust can get you a little bit of power.
        Finally, the cheapest, best-value, and all-aroud best go-fast
goodie that you can possibly get is:  Driver education.  Go to an autoX
school, or even just an autoX.  Go to a Driver Education event at a real
racetrack.  Unless you're *really* flexible, it's the most fun you can
have in a 914, period.  And you get to see exactly how far you can push
your car, in a *safe* environment!

- --DD

"No cones, no cones..."    ____--/~|___\_____.      _____
                          (  _             _  >    |_____|___|__/____|_
Dave Darling               ~' `~~~~~~~~~~~' `~      _____|   |       |
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov `~'           `~'



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 11:14:34 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Anti-sieze Compunds.


Unless directed by the Porsche shop manual to do so, do not use anti-
sieze compounds on Porsche engine, transmission or other components.
There was a service bulletin on spark plugs and anti-sieze in water 
cooled aluminum heads backing out if anti-sieze was used. 

One place you are DIRECTED to do so is on 944 and 928 head bolts and 
nuts, you are directed to only use light oil in this instance. 

The Porsche Technical Specification for your model Porsche has many of
these tips in its pages. These books are about $11 and should be 
considered as a required object for any and all Porsche owners.

For 928 owners, these books are surprisingly detailed, still not a
substitute for the shop manuals, but many critical pieces of information
about your car are in those pages.

For all technical spec, order from a dealer and ask for the one for your
specific year and model Porsche.

I did get mine from Automotion, they carry the entire line of Tech Specs.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 14:17:27 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: Blind Brand Loyalty (was "Decisions, Decisions")

>My recommendation would have been not to purchase a Porsche too.  
>Anywone who has to scrimp to buy a Porsche will only regret it in the 
>future.  Porsches *are* expensive to own and maintain and I believe 
>that trying to buy one on a budget is potentially troublesome.

I have a problem with this perspective. I expect that most of us on this
list need to do at least some budgeting, in terms of choosing what is
most important to do with limited money (although that level of money
will also vary). If you are not in any way limited by money, please do 
not respond. It will only depress the rest of us. 

The real issue in my mind is that if you have to ask this group if you
should buy a Porsche or something else, then you don't want a Porsche
badly enough to make the necessary compromises, unless you have something
approaching unlimited money. I see this as a small variation on the old
saying: "if you have to ask (the price), you can't afford it".

The other point to be made, which is partially contained in the above
post, is that even if you want a Porsche so bad you can taste it, buy one
which you have a fighting chance of maintaining, with some combination
of money and time. Don't assume nothing will go wrong.

In case it is not clear, I would also have recommended that this particular
person not buy a Porsche. My comment relates to the more general 
pronouncement made. Of course, those who have no doubt that they really
want a Porsche will ignore it and buy one anyway.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 11:25:36 -0800 (PST)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: Re: 944 Wheel Bearings

On Mon, 20 Mar 1995, Dave Darling wrote:

> >I found the Haynes technique gave way too loose a setting.
> 
>         So the idea is to tighten up the nut until the washer can
> *just barely* be moved.  


IMHO,the washer method is highly inaccurate. First, the smoothness of the
rear surface of the locknut which contacts the washer probably varies
greatly from car to car. Mine was a bit rough. This in turn leads to
varying amounts of force required to shift the washer. Another factor is 
the amount of grease between the washer and locknut which I suspect also 
greatly influences the effort required to move the washer.
 
Just my opinion...

Joe '86 944

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 14:31:36 -0500
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bartonc@annap.infi.net>
Subject: Re: '77 911S

In message <9503201718.AA07274@dividivi> Peter Gregory writes:
> Phellow P-philes:
> 
> Could one of the enlightened ones kindly describe to me under what
> conditions (ie. what's been fixed/changed) one would consider before
> purchasing a basically-stock '77 2.7l 911S Targa?

First, have the entire vehicle inspected by an *independent, *porsche* expert 
(cost around $200) and get a detailed report on the condition of the vehicle.  
This makes an excellent negotiating instrument, and will insure against 
potential disaster.  911s can be horrendously expensive to repair...
 
> Subject vehicle still has stock (not Carrera) tensioners; thermal reactors
> have been removed (smog implications?); 11-blade fan; otherwise stock,
> insofar as I know.

Personally, I'd walk away from any vehicle like you describe, but:

1.  Case should have shuffle pins installed,
2.  Non-dilivar studs should be replaced with dilivar
3.  '84-on Carrera tensioners should re retrofitted.
4.  Replace thermal reactors, or update entire emission control 
(induction/exhaust) system to later vintage, or it'll *never* pass emissions 
inspection.
5.  Price all this work; *then* *walk* away (advice is always worth just what it
costs you...)


------------------------------

Joe -

If this is so inaccurate, what do you recommend?  I have been using this
method for years without a porblem on many different cars that use this
same adjustment.  I don't know of any tool that is available that could
measure what you are looking for.  BTW, most, if not all, shops use this
same method; we all can't be wrong?  It's like anyhting else, after you
have done it a few times you will find it to be accurate and you will be
comfortable with it. 

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 14:09:57 CST
From: ourios@zeus.wustl.edu
Subject: Hiring/Driving a 911 in Europe...


A few weeks ago I said I learned to drive while I was a student in England
and living 7 months of the year in the UK and 5 months in Greece.
I learned traffic-driving in Greece and polite/correct driving in UK.
Then I made a comment that I never had a problem with Boston drivers
(I usually drove there politely, until they tried to be different,
in which case the Bostonians found out they are no match for 
Athenian drivers).

I confirm Peter Diffey's comments that hiring a 911 in Germany is a bit 
expensive, renting any car in Greece is outrageously expensive, and 
that you may get your car dented or worse in certain places in Europe.

In Paris people parallel park by pushing other parked cars front and back
until they have created a new space where there was no space before. 

I am glad I know live in the US, and I would never own a "touch it not"
car in Athens, Paris or downtown Boston. In those places, the 
rustiest car wins at the intersections...

Theo
Theodosios Korakianitis

Subject: Valuation of the 944 Turbo S

Hello George B. and Porschephiles:

I drive a 1988 944 Turbo S.  I'm trying to get an idea what the street 
value of my German "investment" is currently.  I've looked at news papers, 
certain classified car magazines and the NADA blue book.  All of them 
mention the '88 944 Turbo but not the Turbo S.  These publications do, 
however, mention the '89 944 Turbo ('88 Turbo S equivalent) at a 
significant increase in cost; more than is justified by the year 
difference in age.

What I'm asking is "what have you seen an '88 944 Turbo S or 89 944 Turbo 
sell for?"  Your observations will be rolled into other information I've 
gathered that will help me realistically valuate my car.

Many thanks in advance,


Bert

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 13:39:09 -0700 (MST)
From: "Byron D. Short / AFS Inc." <bshort@usa.net>
Subject: Re: 944 Aftermarket Mufflers

 
 I mentioned my 3" straight pipe on my 951 and have generated 4 responses
 about the worthiness of straight pipes.  Two were for, and two were
 against.  Jim Pasha, who is much respected and seems to have a great deal
 of real world knowledge on the subject, feels the pipe is not likely to
 increase power, and that the stock muffler produces *very* little
 restriction.  Neil Walker insists that these kind of changes produce more
 power in a very narrow band, and less power everywhere else due to
 "resonance power", or the "megaphone effect" or something like that. 
 OTOH, Le Triet, who asked the original question which started this thread,
 seems for, but only based on my assertion that it should be better.  Jay
 Ellis has done about the same thing I have for his 951 and reports much
 improved torque on the track compared to 951S at Summit Point. 
 
 Of all these opinions, including my own, only one is track specific for 
 951's, or at least indicates that.  
 
 I've heard many, many folks say that the stock mufflers are so good that
 nothing else, including a straight pipe will do better.  But wait.  Why 
 did the factory Turbo Cup cars have a different muffler, as indicated in
 Jay Ellis' post?  Hmm. 
 
 Here's my theory:

 Engines are air pumps.  The easier the air goes in and out, the higher the
 efficiency of the pump.  A secondary effect however, is the mass flow of
 air down the exhaust can produce a flow effect which helps to scavenge the
 cylinder before the piston begins to come up and force the exhaust out. 
 This effect can be pretty beneficial and is perhaps best illustrated by
 the concept of longer intake runners employed on many high performance
 cars (although on the opposite side of the cylinder)--the air rushes
 through the pipe as a large mass which has a tendency to maintain speed. 
 Of course, it's the exhaust pipe which harnesses this flow, not the
 muffler. 
  
 The two other factors, of course, are weight and sound.  A straight pipe 
 probably saves on the order of 40 pounds.  And the sound is such that 
 it's easier to hear when the car is beginning to rev a little too freely, 
 indicating more wheel spin than you might want.  (Of course, with LSD, 
 you typically feel wheelspin as a lateral force.  Even so, I still 
 like the sound to reinforce the feeling.) 
 
 So what's best?  I dunno for sure.  I believe in the straight pipe for
 many reasons, but Pasha's concerns about the DME are interesting.  It
 might be a good idea to take the two pipes on my 944 S2 and compare
 with a g-analyzer.  (I've moved the exhaust onto my S2.)  Use say a second
 gear test from steady state throttle at 2000 rpm up to redline, best of
 three tests, to see which is best.  This is also a good test for airfilter
 performance.  Since K&N offers no filter for the S2, I've custom built one
 which I believe will give higher flow, at the expense of getting dirty
 much quicker.  (It's a race car, I'll just have to clean and/or replace
 more often.) I'll post the results when I'm done. 

- -- 
                   *****************************************************
Byron Short        *      Call me at the office--if I had wanted       *
                   *   to do real work, I'd have gotten a real job!    *
90 944 S2          *        (719) 531-9511     bshort@usa.net          *
87 951 (4 Sale)    *  "I made this letter longer than usual because I  *
                   *    lack the time to make it shorter." -- Pascal   *
                   *****************************************************

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 16:04:22 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Front Seat

> I own a 1986 944.  The previous owner's kid carved some stars out of the seat
> fabric. (Obviously people who didn't deserve the car).  Anyway, only the
> fabric is damaged, all leather trim is intact.  This is a high back (sport? I
> think) seat - no power.  My question, is it possible to just replace the
> fabric?  Do I have to replace the entire seat cover?  Is it better to replace
> the whole seat with a used one - given the age of the car and the faded
> fabric in the rest of the car?  Any help you can give would be greatly
> appreciated.  Thanks.

Hello, LTDES,

BTW, did you AOLers know that you can type your real name so we can know
who these cryptic userids translate to... :-)

Anyhow, you might be able to buy the cover for the seat bottom. But probably
not.  I did look at the price list for a couple and the fabric itself for
the bottom only came to a whopping $323.  

My advice is to locate a good seat at a swap meet that might be a good donor
of material, or just a replacement...

You might be able to find a perfect match.

In the meantime, you might consider some SeatSavers (if they are still made,
anyone know?).  I had a 1980 Scirocco with some fabric seats that the left
side bottom bolster wore out on and used the products.  They were real good
at hiding the problem...

Good luck...

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 16:13:41 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Valuation of the 944 Turbo S

Hi, Bert,

> What I'm asking is "what have you seen an '88 944 Turbo S or 89 944 Turbo 
> sell for?"  Your observations will be rolled into other information I've 
> gathered that will help me realistically valuate my car.
> 

Well, of course, value is determined by a couple of factors, among them,
supply, demand, condition, history, options, availability of maintenance
records, color and the size of the wallet of the prospective purchaser :-)

That having been said, I have seen a 1988 Turbo S, 40 K miles, white with
Burgundy Leather (yes, it was available in late 88 with other than the rose
and plaid), and in excellent condition sell in 1993 for 16K dollars, US.

I have also seen 88 Turbo S cars trade in 1995 for 22K dollars, US. 

That was here in the Northeast USA, where you can drive them for only  6 or
7 months out of the year...

I would guess that your car is worth between 12K and 22K at this time,
depending on the above factors. More detailed information would tend to
narrow down the range of the estimate.

Bert, if you want a closer valuation of what the car is worth up here, send
me something offline with a lot more detail, and I can give you a closer
number.

Later, GB

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 15:04:29 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: 914 Valve Adjust

        One more 914 question/sanity check from this weekend:
The idea behind getting the piston at TDC to do a valve adjust is
to get on the "round" section of the cam--i.e., the part that isn't
calling for any valve opening.  This should also be where the valve
clearance is the greatest, right?
        The reason I'm asking is:  I put #1 at TDC by using the '0'
mark on the fan, and the notch on the flywheel (which, BTW, seem to
be about 0.5-1.0 degrees apart...)  I then checked and adjusted #1.
Rotate the crank 180 degrees; hey!  Paint mark on both fan and fly-
wheel!  Cool!  Did #4 (I think it was), etc.  At one point, I poked
a feeler gauge into a valve gap for a piston not at TDC--the other
valve was depressed.  The gap was bigger, by about .002 or so!  I
re-checked both valves back at TDC, and they were fine!
        Does the stock 914 (2.0) cam go "negative" anywhere?  If not,
what the heck did I do?
        Thanks!

- --DD

"No cones, no cones..."    ____--/~|___\_____.      _____
                          (  _             _  >    |_____|___|__/____|_
Dave Darling               ~' `~~~~~~~~~~~' `~      _____|   |       |
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov `~'           `~'

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 13:27:15 -0800 (PST)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: Re: 944 Wheel Bearings

On Mon, 20 Mar 1995, Mike Lommatzsch wrote:

> If this is so inaccurate (checking washer movement for correct tightness), 
>  what do you recommend?  I have been using this
> method for years without a porblem on many different cars that use this
> same adjustment.  I don't know of any tool that is available that could
> measure what you are looking for.  BTW, most, if not all, shops use this
> same method; we all can't be wrong?  

With experience, I have no doubt that this method will do. However, as a 
beginner I found it difficult to judge the tightness strictly from the 
washer. Therefore, I found the method of feeling for actual play, with a 
tire installed to be more accurate and reassuring.

As for other cars, my old BMW specified a torque for the  castellated nut 
after which you backed it off to the next slot you could insert the 
cotter pin. The procedure for my Mercedes (which has the same nut as my 
Porsche) is a little different. If I recall correctly, you tighten the 
nut until you can no longer move the wheel. Then you unscrew it a certain 
number of degrees and tighten the allen screw. Finally you give the hub a 
sharp whack to release the tension.
 
As for what 'shops do', after seeing the work some of them have done 
for me (or done to me?) in the past, I've come to question some of their 
methods and practices. Of course, this is not to say there aren't good 
shops out there but they seem to be the minority.

Joe '86 944

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 13:57:10 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: 911 Dash in a 914

Lee Atkinson (Lee=Atkinson%Port=Perf%Port=Hou@bangate.compaq.com) wrote:

>Getty Engineering makes the "911 dash," it is a fiberglass (?) model of 
>the 911 pod, meant to replace the 914 layout. It takes the standard 911 
>gauges, and comes available covered in either leather or vinyl.

Here's an alternative for those who want to put a full range of gauges 
in their 914:

Call your local highly-respected speedometer shop (I particularly like 
North Hollywood Speedometer) and get them to replace the big red warning 
light in the upper quadrant of the fuel-guage with an oil-temperature 
gauge.  While you're at it, make sure the gauge is calibrated in 
degrees.

Next, have them modify a 911 Turbo tachometer to replace the boost gauge 
with oil-pressure.  It'll take a little recalibration and a new tach 
silkscreen, but the final results are well worth the effort; oil 
pressure will be displayed in the center of your tach, right where you 
can most easily see it.

This whole procedure cost me only a couple hundred dollars through North 
Hollywood; I don't have their phone number handy, but they advertise in 
Pano.

 -Andy


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 14:08:52 -0800 (PST)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: 944 Wheel Bearings

Joe -

As far as shops are concerned, no doubt some of them fail in their 
ability and you just have to find one you like if necessary.  With a 
number of shops around me in the San Francisco bay area, some people 
don't like one but then others just rave about that same shop.  It is up 
to you who you can trust and who you can't.  I haven't heard many (if any 
I can remember) complaints about people loosing wheel bearings/hubs very 
frequently from a shops mis-adjustment.  Maybe this adjustment isn't as 
critical as you are making it.

With regrads to your methods on various other cars, I could sit here and 
find faults with those methods too.  A few come to mind quickly.  Again, 
use what you feel comfortable with.  Yes, the wheel method is what we 
commonly use to tech cars for autocrosses, time trials or drivers events 
only becuase it is simpler.  Realize though, that with the "wheel" you are 
going to feel a little more play then you would see from the 
"screwdriver" because of the leverage/distance you are working with.  Now 
where do you draw the line.  Again, it's a feel you have to just do and 
get use to.  Go out to a drivers event some time and work tech.  You 
would be suprised at the differences from car to car.

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR
SCCA-SFR/RR

much to the list readership at large.

responsibility of becoming a wage-slave to your automobile, you'll also

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 14:33:36 PST
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert H. Albrecht)
Subject: electrical gremlins

        For those of you amused by strange electrical problems - This
weekend I was preparing for a club tour by rigging up a CB in the Targa.  I
haven't used a CB in the 911 before, but the tour leaders are going to use
them to keep track of folks on the road, and since I have a pile of old CBs,
figgured I may as well "have ears on".  So I put a new connector on an old
clip-on antenna, jammed a piece of folded paper into the cigar lighter
alongside the old (smaller diameter) cigar lighter attachment to hold it in
place, and walah, it worked.  The problem is that when I key the mike, the
windshield wipers come on.

        When I finished laughing I, I went to pull the wiper fuse to "solve"
the problem (this is a one-time thing), and found that the cigar lighter,
and wiper circuit share the same fuse.  I guess keying the mike feeds back
into the power circuit and trigger the wiper motor as if you had used the
w/s washer.  I wonder if using the cigar lighter also cycles the wipers
(didn't think to try it).

Bob     '83 SC

Bob Albrecht, San Diego Region
'83 SC Targa, Platinum
'65 SC, Battleship (Dolphin) Grey
Cat named "Mouse"

From: cew@leland.stanford.edu (Carlin E. Wiegner)
Subject: modifications to 944S2....

greetings all.....hope march is going along merrily!

I've put off my 60,000 mile as long as possible (not really that long!) and
I figured I might as well make the spring mods to the car at the same time.

I've chipped the car with a custom chip from the 944S2s in the firehawk
series. I've also added a Bursh exhaust (great addition, really made the
car sound good, as well as giving noticeable better response and better gas
mileage)

I dislike moving part changes like camshafts, compression changes as they
raise the maintenance of the car.

Any ideas? Would a different manifold also improve response time? How about
a bigger anti-sway bar then the stock one for the rear or front? Do you
need to do both at the same time?

I have about $500....Any advice would really be appreciated. Let me know if
you want any more information....
cw

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 17:38:42 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: Andy gives up - was brand loyalty



In poor Andy's defense, there was an interview in Panorama a
few years ago by Porsche's head of design. Can't remember his
name but he was born in Riga Latvia (how's that for useless
selective memory?)  He pissed and moaned quite a bit in the 
article about the "untouchables" in the 911 design, like the
"widows peak" front window line and the rear window lines. He
and others at Porsche had wanted to redesign the car for better
air flow etc. and the "buying public" (like us) wouldn't let
them. He also was very concerned that the cars cost so much,
but lamented that the lower priced cars never went over very well.

Oh well, he was from Latvia, what does he know?


Reid



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 14:48:52 PST
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: 356 rear bearing question.


This is for the 356 guys that were working on the rear bearings.

Over the weekend, I got it into my head that I would change the
rear bearings that the axle go through on my type I VW.  After reading 
up on the procedure, I found that there is a special tool to use with 
fingers that grab the inside of the race and use the end of the axle 
to press against (looked _alot_ like what has been discussed here for the
356 job).  Well, I took the cover off, just to look at the job
anyways.

Once I was looking eye to eye with the bearing, I figgured I would add
some grease to the bearings and worry about the change later.  To add
the grease, I used a greasegun with a needle to put the grease in the
bearing, working my way around the bearing between the rollers.  

Now, here's the importain stuff, as I added the grease, the bearing
started to wiggle its way out.  After a few more pumps, I was able to
remove the bearing by hand.  After cleaning, I found them to be in
good shape, repacked them, and reinstalled them.

So, is there anychance this grease-preasure-removal method will help
any of you 356 people?  I know that my VW is several years newer, but
there still might be a chance that this will help.

Pat
pat@ixi.saic.com

Diagnosed Porschephiliacs,
	I checked on that odd corvair engined 914 and it was only a "4" 
not a "6" as he had hoped.  He said the possibility of it being a six was 
the only reason he didn't get rid of it, the car has few parts valuable 
to a mechanic (weird engine, badly rusted body).  He then asked if I was 
interested in buying it.  He said he'd tow it to my garage for $500.  I 
thought about it for about, oh, 5 seconds and agreed to it.  
	Some of the cool things it has:
                       Five bolt vented discs (need to be turned),  wide 
(don't know exactly) minilite style wheels with polished outers and gold 
painted inners,  crazy looking(??)heavy duty rear suspension that flare  
the wheels out about 5 inches, Koni shocks, nice interior w/ real 
leather seats but cracked dashpad, fiberglass front/rear flares (one fell 
off it was so rusted around it! still have all 4 though), and complete 
(from what I can see) Corvair flat six conversion.  I think the clutch is 
bad, that's probably the reason its in a repair yard.  
	What I need:  I'm going to try to find a 914 with a decent body 
but bad engine/ interior to swap all my stuff into.  Is it worth it or 
did I buy a pile of worthless junk?  I love to tinker with cars, and if 
it's not worth swapping into a good body, I'll just get it running in its 
present rusty shape and have one fast 914 that looks like sh*t.  About 
the 912E, its still sitting in the shop waiting for winter season (lax 
time for mechanics here) to come again so he can chop it.  That STILL

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 15:29:59 -0800 (PST)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: Re: 944 Wheel Bearings

On Mon, 20 Mar 1995, Mike Lommatzsch wrote:

> I haven't heard many (if any 
> I can remember) complaints about people loosing wheel bearings/hubs very 
> frequently from a shops mis-adjustment.  

My comment on shops was meant as a general one on all repairs. For 
example, my local Porsche dealer does not use the P9201 tool for checking 
belt tension. Given that there are probably some mechanics which can do 
it properly by feel, surely not EVERY mechanic at this place which would 
change a 944 belt has that skill. 

Wouldn't it be great if all mechanics worked on their customers' cars 
with the same care and attention they would use on their own car?

> With regrads to your methods on various other cars, I could sit here and 
> find faults with those methods too. 

I'm sure they have faults too. However, those other methods came from the 
Haynes manuals for those cars (which in turn I assume they get from the 
manufacturer).

Like you said, one should use whatever method  they feel most comfortable 
with. But it never hurts to hear other points of views...
 
Joe '86 944

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 18:50:17 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: modifications to 944S2....

> greetings all.....hope march is going along merrily!
> 
> I've put off my 60,000 mile as long as possible (not really that long!) and
> I figured I might as well make the spring mods to the car at the same time.
> 
> I've chipped the car with a custom chip from the 944S2s in the firehawk
> series. I've also added a Bursh exhaust (great addition, really made the
> car sound good, as well as giving noticeable better response and better gas
> mileage)
> 
> I dislike moving part changes like camshafts, compression changes as they
> raise the maintenance of the car.
> 
> Any ideas? Would a different manifold also improve response time? How about
> a bigger anti-sway bar then the stock one for the rear or front? Do you
> need to do both at the same time?
> 
> I have about $500....Any advice would really be appreciated. Let me know if
> you want any more information....
> cw
> 
> 

Since you didn't mention driver education on your list, I cast my vote for 
improving the driver.  $500 would go a long way around here to making your
car F*A*S*T...

Other than that, on your particular car, $500 will not do anything to
measurably improve performance...Leave it alone and modify the primary input
device...

Good luck,
