Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 19:13:12 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: 944 Technical Session - Tech Tactics

If you don't own a 944, stop here...

If you do, I'll pass along a couple of items of interest that came about
during the Zone 1 Tech Tactics, held this past weekend in Springfield, Mass.

Tom Charlesworth, the PCA National Tech Committee Chair for 924/944 cars,
and one of the Stewards for PCA Club Racing, came from Tulsa to cover our
beloved water-cooled autos.

First, he stunned the audience by displaying a broken crankshaft from a 944.
Seems that the clutch's rubber center had come apart and had not been
repaired by the owner for a year or so.  Eventually all the banging in there
caught her attention, and she brought it in. After fixing the clutch, there
was still a noise from the motor. Tom figured it out after moving the
flywheel (front to rear) and not seeing the crank pulleys move.  The shaft
had fractured from the constant knocking on it... Fix your clutches now...

Number 2 rod bearings were covered.  Scared the bejesus out of me. I have
ordered my set and a set of connecting rod bolts to do my job now.  $100 in
parts, should take me about 2-3 hours if I don't have any problems... My
particular concern is that I have about 300 track hours on my 83 and have
never dropped the pan... I'll post a followup to let you know how it goes...

More on #2 Rod Bearings:  Seems that 928 cars with the 4.7 litre motors have
a similar problem. May be a crankshaft design problem, but more study is
being done by the tech committee... Also, the problem seems to be related to 
high engine revs (greater than 6000 rpm) rather than high power output.

Aluminum Control Arms: Still breaking, several suppliers of problem fixes
were mentioned at the meeting (if you want the names, send me your PCA
Membership Number and your email address...:-)

Oil Cooler Failures: Still happening.

Clutch Upgrades: For stock 944s, recommended to continue with rubber center
clutch. For Turbos, upgrade to Turbo Cup Clutch.  For now, stay away from 
carbon fiber clutches (let someone else be the guinea pig...)

CV Joints: clean, repack, and re-orient early, and they will last twice as
long. Let them wear too much before you do the job, and they will knock on
deceleration...

Camshaft Carrier Leaks: The O-ring at the front of the cam swells and
obstructs a drain hole, causing leaks front and rear.  Easy fix...

Cracking Dashes: They all do that...   :-)

Engine Oil: use the stock filter - Porsche filters have a relief valve that
is backwards from most designs.  Good engine oil combination is 50/50 mix of
conventional oil and Mobil 1. (Slipperiest combination).

1986 Turbo Transmissions: 3rd gear is pressed onto the mainshaft and will 
spin (break) on cars with more than stock horsepower. Fix is to replace with
1987 Turbo or later Transmission.

That's all I can remember for now. If I think of something else, I'll post
later...

Good luck,

- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 18:04:25 CST
From: drozt@comm.mot.com (Peter Drozt)
Subject: Maintenance Records


What is everyone's opinion about purchasing a pre-owned 911 which was
bought through an auction and doesn't have any maintenance records and
an unknown history?

Over the weekend, I looked at an '88 Carrera.  It looked good and
drove well, but being a Porsche novice I'm not sure if that means
a lot.  I guess what I want to know is opinions about how important
the history of the car is.  Obviously knowing how the car has been
treated in the past would be helpful in determining how reliable it
will be in the future.  But even as the dealer suggested, maintenance
records can lie.

Would a Porsche mechanic be able to determine how well the car has been
maintained during a pre-purchase inspection?  Is staying away from
a car without any documentation a bit too drastic?  Or am I asking for
trouble without any history?

Thanks...
Peter Drozt
drozt@comm.mot.com

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 16:15:19 -0800

Subject: RE: Blind Brand Loyalty

pfilers,

I can't even believe that I'm responding to this, but I can never
resist the occasional T*d of the month candidates:

Andrew sez, among other things:

> Distinguished," though?  I don't think so.  While the car has a
> distinguished history, the design just looks old-fashioned.  If Porsche
> had never built a 911, and Hyundai unveiled a car with the same body
> style today, people would laugh.  It's only the mystique of the Porsche
> flagship, and the association with the long history of 911 racing
> victories, that makes the design even acceptable today.

Andrew,

Didn't T*d make a career here for a brief while stating his personal
beliefs as *ABSOLUTE*  *UNASSAILABLE* fact?  I am of course interested
in your *opinions* and would probably welcome them as such.

Everyone on the list is fully aware of the 911's complete list of
*features*.  The 911 owners love their 911's in spite of and in some cases
because of those features--some even love their cars because of the way they
*look*.  Of the many reasons not to own a 911 ****IMHO***, they way they look
is not among them.

BTW, I agree, Tim probably shouldn't buy the 911. If you have to ask, then the
answer is no.  Not because he can't afford it--maybe he can. It's just that I
can't imagine "sort of wanting a 911".  Same as you can't be a little bit
pregnant.

I wouldn't buy a 911 with metrics: cost of ownership, price/performance,
0-60,etc. I have never once bought a sports car using any cost-justifiable
criteria. I have never bought one yet that I could actually afford!  I bought
every sports car and motorcycle I've owned because I *had* to have it. End of
story.

Tim, buy a car that makes you smile every time you drive it.  Buy one that you
love so much you don't care if it breaks because it's just another opportunity
to make it better.  If you can't do that, don't buy a sports car!!!

Vol

>Sorry Bob, but I just have to throw my two cents in about this.
>
>Remember the line about buying a $10.00 helmet if you've got a $10.00
>head?  The same line of thinking goes for used helmets.
>
>Two problems with used helmets:
>
>  1)    The lining (styrofoam) dries out in a couple of years, making
>        the helmet useless.  Three years is about the life span of
>        a helmet.
>
>  2)    Helmets are "use once and discard" items.  The very first time
>        you say to yourself "Darn, I'm glad I had a helmet on", THROW
>        IT AWAY AND GET A NEW ONE!  It now has a gazillion tiny little
>        cracks in it, and probably won't work next time.
>
>Helmets are cheap; heads are not.
>
>Gary.
>

problem.

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 21:46:21 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Maintanence costs?

> Hello all,
> 
> 	I am in the market for an 86-89 944, and wanted to trouble y'all with a
> quick question.  I'm trying to determine how much I will need to budget towar
ds
> ongoing maintenance, etc. on the car.  I've heard that the 944 is alot more
> maintanable than the 911 or 928, but still if I could get verification of thi
s
> via quantifiable numbers (ie., rough $/month) from some of you knowledged
> readers, I'd greatly appreciate it.
> 
> 
> -andrew
> 

Plan on costs on the order of $1000 per year and you will probably be safe. 
(If you don't know what "on the order of" means, check with your local
statistician...)

If you maintain the car yourself, then all that you have to worry about are
parts costs, which can run $500 in a good year, $5000 in a bad year. Add the
cost of a mechanic's boat if you do not maintain the car yourself.

There, that should cover it.

BTW, my average cost per year for my 83 944 is $300 per year for maintenance.
Lots of oil, grease, soap and wax. Not many parts...

And, oh, don't forget to budget the $36 per year for the Porsche Club dues,
and your $50 for porschephiles...

Good luck,
- --

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 21:58:56 -0500 (EST)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: Weber carb info

You asked me where I read to set the fuel pressure regulator to 1.5 psi
on my Weber 40 IDFs instead of the recommended 3.0-3.5.

Read?  Am I being accused of reading again?  Well, uh, OK, I admit it, I 
*can* read (don't tell my boss). 

Seriously,

The 1.5 setting comes from experience with T1 VWs in brush buggies.  Lots
of bouncing around over uneven territory tendend to cause "float bounce"
which would increase the fuel level in the bowls to unacceptable levels.
A lower pressure setting *seemed* to ameliorate the problem.  'Course,
could have just been wishful thinking.  Still, my carbs never feel starved
for fuel even at WFO.  

Now, if I could just make those darned velocity stacks work!  (my carbs could
look cool, too!)


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 21:59:25 -0500 (EST)
From: Jan Ringnalda <RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu>
Subject: 944 Alarm saga ends...

As I've just arrived back here at my terminal with hands still smelling of diesel 
oil (great for freeing up seized parts) I do have the factory alarm finally 
working.  Thanks to everyone that replied, and as suggested this was only a 20 
minute job.
	Here goes: Remove black trim from outside, taking care not to scratch nice 
paintwork.  Undo large 22mm nut. Push lock into car. remove vent in door-pillar, 
retrieve lock.  Undo one terminal, drop all spanners, locks, etc. on floor and hit 
head on roof as alarm starts to go off.  Say to oneself: "yes, this is good, it 
means alarm still works, and people *HAD* mentioned this on the net"  Take off 
battery negative and undo connectors from alarm switch.  Using small screwdriver 
pry the back of the switch off, which reveals lots of room and the cylinder barrel 
retaining mechanism: Big E-clip.  Remove E-clip and hammer out seized lock 
cylinder.  Put assembly in ultrasonic cleaner, or if this not available bring out 
the trusty can of WD40 and clean all moving parts.  Don't drop any of the tumblers 
out or a jigsaw puzzle will appear before your very eyes.
	Assemble in a reverse order to the description above, and hey presto, a 
functioning unit and some $$$ saved.  Hope this will help some other souls prepare 
their cars against the unwanted elements of society...
	Oh yes and by the way, Alan, the alarm key is very different from the 
ignition key, it should have a symbol of a key and the letters nopi (not 
necessarily in that order or indeed that way up) in the symbol to match the symbol 
on the lock.
Cheers,  Jan

------------------------------

which is apparently intended for motorcycles is a perfect fit on most 
911's (maybe others too). When combined with a standard H4 bulb (Hella 
8GJ 002 525-131 etc.) you can have a pair of new H4's for about $60.
Even Roy Rogers stocks them!

Of course, one must do some form of budgeting to accomodate ownership of
any vehicle. Budgeting for a Porsche however enters entirely different
strata. For a younger person, insurance alone may be prohibitively
expensive, if not downright unobtainable at any price. I could never
recommend a 15 year old Porsche (or any other 15 year old automobile for
that matter) to someone who is primarily concerned with maintainence and
repair costs.  Old cars break! Old Porsches break and are incredibly
expensive to repair.  This I know as fact.

If money is the main issue, then don't buy a Porsche. If passion is the
issue, then go for it regardless of the budget!  Passion has ruled my life,
frequently to my chagrin. But I'll always own a Porsche!

No, I'm not in a position to disregard monitary issues.  I wish I could
though because I'd have me one of them new 4WD 993 Turbos!  Ahh to dream. .

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 22:31:38 -0500 (EST)
From: CHORVATH@delphi.com
Subject: Re: metal polishing question

Eric,
   When polishing metal using cloth wheels I clean the cloth wheel
using a buffing rake about once every ten minutes. This exposes fresh new 
cloth with plenty of hair. A stiff wire brush might work, but it shouldn't 
flex. A buffing rake can be easily made by cutting teeth into a 4" x 6" 
piece of 18 gauge sheet steel. Teeth should be cut as such  ^^^^^^^^
Screw the metal to an 18" peice of 1x3 and that's it. You can purchase 
the buff rake teeth for $4 from suppliers.

   When appplying compound to the wheel, allow the compound to heat up by 
placing it against the buff turning at full speed. As the compound melts, 
slow the buff down by applying firmer pressure. Keep the buff turning at 
low speed by continuing the pressure or toggling the on/off switch. The 
object is to get a good layer of compound across the face of the buff 
without it flying off. Switch the buffer off for a few seconds to allow the 
compound the cool. Repeat about every 2-3 minutes. Never mix compounds
on the same buff wheel. Finish your work by buffing with a new wheel
and white rouge to bring out the best color.

   Try using a "felt bob" mounted on a 1/4" shaft for more intricate 
areas. "Razor buffs" are used to obtain polished edges and flanges. They
are generally constructed of several layers of rigid fabric that provide
a face about 3/8" wide. I used razor buffs to polish all the flange areas 
on a stainless steel exhaust with dual mufflers and resonators.

Chris Horvath - Manager of Systems Engineering - Cheyenne Software


>Date: Fri, 17 Mar 95 14:26:52 TZ
>From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
>Subject: metal polishing question
>I am polishing some Fuchs wheels I recently acquired. I am using
>a 4 inch dia. cloth wheel on a 2K RPM drill with tripoli compound. The
>wheel doesn't seem to be cutting as agressively as it did when
>newer, so I am guessing that the wheel needs to be cleaned of
>the built up compound/aluminum. Is a wire brush applied to the
>spinning wheel the correct approach? Any hints would be
>appreciated.

2 heater control boxes [ the ones that are under the car and are attached to
the body and and draw heat from the heater boxes via orange hose ]
1 heater blower [ the one that sits high in the engine bay and blows hot air
into the car not to be confused with the one that's in the front comparment ]
1 interior control unit [ this is the whole unit that controls all the cables
and fresh air blower and vents it is made of black plastic and has a habit of
cracking to describe it better the unit in the center of the dash with three
levers ]

and i'll be sure to get back to you       thanks in advance

into three parts, one view out the window, another view of telemetry data
consisting of speed, RPM, gear, and braking, and a final view of the car
position on the track. ESPN had some great shots of him driving absolutely
flat out in the rain. The amount of work he did was amazing. Every few
minutes he had to wipe the windshield with a rag to stop it from fogging. All
this while trying (and suceeding) to pass the class leading Nisson.

One question, each time Stuck shifted, there was a strange sound from the
car. It almost sounded like the wheels would spin with each shift, or maybe
the gears would grind a little (wasn't the gearbox a synromesh unit?). Does
anyone know what the noise was?

Barry Lenoble
86 944 (still for sale)
Blenoble@aol.com

Porschephiles #1255                         Tue Mar 21 02:00:06 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 00:28:42 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: Bargain Bosch H4's

David:

I have used these headlights in motorcycles for years and they are great.
 There is one minor difference from the auto H4's you might want to know
about.  Instead of dipping down and to the right as the normal RHD headlights
do, they dip straight down on low beam.  The only problem I can see is they
won't illuminate the shoulder quite as well.  I've never used them in a 4
wheeler so I don't know if it makes a significant difference or not.
Good luck with them, the price sounds right enough especially if they include
bulbs.

Regards.

Pat Moyle (pm9146@aol.com)

Date: Mon, 20 Mar 1995 22:37:01 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: Used Helmet

Somebody (Gary, maybe?) wrote:

>  2)    Helmets are "use once and discard" items.  The very first time
>        you say to yourself "Darn, I'm glad I had a helmet on", THROW
>        IT AWAY AND GET A NEW ONE!  It now has a gazillion tiny little
>        cracks in it, and probably won't work next time.

Just a small note...

Helmet manufacturers would prefer that you send "used" helmets back to 
them, rather than throwing them away... They like to analyze the damage 
so they can improve the next generation.  Many manufacturers will even 
cover the shipping costs associated with returning damaged halmets.

 -Andy

Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Monday, 20 March 1995 11:44pm MT
From: MARTENS%emc2@ccsvm.stortek.com
Subject: Carrera RS & RSCS details

Carrera RS details.  Press release from Porsche Cars Australia.

Porsche's new Carrera RS - the most potent and exclusive expression of the classic 911
model - has arrived in Australia.

Eighteen of the lightweight, 300 Hp performance models, collectively worth nearly
$4 million will be envied on Australian roads and racing circuits this year.  The entire
1995 allocation has been pre-sold.

Based on the new 993 series 911 Carrera launched in Australia last year, the 911 Carrera
RS weighs 100 kilograms less, is fitted with a larger bore 3.8 litre six cylinder engine
producing 221 kW (300 Hp) and features race-developed aerodynamics, even bigger
brakes and competition tuned suspension.

It is being produced in two road registerable configurations : "RS Touring", with minimal
trimming and comfort equipment, and "RSCS (Clubsport) " - an even more spartan version
designed for production based motor racing.

The Australian price of the 911 Carrera RSCS is $218,000 and the RS Touring is $207,000.

Initial work at Porsche has concentrated on building the 100 RSCS models needed for
homologation to FIA GT2 requirements.

Unlike the normal RS model, the Clubsport has no linings or insulating materials and the
entire interior is painted in the body colour.  It features additional safety equipment for
racing including a front suspension brace, lightweight bucket seats with six point
harnesses, a fire extinguisher and a battery "kill" switch.  A modified, high downforce
front spoiler and an adjustable rear aerofoil, which incorporates air intakes for the engine
compartment, completes the road or track package.  10 of these vehicles have been sold
to Australian customers and all arrived in early March, with most having a racing destiny.

Production of a further 1000 RS Touring models has already begun at Porsche, with
Australian deliveries due in June.

Weights of both models are RS Touring 1270 kg and RSCS  1235 kg.

Deleted in the new RS are power windows, electrically adjustable mirrors, central locking,
headlamp cleaning system, intermittent wiper setting and sound system speakers.  The
windscreen washer reservoir holds only 1.2 litres instead of 6.5l, while the sophisticated
interior lighting system of the standard model has been replaced by a small lamp from the
911 Speedster.  The use of thin pane windows and the elimination of the rear window
defroster have saved a further five kilograms, while the Aluminium bonnet (hood) saves
a further 7.5 kg.  The shell style leather upholstered bucket seats are painted the same
colour as the body and saves a further 30 kg, insulation has been reduced to a minimum
and the doors are fitted with simple linings and are opened and closed by means of a loop
and a light handle.

The extra capacity from 3.6 litres has been achieved by increasing the bore from 100 to 102 mm,
while power has increased from 200 kW (272 Hp) and torque is now 355 Nm at 5,400 rpm.
Some major advances have been achieved by modifying the engine's air ducting.  Using a
system called "varioram", Porsche engineers managed to raise both max. engine power
while also enhancing mid-range torque.  This endows the RS with the dual blessings of
max. power for racing and max. tractability for traffic operation.  Large intake and exhaust
valves and modified camshafts and timing, complete the engine modifications.

The RS Carrera features a modified six speed gearbox from the 911 Carrera, with the ratio
of the first three gears raised to complement racing use. The new double-cone syncromesh
for first and second gear reduced shifting effort by nearly 40% compared to the previous
model.

The RS is 30 mm lower at the front and 40 mm lower at the rear than the 993.  To adapt the car
to different driving applications, there is a choice of five settings on the front stabilisers and
up to three on the rear.  The Dynamic Driving differential lock available as an option on the 993
is standard on the RS.  This system provides additional stability and consists of two
elements - the automatic brake differential (ABD) and a mechanical transverse rear-axle
lock, both of specifically adjusted for the RS.  Despite weighing an extra 7 kg power steering
remains a standard feature on the RS, although the steering force required from the driver
has been increased to enhance feel.

The 911 Carrera RS is shod with 225/40 ZR 18 front and 265/35 ZR 18 rear tyres, mounted on
RS Cup Design eight and ten inch rims respectively.  Braking tests have shown the RS takes
just 2.7 seconds to stop from 100 km/h.  Race proved four-piston fixed-caliper aluminium
brakes act on huge 322 mm discs all round, compared to the 304 mm front and 299 rear discs
of the 993.  The standard ABS 5 system has been optimised for a shorter braking distance on
uneven roads due to improved control efficiency, with reduced feedback pulsing of the pedal
during ABS operation.

Dream on Pfilers.
Joe Martens
'86 944
bits of a 906.

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 95 00:34:03 PST
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: RE: Used helmets

>From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
>To: "'porschephiles@tta.com'" <porschephiles@tta.com>
>Subject: RE: Used helmet
>Date: Mon, 20 Mar 95 15:54:00 PST
>
>
>Hi Gary, (and Bob)
>
>I find the theory that styrofoam *drys out* interesting.  I can understand 
>some breakdown due to oxidation and/or u.v., but that should be minor in a 
>properly stored helmet.  Even if there is a chemical change over time, does 
>it effect the energy-absorbing qualities enough to warrant tossing the 
>helmet?  Fill me in on this, please.
>
>I concur that once you bonk the lid it should get tossed.
>
>Bob Brewer
>rebrewer@ucdavis.edu
>He who may be looking for a new helmet this season....

I don't know the exact process, but apparently when they expand the
polystyrene to make styrofoam, they do it by bubbleing a gas like
freon (or some EPA approved equivalent) through it.  And the trapped
gas is what makes it rebound.

After time, this gas leaks out, and the foam "dries out", making it
brittle.

And I suppose that if you stored your helmet in an air tight bag, it
would last a much longer time.  But who does that?

Three years may lean towards the "better safe than sorry" side.  But
there is no non-destructive way to test a helmet.

Gary.

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 08:53:58 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: 944 Maintanence costs?

On Mon, 20 Mar 1995, Andrew Wheeler wrote:

> Hello all,
> 
> 	I am in the market for an 86-89 944, and wanted to trouble y'all with a
> quick question.  I'm trying to determine how much I will need to budget towards
> ongoing maintenance, etc. on the car.  I've heard that the 944 is alot more

Andrew - quick summary of my costs for the last 2 years (80k miles)

OIL - Castrol synthetic 40 ltrs - 240 pounds
MAINT KITS X 8 - 320 pounds
CAM & BAL BELTS X 2 - 130 pounds
TYRES X 4 - 500 pounds
STEERING ROD + BEARING - 150 pounds
ANTIFREEZE - 20 pounds (got a leaky rad)
VARIOUS bulbs and fuses - 20 pounds

I have a couple of outstanding maint tasks to do -
NEW ENG MOUNTS - 250 pounds
CAM BELTS - 65 pounds
MINOR TRIM ITEMS - 80 pounds

thats it - 1800 pounds for 80k = 2.2 pence per mile - say 4 cents

now add in fuel at 6 miles/ltr = 13333 ltrs @ 55p/ltr = 7333 pounds

insurance 800 pounds/year = 1600 pounds

The original car 85/944 cost 6500 pounds
- ----------------------------------------------------

as you can see maint costs are dwarfed by fuel and insurance

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 08:20:01 -0500 (EST)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: RE: Used helmets

On Tue, 21 Mar 1995, Bob Brewer wrote:

> >Hi Gary, (and Bob)
> >
> >I find the theory that styrofoam *drys out* interesting.  I can understand 
> >some breakdown due to oxidation and/or u.v., but that should be minor in a 
> >properly stored helmet.  Even if there is a chemical change over time, does 
> >it effect the energy-absorbing qualities enough to warrant tossing the 
> >helmet?  Fill me in on this, please.
Yes, styrofoam takes approximately 500 years to degrade to a significant 
point. But, I wonder, how would UV get a chance to affect it? 
(Interesting that styrofoam, that which allows such evils to get through 
our atmosphere would be affected by them) Sunlight would have to hit the 
interior of the helmet, and if you're just careful with it and sit it up 
right outside, you shouldn't have any problems.
> >I concur that once you 
bonk the lid it should get tossed.
Yes, since styrofoam is made of compressable air pockets, it'll be 
useless after that.
 -Derek Cahill

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 95 09:15:54 EST
From: scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com (Scott Humphreys)
Subject: Re: Insurance


If you or one of your parents was in the military,
even for a short time, you are eligible for USAA
auto insurance (and mutual funds, etc.).
[ phone 1-800-531-8111 ]  USAA is a private company
that offers very good insurance rates AND service to
veterans and their families.  

I've had two sports cars insured with them-
My 1985 RX7 cost about $1,000 per year; State Farm
didn't want to insure it, but apparently they couldn't
come right out and deny insurance to anyone.  They
wanted $4,300 per year on the car (book value $6,000
at the time).

I was unlucky enough to have two accidents in 2.5 years
in that car (with 80+ year olds that should not have 
been driving - only to be expected in South Florida) and 
USAA took great care of everything both times.  My rates 
never went up, as I was not at fault.

The 1987 944 costs about $1,250 per year, but I have
higher limits now, as well. (Yes, I'm 28 and married and
only one speeding ticket ever.).

Scott Humphreys
scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com
1987 RED 944

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 09:58:00 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: Defending Porsches and Toyotas

Greetings fellow Porsche dwellers,
	I have been reading the posts on whether or not for some guy (?) 
to buy a Toyota or a Porsche, and have decided to come out of the closet 
and reveal that, yes, I own a Toy.  It's a 1980 Corolla 2-door with 
321,000 miles on the odometer.  Original untouched engine & 5-speed, 
I use it to commute in the summer (924 has no AC) or on the rare occasion 
when my P-car is in need of repair.  This car has been abused for many 
years by my sister, and it just keeps going.  
	My criteria for the decision is this: If he wants a car that 
takes a lickin and keeps on tickin (cliche, I know) get a Toyota.  If he 
wants a car that will thrill his emotions and demand care and maintenance 
as well as some money, get a Porsche.  IMHO, either will be an excellent 
car!  
Jay Karolyi
'70 mettalic gold Corvair/914
'77 lima bean green 924
'80 mustard yellow (YUCK) Toy Corolla

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 10:02:02 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 questions


<I want to lower the front end of 1973 914 2.0 about 1 1/2 inches and I am
curious
<about the correct procedure. I also want to check all my electrical wiring
and I am
<looking for an "easy to read" diagram to help me out. 
<Any help you may provide will be greatly appreciated.
<thanks, Jeff
<prezcook@aol.com


Dear Jeff, 

Lowering the 914 front end is easy and rewarding if you have height
differential. It is important to first replace the rear springs to establish
proper initial height. From there we adjust the front height to match the
rear.

Front height is measured in the front by subtracting the height from the rear
center torsion bar cap to the ground from the center of the wheel cap to the
ground. The height left to right should be the same.

Seat of the pants adjustment (on a level surface) is as follows:
     1. Measure from the lower tip of the rear quarter panel to the ground on
the left and right sides.
     2. Measure from the rear tip of the front fender to the ground on both
sides.
     3. Raise or lower the front end to match the rear measurement.
     4. Soak the torsion bar adjusting screws with WD 40.
     5. If lowering, unscrew both 11mm bolts or allen adjusting screws one
turn.
     6. Bounce on both fenders to settle the car and remeasure.
     7. If still too high, crank both screws one quarter turn and then bounce
to settle and remeasure.
     8. Repeat the procedure until proper height is achieved.
     9. If the front is too low, you need to first take the weight off the
torsion bars with a floorjack under the cross member before screwing in the
adjusters. Repeat the procedure as above as you adjust up.

Remember, do not take this procedure out of context. This seat of the pants
adjustment has nothing to do with corner balancing or torsion bar tension or
height, just body level. Many factors influence overall height, four corner
balance and spring/torsion bar tension. Beware!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 10:02:35 -0500

A 1971 914-6 is worth much more than a 1970 914-6 as they only made 443 of
them in comparison to 2,668 '70 models! For a rust free example, $9-10K is a

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 10:03:42 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914: No engine #?


<So, what's it mean when your engine has no serial number?
<I guess I assume that it's a replacement case.  Any way of veri-
<fying that it isn't the 75-76 case from the outside?  (I seem to
<remember Dr. 914 mentioning that the 75-76 were different and
<undesirable for some reason.)
        <I could simply be overlooking the numbers, of course.
<But I've checked on the bit in front of the oil filler, I've
<looked behind it as well, and even on the flat spot toward the
<back of the engine where the number is on my 1.8....
        <Small puzzle...

- --DD


Dear Dave,

If your 914 engine case does not have a serial number (and remember 1.7,1.8
models number is at the rear top just to the right of center while the 2.0
models (and VW buses) are in the crevas between the oil filler and the front
impellor housing) then it has had a factory new replacement case at one time.
Since all cases are basically the same, with work they can interchange. I'm
sure the rebuilder use the proper one for your engine.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 10:03:50 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Help on paint and "tyres"...


<Anyone have any idea where I can get a little touchup paint to match my
<1972 914-4?  It is a blazing orange-red and needs a little touch-up here
<and there, but I can't seem to find paint to match.  I know it is the
<original color, though I don't know the name of said hue. 
 <Also, I think I need some new tires.  Not that I'm completely out
<of tread, but these tires are dated "1977" and I imagine a blow-out in a
<rear tire of a 914 (with, oh, 2 mm of clearance from the fender) would end
<in an aesthetically displeasing manner.  I don't have a lot of money to
<spend on tires but I would like something with a reasonable speed rating
>for my street driving habits that will fit my existing alloys (which I
<also need a little advise on how to clean by the way...) Suggestions and
<comments are very welcome!


Dear Rick,

Various colors are still available in the factory pack. Among them is your
Rally or Phoenix red color.

However, if not available, a good auto body paint store can mix your touch up
from the paint number in the left front door jamb plate. Your color is L-32K.

The best all around tire for the factory Pedrinni alloy originally fitted
optionally to 70-73 914 1.7 models is a 195/65x15. It is not the widest that
will fit, but the one to give overall best performance.

The Pedrinni alloy was originally painted by the factory and if dingey, can
be repainted with Porsche silver color (which is about like dull aluminum).

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 95 10:13 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: Defending Porsches and Toyotas

Oh, man, and I was going to stay out of this one, too...

Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu> writes:
	    My criteria for the decision is this: If he wants a car that 
    takes a lickin and keeps on tickin (cliche, I know) get a Toyota.  If he 
    wants a car that will thrill his emotions and demand care and maintenance 
    as well as some money, get a Porsche.  IMHO, either will be an excellent 
    car!  

Your low-end Toyotas are, indeed, extremely beatable, but is the same true for
the high-end sportabouts?  Can you really expect to be able to beat the car to
death every day, leave it parked on the street, feed it cheap gas and change
the oil every spring and fall and still expect it to be reliable.  I know the
old Corollas seemed to thrive, or at least hold up well, under such treatment,
but I can't see redlining an MR2 through every gear every time the light
changed on 87 octane and "Bubba's Best" 30-wt and still having no problems.

Well, enough run-on sentences.  I just wanted to say that I don't think that
reliability should be a consideration when purchasing a sports car.  If you
take car of your car, either a Porsche or a Toyota will be reliable; if you
don't, then neither will be.

Junk food for thought!
- -- Tracy Nelson

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 09:22:34 -0600
From: dgcole@sam.neosoft.com (David G. Cole)
Subject: 912 restore ?

Hi,

        An opportunity(?) has presented itself. A local garage has a '68 912 
for sale, in a "to be restored condition". While I am looking for a long 
term project car, I have no experience with pre '74 Porsches in general and 
912's specifically. Shop is asking a $1000, here is *currently known* condition:

        Floor is supposedly rusted (have not seen extent for myself)
        no engine/trans in car
        no wheels
        rust spot on engine lid (paint bubbled up)
        rust spot on hood (paint bubbled up)
        rust spot bottom corner of windshield frame (paint bubbled up)
        suspension/steering/brakes appears all present and attached
        external body looks good (no ripples in body, no strange outlines in 
paint)
        supposedly never wrecked / no bondo on car

main reason I am giving this such a closer look is that the interior has all 
ready been redone:

        new (looking) carpet
        new leather seats
        dash top and front/face look new
        instruments complete and look refurb'd
        door panels and internal trim has been replaced / refurb'd
        has A/C hookups (this IS an issue in Houston as it would be a daily 
driver)

        I have somehow (WAG) came up with around $8k as being the number 
required to get this thing into a very good mechanical/structurally correct 
*daily driver*, not a show car. Have I been taking one of our list members' 
pills without a prescription again? About how far off is that $ number?

        Now, if the general consensus of the net gods is that this looks 
like an acceptable situation, can someone give recommendations on a (Houston 
area) shop to do the cutting/welding on at least a new floor pan? Final 
painting of the car? Source of mechanical tidbits that are 912 specific?

thanks for your time in this matter

Dave
dgcole@popmail.neosoft.com

80 931:  (Carrera GT wannabe)
84 LiLi: Cross-eyed, brain damaged house cat

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 16:28:48 +0100
From: Trond Vidar Olsen <Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no>
Subject: T-6 front clip again....

Hi again,

Anyone have any experience modifying T6 clips for use on T5 cars?

I understand you will have to do a 'butt weld' (?) after the drain
channel of the T-6 clip is cut away. 

The remains of the T5 clip should be cut to fit the edge of the T6
clips hood perimeter.

When done correctly, you save $1500!  T6 - T5 = $1500  ;-)
 
Trond V.
PS: T6 clip seller emerged yet...?

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 95 10:56:12 EST
From: scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com (Scott Humphreys)
Subject: RE: Insurance


If you or one of your parents was in the military,
even for a short time, you are eligible for USAA
auto insurance (and mutual funds, etc.).
[ phone 1-800-531-8111 ]  USAA is a private company
that offers very good insurance rates AND service to
veterans and their families.  

I've had two sports cars insured with them-
My 1985 RX7 cost about $1,000 per year; State Farm
didn't want to insure it, but apparently they couldn't
come right out and deny insurance to anyone.  They
wanted $4,300 per year on the car (book value $6,000
at the time).

I was unlucky enough to have two accidents in 2.5 years
in that car (with 80+ year olds that should not have 
been driving - only to be expected in South Florida) and 
USAA took great care of everything both times.  My rates 
never went up, as I was not at fault.

The 1987 944 costs about $1,250 per year, but I have
higher limits now, as well. (Yes, I'm 28 and married and
only one speeding ticket ever.).

Scott Humphreys
scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com
1987 RED 944

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 11:38:32 -0500 (EST)
From: JAN RINGNALDA <RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu>
Subject: 944 MAINTENANCE

Andrew,
	How long is a piece of string?
There is no way of predicting maintenance costs because basically all cars and 
all drivers are different.  Oil changes at every 3k, and TLC go a long way to 
preserve the condition of the car, and it has been my experience that the 
exterior of a vehicle does give something away about the general mechanical 
condition, also.
	So what do you mean by 'ongoing maintenance' I own a 944 with 138,000 
miles on it and strong compression tests show that the vehicle is just nicely 
run-in.  Get a car which looks good, and has a service history so you can check 
on the things which have been mentioned on this net, such as motor mounts, 
oilcooler, driveshafts and timing belt/tensioner replacement at the expected or 
required intervals.
	Another big issue is whether you can do any 'spannering' yourself.  I 
bought my 944 with (complete with needs engine work tag) with an estimate of 
$2500 for an engine rebuild. 
	Now and $340 later, I am driving said 944 around, so the gamble paid off.
Cheers,  Jan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 08:48:15 -0700
From: stephenk@synopsys.com (Stephen Keller)
Subject: Re: 912 restore ?

Dave (dgcole@popmail.neosoft.com) writes about a "rebuildable '68 912":

>        I have somehow (WAG) came up with around $8k as being the number 
>required to get this thing into a very good mechanical/structurally correct 
>*daily driver*, not a show car. Have I been taking one of our list members' 
>pills without a prescription again? About how far off is that $ number?

Your $8k estimate sounds low.  Rust repair eats up a lot of dollars quickly.
We recently got estimates for rustoration and repaint of a '75 914 (a major
portion of this job was serious floorpan replacement): bids ranged around
$7k.  Then you've the matter of the missing engine, transaxle, and all the
various accouterments that hook to the engine (carbs, generator,
distributor, A/C system, oil cooler, etc).  I have no idea what all this
would cost for a 912, but let's guess and say you could find all of it used
but servicable for $3k (someone out there will correct me :-).  Next, add an
additional $2k in misc. stuff--brake system rebuild, fixing the inevitable
electrical gremlins, wheels, tires, shocks, and whatever else you don't know
about until it breaks.  I think a optimistic estimate of your rebuild costs
is closer to $12k.

I think you'd be better off to look for a complete, running automobile to
drive. Even using your estimate of $9k for this car, I expect you could find
a reasonably nice, running '68 912.  You might consider this one for a parts
car, though.  If the external panels are straight and not too badly eaten up
by rust, they and the interior might be worth the $1000 the shop is asking.

That's my 2c anyway.

Stph
- --------------------------------
Stephen Keller
'73 914 2.0L
stephenk@synopsys.com

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 8:58:50 -0800 (PST)
From: JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: 914 autox and handling fun

Hi all,

The cast: me and my  74 914 2.0L
The location: McClelan AFB, SCCA SFR #2&3

	My brakes are done, and I got to give them the real test 
at this weekends two day autox event at McClelan AFB. I 
couldnt really determine how they were going to work on the 
first day as it was raining in the morning and I was in the 
first run group, although it was alot of fun slipping and 
sliding in the wet. But the second day was dry, and I was 
able to see where my brakes were working and where there 
wernt. I still need to do some work, the front left locks up 
before the right, and I probably couldnt get the rears to 
lock if I tried. The new system is a 19mm master with 
carbon/kevlar pads, and new rotors. Any suggestions beyond 
the neccessary rebuild of the front calipers?
	
	The autox was a blast. The wet, although frustrating, 
was a blast. What was frustrating was that I couldnt tell 
what was wrong. I couldnt manage to get the rear around on 
the gas unless I got really drastic. Not spin, just rotate. 
The only time I found I could get the car to rotate was on 
trailing throttle. Wow! It was great, the car would whip 
around and lock right into position. But because this was 
only on trailing throttle, I lost time. Lots of time. Yeah 
theres other factors too, like my driving just has to get 
better first. But wait, theres more. On the next day it was 
warm and dry for our run group. We had five runs, and on the 
first three runs, once again, I couldnt figure out what in 
the world I was doing wrong. I was trying so hard to drive 
the car the way I -thought- and -knew- the car should handle, 
that I was ignoring the obvious. It wasnt until after my 
third run, that I paid closer attention to tire temps. The 
rears were even across the tread but the fronts were cold on 
the inside. Aha! Well that should tell me something. Too much 
toe in? Not enough camber? Understeer! DUH! Of course! Once 
that had FINALLY occured to me, I was suprised that I hadnt 
caught on earlier. I should have spotted that on the first 
run, but I was so caught up on testing the brakes and trying 
to get the car to handle the way I -thought- it could, that 
it didnt even cross my mind. Well, having no adjustable 
suspension, and no front sway bar (not for much longer), all 
I had was tire preasures. So I added four pounds to the front 
and bingo! Three seconds off my time. Doh! If I had noticed 
that earilier, I could have spent my time on improving my 
driving rather that fighting my car. I probably could have 
used more in the front still, but I ran out of runs. First 
official autox of the season for me, I gota get my brain 
working faster than that.
	Out on the course, everyone was noticing the hideous 
body roll my car was exhibiting. Well, once I had a couple of 
pieces, the rest all fell into place. The understeer was most 
likely a result of having totally shot rear stock springs. 
And the massive body roll was probably covering up some 
of the feel of the understeer. So the question I pose to 
anyone whos actually perseveered through all of my autox 
drivel is, what do you think my next course of action should 
be with the suspension. So far my plan would be to go for 
140lb rear springs and a front sway bar. If I had a bigger 
wallet, I would throw in the koni shocks and the torsion bars 
too. But Im on a bit of a limited budget. Id like to do 
something before the April 2nd drivers school, but I cant 
afford to go all out yet. Also, any suggestions to 
get the brakes better balanced? Thanks...

BTW, Im running in SCCA CSP-R class, so I gotta obey the 
rules.

 -Josh

Joshua Hadler				'74 914 2.0L CSP
Accelerator Operations
Stanford Linear Accelerator Center

jah@slc.slac.stanford.edu

Everything expresed here is the opinion of the idiot that wrote it, 
namely ME. So don't go suing the DOE, they don't care...

Porschephiles #1257                         Tue Mar 21 15:17:07 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 11:20:48 +0600
From: rondl@uscbu.ih.att.com
Subject: Brake Fluids

There was a recent inquiry about what kind of brake fluid to
use on a early 912.  I used the Castrol LMA GTX brake fluid, I think
the LMA means "low moisture activated" or something like that.
Its a dot 4 if I remember correctly and works with dot 3 fluids.

After witnessing and later assisting with bleeding a 'vette with
silicon fluids, I wouldnt touch that stuff if you paid me.  It was
miserable bleeding silicon, not to mention expensive!

Anyway, that's my 2 cents worth,

Ron

rondl@uscbu.att.com

'66 912 Almost Done!! License plates: "NOT A 911"
'92 Isuzu Rodeo - Car parts hauler
'88 BMW M6 - Wanted!

> limits, a $500 deductable, and no driving restrictions.

GEICO isn't available in NJ, so I can't insure my 911 with them.  Its a
shame considering its costing me a backbreaking $800 per year. :-)

Granted, I have higher deductibles ($1K) and its an '85 (lower cost), but
Northern NJ has the highest overall rates in the USA _again_.

Our coverage sounds mostly comperable except that I have a "pleasure only"
rating, but I have NO MILEAGE LIMIT.  Then again, I have no airbag
discount, no ABS discount, no alarm discount either - so that $800 could
theoretically be even lower.  The other cars, an Audi and a VW bring the
total policy to ~$2000/year.

If you're in NJ, try to get into NJ Manufacturer's.

Date:         Tue, 21 Mar 95 11:37:38 CST
From: Darren Evans-Young <DARREN@UA1VM.UA.EDU>
Subject:      Re: 944 Belt Tension Intervals

>
>Hi, Tracy,
>
>Let me clear up one thing about the MY87+ cars with the built-in tensioner:
>
>The tensioner does not provide a continuous adjustment.  It is used at the
>time of the initial installation of the belt and at further maintenance
>activities. Once the timing belt tension is set, the adjustment is locked
>down and remains that way until the tensioner is loosened.
>
>In light of that consideration, and in light of the fact that the balance
>shaft belt does not have the benefit of an automatic adjuster, I would
>follow the above recommendation...
>
>Good luck
>--
>George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
>944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
>172 Hardenburgh Road
>Ulster Park, NY  12487
>1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

George,

Just an observation about the timing belt tensioner.
I adjusted the tension on my new belt at 2000 miles and
the tensioner moved a bit to remove the slack.  I just did
another retension at 10000 miles and the tensioner didn't
move a bit. So from my sampling rate of 1, I would say that
the initial 1500-2000 mile retension is MUCH more important
than the 10000 mile. (I'm not saying the 10000m retension
wasn't important or didn't adjust the tension. This was just
a visual observation.)

Darren
'87 944S Indischrot

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 95 09:52:32 PST
From: Scott=D=Berry%MfgEng%GPID@banyan.BV.TEK.COM
Subject: Restore 912

I am on my second 912 right now and unless you are looking for a parts car or 
REALLY want to spend many many hours of fun (?) and probably a lot more money 
than $8k putting this thing back together I would run away!  The leather seats 
alone are worth quite a bit of money if recently redone but any rust on the 
floor, strut mounts, etc will cost a fortune to repair correctly.  If you have 
$8k to spend keep looking.  You can find a nice 912 for that.  Good luck!

Scott  66 912 #2

Scott.D.Berry@email.hub.TEK.COM

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 13:16:57 -0500 (EST)
From: takaharu@sas.upenn.edu (Takaharu Mizutani)
Subject: Toyotas and the like

To settle this issue,
I'd like to add one more statement:

Toyotas, such as Corollas and Tercels, are great for basic 
transportation. They're nearly unbreakable, utterly reliable and cheap to 
operate and repair.

However, the subjective driving experience of a car as unique as the 
Porsche 911 is, IMHO, sublime and cannot be compared to any other sports car.
Granted, cars like the new Supra Turbo, the Nissan 300ZX Turbo, the Mazda 
RX-7, and especially the Nissan Skyline GT-R are all nice cars, but they 
aren't Porsches. I _like_ the idiosyncrasies of the Porsche 911- it makes 
the car unique and interesting.

Personally, I would never use a Porsche as primary transportation. Being 
that I live in an urban area, there are too many problems associated with 
commuting in a Porsche or a similar sports car. Heavy stop-and-go traffic 
make me wish for an automatic (otherwise, I hate slushboxes). The massive 
potholes of Philly will destroy low-profile-tired alloy wheels. The large 
number of unlicensed, uninsured drivers out here will increase the 
possibility of your P-car getting in an accident which you will have to 
pay for. Finally, the high cost of maintenance makes it impractical to 
drive a P-car in such harsh conditions (IMHO).

As for what other people drive, and "mall-cruising wanna-bes," I couldn't 
care less. The 80's are over, and I think we'll see less of these Porsche 
owners who only bought the car for the image.
 
Sorry for all the rambling.
- -- 
Taka Mizutani                                     University of Pennsylvania
takaharu@mail.sas.upenn.edu                            Philadelphia, PA, USA
Land line: (215) 243-1247                             Mobile: (215) 960-0592

Date:     Tue, 21 Mar 95 13:12:50 EST
From: "Hugh A. Huntzinger" (CCAC) <huntzing@PICA.ARMY.MIL>
Subject:  RE: Decisions, Decisions

Tim's "MR2 Turbo or [one of several] 911?" question
(See also "blind brand loyalty thread")

> Now, I was all ready to purchase a 92 MR2 Turbo, when my 3 friends...
> 						..."Why purchase a
> wanna-be, mall driving, sports car.  Get something with class."
>
>
> Needless to say, I am beginning to be swayed.  My $$$ limit is
> approximately $12,000.  However, the main reason I am getting rid of my
> 1983 toyota celica is the constant headaches with its falling apart, 150K
> miles...Now with the price range I am in, I am relegated to...[old 911s?]

Tim,

You've already answered your own question.  With only $12K and a strong
desire to avoid 'headaches of repair', the answer to your question is:

'NONE OF THE ABOVE'.

It sounds like your #1 priority is for a rugged, dependible, inexpensive
to maintain daily driver.  If it could be fun, too, that would be great.
But none of these cars fit that BASIC requirement.

If you really want to buy a toy cars right now, consider keeping your
Celica as the daily beater...its virtually worthless as a trade-in anyway,
but it will wonders to your insurance rates if you can list a toy car as
a "Pleasure Only" vehicle.  My 'beater has a 50% ROI (Return on Investment) 
just from what it saves me annually on insurance costs on the 911.  


...or maybe ~$8K on a cheap econobox and a basic 914 for ~$5K...?  :-)



 -hh


BTW, for the "Is a 911 ugly?" question, one boss at work calls my 911
"The Blue Frog" becuae of its 'bugeye' headlights.  Not complimentary,
but then again he has 3 Corvettes (all post '84s, none of which RUN! ;-)

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 95 13:32:03 EST

Allow me to recommend a 1981 Toyota Corolla to meet that BASIC requirement.
The 3T-C engine is bullet-proof and quite ammenable to souping up a bit,
and the handling and traction improve greatly once you put on low-profile
Yokohama A-509 tires (awesome in the wet). Mine has gone 217,000 fun-filled
miles already...

from your $12,000 limit. Like at least $10,000.

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 95 13:58:59 EST
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: RE: Insurance

Thanks for the phone number for USAA.  Need to clarify eligibility --
I just talked to their sales dept. since my current insurer, Am. Hardware
Mutual, is no longer going to be writing auto policies in NJ.  

USAA insures current and former *commissioned* officers (not NCOs) and
the children of USAA insureds.  Thus I can only get ITAA insurance if my
dad has it.  The fact that he *could get it* isn't enough.  Widow(er)s of
commissioned officers qualify.  Divorced spouses do not.  FBI agents and
some other miscellaneous officialdom are treated as commissioned officers
for USAA purposes.

I've heard about them before so I had my hopes up, but it looks like they
leave me out.
B.

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 95 14:04:57 EDT
From: "Bill Elwell" <B.Elwell@zds.com>
Subject: Way too much about Toyotas


Jay Karolyi writes:
     My criteria for the decision is this: If he wants a car that takes a lickin
     and keeps on tickin (cliche, I know) get a Toyota.  If he wants a car that
     will thrill his emotions and demand care and maintenance as well as some
     money, get a Porsche.  IMHO, either will be an excellent car!  

Tracy Nelson then writes:
     Your low-end Toyotas are, indeed, extremely beatable, but is the same 
     true for the high-end sportabouts?  Can you really expect to be able 
     to beat the car to death every day, leave it parked on the street, 
     feed it cheap gas and change the oil every spring and fall and still 
     expect it to be reliable.

You make a good point Jay.  Actually, the older non-turbo MR2's should be very 
reliable.  The one that I drove used a Corolla drive train.  Toyota isn't 
stupid.  They took an existing drive train (the Corolla's) and married it to a 
simple, cheap to build body/chassis.  Then they sell it for lots of money.  The 
result is that most people (myself included) think it is a fun car to drive and 
it will take an incredible amount of abuse.

Oh yes, I almost forgot.  I think that the guy should buy the MR2 (calm down 
everybody, it's just a joke).

Bill Elwell

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 14:13:32 -0500
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: Used helmets

Gary writes

> they do it by bubbleing a gas like freon (or some EPA approved >equivalent)
through it.  And the trapped gas is what makes it >rebound.


Something not quite right here -Helmet linings are not made to rebound - they
are crushable -that is how they protect your head, by absorbing the impact,
and that is why, once "used", they are no good and need to be relined ( at
least) or more likely thrown away.

A rebounding lining would just put the energy absorbed back into play - on
your head! 



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 95 14:16:59 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: 914 questions

>
><I want to lower the front end of 1973 914 2.0 about 1 1/2 inches and I am
>curious
><about the correct procedure. I also want to check all my electrical wiring
>...
>Lowering the 914 front end is easy and rewarding if you have height
>differential. It is important to first replace the rear springs to establish
>proper initial height. From there we adjust the front height to match the
>rear.
>...(George's good advice on the actual front adjustment procedure deleted)

Another option, instead of replacing the sagged rear springs to start at
the factory settings, is to leave the sagged, stock rear springs in place,
and lower the front to match. This results in a lowered car, which, 
combined with decent shocks and front and rear anti-sway bars, produces
a very nice handling 914. Follow George's procedure for the actual
adjustment, but adjust the front so it is slightly lower than the rear,
as determined by the slope of the door jamb (slight downward slope to
the front). As George suggests, weight balancing is a useful addition,
once you have the basic height adjustment you want. I was initially
worried about bottoming, either on the bump stops or on the foot valve
of the shocks, but I drove the car this way for about 100K miles, with
100 or more reasonably aggressive track events along the way, without
apparent problems.

It has also been my experience that for 914's without extra chassis
stiffening across the passenger area (as would be provided by a full
cage), stiff suspensions are frequently counterproductive. A stiff
suspension on a flexible chassis just makes the chassis act like
the suspension by bending. I found that 914's with stock or near stock
spring rates were usually faster than cars with very stiff springs.
Of course, with the addition of a roll cage or other stiffening,
stiffer suspensions have more to offer.


Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 95 14:33:52 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: 914 alignment settings

>I am having my 914 track car aligned this coming Monday and lost my notes on
>the best alignment settings.  I do a lot of autocrossing and 2-3 track
>events every summer and fall. My wheel and tire combinations are 15x7 with
>205-50 Comp TA R1.  Any help is appreciated.

For a street-driven but frequently tracked 914, using 206/60-15 tires on
stock (5 1/2" x 15) wheels and near stock suspension (just somewhat
lower), I found that the following was a nice compromise:

Front camber: 30 to 40' negative
Rear camber: 1 Deg. 30' to 1 Deg. 40' negative
Front toe: 0 to 1/16" total toe in, pressed
Rear toe: 1/16" toe in per side

If your emphasis is autocross, you may want some front toe-out. If
you are willing to compromise street drivability and the suspension is
still stock, even more negative camber can be used. A good rule of
thumb is to make the back camber about a degree more negative than the 
front.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 95 11:56:02 PST
From: sean@scifi.ucsf.EDU (Sean Steinman)
Subject: Bosch Plug Meltdown!

This is semi Porsche related... My friend called me the other day and told me
his Chevy S-10 V6 was running really bad. Kind of like on 4 out of 6. I asked 
about the last time he tuned it, 30k ago it turns out. I have him go out and 
get the parts. So I'm at his place and I pull out one of the bosch platiniums,
Much to my suprise, The anode is melted across to the grounding electrode. No
kidding, there was a fine wire connecting across the gap! So I figure that
since it's so thin I could just knock it off, Not a chance it was welded across.
So I pull the next plug, not completely across but almost. Talk about screwing
up the gap... So I replace the plugs and the rest of the parts he got and the
truck runs like new. I`ve been working on cars for a pretty long time and
have never, never seen something like this. Anyone had a similar occurrence
with Bosch platiniums? Seems to me his truck was actually running on 5 of 6.
Sean
69 912 (without bosch platiniums)
Zero & Maddog: 8 Legs of Terror!

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 95 14:24:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944T Coil-overs


Jim,

Answers are to the best of my knowledge.  I'm sure somone will correct
me if I stray!

>what type of coil-overs did the Escort (Turbo Cup) cars come with?

Bilsteins.

>what does the M030 option provide (as pertains to coilovers) are
>these bilstein or koni?  are they adjustable?

Koni, single adjustable (rebound, not compression).  Height adjustable
spring perches.

Conversion to double-adjustable is available;  let me know if you're
interested.  It is also possible to convert the perches to use a standard
ID racing spring (2-1/4" or 2-1/2"), which allows you to select from a
range of inexpensive Eibach or Hypercoil springs.

Kevin

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 16:02:46 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Renting in Europe

As I replied privately to the person who originally posted this question:
check with your local travel agent.  They can arrange rentals on anything
your heart desires (and your pocketbook allows).  The last time I checked (2
or 3 years ago, I think) while in Germany, the daily rate on a 911 was
several hundred dollars.

Renting before you arrive in Europe is cheapest.  Failing that, pay with a
credit card for the very best exchange rate (that goes for all purchases
there, by the way), and don't forget that you may have some kind of insurance
coverage included with your credit card.

Given the price of renting, I think Pete's idea of shipping your own car over
for a couple of weeks probably makes good sense (I wouldn't mine taking my
356 back to its home, either).  Anyone have any idea off-hand about current
shipping rates (container only, thank you), customs requirements,
availability of short-term insurance in Europe, etc.?

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 15:02:55 -0600 (CST)
From: kenitkw@ndlc.occ.uky.edu (Dr. Keith Kenitzer)
Subject: RE:  912 Restore ?


Dave:

My advice is run, do not walk, away from the project you are 
contemplating, unless you have some tremendous desire to spend lots of 
$$$$$ and lots of TTTTIIIIIIMMMMMMEEEEE on your project.  If that is the 
case, I have a project for you.

Seriously, 13 years ago I had to have a Porsche.  I was young and 
foolish, (and a poor college student) so I decided the way to get my 
dream car was to find a fixer-upper.  On one day I looked at a 1970 911T 
and a 1966 912.  I liked them both.  The 912 had one thing going for it, 
it was $1500.00 cheaper.  It also needed a lot more work.  Being young 
and etc., etc., I chose to save money today and took the 912 home.  After 
a good investment of time and $$$$ I had my P-car, a better 66 912 that 
was still somewhat a fixer-upper, that wasn't worth the $$$$$ invested.

About a year later my 912 developed a large gushing oil leak going back 
to school on a cold Wisconsin November night.  I had the car towed to my 
parents house to await the inevitable repair.  Being still young and 
foolish, I decided to rebuild the motor and do a few others odds and ends 
to complete the restoration process.  Unfortunately the time and $$$$ 
were a bit lacking and the car still sits and awaits it's restoration, 
although it is in my driveway now.  

My car is currently in better shape than you describe your proposed 
project.  I figure a minimum of $10,000, with me doing most if not all the work, to get 
back on the road with a very nice, reliable daily driver 912. I have so 
much time and $$$$ invested in my potential project right now that 
there is no turning back.  I must see it to completion.  Truth be told, I 
would probably be better of to sell what I have for parts and buy the 
best P-car I can afford than to stick more into my car.  Unfortunately, I 
have the EMOTIONAL investment in it already and that is what will drive 
me to complete the project.

I do not relate this sad tale to gain any sympathy.  It was not the only 
foolish decision I made in my life.  I love my 912 and will probably have 
it until I have drool running down my face and they stick me in a home.  
I just offer this advice on the hopes that someone else might avoid 
making the same mistake that I did.

Keith Kenitzer
'66 912 (disabled)

PS:  I have been a member of this list about a month now and it has given 
me the inspiration to get my 912 back on the road to good health.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 15:08:15 +0600
From: rondl@uscbu.ih.att.com
Subject: '68 912 restore?


As the proud owner of a '66 912, and bought it as a rust bucket for $2500,
I guess I can add some perspective here.  RUN AWAY!  I wanted a '66 912
for very specific reasons - easy to work on, used to ride in one all
the time as a kid, wanted to learn how to weld.....  I've got $8k in
mine easy, and I had the engine/trans in the car (running!).  Granted,
with 3 years of my labor, I'll have a perfect car, but, if that's
not what you want, dont do it.

I've seen *many* early 912s, running and rather clean daily drivers
in the $6k+ range.  You would be *much* happier buying a running, clean
example and having fun with it right away.  The headaches and $$ associated
with getting it road-worthy will be profound unless you go into it
wanting a long-term project!  If you dont plan on doing a lot of the
work yourself, the miscellaneous parts/labor alone will kill you.  If it
really needs a floor pan, it is probably very rusty and the small misc
stuff associated with the running gear is very expensive.  
Hang in there and buy a running example for $6k and save your
remaining money for the eventual rebuilds or mechanical work.

The only other advice I can give is to find a local short-wheel base
911/912 expert and have him/her go with you and look it over for you.
Maybe (and its probably a long shot), its not that bad.

I must say that the short-wheel base 911/912s are major cool and
they are the only types of Porsche(no Toyotas in my future) I want.

Good Luck!

Ron De Lange
'66 912 Almost Done!
'92 Isuzu Rodeo - Car parts hauler
'88 BMW M6 - Wanted!

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 14:18:45 -0700
From: Drew Spencer <Drew_Spencer@Novell.COM>
Subject:  Question: Using "Race" Brake Fluid -Reply

>What are the _disadvantages_ of using a racing-type brake
>fluid (e.g. ATE
>Super Blue Racing) on a street car?
>
> ____________________________________
>| Andrew E. Kalman   aek@netcom.com  | 
>|____________________________________    
>

Andrew,

The only disadvantage of running ATE is the cost, and
even then, it's not a huge difference for what you get. IMHO.

One interesting data point to consider...
When deciding on what fluid to use in my RS America
for track events, I decided to check out what the factory
fluid is from the dealership.  They brought out a can that
was the exact same size and shape as the ATE can.  I
compared the numbers and guess what?  The dry/wet boiling
points are EXACTLY the same and are printed in the same
font, but different color.  What I've concluded is that the ATE
Blue and Porsche OEM fluids are the same stuff, only the
ATE has blue dye in it while the Porsche fluid is the standard
light amber color.

Drew
Drew_Spencer@novell.com
'93 RS America 
'82 911 SC



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 15:54:17 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: Re: Bosch Plug Meltdown


>there was a fine wire connecting across the gap! ...
>Anyone had a similar occurrence with Bosch platiniums? ...

>Sean

This is a very common failure mode for the new style platinum plugs
and I'm surprized the press hasn't picked it up. Seems that when the
plug overheats, the wire slips down out of the ceramic and shorts out
the plug. Maybe it doesn't have anything to do with overheating and is
just a QC problem, but they all fail the same way. If the platinum is
molded into place it would be easy to just swage it to keep it from
slipping, but it looks like it's drawn through a hole in the ceramic
after it's fired. I have a friend who works for Bosch and I'll see if
she can put me in contact with one of the spark plug guys unless someone
else already has a contact.

(everybody keep those bad plugs, just in case)

 - Reid (reid_zeigler@merck.com)

that this means a new rack.  Is my diagnosis correct?  Where is a

Date: 21 Mar 1995 14:30:21 U
From: Soren LaForce <Soren_LaForce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: re-used helmets

                       Subject:                               Time:2:17 PM
  OFFICE MEMO          re:used helmets                        Date:3/21/95

A couple of points:

It's not just the Styrofoam.  The fiberglass also drys out and 
becomes brittle.

So it takes 500 years for Styrofoam to *bio* degrade, so what?
It's completely irrelevant to the helmet discussion which is 
concerned with structural degradation.

Perhaps I missed a reply from the original poster and he may 
have addressed this, but I assumed that by used he ment worn,
not impacted.  I mean, if you were selling a helmet would you 
call it unused after wearing it all season?

I think Bell recommends using a helmet no more than 4 years 
from manufacture date.


- --Soren
soren_laforce@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov




------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 95 17:33:13 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: 914 questions

>        [lots of good advice deleted]
>> This results in a lowered car, which,
>>combined with decent shocks and front and rear anti-sway bars, produces
>>a very nice handling 914.
>
>        Just a word on rear sway-bars:  They are not recommended by most
>of the local 914 gurus (SF Bay Area) except with stock suspension (and
>possibly stock-type tires?) or with limited slip.

Of course I began my recommendation by saying stock springing. From my
experience, which I believe parallels the East coast consensus, you want
some additional rear roll stiffness, when working with stock front
torsion bars and a front sway bar roughly as stiff as the factory bar.
This additional rear roll stiffness could be 140# rear springs, without
any rear sway bar, or stock springs, with the factory rear anti-sway
bar. Limited slip is not an issue on unmodified 4 cylinder 914's,
in my experience. All of this is from a racetrack driving perspective,
as opposed to autocrossing, where other setups might make more sense.
I believe that it should apply for R-series DOT tires, as well as
"ordinary" tires. 

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

Josh writes:


>	My brakes are done, and I got to give them the real test 
>at this weekends two day autox event at McClelan AFB. I 
>couldn't really determine how they were going to work on the 
>first day as it was raining in the morning and I was in the 
>first run group, although it was alot of fun slipping and 
>sliding in the wet. But the second day was dry, and I was 
>able to see where my brakes were working and where there 
>wern't. I still need to do some work, the front left locks up 
>before the right, and I probably couldn't get the rears to 

Also check that your front allignment is correct.  Uneven 
camber might cause one wheel to lock before the other.  I 
know this can happen with the rear wheels of a 911.

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 15:24:44 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: Bargain Bosch H4's

>We have discovered the Bosch H4 headlight, part number 0.301.600.118, 
>which is apparently intended for motorcycles is a perfect fit on most 
>911's (maybe others too). When combined with a standard H4 bulb (Hella 
>8GJ 002 525-131 etc.) you can have a pair of new H4's for about $60.
>Even Roy Rogers stocks them!

European Car did an article in the November 1994 issue about installed 
Hella H4s in 914s - basically just a bolt-in. (7" round, of course.) They 
come with 55/60w bulbs. German Parts and Restoration sells the 
headlights for $30 each, $8 for a 55/100w bulb.

From calling my local accessory dealer (Wilco), I found that Hella now has 
a street-legal, DOT approved version... I'm not 100% sure of the official 
name, but perhaps Hella Vision? Anyways, I'll probably be installing them 
by the weekend. (My 914 goes on the road Thursday or Friday, and one of 
the old sealed-beam non-halogens burnt out, so perfect time.)

Date: 21 Mar 95 15:38:24 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Ford HD Brake Fluid


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Ford HD Brake Fluid
Date: 1995-03-21 17:35
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

On the thread of "which brake fluid" a sleeper out there is the Ford HD Dot
3 fluid.  I probably even got it from P-files (like everything else), but a
few of the local SCCA "shoes" are happy with it.  Cost me a bit over $5 a
pint, has a 572 deg F dry boiling point.  My only data point so far is with
back-to-back drivers in lapping sessions at Texas World Speedway (NOT a
track that is hard on brakes - with a bazillion foot long straight to cool
'em) -- stock pads, me easy on brakes & Sally a long/soft braker (read *hot*
parts).

We had firm brakes all day in the Carrera...

I've used Motul in the past and like it, but don't like it relative to cost
and amount of fluid changing it requires to keep dry...

 -Scott Jessen



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 15:40:23 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: Extra ignition keys

>Please forgive me if this is a stupid question, but when I bought my 1985 911
>Targa I was given three sets of keys, but only one of these actually operates
>the ignition.  Somewhere I picked up the impression that extra ignition keys
>have to be obtained from the factory and cannot be made by your local
>friendly locksmith.  I live in fear of losing my only ignition key and wish I
>had at least one extra.  Does any of this ring any bells with anyone?

Speaking as a Porsche dealership parts guy, you can order cut keys directly 
from Germany with just your VIN code. I'm not 100% sure if a locksmith can 
make them as well, some keys are laser-cut and cannot be copied by 
locksmiths. Plus the fact that copies rarely work as well - I had a very 
reputable lockshop copy my 914 key, and it only works in one direction. (Ie, 
it's cut on both sides, but not both sides work correctly.)

Mercedes-Benz and BMW keys are this way, as are some other high-line cars. 
In fact, the newest BMW 7-series and the new Land Rover SE has electronics 
in the key that "talk" to the car every time you start the car, and have a 
special code that changes every time you start the car... All in the name of 
reducing car-thefts. What this means is potentially long waits for a duplicate 
key (depending upon manufacturer), and big-time expensive (to the tune of 
over $100 per key.)

Anyways, summation: Go to your dealer, and order a key. (They don't need 
your key at all, just your VIN.) It'll be more than the $3 or whatever a 
lockshop charges, but it'll be right, and you'll be able to sleep at night. :)


- -- 
| Jeff Kyle                           "I don't know what they have to say |

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 16:05:11 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Bargain Bosch H4's

An alternative to Bosch or Hella H-4's are Cibie's Z-Beams - these are
truly fantastic headlights, and have a convex face (not flat like H4's).  I
use them on my 914 and on an Alfa.  I find their pattern to be outstanding,
and IMHO they look more appropriate on older cars. They are tough to find -
I used to buy mine from AutoMod in Atlanta.

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 19:45:14 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Idler Pulleys 944

Joe asks when do you know if the idler pulleys are bad on a 944;

Joe,
Porsche says the idler pulley bearings are bad if you can hear them when the
car is running. That's pretty subjective. The method I used when I changed
mine was to "feel"  them carefully. If they are rough when rotating or have
side to side play they get replaced. Several shops that I have asked have
said that the bearings are the most neglected area of the Porsche Cam Belt
conundrum. One shop accused the pulley as being the leading cause of belt
failure, the rational being that a bad bearing allows the belt to twist. 
Maybe someone can give you a more definitive answer. It just seems that while
you are doing the project you might as well take care of that variable.
I got my parts from Porsche BTW

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
7:23 pm

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 18:26:52 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Once again. . . toyotas...\

> Ok, I'm the guy who orignally started this thread.  Please indulge me 
> further with one more question.  The Porsches I am looking at are the 
> 1979-1981 911SC.  Although I am on a somewhat limited budget, I am not 
> indigent.  From what I gather, the mid-engine layout of the mr2 makes 
> repairs not too pleasant.  So, how about the maintainance costs of the 
> 79-81 911SC's?  Also, what is the general rule regarding milage on an 
> older Porsche.  I keep hearing the "300,000 miles without a major rebuild 
> is not unusual" line, if the car is properly maintained, should it last?  
> My friends mechanic is very good, so I am sure I will get a 911 with a 
> decent bill of health, but after that what can I expect?

Having raced MR-2s (and running the MR-2 digest, but that hardly makes
me an expert), as well as my P-car involvement, it might be time to
speak up here now that we've gone back to real content instead of
marque-centric flaming.

The MR-2 is a jumbo pain in the ass to work on. The good news is you 
don't need to do it very often when it's new. It's a great car to own
for the first 5-6 years. After, well... ever wonder why they Mk I
cars are so cheap? Thought not, but it might be time to start...

The 911 on the other hand is only *ocassionally* a jumbo pain in the ass
to work on, like when you're trying to reach a forearm that's 15 inches
around into a hole that's only 4 inches across... If you don't do *ANY*
of the work yourself, here's what you're looking at:

annual "major service" -- adjust valves, check CIS, change plugs, etc etc
is about $600-700, depending on where you get it done.

oil change, every 3000 miles or 3 months (so you need 3 of these plus the
major service) is about $85-120, depending on where you have it done and
if they use synthetic oil or not.

tires -- you'll eat a set of *good* tires (AVS Intermediates or similar)
every 12-14 months in the back at about $170 a tire. You'll need to
replace the fronts every other set of rears.

You *may* need valves and guides in the 100-150k mile range, depending on
whether or not the car has been well cared for, how lucky you are, etc.
The bottom end typically goes well over 200k, and 300k has been seen.
On the other hand, one typically gets "shipwright's disease" when doing the 
valves and says "well, as long as I'm already in there..." and then you
split the case and that's that...

Of course, you get into "stuff that should have been done before" like you may 
need shocks or a clutch or something. And "stuff that breaks" like
clutch cables, etc. And that's it.

Oh, and certainly, "improvements".... 8{)

Over five years, my 911 cost me *LESS* per year than my previous 3 street
cars (Volvo, Audi, Mercury). Once you factor out the "improvements" that
is... 

Stan
