------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 11:15:39 PST
From: Greg DesBrisay <gd@CellNet.com>
Subject: Re: '66 912 needs safety additions 



> Date: Tue, 06 Dec 1994 14:52:50 -0800
> From: Kathleen Urbanic <kurbanic@wpo.borland.com>
> 
> I'm looking for shoulder belts for the front seats of my '66 912, and belts
> for the back seats.  Any suggestions?  Currently there are only lap belts
> in the front.  I'm trying to cut down the amount of damage I'll do to the
> interior..


Kathleen,

Here's a copy of an old message from Stan with some suggestions about
shoulder belts.  I checked out the two suppliers he mentioned and came
to the same conclusions.  I got the shoulder belts from Carquip, and
I'm very happy with them.  The only downside is that they are not
automatically adjusting which can be a little awkward at times,
especially for passengers who aren't used to them, but the retractable
shoulder belts from P.E. Products require you to drill holes into the
posts behind your doors.  I didn't want to modify my 912 that way.

Oh, one small complication with the Carquip shoulder belts.  On 912s
and older 911s, the shoulder belt requires a standoff at the point
where the shoulder belt bolts to the chassis (see the 911/912 parts
catalog drawing; I can get the part number for you if you want).  The
standoff is apparently not required on 356s, so Carquip didn't include
them in the shipment originally, but they were quick to send me the
standoffs as soon as I gave them a call (they have a bunch of
dismantled cars from which they were able to pull the parts).  I was
very pleased with their service.


Greg DesBrisay,  gd@cellnet.com
'67 912


 -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Here's what Stan had to say about the shoulder belts in March of 1994;


> From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
> Subject: Re: 912/911 Seatbelt Mods
> To: mystic@halcyon.com (George K. Baldwin)
> Date: Mon, 28 Mar 1994 21:01:39 -40962758 (CST)
> 
>>  I have a '67 912 with original (factory or dealer ?) over the shoulder 
>>  seatbelts, that I would like to convert to more convenient retractable 
>>  types.  ...
>>  Has anyone suggestions re: available kits, 
>>  or parts from later 911/914's that might work?  Thanks for the help.
> 
> I recently decided I needed to add belts to my 356SC. I had a set of MOS
> (that's MOULDY old stock) belts that needed the brightwork polished and new
> webbing (pass), and knew of two other sources for new stuff: Tom Conaway at
> CarQuip in Boulder, and S. Lucas Valdes at P.E. Products in Los Osos.
> 
> Differences: The CarQuip belts were new production of the original factory
> style combo belt, which basicly has slide-the-belt-through-the-adjuster
> adjustments at the rear mount point for the shoulder harness and on the
> inboard belt mount. They were nice looking, and at $169 a set, not badly
> priced.
> 
> The P.E. Products belts were new Repla belts which were fully retractable
> and looked like late 9xx belts in function. They had nice mounting hardware
> and the pictures Mr. Valdes sent showed them off very nicely, made them
> look very much at home in the car, etc. These belts are also available for
> early 911/912s, and he also has replacement modules for all of the 9xx
> cars that use retractable Repla belts. Downside: price was like $180 a
> side, and they don't look very original.
> 
> Partly on price, and partly on look, I chose the CarQuip belts and like
> them very much so far. But I *AM* impressed with the P.E. Products
> line of belts, and would recommend them if that's what you want in your
> car.... And from the sound if it, that's just what you are looking for.
> 
> Stan

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 22:18:20 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: RE: 944T Coil-overs

In an answer to Jim Gregory, Kevin said:


>Answers are to the best of my knowledge.  I'm sure somone will correct
>me if I stray!

>>what type of coil-overs did the Escort (Turbo Cup) cars come with?

>Bilsteins.

Sorry. Turbo Cup cars came with Bilsteins.  Escort cars came with double
adjustable Konis.  How do I know?  We own an '87 Escort car!  
Why the difference?  Turbo Cup cars raced against other Turbo Cup cars, so
adjustables weren't needed.  Escort cars raced agasint Corvettes.  The
Corvettes had different Bilsteins for every track, along with other goodies.

Jon Lowe

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 95 22:09:57 EST
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>

but really to:   Brian_Foster_at_ASTIS at ccmailsmtp.ast.com
Subject: Don't do it!

Brian,

Please but don't sell the 356SC when the first baby is on the
way.  I've still got the (now a project) Berkeley from well
before I had a SO and the 356B was able (before restoration) to
convey my 3rd to his Senior Prom.  If you have the garage space
(or happy climate), keep the cars.  The money they bring won't
make a lot of difference in the big picture.  You don't have to
keep the licensed and insured all the time.

It's spring now .. and shortly my 356 will venture out.  Maybe this
is the summer to fix the Berkeley.  It is air cooled and engine
over the drive wheels as well.

BTW .. where is the 2002 tii on the WEB?  I hope to scan my 356 for
the P'philes collection soon.  And KEEP THE 356 FAITH .......

Rick

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 22:27:31 -0500
From: "Vijay K. Madisetti" <Vijay.Madisetti@ee.gatech.edu>
Subject: Porsche spectra...


FYI -

I can guess that the sound of a Porsche is music to all porschephile
ears - here is some technical information on these welcome vibes.

                                   low gear  high gear
       Porsche 911 - Frequency range   41 - 120 Hz
       VW Beetle     Frequency range   58 - 180 Hz
       Motorcycle    Frequency range   60 - 180 Hz

Those musical instruments that can technically recreate the
above sounds (at least the frequencies) would be the harp, bass tuba
and the French Horn.   Those lucky Baritones and Tenors among us can also,
in theory, mimic the Porsche sound :-).        

              - Vijay Madisetti
                Signal Processing Laboratory
                Georgia Tech
                69, 912, 71;   M-B 250, 71; Grand Prix Pontiac 71. 

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 95 22:23:45 EST
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>
Subject: Renting in Europe

A few years ago I took my family to England and Ireland for a few
weeks.  I looked into rental, but it was steep, so I went another
route.  I arrived in England Sunday morning, early.  By Sunday night
I had been through a set of local want ads and picked out a few potential
cars (remember they only need to last a couple of weeks).  Monday I
purchased a 68 Rover 2000 .. my first car with leather seats and my
only one with a deDion rear axle.  The cost was 150 pounds (a week's
rental for that size car).

Fortunately my insurance agent had an office in London, so I stopped
there for insurance and went to the Post Office for plates on Tuesday...
along with sight seeing.  DONE !!!  I drove the car five weeks with
10 pounds to patch two flat tires and balance the wheels.  That
plus gas and oil were the total cost.

I gave the car to my sister-in-law when I left.  She drove it for
six months (until it needed an new MOT inspection) and then sold
it for 100 pounds.  The insurance for a couple of weeks was trivial.

No it wasn't a Porsche, but it was a fun car and one I'm glad to
have owned.

Rick Dill... 356B and spring coming
Special Olympics World Games will be in Connecticut this summer!
Watch for them on TV in early July!

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 23:11:48 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Toyota vs 911

Hi all, sorry to add to this idiotic thread, but I have firsthand
knowledge in this area.

Last Weekend I drove a '93 MR-2 Turbo at the San Diego
Pro Solo. I have driven my '72 911S for ten years.


MR-2 Turbo vs Porsche 911 : The '93 MR-2 is very neutral and
	nimble. The ABS brakes are awesome! The 911 would have had several
	flat-spots on the front tires after the SD pro solo, and several 
	cones when I would have plowed under braking when I came in to the
	offsets too hot. But the MR-2 just pulsed a bit and turned in!
	The MR-2 is very kind to tires - our 226s wore perfectly evenly.

	   Of course the MR-2 shifter is a big advantage over the 911,
	which you don't PUT in gear but kindly RECOMMEND a gear.

	   The MR-2 comes off the line pretty good if you slip the clutch.
	But if you bog the engine, you lose big time.
	The turbo power is hard to deal with for me - it pulls weakly 
	when you nail it, then sneaks up on you. Never kicks you in the back
	like a 911, and no "on the cam" feel when the revs climb.

	   The MR-2 does not take a cornering set and dig in like the 911 - 
	it drifts a bit which I am not used to. Will be a good battle in
	A-Stock along with the new M3!


Anyway, all this is irrelevant as a few have pointed out - if
you have to ask if you should buy a Porsche then the answer is NO!
If you want to enjoy a relationship with a unique car that you
will always remember, get a 911. If not...

Regards, Mike Piera  AnalogMike@aol.com

No Cats (never have, never will)
12 or so vintage Guitars
100 or so vintage guitar effects
1 more trip to Europe this month (France)

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1259                         Wed Mar 22 02:00:05 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 23:32:32 -0500
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: 912 Restore ?

David,

I think you should consider the car you described as a 'parts' car. You can
find a reasonably good early 912 that would suffice as a driver in the $4,000
 - 7,000 range that won't need restoration if you spend some time looking.

We're doing a Project 912 at Porsche Market Letter that will end up as a
PCA/POC/Vintage Racer.  It had serious rust in the floor and front pan which
we have fixed with parts and labor by project sponsors.  But, this project
has once again proven to me that if you have to pay for major rust repair in
an early 911/912, most cars are too expensive even if they are given to you
free(they're still great parts cars though!).  There are exceptions of
course, but not 68 912 Coupes.

Phil VanBuskirk, Porsche Market Letter, (619)727-4856 Order line

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 00:45:18 -0500
From: Mgibson54@aol.com
Subject: re:racing brake fluid for street

Andrew,  I think the only problem with racing brake fluids id that they are
more hydrophilic than normal.  If you don't change your fluid frequently, you
risk possible H2O damage to your brake's internal components( I think that
means expensive).  I'm not sure how frequent is neccessary.  I'm flushing
every 100-150 track miles in the front of my early S and it needs it.  Every
other for the backs.  Any other ideas from racers out there?

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 21:52:48 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Hole in the Wall

Fred Castro (Cdaar1@aol.com) wrote:

>I'm thinking of installing an amplifier in my goofy-looking 911.  I may 
>have to run a lead through the trunkwall (bootwall? firewall?), and I 
>can't find an opening to run the power lead through.
>
>Any suggestions, advise, etc?

Fred:

If you really can't find a suitable existing hole and have to cut a new 
one, the only advice I have is to remember to line the hole with either 
a rubber or plastic grommet.

Oh, by the way... Make sure your wires are heavy enough to carry the 
current.  If the amplifier's fairly high-powered, switch power to it 
with a relay.

 -Andy


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 21:54:16 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: "Race" Brake Fluid

Someone asked about the wisdom of using "race" brake fluid in a street 
car.

The only thing to watch out for (besides the price of some of the 
fluids) is that a lot of the race fluids have very high DRY boiling 
points, but low WET boiling points.  This matters not to racers who 
change their fluid frequently, but it's a definite concern for the 
average street-car driver.

Of course, if you're only driving on the street, you may not need a 
really high-boiling-point fluid anyway.

 -Andy


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Mar 1995 21:57:28 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Wheel Spacers/Long Studs

Larry Herman (hermanhome@aol.com) wrote:

>Does anyone have any information on how SAFE it is to use longer wheel 
>studs with spacers on the track.  How about the bolt-on spacers that 
>use regular length studs.  I am interested in the strength of the 
>actual wheel mounting.

Larry:

Since 911 Turbos came from the factory with spacers and longer studs (at 
least, before the current Carrera-2 variations -- I don't know what the 
factory does to position the new more-positive offset wheels), I'd 
expect the combination to be perfectly safe.

The bolt-on spacers may be less safe... I don't know.  I do know that 4- 
to 5-lug adapters (like those used for mounting 5-spoke alloys on 
otherwise-stock 914-4s) are universally banned from competition, even 
for relatively light-duty use in PCA autocrosses.

 -Andy

P.S.  If you're using spacers on the front wheels, you may also want to
      keep in mind the effect they'll have on your steering offset.


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 95 08:33:46 +0100

> > accident and they found you were using not using seats designed for your car?
> > 
> PLEASE DONT GIVE THE B**TARDS ANY MORE BRIGHT IDEAS!!!


Err, Pete my old son, you're too late.. TA regulations currently existing in
numerous european countries will shortly become the EU standard which basically
means that *anything* that you fit to your car (wheels, seats etc) must be
TA'd for that application. Whilst it's not, perhaps, going to be a problem for 
most manufacurers of seats etc. to TA their products it will probably mean that
you can't just swap and change as you wish. Up 'til now the UK goverment has obtained
numerous exemptions from EU TA regs for the british market but how long they will
continue to do this (basically to protect UK manufacturers and small businesses)
is doubtfull and the EU will stop them at some point. Most folks in the UK (or EU!)
have *very* little idea of the amount of legislation hitting the EU about TA
(for everything) - motorcyclists have been the first hit 100PS limit story) - which
is small stuff compared to the effects of the coming multi-directive on noise,
emissions & TA. Bastards

I used to be very much in favour of the EU (after all, I live abroad..) but after
having seen the effect Swiss TA regs (and the strictness with which their applied
 - boring bunch of farts!) I would just hate for everybody else to get their rules
(which is basically what's happening) but it's going to happen whether I (or you) 
like it or not...

Kevin.

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 95 07:46:17 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 951 Steering Racks, etc.

Hello, Ross,

> While replacing my front control arm last night, I decided to try
> to isolate my power steering leak.  For the last two years the car
> has had a slight leak.  Over this winter it has gotten progressively
> worse.  I had assumed it was the pump until last night.  I checked
> my tie-rods by rolling the dust boot at the rack back and a significant
> amount of power steering fluid came out of each boot.  I'm assuming
> that this means a new rack.  Is my diagnosis correct?  Where is a 
> good place to get one?  I've seen an add in the back of Excellence 
> for a company that sells rebuilt racks for $250.  This seems like 
> a good price.  Unfortunately, I don't know anything about the company.
> I believe the add is on page 128 of the latest Excellence, but I 
> can't remember the name...  The next best price seems to be from
> Vertex at about $100 more.  Any advice would be much appreciated.

Yep, you need a rack. 

There are lots of rack rebuilders. Some just repaint them and call them
rebuilt. There is one that actually rebuilds them for PCNA, but he charges
more than $250.

> 
> What is the lists wisdom on putting in a manual rack?  Power steering 
s> really seems to be a waste on this small of car, in my opinion.
> What all is involved in switching from power to manual steering?

Don't put in a manual rack:

1) They were only available prior to 1984 and you are now looking at an 11
year-old rack in a much more capable car...

2) The manual rack is not as strong as the power rack, at least that's what
I have been told.

3) The manual rack has a slower steering ratio than the power rack.

If you really want, and your spouse doesn't object, and you don't do much
parallel parking, what you can do is remove the power steering pump,
reservoir, and cooling hose, and run the return hose back into the pressure
hose, right at the steering rack itself. 

Since the system is no longer under pressure, you will lose no more fluid.
And you regain the power that the pump was using. And you keep the same
quicker steering.

What you give up is the power assist at low speeds. Save the parts, and if
you don't like the fix, you can retrofit to original later...

Of course, this modification is permitted on cars that are not driven on the
highway, blather, blather, blather... :-)

> 
> Finally, my bad ball joint apparently took the tie-rod with it.
> Does any one have advice on where to look for a good price on
> a tie-rod?  Only the one side seems to have been affected.
> Is it alright to just replace the one?  

Boy, are you cheap!!..if you replace both of them now, you will save the cost
of another wheel alignment when you replace the other one six months from
now...

Do them both now...

Good luck,
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 95 07:58:00 PST
From: Browning David <BrowningD@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: Re: Bosch Plug Meltdown


Are these the so-called "K-mart" platinums or the "real" ones?

thanks
David B.
'89 944
'81 Rabbit (both run fine on the "K-mart" platinums)
 ----------
   This is a very common failure mode for the new style platinum plugs
   and I'm surprized the press hasn't picked it up. Seems that when the
   plug overheats, the wire slips down out of the ceramic and shorts out
   the plug. Maybe it doesn't have anything to do with overheating and is
   just a QC problem, but they all fail the same way. If the platinum is
   molded into place it would be easy to just swage it to keep it from
   slipping, but it looks like it's drawn through a hole in the ceramic



   

------------------------------

   From: porschephiles-request
   To: MDOYLE
   Cc: porschephiles
   Subject: Re: Spark Plugs
   Date: Friday, March 17, 1995 12:20PM

   Hello,

   Mark Doyle asked :

   >I saw those "KMART" Bosch platinum plug and almost bought some.  What is 

   > wrong with these plug?  Are they different than the Bosch platinums I
   > might buy elsewhere?

   No, these are the same ones you would get anywhere, but since
   K-Mart started pushing them a few years back, I couldn't resist
   calling them that.

   These plugs are easy to tell because they have the ceramic covered center
   electrode and are the only affordable Bosch platinums.
   I'm no Robert Bosch, but I think they are obviously bad, as the
   spark is squooshed inside a small area, and they don't work
   in many applications (foulm turn black, etc).

   The "REAL" Bosch platinums are about $15 each, and specified
   for the 911S and Turbos. But I've been happy with the Silver so far
   (but never ran on a real race track yet).

   Regards, Mike Piera  '72 911S Targa  In San Diego for the Pro Solo.

   

------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 08:18:37 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: My quirky 914...

<Howdy Porschephiles!  Let me tell you about my 1972 914-4 Gretchin. 
<Beautiful blazing red and nice on the curves.  But something's <strange... 


Dear Rick,

Loosening CV joints is a common occurance unless we adhere to the following:
1. Make sure CV joints are not too worn and packed full of grease. A dry or
worn CV will actually run "unbalanced" and loosen the bolts.
2. Install CV joint gaskets between the CV and output flange or stub axle.
3. Properly install two roll pins, 2 half moon locking plates, four 8x46 CV
joint bolts and four seradded cone washers torquing the bolts to 31 ft.lbs.
4. Periodically check the bolts for tightness (every 10,000 miles).

If you do the above, the joints will not loosen!

George Hussey


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 08:19:20 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Valve Adjust


        <One more 914 question/sanity check from this weekend:
<The idea behind getting the piston at TDC to do a valve adjust is
<to get on the "round" section of the cam--i.e., the part that isn't
<calling for any valve opening.  This should also be where the valve
<clearance is the greatest, right?
       < The reason I'm asking is:  I put #1 at TDC by using the '0'
<mark on the fan, and the notch on the flywheel (which, BTW, seem to
<be about 0.5-1.0 degrees apart...)  I then checked and adjusted #1.
<Rotate the crank 180 degrees; hey!  Paint mark on both fan and fly-
<wheel!  Cool!  Did #4 (I think it was), etc.  At one point, I poked
<a feeler gauge into a valve gap for a piston not at TDC--the other
<valve was depressed.  The gap was bigger, by about .002 or so!  I
>re-checked both valves back at TDC, and they were fine!
        <Does the stock 914 (2.0) cam go "negative" anywhere?  If <not,
<what the heck did I do?
        <Thanks!


Dear Dave,

It sounds like its time to print the Dr.914 valve adjustment procedure! Good
luck!

PROPER VALVE ADJUSTMENT

Proper valve adjustment is critical to proper engine operation. Since the 914
engine is air cooled, it operates in a much broader temperature range than a
water cooled car, resulting in more extreme expansion and contraction. This
movement necessitates periodic valve adjustment.

Tools required are as follows:

1. Feeler gauge of at least 8" in length to access the adjuster

2. Pry bar screwdriver to unlatch the valve cover bales and turn the front
fan

3. Spark plug wrench

4. Tire tool, jack, jackstands

5. Crate, milk carton, or small step ladder to stand on

6. 13 mm box wrench to loosen locking nut valve adjuster

7. Short wide-bladed screwdriver to turn the adjusting lugs

8. A small piece of cardboard with a 90 degree edge

9. Stick of bright white touch-up paint

10. 2 valve cover gaskets

11. Can of Brake Clean

12. Several valve adjusting lugs

We begin by removing the spark plugs, the timing hole plug and unclipping the
distributor cap. With the spark plugs removed, one should be able to turn the
fan by hand, although the pry bar can assist through the timing hole. Make
sure you pry against the rear of the fan blades as the front of the blades
are unattached and will easily shear. (You may notice that some of the blades
are already missing from past mistakes! If more than three in a row are
missing, you must replace the fan.) Turn the fan until you notice the "0"
mark show through the timing hole (on 1.8 liter engines this is the red 7
degree mark and on 1.7, 2.0 it is either stamped "0" or a white mark. Do not
mistake the "0" mark for the (1.7, 2.0) 27 degree BTDC (Before top dead
center) mark which is located just to the right passenger side of one of four
big, thick fan blades.) Lift the distributor cap and observe the distributor
rotor. The firing portion should face towards the number one spark plug wire
tower. If your distributor is installed properly, the rotor will be in the 10
o'clock position (considering the front of the car is 12 o'clock). If the
rotor is facing 180 degrees opposite, turn the fan again until the "0" degree
mark shows and the rotor will now be pointing towards the number one spark
plug tower. We are now ready to adjust the valves on the number one spark
plug tower. We are now ready to adjust the valves on the number one cylinder
(the driver's side rear cylinder).

Loosen the wheel nuts and jack the car (under the engine mounting bar) to a
height where, in a sitting position, the fender well clears your head. Place
jackstands under the jacking donuts and make sure the car rests solidly. It
is wise to leave the jack under the car - just in case. Remove the left valve
cover by wedging the bale from the cover. Valve adjustment access is tight,
so it takes practice to perfect the technique.

Since we have already set up to adjust cylinder number one, we can adjust
those valves (both intake and exhaust) immediately. Slide the feeler gauge in
between the adjusting lug and the top of the valve "feeling" the gap. Valves
in perfect adjustment nip the gauge snugly; valves too loose let the tool
sloppily slide in. Valves too tight will not let the gauge pass. To adjust,
loosen the 13 mm locking nut with the box wrench and turn the lug with the
short screwdriver. It is a good idea at this time to inspect the valve
adjusting lugs for damage by completely unscrewing the lug from the rocker
arm. (1973 2.0 valve adjusting lugs will not unscrew without removing the
rocker arm assemblies, so don't try it!) Slight wear on the bottom of the lug
is common, however, if the lug looks pock-marked, it needs replacement.
Adjusting lugs worn in this manner will cause premature valve stem wearout
and a noisy power train! Adjust both intake and exhaust valves of the number
one cylinder, then snug the locking nuts. Specifications for adjustment are
as follows:


1970-75 1.7 and 1.8 .006 inches

1973-76 2.0 .006 intake/.008 exhaust


The intake valves are always the two in the middle of the rocker arm assembly
and exhaust valves are the outboard two. We are now ready to adjust the
number four or the passenger side front cylinder.

Standing on our milk carton (unless you are 6'8"), we recheck the timing mark
to make sure it has not moved and then hold our 90 degree angled cardboard on
top of the rotor, rotating the fan until the rotor moves 90 degrees
clockwise. (The firing point of the rotor will move from being in line with
one side of the cardboard to being in line with the other side.) The reason
we do this is to align the exact firing point for the number four cylinder.
(The engine fires each of the 90 degrees as the distributor rotates clockwise
1, 4, 3, 2.) When we have established that the rotor has moved exactly 90
degrees, we then look down at the fan through the timing hole and use our
white touch-up to mark the fan in the "V" observation notch. This mark now
gives us a reference point for the firing of the number 4 and the number 2
cylinders. (Remember the "0" for (1.7, 2.0) or the red mark (1.8) are still
the firing points for number 1 and 3 cylinders.) We now adjust the number
four. or the passenger side cylinder, in the manner previously described.

After adjusting the number four cylinder, we again go to the top of the
engine and turn the fan. This causes the rotor to move clockwise another 90
degrees to the firing point of the number three cylinder. There is no need to
use the cardboard as when we achieve the 90 degree clockwise turn, the white
(or red 1.8) timing mark will again show! We then adjust the number three, or
the passenger side rear cylinder again by the method previously described.
Our final valve to adjust is of course number two, or the driver's side front
cylinder.

When we turn the fan and watch the rotor move clockwise its final 90 degrees,
we will see our painted mark show when the 90 degrees is achieved. We finally
adjust number two in the manner previously described and then recheck the
valve adjusting nut tightness on all cylinders.

Installing the valve covers is next. If you want to avoid leaks, please read
thoroughly! Carefully check the valve cover gasket mounting surfaces for
leftover gasket material, glue or other debris. Clean the entire cover with
Brake Clean or mineral spirits and dry thoroughly. Place the valve cover
gasket into the cover, pushing it into the two holders and stretching the
shape so it sits perfectly in the cover. If the gasket is kinked or crooked,
you may use a slight dot of black weather-strip adhesive to hold the gasket's
shape in the cover. Do not use gasket cement or glue - it makes a mess, could
fall into the engine and could make it difficult to remove the covers when
valve adjustment is next due.

Place the valve cover against the cylinder head squarely holding it tightly
down and wedge the bale over the cover with the pry bar. If you don't hold
the cover tightly while wedging the bale , it will cockeye and you will have
to begin the whole process again.

When you are sure the valve covers are properly seated, climb back to the top
of the engine, clip on the distributor cap, install the spark plugs, screw in
the timing hole plug and then start the engine. It is important here to let
the engine run for five minutes to check for leaks and excessive valve train
noise. Leaks are caused by cockeyed valve covers and noise:  a mis-adjusted
valve.

If everything checks out, install the wheels and tires and snug the lug
bolts. Jack the car up, remove the jackstands and let the car down. Torque
the lug bolts to 90 foot pounds.

Congratulations!! You have now completed a proper 914 valve adjust and have
helped assure long engine life and optimum performance!


George Hussey

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 95 09:01 EST

From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>

    3 fluid.  I probably even got it from P-files (like everything else), but a
    few of the local SCCA "shoes" are happy with it.  Cost me a bit over $5 a
    pint, has a 572 deg F dry boiling point.  My only data point so far is with

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 08:15:22 -0600
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: Re Hole in the Wall

Fred,

I mounted an amplifier under the passenger seat of my '87 911.  I routed the
power cables along side of the fender and up over the ducting to the passenger
side of the car.  Up above the passenger foot well there are two holes with
cables and rubber boots.  These are big enough to stretch and squeeze the
power cables thru also.  I think I used 6-8 guage copper.  Can't really
remember, but it seemed pretty thick.

Also, if you mount under the passenger seat, there are a couple threaded nuts
welded on the floor pan already.  I think they are for mounting the motronic
on English versions.  Anyway, except for the door holes for the speaker
components, my system went in with zero cutting/drilling.  I figure I can get
new door panels if I want to restore to original.

I'll check again what I did in case I need to update this posting.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
  Wayne D. Michelsen                | W_Michelsen@lfht1.hso.link.com
  '87 911 Targa [Guards-Red/Black]  | RedAcorn@aol.com

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 95 9:07:53 CST
From: jjholt@holt.b11.ingr.com (Jeff Holt)
Subject: 944 oil cooler question


I've got my '86 944 in a shop for some major work (water pump, belts and
engine mounts). I'd heard there was an updated oil cooler on 944s, and it
turns out that I have a 5R, which is the old style apparently.

The car has 100k miles, and there is no sign of oil in the coolant.
Anyone know the story about oil coolers? I seem to vaguely recall
seeing on the list or hearing that there may have been a recall on this,
or at least an update recommendation. Am I living on borrowed time?


With respect to 944 maintenance - my 944 has been great. I did what everone
said not to do - fell in love and bought it at an auction, with no records 4
years and 30,000 miles ago.

Spent $600 replacing belts, fluids, filters etc. Since then this is
the first time I've spent any money on the car except for routine
maintenance (which is very cheap and easy to do at home on 944s).

Just my 2c worth.

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 95 11:05:30 US/Eastern

> or at least an update recommendation. Am I living on borrowed time?

Ain't broke, don't fix it...

Oil coolers on cars earlier than 87 seem to last a long time. It was only in
1987 when Porsche updated the design that they started to have problems.

good luck

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 95 11:14:04 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: 914 Valve Adjust

>It sounds like its time to print the Dr.914 valve adjustment procedure! Good
>luck!
> ... (lots of good advice deleted)
>
>Standing on our milk carton (unless you are 6'8"), we recheck the timing mark
>to make sure it has not moved and then hold our 90 degree angled cardboard on
>top of the rotor, rotating the fan until the rotor moves 90 degrees
>clockwise. (The firing point of the rotor will move from being in line with
>one side of the cardboard to being in line with the other side.) The reason
>we do this is to align the exact firing point for the number four cylinder.
>(The engine fires each of the 90 degrees as the distributor rotates clockwise
>1, 4, 3, 2.) When we have established that the rotor has moved exactly 90
>degrees, we then look down at the fan through the timing hole and use our
>white touch-up to mark the fan in the "V" observation notch. This mark now
>gives us a reference point for the firing of the number 4 and the number 2

My 74 914-2 had a notch in the flywheel which aligned with the case
center (viewed from the bottom of the car) when the engine was TDC on
#2 and #4. This may be both easier and more accurate than the 90 Deg.
cardboard trick. Of course you don't need perfect TDC accuracy for this
job. I ended up putting a paint mark on the pulley for #2 and #4 TDC,
as you did, except using the bottom mark for a reference. I also put
a mark on the flywheel (I used a few center punch marks in a row)
corresponding to #1 and #3 TDC, so I could find everything from either
the top or the bottom, without going back and forth. You can put the car
in 5th gear, and lock the emergency brake on one side, then just turn
the other rear wheel to move from one cylinder to the next, all from
the bottom. I don't know if the whole 914 model line had this flywheel
notch for #2 and #4, or if I was just lucky. I seem to remember a reference
in the 914 shop manual mentioning the notch, but it has been a while.

>...
>Installing the valve covers is next. If you want to avoid leaks, please read
>thoroughly! Carefully check the valve cover gasket mounting surfaces for
>leftover gasket material, glue or other debris. Clean the entire cover with
>Brake Clean or mineral spirits and dry thoroughly. Place the valve cover
>gasket into the cover, pushing it into the two holders and stretching the
>shape so it sits perfectly in the cover. If the gasket is kinked or crooked,
>you may use a slight dot of black weather-strip adhesive to hold the gasket's
>shape in the cover. Do not use gasket cement or glue - it makes a mess, could
>fall into the engine and could make it difficult to remove the covers when
>valve adjustment is next due.

Be especially careful of the top of the gasket. The car won't leak on 
the garage floor, but will leak like crazy under hard cornering, when
a lot of oil accumulates in the cover. Don't ask me how I know this.
Just note that there still aren't many miscuitos -uh- muisquitos oh,
hell, bugs- around the left-hander at Lime Rock. I ended up using RTV,
just between the cover and the gasket, to be sure everything stayed
in place, but still allowing easy removal of the cover and gasket
next time. RTV is reasonably easy to remove from the cover, once you
pull off the gasket. Don't use very much. You don't want any "extra"
to cause a problem.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 08:24:38 -0800

You wrote: 

>
>

real 
>ones look like the normal copper one's?  I've seemed to have no trouble 
with 
>these platinums over the past several years since they came out.  I've 
>usually bought them at some time of Nationwise/NAPA type auto store.  
Have I 
>been swindled all this time???  I've never heard of two types of 
Platinums. 
> Not even from mechanic types.  What's up?  Are they still better than 
the 
>normal copper plugs?  Where do I get real ones and/or silver tipped 
ones.
>What about the three-electrode plugs???
>
>Thanks,
>David B.
>'89 944 (with apparently counterfeit platinums)
>
>P.S.  My dad says from his experience that VW's at least HATE 
Champions.  Is 
>this true for other German marques?
> ----------
>   From: porschephiles-request
>   To: MDOYLE
>   Cc: porschephiles
>   Subject: Re: Spark Plugs
>   Date: Friday, March 17, 1995 12:20PM
>
>   Hello,
>
>   Mark Doyle asked :
>
>   >I saw those "KMART" Bosch platinum plug and almost bought some.  
What is 
>
>   > wrong with these plug?  Are they different than the Bosch 
platinums I
>   > might buy elsewhere?
>
>   No, these are the same ones you would get anywhere, but since
>   K-Mart started pushing them a few years back, I couldn't resist
>   calling them that.
>
>   These plugs are easy to tell because they have the ceramic covered 
center
>   electrode and are the only affordable Bosch platinums.
>   I'm no Robert Bosch, but I think they are obviously bad, as the
>   spark is squooshed inside a small area, and they don't work
>   in many applications (foulm turn black, etc).
>
>   The "REAL" Bosch platinums are about $15 each, and specified
>   for the 911S and Turbos. But I've been happy with the Silver so far
>   (but never ran on a real race track yet).
>
>   Regards, Mike Piera  '72 911S Targa  In San Diego for the Pro Solo.
>
>   
>
>

The "REAL" plugs that Mike refers to are the "DPO" series.  The 
electrode is on the side, not over top, of the tip.  They're good plugs, 
ungodly expensive, but last much longer than the cheaper ones.  I've 
used W5DPOs in my '72 911T for the last few years and swear by them.  I 
pulled a set out after 18 months last weekend and they were still in 
pretty good shape.  The plugs actually last longer than a set of points 
in my car.

Doug Thompson
'72 911T Targa

Date: 22 Mar 1995 11:31:15 -0500
From: cbennet@lmcorp.com (Chris Bennet)
Subject: 911: Motronic Aware Gurus


As I was driving my '86 Carrera to work this morning it died as if
someone had turned the key off and then turned it back to the
"on" position - you know the guages working and the oil light
on, etc.  After recovering from the oil light induced heart attack
I tried to start the car - nothing but the guages flicking to their 
"totally off" position.  [I was thinking that just this week I had said
that my Porsche had never left me stranded...]  I still had power (the
radio still worked for instance). Then I remembered that I had just 
slipped the battery cables over the battery posts without tightening them.
["Just to pull it into the garage."] 
I tightened them the battery cables and felt under the drivers seat for
the brain box and wiggled a little.  I tried starting it again and all was
well.
Question: Should disconnecting the battery cause the car to stop running ?
[I would never do this on purpose for fear of frying the brain so I don't
dare
experiment.]

Wanted:  My toolkit is missing the fan belt pulley spanner wrench.  Does
anyone have a one they'd like to sell ?

  vrooom,
    Chris
    cbennet@lmcorp.com

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 09:08:10 -0800
From: tfrazer@sonic.net (Thomas Frazer)
Subject: Re: '66 912 needs safety additions

I installed P.E. Products belts in my '64 356SC coupe last year and am very
happy with them.  Admittedly, I blanched a bit when I got the bill, but
they work very well and are of very high quality. P.E. Products offered
very good support for the installation which took about 2.5 hours.  My only
complaint is that the plastic guide tends to hang up the webbing for
retraction sometimes.
Just my $0.02

Tom Frazer
356SC (still kinda on the market) and other stuff to insure and polish :)

in bright red is a bit of a clue as to whats underneath. Price in the
UK is 

Do it now..I hear they won't be producing too many of these..

If I may second kindly old uncle Bart and endorse the Audi 200 Quattro
Wagon.  A fine looking rig, completely troublefree in 3.5 years and 48,000
miles.  It handles neutrally, although I've wished for a bit more roll
control.  Once the boost is up, whee!  A fine car to show up at the ski
slopes.  And it's much more a driver's car than an SUV or minivan (although
the Renault F1 minivan has potential...)

If you have to sell the 930, it's a fine alternative.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 13:07:32 -0500
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bartonc@annap.infi.net>
Subject: Re: 944 advice

Hi there,

Most recent is always best for any Porsche.  (Porsche makes running changes, not
waiting for new model year like most).

WRT 944 vs 911 for same cost: Main consideration is which do *you* prefer?
Another, no inconsequential factor to consider is that *very* few cars made 
retain their value as well as the 911, so you might, say for $17.5K, get a 6 
year old 951 (944 turbo), or a 14 year old 911 (SC).  The 951 will out perform
the SC, except in the retained-value arena.  the longer you keep the cars,
the greater the 911s advantage over the 944 (or any wter pumper, even the 928s,
which cost a *Lot* more than the 911 when both were new).

While you can't ignore (OK, You may, but I sure as hell can't) financial 
considerations, beyond determining whether you can *afford* to *own* a 
Porsche, the model you choose should be the one that floats *your* boat!

Bart
'86 Carrera Cabriolet (can't afford it, can't afford not to have it...)

Ed,

What makes you think that a 20 year old 911 can't out handle a
2 year old MR-2?

The basic suspension of a '72 911S is the same as a '89 Carrera.
Without major modification, a '72 911S can be made to handle
better than a '94 Carrera 2.

Sure, a stock '72 911S with stock wheels and tires cannot compete
with today's sports cars. But I can guarantee that Mike's '72 911S
is better than stock.

Scott Winders
winders@support.apple.com

                      weapon)

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 95 13:15:44 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: 944 oil cooler question

>> I've got my '86 944 in a shop for some major work (water pump, belts and
>> engine mounts). I'd heard there was an updated oil cooler on 944s, and it
>> turns out that I have a 5R, which is the old style apparently.
>> 
>> The car has 100k miles, and there is no sign of oil in the coolant.
>> Anyone know the story about oil coolers? I seem to vaguely recall
>> seeing on the list or hearing that there may have been a recall on this,
>> or at least an update recommendation. Am I living on borrowed time?
>> 
>
>Ain't broke, don't fix it...
>
>Oil coolers on cars earlier than 87 seem to last a long time. It was only in
>1987 when Porsche updated the design that they started to have problems.

I tend to agree with the general conclusion of not doing anything,
but weren' there oil cooler problems on earlier 944's as well? I seem to
remember technical bulletins on shims under the seals, and an upgraded
cooler housing for the early (pre 87) cars. In 87 they incorporated
all of the fixes, and then screwed up on the O-rings themselves, many
of which needed to be replaced (including mine). Perhaps the problems on
the early cars were frequent enough to require a TB, but not so frequent
that most cars had them (my impression is that a relatively large fraction
of the 87 cars have the seal problem, at some point).

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 13:30:42 -0500
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 advice, (long)

Paul

You will probably get a lot of responses, here is my $.02.

I currently have an 86 944, I think it is a great car. Things you should know
about 944s in general:

The model came out in 1983. There was a major update done halfway through the
model year in 1985. You will see some cars advertised as 85.5s, those cars
are the same as 86 and 87. Some of the improvements are to the suspension,
and electrical system. If you can afford it, I suggest you restrict your
search to the 85.5 or newer cars. These are currently in the range of $7000
and up (here on the east coast) for a good condition, normally aspirated 944.
In 1986 a Turbocharged car was offered. The turbo has 217 HP (as opposed to
150 for normally aspirated 944), bigger brakes, and stiffer shocks. In 1987 a
16 valve 944 was offered, the 944S. The 944 S was sold in 1987 and 1988 and
had 188HP. In 1988 the displacement of the standard 944 was increased from
2.5 to 2.7 litres. Also in 1988 a special version of the turbo was sold, the
Turbo S model. The Turbo S was rare, only about 400 were produced. The TurboS
has 247HP, bigger brakes, and an even stiffer suspension. In 1988 there were
5 different 944s, the standard 944, 944S, 944 Turbo and 944 TurboS, and the
924s (924 bodywork and suspension, 944 powertrain). ABS and dual airbags
became standard in 1988 (some say 1987). In 1989 the number of 944s dropped
to three, standard 944, 944 Turbo (same as 88 Turbo S), and 944 S2, with a
3.0 litre 16 valve engine (210 HP). In 1990, there were just two cars, 944S2
coupe, and 944S2 cabriolet. 1991 was the last year for 944, the 968 was sold
in 1992. The most desirable 944 is the 88 TurboS or 89 Turbo. Prices for
these cars are in the 18-22K range.

In order to give advice on which model to purchase requires more information.
What do you intend to do with the car? Drive it on weekends, daily, on the
track? Who is going to perform the maintenance, you, local mechanic, dealer,
porsche specialist? What is your budget?

I prefer the 944 over the 911, but I don't have that much 911 experience. The
944 is much cheaper, but the 911 will hold it's value much better. Unless you
are talking about an OLD 911, the only comparably priced 944 would be a newer
S2, or TurboS. This would probably compare to an mint condition 911SC, or an
84+ Carerra. The 944 would have ABS and dual airbags, the 911 would not. The
944 would have the same or more HP, and better balance. But it is not a 911,
which has appeal to a large number of people. When people think of Porsche,
they think 911, not 944.

If you answer some of the other questions, I can give you more advice.

Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@aol.com

P.S. My 1986 944 is for sale. I am in NY, let me know if you want more info.
P.P.S If I missed anything, I'm sorry, please correct me

------------------------------

Hi, Frank

I have never heard the owner of an 1983-1986 944 owner complain about his
personal experience of failure of an oil cooler. Anybody out there have an
evidence to the contrary?

BTW, I routinely dismantle 944 motors with no indication of failure or
replacement (mileages up to 200K).

Of course, my limited experience is only one datapoint.

Kevin, I'm going to go against the tide (and probably regret it later). 
Making a few assumptions, my suggestion would be an older BMW 535is. You get 
the room and a RWD car that's enjoyable to drive without spending a lot more 
than the value of your 930.

Assumptions (that no one to this point has considered)
 - your 1980 930 and a small note won't complete a newer Audi, BMW, etc... 
purchase
 - you may not have the room to keep the 930
 - you are selling the 930 for the money for the next car

these would be _all_ valid reasons for me if my girlfriend forced me to 
marry her and had triplets. But since their not DON'T SELL IT!!! BIG 
MISTAKE!!! (but I'm sure you knew that or you would have never asked us for 
a suggestion)

(BTW does anyone know of a good BMW mechanic in Boston for her 325?)

------------------------------

Date: 22 Mar 95 14:38:48 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Shipping cars to Germany

Hi, Peter.
 
I've worked in Germany for 5 years. I shipped 3 cars from there to here, one
by air (went in the back of the 747 I was riding, picked up from U.S.
Customs the next day) and 2 by container. I have never had a problem, I know
how it works, and it's not that difficult. Trond can tell you the same thing.
And you know about rental costs over there. I would leave the car with
friends for a year or two, so I have wheels whenever I fly over. I have lots
of mileage points to burn off in the next couple of years.
 
If nothing else, my second-owner C coupe would absolutely walk away with the
local concours awards in Germany, judging by the patched-up trash I've seen
posing as "Kalifornien-kar" over there. We have a higher standard of
originality over here, and better basis material.
 
Pete

> Kevin writes:
> 
> >Circumstances dictate that the 2+2 911 must go (suicide permitting) as it is
> >impractical to fit 3 little girls in the back with one big girl in the front.
> 
> >What can I replace it with thats paractical for the above family - weekend
> fun
> >time rather than daily grind. Any realistic suggestions may brighten the
> mood.

If you are in Europe, Japan, or several other places, there are some very 
interesting alternatives to a Porsche 930. :-)

How about an Audi Avant RS2? Porsche-built, Porsche alloys, and 315 hp 
out of a 20v inline-5. It will hold five and their luggage as well.

Or a BMW M5 Touring. 340 hp BMW 5-series wagon with the suspension from 
the M5 sedan, I believe.

In the US:

Volvo 850 Turbo Sportwagon- 222 hp from a 20v turbo inline-5, and a 
5-speed manual option (I think, not sure of this).

BMW 530i Touring (I don't know if you can get this with a 5-speed)

And if you can go with a sedan:
Leftover BMW M5
Leftover Mercedes E500
BMW 540i 6-speed
Audi S6
AMG C36
BMW M3

And finally, as someone else has said, you can always just get a decent
used station wagon or minivan for the kids and keep the 930.

- --

Porschephiles #1262                         Wed Mar 22 22:50:08 CST 1995
Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 15:57:36 -0500 (EST)
From: Richard Hollander <ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us>
Subject: Re: 944 advice

If I had the choice between a 944 Turbo and a 911 of equal price, and 
assuming both cars are comparable in condition, miles, etc., I'd go for 
the 944 Turbo. It's much better handling, much more quiet inside, it 
rides better, and it offers slightly better performance with a minimal 
amount of "fiddling." Yet, if "looks" and status, plus admittance to the 
"gold chain crowd" are what you're after, go for the 911. (No offense to 
911 owners.)


RickSH
ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us

Date: 22 Mar 95 13:13:41 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: spark plugs I like


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  spark plugs I like
Date: 1995-03-22 15:12
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Like Mike Piera, I found my early 911 motor was finicky about plugs ('72E).
 I did some stop watch testing a few years back and actually found a
difference (slight) between a few that I tried.  The ones I tried then were
:

NGK Gold Palladium (whatever...)
NGK Std.
Bosch Copper
Bosch Platinum
ND U-Groove (absolutely were horrible!!)

This also happens to be the order of how I like them.  The most notable
difference was between the NGK Golds and *any* of the others.  These plugs
are about $5 each nowadays.  You could feel a difference mostly in the lower
rpm range between the NGK Gold and the others (except ND) -- the ND's would
barely even run...  BTW,  I have had super bad luck with Champions on just
about anything I've tried to run them in with cracking insulators to just
crappy firing.  Oh, and since we're on the plug topic; I was one that took
advantage of the 30 day money back guarantee on the Splitfires, they ran
marginally better than NDs.

IMHO, I would run the NGK Golds in any fuel happy application (carbs or
inefficient F.I.) they seem to self-clean much better than others I've
tried.  The Carrera seems to be happy with the K-Mart Bosch Platinum's, but
I'll replace them as soon as my NGK order comes in....  Oh and the tow and
commute slugs get about anything that's on sale -- Autolite, A/C, etc... --
they seem to be happy that I even look under their hoods!!  :-)

As always, YMMV!!

 -Scott Jessen
'72 911 (3.2) AX dedicated and looking forward to the TX Pro Solo!!
'84 Carrera (thinking about a chip...)
3 cats, 1 dog (thinking about getting de-flea'd)
1 S.O. (thinking about what color driving suit she wants)

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 95 15:52:26 cst
From: "emontgo" <emontgo@cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Exhibit Number 1/ Oil Cooler Failure 

     George,
     
     Mine went last summer to my suprise. At the risk of sounding really 
     stupid to you all, because I didn't know, heres what happen. I was 
     getting that brown milky substance in my antifreeze. I thought at 
     first that I must have a leak in my head gasket. Only problem is when 
     you have a leak in your head gasket you get the muck in your oil not 
     in your anti freeze. Plus the car will usually over heat quickly. 
     I took it to my normal Euro-mechanic. He said it was odd but it must 
     be a head gasket also. So I made an appointment to get the engine 
     basically rebuilt. Figuring if their that far into the engine I might 
     as well get it all done. 
     While casually talking to mom that day I told her about the problem 
     and her wise words were, Call an authorized Porsche dealer. Let me 
     explain, here in Iowa there is one P-Car dealer and he's a hundred 
     miles away. She said,"If it don't seem right it probably isn't." This 
     coming from a woman that thinks my 944 is cute but doesn't see any 
     difference between it and my sisters Honda Prelude.
     She was right! Without any hesitation he told me that it was the 
     cooler and that they have to fix these all of the time. 
     The good thing was it was only $300. The bad thing was I lost a good 
     mechanic because I wont go back there again. They would have changed 
     the head gasket and I still would have had the problem.
     Sorry to go so long about this but maybe it will save someone else 
     some greef.
     I have been reading lately about the recalls on these and have been 
     wondering if mine was part of the recall.
     
     Ed Montgomery
     '86 944 Alpine White


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 17:04:48 -0500 (EST)
From: "Derek Cahill" <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: 911: Motronic Aware Gurus

In message 22 Mar 1995 11:31:15 -0500,
  cbennet@lmcorp.com (Chris Bennet)  writes:
> As I was driving my '86 Carrera to work this morning it died as if
> someone had turned the key off and then turned it back to the
> "on" position - you know the guages working and the oil light
> on, etc.  After recovering from the oil light induced heart attack
> I tried to start the car - nothing but the guages flicking to their
> "totally off" position.  [I was thinking that just this week I had said
> that my Porsche had never left me stranded...]  I still had power (the
> radio still worked for instance). Then I remembered that I had just
> slipped the battery cables over the battery posts without tightening them.

> I tightened them the battery cables and felt under the drivers seat for
> the brain box and wiggled a little.  I tried starting it again and all was
> well.
> Question: Should disconnecting the battery cause the car to stop running ?
> [I would never do this on purpose for fear of frying the brain so I don't
> dare
> experiment.]
Yes. What this does is keep the full battery power from getting to the fuel
injectors and the engine will stop running. You will have the power to run
the radio and some gauges and the like, but not enough to run the injectors.
This same problem happens on our '85 Buick all the time. The radio and such
will work, but the thing loosens up enough to keep the car from starting up.

Oh, for the experiment, all that should happen is that your engine should
just go 'click' and die. No fuel = no go. But why do this and lose all your
radio stations and such? :)

Disconnecting the battery and running a car without injectors does no harm
(to my knowledge) which is why you can still push/pull-start a car without
injectors.

Since your car has entered this 'golden' age, it would be wise to carry the
box end wrench that fits your battery so that you can promptly leap out of
the car and tighten it. (This was our $1.99 Kmart solution for the Buick)

 -Derek Cahill

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 95 12:46:35 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: Eezibleed (Re: Ford HD Brake Fluid)

| From: Tracy M Nelson  <tnelson@telesciences.com>
| To:  <porschephiles@tta.com>
|
| what recommendations do people have for brake bleeders?  I
| remember Stan mentioned something called an "eezeebleed" (sp?) a couple days
| ago, but I haven't seen anything by that name.  Is that just a 
generic term, or
| an actual product?  The only brake bleeders I've seen are Mityvacs in 
the US$50
| range.  The price isn't a problem, but I'd like to know that I'm getting the
| right thing.

The Mityvac is a suction system that you attach at the caliper bleeding nipple.
Its major drawback, from what I understand, is that it can suck air in 
from around
the bleed nipple's threads so that you never really know when the air is out of
the system.

The Eezibleed pressurizes the master cylinder fluid resevoir so that fluid is
forced out of the bleed nipple when you open it. The Eezibleed must be
connected to a source of moderatly pressurized air, such as a spare tire or,
if you have a collapsing/compact spare, a 12v air pump.

I made a variation of an Eezibleed out of a small regulator, some fittings,
and an old fliud resevoir cap and run it off of my compressor. The output
of the regulator is about 10 psi.

Of course, if you are using any of these systems, you must make sure that
the resevoir fluid level never gets too low or you will force air back into the
system at the worst possible point.

A guy advertises the Eezibleed in Pano: $33.00, shipping included.
John Abbot, Dept P, 2574 NW 29th Dr. Boca Raton, FL 33434
800-795-6958
This isn't an endorsement; I've never done business with Mr. Abbot.

    Eric

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 15:15:29 -0800 (PST)
From: JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: Re: 914 drivers door difficult to close.

>This could come from afew problems.  You should check to see if the car is 
>saging.  This would be more apparent with the top removed.  Do you see any body 
>panel movement when you close the door? You should check under the rocker panel 
>for structural inegrity of the frame.  If it is rusted through, you have found 
>the problem.  The simpler problem would be that the locking mechanisim is dirty 
>and needs to be cleaned and relubricated.  The only way to deal with this is to 
>remove the door panel and carefully remove the lock and latching mechanism and 
>clean the parts with a cleaner that will not attack plasic.
>
>Craig Z.
>'74 914 2.0L

Craig,

	I don't believe there is any significant sagging. As a matter of
fact, I have a better time closing the door with the top off. But that
might be because I can hold the door itself and not the handle. Better
leverage that way. Either way, it doesn't close with a happy mechanical '
click' like the passenger side door does. It needs a hard slam to fully
latch. Alot of the time it closes, but doesn't fully latch, and I have to
try again...


 -Josh

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 17:26:41 -0600
From: "Richard Hocking" <hocking@cig.mot.com>
Subject: Eezibleed and other systems

I guess I don't quite understand the advantages of these $30-40 bleeding
systems over the $2  1-way valve + a foot of clear pipe that I use.

Basically, my cheap system involves putting the 1-way valve over the
bleed nipple, cracking the nipple and pumping the brake, once one brake
is done I can then move onto the next brake.  All a one-man operation.

I'm only a newbie at doing my own work on my Porsche, so maybe this method
has disadvantages I am unaware of.

Please enlighten me on why anyone might want an Eezibleed.  The only reason
I can see is that my current setup involves me pumping the brakes.  However,
this is a big advantage over having the wife do it.

Am I missing something ?

PS  As a newbie I am always a bit wary of getting in the car when
it is jacked up with a wheel removed.  I use the jack stands and chock
the wheels, but it always scary to get in the car with one corner slightly
in the air.  Is this the big advantage to the $30 bleeder setups ?  Or is
my self-preservation instinct making me too paranoid.

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 18:38:33 -0500 (EST)
From: Pat Roberson <root@patrick.mdn.com>
Subject: ALLDATA Web Server

Found an interesting point on the web.

http://www.alldata.tsb.com/

ALLDATA is what the dealers use for diagnostic info.  I have seen them use
it from CD-ROM.

Just my $.02 worth.

Pat Roberson

Jeff,

    Actually, an American Roadster *IS* a cabriolet turbo w/a normally
aspirated 3.6 liter engine, and a normal C2 tail instead of the fixed
"whale tail".  Everything underneath is a turbo!  All of the
suspension bits, brakes, flares, etc.

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 19:34:33 -0500
From: Mgibson54@aol.com
Subject: Re: Brake Bleeders

Tracy,  I used the Mityvac x 2 yrs and the seals failed.  May have been my
fault for not keeping it completely free of brake fluid.  My wonderful wife
bought me a Sunpro Vacumn(?) with the brake bleeder system.  About $70 at our
local parts store.  Much better tool and made from steel, not plastic like
the Mityvac.  I've only had it x 3 mo, but expect it to last much longer.  It
will pull 1 atmosphere negative.  Good luck with either.

Mark Gibson

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 19:54:36 -0500
From: Mgibson54@aol.com
Subject: 71 S Track Susp

Anyone out there think that 23-24 mm hollow front and 31 hollow rear torsion
bars is too stiff for an otherwise stock 71 S race car?  The car came with
Bilstien Sports x 4 and 19 mm front and 22 mm rear Weltmeisters.  The last S
I did with 22 front and 28 rear with Konis and 22 sways front and rear and it
felt a little soft.  Street drivability is of no consequence.  Its only 30-45
min to our 2 tracks up here in sunny Seattle.  Thanks ahead of time for any
feedback.

Mark Gibson

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 20:31:06 -0500
From: Mdch01@aol.com
Subject: Re: 924 perf modes

Hi Mike.
Not too many performance mods exist for the 924 -  but I would suggest the
following to start with:
Make sure you have the 1977 1/2 engine with the 110 Hp motor - if not, swap
one in (or the cylinder head at least).
Replace the stock throttle body with a (1980) 924 Turbo one.
Cut large holes (with a hole saw) in the pre-filtered side of the plastic air
box and install a K&N filter.
Remove as much smog stuff as you can - egr, cat, air pump (this stuff will
only slow you down and add weight) ... this of course depending where you are
located.
Bursch headers from Performance Products are quite good - seem durable as
well.  I use a Dynomax muffler as well which flows very nicely.
Check your fuel injectors - replace them if neccesary (these have a large
impact on performance)
Try advancing the timing 6 degrees or so - check for detonation though after
these changes.
Try Accell yellow 8mm plug wires - <much> cheaper and better than OEM.  You
can buy a universal fit set for a V-8 and have a spare set of four.  I use
Autolite Platinum plugs as well.
These changes have made my car a lot more driveable, and has very noticably
improved the acceleration between 4000 and 5000, where it had previously felt
rather asthmatic.  I estimate my car has 130 Hp or so - this is a subjective
test ... but my Dad's '87 924S doesn't get too far ahead during the
occasional stop light duel ;-)  The early 924's are quite light - and I think
the 4 speed is a bit better for acceleration than the 5 speed (mine shifs
very quickly). 
I have a list of places that offer various "more exotic" mods, like big valve
heads, porting etc - I will send it if you want.
Good luck with it - e-mail me if you need any clarification or whatever - 
cheers MIKE
1977 924
198X Alfa Romeo GTV-6 (soon to be acquired)

------------------------------

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 18:36:34 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: "Unrealistic" Passing (was "993 Turbo ad")

Takaharu Mizutani (takaharu@sas.upenn.edu) cleaned up his signature and 
wrote:

>BTW, it's unrealistic to show a Porsche passing a motorcycle, at least
>not something like a Suzuki GSX-R1100 or a Kawasaki ZX-11.

Taka:

One would think so, but it's not always that simple.

While most motorcycles have power-to-weight ratios far exceeding those 
of most Porsches, they don't corner anywhere near as hard.  In fact, if 
you exclude the really extreme comparisons -- like Eddie Lawson on his 
race bike vs. my sister in her Subaru -- most cars can SAFELY be driven 
faster than most motorcycles.

This is borne out by my personal experience blasting up and down Palomar 
Mountain and across the Ortega Highway.  Both are popular spots here in 
Southern California for motorcycle riders to flex their muscles, and you 
see a lot of high-end superbikes there on weekends (even saw a Bimota a 
couple of months ago).  A lot of the riders are fast, but it apparently 
takes way more talent (or bravery, or something) to quickly get those 
things around corners than it does to get a car to do the same thing.

Given that both participants care about living to see another day, I 
wouldn't be surprised to see Porsche drivers regularly passing 
motorcycle riders.

 -Andy


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 19:04:54 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: 993 Turbo ad on TV, have you seen it?

>I thought the Diablo was only rated at 375HP or so, and the new 993 Turbo at
>405HP.  I also wouldn't be surprised to find out that the 993 is much lighter
>than the Diablo -- I mean, when you've got a car that has *doors* the size of
>a 911's *hood*...

Haven't seen official test results upon the new 911 Turbo, but as for the 
Diablo...

Official manufacturer data is 4.0 seconds 0-60, top speed 202mph.
Car & Driver got 4.4 0-60 and 204mph, on an early Diablo (a non-VT - in other 
words, 2wd - the VTs are all-wheel-drive.)
Roadhandling was .95gs on the early Diablo, as well.

As for horsepower - as I recall, the new 911 Turbo is 408bhp, the Lambo Diablo 
is... Hold onto your hat! 492bhp, 428 lb-ft of torque.

Like I said, the 911 wouldn't stand a CHANCE against the Diablo. :)

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 1995 22:56:26 -0500 (EST)
From: takaharu@sas.upenn.edu (Takaharu Mizutani)
Subject: Re: "Unrealistic" Passing (was "993 Turbo ad")


Andrew Warren wrote:
> Takaharu Mizutani (takaharu@sas.upenn.edu) cleaned up his signature and 
> wrote:
> 
> >BTW, it's unrealistic to show a Porsche passing a motorcycle, at least
> >not something like a Suzuki GSX-R1100 or a Kawasaki ZX-11.

[stuff about cars being faster than bikes in corners deleted]

> Given that both participants care about living to see another day, I 
> wouldn't be surprised to see Porsche drivers regularly passing 
> motorcycle riders.
> 
> -Andy

Andy,
I know that cars are usually faster in corners than cycles.

However, as one person said, this commercial was on the Nurburgring, 
which is a racetrack. Unless the Porsche was passing the cycle in a sharp 
turn, it is unrealistic. Anyway, at every straight section, the cycle 
will blow away the Porsche. I think with enough straight-line speed, you 
can easily beat a Porsche with a motorcycle, even on a twisty course like 
the Nurburgring. This is assuming that the rider has equal riding skill 
to the driver's driving skill.

Porsches don't have a significant enough cornering advantage, IMHO, to 
counter the difference in acceleration between, say, a 911 Turbo and a ZX-11.

Anyone with more real-world experience with both Porsches and cycles care 
to share their thoughts?

BTW Andy, there's no need to make snide remarks.

Porschephiles #1263                         Thu Mar 23 02:00:06 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 00:22:52 -0500 (EST)
From: "Matthew A. Dilligan" <diligan@minerva.cis.yale.edu>
Subject: Re: "Unrealistic" Passing (was "993 Turbo ad")

On Wed, 22 Mar 1995, Takaharu Mizutani wrote:

> However, as one person said, this commercial was on the Nurburgring, 
> which is a racetrack. Unless the Porsche was passing the cycle in a sharp 
> turn, it is unrealistic. Anyway, at every straight section, the cycle 
> will blow away the Porsche. I think with enough straight-line speed, you 
> can easily beat a Porsche with a motorcycle, even on a twisty course like 
> the Nurburgring. This is assuming that the rider has equal riding skill 
> to the driver's driving skill.
> 
> Porsches don't have a significant enough cornering advantage, IMHO, to 
> counter the difference in acceleration between, say, a 911 Turbo and a ZX-11.
> 
> Anyone with more real-world experience with both Porsches and cycles care 
> to share their thoughts?
> 
> BTW Andy, there's no need to make snide remarks.
> 
> -- 
> Taka Mizutani                                     University of Pennsylvania
> takaharu@mail.sas.upenn.edu                            Philadelphia, PA, USA
> Land line: (215) 243-1247                             Mobile: (215) 960-0592
> 
I don't think it is very unrealistic. The car vs. motorcycle debate has been 
hashed over many times on rec.motorcycles, and in terms of numbers on a 
given racetrack the cars have a distinct advantage. It is true though 
that these numbers are being set by pure race machinery, and it is also 
true that your average sports motorcycle will have much more in common 
with it's racer counterpart than you average sports car. In terms of 
passing on the straights, while motorcycles have some advantage on 
acceleration, their inferior aerodynamics slow them down greatly. The 
hottest bikes out there are lucky to hit 200 tops, where this is 
commonly exceeded by cars. The ZX-11 has a top speed of 180, I believe. 
My RD could probably outrun most of the cars on this list 0-60, but on a 
track it would get eaten alive. The same would be true for I think any 
sportbike whatever the vintage. I think the best chance a motorcycle 
could have would be on a tighter track, where maneuverability and not 
maximum cornering ability is important.

Matt
76 Yamaha RD350/400
70 Porsche 914 

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Mar 95 21:59:42 PST
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: RE: "Unrealistic" passing


At the risk of joining a flame war..........

I ride a motorcycle.  I drive a Porsche.  I have opinions.

The advantage of a motorcycle is the power to weight ratio,
and the low speed manouverability (sp?).

The advantage of a car is the low (air) drag, and the high
cornering forces.

I can't imagine any sane person racing a car and a bike at 
the same time, but I have seen car and bike races at the
same track:  Laguna Seca.  Cars are faster.

The "Camel" GTO cars typically pull laps that AVERAGE 40mph
faster than the unlimited (500cc factory) class bikes run.

Flame away.........

Gary
gary@superior.ucsf.edu

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 08:54:21 -0500 (EST)
From: Tomkow <tomkow@nando.net>
Subject: Re: Cleaning Phone Dials??


Hello!

I used to have a BMW K100RS that had silver wheels that were impossible 
to keep clean.  BMW evidently tired of the complaints and began to sell 
"BMW Gel Type Wheel Cleaner."  The stuff is magic!  It clings to the 
wheel and can be left on for up to one hour.  You won't have to remove 
the wheels either.  I use it on the phone dials of my 84 Carrera with 
excellent results.  Price was about $7.00 a bottle.  Enought to do the 
911 and the Ducati twice.  I've even wasted it on my wife's Prelude 
wheels in the interest of peace.

Good Luck!
 -Bill Tomko
 1984 911 Carrera
 1995 Ducati 900 SP

inferences *others* may make from the warm and friendly tone of your message.

this group; I shall, however sad it makes me, come to your assistance.

into the bosom of this group are beyond your ken.  But, I urge you, don't 
despair or be embarrased or humiliated (as I know you would otherwise be) by 
this seeming lack of intellectual capacity!

boot filled with urine (*when* instructions for this task were printed clearly

them did!  Well, OK, 3 out of 150 did.)

Stan Hanks, at the -request (porschephiles-request@tta.com) address (here's

So, DMOON; fare well, old rutabega, come back when you can stay longer (Do
see about that mouth, first, won't you?)  Although we've known each other but

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 06:47:11 -0800 (PST)
From: buetow@bcstec.ca.boeing.com (Bill Buetow)
Subject: Re: sloppy 944 shifter

Adam,
I had the same symtoms about a year ago.  It turned out to be the shifter
linkage at the gear shift.  If you take the gear shift boot cover
off, you'll find that the transaxle shift bar connects to the
gear shift shaft at a pin that "tees" into it.  This pin became worn
like a banana and caused the slop.  I was able to find a used
shifter that wasn't worn and just replaced it.  There is a "wave" washer
that fits on the pin to keep the shift bar tight, it wasn't on mine
and probably got lost when I R&R the clutch several months earlier. 
I'm sure this was the cause, I haven't had any problems since.
Good luck...
Bill Buetow
'86 944 (for sale)
- -- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Bill Buetow                  | >>>Not a company Spokesperson<<<
Boeing Computer Services     |
buetow@bcstec.ca.boeing.com  | Boeing Employees Autosports Club

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 09:58:01 -0500 (EST)
From: qhq2227@dcro2.dcro.dla.mil (Larry Dunlap)
Subject: Re: sloppy 944 shifter

Adam,

Yes, I think I know what your problem is (mine has it too!).  The rod
that connects the shift lever to the gearbox is going bad.  The opening
that connects to the shift lever is becoming oblong instead of round, and
that adds to the slopiness feel.  To check it, take off your shift boot
and the rubber boot underneath it, and look at the opening.  If the little
circlip is missing from the end and the end of the shift lever is worn
down to a point (instead of looking like a barrel), you found your problem!
The good news:  George B. has the part for cheap.  The BAD news:  You've
got to take the gearbox out to change the damn thing!  I'm waiting for
a warmer weekend to tackle this one......

                                            -Larry

ldunlap@dcro.dla.mil
1984 944
1979 924
Cleveland, Ohio

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 10:28:54 -0500
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: 993 Turbo TV ad

Hi,

As you know, the new 911 turbo ad is out. People haven't really described it
very well. They missed the best part of the commercial. 

The ad starts by showing the gates of the Nurburgring opening and a narrator
saying something along the lines of- "In Germany anybody can pay and drive
around the famous Nurburgring". A fully laden Citroen 2CV is shown slowly
going around a corner and then a Diablo is seen going down a straight. Then
you see the 911 Turbo test driver drive up to the gate and hand over his
D-Marks. The narrator then says "This is were Porsche did all its' testing of
the new 400hp 911 turbo." You see the car sliding around the track and pass
the Diablo. Now the best part of the commercial is when the car is seen in
front of a Deutsche Bank  ATM and you see the test driver taking out money.
The narrator says "This isn't a car for a German test driver with an ATM
card." Implying that he will spend all his money going around the ring.  You
can see this ad on the Discovery channel on programs like Beyond 2000 or
Next. I've seen the ad on those programs the last 3 nights. There is also a
new Carrera ad that was shot in New Mexico or Arizona.

There was also a little preview article in the last Auto, Motor und Sport.
The turbo looks great. It has large openings in the front spoiler similar to
the new Toyota Supra. The rocker panels are deeper/lower and the rear is even
wider. The tail is all fiberglass, I guess rubber moulding wouldn't keep its'
shape at 180mph +. I'm not sure I like the new tail but I'll take the car
anyway. Factory numbers are 290kmh (181mph) top speed and 0-100kmh in 4.5
sec. 

Back to the turbo passing the Diablo. Porsche is one of the few manufacturers
that uses conservative performance numbers. How many times have there been
write-ups on Ferraris and Lamborghinis in which the car being tested either
had a problem which prevented top speed testing or the car didn't have the
power to reach the claimed top speed? The Porsches never seem to have that
problem. They always match or exceed the factory claims and they are real
cars that you can still drive to the grocery store everyday.

That's all folks!

Neil K.
'73 911S targa

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 09:33:55 -0600
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: drivability-Webber tuning

I now have about 500 miles on my rebuild and decided to do a checkup
on the motor. Compression test was fine with all showing about 125lbs.
Plug inspection showed that I need some tuning of the carbs. The 1st
problem I noticed was a miss at idle. I took the webber manual home
and studied the theory and application notes and then assumed that 
there was probabably a clogged idle jet in #3. I can't beleive it the
theoretical answer was the same as the application! Now the idle miss
is gone. I cleaned all the idle jets and the main jets on all three throats.
Last night a friend that has done this before "tuned" the carbs. Now
the motor sounds good. No backfiring and all cylindars seem to be firing
properly. I do have a problem with the fuel pump check valve as when it's
warm the fuel pump doesent shut off. A new one should be here Friday.
Something that I have always noticed with the car is a miss at about
2800-3000 rpm. I don't know if proper description is a miss but I loose
the power band at that point. It just isn't as smooth there, as thru most
of the power band. I have a new set of points on the way and will have
the fuel pump installed by Friday evening. Besides rebuilding the carbs
and having the distributer rebuilt, everything else is new or reconditioned.
Annyone have any ideas about the miss? I'm hoping that it is due to a lack
of fuel supply and come Friday I will have (at least) eliminated that area.
Nature of the beast??? Comments?????
Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1974 914 2.0 (for sale)
1966 911 cpe (DONE!!)


------------------------------
