Date: Thu, 23 Mar 95 07:24:34 PST
From: radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil
Subject: Cars vs. motorcycles

          ATTN: Minimal porsche content!

          Just got my latest p-phile digest and thought I could muddy
          the waters.

          I drive a 914 and ride a CBR600F2.  More importantly, I get
          various car and bike magazines.  In one of the bike mags
          there was a best-time race between a powerful, street legal
          bike you can buy at your local dealer (CBR900RR I believe)
          vs. a powerful, street legal car you can buy at your local
          dealer (NSX, or something like that).  The course: Willow
          Springs.  Even though the respected racer behind the WHEEL
          cheated by using shaved race compound tires, there was no
          contest -- the bike won.

          I could never beat a 911 on courses where top speed matters
          (e.g. Indy).  But the ol' 600 sure has surprised a few cars
          on the twisties:  they corner quite well (keeping up with
          the car in question) and then can shoot past them on a short
          straightaway.  Thus for the next turn I am in front, setting
          the cornering pace and then I can shoot farther ahead on the
          straights.

          Disclaimer: I am now older and wiser than the first year I
          had the bike and no longer "street race".  Cars definitely
          have the advantage in terms of cornering safety.  Leaning a
          bike more than 45 degrees just starts to get a bit scary! 
          Not to mention, possibly scarry!

          -Tim
         914 - 4 of them, none run (whahhh!)


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 10:44:12 -0500
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bartonc@annap.infi.net>
Subject: Unsubscribe

In message <199503230114.UAA06535@psyche.the-wire.com> Michael Lo writes:
> Please unsubscribe me from this list.  Thanks in advance.

Dear Michael,

Courtesy breeds same, so I'm happy to help.  Please note that this is a 
different message than a rude, discourteous and pre-emptory command, such as 
one sent by a person, who shall remain nameless (DMOON) sent recently.

As you are obviously new to the net, here's the scoop.  This is a mailing
list.  Lists come in many flavors, most run automatically by software on
a server that requires no human intervention.  In every case that I'm
aware of, you "subcribe" to join, and "unsubscribe" to leave the list.
You do this by sending email to a *different* address than the list
address.

In this case, as was explained in the rules you were provided when you
joined (subscribed), you send your unsubscribe request to our beloved
Listmeister, Stan Hanks (a real human being, not just some bozo who
*Plays* a human being on the internet) at our *request* address, to wit,

porschephiles-request@tta.com

I've done this as a courtesy to you, but please bear this message in
mind, in case you ever need to return to the list, temporarily or
permanently, or change to the *Digest* mode.

One final thought.  Traffic on this list is usually around 100 messages
per day.  Since this *is* a problem for you, you could send a message, to
the *REQUEST* ADDRESS, and request the *Digest* mode.  The digest mode
reduces your traffic to 1 to 3 messages, which contain *all* the
individual messages concatenated.

So you might want to think about this, fellow Porschephile, rather than
lose the best resource a Porsche lover ever had!


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 10:52:19 -0500 (EST)
From: Jan Ringnalda <RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu>
Subject: Re: "Unrealistic" Passing (was "993 Turbo ad")

Hey guys,
	Having moved from being a cold-hard all weather biker to a sunshine 
motorcyclist as well as Porsche and Beemer driver, let me share some of my 
experiences on this thread.  I will start by stating that there was recently a 
test of the fastest car from 0-100 *and* back down to 0.  For shits and giggles 
they also threw in a Kawasaki ZX-R, which is a potent bike by anybody's 
standards.  
	The *TOTAL* time for the bike to get from 0-100 *AND* back down to 0 was 
about 11 seconds.  This was FASTER than the fastest car (Porsche 911 turbo) 
could get to 100! (10.7 seconds)  With such unmatched accelerating and stopping 
power on the modern bikes (which are essentially track-technology with 
headlights) I would fear that a modern car (without extensive suspension 
modification) would not beat such a bike on a given track, unless it is 
exceedingly twisty.
	I have on many occasions won bets with my bike on a local track in 
Britain, whereby we would time the bike over three laps vs. a car over the same 
distance.  However I have also lost similar bets when the track gets reduced to 
a karting track.  The Nurburgring is *NOT* a karting track so on this occasion I 
am going to go with the bike.
	Unless it's an F1 car, of course...  Oh and before I forget; NO RAIN!!
Cheers,  Jan

'86 944 (Arrest me red)
'85 635 CSi (still for sale)
'79 CBX1000 (0-60=3.9 sec)
'80 CBX1000  (slightly slower but looks better)
'82 CBX1000 special (with six-into-six pipes; SOO LOOUUD)
'86 Buick electra for S.O. 'the boat'
'74 260Z Datsun, (ongoing nightmare restoration)

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 95 08:12:23 TZ
From: Jim Harriger <jimharr@microsoft.com>
Subject: 928 CIS strangeness

my '79 928 (CIS) is having a strange problem that i noticed after the 
last tune-up
(it could've been around before that, and i just attributed it to 
needing a tune-up,
i don't remember if it behaved like this before or not.)  it starts 
fine, and runs OK
while warming up. once it warms up however, it has a rough idle, and it 
surges and
stumbles slightly at light throttle openings. from 1/2 throttle to WFO, 
it runs
great and pulls like a freight train.  i had originally thought it was 
the plugs, so i
changed them again, but it made no difference. i'm now thinking it is one of
three things:

	1) fuel distributor mis-adjusted to go with k&n air filter
		(although i would've thought i would've noticed this last
		year, when i put the k&n in).
	2) slight vacumn leak somewhere in the 9-bazillion hoses.
		(i've inspected pretty carefully, just short of ripping them
		all out and testing/replacing them)
	3) warmup-regulator sensed low bank account, and has finally
		barfed.

anything i've missed? does the rubber-hose and propane torch method of finding
vacumn leaks really work? anybody know where to get a 3mm, 8-inch hex driver
for adjusting the fuel distributor (besides from Porsche or Baum: $23! yeow.)?


						jim harriger
'79 928 mochabraun "the pig", '92 f-250 x-cab silver/red "ludo",  '86 
Concours "waldorf"
misc other critters.

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 09:29:23 -0700
From: qmoolla@gpu3.srv.ualberta.ca (Qassim Moolla)
Subject: re: 951 Steering racks etc.


>
>>I replaced my own tie rod + end recently. One side only, because there was 
>>play only on one side.  I own a 944S (87) and the tie rod  assembly 
>>including end, part # 944 347 033 23 is the same for the 1987/88 turbo.  I 
>>was very pleasantly surprised to find that the Volkswagen wanagon tie rod is 
>>the identical part at about half the cost of the Porsche part. You could 
>>therefore look at finding a new (approx. $75 CDN.) or used Wanagon part at 
>>very little cost.  Note! This part will only work on the 87/88 turbos.  I 
>>hope this helps. Let me know how it works out. 
>
>How do you determine when there are VW parts that work on Porsches?
>This would be very good information to have for the future.  
>Thanks for the information.  Btw, do you know what the VW part 
>number is?
>
>Ross Stites
>'87 951
>
>Ross

>I used an OEM part # 251 419 803.  I understand, this is the same tie rod 
for all VW Wanagons (including diesels) from 1980 to 1991.  The VW part # 
may be different, nevertheless any VW parts supplier should be able to fill 
your order from the above info.  
>I agree, a comprehensive cross referencing of parts between the two marques 
would be wonderful.  I have heard that such information exists, but I 
believe this is just another urban legend.
 
Ike Moolla
1984 944
1987 944S
qmoolla@pop.srv.ualberta.ca


------------------------------

Date: 23 Mar 95 11:35:58 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Eezibleed and other systems

 
Richard Hocking says
>Maybe this method [one-way valve, one-man operation] has disadvantages I'm
>not aware of.
 
1) The one way valve will keep old fluid from being sucked back from the jar,
but it won't keep air from being sucked back past the threads of the opened
bleeder nipple.
 
2) You can't see if there is still air coming out of the system, because
you're inside working the pedal.
 
Order of preference for brake bleeding methods:
 
1. Two man old fashioned method, one working pedal SLOWLY, other opening
nipple for downstroke, closing before upstroke.
 
2. Pressure-type systems.
 
3. Vacuum-type systems.
 
4. Check valve systems.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 23 Mar 95 11:36:10 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Car vs. motorcycle

Andy Warren points out that motorcycles aren't necessarily faster than cars.
 
A few years ago I served as tour guide around Weissach for motorcycle racers
Freddy Spencer and Randy?? Mamoula. They put on a big show for them, hauled
out a 962 and gave them fast rides around the test track. After he came in
from his ride, I asked Spencer what differences he perceived. He said that
the car accelerated and turned about as well as his GP bike, but it stopped
a hell of a lot better.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 23 Mar 95 11:36:25 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 993 Turbo ad on TV

 
There is all this, uh, appendage measuring on behalf of the new Porsche Turbo
and Lamborghini Diablo. Figures from Car and Drivel were quoted. As a
professional road tester, using the same equipment as C/D, I can tell you
that C/D has probably never seen a car go as fast as they claim it does.
They do the tests, then apply a "correction factor" which takes some time
off every car they test. This makes it look like they are the only ones who
know how to test a car because their numbers are invariably a few tenths of
a second faster than anybody else's. This sells magazines. Selling magazines
(or rather, the ads in magazines, and the more magazines you claim to sell,
the higher your advertising rates) is the only reason magazines are in
business.
 
Unless they rented a high-speed test track, I also doubt they have been to
the car's top speed. They like to test top speed in the early morning on
Detroit freeways.
 
I have personally experienced 0-60 in 4.25 seconds in the old 1990 3.6 liter
Turbo, on a cold day on a public road in Europe. (Turbos love cold). Backed
that up with 2 runs before the gendarmes got curious. Given nice, dense,
cold intake air, the new Turbo should run well under 4 seconds. I got the
quarter mile on the old model in 12.74 sec at 109.0 mph. Those are
uncorrected what-it-does-is-what-it-does numbers. There is NO WAY to
accurately apply an atmospheric correction to turbocharged cars, and even
normally aspirated is kind of iffy. The correction factors work in the dyno
test cell but were never intended for use on the road, or beyond the narrow
barometric pressure/temperature/humidity limits set in the SAE engine test
code. SAE says that if the temp in your lab is below x or above y, etc.,
figure on testing another day.
 
If there is any doubt about the Eenimobile being faster than the new Turbo,
there is a simple solution: wait a while. Sooner or later the Lambo will
break. You can beat on a Turbo all day long on the drag strip; I've
done it. Brumos Racing rolled Hans Stuck's IMSA Supercar winner out of the
trailer for me at the Pomona drag strip a couple of years ago, said "here's
the car, here's a full tank of gas, have fun, we'll be back in 3 hours." The
car had just won the championship the day before, it still had the worn race
rubber on it, nothing had been serviced (crew too busy celebrating). I ran
the tank dry, most of it at full throttle (wouldn't you?). I wouldn't bet on
the exotics taking the same sort of punishment.
 
Same caveat goes for the new Bugatti. I was at the introduction of the car
in France, and it looked good and all that, but car magazine people who have
driven one here in Southern California tell me that it's disappointing and
the reports that have actually appeared in print have been charitable to
put it mildly.
 
While I was at R&T I asked a senior editor why we kept putting these
unaffordable, undrivable Italian exotics on the cover, and writing stories
about how glorious they are. His reply was that 1) red cars on the cover,
especially red Italian cars, sells magazines and 2) we can't tell the truth
about them, it would only shatter the readers' dreams.
 
To be fair, I just had a Ferrari 355 and it's the first modern Ferrari I
really like. It didn't come off as a kit car at all. Reliability, who knows?
But it was an absolute kick to drive. Not an everyday kind of car, but a
great weekend toy. The Porsches, any Porsches, can be driven to work and
then used as a toy on weekends.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1265                         Thu Mar 23 12:41:16 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 23 Mar 95 11:31:01 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 928 CIS strangeness

> my '79 928 (CIS) is having a strange problem that i noticed after the 
> last tune-up
> (it could've been around before that, and i just attributed it to 
> needing a tune-up,
> i don't remember if it behaved like this before or not.)  it starts 
> fine, and runs OK
> while warming up. once it warms up however, it has a rough idle, and it 
> surges and
> stumbles slightly at light throttle openings. from 1/2 throttle to WFO, 
> it runs
> great and pulls like a freight train.  i had originally thought it was 

My quick guess (and the thing I forget until the last on my CIS cars) is the
rubber O-rings around the fuel injectors.

They get hard and no longer seal properly, allowing false air in.  Lousy
idle, but great every other time.

Check em, and save yourself a lot of time...

good luck
- --

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 9:27:43 -0800 (PST)
From: JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject:  Re: "Unrealistic" Passing (was "993 Turbo ad")

>I don't think it is very unrealistic. The car vs. motorcycle debate has been 
>hashed over many times on rec.motorcycles, and in terms of numbers on a 
>given racetrack the cars have a distinct advantage. It is true though 
>that these numbers are being set by pure race machinery, and it is also 
>true that your average sports motorcycle will have much more in common 
>with it's racer counterpart than you average sports car. In terms of 
>passing on the straights, while motorcycles have some advantage on 
>acceleration, their inferior aerodynamics slow them down greatly. The 
>hottest bikes out there are lucky to hit 200 tops, where this is 
>commonly exceeded by cars. The ZX-11 has a top speed of 180, I believe. 
>My RD could probably outrun most of the cars on this list 0-60, but on a 
>track it would get eaten alive. The same would be true for I think any 
>sportbike whatever the vintage. I think the best chance a motorcycle 
>could have would be on a tighter track, where maneuverability and not 
>maximum cornering ability is important.

I agree on the fact the four wheeled vehicle have the advantage. They
can hold more speed through a turn. As for the top speed advantage?
Yes, full bred race cars and exotic supercars can break 200mph,
but so can the motorcycle counterparts. What about the 215mph turbo
charged ZX-11? What about an NSR500? These machines have hideously
high power to weight ratios. I don't think the NSR500 has actually
been given a track to find it's top speed. But yes, the cars will win
on a track given both are on equall footing. E.g. race vehicle to race
vehicle.

 -Josh

Joshua Hadler				'74 914 2.0L CSP
Accelerator Operations
Stanford Linear Accelerator Center

jah@slc.slac.stanford.edu

Everything expresed here is the opinion of the idiot that wrote it, 
namely ME. So don't go suing the DOE, they don't care...

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 11:38:57 -0600
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: drivability-Webber tuning

I now have about 500 miles on my rebuild and decided to do a checkup
on the motor. Compression test was fine with all showing about 125lbs.
Plug inspection showed that I need some tuning of the carbs. The 1st
problem I noticed was a miss at idle. I took the webber manual home
and studied the theory and application notes and then assumed that 
there was probabably a clogged idle jet in #3. I can't beleive it the
theoretical answer was the same as the application! Now the idle miss
is gone. I cleaned all the idle jets and the main jets on all three throats.
Last night a friend that has done this before "tuned" the carbs. Now
the motor sounds good. No backfiring and all cylindars seem to be firing
properly. I do have a problem with the fuel pump check valve as when it's
warm the fuel pump doesent shut off. A new one should be here Friday.
Something that I have always noticed with the car is a miss at about
2800-3000 rpm. I don't know if proper description is a miss but I loose
the power band at that point. It just isn't as smooth there, as thru most
of the power band. I have a new set of points on the way and will have
the fuel pump installed by Friday evening. Besides rebuilding the carbs
and having the distributer rebuilt, everything else is new or reconditioned.
Annyone have any ideas about the miss? I'm hoping that it is due to a lack
of fuel supply and come Friday I will have (at least) eliminated that area.
Nature of the beast??? Comments?????
Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1974 914 2.0 (for sale)
1966 911 cpe (DONE!!)

Awesome footage of a 993 on a race track, Danny Sullivan in the cockpit
talking to the camera saying "It's not something I recommend that you
do, driving 130 MPH with one hand, but I just want to show how capable
this car is.  Far better than the C2" (slightly paraphrased)  Also
Hurly Haywood talking about the rear suspension...

The best footage is a slow motion oversteering drift with some opposite
lock.  The actual driving scenes are too few IMHO.

emotional appeal.  If you watch this video and don't want a 911,
you'll never have to wonder if this car is for you.

A great line:  "A car not meant to be for everyone, but
everything to some" ....  Again from memory, so forgive me the details.

Four Stars.  Joe Bob says check it out.

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 12:44:16 -0500
From: StreakN@aol.com
Subject: Re: "Unrealistic" Passing (was "993 Turbo ad")

>>BTW, it's unrealistic to show a Porsche passing a motorcycle, at least
>>not something like a Suzuki GSX-R1100 or a Kawasaki ZX-11.

>Taka:

>One would think so, but it's not always that simple.

>While most motorcycles have power-to-weight ratios far >exceeding those 
>of most Porsches, they don't corner anywhere near as hard.  In >fact, if 
>you exclude the really extreme comparisons -- like Eddie >Lawson on his 
>race bike vs. my sister in her Subaru -- most cars can SAFELY >be driven 
>faster than most motorcycles.

>This is borne out by my personal experience blasting up and >down Palomar 
>Mountain and across the Ortega Highway.  Both are popular >spots here in 
>Southern California for motorcycle riders to flex their >muscles, and you 
>see a lot of high-end superbikes there on weekends (even saw >a Bimota a 
>couple of months ago).  A lot of the riders are fast, but it >apparently 
>takes way more talent (or bravery, or something) to quickly >get those 
>things around corners than it does to get a car to do the same >thing.

>Given that both participants care about living to see another >day, I 
>wouldn't be surprised to see Porsche drivers regularly >passing 
>motorcycle riders.

>-Andy


Boy, Andy, while I don't disagree with your statement comparing ultimate
cornering capabilities, I am surprised that you regularly smoke motorcycles
on your highway run. In another part of Southern California, the run up the
Angeles Crest Highway, it is very rare for a four-wheeler--Porsche or not--
to outrun a motorcycle. It is, in fact, becoming much more of a problem
during runs up the Crest, as immortal teens frequently end up--in your
lane--at high speeds. While motorcycles rule the roost on this roadway, the
closest thing I saw to  challenge a two-wheeler was a Ford RS200 Group B
rally car, fully kitted. I expect the reason for the motorcycle edge over
cars is the tightness of the intitial 10-15 miles of the Crest--cars cannot
accelerate out of the slow turns as fast as bikes, so any edge 4-wheelers
have is muted.

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 95 9:46:52 PST
From: Miq Millman <mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com>
Subject: Re: "Unrealistic" Passing

> 	I'd like to know what the motorcycle lap record is for Willow 	
> 	Springs.  As far as I know, the fastest anyone's done it in a 	
> Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
> Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California


I don't know about Willow Springs, but I do know about Portland Int'l
Raceway.  PIR lap record (with chicane) is held by Emerson Fittipaldi during
the practice sessions for the 1993 Indy Car race:  1:06:03.  Or about 104 mph
average.  GT1 race cars usually have times about 1:12 or so, 911's and 951's
are in the low 1:20's - 1:22's.

500cc Motorcycle races usually lap at about 1:16 - 1:22.

That's about all I can say on this subject.....

Date: 23 Mar 95 12:40:11 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Panel flanging & body shop tools

A couple of weeks ago there was a discussion about panel flanging tools,
used to put a step or jog in sheet metal panels to make neat lap joints. My
feeling, and that of others, was that this is not the best way to go, but
was sometimes unavoidable.
 
Anyway, I'm looking through the latest flyer from "Auto Body Toolmart"
(1-800-382-1200) and they have a flanger for use in a standard air hammer,
for $24.95. I think Eastwood wants lots more for one.
 
There is also an air tool called an "Astro straight grip punch flange" which
appears to do two things -- punch holes or flange panels. I'm not familiar
with it, but at $78.95, if indeed it does both jobs, it's a steal.
 
They also have various American-made jack systems, including the two-post
screw type that lifts from the center of the car, at $3 or $4K depending,
and what I think would be neater for my garage, a pantograph-type system
that also lifts from the center, but you drive over it and it lifts the car
12, 18, 22 or 25 inches from the ground, plenty for the sort of stuff I do,
and I don't have the headroom to lift a car more than 4 feet or so clear of
the ground before hitting the main ceiling beam. $1700.
 
Anybody who does any of their own bodywork should call them and ask to get
on the mailing list. Lots of brand names, not (just) People's Republic of
China junk. Looking through it, I even see Porsche-specific tools, like
clamps to attach a 911 to a Champ #3000 Unibench for pulling the frame. Not
that most of us have the skills or tools to start tugging on a 911 frame,
but that's the sort of market this company sells to.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 12:55:54 -0500
From: StreakN@aol.com
Subject: Re: "Unrealistic" Passing

 >I'd like to know what the motorcycle lap record is for Willow  
 >Springs.  As far as I know, the fastest anyone's done it in a  
 >real production-based Porsche (I'm excluding "production" >cars  
> like 935s, 956s, etc.) is 1:29 or so, in a 914-6.  Since Willow 
> is a popular track for both cycles and autos, this information 
> would probably settle the question.

 >Anyone know?

I'm not sure if your 1:29 or so was set before Willow was repaved (with wider
and smoother turns one and five),
but over the winter Superbike (NOT GP machinery) times dipped into the
1:23's. Having said this, on the vast majority of tracks REAL race cars are
substantially faster than REAL race motorcycles, due to the substantially
higher cornering forces 4-wheelers can generate. In fact, in this month's
RACER magazine, there is a comparison between GP bikes and Formula 1
cars--check it out.

>Mark Doyle asked :

     There was the "Garbage Bin", "Discount Store Bin",and "Good Bin".

     on the lower edge of the quality threshold (and therefore were sold for 
less).

The question I saw was:

> <wheel!  Cool!  Did #4 (I think it was), etc.  At one point, I poked
> <a feeler gauge into a valve gap for a piston not at TDC--the other
> <valve was depressed.  The gap was bigger, by about .002 or so!  I
> >re-checked both valves back at TDC, and they were fine!
>         <Does the stock 914 (2.0) cam go "negative" anywhere?  If <not,
> <what the heck did I do?

Dr914 gave the compleat instructions for valve adjustment, but no
answer to the question! I'm wondering, as was the original poster,
"Does the stock 914 (2.0) cam go negative anywhere?" and this has
not been made clear. Could it be that the poster has a worn-out cam?

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 10:35:57 -0800 (PST)
From: buetow@bcstec.ca.boeing.com (Bill Buetow)
Subject: Re: sloppy 944 shifter

Larry Dunlap wrote:
> 
> > 
> > Adam,
> > I had the same symtoms about a year ago.  It turned out to be the shifter
> > linkage at the gear shift.  If you take the gear shift boot cover
> > off, you'll find that the transaxle shift bar connects to the
> > gear shift shaft at a pin that "tees" into it.  This pin became worn
> > like a banana and caused the slop.  I was able to find a used
> > shifter that wasn't worn and just replaced it.  There is a "wave" washer
> > that fits on the pin to keep the shift bar tight, it wasn't on mine
> > and probably got lost when I R&R the clutch several months earlier. 
> > I'm sure this was the cause, I haven't had any problems since.
> 
> 
> Bill,
> 
> I've got the same problem as Adam.  As far as I know, the only way to change
> the lever is to drop the gearbox.  Did you replace it yourself?  Any tips?
> How long did it take?  TIA
> 
>                                       -Larry
> 
Larry,
My gear shift lever (verses the transaxle shift tube) was worn. Your 
correct, if the shift tube is worn at the gear shift lever pin then 
you do have to remove the transaxle. Mine was okay and just the
shift lever pin was bad.  This only takes a few minutes and 
simple tools to remove (be careful not to drop bolts down around
the torque tube). I just removed the cir-clip and slipped the
transaxle shift tube off, then un-bolted the gear shift lever base 
from the torque tube. 
If the transaxle shift tube is in the way, you can loosen the connection
at the transaxle to give some front/back movement.

Goodluck... 
Bill
'86 944 (for sale)

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 13:46:22 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Misc. 914-6 questions


Dear Barney,
You wrote:
<Hi George!

<You have been so helpful with other P-philer's 914 questions that I wonder
<if you can help me with a couple.

<I have a wonderful '70 914-6 that I race in PCA Club Racing, STOCK Class
<"I". Yes, I know, a risky venture at best. Nevertheless, it really is a
<great track car with a couple of exceptions.

<BRAKES:
<The brakes are marginal. It's not that they overheat, it's that they don't
<seem to have enough stopping power. (I'm running Blue Cool Carbons) This
<car has the steel calipers. Do ALL 914-6 have the steel ones or can I go to
<the alloy units? Are the alloy calipers really any better or any bigger?

<SEATS:
<I'm looking for a Racing Seat. Even with the seat cushion out, my head
<(with helmet) still bumps the top of the targa top. Do you know of any
<racing seat that sits lower to the floor than the stock seat? The seat
<needs to remain adjustable since my wife also drives the car in our local
autoxs.

<FRONT SPOILER:
<I'm presently running AA's #ACC 1000 air dam. I've drilled five 1.25" holes
<near the top to let the bonnet mounted oil cooler work. Actually the dam
<seems to work great except that it is kind of "notched up" in the lower
<middle which allows some extra air under the car. What I'm looking at is
<Performance Products "new" RS-914 dam, which looks somewhat lower and more
<aggressive. I'm wondering about your opinion of air dams in general and
<specifically about the RS-914.


Please don't damage your museum piece 914-6 in stock PCA racing events!

Stock 914-6 brakes work well with orange cool carbon brake pads and DOT-4
brake fluid. This combination will give you the extra bite you need. As a
passing note, make sure that the non-stock spoiler is not interfering with
front brake cooling. 911T calipers were originally fitted to the 914-6 and
the aluminum S calipers have too large a mounting to bolt to the to the "six"
struts and easily warp and/or corrode. But they are lightweight!

In the stock PCA class "I" in which your 914 runs, you may substitute any of
the stock braking setups originally supplied by the factory for that type of
vehicle. Since 914-6 models (except for 914-6 GT and 916) never were supplied
by the factory with anything else but 911T front (and virtually rear) brakes,
that is what we are relegated to using - sorry.

By removing the backpad, there are many different racing seats that will sit
lower, but not necessarily look good in your 914! You must be one of those
height-impaired individuals - huh? My dad and brother both tower over me
(they are over 6 feet) and cannot fit in 914s either!

With a remote oil cooler, we are not so worried about air flowing under the
car to cool the engine, but are worried about brake cooling and high speed
lift. If racing over 115MPH the 914 in stock dress becomes too light. Hence,
we need spoilers to keep it firmly planted on the ground. This means both
front and rear spoilers.

The best combination is a front euroflex air dam with oil cooler cutout area
and brake cooling holes along with and A.I.R. rear extend ducktail spoiler.
This combination certainly increases down force and top end handling.

George Hussey




------------------------------

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 13:46:39 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 1972 914 1.7 D-Jetronic FI


Dear Archie, 
You wrote
<George, thanks for the post.  Last evening I took the auxiliary air valve
<off the 914.  I put an ohm meter from the electrical lead to the metal
bracket
<that bolts the valve to the motor bracket.  First no reading then got a
reading
<of approximately 800,0000 ohms.  Connected a 12V battery from lead to
ground,
<at first the body of the valve got slightly warm but the valve did not
close.
<Tried again and got no warming and no closing of the valve.  An ohm meter
<from the lead to ground read infinity.

<This morning I put a volt meter from the lead that connects to the auxiliary
<air valve from the wiring harness to ground and turned the ignition on.
 There
<was no voltage present.  I did not start the car while the meter was
connected.
<An ohm meter from the harness lead to ground with the ignition off read 0
ohms.
<Your catalog tips on page 71 indicate that high idle can be caused by a bad
<aux. air valve.  Also sometimes starting cold engine will start and then die
<the first try.  The trouble shooting chart indicates this can be caused by
<a defective air valve also.

<I had the car timed and tuned by a local garage (VW specialists?) and
discover-
<ed that the master machanics there had taken the air hose from the vacuum
<device in the air cleaner to the intake air distributor and had placed a
steel
<ball in the hose that runs from the air breather intake that comes off the
<aux. air valve and runs to the deceleration control valve!

<Any additional thoughts would be greatly appreciated.

Testing the 1.7,2.0 auxillary air valve is easy. When cold, blow through it.
If it is closed, it is bad. Next connect a 12 volt battery to the positive
red lead and the aux air valve case. As the valve heats (approx. five
minutes), it will close and you cannot blow through it. If it is not closed
in five or so minutes, it is bad.

To repair this valve (new ones are no longer available), pry around the top
crimped portion and remove the top. You will find the slider valve to have
rusted, stuck from years of crankcase vapor. Simply sand, clean and lubricate
the valve until it slides freely and reassemble silicone, gluing the top.
This device is absolutely necessary for proper and smooth cold engine
running.

As an added note, some have installed a 1.8 air valve in the original's
place. It does not fit, looks totally out of place (especially for concours!)
and does not open as wide as the original. If desperate, use it. It is cheap!

Finally, your mechanic used the old BB in the decel line trick.

As the deceleration valve causes a momentary vacuum leak as programmed by the
factory, it enables the idle to return more slowly and dilutes the parts per
million exhaust emmissions. Additionally, it prevents the rapid fall to idle
and subsequent stalling. when the diaphram in this device breaks or sticks,
the idle remains high because of a constant vacuum leak. Installing a BB in
the small vacuum line virtually disables the device.

As a quick fix, try spraying WD-40 into the decel valve and evacuate and let
off several times to free the diaphram. If it will not evacuate, it is bad
and needs expensive replacement. Good luck!

George Hussey

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 13:42:00 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: re:K-Mart Quality



>A guy at work here, used to work at an auto parts factory in Ontario 
>that made various car parts. He said that when the various parts were put
>through their quality control they were put into various bins based on their 
>quality. There was the "Garbage Bin", "Discount Store Bin",and "Good Bin".
>The parts put in the "Discount Store Bin" actually worked but were
>on the lower edge of the quality threshold (and therefore were sold for 
>less).

Sorry Kevin, that's pure urban legend! The discount stores sell such
high volume that companies would have to have totally rotten quality
control to supply all those parts. When I worked for Amoco, even our own
employees who saw the oil canned for discount stores (out of the same 
barrel as the good stuff) wouldn't buy their oil at K-Mart - I have to
admit, even me! 

Now Radio Shack, on the other hand might... after all, they never promised
the real thing, just realistic. 

Reid

Steve,

Another possibility is that the fuel line is pinched.  I had this problem
on my 75 914 when I first bought it.  Someone had changed the fuel filter
through the front trunk access and routed the fuel line so that the fron
sway bar pinched the line when cornering in one direction (I can't remember
direction.)  Some other things you might check is the fuel pump fuse on the 
relay
relay panel (engine compartment) and the connector and wiring to the fuel pump.

Dan

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 95 10:39:27 
From: da@airsoft.com
Subject: Re: Help with 911 blower wiring needed


     
It connects to wiring which exits from a hole in the left side of the fan 
shroud.  Some of these wires connect elsewhere but there will be a pair of wires
with a connector for the blower motor.  The fuse for the blower is behind the 
plastic cover that is held on by wing-bolts, on the left side of the engine 
compartment.  You may need to this the fuse too!

Derek Au

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 01:46:00 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Oil, etc.----YOU SHOULD READ THIS!

Hello to all fellow P-philers,

There has been much debate raging lately in regard to oil change intervals, 
types of oil, filters, synthetics, etc.  I would like to, however, bring up 
another related point.  That is the point of oil additives.  NOW BEFORE YOU 
GO AND IMMEDIATELY DELETE THIS MESSAGE, BEAR WITH ME.  I know this topic has 
proliferated here before, but I would like to add what I *think* is a new twist.

It is rather clearly stated in the FAQ that oil additives are generally 
considered *not-good*.  The following was taken (without permission--sorry) 
from the FAQ :
Stan comments "Duralube, Slick-50, and *EVERYTHING ELSE THAT ISN'T JUST 
PLAIN OIL* is, to be blunt, snake oil."  Bruce Anderson calls such additives 
"a cash flow device".  It is also mentioned that Slick 50 is *evil* in an 
aluminum engine, and that DuPont has categorically stated that (the 
frequently found ingredient) teflon is useless in such applications.  

It's obvious that the FAQ consensus is *forget oil additives, especially 
those containing teflon*.  I have, however, come in contact with another 
particular additive, and I wish to get everyone's brains moving on this one. 
 It is, to the best of my knowledge, a "different" type of additive, and it 
is not well known or advertized.  This product is called MILITEC-1 and it is 
distributed by Advanced Product Distributors, Inc., and it boasts some 
extensive capabilities.

According to my info., Militec-1 is a *metal conditioner* that dramatically 
reduces friction between metal surfaces.  It is an oil that gets into 
micropores of the metal and bonds there, protecting the metal surfaces 
without depending on the film strength of the oil, and the bond remains even 
through oil changes as it has become part of the metal itself.  It **DOES 
NOT CONTAIN** any solid particles such as metals or ***P.T.F.E. ( 
Polytetrafluoroethylene---that's "teflon")***, nor does it contain 
chlorinated paraffins or other harmful chemicals.  It is the only product 
added to oil that has been certified and approved in both *federal 
government* and heavy industry. Documentation is available for comparing 
Militec-1 with the independant documentation for other products.  It works 
in both extremely hot and cold temperatures, protecting against cold starts 
and overheating abuse.  Militec-1 is compatible with regular synthetic oils, 
transmission fluids and greases.  It is designed to be used in relatively 
small amounts on many moving parts:

Militec-1 is effective at a ratio of only 1.5 ounces per quart of oil for 
most applications.  Most engines will require 6 to 8 ounces every 15,000 
miles regardless of the number of oil changes during that period.  The 
transmission needs a total of only 4 ounces every 30,000 miles.  Add 2 
ounces to the differential and 1 ounce to the power steering.  For these 
sealed units, apply every 30,000 miles.  The MSRP is $18.95 for an 8-ounce 
bottle, and $29.45 for the 16-ounce bottle.

Militec claims to provide many advantages.  It can achieve 5% to 15% better 
fuel economy.  It can reduce wear by *95%* and more, and that means reduced 
maintenance costs.  It is extremely resistant to water and antifreeze, thus, 
contamination of oil has almost no effect on Militec-1's ability to 
lubricate.  It allows for greater available power by reducing energy wasted 
on internal friction.  It is claimed that *unlike other products that are 
added to oil* Militec-1 is independently documented to be completely safe.  
Militec-1 works in environments where oil has lost its effectiveness due to 
heat and stress. Likewise, Militec-1 works in environments where oil has 
become contaminated by particles, water, solvents, etc. and it also reduces 
corrosion and rust.  It also helps reduce engine wear when it is at its 
worst, *at start up*, because Militec-1 lubricates moving parts before oil 
begins flowing.  It is also advantageous for cars that are driven cold 
without being warmed up first, as well as for cars involved in stop and go 
commuting.

I came in contact with this product a while back, and I was unsure as to its 
true worth.  Then, I recently came in contact with it again at a booth at 
the Auto Show.  I spoke at length with the representative.  I questioned why 
the product seemed to me to be so obscure and unpublicized when compared to 
other products such as Slick-50.  Was it a hoax?  He simply reminded me that 
Militec does very little advertising, unlike Slick-50, and their major 
market is government agencies and the like.  He explained to me (if my 
memory serves me correctly) that the teflon contained in Slick-50 is 
designed to essentially "melt" and "bond" to engine parts to provide its 
lubricating properties, but for this process to take place, the engine had 
to reach a *very* high temperature (I forged the exact number) that was 
highly unlikely that most any engine would ever reach.  Thus, the 
"un-bonded" Slick-50 fluid is almost completely drained out of the engine 
along with the oil at the first oil change.  Militec-1, on the other hand, 
requires a much lower and common engine temperature at which it reacts with 
the engine parts, and it actually *becomes* part of the metal itself.  The 
rep then proceeded to conduct a rather convincing demonstration of his 
product.  Obviously, such a demonstration is designed to convince the buyer 
about the advantages of Militec-1, and I realize that it is entierely 
possible that such a demonstration might be set-up or "rigged" in such a way 
as to exaggerate or falsely create a believable product.  Being the 
skepticist that I am, I carefully watched the demo, and IMHO it seemed to be 
very legitimate and truthful.  I (the observer) was able to choose which 
products I wanted to compare Militec-1 to.  I chose a comparison of 
Militec-1 to conventional oil (what I use), and another test compared to 
Slick-50.  In both tests Militec-1 had clearly superior lubricating 
abilities.  If anyone is interested in exactly how the test was carried out, 
just write me and I will post that info as well.

Ok, this is a lot of fact and a lot of marketing lingo, *BUT* how much of it 
is true?  The above info stems largely from sales literature, which 
obviously fails to mention the disadvantages of Militec-1..........*if there 
are any*.   So, that is my question......Does anyone know anything about 
this stuff?  *IN THEORY* this sounds like some *GOOD S&#T*, but in actuality 
is it as good as it sounds?  Does anyone have any experience with using 
Militic-1 in both the short-term and in the long-term?  Can anyone shed some 
*new* light on oil additives and Militec-1.  I'm looking for some 
legitimate, factually based responses rather than a bunch of hyped up 
opinations, etc.  Perhaps Stan, with his earlier wisdom and comments 
regarding oils and oil additives, has some new comments in regard to 
Militec-1.........or does it too fall into the category of "Snake Oil"? 

Sorry about the length, but I felt it was necessary to provide all the 
facts.  I hope this gets everyone thinking about their cars and their oil, 
and I hope the wisdom of the net can open up the truth about this stuff.  It 
***sounds*** like a great product.  Is it?   Let me know what you think!  

Andy


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 95 14:10:03 EST
From: RON OLSON  23-Mar-1995 1409 <olson_r@cho000.dnet.ge.com>
Subject: Is motor-flushing my 944 a bad idea?

My '84 944 (59k miles) has a couple symptoms that point to a possible
stuck piston ring.  It burns 1qt oil per 500 miles, and has
poor leak-down (20%) past one ring.  As best as I could tell
looking through the spark plug hole, the cylinder wall is OK.

Without actually pulling the engine apart, the 'stuck ring' theory is
only a guess, but two different mechanics suggested that I try
to unstick the ring with one of the 5 minute motor flushes such as Gunk.
Two other mechanics said they wouldn't risk the possibility
of the flush breaking a particle free and doing some damage.
I did try a couple treatments of Techron, but with no improvement.

So, does a motor-flush have much chance of helping?  of hurting?
Any other thoughts?  Is a rebuild the only safe way out?

Ron Olson  (olson_r@cho.ge.com)

warnings about rust. They don't apply to Italian cars which are dipped
several times in salt water before shipping to make sure they turn back
to the basic elements in the shortest possible time. This car is already
full of lapped seams and a few more won't make a significant difference
in it's intended lifetime.

I PROMISE I won't ever use it on an air-cooled P-car.

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 95 14:24:03 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: "Unrealistic" Passing (was "993 Turbo ad")

> While most motorcycles have power-to-weight ratios far exceeding those 
> of most Porsches, they don't corner anywhere near as hard.  

Bikes corner just as hard as cars, unless the cars have downforce.
A production sportbike vs a production sportscar on most racetracks
(ones with turns, that is...) will be "no contest" -
the bike will waltz away in the straights. This assumes "very competent"
driving for both machines...

Race machines are a different matter - a racecar can generate about 3Gs of
aerodynamic downforce, which means that they can corner at about 4Gs, while
the race bikes are stuck at 1.2Gs, or thereabouts, since they have to make
do with "mechanical grip".


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 11:42:19 -0800 (PST)
From: Ryan John Cousineau <rcousine@sfu.ca>
Subject: Porsche v. Bike (was 993 ad)

>

> >care to share their thoughts?
> 
> 	I'd like to know what the motorcycle lap record is for Willow 	
> 	Springs.  As far as I know, the fastest anyone's done it in a 	
> 	real production-based Porsche (I'm excluding "production" cars 	
> 	like 935s, 956s, etc.) is 1:29 or so, in a 914-6.  Since Willow 
> 	is a popular track for both cycles and autos, this information 
> 	would probably settle the question.
> 
> 	Anyone know?
> 

Here's the deal: street motorcycles win against street cars on race 
tracks, if both are driven by highly competent pilots. The last test I 
saw was of a CBR900RR on street-compound tires ridden by Nick Ienatch 
(sp?) (long racing resume, current _Sport Rider_ editor) roasting an NSX on 
autocross tires driven by the US NSX champion or something. They ran at 
both Willow Springs and Streets of Willow, the latter being a tight road 
course. The upshot is this: in those conditions, the bike's ability to 
accelerate out of a turn overcomes the car's ability to brake later and 
drive faster through the turn. This mirrors contests I've seen between 
ZR-1s and FZR1000s, and FZR1000s and Caterham Super 7s (aka Lotus Super 7s).

Now, it should be pointed out that the average driver (ie me) can 
typically go faster by bike than by car. A determined car driver should 
be able to smoke by me on a typical twisty road. Csaba Csere brought it 
home in an editorial a while back where he tells of catching a GSXR1100 
rider on the Pacific Coast highway while driving a 5 or 7 series BMW (!). 
His point was he could drive closer to the margins of the car than the 
rider could ride to the margins of the bike. 

On the other hand, in many a day of sporting riding, I have caught many
sports cars (including a lipstick red 944) and have not been passed (to my
recollection) at all. 

Finally, at the high end: GP500 motorcycles, weighing around 300 lbs and 
with about 180 hp, are no match for F1 cars, IndyCars, or likely even 
NASCARs. 

Finally Finally, Nurburgring: Serious biker v. Serious Porschephile, honor 
or worse on the line, the Porsche will start losing from the starting 
line and will never catch up.

------------------------------

Militec's makers) out there in cyber-space could shed some genuine truth on

SIGNIFICANT DIFFERENCES WHEN COMPARED TO OTHER ADDITIVES????

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 95 15:00:52 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: "Unrealistic" Passing

> >I'd like to know what the motorcycle lap record is for Willow  
> >Springs.  As far as I know, the fastest anyone's done it in a  
> >real production-based Porsche (I'm excluding "production" >cars  
>> like 935s, 956s, etc.) is 1:29 or so, in a 914-6.  Since Willow 
>> is a popular track for both cycles and autos, this information 
>> would probably settle the question.
>
> >Anyone know?
>
>I'm not sure if your 1:29 or so was set before Willow was repaved (with wider
>and smoother turns one and five),
>but over the winter Superbike (NOT GP machinery) times dipped into the
>1:23's. Having said this, on the vast majority of tracks REAL race cars are
>substantially faster than REAL race motorcycles, due to the substantially
>higher cornering forces 4-wheelers can generate. In fact, in this month's
>RACER magazine, there is a comparison between GP bikes and Formula 1
>cars--check it out.

This seems to agree with the conclusions of this debate which have been
generated most of the other places it has been discussed. The typical
conclusion is that on a race track with comparable driver/riders, street
bikes beat street cars, but race cars beat race bikes, assuming roughly
the same level of "vehicular intensity" (super bikes against super cars,
top class racing bikes against F1 or other "top end" race cars).

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 15:40:06 -0500 (EST)
From: Frequently Frustrated! <quartz@minerva.cis.yale.edu>
Subject: More 914 quirks...

Doctor Doctor!
	I recently gave Gretchin a thorough tuning and found that, after 
replacing and optimizing all ignition components (New points made the 
biggest difference) that she idled WAY too high.  I COMPLETELY closed the 
idle screw and STILL it was too high.  My auxiliary air valve was not the 
cause, it is working fine and plus I plugged it anyway to be sure.  I 
still have a warm idle of 2300 RPM!
	So I took my unlit propane torch and went over all the lines when 
the car was running to see if I could detect a change in idle speed 
indicating an air leak, ad nauseum (literally)  with no effect.  I can 
turn the idle down by changing the points setting, but I trust the 
dwell-meter settings at factory specs.  Is that wrong?  Then of course 
there's that adjusting screw on the pressure sensor which I've never been 
too sure of...  So I'm out of ideas here...
	While we are on quirks, I just noticed yesterday that my steerin 
wheel jerks on rare ocassion a bit, and I think I have localized the 
problem to my left outer brake caliper, which seems to be rubbing against 
the disk for some unknown reason.  The pads and disks are a year old and 
in good shape, so I fear for my calipers.  I have sooo little time to 
mess these days with my primary source of transportation that I was 
wondering if someone might give me a clue as to what I'm getting into 
before I try to take it all apart this weekend and find I need parts or 
something.  Any guesses are welcome!  Thanks!
Rick
1972 914-4 traffic cone orange "Gretchin"

NSR500, Grand Prix racing bike made by Honda, weighs about 240 LBS.  It is a
fuel injected two stoke machine.(sometimes carb) It makes 180+ horse power.
Honda engineers does not want to say exactly how many ponies this little bike
carries.  It did reach 200+ mph on Hockenheim (sp?) track with their factory
racer (Itoh) during the normal race.  I don't remember the lap times.  But they
are not as fast as F1 cars.

I've seen a 928 belt about 4-5 years old that was dry rotted!
The belt didnt have that many miles on it.

Inspect your belts and replace if they look worn or cracked.
Belts are cheap compared to the cost of a valve job.

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 14:14:24 -0800 (PST)
From: pft@netcom.com (Patrick Ford Trumbull)
Subject: Re:cars/bikes

 
	Yes , this has been covered before, but....Racing cars with racing
	tires and the downforce to fully exploit them are *much* faster.
	At Laguna, Cart cars run about 1:10's, the best 500's run 1:25's.
	But...at the expense of coming off as a motorcycle squid(I admit
	it) fast street bikes on street tires are at least the match of
	fast street cars on street tires.  In sane street driving, where
	fear of law and dismemberment are always present, playing at going
	fast is often point and squirt stuff, and the difference in cornering
	speeds is not significant. The acceleration difference is.  I talked
	to Don Canet right after Road and Track did their 0-100-0 test,
	when R&T was so amazed by the zx-9.  He said that it would have been
	even more of a blow out if the bike had had the same surface to 
	stop on as the cars, but the bike was stopped before it even got
	to the sticky part the cars were using to stop on. I hesitate to
	talk about street sillines on an open forum, but yes, I have had
	play races(sorry Stan) with P-cars on my CBR600f2, and yes, the
	bike is quicker in real world point to point stuff. Throw in bumps,
	dirt, water, etc, and the car wins every time, but not in ideal 
	bike conditions..
	As to race tracks with street cars and street bikes, I seem to 
	remember a Motorcyclist Magazine test at Willow, FZR1000(I think)
	vs a ZR1(shaved tires, race car driver) Bike won. These things
	happen.

	Patrick

	Bunch of fast cars
	Bunch of fast bikes
	no sense

I've just used it.

I ordered this stuff, Quick n Brite, off of the Home Shopping Channel.
(Although you can order it right from Quick n Brite Inc.) So here's how I
used it. The interior of the '73 911T was kinda crappy and the case being
that sunvisors are rather unavailable, I decided to try and clean them
(couldn't hurt, they were brown).

Anyways, I believe that because it is all biodegradable and concentrated
that it cleans well and keeps the moisture in the leather and vinyl. Either
way, it has stayed soft and not slick, but still 'moist' like.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 95 17:31:30 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Heater control problem

> I'm having a problem with controlling the temperature inside my 89 944s2.
> It seems that the heater will be on full blast even though I have set
> the temperature control to the lowest setting. I've even tried to turn on
> the A/C but it is still blowing out hot air. I'd appreciated any comments/sol
utions
> to this problem.
> 
> Thanks,
> Khang Bui

Hello, Khang,

One of two problems:

1) the coolant valve (which controls how much coolant is allowed into the
heater core, and thus how much heat) may be either non-functional (due to a
bad vacuum diaphragm) or may have a hole in it allowing hot coolant through,
even though the diaphragm is pulling it closed.  Cheap thing to fix.

2) The AC control switch is broke. EXPEN$IVE... Dealer price is $660, used
price is $225.

good luck
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 15:57:56 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Oil, etc.----YOU SHOULD READ THIS! (fwd)

> > According to my info., Militec-1 is a *metal conditioner* that dramatically 
> > reduces friction between metal surfaces...
> 
> Something about submicrom borate speres acting as tiny ball bearings.

I'm not a petrochemist, but I know a lot of them. Ditto on metallurgy,
engine dynamics, etc.

The only things I've even *HEARD* of that has any promise as an additive
isn't even an additive -- it's a complete lubrication replacement using
buckyballs suspended in some polycarbonate ester. Of course, it requires a
ground-up lubrication system replacement, and double of course, would *NOT*
be advisable in any air-cooled application where most of the heat load
is borne by the oil...

I'm *VERY* skeptical about anything that says anything about bonding,
pore filling, or particulate adhesion to promote surface smoothing 
all in the name of reducing friction. There's a *LOT* more going on to 
create friction -- side loads, expansion of materials from heat, etc
than can be compensated for in this way. In fact, the "traditional" break
in period on an engine is a time in which the moving parts self-conform
and there *SHOULD* be no major friction left from rough surfaces, etc.
at that point.

Horse puckey, most likely. Again.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 19:53:23 -0500
From: PerryS7342@aol.com
Subject: Re: "Unrealistic Passing..et al"

Taka, Kyle, and Andy:

Don't know about the new 993 Turbo vs the Diablo, but I have driven
Nurburgring a few times in years past with all sorts of "conveyances" for
comparison (Tour buses, family sedans, racing bikes, factory test cars, etc).
 Also a few  "restricted" ??? sessions for performance sedans, sport cars,
and racing motorcycles.  One such session had a good variety of full fairing
racing bikes (Hondas, Kaws, Suzukis, MVs, Ducatis, etc) and a wide assortment
of Ferrari TRs, 288 GTOs, Porsche 934/935s, MB AMG "Hammers" ,  and at least
one Countach.

On the 22 km long Nordschleife, particularly on the backside (sorry I don't
remember the turn names but it's on the Adenauer side) the track elevation
drops dramatically  with a series of almost continuous turns on a relatively
rough and usually always damp track surface.  The performance cars
consistently passed the bikes and drove deeper into the corners where the
intervening straight was short enough that the bikes superior "lo end"
acceleration didn't help.  These appeared to be well ridden machines (I owned
a  KZ 1000 at the time ) but their braking and setup for the corners allowed
the cars to get by.

Similarly, on the front straight (leading up to what was the old Hotel
"Tribune") the cars passed the bikes about a third of the way up at  speeds
of probably  220-240 kph.

I had a excellent vantage point going into the corners since about everything
passed me.....

Also, if you've seen the video of the Ruf Yellow Bird on Nurburgring, the
cars like to use enough oversteer in the corners to convince the bikers to
stay away!

Perry



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 19:40:51 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 car stereo

> I'm curious to know what other 914 owners have done with respect to stereo
> design and speaker placement. I just bought my 2nd 914 (a 95% restored 1974
> 2.0) and have about $1000 to spend on stereo equipment. Any suggestions?

Yes. Spend it on a nice home system upgrade. 

In a well-done 914, with the top off, you'll not be able to hear it
anyway. Hell, more importantly, once you get used to listening to the
engine, you won't *WANT* to hear it....

Stan

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Oil, etc.----YOU SHOULD READ THIS!
Author:  porschephiles-request@tta.com at SMTPGATE
Date:    3/23/95 11:21 AM


Hello to all fellow P-philers,

There has been much debate raging lately in regard to oil change intervals, 
types of oil, filters, synthetics, etc.  I would like to, however, bring up 
another related point.  That is the point of oil additives.  NOW BEFORE YOU 
GO AND IMMEDIATELY DELETE THIS MESSAGE, BEAR WITH ME.  I know this topic has
proliferated here before, but I would like to add what I *think* is a new twist.


It is rather clearly stated in the FAQ that oil additives are generally 
considered *not-good*.  The following was taken (without permission--sorry) 
from the FAQ :
Stan comments "Duralube, Slick-50, and *EVERYTHING ELSE THAT ISN'T JUST 
PLAIN OIL* is, to be blunt, snake oil."  Bruce Anderson calls such additives 
"a cash flow device".  It is also mentioned that Slick 50 is *evil* in an 
aluminum engine, and that DuPont has categorically stated that (the 
frequently found ingredient) teflon is useless in such applications.

It's obvious that the FAQ consensus is *forget oil additives, especially 
those containing teflon*.  I have, however, come in contact with another 
particular additive, and I wish to get everyone's brains moving on this one.
 It is, to the best of my knowledge, a "different" type of additive, and it
is not well known or advertized.  This product is called MILITEC-1 and it is 
distributed by Advanced Product Distributors, Inc., and it boasts some 
extensive capabilities.

According to my info., Militec-1 is a *metal conditioner* that dramatically 
reduces friction between metal surfaces.  It is an oil that gets into 
micropores of the metal and bonds there, protecting the metal surfaces 
without depending on the film strength of the oil, and the bond remains even 
through oil changes as it has become part of the metal itself.  It **DOES 
NOT CONTAIN** any solid particles such as metals or ***P.T.F.E. ( 
Polytetrafluoroethylene---that's "teflon")***, nor does it contain 
chlorinated paraffins or other harmful chemicals.  It is the only product 
added to oil that has been certified and approved in both *federal 
government* and heavy industry. Documentation is available for comparing 
Militec-1 with the independant documentation for other products.  It works 
in both extremely hot and cold temperatures, protecting against cold starts 
and overheating abuse.  Militec-1 is compatible with regular synthetic oils, 
transmission fluids and greases.  It is designed to be used in relatively 
small amounts on many moving parts:

Militec-1 is effective at a ratio of only 1.5 ounces per quart of oil for 
most applications.  Most engines will require 6 to 8 ounces every 15,000 
miles regardless of the number of oil changes during that period.  The 
transmission needs a total of only 4 ounces every 30,000 miles.  Add 2 
ounces to the differential and 1 ounce to the power steering.  For these 
sealed units, apply every 30,000 miles.  The MSRP is $18.95 for an 8-ounce 
bottle, and $29.45 for the 16-ounce bottle.

Militec claims to provide many advantages.  It can achieve 5% to 15% better 
fuel economy.  It can reduce wear by *95%* and more, and that means reduced 
maintenance costs.  It is extremely resistant to water and antifreeze, thus, 
contamination of oil has almost no effect on Militec-1's ability to 
lubricate.  It allows for greater available power by reducing energy wasted 
on internal friction.  It is claimed that *unlike other products that are 
added to oil* Militec-1 is independently documented to be completely safe. 
Militec-1 works in environments where oil has lost its effectiveness due to 
heat and stress. Likewise, Militec-1 works in environments where oil has 
become contaminated by particles, water, solvents, etc. and it also reduces 
corrosion and rust.  It also helps reduce engine wear when it is at its 
worst, *at start up*, because Militec-1 lubricates moving parts before oil 
begins flowing.  It is also advantageous for cars that are driven cold 
without being warmed up first, as well as for cars involved in stop and go 
commuting.

I came in contact with this product a while back, and I was unsure as to its 
true worth.  Then, I recently came in contact with it again at a booth at 
the Auto Show.  I spoke at length with the representative.  I questioned why 
the product seemed to me to be so obscure and unpublicized when compared to 
other products such as Slick-50.  Was it a hoax?  He simply reminded me that 
Militec does very little advertising, unlike Slick-50, and their major 
market is government agencies and the like.  He explained to me (if my 
memory serves me correctly) that the teflon contained in Slick-50 is 
designed to essentially "melt" and "bond" to engine parts to provide its 
lubricating properties, but for this process to take place, the engine had 
to reach a *very* high temperature (I forged the exact number) that was 
highly unlikely that most any engine would ever reach.  Thus, the 
"un-bonded" Slick-50 fluid is almost completely drained out of the engine 
along with the oil at the first oil change.  Militec-1, on the other hand, 
requires a much lower and common engine temperature at which it reacts with 
the engine parts, and it actually *becomes* part of the metal itself.  The 
rep then proceeded to conduct a rather convincing demonstration of his 
product.  Obviously, such a demonstration is designed to convince the buyer 
about the advantages of Militec-1, and I realize that it is entierely 
possible that such a demonstration might be set-up or "rigged" in such a way 
as to exaggerate or falsely create a believable product.  Being the 
skepticist that I am, I carefully watched the demo, and IMHO it seemed to be 
very legitimate and truthful.  I (the observer) was able to choose which 
products I wanted to compare Militec-1 to.  I chose a comparison of 
Militec-1 to conventional oil (what I use), and another test compared to 
Slick-50.  In both tests Militec-1 had clearly superior lubricating 
abilities.  If anyone is interested in exactly how the test was carried out, 
just write me and I will post that info as well.

Ok, this is a lot of fact and a lot of marketing lingo, *BUT* how much of it 
is true?  The above info stems largely from sales literature, which 
obviously fails to mention the disadvantages of Militec-1..........*if there 
are any*.   So, that is my question......Does anyone know anything about 
this stuff?  *IN THEORY* this sounds like some *GOOD S&#T*, but in actuality 
is it as good as it sounds?  Does anyone have any experience with using 
Militic-1 in both the short-term and in the long-term?  Can anyone shed some 
*new* light on oil additives and Militec-1.  I'm looking for some 
legitimate, factually based responses rather than a bunch of hyped up 
opinations, etc.  Perhaps Stan, with his earlier wisdom and comments 
regarding oils and oil additives, has some new comments in regard to 
Militec-1.........or does it too fall into the category of "Snake Oil"?

Sorry about the length, but I felt it was necessary to provide all the 
facts.  I hope this gets everyone thinking about their cars and their oil, 
and I hope the wisdom of the net can open up the truth about this stuff.  It 
***sounds*** like a great product.  Is it?   Let me know what you think!

Andy

Porschephiles #1267                         Fri Mar 24 02:00:06 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 21:36:07 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Interesting 911SC for sale...

>The fuse for the blower is behind the 
>plastic cover that is held on by wing-bolts, on the left side of the engine 
>compartment.  You may need to this the fuse too!

This statement reminded me of a car I saw at our local pcar repair
shop yesterday.  While wandering amidst various Porsches in need of
repair, I saw what appeared to be a nice SC with the rear up on car
ramps.  I walked over and saw that the lower valve covers had been 
removed and that one of them contained a couple of broken head studs.
Ouch.  The mechanic then suggested I take a look at the #3 exhaust
valve rocker shaft.  It had backed almost completely out!!  I half expected
the rocker arm to fall out.  I also noticed that the valve adjustment
locknuts were so covered in crud that they were barely visible.  The
entire underneath of the car looked like a refinery - due to the leaking
engine oil cooler.  I then stood up and looked in the engine compartment
and saw something a little out of the ordinary.  You know those little
needles that you use to pump up footballs, volleyballs, etc?  One was
being used as a FUSE in the fusebox noted in the above post!!!!  It had been
there for awhile, too.  The car also had three different brands of tires
on it, and it was a white car that had been painted black - and they
missed a few spots.

Having seen all of this, I asked what I thought was an obvious question -
"What was the car brought in for?".  The mechanic simply replied, "Won't
go into 5th gear".

This car is for sale - as soon as 5th gear gets fixed.  I'll get the number
for you....<vbg>.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Lo Eric,

Start with your shift bushings under that vent in the floor just in front 
of the rear seats.  I'm a little more advanced in that I machine my own 
our of delrin.  New bushings here *REALLY MAKE A DIFFERENCE*.  You also 
have a chance to place the shift pattern at perhaps a more advantageous 
position for you.

legroom! (For the passenger. For the driver, the pedals are so narrow 
and tightly-spaced, you can't wear sneakers when driving, otherwise 
you'll unavoidably press two pedals when you try to brake...)

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 19:53:36 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: 914 Car Stereo

David (DavidSoCal@aol.com) wrote:

>I'm curious to know what other 914 owners have done with respect to 
>stereo design and speaker placement. .... Any suggestions?
>
>Also, is the center console standard on the 1974? My 1970 didn't have 
>one.  It's cheesy and I'm planning on removing it.
>
>Finally, I'm happy to have joined the list (as of today)!

David:

While Stan's correct about the difficulty of getting a car stereo to 
compete with the noise generated by a 914, there are a couple of things 
you CAN do.

Buy an amp.  It doesn't have to be good, just loud.  50W/channel is more 
than enough.

Speaker placement is a real problem.  The obvious locations are in the 
lower-front corners of the doors and in the kick-panels just in front of 
the doors (in the outer corners of the footwells).

As long as you still have the center console, you can fit a couple of 8" 
drivers (back-to-back, firing out the sides of the console) in there.

Several companies make headrest-mounted speakers that'll make it easier 
to hear the stereo while the top's down; naturally, the sound quality is 
somewhat less than excellent.

 -Andy

P.S.  I wouldn't spend $1K on the thing; after $3-400, you'll probably 
be well into diminishing returns.


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 20:14:44 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: 993 Turbo ad on TV

>There is all this, uh, appendage measuring on behalf of the new Porsche Turbo
>and Lamborghini Diablo. Figures from Car and Drivel were quoted. As a

As I started this whole convo, let me clarify something - I am not a drooling 
Lamborghini fanatic - far from it. However, I do not believe that the new 911 
Turbo can approach a Diablo's performance. (Remember, this was in reference 
to the Nurburgring, where both cars were already moving along smartly.)

>a second faster than anybody else's. This sells magazines. Selling magazines
>(or rather, the ads in magazines, and the more magazines you claim to sell,
>the higher your advertising rates) is the only reason magazines are in
>business.

That's funny. I subscribe to Car & Driver because they have intelligent, 
humorous writing, what appear to be honest road tests, and they're a bunch of 
lunatics, like me. (Cannonball Baker Sea-To-Shining-Sea Rally? Car vs 
airplane? Piloting an Amphicar around the Queen Mary? That's C&D for you.)

>Unless they rented a high-speed test track, I also doubt they have been to
>the car's top speed. They like to test top speed in the early morning on
>Detroit freeways.

They do use a high-speed test track, and a fifth wheel at all times - which I 
daresay you didn't use when you came up with "4.25 seconds" on an older 911 
Turbo.

>If there is any doubt about the Eenimobile being faster than the new Turbo,
>there is a simple solution: wait a while. Sooner or later the Lambo will
>break. You can beat on a Turbo all day long on the drag strip; I've

It's German. But that doesn't mean it won't break. But it's unfair to assume that 
the Diablo will break more often than any other car.

>While I was at R&T I asked a senior editor why we kept putting these
>unaffordable, undrivable Italian exotics on the cover, and writing stories
>about how glorious they are. His reply was that 1) red cars on the cover,
>especially red Italian cars, sells magazines and 2) we can't tell the truth
>about them, it would only shatter the readers' dreams.

I have middling respect for R&T, and mostly for their old-car stuff. I despise that 
right-wing jerk (PJ O'Rourke? or someone else) who writes for them, and their 
covers are apalling. The ONLY time they don't have a red car on the cover is 
when you can't see the car in red, like the Viper GTS coupe. (Did I mention that 
I hate red cars... It's annoying that all three of my cars are red. Not my choice. :)
(At least they're better than Motor Trend - I wouldn't let my cats poop on that 
rag.)

>To be fair, I just had a Ferrari 355 and it's the first modern Ferrari I
>really like. It didn't come off as a kit car at all. Reliability, who knows?

My good friend recently sold one of his two Ferrari Dinos, a '72 U.S. spec GT. 
He'd owned the car for fifteen years and it never broke down on him. Neither 
has his other Dino. (He also had a 911 that he drove all years long - used to piss 
off the PCA folks by driving it in the winter - it was the only car he had at the 
time. He eventually sold it with over 300K miles, and it was in very good 
condition, to help finance the second Dino.)
Ferraris (with the possible except of the insane-fast ones like the F40, 288GTO, 
etc) are as reliable as most cars, as long as they're maintained well.

Anyways, that is SO far off the point as to be a total waste. But let's do a quick 
comparo - 911 Turbo vs Diablo VT.  Both have AWD. Lambo is mid-engined, 
ensuring smoother handling. The Porsche has a twin-turbo 3.6l 6-cylinder 
motor. The Lambo has a normally-aspirated 5.7l 12-cylinder. The Porsche tops 
out at 181, the Lambo has been proven to go over 200mph.

We'll have to wait for the test times to see how the 911 Turbo fares under "real" 
testing.

(If you have flames, anyone, let's try to keep them intelligent, no "you're crazy, 
you're wrong, you're stupid". If you can, prove me wrong. If not... Well, you 
know. :)

Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 21:05:33 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: 911 vs Diablo vs Viper?

>        Also just to go back to passing bla, bla, bla. Last week two  my
>friends, (one has Dodge Viper, other 911 Turbo 3.6) tried the old fashioned
>drag lane, guess what VIper got trashed specially after a certain distance. Of

>Diablo, and since 911 takes care of Viper! Logic!

low, the Viper's incredible torque should win...

Of course, I'd much rather own a Viper than either of the other two. (Someday, I'll 
get my yellow Viper... The 914 is the "Targa Training Car" for it. :)

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 12:01:00 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: 914 Car Stereo

David,

FYI the topic of stereos, amps, speakers, etc. raged here earlier.  Check 
the archives arount the beginning of Feb. 1995 if you want to learn more.  
Stan was right when he said that you will have difficulty hearing a system 
over the road/engine noise in a top-less 914.  Andy Warren was also correct 
is recommending an amp.  A solid amp is your best first defense for 
overcoming noise.  I would like to add, however, that it IS important to 
purchase a good amp.  It need not be "competition level equipment", and a 
moderate power level will be adequate, but a cheap, poor-built amp will do 
more harm than good.  Andy is also correct to some degree that after a 
certain price range, you will enter diminishing returns with respect to 
overcoming noise.  You might be surprised, however, at how quickly you can 
drop $1000 into car stero.

Feel free to e-mail me if you would like more info.

Andy
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Installer)
