Date: Thu, 23 Mar 1995 23:52:17 -0800
From: gschoepp@netcom.com (Gene Schoepp)
Subject: '86 928S Six Month Report (LONG)


For the members, patrons, readers, and the archives... I humbly present 
this, my 6 month recap of owning my first Porsche.

In August of 1994 I came to grips with a three year sport-utility induced 
absence of a sportscar in my life. I assessed my options and began the 
search for a Porsche 944. In doing my research, I stumbled across this list 
and various other sources of information (magazines, etc).

I quickly came to the opinion that the 944 would require significantly more 
maintenance than I was interested in (flames to /dev/null; it's *my* 
opinion). This, combined with the unexpected values to be had in the mid to 
late 80's 928 models sent my search in another direction. I'd always loved 
the styling of the 928.

My search here in Dallas was fairly difficult. Two of the three Porsche 
dealerships said that they hadn't seen used 928's in a "long time". 
Surprisingly, the third dealer had THREE; an '84, an '86, and an '89. I 
went and drove all three. In addition, I viewed a few private-sale cars. 
Nothing there worth buying or even pre-purchasing, unfortunately, as the 
price points were significantly better.

I set my sights at this point on the '86 928S in Marine Blue Metallic at 
the only 928-possessing local dealership. I arranged an 8 hour "test drive" 
to include a non-invasive pre-purchase inspection. The car had just 44,000 
miles on it and the immediate previous owner was the wife of a local auto 
dealership owner. The pre-purchase came back very positively; very good to 
excellent mechanical condition, good to very good exterior/interior. A few 
items were noted for future exploration (water pump/timing belt by 65k, due 
for 45k major service), and a few for immediate attention (Vitron camshaft 
seals, front and back).

I consulted my insurance agent and found that my insurance would not be too 
awful on the car (ABS and alarm discounts). Somewhere in this timeframe I 
was discussing the car with an associate (soon to become my partner in a 
new firm), and he remarked "You better be careful; pretty soon you won't 
have any excuse not to buy that car..." Too true.

In the middle of September, right smack on my birthday, I went to the 
dealership to sign the papers. Interest rates on used cars weren't very 
appealing at that point (I imagine that they're not much better now), so I 
borrowed the money from myself and plunked down $18,500 for the car. At the 
time, with the given mileage, $18.5k was considered "right on" for an 
"average" condition *retail* 928S, and was just a tad lower than the asking 
price. However, the dealership corrected a few minor interior and radio 
problems, and re-dyed the leather seat exit/entry bolster on the driver's 
side which was worn. I was, and am, satisfied with the amount I paid for 
the car.

Within a week of taking possession, I put the car in for its 45k service. 
The service, including oil/filter change was around $275. I had the 
camshaft seals updated to the tune of about another $250, and had all the 
belts replaced for roughly another $150. I decided to wait on the timing 
belt/water pump replacement until about 55k (creeping up there now...).

So much for the formalities... I had the car. To me, it probably represents 
the pinnacle of a civilized performance vehicle. The engine is strong and 
willing at almost any point in its curve, and the sound it makes past 3,000 
or so rpms is sweet music. Its road manner on the highway is quiet, 
comfortable and very enjoyable, even over long periods of time. One 500+ 
mile in a day trip, done twice, proved this last point out. It cruises like 
it was on glass and holds 80mph at a steady 2400rpm.

I've had both the good and the bad "other people" Porsche experiences. 
There was the gorgeous, drop-dead blond who I formerly worked with who 
fairly gushed about how she "loved my car"; and the beer drinking jerks on 
the road who "show no mercy" when it comes to merging German metal.

When it comes to other Porsche owners, I've always been received warmly 
here on Porschephiles (except by Stan, who still thinks I should have 
bought a 911 and whose most complimentary comment was "sounds like a nice 
car- for a 928" :-), but alas, Porschephiles is not reflective of the 
Dallas Porsche landscape. The folks who bought 'em in the 80's still have 
their 911's and are either confused or perturbed by my flashing and waving. 
928 owners, however, always wave, flash, and alert me if I've not already 
alerted them of my presence. A smile and a wave is the minimum I've gotten 
from other 8 cylinder, water cooled, engine mounted where God intended 
Porsches [deliberate flame bait: tongue in cheek: I am smiling right now].

Other than the initial services, my car hasn't been to see the mechanic. It 
is now due for an oil change (5,000 miles on 20W50 synthetic) and will have 
that done shortly. I topped the oil up once, about half a quart roughly 
three weeks after its service. It has been fine since.

The car still puts a smile on my face; whether I'm driving it, washing it, 
or filling it with crappy reformulated, oxygenated, adulterated 
almost-fuel. As a "life experience", this is one that I personally rank up 
there with my big successes in life; birth, marriage, quitting my job to 
start my first company, buying my first Porsche. In my obviously shallow 
opinion, it has enriched my life far beyond what I thought an automobile 
could. This is the first vehicle I've owned that after six months of 
ownership I'm really not thinking about what I want next; I'm just looking 
forward to the next time I'll drive it.

Having re-arranged my home situation to accomodate seperate feline/Porsche 
accomodations (yes, I was the one who inccocently started the cats/Porsche 
thread- no additional follow-ups necessary), everything is well in the 
Schoepp household. My wife of five years (another of my successes- hope she 
thinks so too) loves to ride in the car; a little less enthusiastic on 
driving it, but she's done a little of that too.

It has grown late while I've been composing, so I apologize if this has 
been a tad bit rambling torwards the end. To sum it all up, and 
to shamelessly quote Stan...

                "I can't imagine owning anything else"


Gene Schoepp
gschoepp@netcom.com
'86 928S Marine Blue Metallic
'6x Spousal unit, "Ginger"
2 DSH cats I actually own
5 DSH cats seen to be near my home
Various other non P-cars; Honda, Shelby, Scout II



------------------------------

Date: 24 Mar 95 11:10:00 +0000
From: swellen@intgp1.att.com
Subject: RE: additives in oil.

So we hear of yet another does everything oil additive.
Look guys there is a simple guidance for oil additives,
funny spark plugs, economy devices, tyre softners etc.

Car manufactures, oil companys etc would fit these magical
devices if they worked, after all they want to impress us
all with better performance, good economy etc. Porsche 
actually research a lot of these products, if it is any
good it'll be factory recommended. If it isn't factory
recommended then treat it's claims as if Doctor Hook was
selling you his elixir of life.

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 95 07:22:28 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 3200 RPM 944

> 
> Dear George,
> 
> Several local owners of 944's here have experienced a vibration at 3200 
> RPM.  It seems to appear in gear or out, clutch in or out.  The vibration 
> appears in a very narrow range of motor operation.  Local dealer advise 
> is that the slots that correctly allign the balance shafts are off.  I'm 
> a 911 type and have had very little experience with 944s but can follow 
> what you say.  Your opinion would be appreciated.
> 
> David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
> "Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
>                                       Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974
> 

My experience with this kind of problem is that the shift knob buzzes like a
vibrator (female readers should not try this, for fear of losing control.)

Your dealer is probably right.

The proper alignment at TDC on #1 Cylinder is shown in a diagram that Jim
Pasha included in one of his articles on 944 timing belts in Excellence
around June or July 1994.

Usually, the misalignment occurs when the water pump is replaced or when the
balance shaft seals are replaced.

Good luck
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net

172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 95 07:28:31 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Smashed 924-S rear hatch

> Hi.
> Well some piece of human filth smashed the rear hatch of my Dad's 1987 924-S
> tonight.  Does anyone know where I can find a good, cheap(er) replacement
> hatch? 

I do, give me a call and I can help you...

 Can I use a 1977-1982 924 Hatch and just attach the rubber spoiler
> from the S?  

Possible, but chances are you will break the 924 hatch when you drill the
holes for the spoiler.

> As an alternative, is the glass seperate from the hatch frame -

Not by design, but some glass has separate from the frame. Generally not
separately available.

> can I replace only the glass and keep the original frame (or are they one
> unit)?

Probably not.
> BTW, has anyone weighed one of these hatches?  

Yep, they are heavy, and cumbersome to hold.

>I put all the glass bits into
> a bin and it was AMAZINGLY heavy - seems like a bit of a performance handicap
> (any lexan replacements??)

Yep, lexan replacements, not including frame, are about 700 dollars US.

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 95 07:31:27 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Lowered 944?

> 
> There were some comments a few months ago about problems with ball joints 
> breaking at the control arms for 944s which were lowered and used on the 
> track. My 944 is lowered between 0.5 and 1.0 inches. I have Koni sport 
> shocks and use stock alignment specs because I drive this car on the street. 

> Should I be concerned at all?
> 
> Thanks.
> Peter

You didn't say what year your car is.

If it is 1985/2 or later (aluminum control arms) I would keep a close eye on
them.

Even the non-lowered cars wear out their ball joints.

Good luck

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 95 08:32:05 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: More 914 quirks...

>	I recently gave Gretchin a thorough tuning and found that, after 
>replacing and optimizing all ignition components (New points made the 
>biggest difference) that she idled WAY too high.  I COMPLETELY closed the 
>idle screw and STILL it was too high.  My auxiliary air valve was not the 
>cause, it is working fine and plus I plugged it anyway to be sure.  I 
>still have a warm idle of 2300 RPM!

As you suggest, you have the classic symptom (in a MPC FI car) of an air
leak. I'm not familiar with the propane torch approach to finding it, but
some common leakage spots you may want to check are the pressure sensor
(remove the hose and suck on it- any air flow at all constitutes a leak)
and the fuel injector seals. Temporarily disconnect and plug all of the
"unnecessary" things you can (you already did this for the aux. air valve).
The "suck on it" method also works for checking other things you may not
want to disconnect, like the vacuum advance diaphram.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 08:38:08 -0500 (EST)
From: "Derek Cahill" <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: 914 headroom

In message Thu, 23 Mar 1995 20:26:20 -0800,
  jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)  writes:

>> By removing the backpad, there are many different racing seats that will
>>  sit lower, but not necessarily look good in your 914! You must be one
>>  of those height-impaired individuals - huh? My dad and brother both
>> tower over me (they are over 6 feet) and cannot fit in 914s either!
>>
>
> I'm surprised to hear you say that. I'm 6'2" or 3" (dunno for sure :),
> and my 914 has PLENTY of headroom - even with the top on! :)
>
> That was one of the things that amazed me most about the car. Legroom
> could be a bit more, though...

For a tight space, try out a Camaro... or better yet a Miata! Me, at
5'10-11", with the seat all the way down, the windshield top blocks my view,
but if I put it all the way up :) I can just live without the top up here in
cold, rainy New Jersey... :(

Now, for the Porsche related bit (!), the 914 fitting certain 6 footers
while not letting others in can be explained like this: you are basically
two parts, top and bottom. If you are mostly top, clearly you won't fit into
most cars, but if you are mostly bottom, you'll fit into nearly anything.
(The amazing reason they give legroom and headroom numbers...)
 -Derek Cahill
(adding the obvious to the discussion)

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 07:59:44 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: RE: K-Mart Quality



My most humble apologies to Kevin re urban legend comment.

Maybe I'm naive, but I don't think a manufacturer in the
U.S. could get away with selling their rejects to a 
discount chain without getting sued. This all started with
Bosch plugs, and I think we can reasonably expect the spark
plugs we buy to be the same whether we buy them from the dealer,
a car parts store, or K-Mart. The fact that the new style Bosch
plugs sometimes fail is independent of where they are purchased.

QED

Reid

I drove a 67 Elan (fixed head coupe) as my only car back in the late
60's, when I was young and stupid (I'm not young anymore-). This 
included work and play, snow, etc. You can drive the car with almost
anything on your feet, including heavy work boots, by using the sides
of your feet. Of course for "spirited driving" you want something narrow
enough to use the pedals right. As you note, they were (and are) 
wonderful cars. In fact they were wonderful just as Colin Chapman
made them, without flares, wide tires, etc. There were a number of
things about my 67 911S which I didn't like in comparison to the
Lotus, after the Lotus burned to the ground from a leaky fuel line :-(

True enough!! I'm *only* 6'3", but to put it in perspective, that's over

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 95 07:03:33 PST
From: radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil
Subject: Oils and stuff

          Someone posted a Web address a few days back...

          http://ganglion.anes.med.umich.edu/NSX/other.html

          For all of those interested in getting some FACTS on oil
          additives (and have WWW access) this site is an almost
          religious experience!  I spent over 2 hours after work
          yesterday just reading up on scientifically based car stuff.

          What did it say?
          Oil Additives are for the most part crap (but we already
          knew that).  For the most part it is OK to mix dino and
          synthetic oil -- just make sure to use oil with the same
          rating (i.e. mix SG with SG, not with SE).  All those ads
          that show engines running w/o oil are true... its just that
          if you use the oil additive first there is MORE cyclinder
          wear than in you just use regular oil and drain it (feel
          free to try this at home.

          And now a questiion for the P-man STAN:
          Stan... a while back you said that 914s should run on
          straight 30 weight oil (correct me if I'm wrong) but I plan
          on running a pure synthetic.  Amsoil has a straight weight
          but they say it is for diesel engines.  I did notice that it
          had an SG rating in addition to a C? rating (S=spark
          ignition, C=compression ignition for those out there who
          care).  Would this be a good straight grade to use in the
          914 when the engine is rebuilt?  Do you have any better
          recommendations?  Is the benefit over multi-weight Mobil 1
          worth the effort? 

          One more tasty tidbit from the "oil web site":  Mobil 1 and
          Amsoil use completely different formulations for their
          lubrication base.  Get to the web site and find out!

          -Tim
          (apologies if this is old news to everyone....)

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 10:52:50 -0500 (EST)
From: "Gerald G. MacDonald - Thomas Cooley Law School" <macdonag@mlc.lib.mi.us>
Subject: Re-emergence


It's (FINALLY) that time of year when my beast awakes from hibernation.  
It has been stored in my two car garage in the OmniBag for the winter 
(since Dec. 10).  The other bay was used all winter by the family 
mini-van (soon to be known as the "track support vehiclce"!)

Here' my plan for re-emergence.  I am looking for any suggestions on 
other appropriate procedures which I might not be aware of given this is 
my first hibernation.  Thanks in advance!

1.  Roll car out of OmniBag into driveway.

2.  Replace battery (stored in basement for winter on wood blocks);  will 
I need a re-charge for certain?

3.  Change oil and filter. (No flames please but this did not get done 
before storage as winter descended unexpectedly);

4.  Hose out garage (salt/sand in other bay);

5.  Zymol car (first time so use cleanser, then wax);  Which kind do I 
use for a Cognac Brown car (in German rauschquarzmetallic - literal 
translation "smoked quartz")?

6.  Lower air pressure in tires to running pressures (Dunlop D40's).  Any 
suggestions on best pressures or should I just go with the manual?

7.  Put protectant on rubber/vinyl parts (403)

8.  Hide Food all leather (seats, door panels etc.)

9.  Start car and allow to idle (for howe long?) to listen for any problems.

10.  DRIVE IT!

Jerry Mac
84 911 Carrera Targa (Cognac Brown)(beginning to stir from hibernation)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 10:05:57 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@ilab.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  928 Clutch Problem

>>
>>My 84 928S clutch is having the following symptom.
>>
>>I feel that the clutch pedal is not sprung back
>>all the way after I stepped on it. Also, I feel it 
>>is not as tight as before. I don't know how to 
>>describe it best, but it feels like I'm stepping on a 
>>sponge. Now, I can't rev the engine over 3000rpm. 
>>I asked myself, I guess it is the clutch hydralic pump. 
>>
I had roughly the same problem, which eventually got to the point
that the clutch pedal wouldn't come back up at all on cold days.
I convinced myself that it was the clutch master cylinder,
because I didn't seem to be losing any fluid, but I ended up
changing the slave cylinder also before the problem was fully
corrected. The slave cylinder is easy - just get under the car
and there it is - but the master cylinder is a pain because it
is buried behind the brake booster and master cylinder, which
have to be removed for access. Nothing needs any special skill
or special tools, just patience. Got both parts from Zims for
about $70 each, as I recall.

None of this has anything to do with the engine not revving
over 3000 rpm, however - that sounds like another problem
altogether. There is no "clutch hydraulic pump" per se; just
a reservoir (the brake fluid reservoir), a master cylinder, a
slave cylinder, and a line connecting the two.  Pretty simple.

 -John White-
'84 928S

Date: 24 Mar 95 10:13:38 -0500
From: mvmas@mvujc.att.com
Subject: Re: More 914 quirks...

    
>Doctor Doctor!
>	I recently gave Gretchin a thorough tuning and found that, after 
>replacing and optimizing all ignition components (New points made the 
>biggest difference) that she idled WAY too high.  I COMPLETELY closed the 
>idle screw and STILL it was too high.  My auxiliary air valve was not the
>cause, it is working fine and plus I plugged it anyway to be sure.  I 
>still have a warm idle of 2300 RPM!
>	So I took my unlit propane torch and went over all the lines when 
>the car was running to see if I could detect a change in idle speed 
>indicating an air leak, ad nauseum (literally)  with no effect.  I can 
>turn the idle down by changing the points setting, but I trust the 
>dwell-meter settings at factory specs.  Is that wrong?  Then of course 
>there's that adjusting screw on the pressure sensor which I've never been 
>too sure of...  So I'm out of ideas here...
>[etc]
>Rick
>1972 914-4 traffic cone orange "Gretchin"

You could also check the condition or placement of the rubber ring which
sits under the throttle body.  If it is torn or out of place you will not
get a decent seal.  Or, maybe the screws holding the throttle body down
are not tight as the seal is compressed over the years.

You could also check that the vacuum advance is not stuck on the distributor.

I don't know if this part was there on the '72, but many 914's have an
overrun valve which adds air if you lift the throttle suddenly, to improve
emissions.  If it's bad, it could be letting air through constantly.  Plug
all three hoses and try the car without it.  I think Haynes lists the way
to test the valve also.

Mark Skala
mvmas@mvujc.att.com    '73 914, and possibly soon '88 924S

In a previous round of the axis powers fighting it out was the following exchange:

>>If there is any doubt about the Eenimobile being faster than the new Turbo,
>>there is a simple solution: wait a while. Sooner or later the Lambo will
>>break. You can beat on a Turbo all day long on the drag strip; I've
>
>It's German. But that doesn't mean it won't break. But it's unfair to assume that the Diablo will break more often than any other car.

A friend's father in college had a 72 Dino from Italy, and to paraphrase from the owner's manual (I am paraphrasing because it was in Italian and I don't read or speak Italian but he did) under starting the engine in cold conditions "... If the engine doesn't start after three attempts wait until later ..."  His never broke down either, but he only put about 2,000 miles a year on it and still had it tuned frequently.

Unfair ?  If you consider past history I don't think so, If you pretend that there is no Italian car reliability history I see how you would think it unfair.  I do have more than one data point on Ferrais but this one had the best anecdote.  The same goes for Alfa's, those stories of them spontaneously igniting on the showroom floor are not all legend (flames no, smoldering yes).  My neighbor put his mechanic's children through college keeping his Alfa going, technically it never broke down (except that brake booster failure that sucked all the master cylinder fluid through the engine, but it kept running) but was well cared for (and often). I don't know anyone who has owned a Lamborghini but I'm going to call this interpolation rather then extrapolation :)


>(If you have flames, anyone, let's try to keep them intelligent, no "you're crazy, 
>you're wrong, you're stupid". If you can, prove me wrong. If not... Well, you 
>know. :)

Unfortunately he didn't look up the words in the dictionary, so they were pretty, but didn't make much sense.  (Yes that is a shot but I held out for three months :).

Date: 24 Mar 95 11:37:08 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 993 vs. Diablo

Hi, Kyle.
 
>Let me clarify something - I am not a drooling Lamborghini fanatic.
 
Me neither.
I spent ten days in a Lamborghini truck on One Lap of America. I used to
like the brand before that <g>. Worst damn gold chainer goat roper design
ever made. And yes, things broke (2 trucks in team, both lost reverse;
everybody brought their frequent flyer cards along just in case).
 
>I subscribe to Car & Driver because they have intelligent humorous writing,
>what appear to be honest road tests,
 
Depends on what you call honest. I don't consider doing your best possible
run, and then taking off a few more tenths of a second for "atmospheric
correction" to be honest. What it runs is what it runs.
 
>They do use a high-speed test track, and a fifth wheel at all times - which
>I daresay youdidn't use when you came up with "4.25 seconds" on an older 911
>Turbo.
 
If they use the Honda test track in Ohio (formerly Transportation Research
Center) they will run out of straight before they hit 202 mph or whatever.
You need several miles to get up to that. I forget if TRC is 2.5 or 5 or
whatever, but even a 2-mile straight isn't enough for a car like this.
 
As for test equipment, before you dare say anything, you should be aware
that 1) I use a "fifth wheel" too; 2) I use exactly the same "fifth wheel"
system as C/D; 3) I bought mine years before, and have used it longer than
they have; 4) it's not a wheel at all, it's a German non-contact optical
device; and 5) yes, it was on the 1990 Turbo I tested in France.
 
>If you can, prove me wrong...
 
If you would like, I can fax you copies of the device printouts for that
test. I no longer have the ASCII files stored in device memory for those runs
or I would upload that directly. If you need a witness, somebody who lurks
on P'philes was present but I don't think he's active on the list anymore.
 
And re your next post, wanting a Viper, geez, Kyle, I wouldn't even wish
that piece of shit on T*d. Have you ever driven one? If not, suggest you do so.
Rent one for a weekend and try to live with it. Then return it, and think of
all the money you'll save by no longer lusting for one. I have a lot of
respect for Chrysler's new products, every one except this thing. If Motor
Trend is something you put under the dog, then the Viper is something you
put on top of Motor Trend. The automotive press goes gaga for the Viper
because it's politically correct to do so. But it's poorly designed, poorly
built, using cheap materials slapped together kit-car style. I have driven
them twice now. They overheat (barfed coolant just following a ZR-1 on
mountain road), the panels don't fit (doors rubbed against fenders when
opened), the instrument panel is just plain stupid, the welds on the frame
look like they were done by vocational school students on their first day of
stick welding, etc. What the Viper does have is a good engine/drivetrain,
quick steering and great grip. It doesn't have any brakes.
 
Pete

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 95 09:36:00 PST
From: "Craig Friedrich (craigf)" <craigf@sequent.com>
Subject: Re:  928 Clutch Problem


I don't understand the context for the 3000 rpm problem, so
I don't think that I can help there.

I did however have a similar clutch problem on german iron
(not a nine two eight however) that turned out to be a cracked
pressure plate (cracked all the way through the face).  It
also had a tendancy to make it difficult at times to get in gear
without an effort and/or a clunk, but this was not consistent.

Because of the crack, the pressure plate did not fully clear
the clutch disk when the pedal was depressed.  It also left
the pedal feeling spongey.  I chased the hydraulic route too
before I ended up yanking the trans.

Here's to hoping I am wrong,
craigf@sequent.com
 ---------

|

|describe it best, but it feels like I'm stepping on a
|sponge. Now, I can't rev the engine over 3000rpm.

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 10:07:15 -0800 (PST)
From: budd <budd@rohan.sdsu.edu>
Subject: WOW!!

Yes, I am the guy who instigated the whole Toyota v. Porsche thread.
A couple of day ago, I went to a shop to try a 1991 MR2Turbo, the dealer 
said that he lent it out to someone else.  So, he said we could drive 
over to where it was, the car we took...a 1978 Porsche 911SC Targa, with 
340,000 mile (1 owner).  As I was driving it, I kept thinking "what will 
the MR2 look like after 340,000 miles.  Although the Targa was pretty 
beat up, the engine still seemed fairly strong.  The MR2 was pretty beat 
up as well with only 66,000 miles only.  I first drove the MR2, I wasn't 
too happy with the turbo, it kind of sneaks up on you.  I felt really 
confident in the corners,like I was on rails.  However, at 80 the car 
started to vibrate, I don't think this is indicative of the model, the 
dealer said that it needed new tires.  I was skeptical.  I then asked to 
drive the 911 on the same route I took in the MR2.  As I said before,, 
itw as pretty beat up, but I LOVED it.  There was something special about 
downshifting into 2nd at 50 mph and blowing past a car doing 50 on the 
freeway.  The next thing I knew, I was doing 90, I told the dealer I 
thought the speedometer was broken, he just smiled.  In corners, although 
I wasn't as confident into the corner, as I was with the MR2, coming out 
of it was just amzing.  I can't wait to drive a 911 that is actually "in 
shape."  I think the next few weeks are going to be fun!!

Tim

P.S. Thanks for all your help, I sure appreciate it.

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 13:43:49 -0500

George Hussey said "Please don't damage your museum piece 914-6 in stock

Sorry George, but this is exactly what the car should be used for.
Keeping it in a garage would be idiotic. There are plenty of
914/6's around, and if it gets trashed, so what??? Take the serial
numbers and good stuff and clone it on a 914/4 shell. Otherwise
George's 914 information has been great.

In Connecticut, we have guys racing a 911 SC/RS (one of 50 or so made
for rallying/racing, worth about 10 times that of a GOOD 914/6),
911 Carrera RS, Rare '72 factory 911S/T vintage race car,
924 carrera (?) specials, Every turbo 911 model, 911 RS Americas,
etc etc. PCA club racing is as safe as it gets, and any Porsche
should be raced if possible. Puts character in the cars and drivers!

Jim Newton won the "Manhatten award" at the Porsche Parade in '86 (?)
in his '73 911 RS lightweight. It was the CLEANEST PORSCHE IN THE
WORLD! Every nut and bolt was replaced or refinished. You can see it
in Bruce's book "911 performance handbook".
Jim was offered more money than you could believe for it.
Then he took it out to autocrosses and race tracks!

End of lesson.

Mike Piera '72 911S Targa (rarer than a '70 914/6 or '73 Carrera)

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 95 13:41:31 cst
From: "emontgo" <emontgo@cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: 3200 rpm 944

     
     George,
     
     For what it's worth (because I am not a Porsche mechanic), when they 
     (Porsche dealer) tore my engine down they noticed the vibe. They took 
     it apart 3 times. When they found the problem they told me it was the 
     gear at the end of the balance shaft was on backward. It fits either 
     way. and I guess no one usually takes it off but they said someone who 
     had worked on it before replaced it backward. It looks the same from 
     both sides but is balanced for one.
     I have never seen it but figured I would pass this along just in case.
     
     Ed Montgomery

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 15:19:57 -0500 (EST)
From: "Derek Cahill" <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Slick 50 re-visited

I don't really want to get into whose oil is better or whatever, but I just
thought that as I was getting ready to use this morning to change oil in the
Toyota Camry, I decided to compare the synthetic blends. There are two
simple ratings: Energy Conserving and Energy Conserving II (II clearly being
stricter and better). Anyways, this update must have come sometime between
1985 and 1992 as our Buick doesn't recommend II, but the Toyota does.

Slick 50 is *NOT* Energy Conserving II! As magically the engine additive
DOES make a difference, the oil itself does not. I have heard that AAA will
do oil analysis for free or a small charge (I'm a member) and I intend to
check out the numbers. Mobil 1, BTW, is Energy Conserving II... I think I'm
going to try that or Castrol Syntec today...
 -Derek Cahill

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 14:37:09 -0600
From: Brian Scudder <bscudder@spdmail.spd.dsccc.com>
Subject: 928 Clutch Problem

Carlos writes about a spongy 928 clutch peddle and people have responded
with expensive fixes (clutch master cylinder, slave cylinder, and a
broken flywheel.)

My suggestion is to bleed the clutch first. Because it is the lowest
point in the hydraulic system and it probably does not get bled as often
as the brakes, the fluid will collect dirt and moisture. Access to the
slave cylinder is easy, just jack up the front, slide in, and locate the
bleeder valve on the slave cylinder (bolted to the clutch housing near
the starter). Then select any brake bleeding method that we have just
discussed.

Brian Scudder
'83 928S (broken transmission)
'70 old blue trunk (with new Hurst Indy floor shifter)
'93 Redi (the cat)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 95 15:36:52 est
From: "Walczak, Lee" <lwalc@mh.com>
Subject: race wheels

     P-folk:
        Anyone interested in 17-in. Porsche race wheels designed for the
     Carrera Cup series? These are mag wheels (centerlocks), ultralight,
     in 7-in and 9 1/2-in. widths. (Note: These are *not* SuperCup wheels). 
     An acquaintance of mine who is the Porsche tuning business just called 
     to say his outfit in Germany has bought a ton of these wheels from 
     Porsche (not from Speedline). They will fit on 964s and 993s. If 
     anyone is interested, please drop me a note and I'll put you in touch 
     with Mr. Wheels.
        Also... still trying to rustle up U.S. interest in 18-in treaded 
     track tires. So far, interest has been negligible, but if anyone out 
     there should want a set of these full-race Pirellis, let me know 
     soonest.
        Consumer disclaimer: I am not in the wheel, tire,  or snake-oil 
     additive business.
        Lee Walczak / Wash., D.C.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 16:06:08 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@ilab.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  928 Clutch Problem

>>
>>Carlos writes about a spongy 928 clutch peddle and people have responded
>>with expensive fixes (clutch master cylinder, slave cylinder, and a
>>broken flywheel.)
>>
>>My suggestion is to bleed the clutch first. Because it is the lowest
>>point in the hydraulic system and it probably does not get bled as often
>>as the brakes, the fluid will collect dirt and moisture. Access to the
>>slave cylinder is easy, just jack up the front, slide in, and locate the
>>bleeder valve on the slave cylinder (bolted to the clutch housing near
>>the starter). Then select any brake bleeding method that we have just
>>discussed.
>>
>>Brian Scudder

When you go under there, take the little rubber cap off the underside
of the clutch housing and see if there's any fluid in there. I found
brake fluid, which gave me my first clue that the slave cylinder was
shot. Better than finding oil or water, anyway. You can also look up
in there and see the position of the release arm (that links the
throwout bearing to the outside world). On an '84, it should be about
in the middle of the hole; if it is too far from there, it's time for
some clutch work. If you really want to know what the allowable
tolerance is, I can look it up in the shop manual.

 -John White-
'84 928S

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 95 16:34:22 EST
From: Neil.NW.Walker@ccmail.ae.ge.com
Subject: Oil Additives

Oil Additives.
We had a request for information recently for more information on a newly 
discovered (by the author) oil additive which was supposed to work by bonding a 
long molecular chain to the parent metal. Many replies said "snake oil, if it 
were any good it would be used by the Lube and/or Engine Manufacturers". Well 
guess what, based on the less than explicit descriptions given in the 
discussions to date it would seem to be the identical description used by 
Castrol in the blurb sheet for Syntec.
The product can now be described as being used by a manufacturer, so, is it no 
longer snake oil? or do way have say the manufacturers are selling snake oil?
Inquiring minds would like to know.

Much more serious matter please note new form of address.
neil.nw.walker@ccmail.ae.ge.com

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 17:12:31 -0600
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: 914 car stereo

>I'm curious to know what other 914 owners have done with respect to stereo
>design and speaker placement. I just bought my 2nd 914 (a 95% restored 1974
>2.0) and have about $1000 to spend on stereo equipment. Any suggestions?
>
 Hi David,
   Here's my solution. I called Dr. 914 and had him send me a new DIN
face plate. The original stereo is on the bench getting re-aligned. I put
in a regular Pioneer Cd head unit with 4 low level outputs. These feed a
matching 25 watt per channel amp. The "front" speakers are the factory
installed units. For the "rear" speakers I drop a set of Pioneer truck
speakers that sit on the floor. The object here is not to cut and damage
anything that was original. When this car is in storage the head unit and
the truck speakers are removed. After the original radio is renewed, it will
find it's home back in the dash for good. I have found that the motor in my 914
is pretty quite and am not able to hear it as well as my 911, and therefore
listining to the stereo doesent bother me quite as much as when driving my
911. This solution is not as pretty as it could be but I am satisfied with
the quality and volume of the sound, even while moving at freeway speeds.

Have fun!
Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1974 914 2.0 (for sale)
1966 911 cpe (DONE!!)

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 18:41:38 -0500
From: DrRSR@aol.com
Subject: Re: '72 and '73 911S targa #s

From Bruce Anderson who got it from "ESSES" (who got it elsewhere)

Porsche 911S Production (Coupes and Targas)

1970    2,473; 394 imported
1971    2,218; 332 imported
1972    2,739; 332 imported
1973    2,335; 524 imported

Interesting note: 1973    113 RS's were imported.

 -Allen Henderson-
'72S, 59A coupes

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 18:14:51 -0600 (CST)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: 911 Alt/Charge/Battery Light

Hi Wayne,

When this happens in my Nissan PU, it starts with a small glow and gets 
worse.  Every time that it has happened , I have found that the diodes 
were were failing one at a time in my alternator.  A good automotive 
electrical shop can check you problem retty quickly.

>before storage as winter descended unexpectedly);
>
>4.  Hose out garage (salt/sand in other bay);

>
>6.  Lower air pressure in tires to running pressures (Dunlop D40's).

>

>
>8.  Hide Food all leather (seats, door panels etc.)
>

problems.
>
>10.  DRIVE IT!
>
>Jerry Mac
>84 911 Carrera Targa (Cognac Brown)(beginning to stir from hibernation)
>
>
>

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 13:26:02 -0800
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: Re: RE : Don't race your 914/6


Mike said,

>George Hussey said "Please don't damage your museum piece 914-6 in stock 
                    PCA racing events!"

>Sorry George, but this is exactly what the car should be used for.
>Keeping it in a garage would be idiotic. There are plenty of
>914/6's around, and if it gets trashed, so what??? Take the serial
>numbers and good stuff and clone it on a 914/4 shell. Otherwise
>George's 914 information has been great.

>In Connecticut, we have guys racing a 911 SC/RS (one of 50 or so made
>for rallying/racing, worth about 10 times that of a GOOD 914/6),
>911 Carrera RS, Rare '72 factory 911S/T vintage race car,
>924 carrera (?) specials, Every turbo 911 model, 911 RS Americas,
>etc etc. PCA club racing is as safe as it gets, and any Porsche
>should be raced if possible. Puts character in the cars and drivers!

>Jim Newton won the "Manhatten award" at the Porsche Parade in '86 (?)
>in his '73 911 RS lightweight. It was the CLEANEST PORSCHE IN THE
>WORLD! Every nut and bolt was replaced or refinished. You can see it
>in Bruce's book "911 performance handbook".
>Jim was offered more money than you could believe for it.
>Then he took it out to autocrosses and race tracks!

>End of lesson.

>Mike Piera '72 911S Targa (rarer than a '70 914/6 or '73 Carrera)

Mike,

I agree with what you said about racing Porsches and not letting them become
garage rats.  What I don't agree with is the idea of transfering the serial
numbers, etc to a 914/4 if your rare 914/6 gets trashed. This is dishones, 
unethical, and I might add, illegal.  There have been cases where a cloned
car was sold as a rare 914/6 and the new owner took legal action upon discovery
of the scam.  Trust me, it is quite easy to determine if a car has been cloned!

Dan
70 914/6 Almost restored, (and I will drive it!)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 19:14:46 -0600 (CST)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: spare keys

Recently there was a posting/thread about cutting spare keys from vin 
numbers.  I have investigated this and found that P-Cars from around '83 
on, have their key codes recorded.  Keys for earlier cars can be cut from 
the key codes.  These often can be found on you ignition lock in the 
dashboard.  Yes, just simply tear your dashboard apart!  This isn't 
difficult after unscrewing the bezel around the ignition lock.  Unless 
you have "hang down air".  Sure nuff, mine has it.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 07:37:18 -0500
From: Cdaar1@aol.com
Subject: Re: K-Mart Quality

>Which for you Americans is a discount chain similar to K-Mart or >Wal-Mart.

I used to wonder about this phenomenon.  For years, I bought SEARS Kenmore
appliances to install myself, and the "urban legend" was that they were made
by Westinghouse or some other reputable appliance manufacturer, but this
never made much sense to me because I could not see them with a) a terrible
quality control problem, nor b) a separate production line for the junk that
Sears turned out.

I concluded that Kenmore may have been made abroad (Mexico, or some such).  Co
uld a similar situation be the case for auto parts as well?


Fred Castro



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 20:43:22 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: re:K-Mart Quality

Reid says, "When I worked for Amoco, even our own employees who saw the oil
canned for discount stores (out of the same  barrel as the good stuff)
wouldn't buy their oil at K-Mart - I have to admit, even me!"

The same goes for gasoline, with a caveat or two.  If you trail the
common-carrier tankers filling up the underground tanks at your favorite
"no-name" service station or convenient mart, you'll usually find them
loading at the same terminals that supply the name-brand stations.  And, even
if the terminal is a "no-name" one, it probably gets its stock from the same
refineries supplying the name-brands.  In short, gasoline is gasoline, and it
has very little to do with brands.  The caveats?  Gasoline is refined from
oil pumped from different fields, and the quality of the crude varies
depending upon those fields.  For example, for years a well-known major brand
had such high sulfur content in all its petroleum products that heavy
equipment manufacturers specifically recommended that its diesel fuel not be
used in their engines.  It quickly clogged the injectors.  The second caveat
concerns brand-specific additives; if these appeal to you (and some are
worthwhile, unlike most after-market additives), then buy that brand.  You
may get the same additives by buying at the convenient mart, but, then again,
you may not (though you'll probably get a competitor's)!

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper

p.s.  Perhaps a third caveat should be to avoid filling up at places that
don't stick their tanks for water regularly (and pump it out when it reaches
an unacceptable level).  Water and rust scale at $1.20/gallon is expensive
(in more ways than one).  

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 20:49:32 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: Don't race your 914-6

Greetings:

This thread brings to mind a story I heard years ago regarding Ferry
Porsche's visit to the Parade in Monterey.  (The year escapes me but perhaps
mid 70's?)  Part of the planned itinerary for Dr. Porsche was a visit to
Harrah's Museum in Reno.  During the tour, which was conducted by Bill Harrah
hisself,  Harrah apologized to Dr. Porsche for not having a Porsche in the
Museum.  (I think the closest thing they had was a VW beatle of some sort.)
 Without skipping a beat or batting an eye, Dr. Porsche said to Harrah that
no apologies were necessary.  His cars were meant to be driven, not locked
away in museums.
I have gotten a lot of mileage out of this story as I use it every time
someone chides me for racing my original (well....mostly) 914-6 in drivers
ed. and PCA Club Racing.

Regards

Pat Moyle
1970 914-6 (BIG brakes, good suspension, and nooooo horsepower)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 20:55:10 -0500 (EST)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: How I Spent My Spring Break, by Nate Nagel

    Well, well, well, it's that time of year again, when a young man's
fancy turns to thoughts of... love? well, maybe. nice crisp apexes? 
maybe.  Brake jobs?  definitely.
    Day 1.  I get home.  914 is out of gas.  Mom took car and left.  I
putter around with some electrical work that I'd been putting off.  Soak
down all fasteners with WD-40 and Liquid Wrech, alternately.
    Day 2.  Got gas, brought 914 down to garage, put up on blocks.  Mom
and dad took me out to dinner.  Very cool.  I was up until about
midnight because I just started messing with stuff and it was all coming
apart very nicely.  By the time I went to bed I had the front end
stripped down to the spindles, rotors cleaned and painted with black
engine paint, new bearings in and packed with Redline (very cool-looking
stuff, IMHO) and rotors reinstalled.  Went to bed happy.
    Day 3.  Started on rear.  Was just going to loosen bleeder screws
and drain the fluid, then put the new master cylinder in.  Two screws
will not come out, some moron had stripped them and then left them. 
Grr.  Start on MC.  It comes off OK, all except the LF brake line.  More
on that later.  Spend all day quite unproductively.
    Day 4.  Get pissed off.  Break a bleeder screw.  Swear a lot. 
Realize I need a 19mm wrench (not socket, which I have) to get rear
calipers off.  Make a speed run to Sears.  Pick up 11mm flare nut wrench
also.  Try this on the brake line that's stuck at the MC.  Fitting
finally breaks free but is spinning the brake line with it.  Spend
several hours trying to break it free before I give up and break it off.
 New wrench does not help getting rear caliper off, bolts are too damn
tight.  Put in new MC, kludge together a fitting to get it working
without LF caliper (remember, it's gotta be out of Mom's garage before I
leave!)  Front brakes won't bleed.  Why????
    Day 5.  Remove master cylinder, drag out old, rusty, leaky one,
compare parts.  They're exactly the forking same!  I put the old parts
in the new master cylinder.  This seems to work OK.  I try to put the
new parts back in.  The seals have all swelled!  Argh!  I pry them in,
very carefully, with a small screwdriver, and try it again.  No go.  I
put in the old parts from the replacement master cylinder (before I
rebuilt it) and THEY don't work either.  The only ones that do work are
the ones that were in the car.  Curiouser and curiouser.  I put it all
together, try to put it in, get frustrated by the reservoir lines.  Go
to bed.
    Day 6.  Connect reservoir lines.  Have mom help me bleed brakes. 
She seems unimpressed by her first seat time in a p-car.  So car now has
1 front + a little help from the back brakes.  Enough to get it to the
barn, I figure.  Hose out garage, which looks like a war zone.  Sigh
with relief.  Back to school.

Moral of the story:

    Always use anti-seize on all brake parts.  If I buy a car from you
and find you have not, I will be very unhappy.  Not very obvious but
probably a good idea would be to use it on the fittings of the hard
lines - not necessarily on the threads, but on the line itself, where
the nut slides over it.  If you want to do a brake job on a 914, you
will need a 19mm wrench and a 11mm flare nut wrench, in addition to the
usual assortment o'stuff (I think a 13mm wrench, 19mm socket, and 17mm
socket, off the top of my head.  Oh yeah, and a 7mm wrench for the
bleeder screws.)
    Whoever said to connect the reservior lines before tightening down
the master cylinder was right.  It looks like the hard way.  Actually,
it is the hard way.  But it's easier than the impossible way.

Questions still unanswered:

    Why did my various master cylinders work/not work, when their parts
were identical?
    How do I get my rear caliper off so's to drill out the bleeder screw
that I broke off in a fit of pique?
    And finally, if any of you guys who are disassembling 914's could
shoot me that little teeny hard line for the left front caliper that
comes right out of the master cylinder, I would be greatly obliged.

    Oh yeah, one last tech tip.  After I got my car back in the barn, I
forget why I had to go out but I passed by the local foreign car garage.
 I went in for a chat about where to go to get the rockers replaced and
to see if he had any bleeder screws.  He had some VW ones that looked
the same, but were BRASS!  Oh, Stimpy!  Wish someone had used those on
my car before...

happy wrenching,

Nate

'71 914 with very spiffy looking front wheel bearings, I must say.

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 95 18:13:05 PST
From: QLD1%PwrFin%ESBU@bangate.pge.com
Subject: Airbag Light - 1991 911 Turbo

> I have a 1991 - 911 Turbo the car has been in storage, dead battery etc.
> After replacing the battery and starting the car the airbag light is staying
> on constantly.  I was told by the dealer that the system needs to be reset
> when power is interrupted.  Is this something that I can do myself? Does
> anyone know how to reset the airbag system?

> thanks jeff

Jeff,

I have a 1990 C4 and dealer is right about the system needing to reset itself 
after disconnecting the battery, but according my owner's manual, the car 
will reset itself if you run the car for about 5 or 10 minutes.  I regretably 
cannot drive my C4 often enough and therefore I have installed a battery 
cutoff switch to disconnect my battery whenever I don't expect to drive it 
for awhile.  Everytime I connect my battery, the only thing "I" have to do 
reset anything is my clock and my radio--period.  My airbag light goes off 
after a couple of minutes upon starting the car up

My 1991 cars have a different system than my 1990.

Quincy Dong
QLD1@pge.com

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 23:09:43 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Re: RE : Don't race your 914/6

Hi Dan,

- ------------------
I agree with what you said about racing Porsches and not letting them become
garage rats.  What I don't agree with is the idea of transfering the serial
numbers, etc to a 914/4 if your rare 914/6 gets trashed. This is dishones, 
unethical, and I might add, illegal.  There have been cases where a cloned
car was sold as a rare 914/6 and the new owner took legal action upon
discovery
of the scam.  Trust me, it is quite easy to determine if a car has been
cloned!
- -------------------

This is true, I would certainly be pissed off if I found out that my
914/6 was not original. But I thought there was no difference
if you did it right, as the bodies were made on the same lines
before the sixer was sent to the Porsche factory. I think the cases
you mentioned were "fakes" rather than "rebodies". That is a big
difference and illegal.

However, my mind thinks mostly in terms of racing- I only care
about what is legal in racing (in real life we should try to bend
the rules as much as possible and beat the system, but in
racing it sucks to be disqualified). So for racing there would
be no problem in re-bodying a car like this. You wouldn't
even need the serial numbers, only the right specs.

> 70 914/6 Almost restored, (and I will drive it!)

This is great to hear, another sixer rescued and back on it's
4 wheels (or 3 if it's driven properly!).

Mike Piera '72 911S  '73 914/2.0 (A real 2.0 I think :-| )

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 22:43:19 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: Oil, etc.----YOU SHOULD READ THIS!

        [Wow!  And I thought *I* was a wordy SOB!     ;)   ]
>According to my info., Militec-1 is a *metal conditioner* that dramatically
>reduces friction between metal surfaces.  It is an oil that gets into
>micropores of the metal and bonds there, protecting the metal surfaces
>without depending on the film strength of the oil, and the bond remains even
>through oil changes as it has become part of the metal itself.

        This sounds as if it might be one of the zinc (?) compounds mentioned
in the Snake Oil FAQ.  (Which you might want to look at again.)  There are
disadvantages to very high levels of these compounds in your oil.  They were
either more ash left when the oil burned, or more plug fouling.  (Sorry, it's
been a while since I re-read the FAQ.)  Most oil companies put some level of
these compounds in their oil already.  They generally don't come into play
until there's actual metal-to-metal contact, which hopefully never occurs.
        Then again, it might be some other type of stuff.  The claims, how-
ever, sound basically identical to what Slick-50 used to say.  And just
because the government uses something dosen't make it right for your car.
(After all, the glorious Shuttle uses 1960's-vintage computers...)
        The FAQ is available for FTP at tta.com.  And no, I don't have a
copy I can e-mail anyone.

- --DD

        "I used to have a life, but I sacrificed it to my car."
Dave Darling
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov                          914s Rule!

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 22:45:08 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: K-Mart Quality

> I concluded that Kenmore may have been made abroad (Mexico, or some such).
> Could a similar situation be the case for auto parts as well?

Geeze. OK, guys, this is Business 301 -- Private Label Merchandise.

Vendor X has manufacturing capability for 100,000 units of Item Y per
month. They have retail capacity for moving 65,000 units per month.
Cost per unit is relative tothe total number made. Margin per unit is 
thus higher if they can make that extra 25,000 units a month.

Enter Vendor W, who has zero manufacturing capability, but has some
product specs. For a nominal line conversion fee, Vendor X is able to
make 25,000 units of Item Y++, nearly Item Y but to Vendor W's spec
*INCLUDING* having the Vendor W name plate on it.

Vendor W now makes money because they know in advance what it's going to
cost them per unit -- there are no labor or materials fluctuations that
can screw up their planning. Vendor X makes money because they now have
higher margins on their core Item Y product because the plant is now at
full capacity. If the management team is on the ball, they also make  a
nickle or two by actually making the units for Vendor W, *PLUS* can make
a few more nickels by figuring out how to cut production costs (provided
that Vendor W hasn't got nasties in the contract that might cost Vendor X
money if the quality slips any).

And so it goes with any generic product, any store-label product, or for
that matter, any high-demand product that a vendor might want to make sure
they have a second source readily available for.

No "seconds" bins that go to K-Mart. No "Made in the People Republic
of Vergaak" mystery parts. Just good, simple business practices.

Stan

P.S. How the hell did any of you people get to the point where you 
could afford these cars anyway??? 8{)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 22:55:34 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Red Line Oil

> Everyone always talks of using Mobile 1 ETC, but never a mention of Red Line
> oil. I use it and am curious as to why no one else ever mentions it..  I know
> it is expensive . Am i wasting my money? 

You can walk up to any PEP Boys, Hi-Lo, etc. and for that matter practically
any K-Mart, Target, Seven-Eleven, etc and buy several synthetic oils:
Mobil 1, Syntec, Valvoline Synthetic. 

To buy Amsoil or Red Line, you have to (a) want to (i.e. you won't do it
by accident because you grabbed the wrong stuff at Walmart), (b) go to 
someplace special that actually sells it, and (c) spend more money.

On the other hand, years ago, if you wanted a synthetic, you *HAD* to
look up your Amsoil or Red Line dealer...

I see it as a personal choice. I actually use the Red Line 50W Racing
synthetic in a few particular applications. It's good stuff. There are
no other single grade synthetics out there.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 22:58:13 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 928 Headroom (was Re: 914 Headroom)

> Have not removed the driver's seat to see if
> it can be lowered. Will try restuffing the seat cushion before chopping
> the roof. 

You *CAN* hack the seat mounts. I've done that on a couple of 911s now
to get the head room I wanted. I forget who clued me in on that --
Steve Tynor? someone, on this list, a *LONG* time ago... Hacking the
seats directly is less desirable, as you can lose a lot of support that
way.

> Is there a clean, reversable way to plug the sunroof, reline
> the interior, and get back some of that room?

Surely you jest. Nope. Bodywork of that magnitude is *NOT* casually
reversible.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Mar 1995 23:00:32 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: PCA Club Racing - How Safe?

> How safe or dangerous is club racing on cars? By this I mean damage due to
> accidents, not mechanical damage from running at high RPM, etc. How many car
> to car accidents are there? How many car of road into something hard
> incidents occur in a race / weekend / year? Estimates will be fine. I am
> thinking of going racing, but not I will break anything.

Club Racing has a 13/13 rule -- if you bend anything, you're on suspension
for 13 months; if during that time you repeat, you're *OUT* for 13 months.
As a result, it's pretty safe relative to SCCA racing. Kevin -- any recent
incidents come to mind that weren't the result of equipment failure??

Stan

Ouch. But I fear right to the point. I've been finding more and more threads 
on <interesting> topics like three wheelers vs. four wheelers etc... Stan, 
would you like me to write an A.I. program to filter out such discussions 
that belong on 'The Porch Enquirer'?

One discussion that got off to a 'bad start' ended well. I found useful the 
conclusion to the 'Add junk to your oil thread'. I admit I was getting 
confused with all the noise in print, TV, radio advertising about 'Sleek-50' 
and others, and considered buying some a few weeks ago. After all, Teflon is 
great when I'm cooking an omelette, so why not throw some in my Porsche (the 
Teflon, not the eggs stupid). The gentleman that started the discussion had 
a valid question in light of all the confusion out there. The later mention 
of Porsche's own R&D trying out these products anyway was so logical (and 
conclusive IMHO) that I will pull that reminder from my back pocket next 
time I see an ad. for 'Helium-01 Ultralight Tire Inflater Addictive'. (Don't 
you get any bright ideas now!)

Of course it normally be difficult to write such an A.I. program but since 
the level of intelligent in some of these threads is so low, all I have to 
do is write an A.S. filter program instead (Artificial Stupidity). Piece of 
cake actually!

Could someone point me in the direction of the F.A.Q. /thread on 'Fuel Lead 
Substitutes' for early P-cars ? Really.

Date: Sat, 25 Mar 1995 07:51:07 -0500
From: BUBBAUSA@aol.com
Subject: Re: 1959 356A, no floor, otherwise ok - opinions?

My opin is that unless it's really special like a Sunroof & has some
accessories & tool kit -$3000 sounds more in tune with current prices. Unless
you are great with your hands & have a fair stock of parts etc you will be
getting into some $$$$ for floors etc ( they NEVER just need floor panels -
closing panels, longitudinals, inner rockers, torsion area, frame struts
etc). Motor installation is easy - IF that's all that has to be done -ie no
overhaul.  By the time you get into the above, then paint, accessories,
brakes etc get the price into more than the car is worth...unless the late
80's come back when the magic formula of greed+briefcase
brokers+"status"+inflation+unawares buyers with deeeep pockets made for some
BIIIG prices. I admit during that period I had a few cars around for parts
that I sold for market value, but I feel I never hosed anyone.  I think you
can buy a NICE rust free TX,AZ or CA car now, that you can drive & have fun
with, and need minmal mechanical work, for a LOT less than the cost of
purchase,transport & repair of the one in Canada.
Just one guy's opin. Good luck. - Try Pano or 356 Registry or
Hemmings motor News for a whole lot more selection.
(if you're really bent over on the car-go eyeball it since it has rust
etc-cheaper than buying it from photos & discovering you have some real costs
& problems (not implying it is being misrepresented) ). 
Best,
George
50 Cpe
57 GS S/R Cpe
61 Roadster
65 C Cab 


------------------------------

Date: 25 Mar 95 08:41:07 EST
From: Michael Kehr <71324.3010@compuserve.com>
Subject: RE: Number of 944 Turbo S


>Subject: Number of 944 Turbo S

>Does anyone know the number of 88 944 Turbo S and 89 944 Turbos made and sold
>in US. I have heard 399, 700, 1000 for the 88 Turbo S, and I have no idea how
>many 89 Turbos there were.

>TIA,

>Barry Lenoble


Barry,
I just recently was fowarded a letter from a guy in my local region. He owns a
'88 944 Turbo S. He asked Porsche AG in Germany the same question. The letter
is dated 10.11.91 and is signed by, K. Resch and O. Lang.
Following is an excerpt from that letter:

" The total number of 944 turbos built for model year 1988 was 4087. Of this
  number 1006 were 944 turbo S models of which 399 were sent to the U.S.."

Just a note: Not all of these 1988 Turbo S models were the Silver Rose        
      Metallic color. Other colors were produced at the end of the
             production run.
Sorry I couldn't help with the 1989 model year. Can anyone on the list
help with this.

Hope this helps.

Mike Kehr   '86 951


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 25 Mar 1995 09:15:27 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: PCA Club Racing - How Safe?

Barry writes, "How safe is Club Racing" (snip) "will I damage my car"

Well Barry let me put it this way... Racing is racing so in the heat of
competition and at the speeds involved shit does tend to happen. If you are
going to go racing you must have the attitude that if the shit lands on you
you had best be prepared to eat it. In other words, and this applies to a
lesser extent to Track Events, you have to be able to rationalize the fun
potential over the possible damage potential.
Certainly the emphasis is on safety and fun. I don't think anyone wants to
damage their Porsche anymore than you do. If clear heads prevail the events
are usually very safe. If the red mist appears than stuff can happen. It is
important to identify the yo yos and keep out of their way and drive within
yourself. If you take the proper attitude out on the track you will reduce
your exposure to problems.
BTW I have seen more damage at High Speed Drivers Ed than at many of the race
events.
Hope this is a help.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
9:01 am

Date: 25 Mar 95 10:57:51 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Don't race your 914/6

 
George Hussey said
>Please don't damage your museum piece 914/6 in stock PCA racing events!
 
to which Mike Piera replied
>Sorry George, but this is exactly what the car should be used for. Keeping
>it garaged would be idiotic. There are plenty of 914/6s around, and if it
>gets trashed, so what??? Take serial numbers and good stuff and clone it on
>to a 914/4 shell.
 
Amen to that. I hear the same sort of BS re the 356s, from self-appointed
maestros and such. 356s are even less rare than 914/6s. None of these cars
are truly rare. Chevy Vegas, now, those are rare and should not be raced.
Well, they should not be raced for other reasons. Never mind. The (real)
Ferrari owners have the right idea (real Ferraris have V12s mounted up
front). If you trash it, you can always make a new one from a stack of sheet
metal for less than the cost of buying another one.
 
You want rare? I have a friend who owns a 550 Spyder. He wrecked it while
vintage racing. It is nearly completely rebuilt now. He'll go race it again.
550s are rare. Chevy Vegas are rare. 914/x and 356 and even 356 Carrera are
NOT rare.
 
How come people who deal with one specific model for a living seem to feel
that it's necessary to foster the idea that that model is somehow rare and
valuable? Really solid 356s cost less than a new Dodge Neon. 914/6s cost
less than a new Mustang V6 automatic. (That one only sticks in my mind
because I just returned one and we determined that my daily driver 356
out-drags it. Not even a question of out-handling it.)
 
Pete

------------------------------

Date: 25 Mar 95 10:57:56 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 1959 356 A, no floor

 
Hi, David.
 
Sounds like another parts car. There are a few, very few, people who can put
new floors in professionally and do it right. The question here is how much
damage was done when a "sheet metal" floor was put in? You can do a LOT of
damage by welding it in wrong. Warp car, etc. How do doors close? How do
door gaps look?
 
Rockers are very difficult to get right. Yes, I know, repros are available.
Doesn't matter, repro is almost never as good as original, and rockers are
very difficult to get right.
 
No rust anywhere else -- where else could you get it? That's about as bad as
it gets, structurally. How about the longitudinals? They are what holds the
car together. If the floor and rockers have been replaced, chances are these
have problems too. You will need to look under the carpets. The only other
really serious structural rust area I've seen is the rear torsion bar tube.
Look under the bolted-in plate that holds the torsion bar in. If the area
under the plate is rotten, at the lowest point of this frame member, it's
another job for an expert. Other, non-structural rust: you could also check
for rust behind headlights, ahead of door hinges, along bottoms of doors,
under the battery, under gas tank, under pedal cluster.
 
Pete

Nancy J Duffield

are beautiful works of automotive art.

brains and a *great* attitude!  vs. just seeing her in person).

Cars, Women, Bungee Jumpin', Sky Diving, Aerobatics! - Love 'em all and
they're a lot more fun *to do* than *to watch*!  <No sexist inference
intended>

I don't drive a rare P-car, but I did take first place in my class at the
Oregon Region Rainbonnet concours with my SC.  I won on Saturday night, and
then took the car on the track (and off-the-track) on Sunday morning.  Funny
how these things "speed up" once they get off on the grass.  Don't want to
sound like I am braggin' here, jus' practicing what I preach.

Not lookin' to generate any flames here, but if you are truly interested in
"Garage Art"............. buy a poster!

Date: Sat, 25 Mar 1995 13:05:47 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: PCA Club Racing-How Safe? 

Greetings:

Are we talking about damage to Porsches, or damage to Porsche drivers?
As far as damage to the most important component of the package is concerned,
the worst I have seen is a minor cut on the hand.
Last year, Alan Friedman, (Club Racing founder, guru and statistician)
published a breakdown of incidents citing average number of incidents per
event, ratio of 1 car incidents (spinning off course and contacting something
which causes damage to the car) to car contact incidents (2 or more cars
coming together causing car damage).  If you call him at 703/620-9268 I'm
sure he will share this information with you.  This was published in the
quarterly publication "PCA Club Racing News".  Perhaps someone on this list
can dig out that copy and post the stats.  The numbers were very low and as
Jerry said, most were caused by either judgement error or brain fade.

We have sanctions available to us which we impose when necessary, and
although some may disagree, we do *not* enfoy imposing them.
The 13/13 rule Stan mentioned is used in incidents resulting in car damage.
 If a person "creates" an incident resulting in car damage, after a thorough
review of the situation with as many eyewitness reports as possible, the
"creator" is placed on a 13 month probation period.  If a driver creates
another incident within this 13 month probation period, he is placed on a 13
month suspension.  The 13 month probation period does not place any
restrictions on the driver, it is just a hammer hanging over his/her head,
waiting to drop if it happens again.
Even this is not cast in bronze.  We have had a couple of situations which
caused the Chief Steward to place a driver on suspension as the result of the
1st incident.
These sanctions are used to try to keep this program as safe as it can
possibly be in the context of wheel to wheel racing.  Your concerns echo
those of the majority of people pondering involvement in this fine program.
To date I have raced in 8  events (yes, in my 914-6) and served as Chief
Steward at 10 more and I have made the following observations.
1.  The only incident I recall created by verifiable mechanical failure (not
a sanctionable offense) was a tire blowing on a 935 at Road Atlanta in 1993.
 This happened on the back straight (straight?) and the car made an abrupt
left turn at very high speed taking out about 50 feet of chain link fence.
 The damage to the car was mostly cosmetic and the driver was fine.
2.  The majority of the car to car incidents occur in the higher classes.
I.E. modified or purpose built race cars.  Very seldom do you see a car to
car in the stock or improved classes.  I feel the reason for this is that
these people (myself included) are more intimated by the possibility of
damaging their equipment, therefore treat each other and their cars with a
tiny bit more respect.  That is they give each other a little more room and
perhaps drive at 9.9 instead of 10.1
3. *Most*  incidents are "created " by drivers with "middle level" racing
experience. (2-3 years perhaps).  Why?  My feeling is that beginning racers
tend to be very conservative and not take unecessary chances in questionable
passing situations and very experienced racers know enough not to try a pass
if it won't work.  (they also get to know very quickly who they can race
closely with and who they can't).
4.  The general attitude of drivers in PCA Club Racing is one of camaraderie
and fellowship.  They are all there to have a great racing experience in cars
which, for the most part, cannot be wheel to wheel raced in any other venue.
As Jerry said, I have seen as much car damage in high speed drivers ed events
as I have in PCA Club Racing.  If you like drivers ed you will *love* club
racing.  It adds a whole new dimension to the Porsche driving experience.
Incidently, to apply for a Club Racing license you must have completed at
least 8 days of verifiable drivers ed. (Track not auto-x)
The rule book and license app may be obtained by calling Ruth Harte at the
PCA National office (703/922-9300) and requesting one.
If you still have doubts, make arrangements to go see one in person and I
think you will be impressed by the quality of driving, the array of cars and
the great time everyone is having with their p-cars.  Do this at your own
risk, however, this is an addictive thing you could easily become caught up
in.

Sorry for the length of this, but I feel it needed to be said.  Barry isn't
the only one with this question on his mind, he's just the only one who's
asked.

Regards

Pat Moyle
PCA Club Racing National Steward
70 914-6 (I smoke 'em in the corners, they smoke me on the straights)

------------------------------

     have: 205/50, 255/50, 255/40, 245/45, 275/40, and 315/35. FYI, my
