------------------------------

Date: Sat, 25 Mar 1995 13:45:35 -0500
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bartonc@annap.infi.net>
Subject: Re: formation of P-car widows (long)

 "Nancy J. Duffield", demonstrating that ol' David J. is one *very* fortunate 
fellow, indeed, writes:

> I'm Nancy, a not so sleek, but, none the less a 1948 model classic.  
[deletia]

> If any of you are 
> interested please let me know, until then I will try to keep on keeping 
> on.  Ohhhh lonesome me !!

I'm not Dora, (a pre-war classic with a pre-war husband), who doesn't do
computers <sigh>; but I am her *happy* husband.  I just showed your delightful
note to her, and she said to tell you that if she *did* the computerizer
bit, she'd be the first to rush to join you!

Since no good deed should go unpunished, I'm going to inflict Snake's tale
on you in retal... er, appreciation of your day-brightener.

You do know the difference between a War Story and a Fairy Tale, don't you?

Fairy Tales start with:  "Once upon a time"; while War Stories start with:
"Now this is no shit..."

     [ The captain has now turned on the No-Shit Light: ]

Now this is no shit, it really happened to me (no shit, it really did!) a
few years ago, when I lived in Saigon (actually, it was Gia Dinh Province,
about a block before the Province Headquarters, on the road from Tan Son
Nhut airport to Highway 1, made famous by the French Writer, Bernard Fall,
as the "Street Without Joy" (Rue Sans Joie) in his excellent book by that
name).

I shared a very large, one story villa with some Vietnamese folks and a
bunch of servants.  The villa had a large, sunny atrium in its center, and
formed a large U around the atrium. A very large spacious living/dining
room room, and then my suite (Bedroom/bathroom on the right of Bedroom)
formed the left side of the U.

A very large bedroom that opened from the left side into the Living Room
space, and from the back into the Kitchen, and with a barred, glass-less
window opening into the atrium, formed the bottom of the U.

A Store-room connected to the kitchen, and several bedrooms formed the
right side of the U. The U was closed by a full height (about 14ft)
extension of the front living space wall that ran across the front of the
villa and became the forward wall of the bedroom on the right side of the
atrium.

My Bedroom was entered from Living Room space and also was connected to my
private bath; which, strangely enough, also connected directly into the
(very large) kitchen.  The Kitchen also opened into the Living Space, the
bedroom on the bottom of the U facing into the atrium, and into the store
room.

Snake (as he/she/it was better known) came into my life one night when I
was playing poker with some of my Army friends, in a group house where
about 15 of them lived.  Someone mentioned that they had a *really* big
snake for sale for $25MPC (Military Payment Certificates, supposedly
unusable except in military facilities.  Ohhhh yeah, *un*usable, sure
thing, GI... available on the open market at $2MPC to $1Green backs or,
simply, Green.  But I digress...). Short version: Snake went home with me.

Folks, there were a *lot* of *small* people living in this villa, the
Landlord had a (tiny) daughter about 6, and the house-amah had a youngster
about the same age and size.  There were also assorted young girls ranging
in age from 11 to 18 belonging either to the Landlord or the amah; and
total number of the number of people other than me, over 5 ft high was
equal to the number of them sharing my enthusiasm for ol' Snake's company.
If I had to guess, I'd estimate that number to be, oh, say... Zero or
less.

Well, because Snake had just eaten the day or so before he became a guest,
he was very lethargic from a full belly.  So since he was on his best
behavior, everyone *reluctantly* agreed to give him a chance.  Thereafter,
during the days that followed, Snake played inner-tube, spending the heat
of the days curled up inside an old truck tire out in the atrium.

Among the things I learned from living with ol' Snake, was that the old
wisdom about letting sleeping dogs lie doesn't necessarily apply ONLY to
dogs.  I also learned that it's not a real good idea to kick a tire that
has a large snake sleeping inside.  I also (accidently) learned that white
boys can, indeed, jump!  As a side note here, you'd positively be AMAZED at
how LOUD a 98 inch python can hiss, and how much HOSTILITY even a
good-humored one can interject into such a simple sound. I promise you;
it'd definitely get your attention!  It might also prompt you to change
your under-shorts sooner than you might otherwise have planned.

In the evenings, I'd occasionally take Snake with me and we'd go strafing
the bars.  Just before going in, I'd wrap ol' Snake around my waist and
stroll in and take a seat.  As anyone who's been there will recall, these
were highly cultured places where gentlemen could go and meet ladies of
refinement, and while away the hours in genteel conversation.

For those of you who've missed that uplifting experience, picture this.
Your basic bar (pretty much the same the world over, a long narrow, dark
room with a bar running along one wall), but well stocked with Ladies eager
for "Cultural Exchange."

Its not uncommon to find this kind of feminine companionship already
present in any bar in any part of the world.  In many parts of the world,
(by no means universally so, however) sharing that companionship is
optional. Not the case in Saigon.  There, to enter a bar was to be
virtually *engulfed* in a swarm of young lovelies, each greeting the
newcomer in his native tongue, with the same seductive, subtly
sophisticated greeting "Hey Joe! You ver han'some! Where you come from in
Uni' Stat?  You buy me one Saigon tea!"

[editor's note, Serious Mode: ON]  I'm not demeaning the ladies or their
culture.  They spoke a hell of a lot more English that most of us spoke
Vietnamese.  They were honest.  It was tea, at whiskey prices, true; but
they never said it was anything *but* tea!  And, to their credit, they
almost *never* were prostitutes.  It was pretty much all good, clean fun,
and (almost) everybody understood that.  [Ok, enough.  Serious Mode: OFF]

This feminine companionship, however, definitely was *not* optional.  If
you only wanted to get a beer and swap lies with your buddies without this
companionship, you had to go somewhere other than a bar.  That is, (heh,
heh...) UNLESS say, you happened to have a 98 inch python under your shirt,
and he happened to stick his head out to join the party...  Now that, my
friends, would get you some SERIOUS breathing space; and right NOW!  You
just wouldn't believe that ladies that small could move that fast.  I get
tears in my eyes just thinking about it.  (but then again, I'm notoriously
easily amused...)

But I digress again (I'm also pretty easily distracted).  Snake had been a
member in (more or less) good standing around the villa for about a year.
Every two weeks, during that period, the cook would go to the market and
buy a live, *large* white duck (10-15 lbs) for Snake (35-40 lbs). All the
residents would gather in the bedroom pressed up to the window facing the
atrium in breathless anticipation of the life and death drama to come. Once
everyone had secured an observation place, the duck would be tossed out and
introduced to Ol' Snake.  Sometimes the duck would go berserk and run
around squawking its head off, and sometimes it would stand *very* still,
trying to pretend it was an inanimate object. Either way, it became Snake's
dinner. Everyone in the house, except me (and, of course, the duck) found
this endlessly fascinating.  I watched the first time, but had no stomach
for any more. [But hey, this is the stuff of life, not *pointless*
cruelty...anyway, I'm getting to the point; keep your shirt on...]

Once Snake had suffocated the duck, he'd spend at least half an hour
checking it over thoroughly for signs of life.  Then, he'd spend about the
same amount of time fastidiously stretching the bird out in a straight
line, grasping the bill in his mouth and maneuvering around until he got it
just right.  Next, he'd maneuver himself to approach the duck nose to beak,
and start working the bird down his throat.  Pythons (hell, most all
snakes) have a mouth full of thin, inwardly-curving teeth like fish-hooks
without barbs.  It's important to know this, as once food starts down that
long journey, it's  a *one* way trip.  No returns, No cancellations!  In
fact, a number of large snakes die each year from starting to eat something
too big to swallow.  I believe that's why Ol' Snake took so long looking
the duck over before starting to eat.  Snakes have a unique perspective on
this "Don't bite off more than you can chew" business...

In those days, I used to spend about a week out of each 4 to 6 weeks, split
between Hong Kong and Bangkok.  I had one of these trips planned that would
take me away over Tet, the Vietnamese Lunar New Year, so the Vietnamese
residents planned to take advantage of my absence to celebrate a big,
traditional family feast to celebrate the holiday. No round-eyes invited.

Now Snake had been scheduled to "do the dinner thing" with a duck about 10
days prior to my departure.  But this time, when introduced to the duck,
Snake completely ignored it.  By the time for me to leave, Snake and the
duck (who had to be fed every day!) had become like old married folks.
Snake ignored the duck, and the duck had come to ignore Snake.  I was
worried about Ol' Snake's health, but none the less, I still had to leave
as scheduled. Something unexpected came up when I got to Bangkok, however,
that caused me to curtail my trip and return early to Saigon after being
away only three days of the seven I had planned.  I arrived back at the
villa about 5:00 pm the day before Tet and the planned big celebration; and
agreed to accommodate the Vietnamese folks by either leaving and staying
gone all the next day, or by keeping to my private quarters all day while
the celebration took place.  Snake, up to this point, still hadn't eaten
the duck.  My return however, must have precipitated the return of Snake's
appetite; as he forthwith commenced to make dinner out of one large, *very*
surprised, duck.

Now normally this would result in a very lethargic snake with a very large,
football shaped lump about a foot or so down from his head; and *total*
disinterest in food for at least the next week or more.  This seemingly
happy turn of events was completed just minutes before the cook arrived
with five live chickens for the next days festivities.  Seeing Ol' Snake in
his well-fed stupor, she put the chickens out in the atrium with him and
started on the other kitchen preparations.  Meanwhile, I went back to my
quarters and showered-off the accumulated grime from my day's travels.

Just after I stepped out of the shower and into my bedroom, the most
incredible, god-awfull commotion erupted.  It sounded like it started to be
a mere riot, but blossomed into utter chaos.  In a span of about 15
seconds. I mean, there's just no *way* to adequately describe the utter
pandemonium; yelling, screaming, hollering and shrieking!  It sounded like,
as a bare minimum, the Viet Cong had picked the atrium as the launch-site
for a new offensive!  Honestly concerned that something like this might be
the case, I cinched the towel around my waist, grabbed my .45 cal
grease-gun and my flack-vest, threw open the door from bathroom to the
kitchen, and dashed through and into the bedroom facing the atrium
expecting to meet the worst.

Boy and Girls, the picture these eyes beheld was the the most wondrous
sight this old soldier *ever* expects to see, even if he lives another 7
lifetimes!  Snake, it seems, had developed a *tad* more appetite than he'd
let on up to that point, and the presence of those chickens in his living
space was a temptation he never even *thought* about resisting. Before
anyone knew what he was up to, he'd snared one of the chickens and promptly
dispatched it.  The other four chickens, having been surprisingly quiet up
to that point, began getting seriously agitated, leaping up into the air,
running here and there, screeching, squawking, defecating, shedding
feathers, flapping their wings, generally disturbing the peace and
declaring the end of the world as we knew it, to be at hand.  Hoo Boy!

That was all it took to incite the entire household of small, and
surprisingly vocal, humans to riot; or at least to show their solidarity
with the chickens by emulating them, running in all directions, shrieking,
waving their arms in the air, and I don't know what-all.  Four excited
chickens, when they put their minds to it, can raise a fairly respectable
ruckus on their own.  Add in, ohhhh, say... 7 to 12 small hysterical female
persons, ranging in age from 6 to 50, each determined to out-panic and
out-shriek the others, and the chickens, too...  Now THIS was flat-out
AMUSING, not to mention FUNNY!

But I may've led you to believe that, given this delicious lunacy, the
level of pandemonium and the general level of chaos and disorder currently
reigning, things were about as amusing as they could get.  That's what I
thought anyway.  Fat chance!

Snake, calmly ignoring the live chickens and other distractions, had
started to swallow his dessert.  Did I mention that this is not a
reversible process?  I'm sure I forgot to explain that to the cook.

Seeing Snake start on HER chicken, she gave a whoop of outrage, squatted
down on the tiles and started tugging on the back half of that chicken for
all she was worth.

Snake, not appreciating this interuption of his dinner, was not very much
inclined to look favorably upon the misguided efforts of the cook to impose
this measure of dietary discipline upon him.  Neither was he inclined to
keep his displeasure to himself.  Or to give up that chicken...

In the meantime, all the other occupants of the villa; chickens, humans,
(probably a Martian or two as well, who could say?) went on, raising merry
hell. I had to put the grease-gun down, lest, in my by now hysterical
convulsions, I shoot myself; OR, (possibly worse, all things considered
under the circumstances) drop my towel!  Just about that time (all the
while thinking to my self that NOTHING could possibly be *this* funny) one
of the most-active chickens in the group, (probably the ring-leader)
expired of fright or excitement and fell to the tiles with an audible
thud.

The demise of the second chicken inspired that hysterical bunch to rise to
a truly *Olympian* level of frenzy!  And, as if that were not enough by
itself; clearly audible over even this impressive cacophony, came the angry
screams of the cook; punctuated by the answering, indignant bellows of Ol'
Snake, who, despite a mouth filled with fully half a large chicken, was
snortin' his outrage like an 18-wheeler demanding a passing lane, and
whippin' his considerable bulk around like a bull 'gator in heat.  Lord
have Mercy! The mind boggles! This was totally Surreal!  This was Bliss for
the easily amused!  Whew!!! I accidently woke Dora in the middle of the
night the other night, shaking the bed with laughter as I relived the
experience in my mind (she, on the other hand, was curiously un-amused...
maybe you had to be there). I know I'll never see or experience anything
that funny as long as I live, and believe me, it's a damn good thing; I'd
never survive another one like that!

Snake won the tug-of-war over the chicken that night, but also got his
walking (slithering?) papers at the same time. Something was said about a
unanimous concern that a couple of the smaller girls weren't much, if any,
larger than Snakes new found appetite...


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 25 Mar 1995 13:18:02 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: spare keys - Official Story

>Recently there was a posting/thread about cutting spare keys from vin 
>numbers.  I have investigated this and found that P-Cars from around '83 
>on, have their key codes recorded.  Keys for earlier cars can be cut from 
>the key codes.  These often can be found on you ignition lock in the 
>dashboard.  Yes, just simply tear your dashboard apart!  This isn't 
>difficult after unscrewing the bezel around the ignition lock.  Unless 
>you have "hang down air".  Sure nuff, mine has it.

According to Porsche itself, it has all Porsche key codes on file with the 
VINs from 1970 on (except 914s). So if you have a 1970 or newer 911, or 
924/944/968/928/whatever, all you need is your VIN code.

Date: Sat, 25 Mar 1995 17:22:52 -0500 (EST)
From: Tomkow <tomkow@nando.net>
Subject: Re: "Unrealistic" Passing (was "993 Turbo ad")

Hi Andy, 
    Your point is well taken.  I own both a '84 911 Carrera and a '95 
Ducati 900 SP.  On the same road, both have their strong points: The 
Porsche has a safety factor that the bike doesn't, combined with more grip 
at the limit; the bike owns the acceleration and transitional handling 
categories.  I have driven the 911 at 10/10th's; however, I am not the 
rider that the Ducati needs to be ridden to that degree.  It's not a 
question of "balls" (excuse me, ladies) but more of common sense 
(realizing the limits of my abilities).

    On the other hand, very few cars pass me while piloting either 
vehicle.  More bikes than cars in both cases!  Well, you have inspired me 
to do more research.  Thanks!

 -Bill Tomko

Date: Sat, 25 Mar 95 20:22:55 -0500
From: tom@radical.chm.jhu.edu (Tom Tullius)
Subject: Moldy 911T

Dear Porschephiles,

I have just visited my '73 911T for the first time since I put it up
on jackstands last August in preparation for my year-long sabbatical
in the Netherlands. (Some of you might remember my request then for
advice on long-term storage. While I didn't take Ben's or Bart's
advice to ship my car to Europe, we did acquire a used BMW in Holland,
which has been a lot of fun to drive on the autobahn).

While it was really great to see my car again after these many months,
I was dismayed to find an amazing growth of mold in the interior. All
the vinyl upholstery is affected, but seemingly worse is the presence
of mold on the cloth inserts of the Recaro seats.

I am presently in the U.S. just for a short visit; I won't be
returning permanently to the States until August. I was hoping to
clean up the mold while I am here this week, so it is not an even
bigger job next summer. What is the recommended procedure for mold
removal? Any suggestions for keeping the interior mold-free for the
next few months? The car is stored in an unheated garage. Should I
keep the windows open (at least partially)? Until now the windows have
been closed.

Thanks for any help.

Cheers,

Tom

Date: Sat, 25 Mar 1995 20:57:14 -0500 (EST)
From: "Derek Cahill" <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: RE: Mixing Synthetics with Dino-juice

In message Sat, 25 Mar 1995 10:40:18 -0500 (EST),
  "Gerald G. MacDonald - Thomas Cooley Law School" <macdonag@mlc.lib.mi.us>  writes:

> Sorry for the repitition.  Quick Q:  If I want to put Mobil 1 in the
> Beast this Spring but up to now its been slipping away on genuine rotted
> dinosaur carcass, will there be a problem?  I ask because it is my
> understanding when you change the oil in a 911 you usually leave about 2
> quarts of the old stuff behind when you drain.  Suggestions anyone?

Yes, this will be a synthetic blend. True, you can't get all the oil out
without some truly intensive work. For instance, when I changed the oil in
the Toyota, using ~4 quarts of Mobil 1 and 1 quart of Castrol GTX (dino
juice). The thing you have to watch for is to match SG and SH oils (Mobil 1
is both, so you should have no problems). Once you choose a certain weight
though, you should stick with that, or else you'll get a suspension (where
one oil floats on the other), but after one or two more changes, it should
all come out anyways.

BTW, most of the 'synthetics' are actually synthetic blends. Amsoil and Mobil
1 are synthetic (100%) while Slick 50 and Exxon Synthetic are only blends.

2 quarts does sound like a high number though... are you draining ALL of the
oil?
 -Derek Cahill

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 25 Mar 1995 21:35:47 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : 17" BFG track tires

Lee Walczak asked :

>    I'd like to order a set of BFG R1s for my 993. They have to go on 
>     the stock 17-in. rims, which are 7s in the front and 9s in the rear. 
...
>     But my new '95 size chart from BFG shows no 235/17s. Here's what they 
>     have: 205/50, 255/50, 255/40, 245/45, 275/40, and 315/35.

I don't know where you got this info, but it's not correct.

In the past, there were NO good tires for 17" 911 fronts (for 
autocrossing at least). This year BFG finally has a good tire :
the 235/45 (?) /17. They have been used with success on the
new M3 (front and rear) at the pro solos this year.
This is great news for C2 and C2 RS America drivers, as well
as the 993 with the 17" rims. These should be perfect on
7" or 8" rims.

The new BFG Comp TA R1 tire (230) is designed for track
but is also used for autocrossing as the 226 compound has
been retired. This is no great loss : even though the 226 was
extremely fast, the wear was terrible and the tires would cord
in the center groove before the outer edges were worn much
at all. Added bonus : now autocrossers can do a few track
events too!

Call (800) RACE-BFG for the sizes and prices.

Regards, Mike Piera  '72 911S (now I can finally get a new 911)

P.S. I'm interested in co-driving an A-Stock 911/993 for the LA Pro Solo
April 22-23, as I'm not very good in an MR-2 Turbo.


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 25 Mar 95 20:41:44 CST
From: "David Kelly" <dkelly@iquest.com>
Subject: Re: 928 Headroom

John C. C. White" <jccw@ilab.mitre.org> said:
>There was a November '83 Tech Bulletin (or some such thing) that
>was titled "Power Seats Height Modification to Increase Headroom".
>Might be some information in there that would be useful to you.
>I don't have the bulletin, just a pointer to it from Alldata, a
>Web server at http://www.alldata.tsb.com.
>
> -John White-
>'84 928S

I gave them a try. Sure enough, I found a large list of Porsche bulletins
relating to my car. And couldn't figure out how to download the meat of
the bulletin via Netscape. They suggest downloading their MS-DOS application
and they'll give me 10 minutes free. Whoopie. They might as well have
suggested they'd give the data to anyone who shows up in a Yugo.

At least I have the list now, and on to bug somebody for the data as there
are lots of things there other than more seat height that are interesting.
Considering my nearest Porsche dealer is 100 miles away, what sources do
we have for obtaining Porsche service bulletins? PCA?

Date: Sat, 25 Mar 1995 21:56:17 -0700
From: qmoolla@gpu3.srv.ualberta.ca (Qassim Moolla)
Subject: Parts for 1987 944S

Anybody out there is, or know of somebody who is, interested in selling a 
skid plate and a cam tensioner (Porsche part # 944 105 067 16) for an 87 944 
S ?  This tensioner is as far as I know, unique to the 87/88  944 S.  
I changed the belts and rollers on this car because the old belt (only six 
months old) had developed a warp probably due to a worn roller and was 
making some noise.  The tensioner spring appears to be weak and perhaps that 
is all that needs replacing.  I am interested in other opinions on this 
matter since the tensioner is a pretty expensive piece (dealer only part) to 
purchase.
 
Ike Moolla
1984 944
1987 944S

Date: 26 Mar 95 00:51:21 EST
From: Richard Kovach <76253.1567@compuserve.com>
Subject: Water leaks & sticky door triggers

Help!

My recently-purchased 1984 944 is displaying a couple of very annoying
qualities.  First of all, when I first got it there was a lot of moisture in the
back under the hatch, making the carpet damp, etc.  Didn't worry too much,
thought it was due to just collecting to much humidity when the dealer was
washing it twice a day (test driving in mucky spring weather).  But today I got
back from a 2-week trip to discover a LOT of dampness back there, completely
dampening the carpet, & soaking a Chilton's book and a whole roll of paper
towels I left back there.  Worse, I didn't notice it until my Soundstream amp
(located in with the spare tire) blew it's fuses due to all the moisture.  After
removing the carpet, there are a lot of droplets on the metal surface near the
spare tire, but nothing really collecting deep in the spare tire space or down
in sides behind the rear wheel wells.
The question is, what could be causing this?  I know for certain it accumulates
when the car's been sitting still in the rain, for a long period.  The moisture
only accumulates in the area around 6-12 inches from the back (taillights area).
It seems to be evenly on both sides (so I think it's not leaking around the
power wiper), and doesn't seem to come from the drain tubes by the hatch catches
(I made sure they're not plugged, and the dampened spots seem a bit far from
this)  The sunroof drains also seem clear and working properly.  	
I checked when it was raining today, and couldn't see any trail of water from
any seals or drains to the spots where the water seems to collect.  There was
lots of condensation on the inside of the hatch though.  The one thing I haven't
done is disassemble the hatch catches to see if the water could be somehow not
getting to the drain tubes -- but again, the pattern of wetness doesn't make it
look like it's coming from there.  ANY ASSISTANCE WOULD BE GREATLY
APPRECIATED!!!!!  (in other words, it's driving me NUTS!!!)

The other question is:  How can I properly lubricate my door-handle triggers?
Since I got the car, they seem to vary between being "OK", to usually being
"very stiff", to sometimes being "squeeze-with-both-hands-and-curse-loudly".
What's stranger is their behavior doesn't seem to really correlate with how wet
or cold it is, or any other condition I can think of that should make a
difference.  I've tried oiling the parts of the triggers and lock catches that I
could get at externally with a flexible tube, but none of that seems to really
work.
Would really like to get it fixed up quick, as new handles seem to be pretty
darn pricey (about 8 to 10 times the price of Volkswagen ones I've seen
advertised, which seems silly -- are any of the parts common between the two?
My friends with a late-model Golf Cabriolet and lots of older VWs with
trigger-handles have never had problems)  ?????

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 03:13:56 -0500 (EST)
From: Steve DuChene <s0017210@cc.ysu.edu>
Subject: need prices for rare 356/4-cam spares


	I have some spares I need to sell to help pay on some
	student loans. Unfortunately I am a little at a loss as to a
	fair price for them. If someone could make some suggestions
	as to what they might be worth I would appreciate it. I want
	to place an add in the 356 Registry mag without being
	completely out of the ball park (i.e. neither outrageously
	high nor way under priced).

	First is a set of four NOS sodium filled intake valves for
	a 4 cam Carrera motor. The ATE part number on the stem of
	the valves is 3939 and on there is also the letters EIN KO on
	the other side of the ATE symbol. They are in a Tranco box
	which has the part numbers SAS3479SF on it. This same number
	is also stamped on the valve stems just below the keeper area.
	My research based on a very old (mid sixties) Beck catalog 
	(apparently before it was Beck-Arnley) shows this to fit 
	55-59 Carrera and Spyder. I originally purchased these from
	an old import parts warehouse thinking they were Super-90
	valves but got them home and discovered the were a LOT larger
	than that. 

	The second item is a Stork oil (or OEL as it is marked :-)
	temperature gauge that has the long thermo couple that terminates
	in the dipstick which has a screw-on loop type handle. I believe
	this may be NOS also but I have no way of verifying this except
	to say that it came from a defunct Porsche importer from the
	fifties and still has steel packing bands around the coiled up
	thermo couple wire. From what I have been told this is a Pre-A
	piece of equipment. The gauge face is black with green lettering
	and a double ended green needle.

	Like I said I would appreciate some guidance as to what these
	might be worth. I am aware that Palo Alto Speedo is marketing
	a reproduction of the Stork gauge but I would think an original
	would be more desirable.
- --

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 00:33:47 -0800 (PST)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: Re: Water leaks & sticky door triggers

 > My recently-purchased 1984 944 is displaying a couple of very annoying

coming in from where the tailight assembly meets the body? After the body 
shop replaced one of my tailights, I noticed a bead of cauking (gorilla 
snot?) carefully lining the edge of the lights where it meets the body. I 
also noticed this on the old light before it was replaced. Maybe water is 
coming in from this seam?

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 07:12:09 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Control Arms-revisited

Jim writes,
>Are you running stock lower control arms?
>The more info I gather, the more concerned I become. It appears from what
>I am reading  that the Fabcar parts are  only slightly better. What
>seems to be the current line of thought for this, particularly as it applies
>to club racing?

Hi Jim, 
Got my new proportioning valve yesterday. It's marked 5/33. I hope that's
correct. Will install today.
Yes I am running the stock TurboS control arms. When I was at Sebring I posed
that question to the Kelly-Moss guys. They claimed to have never had a
failure of that part it 50,000 track miles which I find encouraging. They
claimed that failure was caused by using larger than normal (they didn't
define larger than normal) front sway bars. They said my 30mm bars were not a
hazard. They also claimed that excessive lowering was also contributory.
They contend that the stock TurboS springs were wimpy and should be upgraded
instead of compensating with super heavy anti roll bars.
It also seems that the ball joints should be checked regularly and replaced
when there is any signs of play. I had to do this last year. I sent my arms
to European Dynamics in Houston and they came back like new. Apparently the
ball joint unit is epoxied into the arm. With a bit of heat the epoxy softens
and they can be removed. European Dynamics then replaces the joint unit with
a heavier duty one and epoxies it back in place. They wouldn't tell me which j
oint they use but rumor has it that it is a VW truck item.
Anyway so far so good and I do check them regularly as you can imagine. What
did you hear about the Fabcar design that was negative?I was considering
going that route in the future if the ball joints failed again. After all the
factory unit is more expensive than the FabCar unless you can get deals.
Be interested in the scuttlebutt you've heard.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
7:06 am

------------------------------

street corner, (Hotel Street, appropriate name ?) and yell, "Hey Joe,

356.  What?  Of course he was an honest cop, and never on the take ! ;-)

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 07:32:11 -0500 (EST)
From: "Derek Cahill" <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: First day out...

Well, being the second weekend of spring weather and I had a few free
minutes, I decided to live on the risky side today... I drove the '73 911T
around the block... twice!! (Now keep in mind, this car is 'the baby' and
has no insurance, so has been living under house arrest since our last
insurance policy expired... next week, the license plates expire and it
shall be put away until... later)

I now live in (relatively) flat NJ, after moving from southern Indiana. Now,
in S. Indiana, the hills and driveways were steep, so steep in fact, that
the Porsche would roll away if not in gear (something terribly difficult to
do while it is running), because the parking brake doesn't seem to do a very
good job of keeping the car from defying gravity. I noticed this again
today... on a slight incline, I went into the house for a minute, came back
out to find the car leaving without me (which I believe is illegal in this
state :) )

Anything I should look for in trying to strengthen the parking brake, or
before I break out (no pun) Haynes, is this just a design limitation?

Another 'problem'... This is a normal problem, like if suddenly the car
stopped leaking oil... Anyways, I started the car up like usual, and like
every now and then it does, backfired. Now, the weird thing was that the
oil pressure shot up to normal, not high, not low, just smack dab in the
middle. This was at 1000 RPM (idle), and running the speed up ran the
pressure up. It was just weird that 10 seconds into the run, the pressure
was where it normally takes 15 minutes to get to. I doubt this is a problem,
but what caused it?

 -Derek Cahill

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 06:01:08 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: 914 First Day

Well, I officially have Katarina on the road, and took her out for a 
while yesterday. I'm VERY happy to have the new heat 
exchangers - sounds like a sewing machine now, instead of a top 
fuel dragster! However...
Below 2000rpm, it stumbles a lot when it's cold. 2000 rpm is like a 
switch - suddenly it runs smoothly.

The damn thing won't idle! Gotta check the idle adjust when it's 
warm, I turned it and turned it when it was cold, and it didn't 
seem to make any difference. The screw seemed to turn too 
easily, as well.

Oil leaks! After I drove it for a while, I could hear drip, drip, drip, 
drip onto the heat exchangers... My mechanic mentioned that it 
might be the pushrod tubes...?

Oh, and I got the street-legal H4s from Hella (they're called Hella 
Vision Pluses, and they claim they use HB2 headlights, but don't 
let that fool you - they're real H4s), turned 'em on at night, and 
the wire behind the headlight switch started to burn up, causing a 
most unpleasant cloud of smoke from behind the instrument 
panel. So I had to drive home with running lights only... Yuck.

But it's still nice to be "back in the saddle" again. :)

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 09:14:19 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: RE : Don't race your 914/6

Dan said:

>I agree with what you said about racing Porsches and not letting them
>become garage rats.  What I don't agree with is the idea of transfering >the
serial numbers, etc to a 914/4 if your rare 914/6 gets trashed. This >is
dishones, unethical, and I might add, illegal.

If the car is sold as all original, I would agree with you.  But remember,
the factory sold replacement bodies; all you had to do was supply the serial
number of a wrecked car, and presto, new car. The part numbers are in old 914
parts manuals.  My brother in law had a 911 at one point that had a '71
title, but had been rebodied with a '78 chassis.  The factory sold them
either as a body in primer or complete painted bodies with all interior trim,
wiring, etc., less seats, drivetrain, and suspension. If the conversion is
complete, ie., all special bits, mounts, brackets, who cares?
Porsche certainly didn't! :)

Jon Lowe

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 09:26:03 -0500 (EST)

My dad has an 85 928 and me, dad, and my brother all fll bewteen 5'11 and
just a notch under 6'2" abd none of us had any trouble with 'driving' the car

safe to assume you  played around with the tilt of the seat?  bringing the
front edge up and pushing the whole seat forward a bit, gave us all sorts of room.

try some strange seat positions to see what happens!

scott s

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 07:23:03 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: "Are You Listening Video", brochures

>On a related note, has anyone ever successfully convinced a Porsche 
>dealer to mail you the video and a dealer-type thick, glossy brochure?
>
>I'm currently Porsche-less (totally car-less :-() so getting to the local 
>dealer is virtually impossible.

There are two Porsche videos - the Are You Listening? one (a real snooze 
job, IMHO - virtually ZERO car scenes, mostly new-age baby x-ray pictures, 
stuff like that), and a copy of the 911 Carrera road test that was on Motorweek. 
As for the brochures, they aren't "glossy", they're smaller format, hardcover 
"books"... Two 911 ones (one 911 Carrera, one New 911 Carrera - both for the 
993, only minor differences), and any BUT the 911 ones are in quite short 
supply. (928GTS ones are the rarest.)

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 07:28:28 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: spare keys - Official Story - How?

>> According to Porsche itself, it has all Porsche key codes on file with the 
>> VINs from 1970 on (except 914s). So if you have a 1970 or newer 911, or 
>> 924/944/968/928/whatever, all you need is your VIN code.
>> 
>OK... Now how do I go about it? We don't have a dealer within 200 miles. 
>Can one order by phone?

Depending on your dealer, you probably can - the problem is proving proof 
of ownership, though they may not even bother checking. The problem is 
it'd be easy for someone to see your car, look at the reg. sticker and copy 
down the VIN, and get a set of keys made for it. Mercedes is getting pretty 
picky about this now, you can understand the danger!

Anyways, we ship out keys all the time, so shipping them isn't a problem - 
you should be able to give them a c.c. # and be all set.

| "General Lido" '85 Dodge Shelby Charger                   -Groucho Marx |

Subject: Re: Sample RaceTech and new subscription price

RACETECH

INSIDER NEWS AND ANALYSIS FROM THE WORLD OF RACING TECHNOLOGY

If you're interested in how technology is used in professional
motor-racing RaceTech is for you. Published by Rick Carlton, On-Track
Contributing Editor, RaceTech is the only monthly newsletter geared to the
latest technology and its impact on racing as a sport, and as a business.
RaceTech can be had via E-mail or regular mail for $40.00 per year, or via
Fax for $65.00 per year. For a sample issue contact migs@netcom.com on the
internet, or R.A. Carlton, 635 W. Baker Q103, Costa Mesa, CA 92626. 

Series to be covered in this years editions include:

F-1
IndyCar
NASCAR
IMSA
SCCA Pro Racing
BTCC
DTM
Porsche Super Cup and more!

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 08:47:00 -0800
From: CLEVBC@ix.netcom.com (Don Takitch)
Subject: 914-4 valve adjustment problems

I have a slight problem.  My '72 914-4 is just about ready to go back on 
the road with  the finishing touches being made to the body (pre-paint) 
and engine.  I completely rebuilt the engine with an updates Weber cam 
and new heavy duty rocker springs.  Before I put the rocker assemblies 
back on, the engine turns over fine using the fan bolt or even turning 
the fan belt.  When I put the rocker assemblies back on (in previous 
valve adjustment settings), the engine will turn up to a point, but 
then won't turn anymore.  Is this due to the heavy duty springs?  None 
of the springs are fully compressed when I'm trying to turn.

I'd like to get the valves adjusted before I put the engine back in so I 
don't have to puch it around the driveway to adjust the valves. (at 
least this time)  Any help would be greatly appreciated!

Regards,

Dion
'72 914-4

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 12:40:10 -0500 (EST)
From: RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu
Subject: Re: Water leaks & sticky door triggers

Richard Kovach wrote:
ANY ASSISTANCE WOULD BE GREATLY
APPRECIATED!!!!!  (in other words, it's driving me NUTS!!!)

	I think your problem may be just condensation; that huge rear window can 
generate a lot of droplets over the course of a wet evening.  Try to put some 
paper towels in strategic places under the window and see if it's coming from 
there.  

	Regarding your door handle triggers, the door handles come off so easy 
that it is best to remove them and soak them with our good friend WD40 or similar.  
Then use some light oil to lubricate moving parts.  Oil is better than grease, 
since grease tends to go hard and picks up foreign particles which makes operation 
more difficult.  
	I have never tried to interchange parts of a VW/Audi door handle with a 
Porsche one, however I do still have some parts of VW/Audi doorhandles as they are 
notorious for seizing up.  I have successfully interchanged handles and parts of 
handles between all sorts of VW and Audi models; My guess would be that some of 
the parts would indeed interchange with Porsche parts, but I haven't tried....yet.
Cheers,  Jan

the post-Parade Portland race) in addition to a number of autox's,
socials, tours, etc.  There are a number of good independent shops
as well as as two supportive dealerships in the area.  Let us know
if you have any other questions...

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 95 13:28:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: forged vs. cast


Ron,

This is correct.  As of the C4, the only available rims were the painted,
pressure-cast ones.  I think this remains true of all production wheels
since then, with the possible exception of the exotic rims used on the
911 Turbos.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 95 12:52:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 87 Carrera Cpe


Roger,

No street '87 Carrera came from the factory with 17" rims.  I don't know
anyone, off the top of my head, who runs a 3,2 Carrera with 17" rims
and so cannot point you towards an example.  But you will have to find
rims with the right offset, and you may need to make use of modified
steering stops and fenders which were introduced by Porsche for
people wishing to use 17" rims on 3,6 Carreras.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 95 13:31:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 911/951 Brake query


>Does anyone know if 951 caliper will bolt onto
>911 suspension (911sc suspension to be exact)?

VCI sells a number of brake update kits, and they would be able
to tell you.  Most recently, they showed an adaptor for mounting 930
callipers on SC hubs.  I'd give VCI a call.

Kevin

Very hard to find. Plan on spending lots of money.

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 95 15:03:54 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: 944 Ride Height

944 Owner-Porschephiles:

We need a favor.

If you would walk outside to your favorite 944 and take a measurement from
the center of the front wheel (the wheel hub cap center) to the bottom of
the fender directly above it, on both sides of the car and send the
following information in a note to georgeb@mhv.net, it would help us to
establish what a normal ride height 944 should be.

Here's what we need:

Your name and email address:

Year

Model (8valve, Turbo, S, S2, 968)

USA/Canada/Other Country (please identify)

Lowered? (Y/N)

Driver Side Measurement (inches or centimeters)

Passenger Side Measurement (inches or centimeters)

Wheel size (front)

Tire size (front)

Thanks for your help.  Your data will help us determine a safety factor for
the aluminum control arm problem.

George Beuselinck
Zone 1 48 Hours Registrar, on behalf of the Zone 1 Safety Committee
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 15:13:55 -0500 (EST)
From: Steve DuChene <s0017210@cc.ysu.edu>
Subject: Re: help - 914

 Nate wrote:
> need some help.  First, if anyone is disassembling a 914 and could spare
> that little hard line that runs from the master cylinder to the LF brake
> hose, I kinda... busted mine.  Also, if anyone has ever taken the rear
> 
	Nate: Why don't just get yourself a brake line flaring kit and
	make up a new one? You still have the pieces of the old on so
	it shouldn't be real difficult. Even if the fittings are unusual
	you could use the ones off the old line. A little heat carefully
	applied should free up your frozen fitting that caused you to
	break the line originally.

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 16:06:12 -0500
From: Jamesz1953@aol.com
Subject: parts needed for 78 thru 83 911



2 heater control boxes [ the ones that are under the car and are attached to
the body and and draw heat from the heater boxes via orange hose ]
1 heater blower [ the one that sits high in the engine bay and blows hot air
into the car not to be confused with the one that's in the front comparment ]
1 interior control unit [ this is the whole unit that controls all the cables
and fresh air blower and vents it is made of black plastic and has a habit of
cracking to describe it better the unit in the center of the dash with three
levers ]
if you have any of the above please leave me a note and a land line number
and i'll be sure to get back to you       thanks in advance

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 16:09:30 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: Dave & his 924 cam problems...

Hey Dave and other Porschephiliacs,
	The 924 did use a version of the engine that the LT van (sold in 
Europe only) has, but it is a bit different.  Trying to find and adapt 
such a cam wouldn't be worth it.  Call PAP, at 1-800-944-2964, they'll 
have the proper one at a cheap price. I've had good luck with them on 
other parts, but if they don't have it try Part Werks at 1-800-366-9147. 
Check which has the best price.  Send me some mail about other problems 
you might have, I love to talk about 924s. Write back!

Jay Karolyi  E-mail:    jkarolyi@southern.edu
'70 Corvair/914 rustbucket project
'77 lima bean green 924
'80 Toy 'rolla w/bumper sticker "My Other Car Is A Porsche" ...no lie!

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 17:05:27 -0500 (EST)

Excerpts from mail: 26-Mar-95 Re: help - 914 by Andrew Kalman@netcom.com 
> Hi Nate:
> 
> The raer calipers' bolts are tightened to 50 ft-lbs, so it shouldn't be too
> hard to take them off.  I used a wrench (the box end), and braced my legs
> against something so I could pull on the wrench (this is easier for the
> pass. side than for the driver side).  Make sure you don't slip and round
> off the bolt's head. I remember they were pretty tight.

    That's what I was doing... still felt too tight to me.  Of course,
somebody else has already pointed out that there might be locking tabs
keeping it from turning.  That would go a long way toward explaining
things.
    Also, unfortunately, the side I have to take apart was the side of
my garage that has no lights.  Hence the fact that I couldn't poke my
head in and see this.  But I digress.
> 
> Even better than getting a brake line flaring kit is to buy a rigid line
> with European fittings on both ends - then you just need to bend it to
> shape (NOT BY HAND - use a tubing bender).  Lots of auto parts store in my
> area carry these lines in a variety of lengths - they're made by Bendix,
> and the fittings are light blue.

    My Haynes manual tells me there were two different kinds of fittings
used for 914's - some were tapered thread, and others were straight
thread.  According to the book, mine should be straight.
    As even my flare nut wrench (eleven bucks!) wouldn't get the line
free, I had to use vise-grips and would prefer to get new fittings if at
all possible.  Anyone know if the above info. is correct and if so, how
to make sure I get the right stuff?
    Also, does anyone sell cheap tubing benders?  My grandpa has a bunch
(NOT cheap ones!), as he used to be a tubefitter in a mill, but I
believe they're all SAE... rats.

thanks,

Nate

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 04:48:27 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Clarify early and late 944 susp.

Could someone (who actually knows) please clarify the actual suspension 
changes made to the 944 in 85/2.  I have been told that the arms were 
upgraded from steel to aluminum construction.  I have also heard that the 
mounting was changed, thus resulting in better control of the rear wheels, 
and reduced noise and harshness transmitted to the interior.  Is this 
correct?  Is there more?  Is there less?

Did the suspension changes have a notable or highly significant effect on 
handling, ride, etc?

Aside of the above susp. changes, and the interior changes was anything 
changed on the car in mid 85?

Thanks in advance!
Andy

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 17:31:57 -0500 (EST)
From: "Matthew A. Dilligan" <diligan@minerva.cis.yale.edu>
Subject: 914 bucks

In the brief hour I had to drive my newly acquired 914 before I had to 
catch a flight to the east coast the car ran fairly well, but at times it 
would buck quite violently. This was on freeway driving, and accelerating 
seemes to make it go away. It got better as it warmed up, but even after 
an hour on the freeway it still did it on occasion. The car had sat for a 
few months before i bought it, and the tailpipe had a signifigant amount 
of soot built up. I would assume this means it's running rich and the 
(assumed) poor condition of the plugs is leading to misfiring. Similarly, 
sometimes the car would suddenly seem to loose a little power which would 
come back when I accelerated. 
	I'm going to be back in town fow two days before I have to leave 
again and I'm hoping in this time to get it running good so I can get it 
all registered and such. My plan is to replace the sparkplugs and see 
what that does, but judging from the tailpipe it's running quite rich. Is 
there a quick fix for this or should I wait till my manuals arrive and 
work on it then? This is a 1970 with the 1.7 BTW. It's got around 80k 
miles on it and within the past year it's had a valve job and had the 
injection control box replaced.
	Thanks in advance.

Matt
1970 914

Hey Kevin,

While working a stint in a friend's foreign repair shop I found that 
certain MB calipers used the same pad as the early alloy "S" calipers.  I 
think that it was one of the 300 series.

Arn't the "A" calipers the cast version of the alloy calipers?
The '78 and later 930 front calipers were larger.

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 95 19:13:49 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Clarify early and late 944 susp.

> Could someone (who actually knows) please clarify the actual suspension 
> changes made to the 944 in 85/2.  I have been told that the arms were 
> upgraded from steel to aluminum construction.  I have also heard that the 
> mounting was changed, thus resulting in better control of the rear wheels, 
> and reduced noise and harshness transmitted to the interior.  Is this 
> correct?  Is there more?  Is there less?
> 
> Did the suspension changes have a notable or highly significant effect on 
> handling, ride, etc?
> 
> Aside of the above susp. changes, and the interior changes was anything 
> changed on the car in mid 85?

Everything was changed on the later 944s, primarily to allow Porsche to
build the 944 Turbo.

It's easier to tell you what was not changed: The front fenders, the rear
fenders and the rear hatch. If you look closely, just about everything else
is different.

No, there is not a notably significant difference between the handling and
ride of and early 85 and a late 85 car.

- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Mr Kyle wrote:
 >  There are two Porsche videos - the Are You Listening? one ( a real snooze
job, IMHO - > virtually ZERO care scenes, mostly new-age baby x-ray pictures,
stuff like that), ...
  
IMHO, it's an effective video for its target audience: aging baby-boomers,
mainly male, who after they buy their 993, are certifiable as in "mid-life
crisis."  Everyone who likes cars admires the latest that Porsche has to
offer, but not many can afford their product. Even Bill Gates is over thirty.
 Porsche - in this video -(IMHO) do an great job of telling us baby boomers
to "go for it" and spend the 60 or 70 large on a 993.  Actually, I see the
video as a way to get  people into the store to test drive the Porsche.  At
that point, if the money is there, the car is probably sold!  It's really
quite a video:  the background music, "Deep Forest", is quite spectacular all
by itself..

BTW, I first saw the video last week, the test drive sold me on the virtues
of the 993.

Neil Halvey
1995 Porsche 993 (white coupe)

about $1,000-1,500 in work, mostly minor things.  It could also use a new
set of tires (about 20% left on the current set). Finally, the clutch is
fine but is fine now, but can not be adjusted any farther.

before they find one they want to buy.  While I drove a few cars before

saw a huge amount of oil smoke out of the exhaust.  After th oil burned
away, there was no smoke for a while, then the same thing again.  I
drove it home, and noticed a large amount of oil in the air filter box,
the intake plenum, and around the sheet metal.  My 914 has the factory fuel
injection (2.0 liter), and the engine is in resonable shape (one minor
oil leak in the rear main seal (to be fixed next weekend if this is not a
major problem)  I havent noticed any strange sounds, but I am not good
at diagnosing things by sound.  Does anyone know what this could be, the
amount of oil seems to indicate it is coming from somewhere then burning
through the engine....

  Thanks in advance for your help.

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 19:31:03 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: 914 and lots o' smoke

Well a couple of quick things come to mind"

	1. Burned piston, broken rings, sucked a valve,

all of these are possible. need to do a compression ck first. As you 
take out the plugs look at them one of them could be oil soaked. This 
would be the cylinder which has the problem.

If the compression is ok then start looking around for exterior oil 
leaks which may have looked like exhaust leak.

						mike 

- -- 
- --
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 21:25:09 -0600
From: ricp@ids.net (james stephenson)
Subject: Questions on 911 wheels 

I need some advice on 911 wheels!
I have been on the track a number of years with a 1972 911S having 6 inch
wheels and R type track tires, 205x60x15. Recently, I had a new 1989 Carrera
3.2 engine put in the car (250 hp), with a racing suspension ( ie heavy
torsion bars, sport shocks, and upper strut bearings with stress bar).
Therefore, I have been thinking of buying  7 or 8 inch wheels with maybe
225x50x15 in back and 205x50x15 in front. The wider wheels will cost me
$800. and another $600 to pull out the rear fenders. The shop which set up
my car said that wider tires are not really necessary, and my money would be
better spent on more suspension work. They also recommended that if I did
want wider tires, that I should buy 7" wheels with 205x50x15 on all four
wheels. But, I sort of think that wider back tires would be good if there is
enough space on the inside of the rear tires ( with the 205 tires now, there
is only 10 mm between the edge of the tire now and the oil lines ).
Therefore, I tried putting on a  8" wheel on the right rear with a 225x50x15
tire, and there seems to be plenty of inside room, with almost all the
larger width going to the outside of the car - sticking about 2" beyound the
fender, but about 1 inch below the fender lip. This really surprised me!  
Questions: (1) are all 1984-89 Carrera wheels made so that the extra width
goes to the outside (instead on inside)? (2) Am I safe that 225x50x15 rear
tires will not rub on the oil lines?  (3) Do I have to flare the rear
fenders, even though the botton of the fender is about 1 inch above the
tire, because of bouncing? (4) will the wider tires provide a substantial
advantage in traction? (5) Are the wider wheels worth the cost - $1,500.?    
I would appreciate your advice and experiences.  
James Stephenson
Rhode Island Capital Partners
115 Brisas, East Greenwich, RI 02818
Phone 401-885-4357 Fax 401-884-2255
E-Mail address: ricp@ids.net

Date: Sun, 26 Mar 95 21:55:43 CST
From: "David Kelly" <dkelly@iquest.com>
Subject: 928 Cargo (was 928 head/leg room...)


>Date: Sun, 26 Mar 1995 09:26:03 -0500 (EST)
>From: Scott S <CAMELJOCKEY@delphi.com>
>Subject: 928 head/leg room...
>
>
>My dad has an 85 928 and me, dad, and my brother all fll bewteen 5'11 and
>just a notch under 6'2" abd none of us had any trouble with 'driving' the car
>getting out of it some time took some acrobatics but never driving...
>
>safe to assume you  played around with the tilt of the seat?  bringing the
>front edge up and pushing the whole seat forward a bit, gave us all sorts of
room.
>
>try some strange seat positions to see what happens!
>
>scott s
>68 911L
>
>ps after putting the rear seats down in the 928 - I once managed to get 
>four card tables and thier accompanying chairs into the back!  Plenty of
>cargo space...

Yes, with the seat all the way down and the back tilted suitably to keep
my head from pressing against the roof, the seat has to come forward for
my hands to reach the steering wheel. At some point my knees contact the
dash. One solution might be to extend the steering column 1.5" or 2".

Never had any trouble getting in or out, unless I was climbing in upside
down to work under the dash.

I plan on pursuing the Porsche service bulletin on the subject, and also
(per Stan's suggestions) pull the seat and consider alterations there.

As for the carrying capacity of the car, its great! In 1993 when shopping
for casual transportation I wanted another hatchback. Really wanted another
4 dr VW Golf but they were not available for another 6 months.

My most memorable moment hauling things with my 928 came when I was asked
to drive a severely disabled friend & attendant home. Was handed the keys
to a Chevy Celebrity stationwagon. It was awful. Fortunately my 928 was
parked on the route so we stopped and figured out how to fit everything
in it. What passed for a wheelchair was folded and went in the front.
Attendant went in right rear seat, and a bed was made for my friend in
the rear. His head nearest the exhaust pipe. The next 45 miles I was
barraged with "how fast are we going?" 60 or 65. "So this is a Porsche?
That's all the faster it goes?". Got within a mile of his house and realized
this was the last opportunity so I didn't slow down when turning off 4 lanes
onto his road. Nice drift on that corner. Shifted down to 3rd and punched
it on exit from the corner. We stayed below 80 on a 2 lane country road with
good visibility but the engine was making wonderful music. Daryl screamed the
whole way, "Slow down! You're gonna get us killed!" We had a great time. Its 
been several years, but he still tells visitors about his ride in a Porsche, 
right up there with his ride in an airplane and trip to Niagara Falls.

- --
David Kelly N4HHE,   n4hhe@amsat.org,    dkelly@iquest.com

- -- the rest is overhead for the operating system.

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 10:01:07 +0100 (BST)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: re:K-Mart Quality

On Fri, 24 Mar 1995 Bob356@aol.com wrote:

> 
> The same goes for gasoline, with a caveat or two.  If you trail the
> common-carrier tankers filling up the underground tanks at your favorite

In the Uk recently there was a ho-ha about discount gas, and it became 
clear that the discount stuff was definitely inferior -

the discount shops ( our superstores ) were not putting in any of the 
detergent additives, with the consequence that valves wer getting badly 
fouled.

As soon as sales were effected, the discount shops started adding 
detergent. Whether the special additives are the same or as good is a 
matter of conjecture, but shell etc have no longer got the stick to beat 
them with.

I need to work on something else :-)

clutch into 1st and sometimes 2nd.   I'm going to replace the 1st
and 2nd gear synchros.  I have several questions:

1 - Is it possible to do this in a weekend assuming I have all the parts
    in hand before I start.  Including R&I ?

2 - I need a hydraulic press right ?  Or do I ?  This may sound dumb, but
    what exactly is a hydraulic press - ie is it something I can buy
    cheaply or is it like some big floor standing machine shop tool ?

3 - What parts typically will I need to replace.  1st and 2nd gear
    synchros, are the gears themselves usually worn to the point of
    needing replacement ?

    caveats are there with this mod ?  Are there other ratios available

    advertised, stock is 8.3:1 right ?) ?

Date: 27 Mar 95 09:46:41 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Forged vs. cast

 
Ron S asked about the unavailability of factory forged wheels for the 993.
 
That's right, they're all cast now. They are using a new process which they
claim makes them as strong as the old forged wheels. I'm not sure,
they may be vacuum cast like the 993 rear suspension members. This means you
don't get bubbles and voids and such to act as perfect little stress raisers.
 
If you are worried about the strength of the wheels, consider that 1) they
would have to be stronger to take the higher cornering loads made possible
by the 993 suspension and latest tire technology; 2) the German TUeV won't
allow substandard wheels onto the market; your registration becomes void if 
you put on non-TUeV approved, non-type-certified wheels etc.; 3) they are 
using the same technology for the 993 Turbo and the Carrera Cup cars which 
have even higher wheel loads. 4) in a world full of scumsucking lawyers 
Porsche won't take a backward, potentially suicidal step with something 
like wheel strength.
 
Then of course the're The T*d who swears that the only wheels worthy of the
name are BBS alloys, they're STRONG, man, you can bounce dem offa curbs and
dey won' crack. I think he's still trying to sell some T*d-tested wheels
(seems every tire he puts on them leaks; can't possibly be the wheels
though, they were straightened by a Real Good Shop).
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 27 Mar 95 09:46:38 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Passat pieces

 
Pat Garvey complained about cheap interior pieces in his VW.
 
Just out of curiosity, do you know if your Passat is Made in Chermanny or
Hecho en Mexico? If you can't find a "made in --- by proud craftsmen"
sticker, try the VIN number. If first three characters are something like
WVW, it's German.
 
You have to remember that at present, as far as we are concerned, VW is no
longer a German car company. Virtually all of their products for North
America are made in Mexico. (I had a Golf Cab a few weeks ago that was
German production, Karmann, but I think that's only because it's made by an
outside supplier anyway and Mexico can't do it yet.) VW has a much smaller
U.S. presence than it had 10 or 15 years ago. It's a tiny company, dealers
are going away, someday it may go the same route as Fiat and Peugeot in this
market.
 
Pete

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 10:27:47 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : Questions on 911 wheels

James Stephenson asked several questions on putting bigger wheels
and tires on a '72 S track car and flaring the rear.

> Recently, I had a new 1989 Carrera 3.2 engine put in the car (250 hp) 

This engine is heavier than your stock engine, so the car will not
be as well balanced with same size wheels on the rear. Stock, your car
had 40/60 weight distribution, now it is even worse. You can get better
handling with wider rear wheels AND tires. What did you do with
your old engine - want to sell it???

> Therefore, I have been thinking of buying  7 or 8 inch wheels with maybe
> 225x50x15 in back and 205x50x15 in front.

These should work OK. You may want to run 225/50/15 on the front
and 245/50/15 on the rear. They work great on 7x8 with SC type rear flares.
However, flaring the car will reduce it's value, as there are not many
2.4S left stock. I guess you could put stock flares back on at some point if
desired. You may also have to "roll" your front fender lip with the 
225/50 on 7" rims.

> The shop which set up my car said that wider tires are not really 
> necessary, and my money would be better spent on more suspension work. 

You mentioned that the suspension was already quite modified. The wider
tires and wheels would help even if your suspension was STOCK, more than
any suspension modifications. It sounds like the shop wants to make
more money from mods (they won't make any money if you buy wheels/tires
elsewhere). Tires and wheels are the most important part of your
car for performance (more than engine even).

> They also recommended that if I did want wider tires, that I should 
> buy 7" wheels with 205x50x15 on all four wheels. 

These may not even fit under stock rear flares. And you will have to make
the front of the car too stiff to get rid of the oversteer due to
too-small rear tire contact patch for the car. Does this shop have
a lot of track experience (winning cars)? Doesn't sound like it.

>Questions: (1) are all 1984-89 Carrera wheels made so that the extra width
>goes to the outside (instead on inside)? 

All 911 wheels except the early 911R 7x15 have this type of offset, with
the extra width on the outside. So the inside clearance should not be a
problem. The 7 and 8 by 15's you are looking for became available in
late '74 on the 2.7 Carrera, and later the Turbo and SC used them too.

>(2) Am I safe that 225x50x15 rear tires will not rub on the oil lines?  

Yes, even 245/50/15 will not rub if you use the factory offset. I used the
911R 7x15 offset on my '72 S and had slight oil line rubbing with
225/50/15 tires. I had to use a 1/4" spacer with the R offset (revolution) 
wheels. By the way, the revolution wheels are quite a bit heavier than 
the Fuchs forged alloys.

> (3) Do I have to flare the rear fenders, even though the bottom of the 
> fender is about 1 inch above the tire, because of bouncing? 

Probably.As the suspension works, the tire will come into contact with
the fender about 1" above the lip and bubble your paint (guess how I
know?).

>(4) will the wider tires provide a substantial
>advantage in traction? 

Yes, your car can not be correctly balanced (under/oversteer) with
the same size tires on all four wheels. Well, it can be balanced (I've
done it for staying within stock rules) but it will not be optimized.

>(5) Are the wider wheels worth the cost - $1,500.?    

Since your engine is modified, you might as well go to the limits of
the rules and flare your fenders and get some 7 and 8" wheels. You should
be able to find a set of used wheels for under $1000 in perfect working
condition. It is not a cost like tires- you will get your money back when
you sell the wheels in good condition. Think of them as an investment.

You should come to some of the Connecticut Valley autocrosses with
your car, I'd love to see it! I would be glad to help you set it up.

Regards, Mike Piera '72 911S (with 2 sets of 7 & 8 x 15 wheels which
won't even begin to fit under my stock fenders. But I do use the 7's)

P.S. I'll be in France most of this week w/o net access.


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 10:31:06 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: More 914 quirks...


Dear Rick,
You wrote:

<Doctor Doctor!
 <I recently gave Gretchin a thorough tuning and found that, after 
<replacing and optimizing all ignition components (New points made the 
<biggest difference) that she idled WAY too high.  I COMPLETELY closed the 
<idle screw and STILL it was too high.  My auxiliary air valve was not the 
<cause, it is working fine and plus I plugged it anyway to be sure.  I 
<still have a warm idle of 2300 RPM!
 <So I took my unlit propane torch and went over all the lines when 
<the car was running to see if I could detect a change in idle speed 
<indicating an air leak, ad nauseum (literally)  with no effect.  I can 
<turn the idle down by changing the points setting, but I trust the 
<dwell-meter settings at factory specs.  Is that wrong?  Then of course 
<there's that adjusting screw on the pressure sensor which I've never been 
<too sure of...  So I'm out of ideas here...
 <While we are on quirks, I just noticed yesterday that my steerin 
<wheel jerks on rare ocassion a bit, and I think I have localized the 
<problem to my left outer brake caliper, which seems to be rubbing against 
<the disk for some unknown reason.  The pads and disks are a year old and 
<in good shape, so I fear for my calipers.  I have sooo little time to 
>mess these days with my primary source of transportation that I was 
<wondering if someone might give me a clue as to what I'm getting into 
<before I try to take it all apart this weekend and find I need parts or 
<something.  Any guesses are welcome!  Thanks!
<Rick


You checked the obvious thing (the aux air valve) and the decel valve as
someone suggested, but the problem is the PCV valve hose (since you already
checked the vacuum system for leaks). It is probably sucking air through the
open PCV. This hose is connected to the right passenger side of the oil
filler. Simply pull it off, put your finger over the hose and the idle should
die down. Try it!

The sticking caliper can be a clogged flex hose or sticking caliper. These
are both easily diagnosed and repaired. Write for details.

George Hussey

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 95 10:19:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 911 SC Ring and Pinion Ratio/Tranny Rebuild


Martin,

>1 - Is it possible to do this in a weekend assuming I have all the parts
>    in hand before I start.  Including R&I ?

Sure.

>2 - I need a hydraulic press right ?  Or do I ?  This may sound dumb, but
>    what exactly is a hydraulic press - ie is it something I can buy
>    cheaply or is it like some big floor standing machine shop tool ?

It depends on what you have to replace.  If you have to push gears on
and off the two shafts, for example to replace their dog gears, yes,
you'll need one.  No idea what they cost or whether they can be rented.
It may also be that you can rent or buy a puller with a really long grip,
but I don't know.

>3 - What parts typically will I need to replace.  1st and 2nd gear
>    synchros, are the gears themselves usually worn to the point of
>    needing replacement ?

Typically synchros and, if you've been naughty, dog gears.   Sometimes
operating sleeves and other stuff.  You  probably don't want to invest in
all these parts on spec.  So you might want to plan on using one weekend
for tear-down, the week to order and receive what you need, and reassemble
the next weekend.

Hope this helps.

Kevin

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 10:55:08 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: Re:Passat pieces&Mexican VWs

Hello Peter and other Porschephiliacs,
	About the Passat, all of this model is produced in Germany along 
with the Golf Cabrio, Jetta GLX, Corrado(NLA?), and Eurovan.  Only the 
normal Golf, Jetta, and GTI come from Mehico.  I researched this 
thoroughly before advising my dad to get a '94 Passat GLX VR6(he loves it 
and seems to have high assembly quality. Maybe the other one was built on 
Monday?)  Its somehow hard for me to believe that someone in Mehico 
making $2.00 an hour would build a better car with as much care as 
someone making $24.00 an hour in Germany.  
	Unfortunately, the plain Golf and Jetta are the ones selling 
well.  It's too bad VW had to quit its US assembly at the time when its 
becoming fashionable for other makers.  The move to Mehico has been 
disastrous for them with poor assembly quality and numerous labor 
strikes.  I too would be surprised to see them here after five years.  
Our market would be much the less without them :^( 
Salut!
Jay Karolyi
'70 Corvair/914 (RUNS!!!, needs clutch cable...)
'77 924
'80 Toy 'rolla

Date: 27 Mar 95 11:09:27 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Re: 993 vs. Diablo

Hi, Jeff.
 
Gosh, somebody thinks I flamed you. (See previous post).
In case you feel warm, apologies and all
that. I flamed some of the cars you like, don't take it personally <g>. In
fact, if I managed to talk you out of ever getting a Viper, shouldn't I get
an unfinder's fee for the money and grief I saved you? Doesn't sound like I
succeeded though.
 
I wanted to express my opinions (I'm beginning to doubt of the existence of
non-mathematical fact in a modern universe) re test equipment, magazine test
procedures, atmospheric fudge factors for performance correction and how/why
magazines fudge on test equipment and Truth (or Fact, whatever that is).
 
Yes, C/D and SCI (used to; not any more) use the same equipment. I no longer
test for SCI (they "don't see the value of testing," and life's too short to
educate child editors), so SCI no longer has access to the equipment. I now
use my equipment for Autoweek and other clients among magazines
and industry. The third organization that uses the equipment (aside from
development departments at car companies) is Consumer Reports. Lord only
knows what THEY do with it. ("We drag strip test all the Earth Muffin Cars
- -- story on p. 87; sidebar: "Safety Fast -- the Amazing Wheelstanding CR
Volvo Wagon, p. 93...")
 
>I do recall seeing a picture of the Diablo with the fifth wheel hung off it
 
If it is the same equipment as I use, look carefully, there should not be
anything that remotely resembles a round wheel-like device touching the
ground. Just some black contraption that looks like some sort of rocket
launcher pointed down.
 
>Career dreams of becoming a car magazine photographer
 
Keep your day job.
 
The usual career path is something like
1) enthusiasm for cars, combined with good cameras, creativity, and
patience.
2) lots of car magazine work. The four big books pay OK. The
bikini-bimbo-by-pickup books don't pay, you almost have to pay THEM for the
privilege of seeing your work in print. And they capitalize on that.
Example: typical payment for 5-page feature, including writing and writer's
own photographs, $125. Most pros burn more than $125 in film and processing
alone for a single good big-book spread.
3) disgust with car magazines and looking for new outlets.
4) lots of advertising work, shooting cars. Advertising (or any sort of
commercial work) PAYS.
 
Look at Jeff Zwart. Started with R&T. Done good. Done so good that his
rates went so high R&T could only afford him to shoot good covers, and then
not at all. They hired his studio, and JZ would assign one of his staff to
do it. Did lots of advertising shots. Made big money. Bought big house in
Newport Beach. Turned to video format (car company TV commercials). Made more
money. Started rallying Porsche C4. Bought house in Aspen or someplace high
and cold and expensive. That's how it's done.
 
>C/D has been a long-time favorite.
 
Yeah. You need to go back to the really old C/D. Yates, Warren Weith, LJK
Setright (_I_ like him, nobody else this side of the Atlantic seems to
understand his sense of humor). David E. Davis way back when. Here, I'll
haul one out. December 72 (chosen at random). Pat Bedard before he whacked
the wall at Indy. William Jeanes. Don Sherman. Gordon Jennings. Photos and
art by Pete Biro and Ken Dallison. That's just from the masthead. These
people are legendary. I liked C/D's irreverence to balance R&T's
conservatism, and eagerly bought both. I grew up reading about the
Cannonball, Brock Yates' "Sunday Driver," Sam Posey's "Mudge Pond Express."
The 70s were a dismal era for car design, but the high point of automotive
publishing.
 
Thinking about R&T at the time, they had Henry Manney when he was still alive
and Stan Mott cartoons when he was still funny. Real editors like Dean
Batchelor and Tony Hogg and Jim Crow. Manney, Batchelor, Hogg and Crow have
all passed on.
 
Other long dead lamented magazines: Road Test. Sports Cars Illustrated (LONG
time ago, not the more recent Sports Car Illustrated --> Sports Car
International).
 
To correct myself in my earlier post to you (private? don't recall) re top
speed tracks:
Last night I talked to a friend who works in the R&D department of a large
Japanese car company. He thinks you could go 200+ at Honda/TRC in Ohio. I
remember seeing its hands-off speed at 130 mph or so. His company has an
even larger facility in Arizona where the hands-off speed through the turns
is 190ish.
 
Pete

Date: 27 Mar 95 11:09:32 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Don't race your 914/6

 
Jon Lowe points out that the factory would sell you a new body in white if
you gave them the serial number of a wrecked car.
 
I think you had to give them more than the serial number, you had to give
them the remains of the shell, but yeah, same idea. While I worked at
Porsche I came across a folded up shell of a 911 in the central courtyard of
Werk I. It had an airwaybill stuck to the roof, "Please deliver to Porsche
AG, Stuttgart, Germany." It came from Venezuela or someplace. I think the
hood and trunklids touched if you opened both of them. Anyway, that's what
they did, they shipped a new body in white, the owner put all the pieces
he'd removed back in, and Porsche crushed the old number. That way owner
also avoided import duty on a whole new car.
 
Pete

Date: 27 Mar 95 11:09:21 EST

Hi, Scott.
 
Gosh, I didn't mean to flame Jeff Kyle. I didn't call him any names, did I?
I did call some of his favorite cars some names but that's an occupational
hazard that comes of writing about cars. See next post. It is a good idea
not to confuse choice of car with personal character. It is therefore
possible to assassinate a car without actually damaging the owner. <g>
 
The whole idea of my post was just to point out that
1) don't believe everything you read;
2) fair is fair, you probably shouldn't even believe my posts, nor I yours
(or anybody else's);
3) car magazines lie. They aren't the New England Journal of Medicine (and
now some doctor should come in and say NEJM is a running dog lackey of the
Yankee imperialist capitalist pillmongers.)
 
Car magazines are "wish books." They do not need to print truth, or accurate
road tests, any more than Playboy needs to print accurate performance tests
of the Playmate of the Month. (Again, to quote that R&T editor, "it would
shatter all their dreams..."). Perhaps this is where my present attitude of
doubting everything in the universe comes from -- in high school, one of my
math teachers, Mr. Dogadalski, said "You guys all think that the world is
full of girls like the ones in Playboy. Let me tell ya, those photos are all
retouched." At which point some guy in the back yelled out "Yeah, every
night." But too late for humor, the damage had been done. My dreams were
shattered and I drifted off to cars, hoping to find Truth there... <g>
 
If you are going to nominate me for Flamer of the Year award, think twice.
That means I would have to turn pro. Then I couldn't just flame people
because I WANT to, I would have to have a work order, in triplicate, etc.
True, I could still flame people in my spare time, but it just wouldn't be
the same. (Oh, excuse me, did you sign up for the introductory 5 minute flame
or the full course of 30 sessions?) And a monthly retainer. And then I'd have
to try out for the big time, like Andy Rooney's job etc. (is he a flamer or
just a whiner? Not sure). And I'd have to measure myself against the true
Giants of Professional Flaming, like John Cleese.
 
Pete
