------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 11:18:47 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911 SC Ring and Pinion

Greetings:

Martin C. Walker writes:
<Well, now I have had a sound engine in the 911 for 7 months I've decided I
need to work on something else :-)
(text deleted)

I will try to answer your questions one at a time.

1.  Yes, but the problem here is knowing ahead of time just what parts you
need.  Normally this job involves more than just replacing the synchros
themselves.  Other wear items are the engagement dog rings on the gears,
 operating sleeves and occasionally bearings.

2.  Right.  You will also need a fixture to hold the shafts in the press as
you disassemble them.  A universal "bearing splitter will usually suffice if
it's large enough.  A press *is* a large floor standing shop tool which start
in price at about $300.00 for a discount tool store 12 ton model and go up
from there.  Probably not worth buying for 1 job.
You may also need special tools to replace the engagement dog rings, if
necessary and a deep (approx. 14") 41 mm socket to remove and install the
mainshaft nut.  Also a holding fixture for the mainshaft is necessary to
remove the nut.

3.  You will need a gasket set, 1st gear synchro band and a 2nd gear synchro
band.  There is also a small o-ring on the T.O. bearing guide tube which I
don't believe comes in the gasket set.  The P/N is 999.701.359.40.  In
addition, you may need a 1st gear engagement dog ring, a 2nd gear engagement
dog ring, a 1-2 gear operating sleeve, and possibly synchro bands on 3rd, 4th
and 5th gears as well.  Another thing to check for, especially if it's a high
mileage car, is for bearing indentations on the inside of each gearset where
it rolls on the bearing.  This will show up as verticle lines on the inner
race surface.  If you see this on a gear it's best to replace that gearset.
 This can cause not only noise, but the increased friction in that bearing
can cause excessive heat leading to eventual gear failure.  Gears themselves
do not normally wear out unless the trans has run out of gear lube.  If this
had occurred you would have more to worry about than weak synchros.  In
addition you will need 2 locking nuts, P/N 915.302.282.00 for the pinion
shaft and P/N 915.302.281.00 for the mainshaft.  These are one time use nuts
which should be replaced any time a 915 trans is disassembled.

4.  The 7:31 ring and pinion is a good conversion, especially with the
generally shorter gear ratios in the 8:31 gearboxes.  This however requires
special equipment and skill beyond the scope of most hobbyists and is best
left to a pro.  The setup of a ring and pinion is very critical and can't be
guessed at.

5.  This isn't an answer to a question, but this is also the time to pull the
T.O. bearing crosshaft out of the transmission housing so you can clean it up
and lube its bearings.  Also check the guide tube for wear and replace it if
necessary.  These are both contributors to stiff clutch operation.

Hope this helps and good luck with your project.

Pat Moyle

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 08:47:20 -0800
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Porsche vs. Lotus

Mike Piera continued a thread about Lotus Elans vs. Porsches.  I can't
resist following up on it.

I have an old photograph on my wall from a 1968 SCCA race held on the
parking lot at SD Jack Murphy Stadium (the last SCCA race meeting held
there, I think).  When the picture appeared in the local paper, I
ordered a copy.  It shows a single, privateer Lotus Elan leading a pack
of C-production factory supported cars.  Included were two 911S's
driven by Alan Johnson and Milt Minter, a team of Toyota 2000's, a team
of Datsun 2000's, and a few other similar cars.  The Elan went on to
win the race, to my delight.  I owned an Elan at the time.  I loved
that car, and didn't even have much trouble with it or the successor I
got a few years later when that one was totaled (the Lincoln it hit
probably went away with a dented hubcap).  That's one reason I no
longer have one.  I love my '72 T, but I'll always have a place in my
heart for Lotuses.

- --Walt Thode

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 95 11:13:27 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 951 Steering Racks, etc.

Short answer [just got back from exhausting vacation]:

I've been through this, and wouldn't recommend a rebuilt rack without a 
_damn_ good warranty (like 5 years).  I bought a rebuilt rack for 
around $250, and about 1.5 years & 5000 miles later it failed the same 
way, except catastrophically, dumping all power steering fluid during a 
track event.

I have been driving with the power steering pump disconnected since 
then - it's NO fun!  Shortly I'll be installing a new rack, purchased 
from someone other than PCNA though ($$$).

		Jim

- ----------

Date: 27 Mar 95 09:20:40 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Re: Questions on 911 wheels


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Re: Questions on 911 wheels
Date: 1995-03-27 11:11
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------


James,  You probably will get a bunch of replies on your wheel questions.
 Here's mine...

>3.2 engine put in the car (250 hp), with a racing suspension ( ie heavy
>torsion bars, sport shocks, and upper strut bearings with stress bar).

Having done this not too long ago myself and running the combination your
shop is recommending (7x15s w/ 225/50/15), I think your intuition about
wider rear wheels is right on in this case.  The power to contact patch
ratio is damn near dangerous the way you are currently set up (with 6s) and
not too much better with 7s.  Before I go on, I'd highly recommend a limited
slip in the differential if you haven't done so already -- I like my Quaife,
but other's are equally hooked on the factory ZF one (I think I could *kill*
a equally set-up ZF equipped car on a tight course (In My Humble Opinion
Alert here)).

>Questions: (1) are all 1984-89 Carrera wheels made so that the extra width
>goes to the outside (instead on inside)?

Yes.

>(2) Am I safe that 225x50x15 rear
>tires will not rub on the oil lines?

Yes, but this depends on *your* car and the wheel offsets, as well as the
tire you run (Yoko's w/ their softer sidewall, rubbed on my spring plates --
not the oil lines, whereas BFGs did not).

>(3) Do I have to flare the rear
>fenders, even though the botton of the fender is about 1 inch above the
>tire, because of bouncing?

To get anything bigger than a 7 on you do, and a 7 has to have a deeper
backset (more wheel inside than outside) -- 5 1/8" seems to do it fine for
most.

> (4) will the wider tires provide a substantial
>advantage in traction?

Absolutely, as will a ltd. slip.

>(5) Are the wider wheels worth the cost - $1,500.?

The SC or Carrera flares are nice looking and you can stuff a lot of wheel
underneath them.  I used 911 Turbo 9x16s with 245/45/16 on the rear (5 1/2"
backset) and standard offset fuchs 8x15s with 225/50/15 on the front, with
the only mods being SC flares in the rear and rolled fender lips in the
front -- Oh, and BFG R1s -- they don't flex much.  Real Turbo 9x16s are
getting verrry popular -- so you might want to have some HRE's made up in
the right offset -- might as well do the fronts too so they look the same.
 Price will be in the same $1500 range not including body work for flares
and bumper extension mods.

 -Scott Jessen '72 911 (now with 9x16F and 11x17R...)

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 09:25:24 -0800
From: Bill@bpetersen.com (Bill Petersen)

Bev,

Lori saying that she thought a 69 might be in the cards. I dunno, hard to
imagine someone pitting 4 seconds ahead of her...

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 09:29:50 -0800 (PST)
From: "Thomas B. Smith" <toms@comtch.iea.com>
Subject: Re: 911 SC Ring and Pinion Ratio/Tranny Rebuild

Martin-
After having done three of these things, I can probably answer your
question from the standpoint of a non-professional.

1. Can you do the repair in a weekend:  Maybe, if you have everything you 
will need at hand.  But it will be hard to Porschephiles #1276                         Mon Mar 27 13:37:18 CST 1995
know exactly what you will 
need until you get it opened up.  I would suggest a two weekend scenario,
one to get it out tear it down and order parts,  the next weekend to 
reassemble and replace.  This leaves out ring and pinion changes which 
complicate things greatly IMHO.  If you do this, you will need some very
expensive tools, or a lot of time, and gear marking compound, plus a 
shoebox full of shims.   

2. Do you need a hydraulic press:  I have done this without one,  but I   
would not reccommend it.  With gear pullers, hammers etc., it is possible,
but the possibility/probability of damage gets high.  A hydraulic press 
is a floor standing piece of equipment, at least it is if it is big 
enough to be usefull for what you want it for.  It will cost $250-350
for a Republic of China Special.  You will probably need about $200 in  
other tools,some of these can be home-made, but you might need some  
originals to copy.

3. What parts will you need to replace:  beside synchro's, maybe the 
dog-clutch rings and teeth, possibly some bearings.  It is not too likely
that any gears will need to be replaced, if the transmission has been 
well cared for.

4. As far as pitfalls, take very good notes upon teardown, label all of 
needle bearings and their races, keep carefull track of all of the detent 
parts. 

I know that this is not very detailed, but it may help you.  If you have 
any questions, let me know.

Regards

Tom Smith <toms@comtch.iea.com>

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 95 12:43:00 PST
From: Browning David <BrowningD@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: RE: Re:Passat pieces&Mexican VWs


     I think the newer/later Jetta GLX's are made in Mexico, too.  You can 
tell by the presence/absence of the emblem/hole cover for the european side 
marker lights by the door.  I drove a Golf III the other day.  To be honest, 
I was kinda dissapointed.  The clutch and shift action were vague to say the 
least.  Not much feel there at all.  (Although I drove a couple BMW's, which 
I didn't think had particularly good feedback either)  The interior was 
quite plasticky (if that's a word).  The seat was ackward, too.  Differect 
than VW's I've ridden in of years past.
     I fear that the Corrado and Passat may be the last excellent VW's you 
will be able to find for a while.  Although that 10yr/100Kmile powertrain 
warranty is awfully inviting.

David B.

Asad, Pumper fans out there,

If you have a web-browser, try the Porschephiles URL:

http://tta.com/Porschephiles/home.html

I just looked, and unfortunately, there is no FAQ for water-pumpers.  However, 
just being on the list is even better than having a FAQ, we have *lots* of 
dedicated Pumper fans.  Ask your questions to the list, and you'll get *Lots of 
helpful guidance.  (can't blame you for wanting a 911 though...) <vbg>

streets of Wiesbaden, in November, '64), a 928S or S4 was my *First* choice.

(heavy sigh...Life's a bitch, and then you die...)

All right.  I started this, I suppose.

Ok, so it's not for everybody.  If you want a lot of action scenes,
you'll be disappointed.

Jeff Kyle said,

> Yes, but it just seems that there's something wrong with packaging a $65K
> product, and spending only, hmm... 5%? 10%? of screen time on the product
> itself. If you're selling a car, show me the car, NOT other stuff.

You've just proven that you are not the target market for this video!

Neither am I, but I still liked it.   It's clear they are appealing to the
boomer crowd who is *probably not very knowledgable about Porsches*.
They are lookng to develop new interest from a crowd that probably has never
seriously considered a Porsche--not solidify existing support.

IMHO, forgiving the relative lack of action, it's a great piece of work
for the way it appeals to the subjective, emotional aspect of Porsche
Ownership.

YMMV.

Vol

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 95 10:39:44 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: painting 


Matt-

>I'm willing to personally do all the prep stuff I 
>can to keep costs down. 

If you do all the prep stuff, like stripping off the old paint, 
taking off the trim pieces, masking, repairing the small rusted 
spots, filling small imperfections with plastic filler and putty,  
and sanding, you're almost finished!  Why not do the rest 
yourself too?  Most of the cost of a good paint job is in the prep 
work, not the painting.  And none of it is hard.  It's just time 
consuming.  Your costs will be something like:

1) Stripper  -  2 gallons at $25/gal

2) Sanding blocks, sandpaper, filler, putty - $50

3) Primers, paint and thinners- cost depends on color and type 
 - $200 to $400 is a good guess

4) Wet sandpaper, rubbing and polishing compounds - $50

That's $500 or so.  If you can't borrow or rent a compressor, 
add
$350, and another $50 for a spray gun.  (You can get a very 
good gun for $40.  Let me know if you decide to go this route 
and I'll tell you which one.)

>Do I need to get this thing bead blasted?

Nope. Chemical stripper (see above) is messy but it works.  In 
fact, if the old paint isn't cracked or crazed or too thick, you 
can often get by with sanding it to rough it up, and then 
painting right over it.

>I would much rather paint it a darker color (like british racing 
>green)

If you go for a dark color, make sure your panels are all nice 
and straight.  Any imperfections show up like gangbusters 
with dark colors.

 -Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa  (painted in my driveway)


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 95 10:54:07 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 914/6s


Lest all of you think I just play with water-coolers, I have owned 
the 914/6s, one of which was a 914/6 GT. I race the living p*** out of 
them. Time-trials, autocrosses, etc. 

That's what the factory built them for. It was stated "The 914/4 will 
please most customers. The 914/6 is for the enthusiast who demands the
normal level of Porsche performance for competitive events." 1969
Porsche advertizing.

There were a handfull in the San Francisco area that were autocrossed.
Rick Ford, Bob Zulkowski, Myself, Troy Powell, Bernie Buschen, Darryl
Overstreet, Phil Mullen and a couple of others. We did well. In 1980
they shove Bernie Buschen and I in with the Corvettes. We finished 1-2
ahead of them in the local NCSCC series. Dave Colman ran his 914/6 in 
the SCCA series, also winning. Then there was the PCA Zone 7 series,
914/6 being the preferred car in the zone race tire classes. 

Mike Willis and many others competed in the same series with 914/4. They 
were quite successful.

If a 914/6 is solid, there's no reason not to play. 

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 12:35:47 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: 914 cam goes "negative"

        Sorry it took so long, but here's Dr914's answer to my
original query:

>Dear Dave,
>
>You found one of the reasons that it is critically important ot adjust valves
>on top dead center. If you have ever looked at the profile of the factory
>camshaft, it is such that it is actually slimmer on each side of top dead
>center. Hence, the increased clearance.
>
>George

        So yes, the cam does go "negative"!  I re-checked my adjustment,
and found it to be fine at TDC.  BTW, the factory book has a typo--they
tell you to adjust the valves 1-2-3-4, not 1-4-3-2!

- --DD

        "I used to have a life, but I sacrificed it to my car."
Dave Darling
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov                          914s Rule!

Date: 27 Mar 95 14:00:08 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 911 rocker panel stone guard

 
Hi, Afsar.
 
Try Wuerth SKS Stoneguard. It's a vinyl product, should be sprayed on (they
have a sprayer, $30ish, or use a 3M sprayer). Cleans up with water before it
hardens, lacquer thinner or similar after it hardens. It is available in
black (goes on purple gray, dries black), white, or beige, and is paintable.
You can thin it up to 20 percent for different (smoother) texture.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 27 Mar 95 14:00:14 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Sports Car Int'l 4 sale

For anybody who cares about the soap opera world of car magazine publishing:
 
I just got off the phone with a Highly Placed Unimpeachable Source. Sports
Car International is on the auction block. The magazine never made any money
for its new owner, Tom Toldrian, who also owns Excellence and a woodworking
magazine. Toldrian fired the editor who had made the magazine what it was,
Mark Ewing, and hired some kid who worked for a lower salary. The ad page
count kept dropping, the magazine got thinner and the articles were less
interesting for a broader base of readers. Now he just wants out from under.
 
When the original owner of SCI, a printer in the Chicago suburbs, wanted
out, I personally drove up to the Bay Area and got Toldrian interested in
acquiring SCI for his magazine "empire." I figured I did most of my testing
and writing for them, so if a new, friendly owner had it, my future as a
freelancer was assured. That worked, until he fired editor Mark Ewing.
Admittedly Ewing was difficult to get along with, but damn, he knew cars and
he knew car people and put together a beautiful book at the end. The new kid
thinks sports cars must be British, that's all he knows. He doesn't think
testing is important, and they go for the cheapest writers and shooters they
can find. When I stopped writing for Toldrian's magazines, I wished that he
would choke on the magazine that I talked him into buying.
 
I am now very happy to say that it is coming about. And it keeps my record
intact. If we didn't part on good terms, no boss has kept his job for more
than a year year after I left. What goes around etc.
 
One possibility is that Hachette (Road & Track, Car and Driver, Saddam
Hussein) may buy it for next to nothing, just to get its mailing mailing
list, and let it die.
 
This absolutely makes my day. I'm going to take some of Bart's yellow ones
and terrorize the freeway. After I call all the other disenchanted former SCI
contributors who have similar warm regards for Toldrian.
 
Pete

Subject: 1975 porsche 911- purchase help
Author:  porschephiles-request@tta.com at SMTPGATE
Date:    3/27/95 7:22 AM


Hi,

I'm looking to purchase a use porsche and have looked at a few and am 
tring to decide which one to get.  I found a 1971 911T with 146,000 
miles on it that is selling for $6,000 from a used car dealer.  The body 
etc seems to be in good shape, but there is a lot of oil all over the 
engine.  The dealer claims to have spent $800 on repairing rust under 
the car.  Is this a good deal?

I have also looked at a 1975 911 that was imported from Germany.  The 
owner says that the engine was replaced in 1979 in Germany and has 
33,000 miles on the replaced engine.  The car has a sportmatic tranny 
and the owner says that it clunks sometimes.  There is a lot of oil 
leaking and owner claims the main oil seal needs to be replaced at cost 
of $3,000.   The price is $5,000.  I like this car should I look at it 
some more?

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 95 11:44:39 PST
From: Tom Medeiros <tomm@hpsadqh.sr.hp.com>
Subject: What a weekend!

Well, we finally had a beautiful weekend here in Northern Ca.  Got to
take the car out for it's first long excursion.  Wife and self put
250 miles on it.  Went over to the Napa valley, took a few winding roads
and a few straights.  Opened it up and it really performed great.
Max speed 90 (safely), max rpm 4500.  Still only 300 miles on my rebuild.

Now for a couple of questions.  When first starting the engine, oil
pressure is about 5 to 6 bar at idle.  Once warm the pressure drops below 
2 bar at idle and barely reaches 4 to 5 at high rpm's.  Normal?

Second, the oil level gauge that had not been working, finally started to
work at the end of our drive.  At idle the gauge reads between 5 and 6 qts,
at 3 to 4k rpm, reads in red below lowest reading.  Again, Normal?
This last one has me worried, because even taking a level reading the
manual way (dipstick) with engine warm and running, I barely get a reading.

Anyway, I hope this weather keeps up.  I actually had the courage to drive
it to work today.  (No rear targa seal, but no clouds in the sky)

Tom '70 911T

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 14:50:45 -0500
From: David944@aol.com
Subject: Re: Water leaks & sticky door...

Richard writes

> First of all, when I first got it there was a lot of moisture in the back
under the hatch,
> making the carpet damp, etc. <long explanation of exact location deleted>.

I had the EXACT same problem with my 84 944, except over time it gets WORSE,
I could actually see the water streaming into my car <yuck>.  Had weather
stip replaced, no help.  Adjusted length of the cone-bolts that lock the
latch into place, no help.  Went to a glass installer, no help.  Went to the
dealer - "Oh, yeah we can fix it, should take 4 to 6 hours at $85 an hour",
yeah right, goodbye.  They did put me on the right track, saying the pattern
(indentation) that was left on the weather stipping indicated that the hatch
was not sitting correctly.

I spent some time with foam weather stripping adding pieces all over the
place.  I endid up 'building up' the weather stipping by inserting piecesof
 round weather stripping inside and under the exsisiting strip, starting 3"
from each corner, through the corner, and 3" up the side.  That was 2 years
ago, and walla, leak gone.  If this is a bit confusing, give me a call at 212
444-6300 (office), and I'll go over it again for you.

David944@aol.com
84 944 (preped and ready for my FIRST PCA Drivers ed THIS WEEKEND at The
Bridge!)

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 11:57:52 -0800 (PST)
From: Bob Walden <bwalden@aha.com>
Subject: Depressed

Howdy gang,

I have an 85.5 944, which I have owned since new.  It has ~94,000.  I
pulled it out of the garage, this weekend,  having stored it for the winter. 
I had changed all the fluids last fall, as a prep for storage.  I even 
started it every month during the winter, just to keep things lubed and 
to move it around just enough to prevent tire distortion.  Everything
looked fine each time a ran the car.  Per normal 944 aging, I have noticed
that as the car has gotten older, the water temp would fluctuate more widely, 
but never to either extreme.  I had plans to replace the radiator, and upgrade
the thermostat and fan switches per lower open/turn-on temps, this spring.  I
had the preverbial 944 water pump problems at about 28k miles, so I believe I 
have at least one generation of water pump upgrades.  At any rate, after a brief
warm-up, I took it out on the road.  What a great feeling...until the master
engine warning light started to flicker not a mile from my house.  Everything 
looked fine except the water temp.  By the time I got turned around, and back
to the house, the needle was at the bottom of the red mark.  I noticed smoke
from under the hood, so popped it.  I had assumed a hose, but nooooooooooo!!
The coolant tank was pretty much empty, and the smoke was oil leaking from
what looks like the bottom of the cam-shaft housing gasket(?) at the rear
of the valve cover assembly.  This leaking oil was dripping down on to the
exaust manifold.  SH*T.  No other leaking.  I pulled the dipstick, now thinking
loss of oil.  The color of the oil on the dipstick looks like chocolate milk.
SH*T again!!.  Anti-freeze and oil mixture??

Well, I am thinking right now that I have, best case scenario, a blown head(?)
gasket.  Worst case, a cracked block. 

I live in Moscow, Idaho.  Not exactly the Porsche service availablity spot of
the world.  Most all of the work ever done on my car, except basic service,
was done in Boise(300 miles south), by John Harris, a factory-trained, 
water-cooled Porsche specialist/expert.  While I could take it to him, I think
I would like to do the work myself.  I have a garage, a fairly good set of 
tools, the time and money.  Having reviewed what the `Haynes' manual provides,
I am thinking of buying the factory shop manuals, and starting the job.

A few questions first:

  1.  What is the general diagnosis of the above symptoms?
      
  2.  The Haynes manual says the head gasket can be replaced with the engine
      in the car.  I will be doing a compression check tonight, but with the
      high mileage, I would suspect that a partial engine rebuild might be 
      in order if I am going to go through the work of replacing the head
      gasket.  What other items should I consider replacing/reworking?  Valves,
      rings etc?

  3.  Besides the belt-tensioning sensitivity, what other tricky items are
      there to consider?

  4.  Does anyone know of a reliable mechanic in the Spokane, WA area?

  5.  Suspecting a cracked block, is magna-fluxing the best way to find
      the problem if it is not clearly visable?


Thanks in advance,

Bob W.

Date: 27 Mar 95 09:20:40 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Re: Questions on 911 wheels


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Re: Questions on 911 wheels
Date: 1995-03-27 11:11
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------


James,  You probably will get a bunch of replies on your wheel questions.
 Here's mine...

>3.2 engine put in the car (250 hp), with a racing suspension ( ie heavy
>torsion bars, sport shocks, and upper strut bearings with stress bar).

Having done this not too long ago myself and running the combination your
shop is recommending (7x15s w/ 225/50/15), I think your intuition about
wider rear wheels is right on in this case.  The power to contact patch
ratio is damn near dangerous the way you are currently set up (with 6s) and
not too much better with 7s.  Before I go on, I'd highly recommend a limited
slip in the differential if you haven't done so already -- I like my Quaife,
but other's are equally hooked on the factory ZF one (I think I could *kill*
a equally set-up ZF equipped car on a tight course (In My Humble Opinion
Alert here)).

>Questions: (1) are all 1984-89 Carrera wheels made so that the extra width
>goes to the outside (instead on inside)?

Yes.

>(2) Am I safe that 225x50x15 rear
>tires will not rub on the oil lines?

Yes, but this depends on *your* car and the wheel offsets, as well as the
tire you run (Yoko's w/ their softer sidewall, rubbed on my spring plates --
not the oil lines, whereas BFGs did not).

>(3) Do I have to flare the rear
>fenders, even though the botton of the fender is about 1 inch above the
>tire, because of bouncing?

To get anything bigger than a 7 on you do, and a 7 has to have a deeper
backset (more wheel inside than outside) -- 5 1/8" seems to do it fine for
most.

> (4) will the wider tires provide a substantial
>advantage in traction?

Absolutely, as will a ltd. slip.

>(5) Are the wider wheels worth the cost - $1,500.?

The SC or Carrera flares are nice looking and you can stuff a lot of wheel
underneath them.  I used 911 Turbo 9x16s with 245/45/16 on the rear (5 1/2"
backset) and standard offset fuchs 8x15s with 225/50/15 on the front, with
the only mods being SC flares in the rear and rolled fender lips in the
front -- Oh, and BFG R1s -- they don't flex much.  Real Turbo 9x16s are
getting verrry popular -- so you might want to have some HRE's made up in
the right offset -- might as well do the fronts too so they look the same.
 Price will be in the same $1500 range not including body work for flares
and bumper extension mods.

 -Scott Jessen '72 911 (now with 9x16F and 11x17R...)

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 09:29:50 -0800 (PST)
From: "Thomas B. Smith" <toms@comtch.iea.com>
Subject: Re: 911 SC Ring and Pinion Ratio/Tranny Rebuild

Martin-
After having done three of these things, I can probably answer your
question from the standpoint of a non-professional.

1. Can you do the repair in a weekend:  Maybe, if you have everything you 
will need at hand.  But it will be hard to know exactly what you will 
need until you get it opened up.  I would suggest a two weekend scenario,
one to get it out tear it down and order parts,  the next weekend to 
reassemble and replace.  This leaves out ring and pinion changes which 
complicate things greatly IMHO.  If you do this, you will need some very
expensive tools, or a lot of time, and gear marking compound, plus a 
shoebox full of shims.   

2. Do you need a hydraulic press:  I have done this without one,  but I   
would not reccommend it.  With gear pullers, hammers etc., it is possible,
but the possibility/probability of damage gets high.  A hydraulic press 
is a floor standing piece of equipment, at least it is if it is big 
enough to be usefull for what you want it for.  It will cost $250-350
for a Republic of China Special.  You will probably need about $200 in  
other tools,some of these can be home-made, but you might need some  
originals to copy.

3. What parts will you need to replace:  beside synchro's, maybe the 
dog-clutch rings and teeth, possibly some bearings.  It is not too likely
that any gears will need to be replaced, if the transmission has been 
well cared for.

4. As far as pitfalls, take very good notes upon teardown, label all of 
needle bearings and their races, keep carefull track of all of the detent 
parts. 

I know that this is not very detailed, but it may help you.  If you have 
any questions, let me know.

Regards

Tom Smith <toms@comtch.iea.com>

Asad, Pumper fans out there,

I just looked, and unfortunately, there is no FAQ for water-pumpers.  However, 
just being on the list is even better than having a FAQ, we have *lots* of

helpful guidance.  (can't blame you for wanting a 911 though...) <vbg>

(heavy sigh...Life's a bitch, and then you die...)

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 95 10:39:44 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: painting 


Matt-

>I'm willing to personally do all the prep stuff I 
>can to keep costs down. 

If you do all the prep stuff, like stripping off the old paint, 
taking off the trim pieces, masking, repairing the small rusted 
spots, filling small imperfections with plastic filler and putty,  
and sanding, you're almost finished!  Why not do the rest 
yourself too?  Most of the cost of a good paint job is in the prep 
work, not the painting.  And none of it is hard.  It's just time 
consuming.  Your costs will be something like:

1) Stripper  -  2 gallons at $25/gal

2) Sanding blocks, sandpaper, filler, putty - $50

3) Primers, paint and thinners- cost depends on color and type 
 - $200 to $400 is a good guess

4) Wet sandpaper, rubbing and polishing compounds - $50

That's $500 or so.  If you can't borrow or rent a compressor, 
add
$350, and another $50 for a spray gun.  (You can get a very 
good gun for $40.  Let me know if you decide to go this route 
and I'll tell you which one.)

>Do I need to get this thing bead blasted?

Nope. Chemical stripper (see above) is messy but it works.  In 
fact, if the old paint isn't cracked or crazed or too thick, you 
can often get by with sanding it to rough it up, and then 
painting right over it.

>I would much rather paint it a darker color (like british racing 
>green)

If you go for a dark color, make sure your panels are all nice 
and straight.  Any imperfections show up like gangbusters 
with dark colors.

 -Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa  (painted in my driveway)


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 95 10:54:07 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 914/6s


Lest all of you think I just play with water-coolers, I have owned 
the 914/6s, one of which was a 914/6 GT. I race the living p*** out of 
them. Time-trials, autocrosses, etc. 

That's what the factory built them for. It was stated "The 914/4 will 
please most customers. The 914/6 is for the enthusiast who demands the
normal level of Porsche performance for competitive events." 1969
Porsche advertizing.

There were a handfull in the San Francisco area that were autocrossed.
Rick Ford, Bob Zulkowski, Myself, Troy Powell, Bernie Buschen, Darryl
Overstreet, Phil Mullen and a couple of others. We did well. In 1980
they shove Bernie Buschen and I in with the Corvettes. We finished 1-2
ahead of them in the local NCSCC series. Dave Colman ran his 914/6 in 
the SCCA series, also winning. Then there was the PCA Zone 7 series,
914/6 being the preferred car in the zone race tire classes. 

Mike Willis and many others competed in the same series with 914/4. They 
were quite successful.

If a 914/6 is solid, there's no reason not to play. 

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 12:35:47 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: 914 cam goes "negative"

        Sorry it took so long, but here's Dr914's answer to my
original query:

>Dear Dave,
>
>You found one of the reasons that it is critically important ot adjust valves
>on top dead center. If you have ever looked at the profile of the factory
>camshaft, it is such that it is actually slimmer on each side of top dead
>center. Hence, the increased clearance.
>
>George

        So yes, the cam does go "negative"!  I re-checked my adjustment,
and found it to be fine at TDC.  BTW, the factory book has a typo--they
tell you to adjust the valves 1-2-3-4, not 1-4-3-2!

- --DD

        "I used to have a life, but I sacrificed it to my car."
Dave Darling
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov                          914s Rule!

Date: 27 Mar 95 14:00:08 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 911 rocker panel stone guard

 
Hi, Afsar.
 
Try Wuerth SKS Stoneguard. It's a vinyl product, should be sprayed on (they
have a sprayer, $30ish, or use a 3M sprayer). Cleans up with water before it
hardens, lacquer thinner or similar after it hardens. It is available in
black (goes on purple gray, dries black), white, or beige, and is paintable.
You can thin it up to 20 percent for different (smoother) texture.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 27 Mar 95 14:00:14 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Sports Car Int'l 4 sale

For anybody who cares about the soap opera world of car magazine publishing:
 
I just got off the phone with a Highly Placed Unimpeachable Source. Sports
Car International is on the auction block. The magazine never made any money
for its new owner, Tom Toldrian, who also owns Excellence and a woodworking
magazine. Toldrian fired the editor who had made the magazine what it was,
Mark Ewing, and hired some kid who worked for a lower salary. The ad page
count kept dropping, the magazine got thinner and the articles were less
interesting for a broader base of readers. Now he just wants out from under.
 
When the original owner of SCI, a printer in the Chicago suburbs, wanted
out, I personally drove up to the Bay Area and got Toldrian interested in
acquiring SCI for his magazine "empire." I figured I did most of my testing
and writing for them, so if a new, friendly owner had it, my future as a
freelancer was assured. That worked, until he fired editor Mark Ewing.
Admittedly Ewing was difficult to get along with, but damn, he knew cars and
he knew car people and put together a beautiful book at the end. The new kid
thinks sports cars must be British, that's all he knows. He doesn't think
testing is important, and they go for the cheapest writers and shooters they
can find. When I stopped writing for Toldrian's magazines, I wished that he
would choke on the magazine that I talked him into buying.
 
I am now very happy to say that it is coming about. And it keeps my record
intact. If we didn't part on good terms, no boss has kept his job for more
than a year year after I left. What goes around etc.
 
One possibility is that Hachette (Road & Track, Car and Driver, Saddam
Hussein) may buy it for next to nothing, just to get its mailing mailing
list, and let it die.
 
This absolutely makes my day. I'm going to take some of Bart's yellow ones
and terrorize the freeway. After I call all the other disenchanted former SCI
contributors who have similar warm regards for Toldrian.
 
Pete

Subject: 1975 porsche 911- purchase help
Author:  porschephiles-request@tta.com at SMTPGATE
Date:    3/27/95 7:22 AM


Hi,

I'm looking to purchase a use porsche and have looked at a few and am 
tring to decide which one to get.  I found a 1971 911T with 146,000 
miles on it that is selling for $6,000 from a used car dealer.  The body 
etc seems to be in good shape, but there is a lot of oil all over the 
engine.  The dealer claims to have spent $800 on repairing rust under 
the car.  Is this a good deal?

I have also looked at a 1975 911 that was imported from Germany.  The 
owner says that the engine was replaced in 1979 in Germany and has 
33,000 miles on the replaced engine.  The car has a sportmatic tranny 
and the owner says that it clunks sometimes.  There is a lot of oil 
leaking and owner claims the main oil seal needs to be replaced at cost 
of $3,000.   The price is $5,000.  I like this car should I look at it 
some more?

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 95 11:44:39 PST
From: Tom Medeiros <tomm@hpsadqh.sr.hp.com>
Subject: What a weekend!

Well, we finally had a beautiful weekend here in Northern Ca.  Got to
take the car out for it's first long excursion.  Wife and self put
250 miles on it.  Went over to the Napa valley, took a few winding roads
and a few straights.  Opened it up and it really performed great.
Max speed 90 (safely), max rpm 4500.  Still only 300 miles on my rebuild.

Now for a couple of questions.  When first starting the engine, oil
pressure is about 5 to 6 bar at idle.  Once warm the pressure drops below 
2 bar at idle and barely reaches 4 to 5 at high rpm's.  Normal?

Second, the oil level gauge that had not been working, finally started to
work at the end of our drive.  At idle the gauge reads between 5 and 6 qts,
at 3 to 4k rpm, reads in red below lowest reading.  Again, Normal?
This last one has me worried, because even taking a level reading the
manual way (dipstick) with engine warm and running, I barely get a reading.

Anyway, I hope this weather keeps up.  I actually had the courage to drive
it to work today.  (No rear targa seal, but no clouds in the sky)

Tom '70 911T

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 14:50:45 -0500
From: David944@aol.com
Subject: Re: Water leaks & sticky door...

Richard writes

> First of all, when I first got it there was a lot of moisture in the back
under the hatch,
> making the carpet damp, etc. <long explanation of exact location deleted>.

I had the EXACT same problem with my 84 944, except over time it gets WORSE,
I could actually see the water streaming into my car <yuck>.  Had weather
stip replaced, no help.  Adjusted length of the cone-bolts that lock the
latch into place, no help.  Went to a glass installer, no help.  Went to the
dealer - "Oh, yeah we can fix it, should take 4 to 6 hours at $85 an hour",
yeah right, goodbye.  They did put me on the right track, saying the pattern
(indentation) that was left on the weather stipping indicated that the hatch
was not sitting correctly.

I spent some time with foam weather stripping adding pieces all over the
place.  I endid up 'building up' the weather stipping by inserting piecesof
 round weather stripping inside and under the exsisiting strip, starting 3"
from each corner, through the corner, and 3" up the side.  That was 2 years
ago, and walla, leak gone.  If this is a bit confusing, give me a call at 212
444-6300 (office), and I'll go over it again for you.

David944@aol.com
84 944 (preped and ready for my FIRST PCA Drivers ed THIS WEEKEND at The
Bridge!)

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 11:57:52 -0800 (PST)
From: Bob Walden <bwalden@aha.com>
Subject: Depressed

Howdy gang,

I have an 85.5 944, which I have owned since new.  It has ~94,000.  I
pulled it out of the garage, this weekend,  having stored it for the winter. 
I had changed all the fluids last fall, as a prep for storage.  I even 
started it every month during the winter, just to keep things lubed and 
to move it around just enough to prevent tire distortion.  Everything
looked fine each time a ran the car.  Per normal 944 aging, I have noticed
that as the car has gotten older, the water temp would fluctuate more widely, 
but never to either extreme.  I had plans to replace the radiator, and upgrade
the thermostat and fan switches per lower open/turn-on temps, this spring.  I
had the preverbial 944 water pump problems at about 28k miles, so I believe I 
have at least one generation of water pump upgrades.  At any rate, after a brief
warm-up, I took it out on the road.  What a great feeling...until the master
engine warning light started to flicker not a mile from my house.  Everything 
looked fine except the water temp.  By the time I got turned around, and back
to the house, the needle was at the bottom of the red mark.  I noticed smoke
from under the hood, so popped it.  I had assumed a hose, but nooooooooooo!!
The coolant tank was pretty much empty, and the smoke was oil leaking from
what looks like the bottom of the cam-shaft housing gasket(?) at the rear
of the valve cover assembly.  This leaking oil was dripping down on to the
exaust manifold.  SH*T.  No other leaking.  I pulled the dipstick, now thinking
loss of oil.  The color of the oil on the dipstick looks like chocolate milk.
SH*T again!!.  Anti-freeze and oil mixture??

Well, I am thinking right now that I have, best case scenario, a blown head(?)
gasket.  Worst case, a cracked block. 

I live in Moscow, Idaho.  Not exactly the Porsche service availablity spot of
the world.  Most all of the work ever done on my car, except basic service,
was done in Boise(300 miles south), by John Harris, a factory-trained, 
water-cooled Porsche specialist/expert.  While I could take it to him, I think
I would like to do the work myself.  I have a garage, a fairly good set of 
tools, the time and money.  Having reviewed what the `Haynes' manual provides,
I am thinking of buying the factory shop manuals, and starting the job.

A few questions first:

  1.  What is the general diagnosis of the above symptoms?
      
  2.  The Haynes manual says the head gasket can be replaced with the engine
      in the car.  I will be doing a compression check tonight, but with the
      high mileage, I would suspect that a partial engine rebuild might be 
      in order if I am going to go through the work of replacing the head
      gasket.  What other items should I consider replacing/reworking?  Valves,
      rings etc?

  3.  Besides the belt-tensioning sensitivity, what other tricky items are
      there to consider?

  4.  Does anyone know of a reliable mechanic in the Spokane, WA area?

  5.  Suspecting a cracked block, is magna-fluxing the best way to find
      the problem if it is not clearly visable?


Thanks in advance,

Bob W.

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 95 12:17:20 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re:  What a weekend!

Tom-

Glad it's working so well.  I'm at about 300 miles too,
but haven't pushed it beyond 65 and about 4000.  I'm 
sneaking up on it...

About the oil level.  When I filled it up after the rebuild
with the specified amount of oil, my gauge didn't read either,
and the dip stick reading was as you describe, with barely
a reading.  I asked around, even asked Bruce Anderson, if the 
factory spec oil capacity could be wrong.  No one knew, although
Bruce did say that a new engine requires a bit more oil than
a normal refill.  I knew that too, but it looked like I would
need 2 quarts or so more, and that's a lot of oil to be hanging\
around in the sump or oil filter.  Anyway, I decided the dipstick
was the thing to go by, and kept adding oil till the reading
was right in the middle.  At that point, the gauge started to
read right too.  

I have the figures at home (am at work now) but I'm pretty sure
I added 2.5 quarts more than the specified 8.5.  (My car, the
'72, is unique in that it's capacity is lower than other years.)
When I do the 500 mile oil change, I plan to measure how much comes out.
Wonder if it'll be 8.5.  Anyway, I feel a lot better with a
proper dipstick reading, and if I were you, I'd add oil.

The gauge, BTW, will only begin to read properly when the oil
is all warmed up and fully expanded.

Your pressure readings are about the same as mine.  Apparently
they're normal.

 -Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 16:17:42 -0500 (EST)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: Paint

Excerpts from mail: 27-Mar-95 Paint by AHUSAIN@schmed01.ab.umd. 
> What about the dust that gets in the paint?  I had my car repainted at 
> MAACO after I did all the prep and they still managed to do a lousy 
> job.  Overspray everywhere and the amount of dust inthe paint was 
> really bad.  I'm assuming that if a paint shop has dust and other 
> problems, painting in the driveway will be worse.  
>  
> Comments, Advice

    Probably not.  I just painted my roommate's car in my driveway last
year.  Of course, it was a '78 Impala, so he didn't care much. But he
was very happy with the results, most of the problems that arose were
because I was using metallic paint (watch those stripes!  Makes it hard
to make the finish "flow" - the metallic part starts to run long before
the paint does.) and because I was using a cheap spray gun (there's one
drip from the spray gun on the back fender - doh!)
    If you stick to solid color paint and use a good gun, should be no
problem.  Do it in the morning, right after the mist rises.  Use a tack
rag to get the dust off.  Make sure you're using the proper reducer for
the temperature you're spraying in.  Practice first, too...

good luck,

Nate

PS- I have had good results with catalyzed acrylic enamel from both PPG
and some other company that I forget... if we're talking p-cars here,
you might want to go with Sikkens or something like that.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 13:23:31 -0800 (PST)
From: stevew@tamri.com (Steve Watson)
Subject: '73 911 Gas Fumes

I've noticed lately that there are strong gas fumes inside my 911 while 
driving.  Anyone know where to start looking for leaks?  Is there a gas
line going through the inside of the interior tunnel?

Steve
"73 911S Targa



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 16:26:43 -0500 (EST)
From: RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu
Subject: Re: depressed

Bob,
	No need to feel depressed, at least your valves are still all likely to be 
straight!
	The job you describe is best attacked from the top, i.e. with the motor in 
the car.  The gasket set you will need can be obtained from Rodd Sydney in El 
Paso, Texas who is a *REALLY* good source for genuine parts for about $110 I 
believe.  His number is 1-800-590-7770.
	Start by removing intake manifold and exhaust manifold, and fight with the 
allen bolts that hold the valve casing on, all as per Haynes.  The head comes off 
very easily, make sure you follow the correct loosening procedure to avoid warpage.
	You will then be in a much better position to evaluate the necessity for a 
major overhaul.  Make sure that before you rebuild, you do lap in all the valves 
and put new valve seals on, as well as replace the camshaft seals.
	My guess is that you have a blown head gasket, and if the whole thing 
didn't get too hot you may not have warped the head.

Happy spannering,   Jan

------------------------------

	Steve -

	took it for a fill-up, the gas just started running 
	over the tank, under the car, and all over the trunk.
	What a mess! Replaced the seal - fixed it. It's a cheap
	fix too.

gas smell in my 73 by the use of a smog testing apparatus(sp?) to the
fuel vapor condenser just under the windshield in the front compartment in
front of the driver.  It had a nice crack in it.  I can fwd you the exact
part if you like.

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 14:02 -0800 (PST)
From: Robert_Yasek@NOTES.YMP.GOV
Subject: Re: '73 911 Gas Fumes


  Hey Steve,

  In my '73 911T, I too was getting some strong gas fumes.
  What it turned out to be was a fuel line in the area behind
  the instrument panel (it was actually in the trunk, but up
  close to the instruments) The old fuel line (about 3/4 or so
  OD plastic/vinyl material) had gotten old, yellow and had
  shrunk and was coming off the connection. It was an easy
  repair and the smell has not come back in the 3 years since.
  Another thing that convinced me to regularly check the
  condition of all lines, fuel and otherwise.

  Regards,

  Rob Yasek
  '73 911T
  '91 Bixby Noodlehead

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 05:38:47 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: painting

Matt, 

Do all the prep work yourself as others have suggested.  It is the most time 
consuming and labor intesive part of the operation, and therefore the most 
costly to have done.  I also once had a car painted at MAACO, BAD IDEA!  The 
finish was so bad and so full of dust and sanding debris that I refused to 
accept the car.  The owner agreed to repaint the car in order to fix the 
imperfections.  

Be warned that you *could* easily end up with a contaminated finish (dust, 
pollen, bugs, etc.) by painting a car outdoors.  Keep in mind that 
old-fashioned laquer paint has a very short "open" time (wet paint) after 
sprayed which will minimize any possibility of contamination.  A laquer job 
requires many coats, more work, hand polishing, and is generally much less 
durable.  The newer enamels and Urethanes, on the other hand, have much 
greater open times, but they only require a single coat and no major 
polishing.  Enamels or Urethanes, however, are the way to go for durability.

IMHO, if you want the best finish for the least $$$, do all the prep 
yourself, and then contract with a *reputable* paint/body shop to "shoot" 
the car for you in their **spray-booth**.  If you do paint the car yourself, 
at least do it in a garage that has been *thoroughally* cleaned (de-dusted) 
and the walls have been covered with poly to protect from overspray.  

Good Luck!
Andy

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 18:16:17 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: Corvair/914 Lives!!! first drive...?s

Add another Porsche to the "running" list,
	The Corvair powered 914 I rescued from the junkyard is on the road!
All it needed was a clutch cable.  The engine fired up after I siphoned the 
old nasty fuel out of the tank and put in fresh BP 93, cleaned the plugs& 
electrical contacts, and sprayed carb cleaner/starter in all 4 (yes 4!) 
carbs.  Man is this thing LOUD!!! I made sure there were no exhaust 
leaks, but its basically a straight pipe.  Smoked a bunch at first too, 
but that soon cleared (put new 20W oil in).  
	I turned all 4 discs and flushed the system, and they work but 
the master cylinder needs rebuilt.  The carbs need it too no doubt, it'l 
be fun to rebuild all 4 :^)  It was funny driving as I could feel the 
surge in power when they kicked in one by one!  I also put in new trans 
oil and the 901 shifts OK if still a bit stiff.  The shocks were rusted 
shut so it took a few leaps over RR tracks to free them up.  I greased 
the bearings and CVs so it would roll better.  The tires are badly 
rotted, even "Tire in a Can" can't keep air in them, but they lasted for 
my test ride.  
	Oh, did I mention?  This thing has POWER!!!  The guy who built 
this thing was serious, I think it was meant to be a track car(straight 
exhaust, WIDE wheels, etc.)  Handling felt as good as my 924, but the 
body flexes something awful(rust).  I lost another fender flare going into a 
pothole, but it survived unscathed.  Rust was FLYING off this car as I 
rocketed over the bumps on a lonely back road(I didn't bother to license 
or insure it yet).  I still can't get over the power this thing has, why 
haven't more people done this conversion?  I bet its just as fast as a 
914/6!  It really goes!  
	Questions...Will the 901 tranny smooth out with regular use?  How 
do you tell what kind of carbs it has, all I see are numbers?  Is this 
thing worth swapping into another body?
Thanx for any help...
Jay Karolyi
'70 Corvair/914 It's alive...It's alive!
'77 924 (needs power like my 914!)
'80 Toy 'rolla w/ bumper sticker "My Other Car Is A Porsche" -2 to be exact!

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 18:24:36 -0500 (EST)
From: Tomkow <tomkow@nando.net>
Subject: Re: Charging problem



On Mon, 27 Mar 1995, Michael Lo wrote:

> I have a problem with the charging system of my 86 911.  The battery light
> on the dash
> does not come on any more when the ignition is in the ON position.  The
> battery is showing 12.4Volts regardless of if the car is running or not.
> Any help would be greatly appreciated.
> 
> Mike
> 86 Carrera.
> 
> 
Hi Mike,
   If the charging system on your '86 is the same as my '84, nothing 
short of a new alternator will cure it.  A Porsche mechanic 
friend diagnosed my problem as a burnt out diode (at least one).  The 
factory alternator stickered at over $800.00!  He said he could discount 
about $50.00 to me, but I couldn't stomach that either.  I found an ad 
for Vertex (305.442.2727) where they were selling rebuilt units for $160.00.
There is an $80.00 core charge above that.  Installed it myself and it 
has been running strong for over a year now!  

Good Luck!

 -Bill Tomko

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 18:45:36 -0500 (EST)
From: guy.allen@sdrc.com (Guy Allen)
Subject: Rebuilding brake calipers (914/6)


Well, trying to get the 914/6 running again this spring I discovered that
at least a couple of calipers were sticking, so I decided to embark on
a great brake caliper rebuild adventure, and go though all 4 calipers.

Oh boy.

The previous owner (Hi Jim!) had replaced the rears with 911SC front
calipers because of the rarity of the original parts.  The good news
is that I can find parts and rebuild the replacements, the bad news is
that I don't have any parking brakes.  (I keep a 4x4 behind the
drivers seat for emergency use... 8-))

I got the first one off the car (right rear), and tried to get the
pistons out using the accumulated wisdom of porschefiles, first with
air, then by putting the caliper back on the car with no brake pads
and pumping the brake.  The later got the pistons to move, but when I
got them off the car again I *still* couldn't get them out of the
caliper. I thought to then connect to the brake line without the brake
disk involved and get at least one of them out. But then, caught up by
the Red Mist that descends when Things Don't Work The Way They're
Supposed To I did something I had promised my self I wouldn't do.  

I took pliers wrapped in a shop towel to the caliper, and tried to
move it.

The result, which should be no suprise to anyone who has had to free a
stubborn caliper piston, is a small paper weight the size and shape of
a caliper piston.  This one can't even be used as a paper weight at
the moment, as that it is rather firmly ensconced in a brake caliper
for which I have other purposes.  Sigh.

So, I guess I'd like some advice:

   Can I get replacement pistons?  Where?

   Is there a more appropriate caliper to use that is available?
   (besides having no parking brake, these require some washers to get
    things to line up)

   Is there some magic elixir to set my pistons free?  Torch?  Dynamite?

   More hydraulic pressure should get one of the two pistons out, what
   about the other one?  After one is out there's no way to generate any
   pressure on the one remaining. 

   Is there some way to paint calipers that will survive? (other that
   powder coating or the like)

   Anybody know any body shops that really *know* 914s in southwestern
   Ohio?  (car has never seen salt, but was a victim of a mediocre
   paint job earlier in its life)


I'd really like to get to some autocrosses this season (just sent my check
into PCA), but first first I have to get the brakes back working.

TIA

guy allen   guy.allen@sdrc.com
70 914/6  (ice green over original silver, minus one brake caliper)
3 assorted volkswagens
3 cats in house
2 cats in garage (hey, get offa my car!)
1 wife

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 19:14:10 -0500
From: BUBBAUSA@aol.com
Subject: Re: Rebuilding brake calipers (914/6)

I have successfully removed waaay stuck pistons on 356 C calipers with a
greasegun.
Find an old bridge pipe, cut of one end,  braze to a fitting that will mate
it to your handpump greasegun.  Take your good bridge pipe off, insert your
custom made bridgepipe-grease fitting, tighten,and pump away for inside
piston (on the inside piston you may have to plug the hole where your brake
hose would normally connect; a correct thread & pitch bolt works fine);  for
outside piston, insert custom tool into place where bridgepipe was & pump
away.  Make sure bleeder valves are secure.  As the caliper half fills with
grease it WILL pop the offending pistons out...but it leaves a mess to clean
out....but what they heck, you were going to clean everything out before you
went back together with new stuff...right?
Good Luck.
George
50 Cpe
57 GS S/R Cpe
61 Roadster
65 C Cab

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 19:15:05 -0500 (EST)
From: Frequently Frustrated! <quartz@minerva.cis.yale.edu>
Subject: Re: More 914 quirks...

Thanks to Dr. 914 and others for your input.  Unfortunately by pulling 
off the PCV hose the engine REALLY raced, that was clearly not the 
problem.  I really did check everything for air leaks I think.  Maybe I 
overlooked an injector seal or something and should go over them all again...
	As for the caliper problem, taking it apart made things quite 
clear.  I took the wheel and calipers and disk off and lo and behold, 
teeny little cylinders came rolling out, my outer bearing was shot- 
the cage disintegrated.  The resulting wobble caused the rubbing.  What's 
troubling is that I replaced those bearings only a year or so ago, did I 
put in a bad part or do something wrong?  I used the right grease...and 
the other bearing was perfect yet...Ideas?
	Thanks again!    Rick -n- racing Gretchin

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 18:25:54 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Rebuilding brake calipers (914/6)

> I have successfully removed waaay stuck pistons on 356 C calipers with a
> greasegun.

When people first started talking about how hard it was to get pistons
out of calipers, I thought "yeah, right. wimps" Then after The Brake Job 
From Hell (see archives, about Dec 94 or so), when I *broke* a couple of 
pistons extracting them, I somewhat modified my views. 

Hearing about this grease gun technique was another of those "yeah, right"
sort of things. Then last week when I had occassion to buy a new grease
gun for the first time in about 15 years, I was reading the instructions
thinking "oh, right -- like *I'm* going to learn something", when I'll
be damned if I *DIDN'T* learn something. Your average grease gun apparently
puts out 50,000 PSI of pressure. Think about it. That should move
those stubborn pistons! 

Thanks to whoever first suggested this. I haven't done it yet, but I'm i
officially a believer now...

Stan

Porschephiles #1278                         Tue Mar 28 02:00:17 CST 1995
Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 20:16:40 -0500
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: 993 turbo wheels (was Forged vs. cast)

Hi all,

There was a little discussion on whether forged or cast wheels are better and
Pete mentioned that the new turbo wheels are cast like the regular 993
wheels. I don't believe that that's right. The new turbo wheels, according to
the French Christophorus of 2/95, are rather exotic.  The 5 spokes are hollow
and made out of some special forged aluminum alloy which permit a weight
savings of around 3kg (7.5lbs) per wheel. BTW, the fronts are 8 x 18 and the
rears 10 x 18.  They are also the first wheels for production cars to be
friction welded, or as written in French  "soudage par friction." My
technical French isn't that good so if somebody wants to explain what it is
please tell me. 

The article also goes on to explain the Porsche engineers used weight saving
materials in other areas to increase performance as well as fuel economy.
 Great car.

Neil Kumpers
'73 911s targa

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 95 17:54:14 PST
From: pat@ixi.saic.com (Pat Norris)
Subject: Re:  DIY Paint jobs

Other stuff deleted...
>> 
>> Painted in your driveway?  To me, this is a big factor in painting
>> a vehicle yourself.  Where to do it??  I painted my '73 Opel GT by 
>> myself, so I realize it is not an impossible task, and my Urban
>> Assault Vehicle ('87 Toyota 4Runner with big mud tires) needs
>> paint badly.  If I could paint it myself, buying the tools and 
>> everything, for about the cost of a paint job at a shop, I would
>> rather have a paint job and the compressor, paint equip, etc than
>> just a paint job...
>> 
>> Mike Dayton
>> '76 Euro 911
>> 

Actually, what I've done was to use drop cloths (the plastic kind),
duct tape, a staple gun, and a fan for ventilation to build a "paint
booth" in my garage.  The real trick was to add enough lights around 
to see what you're doing!  For the equipment, my dad had it all (ok,
so the spray gun was a xmas gift from me a few years back, but he
_was_ thinking of painting his truck at the time...8-) ), so I didn't
end up with a compressor, but that allowed for a little higher quality
paint.   The only place I wasn't really happy with the finished job on
my 914 was the inside side of the front fenders right next to the turn
indicators.  You see them, but you don't think about getting a good
angle on those; the targa bar, you think about a lot.

The paint job wasn't perfect, but for <$170 it wasn't bad (well, there
are some on the list who have actually seen the car...), but I am the
owner. 8-)

Pat

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 12:06:08 +0900
From: Naoki Kumazawa <kumazawa@mosk.semicon.sony.co.jp>
Subject: Re: Fastest production car on Nurburgring? 

  On Mon, 27 Mar 1995, Takaharu Mizutani wrote:

> I thought the record was held by a Nissan Skyline GT-R, but a kind soul 
> informed me that the car in question was very heavily modified.

  At least Nissan said "it was the same as prodction car and we only put 
  the optional parts(oil cooler) on it, not modified". 

  But true is not. One Japanese famous monthly motor video "Best Motoring"
  reported the differrence between nomal production car and commercial
  car(which leased from Nissan). The difference is as follows;

                a)Height(-15mm)
                b)Camber angle(1.0 degree negative)
                c)Oil cooler
                d)Power(may be boost up)

  The difference of the performance is incredibly large. On the circuit,
  the nomal production car had some problems (higher oil temperature,
  fading out of brake etc.) and it's lap time got slower.

  Most important thing is that many car magazine and featured video 
  products reported only using this modified car and by now most of these
  Japanese commercial car had some modifying. So the editor of "Best 
  Mortoring" wanted to warn these ugly custom.

  But is this case popular in world wide? I heard that in nardo circuit
  the maximum speed chalenge event was held and the attendants(Ruf CTR,
  959, F40) which supplied from constructers was all modified for higher
  top speed achievement.

> So, maybe a Porsche????

  I think even the new 993 turbo can't break the records.

  Regards,

    Naoki Kumazawa     kumazawa@mosk.semicon.sony.co.jp

Subject: 928 wandering - Toe-in?

	I can't take it anymore. We have a '91 928S4 that does not track very

and the 928 just wants to go its own way when trying to drive on it. It is a

LongAcre for my race car) and there is about 1/8" in the front and 1/16" (or
maybe a little less) in the rear. That is measured at the outside diameter of
the tires (about 24"). Does anyone know how much is desirable for the 928? The
factory manual says 15' in the front and 10' in the rear. Am I right that this
is about about .12" in the front (distance between rear of tire treads minus
distance between front of tire treads) and .08" in the rear?
	I know that low profile, wide tires have more problems with tracking, but
my 993 with 17" wheels and lower profile tires track wonderfully! Can anyone
help?
	Also, it is time to replace the tires. Are there brands of tires that
track better than other brands?

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 1995 19:38:13 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Problem with mounting 914-4 rear wheels

I have a question about mounting the _rear_ wheels on a 914-4 ('74 2.0). I
have factory Fuchs alloys with 195/50 VR15's. Perhaps someone has some
insight ...

The short of it is that I have difficulty getting the rear wheels properly
centered on the rear hub/rotors.  They often end up noticeably off-center
(I'm guessing .020" - .050" ), and this is very noticeable at highway
speeds.  There's nothing wrong with the wheels themselves - they're well
balanced and straight.  The fronts are fine and mount perfectly each time. 

The only way I've found to get around this is to use a dial indicator and
make lots of attempts at gradually tightening the wheel bolts until things
are well centered.  Needless to say, this is very tiresome and
time-consuming.

Is there some trick to guarantee proper hub-centric mounting of the rear
wheels on these cars? This is the only car I've ever encountered that
doesn't have hubs/rotors that guarantee hubcentric wheel mounting.

Thanks

Date: Mon, 27 Mar 95 22:34 EST
From: Peter Rhim <0006877381@mcimail.com>
Subject: Blue smoke from 911

During my on-going search for "my first 911", I came across a European '85 911
with 37K miles.  All appeared to be in order: clean, well cared for, full
maintenance records.  There were only a couple of things (besides the price$$)
that caused me concern:

   1) During a cold start, the car produced a healthy size (volume
      approx the size of the car) cloud of light blue smoke.  Is
      this normal for a 10 year old car with 37K miles?  The smoke
      did not continue for more than 5-7 seconds after startup.
      Should any car blow blue smoke, even if it is only for a few
      seconds?  Doesn't that indicate some kind of internal problem?
      Or can oil seep past the rings if the car is not driven for a
      period of time?
   2) There was a slight oil leak, from where I don't know, but
      the bottom part of the engine was "wet" by the end of our
      20 minute drive.  Owner said it was probably the oil pressure
      sensor or something near there (a simple fix) but could not
      confirm the exact location.  There was not much oil on the 
      floor where the car had been stored.
   3) Although I only have 1 other 911 (a 91) to compare to,
      the shifting action appeared to be rougher than normal getting
      it into 2nd, 3rd, and 4th.  Are all 911s gearboxes a struggle?
      Are the European gearboxes any different from the domestic?
      More or less problematic?

Are any of these potentially costly problems in disguise?  Am I being
unrealistic about finding an older 911 that will not come with any problems? 
Any information from those "veteran" 911 owners/mechanics would be appreciated.

Peter
No P-cars or pets
A Porschephiles neophyte
6877381@mcimail.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 01:00:38 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Rebuilding brake calipers (914/6)

> What about those hydraulic parking brake valves I've heard about here
> and there?  Patrick Motorsports sells them for $49.  I don't know if that's
> good or bad or if it includes everything you need.  Are these things safe?
> I wouldn't mind having 911 binders on all 4 corners of my 914 if I could
> do it and still have some sort of e-brake - and not the 4x4 type!  :-)

Works great except for two things:

1) DOT and most state laws require a "mechanically actuated emergency brake"
   so that you have *SOME* hope of stopping the vehicle if there is a total
   failure in the brake system. This requirement pre-dates the dual circuit
   master cylinders that started in the mid-60s, but it's still there. You 
   can and usually WILL fail your state inspection without a real emergency
   brake.

2) the hydraulic gizmo obviously uses the brake system to "hold pressure"
   on the pads. So if you use it after getting the brakes all heated
   up, surprise! You now have warped rotors. There may also be other
   unpleasant surprises, like seals failing from being under pressure
   for prolonged periods of time (duty cycle is now very different
   that they were designed for...)

Stan

------------------------------

Well, actually, this has already been discussed. During the "T*d Wars", when 
he was attempted his first X-event, he took out several cones (plastic) and nearly
a live one, too. This led to the speculation that probably the only way he could do
better was to fill his tires with helium and float through the course. *This*
in turn led to the realization that knowing T*d as we, unfortuately, did, would
probably fill them with hydrogen instead (to get that 'extra' bit of lift) accidently
lock his keys in his car and watch it float off toward Tahoe. 

> ...do is write an A.S. filter program instead (Artificial Stupidity).

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 08:49:41 PST

Subject: R-12 certification for A/C


A couple weeks ago I wrote about obtaining R-12 certification, which
would allow you to buy freon.  Well, over the weekend I found the number:

(215) 679-2220  It's $20 for the first person, $15 for each additional
person, prepaid (they accept MC/Visa)...

The study guide contains relevant information about the laws regarding the
use of R-12 and equipment required (reclamation/recycling) to perform work.


David asked:

>Any idea how long the freon will last in an unopend 5lb storage can?  and
>what the storage requirements are?

No.  I would contact duPont and ask for a material safety data sheet and/or
additional info.

------------------------------

Date: 28 Mar 95 09:20:09 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 993 turbo wheels (was Forged vs. cast)

Hi, Neil.
 
Neil Kumpers writes re new Turbo wheels
 
>I don't believe that's right. The 5 spokes are hollow and made out of some
>special forged aluminum alloy which permit a weight savings of around 3 kg.
>They are also the first wheels for production cars to be friction welded...
 
I think you're right. I just read the German report in auto motor und sport,
they didn't mention the wheels in particular, photo caption just says "huge
brake discs behind newly styled light alloy wheels." But no, now that you
mention it, I did read an internal Porsche document months ago about their
development of the friction welding process and figured that it was about
due for the Turbo. And then promptly forgot about it.
 
Not sure how they friction weld this, probably spin the rim or the center
until it melts into the other part, but the idea is not new. When I
interviewed at GM Electromotive Division in 1978, they showed me friction
welded valves for their diesel railway locomotive engines. They hold the
valve stem, as I recall, in a high speed lathelike device and ram the
mushroom for the head into that until the whole thing glows and fuses
together. Grind the mushed out metal smooth, and you have a valve made with
two different steel alloys. Or maybe filled with sodium or whatever. (Is
this how Porsche/ATE sodium filled valves are made? Dunno).
 
Pete

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 09:27:33 US/Eastern

Subject: Re: 944 Overheating / Oil in Water

Hi, Bob,

Well, sound like you're on the right track.

I would start with the compression check or leakdown test (which can give
you more info than just compression.

Mostlikelyculprit is the head gasket.

A cracked cylinder wall you will spot in a moment.

The heads are pretty stout, so may not even need resurfacing. Use the
factory manual spec and check with mechanics straightedge.

I used to know a girl from Moscow, when I went to school at Gonzaga...

good luck

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 7:42:43 -0700 (MST)
From: BDETELIC@POLLUX.DASD.HONEYWELL.COM
Subject: Brake Caliper Rebuild

 After seeing the discussion about rebuilding brake calipers
I thought I'd share what has worked for me. With the calipers
on the car I take my big water-pump pliers and depress both calipers,
then use a C-clamp to hold the first piston in place and put a piece of 
plywood inside the caliper so that the piston will come free but not 
slam into the C-clamp or come flying out. I wrap the whole dinger-doober
in a plastic bag or with a rag and take special care with braided brake
lines to insure that they do not kink. I then proceed to use a clean 
rag to clean out the piston bore and coat new seal, dust-boot and piston
with break fluid prior to installation. Many pistons require that they
be installed with a certant rotation as the surface that meets the pad
is not even. Repeat for the other piston. 
 I always use surgical gloves to keep break fluid off my hands but find 
that the break fluid tends to break them down fairly quickly. If 
anyone knows of a glove that will hold together but still allow you
to feel what your working on I'd sure appreciate it if you would pass
it along.



Bill D. 

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 09:53:53 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: DYI Paint (longish)


I also paint in my garage, and also staple plastic from floor to ceiling
to make a "booth". A few days before I paint and before hanging the plastic, 
I take everything out of the garage (major job but necessary) I vacuum 
everything I can reach, blow off all the surfaces (including ceiling) with 
an air hose, then vacuum again. I let any remaining dust settle for a day, 
then staple new plastic tarp material from floor to ceiling, covering all 
the walls and duct taped to the floor. I put a muffin fan in a garage window 
with a furnace filter taped onto the inside so that I'm blowing air out. I
*thoroughly* blow the car off outside, then I mist the garage floor with
water and push the car inside and wet down about 10ft of driveway. I pull the
door down to about 6" to leave a little air flow. I tack the car and it's
ready to paint (all the paint mixing and prep work left out for brevity) I
use enamel with hardener which is dust proof in 20 minutes or so.

Using this method, I've never had a problem with dust. The dust people get
from Maaco and other painters is probably sanding dust that gets blown out
of door cracks etc. by the paint gun. That's why it's critical to blow every
square inch of the car off thoroughly outside the garage. I *have* had problems
with water from my compressor which somehow got through the trap, and I've
had problems with a car that had been Armoral'd to death causing trouble
with silicone. Even after using Prep-Sol and fish-eye reducer I had a few
bad spots. If you do get a dust spots, they can be removed *after* the paint
is dry and hard. It's always a disaster trying to remove dust or drips from 
wet paint.

This just covers keeping dust out of the paint. spraying technique, mixing,
masking, etc. also determine the quality of the job. There's no substitute for
practice and it probably shouldn't be on a p-car.

Reid



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 9:04:59 CST
From: jjholt@holt.b11.ingr.com (Jeff Holt)
Subject: Re: Depressed

...

>of the valve cover assembly.  This leaking oil was dripping down on to the
>exaust manifold.  SH*T.  No other leaking.  I pulled the dipstick, now thinking
>loss of oil.  The color of the oil on the dipstick looks like chocolate milk.
>SH*T again!!.  Anti-freeze and oil mixture??
>
>Well, I am thinking right now that I have, best case scenario, a blown head(?)
>gasket.  Worst case, a cracked block. 

There has been some discussion about this recently - some to do with a
question I had.

Basically there is good news and bad news :-)

The good news is that you probably haven't got a blown head gasket. The
usual cause of coolant in the oil is the oil cooler.

The bad news is that Porsche recomends that you need to replace the big end
bearings. Maybe if you know that the water wasn't in the system before you
drove that car, and you could flush out the chocolate milk with good oil you
may be able to get away without doing this (eg drain coolant and old oil, fill
with new oil and turn the engine over for a while). This is just an idea,
based on no actual knowledge whatsoever!!

You may want to check the archives, as I said this has been discussed before.
The last thread was one I started called "944 oil cooler question". There
was a post from someone who had had a blown oil cooler.

Good luck!

***    Jeff Holt  Advanced Graphics Systems Design  (205) 730-6098     ***
