------------------------------

Date: 28 Mar 95 10:24:42 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Blue smoke from 85 911

 
Peter Rhim asked about blue smoke on startup.
 
Heck, yeah, they all do that (standard mechanic's excuse #2.) Every 911 I've
ever owned from new did it a lot when it was brand new, it got a little
better for a few thousand miles, then it just came back. It's nothing to
worry about. A few drops of oil drool past the valve guides and puddle in the
combustion chambers overnight.
 
OTOH, you can use the blue smoke to beat the price down. <g>. Tell the
seller you're worried about engine damage but you're willing to take the
risk for the right price etc.
 
It would be nice if 911 engines were nice and dry on the underside but those
are rare. A little oil is usually nothing to worry about.
 
Synchros, I don't know. The 85 would still have the Type 915 box with
Porsche synchromesh, not the Borg-Warner synchromesh used on the 87-on G50
box, which shifts smoother. If there is a clash on every gear being engaged,
probably needs clutch adjustment. If it's just a matter of waiting a
fraction of a second before you can engage each gear, well, that's Porsche
blocking synchromesh. There shouldn't be any significant wear on the 3, 4,
and 5 gear synchros, they don't see much action (even on a Euro car).
 
If this is a gray market car, make sure its DOT and EPA paperwork is in
order (compliance with emissions and safety regs). Otherwise you have a
potential major problem on your hands. Gray market cars typically sell for
less on the market because of this, but it doesn't make them bad cars. Just
be aware that someday you'll want to sell it again and it will be worth a
little less than an otherwise identical U.S. car. On the plus side, if it is
originally a non-catalyst Euro engine, you have higher compression ratio and
potentially more power. See below.
 
How much time did it spend in Europe before coming here? Europeans had a
tendency to beat the hell out of cars and then sell them to the gray
marketers, who got top dollar for them in the mid to late 80s during the
craziness.
 
You should have a Type 930/20 engine with 231 horsepower (DIN hp), without
catalyst. If you have a tacked-on catalyst, which the 930/20 never had from
the factory, you may have a little less power than that
but that is a reversible process. Depends also on what, if anything, the
gray market converter did to the DME box. The Type 930/20 has a 10.3:1
compression ratio. If you have a build sheet or dealer window sticker or
something, check for option code M298, which was optional for environmentally
nervous Germans and mandatory for Austria, Australia, and Switzerland. This
automatically gives you the U.S. engine, type M930/21, with a compression of
only 9.5 to 1 and only 207 hp DIN and factory standard catalyst.
 
The engine type is stamped into the crankcase. Don't recall where, but if
you find it you can confirm what this used to be. It is unlikely that the
car had lower compression pistons installed just to convert it; you probably
still have whatever it left the factory with. Be aware that the 10.3:1
compression called for 98 Research Octane fuel (which would be about 93-94
pump octane in the U.S.). The 930/20 did not have a knock sensor. Not sure
about 930/21 but it is unlikely it had a knock sensor either. So if you have
a 930/20 engine, hopefully somebody dialed the timing back a bit to keep it
from detonating on the fuel we have here.
 
Brain boxes:
the following DME brain boxes were listed for 1987, unlikely they are
applicable for 1985 but here they are anyway:
 
911.618.111.12   high compression engines, worldwide
911.618.111.13   low octane fuel (Belgium, France, Greece)
911.618.111.14   USA, California, Japan, Canada, Austria, Switzerland, rest
                 of world with catalyst
911.618.111.15   high compression engines with "Sports Package I."
911.618.111.16   low octane fuel with "Sports Package I."
911.618.111.17   USA etc. with "Sports Package I."
 
I think the brain box is located under the passenger seat. Maybe slide seat
and see if you can read the number on the box. If you find these at swap
meets, now you know what they are, and they are probably a plug-in
replacement for yours (same engine type after all).
 
Most of the above info comes from the forthcoming book "Porsche 911: Forever
Young" by Tobias Aichele. I translated it, Aichele works in the factory PR
department, and all the tech stuff was condensed for the book by my former
next door neighbor in Weissach who did technical training so it's factory
gospel.
 
 
Pete

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 07:54:53 -0800 (PST)
From: Bryan Wilkinson <bwilkin@rain.org>
Subject: Re: painting 

> 
> >Do I need to get this thing bead blasted?
> 
> Nope. Chemical stripper (see above) is messy but it works.  In 
> fact, if the old paint isn't cracked or crazed or too thick, you 
> can often get by with sanding it to rough it up, and then 
> painting right over it.
> 

Having gone both of these routes (stripper and plastic bead blasting) on 
my last two projects, I can tell you it really pays to go with the bead 
blasting if you want it done right.  With cars this old, they often have 
4 or 5 coats of paint on them.  When you use stripper it takes forever 
and you will end up using several gallons (at $20 each).  In contrast the 
bead blasting leaves the car looking perfect (no paint left in cracks the 
stripper would lift out) and saves your hours of time...lots of hours.  
Your hands will also thank you for having the car bead blasted.  If you 
use the stripper, make sure you wear heany gloves.

If you're in So. Cal. I would recommend Speed Strip in Glendale/Burbank.  
Talk to Scott.  He knows his stuff and has done several 914s.

If you go with the DIY method, wear a respirator.  Breathing all that 
crap will ruin you lungs...trust me on that one.

Bryan

1979 911SC
1974 914

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 11:01:33 -0500
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: Re: Paintless Dent Removal

R. Warren asked if anyone had experience with paintless dent removal

I have had experience with one organization called "The Dent Wizard" in
Leonia, NJ (201) 461-7766.  I have had as well as seen numerous dents removed
from many Porsches.  If the dent is not creased and the paint is intact,
their system does a beautiful job.  These people take pride in their work and
will tell you up front if they can or can not help. 

I have a customer who was shot in the door of his black 930 with a paintball.
 We cleaned up the paint and found that the impact had left a small dent in
the door.  He took the car to Dent Wizard and 30 minutes later drove home
with a perfect door.  

I can only speak for this one organization.  Their system (a combination
black magic and voodoo - they won't tell you what it is) works.  The key to
any service oriented business is to talk to the people and determine the
level of pride in their work.  

For what it's worth, that's my $ 0.000002 worth.

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 08:03:51 -0800
From: cjk50g@ix.netcom.com (Christopher Woodward)
Subject: RE: parts for '87 944S

Ike,

Two things.  Your 944S self-tensioner spring isn't a likely candidate 
for failure.  What makes you feel it is weak?  If you lossen up the two 
other 13mm bolts on that assembly and place a 17mm wrench on the 
tensioner roller's nut, some pressure downwards with your forearm 
straight to your chest should be all you need to compress it.  I've seen 
only 3 of these assemblies, they took about the same effort.  I hope 
this isn't a part you'll need.  I'm not sure, but think the S2 
assembly's compatability with the S's should be considered (same width 
etc).

Replacing tensioner rollers on these and the S2 cars was recomended to 
me.  I also noticed how, because the original was plastic and its 
replacement metal, the outside edge begins to taper with milage causing 
uneven belt wear on these 16v belts. A relatively small amount of taper 
was beggining to show at 70k, for reference.  The metal replacement 
costs approx $45 (note: it may spin fine and still be bad because of the 
taper).  You can tell if you have a plastic one with a magnet.

Good Luck,

Chris
944S  


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 11:13:39 EST
From: "William R. Kennedy, NJIT CIAT, 201-596-5648" <kennedy@admin.njit.edu>
Subject: RE: 914 cam goes "negative"

I ain't buying this (that the 914 camshaft is "slimmer on each side of TDC"
so that valve lash is greater on each side of TDC than it is at TDC.)  TDC
is just after the falling ramp of the intake valve, and a ways before the 
rising ramp of the exhaust valve.  In both cases it's on a part of the cam
that doesn't get any "slimmer".  And if there's any part of your cam that
measures *more* than the suggested lash, you have misadjusted, noisy valves
that will wear the cams fast.  Could someone confirm?  There's lots of stuff
I can't actually *do* in a garage, but I like to think I could pass the
written test.

Thanks for any clarification.
B.

they'd like to part with?  Or does anyone know of a place that can build 
3 piece wheels for less than $350 each (the price I've got from HRE) that 
is willing to put together wheels with only a 1" outside half?

Porschephiles #1280                         Tue Mar 28 15:52:20 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 08:48:23 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Problem with mounting 914-4 rear wheels

Thanks for your collective input.

Some of you mentioned using the proper bolts.

The bolts I'm using are dull silver, have "rounded cone" seats, have 19mm
heads and are 62mm long (tip-to-tip), with a threaded portion that's 34mm
long.  Are these the right ones?

Dave wrote:

I simply
hold up the wheel, start one bolt (the long kind!), wiggle the wheel
into place so's I can put a second bolt in, and that holds the wheel
pretty much in place.  Two more bolts go on finger-tight, make the
first two finger-tight, then go 'round (opposite corners) with the
torque wrench.  94 ft-lbs, I believe.  About 1/4 to 1/2 turn each pass,
until the wrench goes "click".  No problems.


That's exactly what I do. Perhaps I'm not using the right "lubricant" on
the seats where the wheel meets the bolt(s) -- any suggestions?

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 08:54:21 PST
From: Scott=D=Berry%MfgEng%GPID@banyan.BV.TEK.COM
Subject: 912 - No power @ low RPM

I have a 66 912 that I just rebuilt the carbs (Webers), adjusted valves, points, 
timing and installed new plugs.  When I got last fall the car timing was way 
off, like 15 degrees BTDC.  After changing it to 3 degrees BTDC the car runs 
much stronger from 2000-4000 rpm but it is totally dead at under 2000 rpm.  I 
realize this low of an RPM is not normally used to much but if I am on even the 
slightest incline and my RPM's drop below 2K the engine starts to blubber and I 
lose all power.  As soon as I can get the rev's up to 2K it takes off like a 
rocket (at least a 912 rocket!)  Any ideas?  Thanx in advance!

Scott
66 912

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 10:59:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Depressed


Bob,

The symptoms you describe -- taffee-coloured goop on the dipstick,
are usually a result of oil and coolant mixing because of failed seals
in the oil/water heat exchanger.  Head gaskets rarely go on normally-
aspirated 944's.

Replacing the seals is not a huge amount of work.  However, because
you have coolant in the oil, Porsche recommends that you check the
connecting rod bearings.  To do this, you have to remove the oil pan,
which is a fair amount of work.  (On a car your age, I would plan on
replacing the bearings anyways while you are in there.)  If you find that
the coolant has damaged the conn rod bearings, you have to think
about also replacing the main bearings, which gets ugly...

With regard to your main warning light, I assume it came on because
of lack of coolant causing too high an engine temp.  Hopefully you
didn't run the engine too long in this condition.  If you did, however,
it is possible that your head has been warped.  In this case, it is
indeed possible that you pushed coolant past the head gasket.
But it would tend to be burned and show up as sweet-smelling exhaust,
before pushing past the rings and into the crankcase.

Hope this helps.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 09:18:00 -0800
From: kwatson@wv.MENTORG.COM (Keith Watson)
Subject: Fun Cars or Last Weekend's School

I had the opportunity to instruct at the Team Continental (TC) track
school at Portland International Raceway on Saturday.  TC is a local
racing club.  Some of the Porsche diehards hit every track day the
can including the schools.  My student was Dick Bader who has a
modified 85 Euro 911.  Eventhough Dick was my "student" he has been
driving on the track almost as long as I am old.

After 9 years of track driving his stock "chipped" engine lost a
valve.  They took it completely apart and the bottom end was perfect.
When the engine was put back together it was turned into a dual plug
3.4 L.  This was the second time on the track for the new engine.
I got to ride with Dick has his instructor.  The accelaration of the
new engine is incredible.  Dick would have to lift early (!) at the end
of the front straight because the car would still be accelerating
strong in 5th gear when the tach would swing up into the red.  This
was somewhere up over 140mph.  This was my first time in a car which
had more power than gearing.

Monte Smith was also in town with his yellow 911 RS.

Keith Watson


------------------------------

Date:          Tue, 28 Mar 1995 10:19:19 +700
From: JBUTLER@park.admin.utah.edu
Subject:       912 - No power @ low RPM

>I have a 66 912 that I just rebuilt the carbs (Webers), adjusted valves, points, 
>timing and installed new plugs.  When I got last fall the car timing was way 
>off, like 15 degrees BTDC.  After changing it to 3 degrees BTDC the car runs 
>much stronger from 2000-4000 rpm but it is totally dead at under 2000 rpm.  I 
>realize this low of an RPM is not normally used to much but if I am on even the 
>slightest incline and my RPM's drop below 2K the engine starts to blubber and I 
>lose all power.  As soon as I can get the rev's up to 2K it takes off like a 
>rocket (at least a 912 rocket!)  Any ideas?  Thanx in advance!

Have you tested the distributor advance with a stobe timing light? 
The original 022 distibutor should produce a very fat advance curve 
below 2000 rpm, like 11 degrees of advance at 1000 rpm, 19 degrees at 
1500 rpm, and close to 24 degrees at 2000 rpm. Sounds like the 
previous owner may have advanced it to compensate for a distributor 
that's not up to snuff at the low end.

John, U of Utah
jbutler@park.admin.utah.edu
*Fahren in seiner schoensten form*

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 09:32:17 -0800 (PST)
From: Ted Rodgers <rodgers@indigo01.akctr.noaa.gov>
Subject: 356 oil flow question


I'm looking at modifying my case for an external oil cooler and want to
make sure I understand the oil flow from the diagrams and my case pieces. 
It appears that oil comes from the sump into the right hand side of the
pump, gets pumped out the left side through a passage and into the cooler. 
From there it passes the oil pressure sensor and gets distributed from
there, some to the filter and to the various other necessary places. 

Is this correct?

The design for an external cooler I saw had a boss in the front piece 
drilled for a fitting which, if the above is correct routed the oil to the
external cooler and then returned through a fitting which replaced the oil
sensor, which was relocated in the external system. 

Thanks,

Ted Rodgers

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 12:45:13 -0500 (EST)

Subject: Re: Scratches and things

There is a company that exists who specialize in removing dents without 
painting.  They have a charge of round about $100 per panel for the first dent 
in that panel, and a $10 charge for each dent in the samer panel after that.  
The company is called the Dent Wizard, and they can be reached by dialling 1-800-
dentman. or sometimes 1-800-dentmen.  They couldn't do my door (No cracked 
paint) so I now refer to them as the DENT-WEENY, however they are apperently 
good for hail damage and such like.
Cheers,   Jan

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 12:51:57 -0500 (EST)
From: RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu
Subject: Re: Charging problem

Sounds like the primary side of your alternator is bad, or the bulb has gone in 
the circuit.
	Best way to diagnose: Measure primary resistance directly across 
alternator; if OK check bulb.
	If OK check voltage whilst revving engine, should be around 14 volts.  
If not check regulator.
	Alternatively take regulator and alternator to Autozone and get them to 
do the checking.  Then talk to George.
Cheers,  Jan

P.S. Car electrics do not obey Ohm's law!

------------------------------

metal exposed from rubbing the dent back out.  It is a nice touch and shows a 
commitment to quality that all P-cars deserve.

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 09:53:59 -0800 (PST)
From: "Thomas B. Smith" <toms@comtch.iea.com>
Subject: Re: 2 part paints?

Reid-
About a year ago I used some base/clear paint to refinish some winter wheels
for my Jeep GC.  The paint was a BASF product, and it worked very well.  I
am not a very experienced painter, and I was very pleased with the result.
The only disadvantage I can see is that there is a specified maximum time 
after the base coat is applied that must not be exceeded before the 
clear-coat is applied.  I don't remember what the time period was, but I 
thought at the time that if one was painting a whole car you would need 
to be organized and ready to work.

Tom Smith

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 12:54:03 -0500 (EST)
From: "Naresh H. Singh" <nhs1681@is2.NYU.EDU>
Subject: Re: 924S value?

On Tue, 28 Mar 1995, Reid Zeigler wrote:

> I found a very nice 924S that has been sitting in storage (outdoors)
> for about a year, and I was told that the young owner can't afford
> to insure it. The hood was unlatched so I popped it open and the car
> has acquired some furry friends over the winter but otherwise looks
> almost like new. I'd like to rescue this car but have no idea what year
> it is or what it's worth, and I'd like to get some basic info before I
> call the owner. I wrote down the VIN# but don't have it at work with me.
> Can someone familiar with 924S's give me an idea when they were made and
> a realistic price range?
> 
> Reid (reid_zeigler@merck.com
> 


Hi Reid,

I am by no means a Porsche expert but I'll pass on what little I know. 
The 924S was a limited production entry level Porsche made in 1987 and 
1988. The 924S differs from the regular '70s to early '80s 924 in that the 
924S has the drivetrain of the 944 in the old 924 body.

As for price, they tend to be under or around $5,000 (in NY)

I think that the 1988 924S is more desirable because it had 15 more 
horsepower than the 1987. Also, there were some special edition cars 
without power windows, sunroof, etc. (I think Bob Joyce has one, he may 
be able to help more)

Hope this helps, Good Luck

Naresh

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 10:02:36 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Fram oil filters: No mo!

Thought I'd share some newfound wisdom...

I have used Fram oil filters in my '80 931, against the advice of some
on this distinguished list.  My car runs high oil pressure: up to 7
bar when cold, with the 20/50 Mobil 1 inside.

TWO times now, I have found that while driving one day, my oil
pressure has dropped to 2 bar or so, and it does not recover. (Makes
the heart sink, it does!)  The first time, I suspected oil suction
problems, and so I dropped the pan and cleaned and re-attached the
sump siphon tube and screen (and replaced oil and filter).  Fixed it,
for a while.  This last time, though, I inspected the Fram filter after
removing it... VOILA!  The internals of the filter have separated,
allowing free flow without passing through the filter medium.  Hence,
blacker than usual oil.  I apologized profusely to my poor motor for
my lack of judgement and false sense of economy!  Never again.

I am a new Knecht/Mahle champion now, and I'll save the Frams to look
pretty in the store window sale display!!

 -mike  '80 931 fire engine red...
___________________________________________________________________
mikew@sr.hp.com mailstop 1UR-M
                                      MMS Manufacturing Engineering         
Mike Weihman                          Microwave Instruments Division
Hewlett-Packard Company               1212 Valley House Drive    
(707) 794-4454                        Rohnert Park, CA 94928  USA

| paint) so I now refer to them as the DENT-WEENY, however they are apperently 
| good for hail damage and such like.
| Cheers,   Jan

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 11:07:44 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Dust free paint job



Someone named AHUSAIN@schmed01.ab.umd.edu wrote,

>What about the dust that gets in the paint?  I had my car 
>repainted at  MAACO after I did all the prep and they still 
>managed to do a lousy  job.  Overspray everywhere and 
>the amount of dust inthe paint was  really bad.  I'm 
>assuming that if a paint shop has dust and other  
>problems, painting in the driveway will be worse.  

>Comments, Advice

The way to handle the dust problem is to use fast drying 
paints, and then to wet sand and polish.  Lacquer is the 
fastest drying - it's out of dust (that means dry enough so 
dust won't stick) in seconds.  It wet sands a polished 
beautifully, but is not as durable as other paints.  The new
catalyzed urethanes are out of dust in a minute or so, and 
they also wet sand and polish beatifully, and are extremely 
durable to boot.  Take my word for it.  You can produce an 
absolutely show car finish in your driveway.

 -Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 11:04:07 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Brake piston removal from caliper.



Pressure can be used to remove 356, 914, 911 and other pistons from 
the caliper. CAUTION should be used when pressure is applied. A grease
gun filled with hydraulic fluid works well as you can gradually apply 
pressure. There is nothing worse than a flying piston when it leaves
the caliper.

I usually have a piece of wood for the piston to slam to keep it from 
flying. If you use air, use a regulator to start with an applied 
pressure of 5 pounds, turning the pressure up slowly until you get 
movement. Tapping with a hammer on the housing helps the piston move. 

Unfortunately, when pistons freeze like this, you will usually discover
pitting from corrosion in the caliper bore. On rarer calipers, you may 
have to have stainless sleeves inserted to rebuild for use. There 
are a couple of firms advertising this service in Pano and Excellence.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 09:20:25 MST
From: hearn@drmail.dr.att.com
Subject: Re: Paintless Dent Removal


> From: cmxi@tiac.net (R.Warren)
> Subject: Paintless Dent Removal
> 
> Does anyone have experience with the "paintless dent removal specialists?"
> I have a couple of beauties and was told that they can be pushed/popped out
> without the repair/paint/expensive bodyshop process.      
> 
> I've seen the tools and understand the process but is it a good, clean fix?
 
I tried this dent removal process on my 86 Honda Accord last year. The car
had about 40 hail dents per major panel (ie. hood, roof, etc.). Some of
the dents were the size of golf balls. None of the dents had any sharp
creases. The car has original paint that has been beat on by the Colorado sun. 

I took the car to a place called the Dent Doctor and was given a quote of
$250 dollars per panel (~$800 vs. $3500 from a Body shop). I looked around
their shop (temporay shop since they tend to chase hailstorms) which was
filled with new Audi's in various stages of repair. The body panels that
had been repaired where perfect just like new (I have a lot of experience
performing show quality painting and bodywork). 

I was told that the 8 year old paint on my car might present some trouble,
but they would do their best. I was completely impressed when I picked up
the car, there was no evidence that there was ever any damage. He did 
point out a very small star on the trunk where the paint cracked due to it's
age but even that was almost imperceptible. 

From my experience I would highly recommend this process to anyone 
that wants to remove dents without any sharp creases especially if
the vehicle has fairly new original paint.
YMMV
Mike Hearn	hearn@dr.att.com

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 12:32:35 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: 911 Oil Smoke

Re: 911 Oilsmoke on start up...

My '83 SC does this once, maybe twice a year.  So did my BMW boxer bike.
Totally random as far as I can tell... well, maybe a little worse when
parked with one cylinder bank downhill... I always figured it was one or
more rings coming to rest in a non-optimal position.  Anyway I'd suggest
witnessing at least one more cold start on the subject engine, if it
smokes consistently consider it a major warning flag.  Think of
911s you've watched start up in parking lots... a car-sized oilsmoke
fart is definitely not part of the Porsche mystique IMO.

 -Ed
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC

Porschephiles #1281                         Tue Mar 28 21:37:43 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 13:12:12 -0800 (PST)
From: "Thomas B. Smith" <toms@comtch.iea.com>
Subject: Re: Brake Caliper Rebuild

Bill-
Last summer I pruchased some nitrile exam gloves from a supplier here in 
Spokane.  They were marketed as useful in situations where people have 
latex allergies.  I bought a couple of boxes to use in my garage, and 
they are quite a lot more chemical resistant than latex gloves.  Parts 
washer fluid attacks them very slowly, Perchloroethylene (NAPA Brake & 
Electic Motor Cleaner) will eventually destroy them, but not nearly so 
quickly as latex.  They seem impervious to oil and brake fluid.  They 
were made by Best Mfg. in Menlo GA. 1 800 241-0323.  If you can only get 
them in cases, let me know and I will speak with the local person.  If
I remember correctly they were about $9.00 a box (100) vs. $4.50 for our 
normal exam gloves, so we do not use them very much.

Regards

Tom Smith

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 11:30:53 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: 2 part paints


Reid-

I just did my 911 in PPG basecoat clearcoat, and before that
I did a 240Z, also with PPG basecoat/clearcoat, but a different
type.  I like it very much.  Goes on easily.  Dries fast,
can be wet sanded and polished if you wish, but can also
be left as is (if you happen to have a super-elaborate dust-free
environment, like the one you created).  They say that
it's harder to repair than one-coat systems, and that may be
true.  But the stuff is so hard, and durablem that you won't have
to repair it.  Anyway, I like it.

BTW, you really can do very well in your driveway.  There actually
isn't that much dust in the air, especially if you pick a
good day, and whatever there is goes away with a bit of wet sanding.
I actually didn't wet-sand the 240Z, and it's got a pretty darned
good finish on it.  I've seen many, many far worse, done by
'pros.'

 -Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa

Date: 28 Mar 95 14:22:26 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Paintless dent removal

 
I have seen paintless dent removal done. Done right, it is just as
advertised. PCA San Diego Region had a tech session at a local shop that did
this. By the time we got there, the inner panel of a recent 911 door had
been taken off. Two big dents had been circled with crayon. In less than a
minute each, the owner of the shop had pushed them back, and even when seen
at a low angle, and knowing exactly where it had been, you couldn't find the
dents. The paint was undamaged. One dent was very close to the side
intrusion beam. Dents which cannot be reached from behind can't be fixed by
this method. Seems expensive when you consider how little time it takes
(after door is opened) but consider the alternative. And the guy has learned
a real skill.
 
There is no real secret, just carefully pushing with the blunt, rounded end
of a soft steel rod. If you go too far, they use a piece of highly polished
stainless steel to push the dent back down and start over. It's not
something I would want to try on my own car though. Let the pros do it.
 
Pete

Date: 28 Mar 95 15:05:18 -0500
From: mvmas@mvujc.att.com
Subject: re: How's a Torsen work?

>        I was wondering:  How does a Torsen-type (torque sensing) limited
>slip diff work?  I'm curious about the principle, and I'd like to see if
>I could build one out of my Lego collection.  (No sh*t!)  Some of the more
>modern Legos are good tools for learning about gearing and other mechan-
>ical type stuff.
>        Thanks!
>
>--DD
>
>        "I used to have a life, but I sacrificed it to my car."
>Dave Darling
>darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov                          914s Rule!

Unless some really radical new lego parts have come out in the last few
years, like worm gears with sort of regular gears on each end, you won't
be able to make one.  The Torsen differential is hard to describe in
words and it's hard to figure it out on paper also, but near as I can
tell it relies on the principle of worm gears transferring motion only
one way, the worm turns the gear next to it, but the gear cannot turn the
worm.

However, you can make a regular diff out of regular lego parts if you drill
the center out of one gear.  I also have a 3-spd forward 1-spd reverse
transmission.  (I used to get into legos).
Mark A. Skala
mvmas@mvujc.att.com      '73 914    '88 924S coming soon


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 11:46:45 PST
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: Paintless Dent Removal


- --Boundary-7790243-0-0

Had some door dings removed by Dentpro.  I believe that they are are a 
franchise of a national chain so there's probably one near you.  They did an 
fantastic job on my Mercedes 300.  The techniques they use were first 
developed by Ford in the 40's.  Very simply, they have a series of 1/4-3/8 
diameter steel rods bent at various degrees at one end with different shape  
flattened, tapered ends.  The end of the rod may vary in length, 1,2,3in. and 
the angle may be from 45-90 degrees.  They look like something you could 
easily make with a vise. grinding wheel and file. 
 
They bend a handle of sorts at the other end and vary the length From 5" to 3 
ft.   They then drill a small hole(clearance for the rod) in the door jamb or 
body jamb nearest the dent, work the rod in and push out the dent from the 
inside.  Clearly, skill is as important as tools and concept so be sure to ask 
the person who shows up how long he's been at it. there's also a free standing 
vertical pole used for sighting along that exagerates the dent visually and 
gives the operator more control.  Overall a great process that was overlooked 
for it's simplicity for many years.  They plug the holes with little black 
plugs that look very "factory".  Go to your local Mercedes dealer, look at 
their clean used cars, open the doors and look at the jambs and you'll see the 
plugs. 
 
Good Luck 
Ted Smith   


- --Boundary-7790243-0-0

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 15:18:48 -0800 (PST)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: 914 cam goes "negative"

William writes:
> I ain't buying this (that the 914 camshaft is "slimmer on each side of TDC"
> so that valve lash is greater on each side of TDC than it is at TDC.)  TDC
> is just after the falling ramp of the intake valve, and a ways before the 
> rising ramp of the exhaust valve.  In both cases it's on a part of the cam
> that doesn't get any "slimmer".  And if there's any part of your cam that

(snip - snip)

I'll second that!  I have thought about this for a few days now and can't 
see how or why this would be necessary.  I have worked in a machine shop 
and a grinding shop though not necessarily on automotive equipment, and 
don't remember seeing cams ground with "negative" areas unless something 
was meant to follow it all the way around the cam.

Maybe I'm going crazy or something but it just doesn't make any sense or 
do I have any sense left?

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR
SSCA-SFR/RR


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 17:40:09 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 cam goes "negative"

        I agree that it doesn't make sense that the cam would have
"negative" areas on it.  However:  Stan says they don't, George H.
says they do.  Right now, I'm inclined to believe George, because
it fits in with my current experience (with one car).
        I re-checked the valve clearances:  all were fine (except
for two that I was a little over-enthusiastic with before).  No
metal shreds in my oil, and the pushrods look like the photos in
the Factory and Haynes shop manuals.  What that *appears* to leave
is that *this* cam has at least some "negative" areas.
        Since I've now checked my valve clearances four times, I'm
pretty confident that they're correct.
        However, I've been wrong before.  (We'll see!  $$$$$$$!)

- --DD

        "I used to have a life, but I sacrificed it to my car."
Dave Darling
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov                          914s Rule!




------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 18:28:21 -0600 (CST)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: Problem with mounting 914-4 rear wheels

Hi Andrew,

Check the center hole diameter of the wheel.  Check the center hub 
diameter for your rear hubs.  The fit should be close and concentric.  I 
had to cut some out once when I altered the backspace of a set of racing 
wheels going on a 914-4.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974

Subject: Re: 356 oil flow question

Yep. Wasn't quite sure about the last part, but is your adaptation for
 street or track?
If you have a bolt on VW type kit (which leak because the gaskets are just a
leeetle bit the wrong size) - no big deal - remove shroud, unbolt stock
cooler, bolt on VW type cooler with cheesy -6 cotton braided lines, cut up
your nice fan shroud (since the shoulder on the VW adapter is too big) @ 3x2"
slice for lines to exit. Then find a place where you can bolt the cooler so
cooling air can circulate. Most guys put it under the deck lid grille, but
 be careful of pinches and stretch of the lines. In business - BUT - I think
this is what you're referring to....
I think you would be best served by a single chamber Oberg filter AND a small
to mid size cooler for street use. This is an adaptation of the oil system of
the SCCA E Production car I used to race a few years ago, and have
successfully put into many street cars.  This all fits neatly under the
drivers side rear wheel opening using the fender brace to mount the Oberg;
and the inner panel for a stand off cooler set up.  Recommend you use -8
minimum and preferably -10 Aeroquip lines with aluminum fittings.  Try to
keep as many fittings straight or 45 degrees or less. Each bend costs you
about 3psi or more esp 90 degree ones.  356's need every psi, so don't lose
too many.
To start:  Drill the oil pump cover and fit male threaded fitting. (you can
call ray Litz in CA he already has them made up) Plug oil pump hole inside of
3d pc of case where gears are.
Tap L side of case at closed bossing and insert threaded male fitting.
Reverse oil tube in 3d pc of case (can be done w/ stock rubber plugs in a
reinz gasket set) to block upper hole.  Remove stock cooler, tap and plug
holes.  Remove stock oil filter & store away. Plug hole in case with allen
plug (where oil line goes). And plug hole in temp block (where other line
goes). Suggest you remove oil return spring and piston from 3d pc of case
using only the one in the case with spring and piston.
How you run the lines is optional, some guys made holes in the sheetmetal,
some have removed the carb preheater horns and tubes and run the lines
through there - both work.  Cover your cooler with some screen in case of
flying rocks and debris. Think I got it all. If I have confused this too
much, please accept my apology - Ray Litz in CA or Vic Skirmants-356
Enterprises in MI do this for a living....they can tap and plug your case for
you, maybe even sell you a "kit" they put together for you to do the job
absolutley right....last time I checked it was for reasonable dollars
American.  The Maestro is also lurking out there on the net, but I don't know
if he does this- if he does I'm sure he'd do a great job. Check your Pano or
Excellence - they all advertise there.  
Want to cut this off - sent this to all for info/discussion -don't want the
P-nuts thinking I am feeding spam/snake/ and all the good (bad?) stuff.
One man's opinion on oil flow.....am sure you will get others.
Good Luck.
George
50 Cpe
57 GS S/R
61 Roadster
65 C Cab


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 20:18:34 -0500
From: RobVial@aol.com
Subject: re:K-Mart Quality (gasoline)

Bob356@aol.com says:
"... In short, gasoline is gasoline, and it has very little to do with
brands...."

This is partly true.  Most major refiners and their marketers freely trade
the lesser quality gasolines (regular and mid-grade) over the open market.
 For instance, if you purchase 87 octane gasoline at a Shell station, there
is no guarantee that the gasoline was refined by Shell.

On the other hand, most major refiners do not trade their premium quality
gasoline.  The premium gasoline sometimes goes through more rigorous refining
processes and most times has a better additive package blended in.  I can say
for sure that Amoco Ultimate (Clear) is this way.  It is rerun through a
distillation process to remove any color bodies to make it clear and their
best additive package is blended in.  Amoco Ultimate is only sold by Amoco.

This issue should not make much difference to all of us anyhow since we
should all be using the premium brands from major refiners.  So yes, gasoline
is gasoline, if you buy the good stuff.

Rob
1989 944S2 (Still not Zymoled. Tons of landscaping though.)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 20:31:47 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911 Suspension Bushing Advice

Dirk Bergstrom writes:

>Is this a worthwhile thing to spend my time and money on, or should
>I just put it in the bank and wait?  Will I get any measurable
>improvement in performance from new bushings?  Do I need to go to
>the hard squeaky race bushings, will new factory stuff be useful, or
>is there a happy medium?  Is the installation a complete bear, do I 
>need arcane tools?

>Am I nuts?  Is there a God?  Does she drive a Porsche?  Do Bart's 
>blue pills help?

IMHO, I would put the money in the bank.  If anything, invest in 
"driver upgrades".  Even if you are truly ready to start upgrading the
suspensions components (your capabilities exceed the cars'), 
I would bank the money and develop a "plan" of modifications 
designed to achieve the performance you want.  Then have fun
modifying the car!!!

Is installation a bear?  It can be.  Read my article in the Oct '94
Excellence to get some insight into the fun involved in replacing
your spring plate bushings...  :>)

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 17:44:31 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Vibration from 1st starting on 944

|   '84 944 with 58K
|   Needs your help on vibratiion from 1st starting engine:

|   engine, the engine speed is around 650rpm at first.

exactly these symptoms which new mounts cured.

    Eric

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 17:51:33 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 E-mounts

| From:  <Bob_M_Pachman_at_HRC-Mail@ccmail.howmet.com>
| To:  <PORSCHEPHILES@tta.com>
|
| Hi P-Filers,
|     I,m sorry if this is a FAQ but is there a *simple* way to replace 
the motor
| mounts in a 944. The factory manual tells you to take lots of stuff 
apart but it
| looks to me like there is room to *sneek* the mounts out one side at 
a time with
| some well calibrated supporting and jacking.

The mounts are a very tight fit into the crossmember. The mount has a 
bolt fixed to
the bottom of it. If it had a threaded recess instead, they would be 
much easier to
install. I had to loosen both mounts and lift the engine as high as it 
would go (until
the torque tube hit the tunnel) and unbolt both ends of the crossmember. Then
with a prybar to pull the crossmember down I was able to work the motor 
mount in.

You have to do *everything* the factory manual says. There is no easy way out.
OTOH, it is a fairly straightforward unbolt/rebolt sort of operation. 
If you check the
archives you will see that several folks including myself have relayed their
experiences doing the motor mount thing.

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 17:56:50 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: how much work? 944 Clutch

| From: Andre Rotchel  <lmcanro@LMC.Ericsson.SE>
|
| I was wondering how many hours of work is
| involved in changing a worn out the clutch
| on a 944 '86 ? How much does it cost ?

Lots of work. The tranny needs to be moved back (90% of
the work of dropping the trans). You should figure in excess
of a kilobuck.

| - Other than slippage while in gear,
| are symptoms like having a hard
| times putting in gear related to the clutch
| being worn out or is it a seperate problem
| altogether?

I believe these are rubber centered clutches and when the
rubber breaks up, parts get wedged in between the disk
and the pressure plate or flywheel. This makes it very hard
to shift.

Thank godness the prior owner had the dealer do the clutch
shortly before he sold it to me!

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 18:04:57 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Swirls in Paint

| From: Darren Foo  <badkarma@unix.infoserve.net>
| To:  <porschephiles@tta.com>
|
|        I will be getting a maroon 944T but the swirls in the paint just bug
| the heck out of me! I'm not too sure how this happens but I see a lot of
| black cars with these swirls (oxidation or something?. Anywayz, the car also
| has the regular paint chips found on an 8 year car... but my question is:
| can I remove the swirls and also paint up the chips? Also, there are places
| like diamond coat and mirror finish wihch costs up to 600bux. I've seen
| really crummy cars come out looking REALLY nice... but I'm pretty skeptical
| and $600 is quite a lot for touching up. Any suggestions?

Meguiar's sells a polishing compound called, strangely enough, Swirl
Remover. Using it requires either an electric polisher or some elbow
grease. In fact, I'd stay away from an electric polisher unless you had
some guidance; you can do significant paint damage if not careful.

Porsche sells touch up paint that you can use on the rock chips. Get the
paint code off of the sticker between the rear hatch latches and go to the
dealer.

I don't know for a fact but suspect that places like Diamond Coat are
bogus (a.k.a. cash flow devices).

    Eric

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 21:30:58 -0500
From: Hultgrenho@aol.com
Subject: paintless dent removal

Regarding the paintless dent removers, 
In my klutziest of all time klutz moves, one winter I opened the door of the
911 too fast and it dented the side of the 944S which was parked alongside in
the garage.  (Seems it was a pure act of jealousy, as the 944S was slated to
supplant the 911 as the owner's number one driver).  Come spring, I had the
dent removed in Hartford at the Dent Somebodyorothers by a young man who I
figured was going to really mess up my car and the paint.  It is now 3-4
years later and I can't even remember which side of the car was dinged!
And of course two years later, while manuevering with my heavy briefcase
trying to get in the car with a cup of java, I proceeded to whap the corner
of the briefcase into the passenger side door -- major ding --.  Took it
right down to Dent whatzamagizzards and they made this one disappear also.  
Both cost me less than $100.  Neither have been communicated to lovely
spouse.  I highly recommend the process.
- --Lon Hultgren
87 944S
(previous owner of 911T, 356C and 911 - star of the story.)

Date: 28 Mar 95 18:33:36 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: 911 flares on early car


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  911 flares on early car
Date: 1995-03-28 14:54
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Mike Dayton asks:

>Can anybody give me a ballpark figure for the costs associated with
>adding SC flares to an earlier car.  My '76 is going to need paint one
>of these days and I would love to put some decent-sized tires on the

Depending on how "right" you want the job, costs will be commensurate.  I
had estimates of $500 - $2000 to put SC flares on the '72.   I decided on a
fairly cheap job that included fitting/welding the flares closing up the
exhaust cutout in the rear valance, installing the used side bumpers I
bought (with extensions) and painting/undercoating all, also had the lower
rocker area painted and the non-S style deco trim installed.  Total for this
was $850 and the job is fair at best (I plan on getting the whole car
re-painted -- someday).

The flares themselves will cost you $100 to $250 (I got mine in a trade, so
they were pretty much free). Look in Pano want ads for these. You also need
to modify the bumpers with extensions, I think Twinks has these for $100 or
so -- installation (welding) extra.  So total for a cheap job and parts
might be a kilobuck.  IMHO I'd wait til you are going to do the whole car
and the shop will probably throw in some of the work anyway, plus it'll all
look "right" (in contrast to my "4 shades of white" car -- who cares, it's
faasst).

>thing.  I would also be interested in opinions on whether or not adding
>flares to an earlier car (assuming it is done right) hurts the car's
>value.

Unless you're talking an early E or S body, which has some extra value as an
original keeper, a modified T might even fetch *more* money (there's quite a
few folks looking for early cars to make fast).

 -Scott Jessen

'72 911 -- put flares on, then cut 'em up for bigger wheels.  the things we
do to be competitive...
'84 911 -- poor thing had it's front fenders rolled this weekend -- I think
he's mad at me
S.O. -- I *know* she's mad at me -- I just don't know *why*
3 cats -- one of which is *usually* mad at me
1 dog -- *never* is mad at me



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 18:31:58 -0800
From: cjk50g@ix.netcom.com (Christopher Woodward)
Subject: RE: how much work?  944 clutch

>I was wondering how many hours of work is 
>involved in changing a worn out the clutch
>on a 944 '86 ? How much does it cost ?

Hi Andre,

944 clutch replacement takes considerable time.  My first 
and only time took approx. 3 10hr days (so, I didn't have
a life, but I learned how to do 944 clutches).  This is really
one of those jobs that will take the first timer quite a 
while (I'd bet the second time would be well w/in a weekend).
You'll want to have someone whose done the job whom you can
call, real time, when you're stuck.  The full proceedure would 
eat up some serious bandwidth here, but it should be available 
in the archives.  The archive is available through FTP.  Type
tta.com, get connected and search the porschephiles public 
files for 9-4_968.faq.  Oh, and also, don't make the mistake of 
thinking the factory manual and the Haynes alone are what you'll
need.  There are gross omissions in each, the only difference 
being Porsche AG suggesting theirs were, ROFL, "common mechanical
knowlege".

The going price for a clutch package (includes clutch plate,
pressure plate and throw out bearing) is around $500 (U.S.) if you 
shop around.

Chris
944S

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 22:38:50 -0500
From: PMLetter@aol.com
Subject: Re: refinishing wheels

Thak wrote
>Is it possible to refinish polished Fuchs wheels to their original satin
>finish? Any idea of the cost involved?

Yes, and, as mentioned in a previous response from Pete the going rate is
about $150 per wheel (plus shipping) for stripping, re-anodizing, painting,
etc at the well known wheel polishing/restoring services advertised in most
Pcar publications.  For this price, you get a wheel that looks original.

I'm working with a company now that I think can match the quality of the
'name' wheel companies, but get the job done for about $105 - $110 per wheel
plus shipping.  I have some early Fuchs wheels being restored now and if they
come back looking right, I'll be offering this service thru Porsche Market
Letter.  If 'the list' would like to know, I'll post the results and how to
get wheels restored after the test cases have been finished.  Remember, this
is for restoration, not just polishing of the wheel.  Polishing will probably
be available too, for a lesser amount per wheel.

Phil VanBuskirk, PMLetter@aol.com

...Bill

At this time a year, television producers are planning for the new season
even as they are finishing the current one. One of the reasons that
MotorWeek went on line with Compuserve was to be able to get direct input
from our viewers, and those that might become our viewers. So, here goes.

If you could program MotorWeek, what would you show to entice millions of
car nuts, and just plain people that live with cars, to watch? Now, it has
to be car related, and legal, and oh yes, in good taste?

we can't test just exotics, what would make YOU watch every week? Would you
change the format, the order in which segments are presented?

We'd love to hear from everyone on this. All of your answers will be logged
and considered. Even the corny ones!

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 20:39:52 -0800 (PST)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: re: 911 oil tank bolt

Hi all -

A friend just called to ask my advice on repairing the threaded hole that 
drains the 911 oil reservoir.  Seems previous owner of the car had put 
some rubbery (my guess silicon) on it to seal it.  When my friend changed 
the oil recently he couldn't get it to seal.  So he removed the drain 
plugged again and tried teflon tape.  Now this wasn't to bad until he 
tried what he says the book says (95 foot pounds?) on it.  Wrong.  It now 
doesn't tighten at all.  I know the correct thing is to replace the tank, 
but short of that is there anything else like rethreading with an 
oversize bolt?  Does the hole in the tank make the threads when they 
punch the hole in (like turning in the sheetmetal) during manufacturing 
or is there a nut welded into the bottm of the tank?

What's the groups wisdom on this?  Any help would be appreciated.  And 
yes, I told him to recheck that 95 foot pound figure (I would guess more 
like 9.5 foot pounds on this bolt).

Mike Lommatzsch

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 00:30:22 -30000
From: David Holmes <delphys@ocean.bunyip.com>
Subject: (long) 1959 356A - or how i spent my weekend.

If you're not too interested in 356s or stories of love found and then 
lost again, you may want to skip this one.

First off, many thanks to the folks (Denny, George, Denis, Peter, Robert, 
and Daniel - thanks!) who responded to my request for opinions about a 
356A I was considering.

The ad appears in the May issue of Excellence for a 1959 356A Normal Coupe
(technically a '58 i think); needing restoration - asking $5500 US.

General concensus was, given my brief description after speaking with 
the owner on the phone, that this price was a little high.  It was also 
suggested that there was probably more wrong with the car than just the 
floor.

I live in Montreal and the car is located on the Niagara peninsula - a
good 6-7 hour drive.  Did some visiting and touring and made a weekend of
it - the weather was great for a drive.


The person who invents magnetic bondo will probably make a killing.

The floor was worse than gone - it had taken part of the front of the
center tunnel with it, the "front pedal area" wasn't, and the lower side
of the sills (outer long.'s) was just gone.  This in and of itself didn't
scare me quite as much as all the filler I started to find - doors,
fenders, quarters, front end, hood (hmmm - some minor crumpling there
too...). Also the last bit of work that had been done was a pop-rivet and
braze job. It was enough to bring tears to your eyes. The interim floor
had apparently been a sandwich of two inner sheets, one flat sheet across
the bottom, a handful of brazing rods and too many pop-rivets.  Also, the
inner rear panels (interior portions of the inner rear quarters - not sure
of the proper name; basically the sides of the jump seats) were rotted
right about where the rear closing panel joins in.  Then I had a look at
the torsion bar mounts. Or what was left of the driver's side mount. There
_is_ lots of good metal in the car but at this point I started to hear
porschephiles' voices in ernest.  And, it was just plain more work than I
was looking for.  It was educational to poke around in the shell with a
trouble light as the entire car is striped other than suspension and
steering and harnesses.  And to be honest I'd never seen an 'A' in the
flesh before. 

This car has water-logged-interior written all over it.  The owner
confirmed that the carpets had been soaked when he'd got it. It did have
some strong points though - the roof was fine, as were the doors (other
than skins on the bottom) which opened and closed without protest or fuss.
Door posts were solid as were headlight buckets and most of the frontend
structure other than battery box. All the upper regions of the body panels
were in good shape too. The engine looked better than my motorcycle's 
'79 triple.

The current owner has invested in a lot of new metal, trim, carpet, and
even chromed wheels - he's backed himself into a corner rather heavily. 
He was busy pulling box upon box down from the rafters;  longitudinals,
jack struts, braces, pedal assembly nut plate, floors, diagonal, towing
hook (with rivots even :-), new hub caps, lights, chrome - it was like
Christmas. They'd recently moved into their house so he disappeared inside
for a while and finally returned with heaps of the paper trail, going back
to original factory paperwork. 


Alas, it was much more work than I am ready to deal with.  I am planing to
do my own work but the price he was looking for and the realization that
even all the new metal that the owner has purchased wouldn't fix the all
the serious problems finally convinced me.  The bondo and rivets hurt. The
car is certainly in a salvagable state; it'll just take more money and
time and know-how than I have. I have to admit though, not being from the
more heavily 356-populated regions, that it was difficult to turn my back
and walk away, leaving open the potential for another rivet and brazer to
come along...

Even in a poor coat of black paint and its rear wheels on tip-toes, it was 
hard to deny that wonderful shape... 

Thanks for your indulgence; and thanks again to those who offered opinions
and help.

And if you know an A or pre-A that's tired but still metal and looking for
a good home, let me know... 

                                            --david
                                            delphys@bunyip.com

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 95 23:42:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re: PCA Club Racing - How Safe?


>Club Racing has a 13/13 rule -- if you bend anything, you're on suspension
>for 13 months; if during that time you repeat, you're *OUT* for 13 months.
>As a result, it's pretty safe relative to SCCA racing. Kevin -- any recent
>incidents come to mind that weren't the result of equipment failure??

Yes, it seems to be pretty safe and easy on the coachwork when
compared with SCCA, etc.  To my understanding, PCA club racers
expect by and large to leave the track with their cars in the same
shape they arrived, which is probably less true in SCCA.

The 13/13 rule seems to have worked pretty well.  There are a few bad
apples out of the series by virtue of it, and I cannot think of anyone in
the series who I would describe as "an accident waiting to happen."
Well, maybe one person...

There have been equipment failures and driver errors.  Hard to say
which mode dominates.

While sort of on the subject, I would add that the quality of Driver's Ed
events here in Zone 1 has risen markedly in the past few years.  It always
seemed pretty good to me, to begin with.  But nowadays, even the
regions which I used to think of as running a little looser than others,
have improved the quality of instruction, instructors, safety, etc.  Which
isn't to say that driver's ed (or racing) has gone pansy-ass, not the case
at all.

Kevin

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 02:33:55 -0500
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: 912 No Power below 2000 RPM

Dear Scott:

       There are several things that can cause a lack of Power below 2000
RPM. First of all, did you check your High Speed Timing? It's all well and
good that you have 3 deg BTDC at idle, but what happens after that?
Specifically, what is the timing at 3000+ RPM? Is the timing smoooooth up and
down or does it vary or "stick"? At a constant RPM, does the timing
vary/waver quite a bit?  And  what is your distributor number (last three
numbers)?
       Second, did you adjust the Idle Mixture Screws on the Webers. (There
are 4, one for each cylinder.) Did they all adjust nicely, like  they should,
or did one (or more) NOT adjust- i.e. if you screwed it in allllll the way,
did it not change the running of  the  engine much?  If so, this could
indicate a clogged idle jet, which could explain your problem. Another way to
tell if one carb is the problem is to drive on one carb only by disconnecting
the downcoming linkage rod to the carb. Yes, it'll drive poorly, but oughta
get up to 45-50 mph. If so, then try driving on the other carb. If one carb
will only get  to 25-30 mph, try disconnecting one plug wire on that side. If
you pull off  the bad one, the car will run the same as before. If you pull
off  the good one, the car won't move! This is my Binary Search technique
that in two tests allows you to find the one cylinder that's bad!
     Finally, you might well have a "high performance" cam inside that will
ALWAYS be weak at the low end ifin it's strong at the high end! That's the
penalty for a "high performance" cam- you get lots of high end power, but at
low RPM you don't have enough torque to pull  the proverbial skin off the
proverbial banana. (That's  why I like the cam grind we've  evolved over the
years- it has good low-end torque, but still pulls to 6000 rpm.)

Hope this helps.
KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
The Maestro

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 02:52:09 -0500
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: 912 Oil flow question

Dear Ted:
            You were almost right about the oil flow in a late 356/912. The
oil exits the pump and goes first to a "bypass" valve whose plunger, when the
engine is first started, gets pushed "down" by oil pressure,  exposing the
oil passageway leading directly  to the bearings. Once oil pressure is
established throughout the engine, this bypass valve plunger gets pushed
"up", forcing the oil to go through the oil cooler. (The oil filter on a
356/912 is a bypass filter whose oil flow is controlled by the approx. 1/16"
hole in the bolt  that holds the oil filter inlet line (going  to the oil
filter can) to  the Junction Block. The resulting flow rate is not huge.)
       The best full-flow system IMHO takes the oil off a specially machined
oil pump cover, to the remote full-flow oil filter and/or remote oil cooler,
and returns the oil to the left hand  side of the Third Piece of the Case,
 where a soft plug has been installed by  the factory to plug a drilled oil
passageway. The soft plug must be removed and the area welded to beef it up
and drilled/tapped to fit the oil lines you are using. This puts all the ugly
full-flow  stuff under the engine and not up on top. The topside then looks
nicely stock, which is nice.
      Note however, that you must  also PLUG the outlet oil passageway
leading from the oil pump, or your  expensive full-flow filter system becomes
a bypass one once again! (And please note- use a nicely-designed plug to plug
the oil pump outlet- one that  won't come out and  take a suicide plunge into
the teeth of the oil pump gears, causing the gears to try to digest the plug,
which causes the drive tang of the oil pump gear to break off,  which causes
NO oil pressure nor flow, which causes  very rapid seizure of the  whole
shebang.  And she go SheBANG!  (There are a couple examples of just this type
of failure in the Broken Parts Collection of the Maestro's Museum!  Broken
oil pump drive gear tangs, and the wayward, poorly-installed suicidial plug.)
 KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
The Maestro

From: Trond Vidar Olsen <Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no>
Subject: Tar paper glue for 356

Hiall,

Slowly finding time to finish my '58 project. It's time to put sound
absorbing material into the car.

What I'm doing is;
Based on correct patterns I'm making 'mats' from tar paper (outdoor
quality(?)) 

I have ~2mm paper and will have to glue 2 similar pieces together. 

I'm planning to install one 2 mm piece, then glue a similar 2 mm piece
to it *in correct position*. This should ensure that the shape and
form of the laminated mat is correct.

I've also dug up somebodys  grandma's special baking tool which is to
be rolled over the mat to give almost similar (...better than none.)
impressions as the mats originally have.

Scissors, heating gun, patterns, halfmask with filters, and glue. That
should do the job?

By the way, any suggestions for real sticky glue for this job? Any
comments?

cheers,
Trond V.

sound absorber mats from ordinary tar paper.

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 95 07:57:45 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: 914 cam goes "negative"

>         I agree that it doesn't make sense that the cam would have
> "negative" areas on it.

Sensible or not, there are some British lumps for which the power setup
involves more-than-stock valve clearance. The power increase is measureable.
The explanation that I have seen for this is that it causes the initial
valve lift to be more aggressive, at some cost in cam & valvetrain life.
I can see that a slight increase in valve clearance just before takeup
might have a similar effect for a 914.


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 08:18:35 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re:  re:K-Mart Quality (gasoline)

Rob says, "This is partly true...."

No, no, no, no.  I ALWAYS tell the truth.  As Kato Kaelin says, "I wouldn't
lie for any amount of money." 

"Most major refiners and their marketers freely trade the lesser quality
gasolines (regular and mid-grade) over the open market. For instance, if you
purchase 87 octane gasoline at a Shell station, there is no guarantee that
the gasoline was refined by Shell.  On the other hand, most major refiners do
not trade their premium quality gasoline...." 

But, then, a wise old engineering professor once told me, "When you use the
word "always", you're probably going to be wrong occasionally.  Amoco is
somewhat of an anomoly in this situation, Rob: you are correct in saying
gasoline with their brand is indeed from Amoco refineries.  However, you can
be sure that ALL branded gasolines meet the specifications for that brand,
whatever that may be, whatever their grade, and from wherever they may come.
 The point, however, is that gasolines sold at the discount stations and
convenient marts almost always meet the same standards and come from the very
same refineries that supply the big boys (yes, even Amoco's refinery...see
Stan's "Business 301" lesson).  You just don't know which of the big boys'
gasoline you're getting, and it may be different from week to week (depending
upon market prices at the wholesale terminal).

"...This issue should not make much difference to all of us anyhow since we
should all be using the premium brands from major refiners...."

Whatever strokes you best.  Using gasoline from a specific major refiner was
important several years ago if you wanted to keep your injectors and valves
clean, but today all the major brands have comparable additives (albeit with
some differences) so it's much less important to be picky.  That's good news
for the consumer, since what you get at the corner convenient mart is just as
good as what you get at the corner Texaco.

"...I can say for sure that Amoco Ultimate (Clear) is this way.  It is rerun
through a distillation process to remove any color bodies to make it
clear...." 

No, Rob, it is not rerun through anything to get it that way.  ALL gasoline
is colorless when it's refined, whatever its grade or origin...the color
comes from dyes that are added to differentiate grades for the consumer (a
practice begun years ago to prevent dishonest dealers from selling regular
for premium!)

Those marketers and ad agencies have got you for sure.  Run, run, run.


Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S  

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 08:18:26 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Problem with mounting 914 rear wheels

David says, and Andrew agrees, "...hold up the wheel, start one bolt (the
long kind!), wiggle the wheel into place so's I can put a second bolt in, and
that holds the wheel pretty much in place.  Two more bolts go on
finger-tight, make the first two finger-tight, then go 'round (opposite
corners) with the
torque wrench.  94 ft-lbs, I believe.  About 1/4 to 1/2 turn each pass,
until the wrench goes "click".  No problems.

"That's exactly what I do. Perhaps I'm not using the right "lubricant" on
the seats where the wheel meets the bolt(s) -- any suggestions?"

Though probably not related to Andrew's problem, it helps to rotate the wheel
as you finger-tighten those bolts (or nuts, if you are mounting a wheel
having studs).  This prevents the wheel from being pinched "off-center" by
the conical surface of the bolt (nut) and ensures that it mounts properly.
 Watch your fingers, however, as the wheel shifts just enough when doing this
to give you a nasty blood-blister!

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 09:02:57 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: Removing 911 starter

Alisdair writes:
=========

I am trying to remove the starter motor from an 89 911 Carrerra as the
positive lead between the solenoid and the motor has corroded.
 
The trouble is that I can't remove the upper of the two Allan keyed bolts which
hold it on.
 
The lower bolt was not too hard to reach but the upper one is very close to
the underside of the rear seats - I just can't get the wrench onto it. 

Anyone got any ideas (bar removing the engine).

cheers
Alisdair Craig
=================

Alisdair:
	I too found that removing the upper hex bolt was difficult. But, I foundout that I was doing it wrong!

I was trying to remove the upper bolt from the starter side. The best way I 
found was to lay right in the center of the car (after securely lifting the
car... Jackstand, etc!). I then wrapped my left hand around the trans (feet
towards the rear) to stabilize the wrench. My right hand, forearm, armpit 
would then go around the right (driver's) side with the wrench. You kind of
have to hug your trans ( Hey what better way to bond with your baby?).

Note, some penetrating oil should help in removing the bolt. Also make sure
that you are aplying torque and pressure at right angles. You don't want to
strip that baby. I don't know whay the Professor has chosen to use that kind
of bolt there...

And finally, disconnect your battery! One of the starter terminals gets juice
at all times!

Hope this helps!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories     len@library.att.com	   201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa  / '85 Guards Red 944
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo / '88 Silver BMW 325is

Date: 29 Mar 1995 10:24:07 -0500
From: "Elliot Entin" <elliot.entin@alphatech.com>
Subject: Re: 911 Battery Size - Chang

Mail*Link(r) SMTP               RE>911 Battery Size - Change It?

You Wrote:
____________________
Okay, guys and gals (Hi, Bev), this may have come up before.  The Group 49
size battery in most P-cars is an expensive lil' booger mostly 'cause of its
size and "limited" availability.  So if I get the proper brackets and change
to, say a Group 24 size battery I already know I don't necessarily give up
amps but I do give up a few pounds of weight in the front end.

Are those pounds significant?  Will a couple of free weights make up for it?
Are there more important concerns in weight/balance front/rear ratios?  Will
there be a seminar at the Parade? Bruce, Maestro, Stan - are you listening?
____________________
Have you considered an OPTIMAC battery.  They are lighter and smaller than a
standard Porsche battery with a much higher amp/hr density.  They are
completely sealed and can be mounted in any position including upside down. 
They list for about $100.  I have heard they can be bought for about $80+. 
The award winning Ohio U. electric race car uses these batteries.

Elliot.

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 08:59:44 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: HELP! 914 wont start!@#$

Hi Alan:

I had a lot of trouble with my '74 914 2.0 starting (basically, everything
would work except solenoid wouldn't pull in, hence no start, and ultimately
it became totally unpredictable) until I did two things -- put in a "remote
starter relay" GM-style, and disconnected the seat-belt interlock thingy
under the seats.  

The remote relay was absolutely necessary despite everything else being in
perfect order.  The tell-tale sign was that the voltage at the solenoid was
dropping to around 8 volts, and the drop was somewhere between the battery
and the "entrance" to the relay box. Since then (1 yr) I've never had
afailure-to-start.

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 10:07:20 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: HELP! 914 wont start!@#$

Sounds like you have the 914 bad ground problem. Ck all of the battery 
cables for corrosion and wear tear.

There should be a ground strap from the rear of the trasn the body. Take 
this off and clean the mounting points.

Pull all the cables loose and clean ck etc.


					mike

Also could be a bad starter or solenoid.

		



- -- 
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 10:11:48 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: More help for the anxious.

To find a good porsche takes time. Ck with the independent Porsche shops 
in your area. Ck with the porsche club in San Diego. 

No matter where you find the dream car have it cked out by an 
independent Porsche mechanic. This will cost 200-300 and is well worth 
the price. Plus the "laundry" list will give you baraining power with 
the  seller.

Paperwork is important but not always necessary.

I do not recomend any savage title porsches if you plan to resell in the 
future. To be savage it was totalled by the insurance company and 
someone somewhere has rebuilt it most likely for sale. 

Try and get copies of the porsche market newsletter this is also a good 
source for porsches. 


						mike

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 95 10:17:29 
From: da@airsoft.com
Subject: Re: Depressed


     G'day Bob,
     
     firstly, don't be so depressed!  I used to own an '83 944 and some 
     problems with oil starting to look like chocolate milk.  This the 
     "mixing" problem.
     
     You probably don't have a cracked case or blown gasket or anything 
     that catastrophic.  Your engine has an oil/water intercooler that is 
     located on the right side of the case, beneath the exhaust header.  
     The intercooler is inside of a small cast aluminum housing that bolts 
     to the case.  The seals (o-rings) that seal (and separate) the oil 
     passages against the water jacket harden and go bad over time.  This 
     allows the coolant to enter the oiling system.  You will need to 
     purchase the oil/water intercooler repair/update kit (includes the 
     latest seals, a green color instead of red and a new oil/water 
     intercooler housing gasket) to be able to repair this yourself.  I 
     ordered mine from Zim's and it was not too expensive.  Now for the bad 
     part:  since your oil already looked like chocolate milk, bearings 
     will have probably been damaged, esp. since the engine warning light 
     came on and the engine overheated, you (IMHO) will at least need to 
     replace the bottom end bearings.  This can be done (except for the 
     foremost and aftmost bearings, I believe) with the engine still in the 
     car.  I did'nt replace my bearings because my "mixing" problem did not 
     get that bad when I repaired the oil cooler problem.
     
     Hope this helps.  Good luck!
     
     Derek Au


______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________

gasket.  Worst case, a cracked block.

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 95 10:56:53 PST

Subject: Speedometer/Odometer Error


Friends-

Now that I have my restored '72 911E on the road, I've 
found a few small, but annoying problems.  Here's the 
first...

The speedometer and odometer are both off,  almost 
exactly 10% low.  I've verified this with time and distance 
trials on a marked section of highway.  It's also obvious 
that I'm not going as slow as the speedometer says, and 
that my mileage to work can't have suddenly dropped 
from 17(in all my other cars)  to around 15 (in this one).

On the other hand, the tachometer/gear ratio relationship 
seems right on, in that the calculated speeds, e.g. 50 mph 
in 4th at 2900 rpm, seem to be exactly right.  Using this 
example, the speedometer would read about 45, the 
tach/gear ratio says it should be 50, and the highway 
distance/time test says it is 50.

I've taken apart the speedo, and it looks fine.  I've verified 
that it is the correct speedo for my car.  It's part number 
and the one in the parts manual agree.  My tires are 
correct for the car, 185/70 15".  This model also came with 
14" wheels in a 'comfort package', so it is possible my 
transmission has the correct speedo drive for 14" wheels, 
even though I have 15" wheels mounted.  But even then, 
the error would only be about 4%, and it's definitely 
bigger than that. More than twice as great.

Any ideas?  Thanks, as always.

Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa (going a lot faster than it is)

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 95 11:12:15 
From: da@airsoft.com
Subject: Re: Tar paper glue for 356


     Hi Trond,
     
     I went through what you're going though, one year ago.  I found that 
     3M Super Trim Spray Adhesive is by far the one with the strongest 
     adhesion.  Be prepared to use up several cans though!  With tar paper, 
     I used two very light coats of spray adhesive, the heat gun to soften 
     the tar in the tar paper then pressed the stuff on with my hands.
     
     Did you know that on the Karmann built bodies, the tar paper had no 
     dimpling or waffling?  It was smooth.  On some Reutter bodies, the 
     waffled (and sometimes dimpled) tar paper was used throughout the car 
     and then there were some cars (I have seen one example of this) where 
     the waffled (and sometimes dimpled) material was used only in the 
     engine and passenger compartments but the material used in the trunk 
     was smooth!!  See if you can explain that one!  BTW, thats how I have 
     my '64 SC (Reutter built body) set up.
     
     Derek Au
