Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 15:19:57 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 cam goes "negative"


Dear Dave, John, William and all,

Let me qualify. We all know that the base circle of the cam is uniform even
on well worn cams. However, with the multi-piece lifter pushrod rocker arm
valve adjusting lug assembly, lift angles and hard-to-reach-and-feel valve
adjust, it is easy to miscalculate the clearance, and when you turn the
engine over several times and things readjust and settle, the clearance is
different, usually wider. This is what we call "going negative" as what you
thought was proper clearance gets wider as the assembly moves. This is a
common occurance and re-emphasizes the point that proper valve adjust and
recheck is critical!

It is also very important to make sure that the adjusting lugs are in good
shape and that the pushrods are firmly seated in the lifter and rocker arms.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 15:21:18 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: HELP! 914 wont start!@#$


Dear Alan,
You wrote:
>Lately, my '73 1.7 has been giving me more trouble than normal.  After
>a reasonable drive (greater than) 15 minutes, the car wont restart!
>The car has always had a starter problem since I got it (10/94) (no flames
>please, I know that this was a bad call ... now), but this was solved by
>connecting a button which went between 30 and 50.  Now, even the button 
>doesn't work.  I hear the fuel pump when I turn the ignition on, and when
>I press the button, I hear a click, but that's it.  I can roll start it.
>And, after a good while, (over 1-2 hours) I can start it with the button.
>One thing, that I've noticed is that when it's giving me trouble, and I
>turn the ignition on, the red light on the left (coil?) does not come on
>whereas it does ususally.  The green light on the right (alternator?) does
>still come on.  

>Can someone please help me start my car?  I'm hoping to take it to Vegas
>in a weak and I'll be devistated if I can't drive through the sunny
>desert with the top off.

>Piles and piles of thanks in advance!

>alan

Starter problems (actually "cranking") are easily solved. Here is the
procedure:
     1. Make sure battery is fully charged, both negative and positive
battery connections are clean and tightly connected and transmission ground
strap to body is clean and tightly connected.
     2. Remove the yellow clip on solenoid lead and insert a test light. Have
an assistant turn the key to start. If the test light lights, proceed to step
5. If the test light fails to light, proceed to step 3 and/or 4.
     3. On '74 and early '75 models, move the passenger seat forward and
repeat the test light procedure on the large yellow and large yellow and red
leads entering and exiting the seatbelt interlock relay (they may have been
long ago connected together, however, by dealer recall). If the test light
lights on one side and not on the other, cut the wires and connect together.
If neither light the test light, go to step 4.
     4. Connect the test light to the large yellow wire exiting the back of
the ignition switch and again conduct the test light procedure. If the light
fails to light, free the ignition switch from the steering column and conduct
the test using a screwdriver in the switch as your key. If the light lights,
replace the key/tumbler assembly. If the light fails to light, replace the
switch.
     5. Short across the clip on solenoid male connector and the large
starter nut where the main cable is connected. If the starter engages,
install a Bosch hot-start kit. If the starter fails to engage, replace the
starter.

Remember, the above procedure assumes the items in step 1 are covered.

Additionally, the yellow solenoid lead wire sometimes loses voltage between
the ignition switch and the solenoid. Check the connections at the seatbelt
interlock ('74-early '75 models only) and the front and rear relay board
connections for corrosion.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 15:21:20 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 bucks


Dear Matt,
you wrote:
<In the brief hour I had to drive my newly acquired 914 before I had to 
<catch a flight to the east coast the car ran fairly well, but at times it 
<would buck quite violently. This was on freeway driving, and accelerating 
<seemes to make it go away. It got better as it warmed up, but even after 
<an hour on the freeway it still did it on occasion. The car had sat for a 
<few months before i bought it, and the tailpipe had a signifigant amount 
<of soot built up. I would assume this means it's running rich and the 
<(assumed) poor condition of the plugs is leading to misfiring. Similarly, 
<sometimes the car would suddenly seem to loose a little power which would 
<come back when I accelerated. 
 <I'm going to be back in town fow two days before I have to leave 
<again and I'm hoping in this time to get it running good so I can get it 
<all registered and such. My plan is to replace the sparkplugs and see 
<what that does, but judging from the tailpipe it's running quite rich. Is 
<there a quick fix for this or should I wait till my manuals arrive and 
<work on it then? This is a 1970 with the 1.7 BTW. It's got around 80k 
<miles on it and within the past year it's had a valve job and had the 
<injection control box replaced.
 <Thanks in advance.

<Matt

Considering that everything is in spec., it sounds like you have a throttle
switch pressure sensor problem. The 2.0 914 models and '73 1.7 models are
notorious for it, the '70-'72 1.7 models occasionally. The throttle switch is
tested by disconnection. Mounted on the bottom of the throttle body, the
switch enrichens the mixture upon initial acceleration and shuts off the
injectors when the throttle is closed and until the idle circuit takes over.
The bucking is caused by a worn switch suddenly, without warning, shutting
off the injectors. By disconnecting the switch plug and driving, the bucking
should go away. (However, you may experience a hesitation upon initial
acceleration and a "popping" in the exhaust when the throttle closes.

The manifold pressure sensor, which looks like a hand grenade or small
pineapple, is mounted on a triangular stand on the right firewall behind the
battery. It senses manifold vacuum and then signals the control unit to
increase or decrease the duration of injection. The engine vacuum moves a
diaphragm in this device and the more vacuum, the more the diaphragm moves:
 High vacuum (idle) shorter duration; low vacuum (full throttle), longer
duration.

When the pressure sensor fails, the diaphragm usually breaks and engine
vacuum will not move it. So, at all engine vacuum conditions, there is a
longer duration of injection and therefore an extremely rich mixture at hot
idle. (You may actually find the car to run better when cold and at full
throttle!)

The simple test is to evacuate the sensor. If it holds 16" of vacuum forever,
it is good. If a vacuum cannot be drawn, or it leaks off, it is bad and needs
replacement. (If you do not have a vacuum pump, you simply can suck on the
sensor and draw a vacuum (like sucking on a coke bottle). The sensor should
hold your tongue without leaking! Replace as follows:
70-72 1.7 0280 100 049
73-74 2.0 0280 100 037
75-76 2.0 0280 100 043

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 15:19:41 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: what tires for my 914?


<Thanks to all who answered my questions re car stereo.

<Now: What's the best tire to put on my 914? It has the Fuchs <wheels. What's
<the widest tire you can put on the wheel? Fit in the wheel wells? I <know
next
<to nothing about tires, so I'd appreciate any general advice about <tires,
as
<well.

<On my previous 914 I had Yokohama 195/60s, and I liked both the <performance
<and the look.

<David

Dear David,

The best overall tire size for the 5-1/2x15 factory wheel is a 195/65x15. We
like Yokahamas (and evidently the factory does also. My 94 Speedster came
shod with them!). This tire size fits the wheel width perfectly, provides
good performance and clears the rear fender wells!

George Hussey

Porschephiles #1284                         Wed Mar 29 19:40:37 CST 1995
Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 15:24:09 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Problem with mounting 914-4 rear wheels


Dear Andrew,
you wrote:
<I have a question about mounting the _rear_ wheels on a 914-4 ('74 2.0). I
<have factory Fuchs alloys with 195/50 VR15's. Perhaps someone has some
<insight ...

<The short of it is that I have difficulty getting the rear wheels properly
<centered on the rear hub/rotors.  They often end up noticeably off-center
<(I'm guessing .020" - .050" ), and this is very noticeable at highway
<speeds.  There's nothing wrong with the wheels themselves - they're well
<balanced and straight.  The fronts are fine and mount perfectly each time. 

<The only way I've found to get around this is to use a dial indicator and
<make lots of attempts at gradually tightening the wheel bolts until things
<are well centered.  Needless to say, this is very tiresome and
<time-consuming.

<Is there some trick to guarantee proper hub-centric mounting of the rear
<wheels on these cars? This is the only car I've ever encountered that
<doesn't have hubs/rotors that guarantee hubcentric wheel mounting.

Welcome to the club. 914s traditionally have had problems with wheel
centering and in 1973, the factory corrected the problem with the front by
building in a centering disc into the rotor. However, they never thought that
the rear balance was as important. Hence, we are stuck with slightly
miscentered wheels.

The proper procedure for rear wheel installation on a 914 is as follows:
1. Install wheel with lug bolts hand tightened.
2. Spin wheel by hand.
3. Put in gear and torque bolts to 20 ft.lbs.
4. Spin wheel by hand.
5. Put in gear and torque wheels to 50 ft.lbs.
6. Spin wheel by hand.
7. Put in gear and apply embrake. Torque wheels to 90 ft.lbs.

This is the best way we have found to center the rear wheels!

George Hussey

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 07:24:30 EST
From: Brian_Bonnick@mac.tsb-intl.ca
Subject: Re: 911 oil tank bolt

Mike,
I ran into the same problem that you describe re a leaky oil plug and
destroyed threads. 

 My solution may not be the most glamourous but it is effective.  I approached
a radiator shop and asked them to cut the old plug out and weld a new one in. 
The shop had no difficulty whatsoever finding a brass replacement drain plug
and female fitting  (7/8" dia). They not only welded/braised the plug in but
cleaned the oil reservoir in their degreasing tank of all its 20+ years of
grime (remove the sender unit first).
Total labour and materials cost me $40.00 CDN and after repainting the tanks
exterior myself only a knowledgeable eye could discern that any work had been
performed.  It has performed without problems now for the last two years.

Brian Bonnick
PCA of Upper Canada
74 911 targa ( fully restored)
75 911 targa (in need of CPR)

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 16:18:37 -0500 (EST)
From: "Derek Cahill" <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: RE: 911 Battery Size - Change It?

In message Wed, 29 Mar 1995 00:00:11 -0500, Carrera3@aol.com  writes:

> Are those pounds significant?  Will a couple of free weights make up for
> it? Are there more important concerns in weight/balance front/rear
> ratios?  Will there be a seminar at the Parade? Bruce, Maestro, Stan -
> are you listening?

No. Those pounds mean nothing... in fact, now that spring is here, I run one
battery only (because it can handle it during the warm weather). I can't
exactly tell you why they are not important, other than the fact that they
make up such a small percentage of the overall weight of the car. You don't
notice any significant performance loss/gain when carrying a passenger, do
you? Although in the middle of the car, the passenger weighs more and still
has no effect.

 -Derek Cahill

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 16:19:02 -0500 (EST)
From: "Derek Cahill" <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: BIG problem... small answer? (long)

Okay, here's the situation... I drove the '73 911T to pick my sister up at
school today (roughly 1 mile away)... I sat in the 'parent line' whilst
waiting for her for roughly 15-20 minutes with the car idling... after all
the nervous worrying (I'm 17 and the cops were watching me the whole way,
not to mention going to an elementary school with a Porsche [They were
meant to be driven, but not mangled by second-graders]) I journeyed back
home (I went roughly 20 miles an hour both ways)
When I got home, I stopped the car in the driveway to open the garage
door... In my stupidity, I stalled the car in the driveway. The driveway is
slightly inclined. Anyways, I tried to restart the car... the starter kept
doing its thing for a short while, but didn't start the engine. I turned it
off, waited for a minute, tried again... same thing. I tried several times,
holding the gas to the floor one time, trying with normal pressure another,
and no pressure, and a combination, but nothing... I got the battery
charger/starter out and plugged it in... same attempts did nothing. (The
battery power was there though, all the lights glowed bright as ever and the
amp didn't pop the speakers like it does when the battery is nearing death.)
I finally figured that maybe it was a hot start problem and went inside to
wait and be pissed at the car. (I turned the battery charger/starter off)

After a short while, about 5 minutes, I went outside again and tried.
Nothing on the first attempt, then I smelled gasoline, so I intelligently
pressed the gas all the way down and started it. It fired up just like
normal.

This has happened several (5) times. All were on a slight incline, with the
engine below the rest of the car. If I wait for it to cool down a little, I
ALWAYS get the smell of gasoline after the first failure, but on the second
try, it ALWAYS starts!

Is this just some unique part of this car's personality, or is there some
fuel hose somewhere that is strange? I've been driving this car for two
years now and have had this problem on occasion, but until today, I just
forgot about it.
 -Derek Cahill

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 95 16:24:08 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Brake disk slots

I am looking for information on slotting OEM brake disk rotors. By
slotting, I refer to a set of several shallow grooves in the face
of the disk, to relieve gas pressures, etc. A friend of mine who is 
taking the next step in track preparation on his street/track 1984
911 Carrera asked me if I could do this for him on my Bridgeport
mill, using a new set of rotors. I don't mind doing it, but I want to
make sure I know what I am doing. Therefore, I have some questions.

 - I assume I want a shallow groove with a round bottom, to avoid
stress concentrations. What size ball mill should I use, and how
deep should I cut? I'm guessing that something like a 1/4" D. ball
mill, and 0.040" deep (~1 mm) would be good choices.

 -The disk itself is cast iron, or at least something relatively
machinable?

 - I am planning to cut 3 grooves, equally spaced around the circumfrence,
with each groove tangent to the "hat" in the center and extending
all of the way to the outer edge. The grooves will be straight, rather
than the involutes or whatever I have seen on some grooves (the mill is 
not NC). Does the direction of the grooves relative to the wheel rotation
matter?

 - Is my understanding accurate that this is relatively safe, compared
to drilling OEM rotors, in terms of the probability of generating
cracks? (my umbrella insurance is up to date, just in case)

 - Is there anything else I should know?

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 16:29:03 -0500
From: ACBRISTOL@aol.com

>Subj:	What type of adhesive for sound deadening pad?
>Date:	95-03-29 10:41:34 EST

>From: root@patrick.mdn.com (Pat Roberson)

>Fellow Pfiles and Distinguished PCA Members,

>As I finish installing a new clutch and put the motor back in the SC >this 
>weekend I will be replacing the sound deadening pad.  Question, >what type
>of adhesive does the almighty list recommend to secure the pad to >the
>"firewall"?



 Pat:


I asked the same question when I was getting ready to replace mine.
A local P repair shop told me they use some stuff they  call called    "
BULL'S SNOT",  however,  I did not want to go hunting for a bull so I used 3M
Super Spray Adhesive . Comes in a spray can, one can is plenty, spray it on
the pad and the sheet metal than let it dry than put the pad in place.      I
had real good luck with this stuff.

BOB

1994 C2 SPEEDSTER
1957 ACBRISTOL

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 95 16:58:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re: Rebuilding brake calipers (914/6)


I always try to stick my fingers between the piston and opposite face
of the calliper before blasting.  Saves wear and tear on the pistons,
as well as the cost of black nail polish.

But seriously, I wear a face shield because things can go flying.  I
also drape a shop towel or two over the calliper to keep brake
fluid spray contained.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 95 16:54:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 E-mounts


Bob,

You don't have to remove the cross member.  You can raise the front
end of the motor enough by jacking on the P/S pump bracket.  Be
careful.  There is more thread on the new mount's stud than you need,
and trimming about 5 mm or so off it will make installation possible.

Kevin

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 17:29:12 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: 944 vs. 944 turbo

I owned both, an 83 944 and an 86 turbo. The turbo has 50% more hp. The end.

Actually, the turbo is also 200 pounds heavier than an early 944, and that
affects how it handles, at least on the track. The turbo is a little more
of a brute. I don't know if things like clutches are cheaper, or not. I
think it boils down to cost, how fast do you wanna go?

you know a prof named andy weiner?

doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon

------------------------------

Date: 29 Mar 95 14:57:03 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Re:  re:K-Mart Quality (gasoline)


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Re:  re:K-Mart Quality (gasoline)
Date: 1995-03-29 16:52
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Bob Joyce was commenting on:
>Rob says, "This is partly true...."
>"Most major refiners and their marketers freely trade the lesser quality
>gasolines (regular and mid-grade) over the open market. For instance, if
you
>purchase 87 octane gasoline at a Shell station, there is no guarantee that
>the gasoline was refined by Shell.  On the other hand, most major refiners
do
>not trade their premium quality gasoline...."

>But, then, a wise old engineering professor once told me, "When you use the
>word "always", you're probably going to be wrong occasionally.  Amoco is
>somewhat of an anomoly in this situation, Rob: you are correct in saying

I have to agree with Bob on this but also say that I'd bet even Amoco trades
for PUL (Premium Unleaded).  Having recently spent a stint with our refined
product traders, *nothing* is sacred out there and *everything* is traded,
bought & sold in the refined products area.  The main thing to remember is
that the additives packages are put in mostly at marketing terminals before
going to the final retailer.  The gas is pretty much a commodity up til that
point.

<snip>

 >The point, however, is that gasolines sold at the discount stations and
>convenient marts almost always meet the same standards and come from the
very
>same refineries that supply the big boys (yes, even Amoco's refinery...see
>Stan's "Business 301" lesson).  You just don't know which of the big boys'
>gasoline you're getting, and it may be different from week to week
(depending
>upon market prices at the wholesale terminal).

>"...This issue should not make much difference to all of us anyhow since we
>should all be using the premium brands from major refiners...."

>Whatever strokes you best.  Using gasoline from a specific major refiner
was
>important several years ago if you wanted to keep your injectors and valves
>clean, but today all the major brands have comparable additives (albeit
with
>some differences) so it's much less important to be picky.  That's good
news
>for the consumer, since what you get at the corner convenient mart is just
as
>good as what you get at the corner Texaco.

Well this is where we will disagree.  All additive packages are *not* equal.
 Different technologies are employed as well as concentrations.  This also
means that the effectiveness of the cleaning additives is different.  All
the manufactures buy or produce cleaning additives so they can claim the
benefits and get your business.  I won't go into my soapbox on why my
company's gas additives are better than the rest, but I will offer a couple
of testimonials:  Every domestic auto manufacturer uses Chevron gas to run
their assembly line emissions test (yes Rebecca, your new chevy is delivered
with a few gallons of good ol' Chevron in the tank), and Chevron's Techron
(Techroline as it's called in the gas) is recommended by a bunch of
manufacturers to clean and maintain those sensitive fuel and injection
systems; Porsche, BMW, etc. are among them...  You buy what you want, I'd
buy Chevron even if I *didn't* work for them...

>"...I can say for sure that Amoco Ultimate (Clear) is this way.  It is
rerun
>through a distillation process to remove any color bodies to make it
>clear...."

>No, Rob, it is not rerun through anything to get it that way.  ALL gasoline
>is colorless when it's refined, whatever its grade or origin...the color
>comes from dyes that are added to differentiate grades for the consumer (a
>practice begun years ago to prevent dishonest dealers from selling regular
>for premium!)

Yup. Refinery 101.  Reniformers are run hard for premium and less hard for
regular -- Mid grade is a blend.  Which reminds me, Scott's tip for the day:
if you use mid grade unleaded in any of your vehicles (heaven forbid, not
your Porsche!), and your favorite vendor charges more than halfway between
the price of regular and premium, you should just mix your own in your tank.
 Around Houston they tend to charge about 3/4 the cost of premium for the
midgrade and you only get 2 octane points more than unleaded.  If you put
half premium and half unleaded in your tank you pay the average price of the
two and get 90 octane gas instead of 89 (our premium is 93, regular, 87).
 This is especially easy at the new credit card pumps...

Time for a disclaimer:
The above comments reflect the opinions of the author and not anyone, or
anything else!

 -Scott Jessen -- been there, ran reniformers, don't have cancer (yet...)

Now that makes sense.  The cam itself doesn't actually go negative, but

revolutions "may" widen the gap.  Thus requiring another adjustment on 
that valve.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 95 15:32:54 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 1974 914 Seatbelt interlock relay


Our insideous legislators mandated that the 1974 cars would have an 
interlock to force people to put on their seat belts. The legislation
was repealed very quickly, but many 914s were delivered with this 
contraption. It was easily defeated, but the circuitry was left inplace.

This will cause problems, as George "Dr. 914" Hussey pointed out in his 
post. What occurs is that the relay resides under the passenger seat, 
interrupting the yellow wire from the ignition switch to the relay panel.
After a few years, the relay and surrounding wiring will corrode, 
breaking the circuit from the ignition switch. 

The total scure is to remove the relay and splice the ignition lead
(yellow) to the relay output (yellow-green, I recall). Be sure to use
a solder connector for this and heat-shrink insulation. I then remove 
all the interlock extraneous wiring and components, shortening all 
required wires to fit in the center tunnel.

If you own a 1974 914, it is well worth the time to remove this trinket
of big-brother's meddling. If you aren't sure what's there, remove the
passenger seat and look, the job may have already been done.

I met a few nice ladies with '74 914s this way. How 'bout you George?

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Mar 1995 11:10:39 -0500 (EST)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: 914 cam goes "negative"

Dave Darling writes:
>
>        So yes, the cam does go "negative"!  I re-checked my adjustment,
>and found it to be fine at TDC.  BTW, the factory book has a typo--they
>tell you to adjust the valves 1-2-3-4, not 1-4-3-2!

You can do it 1-2-3-4 if you rotate the engine counter-clockwise.  It avoids
having to jump back and forth from one side of the engine to the other.

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 15:52:29 -0500
From: NG_COLE@ACAD.FANDM.EDU (Nicholas Cole)
Subject: Hooked again

High everyone. I had someone come look at the 914 the other day. It was the
first real nice day. The guy came over and seemed a bit put off buying a
car from someone as young as me. Seemed to think I would have beat my baby
to death. Anyway after chatting about the car we went out to look at it and
drive it. What a great drive. The car didn't even do its weird FI thing. We
get back he looks around the car again and says I'll give you $4,700 for
it. Well the offer was good enough for me to take, but I had so much fun in
my first ride in the passenger seat that I told him I could not sell it
(the parents freaked at this point). Our new niehbor showed up a couple of
minutres later because he liked the way the car sounded. My mother filled
him in by saying 'this fool (me) wouldn't sell the money pit. I explained
my graduating from college no job lined up no money and loan story. He said
you should sell it, but I should have sold my plane to buy a house sooner.
He then said if you keep you can parke it under the wing of the plane in my
nice warm hanger. Free storage! Falling in Love again! All in all a great
day for me and frustration for the rents.
Nick
PS if anyone has a job for me I'm not too proud to beg I mean send a resume.

Subject: 914 problems! Rod knock and FI

Hey everyone
Now I''m going to keep the money pit lets see what I'm into. I think I can
hear a rod knoock at idle. THere a tapping sound when the car idles that
goes away as it speeds up. Its only audible with head in engine bay. Now
here is the question. I know I need to rebuild or get a long block. Can I
risk another 2000-3000 miles without catastrophic engine failure.

Second FI
Current state of affairs
New rotor distributer cap throttle switches cylinder head temp sensor plug
and plug wires.

problem:
Cold weather 40 or below car starts and high idles fine. After 5 min it
will stall and die. Car starts fine again, but will die quickly. If revs
are 2000-3000 RPMS it misses badly. 4000+runs fine.

Warm car starts fine comes off high idle quickly and then will idle ate
950rpms. If left to idle 5-10 min car will start swing between near stall
to 1400rpms until it dies. The car will strat and if driven will run fine
but miss every ten min randomly. Plugs are differnt level of fouled if they
get pulled out and its never the same plug.
I have too ideas here. the car runs to rich at times in diferent cylinder,
but I have no idea why, or I'm burning too much damn oil and fouling
different plugs.
Nick

Subject: Re: High Temp Paints

Pat Garvey  came down from the mountain and spake thusly...

I have a new 911 muffler that made the trip roughly, with some scratches down
to bare metal.  I'd like to repaint it prior to installing it.  In the past,
I've had very little luck on 914 mufflers, using just about every kind of
high temp paint out there.  Nothing lasted more than a year or so.  But, I

- ---

	Whatever you do, don't use that spray can stuff in white.  The silver
works OK (did my mom's Golf's exhaust in that, still looks OK, very
little rust) so I assumed the white was similar.  WRONG!  I painted my
dad's truck's headers with that, and boy, did it run, didn't cover at
all, made a mess of the garage (white dust everywhere) and wore yet,
less than a year later, the damn things look like s**t.  Stick with the
silver.  Haven't tried black, but I would assume it's good stuff, with
all the woodburners out there.

later,

Nate

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 19:40:59 -0600 (CST)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: re: 911 oil tank bolt

Michael Ladd,

*emergency* stuff.  Some of us can remember a rubber dumbell looking 
thing that you could put in a stripped out oil pan plug hole.  Try Jiffy 
Lube.  Locally I think that they strip one out every day.

I personally would sleeve the hole and rethread it.  Perhaps finding the 
next oversize thread that could be accommodated without cutting through 
the side.  Check the tank.  Mine is Copper plated steel.  Lots of 
different repairs could be made and then have the tank replated at your 
local plating shop.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy

                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 19:58:38 -0600 (CST)
From: "David R. Duffield" <dduffiel@ozarks.sgcl.lib.mo.us>
Subject: Re: 911 Battery Size - Change It?

Here's an aspect to think about.  I learned from my local electrical 
automotive repair shop that a battery acts as a load on the electrical 
charging system.  This may be of a lot more importance than the pounds.  
The pounds were more important in the early short wheel base cars. 

Suggestion:  Find a battery with the proper electrical similarities that 
has a wide application.  Get info at Interstate Battery or Autozone, NAPA 
or the like.  The rest is fabrication.

David R Duffield.....Porsche Guy
"Be happy that the previous owner took good care of your Porsche"
                                      Peter Gregg, Warbonnet Tech 1974

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 18:10:11 -0800 (PST)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: Try this with your fiche manuals...


While playing around with my Micron 780 microfiche viewer, I found that 
if you removed the front translucent screen, you can focus the image on 
the wall and enlarge it pretty big.
 
Now imagine if you're working on or under your car. You could project a 
huge image onto the garage wall for easy viewing. You wouldn't have to 
worry about getting grease on your expensive paper factory manuals.
 
Joe '86 944

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 11:14:32 +0900

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 95 18:49:09 -0800
From: donr@tdnet.com (Don Rutherford)
Subject: Paintless Dent Removal

I've now had dents removed in 2 cars, one of them my 356 Speedster, by a 
local "Dentmaster". Am waiting to have the time to drop some roof liner so I 
can have a tree-branch "sitz-mark" taken out of the roof of my 911.

Results have been about as perfect as I could have wanted.

Anyone can buy the tools to do this job so the key is to find someone who is 
really good with them. The one I used was the one that was recommend as the 
one who does all the work for the local Porsche/Ferrari/RR dealer. If you 
are in LA area (OC specifically) I can give you the number.

Don

>I have a couple of beauties and was told that they can be pushed/popped out
>without the repair/paint/expensive bodyshop process.

>R.Warren - 86/911

factory manual) show this type of advance capsule.  After checking the
specs in the little spec book, I have a suspicion that the retard mechanism
is not giving me enough retard at idle. Perhaps the screw adjust can
rectify this?

Thanks for your input,

Date: 29 Mar 95 22:43:43 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Installing Trond's sound deadener

Hi, Trond.
 
Laminate the paper together BEFORE you stick it into the car. (Not one layer
of paper in car, glue, another layer on that.) If your tar paper is like my
tar paper, you can glue it with contact cement, that yellow/brown stuff used
for laminating Formica countertops and Ikea furniture and stuff like that.
<g>. Anyway, brush or roll both pieces, let dry, stick together (it will
stick instantly; no chance for fixing mistakes), roll out with a flat roller
(I use a 15 cm rubber roller sold for graphic arts purposes like
silkscreening), lay this aside for a day
to let the solvents from the contact cement evaporate fully. Then use a
stiff, sharp blade like a linoleum cutter or those triangular things, or at
worst those break-off hobby knives, to cut out the shape you need. If you
have done it right, you will not be able to see the two layers on the edge,
because they are bonded together and the knife smears the interface a
little. Next use your grandmother's roller. BTW, if you can send me a 5 x 5
cm sample of the result, I'm curious to see what you have. Now glue the
finished, textured part into the car. The factory way is to put hot tar on
the back and stick it in. If that is not practical, try more contact cement
or carpet cement.
 
(Later)
Derek Au suggested some 3M spray trim adhesive. That works just as well,
it's really the same stuff (again spray both surfaces, let dry, stick
together, roll out) but if you have a lot of area to cover it is much more
expensive than buying a one liter can of contact cement and using a brush or
roller. Also brush or roller will get a more complete coat than the thin
stream that comes out of the 3M can.
 
Adroplast (the name of this stuff) was waffled in every pre-T6 I've ever
seen. The T6s I've seen have smooth engine compartment panels. My Reutter T5
has waffled panels everywhere except the firewall which may not be original. If
you are doing a pre-T6, I figure waffled is fine. If indeed the distinction
lies in whether the car is built by Karmann or not, we should find some
Karmann hardtop coupes and look inside those. I suspect it will be waffled.
I don't think Karmann built anything (except those hardtops) until they were
given the job of making T6 Bs and Cs, beginning for the 1962 model year. You
bought a Karmann hardtop, right? So what did you find in it in the way of
paper, smooth or waffled? Engine paper smooth? Under the carpets smooth?
Front trunk smooth?
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 29 Mar 95 22:43:46 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Renewing undercoating

 
Hi, Fred.
 
First get all the old stuff off. This probably means pulling the engine and
trans to do a thorough job. Maybe suspension too. Wire brush will probably
work best. Media blasting is good too but the damn stuff gets everywhere and
if you aren't doing a completely stripped body it's going to be an incredible
mess so don't do it.
 
Next, spray paint the exposed metal surface (ALL of the underside) with a good
metal etching primer. Du Pont Variprime, or similar (Ditzler DP-40?).
Aircraft Spruce and Specialty in Fullerton, CA sells genuine zinc chromate
primer. Nasty if you inhale it. Then paint over the yucky yellow/green stuff
with your favorite color of auto paint. Semi-gloss black Centari is as good
as anything. Imron would be super though. Again extremely nasty. Then coat
the paint with your choice of undercoat. I like Wuerth SKS Stoneguard,
available in black, white, beige I think. Stoddard has it, at $30 a quart I
think. It is also available locally at about half that price if you know how
to get ahold of the Wuerth jobber. Some
concours people like the 3M Body Schutz for originality on some cars. If you
want that, it's not as durable as the Wuerth, but you can apply it OVER the
Wuerth for effect. It eventually dries out just like the stuff you are now
peeling off the car.
 
On more recent 911s, the underside is painted body color. The Wuerth SKS
Stoneguard is paintable.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 20:06:39 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: 914 problems! Rod knock and FI

Hi Nick:

Your tapping noise that's audible only inside the engine bay may only be
the sound of mis-adjusted valves.  I recently did a big overhaul of my
motor ('74 2.0) and after 500 miles or so I heard a tapping sound and began
to feel very, very sick. But it was just the valves needing adjustment. :)

$4700 for a 914 that needs (obvious engine) work is not a bad offer, but if
it's worth that in fun to you, then by all means keep it.  I think it's
really pretty silly to keep a car that you simply can't afford to bring up
to snuff / keep running.  

I paid $3000 for my car, and oodles of my time, a rebuilt transmission,
overhauled suspension, fixed-up little things, rebuilt instruments,
repainted (powder-coat) front & rear bumpers & rocker panels & engine grill
& suspension pieces, overhauled brake calipers, new brake lines & rotors,
new wheel baerings, new body seals, overhauled motor, new heater boxes, new
cables, ... (you get the idea) later its only real problem is that it idles
high (1100-1200 rpm) when hot.

Is it worth it?  Well, this car _IS_ immensely fun to drive, and
super-reliable.  But I would have been better off shopping for a
near-perfect car to begin with.

 ____________________________________

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 20:06:46 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Re: Problem with mounting 914-4 rear wheels

This is to wrap up my experience with my 914-4 factory Fuchs rear wheel
mounting problem.

I followed a combination of your (collective) advice on methods for
mounting the 914-4's rear wheels. I do have the correct wheel bolts.

Basically, I gradually tightened the four bolts in four stages -
hand-tight, 40Nm, 80Nm, 130Nm, all the while rotating the wheel(s).  I
checked for eccentricity and lateral run-out before and after, and it
didn't make much difference.  My rear wheels show about .75mm eccentricity
and about 0.25mm lateral run-out once mounted and torqued down.

This evening's road test showed a different story - whereas before I felt a
considerable rear-wheel wobble (through the shifter), especially when
accelerating at highway+ speeds, now things are _much_ better.  I can only
attribute the difference to the torque value - I used to tighten the wheel
to 80-90Nm, as that's what my other cars require. Live and Learn (and trust
the Spec Book) certainly applies here. :) I presume these wheels can take
this wheel-bolt torque because they're forged.

Anyway, thanks for all your quick replies. To a man, there was no
disinformation, and I appreciate that.

 ____________________________________
| Andrew E. Kalman   aek@netcom.com  |

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 95 23:28:07 EST
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>
Subject: Purchasing advice .. etc

It's SPRING !  Finally the P'philes has gotten off its total tedium
of people who drive all year and the 356 crowd is showing up.

My view on a 61 356 coupe is ... Rusted it is worth $ 5k or less ..
but remember it has a lot of good parts.  Drivable, but looking like
a road warrior it is worth a little more.  Clean and no rust and
running very well I'd peg value to $ 12k.  Really nice looking,
chrome et al would be worth more.  Really concours is well over
$ 20k.

This is based upon the view that each step of restoration is BIG $$$$.
When you buy the result you can spend less than the previous owner
did.  The market is based not on what the previous owner spent, but
on what we are willing to pay.

Mostly it depends on what you want.  Clearly there is a premium for
sunroof, super, SC, etc.  If you really want a 356, get one !!!

Rick Dill
356B .. waiting for a little time and work.
SO, kids, dog, other cars, etc.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 20:42:12 -0800
From: geallen@geallen.seanet.com (Greg Allen)
Subject: Porsche SCCA racing

It might be of interest to those who are interested in racing that we in the
Pacific Northwest area have gone to the SCCA and set up a class to similiar
to PCA racing that is run by and during SCCA events.  We grid all the
Porsches together and divide the classes within the group.

SCCA have accepted most all of the PCA rules but has required we run roll
cages as opposed to the PCA requirment of a roll bar.  Given how much it has
stiffend my car it is really an improvement.

We run under the 13/13 rule as does PCA and Vintage and we usually remind
each other before the race that we are just racing for a $7.00 trophey.

Other SCCA regions are watching to see how this all works out.  So far it
has been a win/win situation.  All of the individuals we have met in the
Pacific Northwest SCCA region have been just wonderful and we are having a
great time.  

If anyone is interested please e-mail me.

Greg Allen
1980 Euro SC, '79 3.0 liter slightly modified (don't tell anyone)





------------------------------

Date: Wed, 29 Mar 1995 23:16:18 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 911 Battery Size - Change It?

> > Are those pounds significant?  Will a couple of free weights make up for
> > it? 
> 
> No. Those pounds mean nothing... 
> You don't
> notice any significant performance loss/gain when carrying a passenger, do
> you? 

Ummmm. No, that's not it.

The weight *IS* significant. There are a few pointed things I could say
about front/rear balance on the early cars, and about polar moment of inertia
and all that. Enough that the factory spent a significant amount of time
dicking with the weight distribution for those cars.

And I notice the weight difference enough (as do most racers) that when
I take the car for setting ride height, corner weighting, *AND* alignment,
it goes in with a Stan-sized pile of plate weights to put in the driver's
seat. That way, when I'm done, the car is set up right for how I have
to use it. If you set the car up for no driver, then it's off enough to
make a significant difference when you *DO* have a driver. For some cars,
(the garage queens) that's not a problem I guess. None of those around here, 
though..

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 00:46:38 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: K-Mart Quality (Gasoline)

I said earlier, "Whatever strokes you best.  Using gasoline from a specific
major refiner was important several years ago if you wanted to keep your
injectors and valves clean, but today all the major brands have comparable
additives (albeit with some differences) so it's much less important to be
picky.  That's good news for the consumer, since what you get at the corner
convenient mart is just as good as what you get at the corner Texaco.

And Scott replies in part, "Well this is where we will disagree.  All
additive packages are *not* equal."

I also said earlier, "Those marketers and ad agencies have got you for sure.
 Run, run, run."

Help, Mom!  Scott the marketing type is after me.  I'm running!

Seriously, Scott, Techron is, indeed, a fine additive package and one that I
would use in any of my cars.  It undoubtedly does what it is intended to do.
 Whether or not I *NEED* to go beyond the corner service station to find it
or a suitable substitute, however, is a different matter.  I doubt it.  If my
sometimes-failing memory serves me correctly in this instance, it was *NOT*
the first additive recommended by all these folks you mention.  Texaco's
System 3 was the first to get the BMW folks' stamp of approval (and BMW
pioneered this effort to test additives in an objective fashion).  That very
public endorsement encouraged all the other big boys to come up with their
own additive to meet BMW's standard, and soon the playing field was level and
more endorsements followed.  And, it remains pretty much so today.

Fortunately for all of us, this isn't a black-or-white issue.  You won't
trash your valves if you find yourself beyond the reach of Chevron's pumps
for a couple of weeks, so don't worry about it.  Life's too short.

I love a good debate, but I hope this one's run its course!

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 01:38:14 -0500
From: Triet Le <trietle@pipeline.com>
Subject: 911 oil tank bolt

re: the rubber dumbell thing 
 
The rubber can sever and spend rest of its life swimming in the oil pan and
attempting to swim into the engine. If you must use a plug. look for
something with nut, bolt and solid rubber washers. At least you can get the
whole thing out. 
 
BTW, in my experience, they all leak. 
 
....sad memories of a Acura Legend (my first NEW car) and a coupon book for
Sears oil changes...

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 01:52:41 -0500
From: Triet Le <trietle@pipeline.com>
Subject: 944 vs 944 turbo

Point: A chipped 944 turbo has 100+ hp over a 944. Plus many other
associated upgrades. Like brakes. Like suspension. For the $2k-3k
difference, you can retrofit some, but not all of this performance into the
944. Plus you will kill resale value. 
 
Counterpoint: Insurance companies love to hear Porsche and turbo used in
the same sentence. 944 turbos are dogs unless you are on the boost. Parts
and maintenance are pricier and more intensive. 
 
Alternative: 944S (16 valve) is a price and performance midpoint offering a
somewhat wider power band..  

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 08:36:01 -0500 (EST)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: 911 Battery Size - Change It?

On Wed, 29 Mar 1995, Stan Hanks wrote:

> ... 

> And I notice the weight difference enough (as do most racers) that when
> I take the car for setting ride height, corner weighting, *AND* alignment,
> it goes in with a Stan-sized pile of plate weights to put in the driver's
> seat. That way, when I'm done, the car is set up right for how I have
> to use it. If you set the car up for no driver, then it's off enough to
> make a significant difference when you *DO* have a driver. For some cars,
> (the garage queens) that's not a problem I guess. None of those around here, 
> though..
I will agree that in a racing situation, autox, driver's ed, anything 
where seconds and tenths of a second will count, that those pounds are 
important, those grams are important (even your wheels are balanced! but 
that's a different topic) However, in city or highway driving, where you 
most likely won't be doing high speed cornering and such, I haven't 
noticed a whole lot of difference... the car doesn't pull to one side or 
another... however, when I go to the driver's ed events this year, I will 
either put the other battery back in, or put something in its place of 
equal weight. At speeds above 80 or so, your weight distribution will 
make a noticeable difference, but at 40 or 50, most people wouldn't 
notice it.

Oh, the other thing is, on the OPTIMA batteries... they will tell you 
that you'll only need one even in winter... this is true for the CCA's, 
but you do want some weight over the front tires if you take your Porsche 
out on the ice, this would be a dangerous situation if you weren't well 
balanced.

Alright, now, since this has started up the 'battery weight' subject and 
will continue (under "some popular subject"), I have a different wonder 
about it. How does it effect the charging system to only have to charge 
one battery vs. two?

Last thing... Has anyone seen the BMW ad, "Oh No." with the car perfectly 
balanced on a point and a feather about to fall on the hood?
 -Derek

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 08:54:47 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Euro spec 911

I was getting near the end of the conversion project,
connecting up the exhaust hangers for the Euro spec
conversion of my 911, shivering in anticipation, and,
I might add, COLD, thinking to myself, "Hope this makes
the cabin heat work a LOT better..." shivered some more,
then started to get a rather strange feeling of being
naked in bed in a cold room with no 911, no Euro-spec
parts, and more importantly NO BLANKETS, since they
were wrapped cocoon-style around my bed companion who
apparently was quite warm. Oh hell, back to reality...

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 09:18:30 EST
From: Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov
Subject: Finally!  My car is back

Hello All;

After 33 days and about $2500 I finally have my 89 951 back from the body shop.  
I put on the new 17" 5 spoke wheels and drove her home yesterday.  Of course it 
is raining in Maryland today, but who cares.  World order has finally been 
restored to normal.

The only negative aspect of the whole affair is that the insurance company has 
kept the damaged rear wheels which they paid to replace.  Does anyone have an 
idea what a resonable salvage value would be for these wheels?  They have 
already been repaired and polished to the tune of $250 each.  They now have a 
bright polished silver finished that almost looks like chrome.  I called Robert 
Wood and THEY thought $250 for repair and polishing was high.  Wood estimated 
about $400 value for a repaired and polished wheel.  These are the 9x16 forged 
seven spoke wheels found on the Turbos.  Anybody have any experience with 
repairing these type of wheels?  Any comments would be appreciated.

Tracy Meyer
tracy_meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov

like usual I will get to drive some (not a whole lot), enough to get the

his "actions" on tape, as he has done for all his other cars before. By the
way if you wonder about where I am from, it's Luxemburg, probably one of the
nicest countries in the world, and with lots of hidden secrets, including
exotics that are driven daily. (Bugatti, Ferraris, Lamborghinis, etc...)
Does anyone know what a nice used RUF BTR or CTR would run these days, not
that I have the money now, but I am expecting to be able to fullfill this
dream in the next 24 months. :)


                        Gerard

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 08:59:49 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: re: K-Mart Quality Gasoline



I worked for Amoco Research for 7 years and agree with
Scott Jessen on the major points - gasoline is a commodity
and is freely traded up to the point of distribution where
the additive packages are blended in. *occasionally* trading
will happen after blending to help another company out of a
jam (at the right price) :-)

Also Scott is right about all additive packages not being equal.
Chevron was certainly the high standard for everyone, not because
of the quality of additives (I think they're all approx. the same)
but because they used *much* more than everybody else. Our auto
engineers used to piss and moan that our gas could produce just
as clean an engine as Chevron if the sales and marketing guys would
commit to using the same quantity of polymer additive. I used to 
get it free and add a couple of ounces to my tank with each fill-up
as an "unofficial test" and had no build-up on my valves in 75,000 miles.

The main thing is to use high-quality branded gas from a high-volume
station. It will save you the extra cost in reduced maintenance - honest!

Reid



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 09:02:20 -0600 (CST)
From: gwj@louie.timeplex.com (Gregg Jensen)
Subject: Correct mix for paint?


- --Boundary (ID nAXiuAik392FWI1qAK5F8A)

For the paint experts,

I have a 77 911 that has what appears to be guards red paint (the previous
owner had it repainted).  I had some minor repair to the passenger door,
which then required repainting.  The auto paint store sold me the replacement
color for guards red (the said that it was the same) called indian red.  I
was curious to know if this was the correct mix for guards red:

DuPont Lucite Acrylic Lacquer                  Mix Size: 1 pint
402L White(HS)        5.0
429L Red             63.0
437L Orange          71.5
465L Binder         163.0
485L Balancer       150.5

The door came out with to much orange and doesn't match the rest of the car.
Now either the previous color was not guards red (could be) or the new color
is not the correct mix.  The thing that caused this mess was the new (to me)
mirror that I put on. It happened to come from an original guards red 911, and
it matches the rest of the car.  I would like to (read that as need to) repaint
the door, but I don't want to continue to do this with a hit or miss pattern
(get a new mix, try it, look at it, does it match, no, repeat cycle). 

Gregg
77 911S guards red(???)

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 10:50:58 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: Optima batteries

Greetings:

My experience with Optima batteries has been varied.  On one hand they are
very powerful (800 cold cranking amps).  Because they are sealed and contain
no liquid they don't tend to emit carpet and metal eating acids.  They have a
wonderful warranty, (6 years, first 2 years total replacement, next 4 pro
rated) and as said before, they can be mounted in any position.

The downside is, to mount and *secure* one in a late (74 on) 911 you need a
special mounting tray, available, I believe from Automotion or one of the
other mailorder outfits.  You also need a longer ground cable.  They are "one
size fits all" and installation at times requires creativity.  They don't
like to deep cycle, and they don't care for long periods of inactivity.  They
are also not light.  (42 lbs)

I have used them as replacements in 69 thru 73 cars.  (Single Optima
replacing dual originals)  by mounting it on it's side in the drivers side
battery well and modifying the mounting bracket.  from a functional
standpoint they work fine.  They won't go in the passenger side well because
they stick out about 8 inches and interfere with the spare tire.  If weight
and particularly weight distribution is a factor, this is *not* the way to
go.  If the car sits for long periods of time it's *not* the way to go unless
you keep it charged by some means other than driving.  For a daily driver it
works great.  It's comparable in cranking power to the optional 88AH
batteries used in some 911s and it *is*  lighter than they are.  It also
works well in 914s and installs with minor modification to the hold down
clamp. 

Regards

Pat Moyle
(Getting self ready for Road Atlanta Club Race.  ((Stewarding, not driving))
and museum piece 914-6 ready for it's first race of the season at Hallett, OK
in May)

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 17:43:35 +0200 (MET DST)
From: Paul Negyesi <paul@ktud.elte.hu>
Subject: ANNOUNCEMENT: Comprehnsive report about the Geneva Show on WWW!

Dear Sir/Madam!

I'd like to let You know that a brand new WWW page has been completed 
recently. If You consider Yourself as an automobile enthusiast I think 
You will find it useful to have a _comprehensive_ report about the 1995 
Geneva show. I know that You can read about some of the exhibited cars in 
car magazines but:
 - this report covers all the exhibited models
 - many of them have "sub-pages" where You'd find pictures, information 
but no ads.
 - there are about 60 pictures which You'd download.

All I ask is: please write me Your impressions because:
 - it will help me to enhance the quality of my future home pages.
 - after all this struggle to create these pages I feel rewarded with You 
comments.

This message has been spreaded all over the Net due to the fact that the 
page contains information about "normal"-cars, kitcars, exotic cars, 
racers etc.

I'd like to thank You the help of 
Mark J. Bradakis and Roger Garnett of the Team.Net archive for their 
support; Dave Sisson (dsisson@alfa-necrophylia.com) whose comments, 
pictures, e-mails are very useful. Without him the Net'd be less colorful 
for me.

The URL is:
http://www.team.net/www/ktud/genf.html

or 

http://www.team.net/www/ktud/ for the index page.
From this You will find links to my forthcoming pages.

A few of the images have been placed and'd be reached via anonymous ftp to:
ftp://ftp.team.net/ktud/Geneva/

Also watch out the alt.binaries.pictures.misc newsgroup for an 
interesting car related quiz. My next message will tell more detials.

Thanks for listening,

Paul Negyesi
Paul@ktud.elte.hu

30th of March, 1995

>--Boundary (ID nAXiuAik392FWI1qAK5F8A)--
>
>
To match any paint RIGHT is a time consuming job. You can't match paint 
out of the can. You need to mix some then test next to the car let dry 
and compare then test again until it matches.

This is where your friendly body shop comes in handy as they have all 
the colors and to "play" with. It took my friend over 10 hours to match 
the paint on my hood. Luckly I didn't have to pay the hourly rate for 
this. But it cost over 400 anyway to have the hood  stripped and 
painted. The good side to this is that the paint matches perfectly.

BTW hood is guards red with six year old "fade"


						mike


- -- 
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com

------------------------------

Date: 30 Mar 95 11:18:17 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 911 battery size -- change it?

 
Stan points out that the factory spent lots of time dicking with the balance
and polar moment of the early 911s. The whole story of iron weights in the
bumpers (NOT lead weights!!!) is covered in the forthcoming 911 book by
Tobias Aichele of the Porsche press department, "Porsche 911: Forever Young."
 
Yes, you can feel the difference weight (and weight distribution) make.
Every car I have ever tested on a skidpad, bar none, goes faster
counterclockwise, because the driver's weight tends to offset the weight
transfer to the outside (right side) wheels. It's consistent and measurable,
typically 0.02 to 0.04 g difference.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 30 Mar 95 11:29:21 EST
From: "Eric S. Shea" <73633.1772@compuserve.com>
Subject: 930 Advice

Hi Gang:

We need your help. My friends looking at a 79 930.  The car has 45,000 miles on
it.  Its been lowered with a few goodies, otherwise the car has been taken care
of well.  The current asking price is $19,000 which seemed a bit low??  My
advise was to take it to a shop and have the engine checked before he went any
further.  It has a rough cold start.

He took it to the shop and had a compression checked.  Heres what they found:
All cylinders are producing 100psi with the exception of #3... 70psi.  When the
engine warms up #3 seems to have a better read, back up around 100psi.

1. Does this sound like rings or valves?
 
2. Whats the life expectancy of the bottom end on that engine?
 
3. Whats the average cost for a top end rebuild?
 
4. Is the car worth $19,000 with that in mind, or how about offering $17,000 and
taking it straight to the local fix-it meister?

Thanks in advance!

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 09:08:38 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: $40 Paint gun


For the folks who asked about the $40 paint gun, it's
distributed by Air Force Power Tools, and it's their 
model Mark I Heavy Duty.  The box also says Silver Touch Spray 
Gun and includes a Model # AFB7S.  I think the main thing is Mark I 
Heavy Duty.

Air Force Power Tools distributes a variety of air tools, and at least 
here in western Washington, they can be found at all the  houseware 
chains that sell air compressors, like, Ernst, Eagle Hardware, maybe 
Costco, and so on.

It was recommended to me by a friend who has been restoring cars 
for many years, and whose restorations, like his 1930's Franklins, are 
in the 90-100 point concours class.  In his opinion it's every bit as 
good as a DeVilbis or a Binks.  It may not be as rugged as you would 
want in a shop that paints cars 12 hours a day (although it actually 
might be), but if you do one or two cars a year, it'll last forever.

I've done four cars with the one I have.  Couldn't be happier.

Bob Spindel
'72 911E Targa (painted with a $40 gun)

Date: 30 Mar 1995 09:18:44 U
From: "John Lucas_GRC" <John_Lucas#u#GRC@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Gumout Fuel Additive Questi

                      Subject:                              Time:  9:08 AM
  OFFICE MEMO         Gumout Fuel Additive Question         Date:  3/30/95

There's been a recent thread concerning types of gasoline and their
additives.  I'd like to ask a question on a slightly different aspect of
fuel additives.  First, the background...

My dad was a master mechanic and he absolutely drilled into my thick
head that I should add 1 can of Gumout to the gas at every other 
fillup.  He also strongly recommended adding about 4 oz. of Marvel
Mystery Oil to the gas at the same time as the Gumout.  He came up
with these rules of thumb back in the 50's or 60's -- way before 
additives were added to gasoline as a matter of course.  He also had
no experience with Porsche engines (or aluminum engines or fuel
injection for that matter).

Now for my question:  is it still a good idea to add either Gumout or
Mystery Oil to the gas?  Do the current additives serve the same purpose
as the Gumout?  Is putting Mystery Oil in the tank somewhat similar to
pouring dollar bills in the tank?  Is there any harm done to an engine 
if I continue to do this?

Any and all Porschephiles wisdom will be appreciated!

TIA
John
'84 928S

Subject: Sound Pad Adhesive


Pat-

Bob's right.  The 3M Super Spray Adhesive works fine.
Also, yuou can use 3M Trim Adhesive (I believe this
is the stuff people call bull's snot.) or 3M Vinyl
Top adhesive.  This last is great stuff.  It works
for carpets, vinyl tops, trim, and sound pads.

Bob Spindel

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 10:46:11 -0800 (PST)
From: Ted Rodgers <rodgers@indigo01.akctr.noaa.gov>
Subject: Porsches as art

Sean, many museums and art galleries have had cars or pictures of cars on 
display, including the Museum of Modern Art (I think that's the correct 
name) in NYC.  Also BMW has commissioned a number of well known artists 
to paint their designs on their products, dating back to the 3.0CSL.

There are several galleries around the country which specialize in 
automotive art.  I realize it's a matter of taste, but your teacher 
probably just doesn't like cars.

Ted Rodgers

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 10:49:00 PST
From: "Chivers, Steve" <SCHIVERS@pcpc.saonet.ucla.edu>
Subject: 912 Tuning/smog check


I'm restoring a '69 912 and recently got it running, but now am facing the 
"smog test challenge."  I took it in and it failed on the hydrocarbons -- it 
was something like 2000 vs 700.

The engine was rebuilt by the previous owner and compression checks out 
okay.  However, it is not stock.  It has webers, an electric fuel pump and a 
mechanical advance distributor.  I know that all these things are not 
"California legal."  My question is, are they the reason it's not passing or 
are there some other more general tuning things I should check first? 
 (Valves and carbs were recently adjusted, but the synchronization on the 
carbs may be off.)  My understanding from past postings is that the Webers 
don't necessarily pollute too much, they just aren't certified as 
replacement parts.  I'd hate to start replacing all this stuff and then find 
out it's related to something else.

Also, does anyone know of a good place in the LA area to have this all 
checked out?  Most mechanics I talk to that seem to know anything about 
P-cars don't do smog checks and I'm reluctant to let the smog check guys 
start messing around at $45 per hour.

Thanks.

Steve C.

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 10:53:49 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: Mounting 914-4 rear wheels

One more thing on this thread. You don't need to balance the tire on 
your foot. Use the "lug nut wrench handle". Put the handle through one 
of the bolt holes and insert it in the hub. It fits perfectly. The 
handle will now hold the tire in place while you start the bolts.

This is not a problem on 73 and later fronts as there is lip to set the 
wheel on as a part of the hub.

No matter what the 4 "bolt" wheels are a pain to put on.


						mike

- -- 
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 12:46:47 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 930 Advice

> 1. Does this sound like rings or valves?

That's why you do a leak-down test in addition to compression check!!
Can't tell without it, unless you just go ahead and tear it down.

> 2. Whats the life expectancy of the bottom end on that engine?

Similar to the 911SC. *BIG* bearings, big oil pump, etc. Problem is
people get stupid with 930s and most of them never make it to their
natural terminal life, so we just don't know for sure. I'd guess
150-200K, just like an SC.

> 3. Whats the average cost for a top end rebuild?

Top end is 50 hours by the book, plus parts and outside machine work.
So figure from there.

> 4. Is the car worth $19,000 with that in mind, or how about offering $17,000 and
> taking it straight to the local fix-it meister?

Personally, I prefer the later 930s, but if the car is otherwise *PERFECT*,
the idea of spending $17k plus whatever the engine is going to cost doesn't
bother me. OH -- one more thing: replace the turbo unit too while it's out.
It's cheap (i.e. "free" labor) and you'll need to do it sooner or later
anyway...

Stan

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 12:53:24 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Porsches Art?

> I was really pissed off, so I couldn't get a good, level-headed
> retort to his instant put down of cars not being pieces of art.  Can anyone
> give me some amo to argue with?  Sean  Black Euro '80 928

OK, here's one more for the "gee, I didn't know that" pile. My minor was
in art. Art history, actually, specializing in post-WWII non-representational
art including film, but that's a nit. 8{) (sidebar: I *love* Trival Pursuit;
the first time I join any given group, I get this "Oh, he's an engineer or
scientist or something; he's harmless. Ha. Little do they know...)

Anyway, I digress. The Museum of Modern Art in NYC had about a quarter-floor
devoted to "The Art of Ferrari" last winter. Ran for several months, I
saw it in January. They had mechanical drawings for lots of cars, physical
parts that matched some of the drawings, a MM155, an early Barchetta, 
an F40, and the prior year's F1 car, plus a spare drivetrain for the
car all on display.

I'd argue that if MoMA says it's art, then it's art. So there.

Stan

Date: 30 Mar 95 14:19:43 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Correct mix for paint

 
Hi, Gregg.
 
You will almost never get an exact match just by following the formula in a
paint book. And your paint supplier should know that. He needs to match the
paint to the car. Take the car to him and have him mix up the paint so that
it matches AS SPRAYED. They have little sample cards with checkerboards and
a hole on them. They spray color on these until the checkerboard is covered
(a check of adequate paint thickness), let it dry, hold against the car and
look at the color difference through the hole. Tint the can of paint, try
again. Etc. It costs extra.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 30 Mar 95 14:19:58 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Porsches art?

 
You can ask your snob of a teacher that if cars aren't art, why are they
wasting valuable space in, I think, the NY Museum of Modern Art (Cisitalia
coupe is on permanent display)? This is space that could be used for more
meaningful dreck like another Mapledwarf exhibit. Or something (anything)
using an American flag in an unconventional and probably silly manner, so
that all those stuffy liberals can upset all those stuffy conservatives and
don't you DARE touch the National Endowment for the Arts, you Philistine, etc.
 
Just yesterday I browsed through an expensive coffee table book at Borders
which chronicles some Japanese artist who used early postwar Mercedes 220 S
cabrios as his canvas. First the cars were immaculately restored, then he
painted tropical flowers and such on them. Sort of like the Bhagwan's Rolls
collection but more tasteful/more craftsmanship.
 
Art Center College of Design in Pasadena is the world's premier center for
industrial design, including automotive styling.
 
If welding some twisted steel beams together is considered art, why should
welding some precisely formed sheet metal together be any different?
 
I had to deal with so-called "teachers" like this too. It doesn't do any
good to argue with them, they hold the ultimate weapon in terms of grades.
In unfortunate cases like this, school becomes a learning experience in which
you learn to conform, not to think, or create, or be different. After a
while you learn that you get positive reinforcement for being a yes-man,
repeating (possibly rewording) the pap you have been fed all semester on the
final exam. When these little tin gods recognize their own ideas accepted
and repeated by the student, they graciously give out A grades and feel that
yes, they are making the world a better place, and in their own image.
 
The worst such case I ever had to deal with was one Joe Carroll at Lane Tech
in Chicago, English lit, 1971-1972. If it wasn't James Joyce or at least
Irish, it wasn't literature. He had us do book reviews. He said "Review
three examples of English literature." So I did the Mutiny on the Bounty
trilogy. He was pissed. He had us read stuff like "The Loneliness of the
Long Distance Runner" and "Mary Queen of Scots." Gack, to quote Bill the
Cat. He called us all Philistines. We called him something else, but not
so's he'd hear (see grades discussion above). He didn't like our mangling of
the English language, so he cut out 6-inch letters spelling out the words
STANDARD ENGLISH and propped them up over the blackboard. One day somebody
broke into the room, made the D a B, and rearranged them to spell BASTARD N
SHINGLE. (Sounds like a pub to me.) It took him about half an hour to figure
out why everybody was grinning and looking over his head. He was pissed.
 
Book you may want to get: Art and the Automobile, by D.B. Tubbs, Grossett
and Dunlap, 1978. There are other, better books on the subject but I don't
have any of them. I think the better ones are French. Try library card catalog
under titles, "L'art et l'automobile." For some reason that sticks in my
mind.
 
(Later) I see Cherie Woodward responded also. BTW, so your little dictator
can't get you for being misinformed, Raymond Loewy is the correct spelling.
 


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 11:28:51 -0800 (PST)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: battery for 914?

Dear Nate,

I'd recommend the Optima battery, which eliminates the problem of acid
forever.  It also has a good warranty (2 years' replacement, 7 years
pro-rate).  I put one in my 911 after restoring a ruined trunk.  It
also holds a charge very well, which is important if your car is
seldom used.

Only problem is availability.  There used to be an ad in the auto mags
with an 818-area-code (north L.A.) number, but I haven't seen it
lately.  The outfit I ordered it from, Auto-Mechanika in Colorado,
used to advertise in PANO, but hasn't lately.  This all makes me
wonder, though I think the product is still in existence.

Another caveat:  the posts are on top, exposed, and not too far apart.
I was tightening a nut on the negative, the other end of the wrench
hit the positive, and I had to kick the thing off.

I'm sure there's someone out there with up-to-date info on dealers,
which is why I made this a group reply.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 11:47:12 PST
From: sean@scifi.ucsf.EDU (Sean Steinman)
Subject: Re:912 Tuning/Smog

Steve,
How's it going?
Some things I'd check would be: jet size, Quite possible that the jets you 
are using are to big. I'm running 110 fuel, f3 emulsion tubes, and i think 
120 airs. Mine passes smog (Wont say where though....Webers, shhh!) Also 
check to see if you can lean out the idle curcuit, with the idle ajust screws.
Haynes has a pretty good book on webers, covers the IDF's too. Sync the carbs.
Just some prelim stuff I think you should check. 
Let me know what you come up with.
Sean
69 912

unfortunately his prof. can give him any grade he wants.

Date: 30 Mar 1995 12:23:12 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Mixing your own gas (was Kmart Quality)


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Mixing your own gas (was Kmart Quality)
Date: 1995-03-30 14:16
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Arthur Golden asks:

>>  Which reminds me, Scott's tip for the day: if you use mid grade unleaded
in
>>  any of your vehicles (heaven forbid, not your Porsche!), and your
favorite
>>  vendor charges more than halfway between the price of regular and
premium,
>>  you should just mix your own in your tank.
>>   Around Houston they tend to charge about 3/4 the cost of premium for
the
>>  midgrade and you only get 2 octane points more than unleaded.  If you
put
>>  half premium and half unleaded in your tank you pay the average price of
>>  the two and get 90 octane gas instead of 89 (our premium is 93,
regular,87).

>Scott, are you proposing to save about $.50 on a tank of gas ($25 a year)
by
>guesstimating how many gallons you need and then playing mixtologist
raising
>octane by 1 point over midgrade if you're lucky enough to guess correct or
>not fill your tank completely?
>
>I'm must be missing something which means at least one other person
>is...hopefully (I hate being alone). Please explain.

OK, so call me Anal Retentive, but I don't like paying more and getting
less...  I'm not sugesting you put Midgrade in your P-Car first off, but for
my truck (26 Gal) or my Lumina (16gal) it's just fine.  Both the truck and
lumina ping on the regular (not much, but it bugs me) so I prefer more
octane.  There is nothing you can screw up by mixing regular and supreme, so
the mix ratio is whatever you want (i.e.: you aren't playing  a mad
"mixtologist").  If you want to get the octane that the manufacturer goes
for, mix roughly 1/3 premium and 2/3 regular (.66 * 87 + .34 * 93 = 89
octane).  Let me give you an example from my corner station: Regular $1.03,
Midgrade $1.20, Supreme $1.25; .66 * $1.03 + .34 * $1.25 = $1.10, or a dime
less per gallon that they charge for the same 89 octane. If you can't spare
the time or hassle to push the credit card in one more time and switch
nozzles, don't do it.  I like to save a penny here and there so I can spend
it on the race car (actually I'll spend it whether or not I've saved it
:-)).  Since I tow the race car a hell of a lot and my round trip to work is
over 60 miles, my savings does add up, I figure around $200 per year between
the two non-P cars we run....

Anyway, just thought it was some useful info, I've found that lot's of folks
don't realize that the midgrade is nothing special -- just a higher profit
maker...

 -Scott Jessen -- regretting suggesting that I know something about gas....



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 14:12:33 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Porsches Art?

> I agree with Sean on the cars but I don't agree with Stan on MoMA. The 
> problem is that just because an "authority" says it's art doesn't mean it's 
> art and vice-versa (thus the debate of this thread). Regularly art critic 
> "authorities" bash MoMA curatorial "authorities". Who's right? Who cares? 
> It's subjective. Sean should be able to present anything he likes as art but 
> unfortunately his prof. can give him any grade he wants.

The debate in the performance and conceptual art circles is this: if it
causes an "art event" to happen for the viewer, then it's art. Period.

Even knowing that arguement ought to make some kind of difference with
the bonehead art teacher. Then again, if he's a strict represntationalist
or follows the cult of the master artist philosophy, you're dicked anyway...

StaN

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 15:35:32 -0500
From: NOONAN914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porsches Art?

Hi Sean,  Call MOMA.  The Museum of Modern Art in N.Y. has elevated many
common objects to the level of "Art" by bestowing their design awards upon
them.  It couldn't hurt to have the credentials of a prestigious Museum
behind your arguement.  Porsche has a long history of designing, (even before
they built cars for themselves) that continues today.  A  design award for a
product probably wouldn't be good enough for your professor anyway.  He
probably dosen't think architecture is Art either (I can hear museums and
cathedrals all over the world crying.)   Just because the sculpture is
functional it can't really be a work of art?  Actually I think your idea of
reviewing a non-tradition object as art is refreshing and would be an
excellent exercise for all your classmates.  Recognized works of art have
been reviewed to death.  Why not subject everday objects to aesthetic critic?
  Too bad about your professor; I think he's been at it too long.  He's
forgotten what great art is about.  That's another discussion for another
day.  Good luck.  Hope some of this was helpful.
Just another ex-art student hiding out in the NER/PCA.    
B.C.Noonan
PS: Apologies for refering to Pcars as "common" and "everyday".  Well, I do
drive mine everyday.

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 14:42:20 cst
From: lcrisler@mail.millikin.edu
Subject: Re: Porsches art?

          As an academic who went from engineering to the social
          sciences, I suspect many of the pointy-headed perfessors
          referred to in Peter's missive are (1) devoid of any
          semblance of a sense of humor; (2) high on any of a variety
          of comforting chemicals; (3) concerned about all the bugs
          our speeding missiles kill; (4) think of P-cars as too hard
          riding; and/or (5) simply jealous of the silly smiles we all
          display when motoring in our P-cars.

          While I agree the auto can be a form of artistic expression,
          I don't really want to encourage it too much.  Wasn't this
          philosophy what drove up the value of all collector cars a
          few years ago.  We need fewer "garage queens" and more
          "daily drivers."

          I really wished that perfessoring (in my field at least)
          paid enough moola to be able to over-indulge in the fine art
          of motoring in a P-Car.

          Larry J. Crisler
          Department of Behavioral Sciences
          Millikin University               phone:  (217) 424-6399
          Decatur, IL 62522                   fax:  (217) 424-3993

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 12:47:24 +0800
From: craigs@amgen.com (Craig Smith)

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 15:52:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 coolant leak at clutch housing?


Standard feature.  You have a leaking heater valve, located at the
back of the engine on those silly eight-valve 944's.  It's the thing
which gates how much hot water to run through the cabin's heater
core.

When it fails, it leaks down onto the clutch via a cut-out in the top of
the bell housing, which is there so you can see the TDC mark.  If
it leaks too long, you can ruin the clutch.

Replace the valve ASAP and you'll be all set.

Kevin
