Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 16:00:16 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Porsches Art?

there was an exhibit at the modern (MoMA) many years ago called something
like art and the machine. The catologue cover was the "boot hill express",
an old horse drawn hearse with a chrysler hemi sporting velocity stacks,
and big slicks. At the same museum is a 47 Cisitalia in the permanent
design collection, along the bell "bubble" helicopter, and many other non
transportation related items. I also recall various "objets" that I've seen
involving cars, car parts, and people merging with cars in one form or
another.
At the Whitney Biennial, now in progress, is a piece including a caddy
hearse, cut in half and completely covered in what smells like wheel
bearing grease. Go figure.

doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

Date: 30 Mar 95 14:54:25 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: More cars and art

I just remembered something. Famous artists often express themselves in the
cars they drive. The one that came to mind was a custom-bodied Bugatti
ordered by Andre' Derain, one of the group known as the "Fauves," whose
best known member was Henri Matisse. Fauvism led directly to Cubism which, I
suppose, led to modern oversquare high rpm engines.
 
Pete

Date: 30 Mar 95 16:40:51 EDT
From: Mark Forrester <Mark_Forrester.LOTUS@crd.lotus.com>
Subject: More than you ever wanted to know about gasoline.

For those non web-challenged p'philers, here's a URL to a document that goes 
into great detail about everything you ever wanted to know about gasoline, 
octane, mixing, knock, etc..  I've included the table of contents below.

http://ram.chem.tulane.edu:8080/f-body/trivia/gasoline.html

Happy reading,
Mark
mrf@lotus.com
==========================================================

1. Introduction and Intent
2. Table of Contents
3. What Advantage will I gain from reading this FAQ?
4. What is Gasoline?
  4.1  Where does crude oil come from?.
  4.2  When will we run out of crude oil?.
  4.3  What is the history of gasoline?
  4.4  What are the hydrocarbons in gasoline?
  4.5  What are oxygenates?
  4.6  Why were alkyl lead compounds added?
  4.7  Why not use other organometallic compounds?
  4.8  What do the refining processes do?
  4.9  What energy is released when gasoline is burned?

  4.11 What are the effects of the specified fuel properties?
  4.12 Are brands different?
  4.13 What is a typical composition?
  4.14 Is gasoline toxic or carcinogenic?

  5.1  Why pick on cars and gasoline?
  5.2  Why are there seasonal changes?
  5.3  Why were alkyl lead compounds removed?
  5.4  Why are evaporative emissions a problem?
  5.5  Why control tailpipe emissions?
  5.6  Why do exhaust catalysts influence fuel composition?
  5.7  Why are "cold start" emissions so important?
  5.8  When will the emissions be "clean enough"?

  6.1  Who invented Octane Ratings?
  6.2  Why do we need Octane Ratings?
  6.3  What fuel property does the Octane Rating measure?
  6.4  Why are two ratings used to obtain the pump rating?
  6.5  What does the Motor Octane rating measure?
  6.6  What does the Research Octane rating measure?
  6.7  Why is the difference called "sensitivity"?
  6.8  What sort of engine is used to rate fuels?
  6.9  How is the Octane rating determined?
  6.10 What is the Octane Distribution of the fuel?
  6.11 What is a "delta Research Octane number"?

  6.18 How can I increase the fuel octane?
  6.19 Are aviation gasoline octane numbers comparable?

  7.1  What is the effect of Compression ratio?
  7.2  What is the effect of changing the air/fuel ratio?
  7.3  What is the effect of changing the ignition timing
  7.4  What is the effect of engine management systems?

  7.6  What is the effect of engine speed?
  7.7  What is the effect of engine deposits?
  7.8  What is the Road octane requirement of an vehicle?
  7.9  What is the effect of air temperature?.
  7.10 What is the effect of altitude?.
  7.11 What is the effect of humidity?.
  7.12 What does water injection achieve?.
8. How can I identify and cure other fuel-related problems?
  8.1  What causes an empty fuel tank?
  8.2  Is knock the only abnormal combustion problem?
  8.3  Can I prevent carburetter icing?
  8.4  Should I store fuel to avoid the oxygenate season?
  8.5  Can I improve fuel economy by using quality gasolines?
  8.6  What is "stale" fuel, and should I use it?
  8.7  How can I remove water in the fuel tank?
  8.8  Can I use unleaded on older vehicles?
9. Alternative Fuels and Additives
  9.1  Do fuel additives work?
  9.2  Can a quality fuel help a sick engine?
  9.3  What are the advantages of alcohols and ethers?
  9.4  Why are CNG and LPG considered "cleaner" fuels.

  9.9  What about alternative oxidants?

  10.2  From Honda Civic to Formula 1 winner.

My girlfriend has a video she recorded call "Art Cars", which is about
all manner of cars that have been "arted" - there's one that has been
made to look like a big copper whale, one that has grass growing on it
(the driver wears a jacket & boots with grass growing on them, too),
and my personal favorite of the bunch, a VW Beetle made of wrought-iron
latticework - it was a 1960 Bug, but the owner (a blacksmith) replaced
all the panels with highly ornate and beautiful iron-work. Plus lots
of other whacky stuff.

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 13:54:22 PST
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Re: 930 Advice


- --Boundary-7849299-0-0

Buy the car!  Grind whatever you can off the price but 19K is a good price if 
the car is real clean and has maintenance records.  The bottom ends last and  
100# warm is good.  There isn't anything else on the road that will give you 
the same thrills/dollar.  78 and 79 930's IMHO were the best of the breed. Had 
a 76 and 79.  CHP hated them.  Got lotsa cheap shot (65in a 55) type tickets.  
Also, if your friend has not had any track time tell him to get some before he 
tries any fast twisties.  Any fool can drive one fast in a straight line but 
they can be full of surprises in the corners.  If he doesn't buy it let me 
know.  i may be interested.  I haven't had a speeding ticket in a while...... 
 
Ted Smith

Received: 30 Mar 1995 08:53:34                    Sent: 30 Mar 1995 08:53:07
From:"Eric S. Shea" <porschephiles-request@tta.com>
To: Porsche,Group,PORSCHEPHILES@tta.com
Subject: 930 Advice
Reply-to: porschephiles-request@tta.com


Hi Gang:

We need your help. My friends looking at a 79 930.  The car has 45,000 miles on
it.  Its been lowered with a few goodies, otherwise the car has been taken care
of well.  The current asking price is $19,000 which seemed a bit low??  My
advise was to take it to a shop and have the engine checked before he went any
further.  It has a rough cold start.

He took it to the shop and had a compression checked.  Heres what they found:
All cylinders are producing 100psi with the exception of #3... 70psi.  When the
engine warms up #3 seems to have a better read, back up around 100psi.

1. Does this sound like rings or valves?
 
2. Whats the life expectancy of the bottom end on that engine?
 
3. Whats the average cost for a top end rebuild?
 
4. Is the car worth $19,000 with that in mind, or how about offering $17,000 and
taking it straight to the local fix-it meister?

Thanks in advance!

Eric Shea

Date: 30 Mar 1995 14:05:14 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Gasoline additives (was Kmart Quality...


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Gasoline additives (was Kmart Quality...)
Date: 1995-03-30 15:06
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Bob, apparently mistaking me for someone who wears a suit and points at pie
charts, replies:

>I also said earlier, "Those marketers and ad agencies have got you for
sure.
> Run, run, run."
>
>Help, Mom!  Scott the marketing type is after me.  I'm running!

Well I have been called worse. But really, Bob, such displays of paranoia!
 No need to run.  Here let me get Unca' Bart to help me hold you down while
we feed you a few of these little yellow ones.  Thaat's better...

>Seriously, Scott, Techron is, indeed, a fine additive package and one that
I
>would use in any of my cars.  It undoubtedly does what it is intended to
do.
> Whether or not I *NEED* to go beyond the corner service station to find it
>or a suitable substitute, however, is a different matter.  I doubt it.  If
my

You're right here, whether or not *you* *need* to go looking for a better
product is relevant to you.  However, I was trying to point out that, just
like there are subtle differences in brands of oil (recall the lengthly
debates on "what type of oil is best"), there are differences in gasoline
additives.  Whether or not you want to believe that is not my concern, I
just thought others on the list with FI cars might be interested.

>sometimes-failing memory serves me correctly in this instance, it was *NOT*
>the first additive recommended by all these folks you mention.  Texaco's
>System 3 was the first to get the BMW folks' stamp of approval (and BMW
>pioneered this effort to test additives in an objective fashion).  That
very
>public endorsement encouraged all the other big boys to come up with their
>own additive to meet BMW's standard, and soon the playing field was level
and
>more endorsements followed.  And, it remains pretty much so today.

Well, to be honest, I don't know when BMW endorsed Texaco System 3.  I do
know that the US majors have exclusivelly used Chevron for years.  And I do
know that Porsche specifically recommends Techron for their cars, and after
all, this is a Porsche list, is it not?   I did read an interesting article
in the Chronicle about  why Texaco pulled it's last ad campaign on System 3;
let's just leave it that the government made the suggestion...

>Fortunately for all of us, this isn't a black-or-white issue.  You won't
>trash your valves if you find yourself beyond the reach of Chevron's pumps
>for a couple of weeks, so don't worry about it.  Life's too short.
>
>I love a good debate, but I hope this one's run its course!

I'm happy with that.  as long as we can agree on three things: Oils aren't
all the same, gasoline additives aren't all the same, and some folks on this
list seem to be interested in that.

I'll shut up now.  Oh and if you're not going to eat all of those yellow
ones, may I have a couple?

 -Scott Jessen

I speak for myself -- let the reader beware....

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 14:11:40 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re:Correct mix for paint?


Gregg-

A good way to try to get a match, rather than just
going by the name, or what the book says is the new
name, is to bring a piece of what you want 
to match to the paint shop.  Like the car,
or in your case, just the mirror.  I good 
experienced person can come pretty close by
mixing and matching.  It'll never be as good
as the 10 hour job described by Mike Willis,
but it ought to be a whole lot closer than you
describe.

Bob Spindel

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 13:36:01 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: 944 fuel tank vacuum

My car has started making a faint "moaning" sound from the
vicinity of the fuel filler neck. It also cuts out on me occasionally.
I wonder if a vacuum being developed in the fuel tank could
produce a supply problem similar to vapor lock?

At any rate, I am looking at page 20-8 of the service manual that
is labeled "Active Carbon Tank for Pollutant-Free Fuel Tank
Venting (Layout)". I am wondering if it is likely that the carbon tank
itself has become clogged or is it more likely that the valve between
the expansion tank and the carbon tank (labeled: 4 - Safety valve)
has become non-functional.

Kevin, George, anybody, suggestions please!

BTW, Kevin, re motor mounts: tilting the motor to one side and
grinding the stud are excellent optimizations. I wish I had
thought of that before doing my motor mounts. Like the man
sez "live and learn."

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 14:34:59 CST
From: husain@zeus1.issc.com (Afsar Husain (N3564))
Subject: Re: 2 part paints

> I just did my 911 in PPG basecoat clearcoat, and before that
> I did a 240Z, also with PPG basecoat/clearcoat, but a different
> type.  I like it very much.  Goes on easily.  Dries fast,
> can be wet sanded and polished if you wish, but can also
> be left as is (if you happen to have a super-elaborate dust-free
> environment, like the one you created).  They say that
> it's harder to repair than one-coat systems, and that may be
> true.  But the stuff is so hard, and durablem that you won't have
> to repair it.  Anyway, I like it.

Bob, 

  I don't know if it's Murphy's law looming around me or sheer bad
luck. One night during last winter, I had a frozen door lock on
my 944. I sprayed some WD-40 in the key hole and was able to unfreeze
the lock. However, the oil I sprayed ran down the door panel and the next 
morning I had a big white spot around the handle. Later that white
area (what turned out to be the clear-coat finish ) started peeling.

Now I have a ugly area :-( around the door handle, which is without the
clear-coat. Any advice for fixing this, most shops tell me that it is
non-fixable and that they have to clear-coat the whole door. Some went 
as far as saying that the whole side has to be repainted with clear-coat,
since the original clear-coat will appear dull along-side the new coat. 

Afsar Husain

- -- 
e-mail: husain@zeus1.issc.com

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 17:17:49 EST
From: scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com (Scott Humphreys)
Subject: Re: Porsches Art?


So much for open-mindedness in the art world!
Screw your instructor!  Many people make their
living by doing automotive art (photos, paintings,
sketches, scuplture, etc.) and the people that
buy the cars and "art" really do consider the
cars to be "art."  The BMW M1 and M6 were displayed
in the Museum of Modern Art in NYC, I think.

Perhaps you should make him wash and wax a Porsche
(928, 944, or 911 preferrably) to see and feel the 
sheet metal up close.  Only then could he possibly 
understand how much effort and creativity goes into 
making these cars.

Good luck.

 -Scott
scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com
'97 944

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 15:10:42 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: 2 part paints

Afsar-

I'm afraid I don't know exactly what to do to eliminate
the white area.  But I can tell you what I'd try.

I'd first try to rub it out with a bit of rubbing compound
and then some polishing compound.  I doubt that the clear
caot has come off, it's ususally a catalyzed paint that
ought to be impervious to oil and stuff like WD-40.  Sounds
like there's beed a little penetration which has clouded
the coat.  Maybe you can rub the clouded (hopefully) top
layer off.  You can't lose anything if you try.

The old shellac furniture finishes used to cloud like that
if you spilled alcohol on them.  Rubbing repaired the surface.

For a cheap, not very durable, but quick repair to make it
at least look nice, have you thought about spraying on a
bit of clear lacquer, like Krylon?  If the paint guys are
right in saying you just have to spray some clearcoat on it
and the white cloud will disappear (sounds odd to me, though)
than this ought to work.

Good luck!

Bob

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 18:12:33 -0500
From: RobVial@aol.com
Subject: Re: K-Mart Quality (gasoline)

Bob356 said:
"Those marketers and ad agencies have got you for sure."

I don't think so.  I worked at the Amoco refinery in Texas City and I am
positive that the blending stock for Amoco Ultimate was rerun to develop a
clear, premium gasoline.  They used it as a market differentiator in a world
of all-the-same gasolines.  To the consumer it may sound like a marketing
gimmick, but it is not.

I also don't remember hearing about blending in dyes to differentiate grades
of gasoline.  In this day and age of clear everything (Pepsi, dish soap,
gravy (SNL :-)) don't you think other refiners would stop putting these dyes
in their gasolines so they too could market a clear gasoline?  Gasolines are
not normally created clear.

I hate to get into a spat about this.  Just trying to stand my ground.  If we
go much further with this I may pull a brain muscle remembering my days at
Amoco.

End of line.

Rob Vial
1989 944S2

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 18:18:03 -0500
From: DavidSoCal@aol.com
Subject: question re polish & wax

Thanks to all who responded to my question re tires. I love this list!!!

I just bought a 914 that was just painted and has no polish or wax on it.
What should I put on it? I don't know what kind of paint or clearcoat was
used, but I can find out from the previous owner. I've got One Grand polish
and wax (carnauba). Should I use that? Is there something you're supposed to
do differently with a fresh paint job? I'd like as glossy a finish as
possible. As you can probably tell, I know next to nothing about paint,
polish and wax, so please don't hesitate to mention anything that may seem
obvious to you. (I'm not even sure what the difference in function is between
polish and wax.) But, hey, I'm learning! Thanks.

David Bombardier
1974 914 2.0

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 16:14:07 -0800
From: badkarma@unix.infoserve.net (Darren Foo)

>
>>We'd love to hear from everyone on this. All of your answers will be logged
>>and considered. Even the corny ones!
>>
>>Thanks for watching!    John Davis   Host Of MotorWeek
>        The Japanese have release videos on a whole bunch of sports cars
(inc. NSX, 911Turbos, Skylines, Supras). The best thing about these programs
is that they show you the best way around a turn and actually show cars
racing. For example, they had an NSX and a Supra goin' at it in some road
and showed the drivers view and oustide view, etc. They also showed tuner
cars like the HKS Skyline and Ruf Porsches in action. I mean looking at
these cars in Road & Track is one thing... but watching them on TV is simply
a different world. Another thing they showed was "trick" driving. Things
like spinning around a cone with the nose always pointed at the cone, making
sliding turns under control, etc. Unfortunately, I can't understand Japanese
and such videos are not available in English but at least I get to watch and
hear the cars in action!
>
>        Oh yeah, they also dragged a lot of high-performance cars to show
the 0-60mph speeds. It's really interesting to watch a Skyline whip the $#&*
out of a Ferrari! One thing I like about this drag thing is that it shows
the acceleration curve. For example, a Porsche 911 Turbo may be ahead of the
Skyline for the first few feet, but after that the Skyline just smokes it!
>
BaD KaRmA

Date: 30 Mar 95 19:27:26 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Porsches art?

 
Andy Clements writes
 
>What the hell happened to the notion that art is in the eye of the
> beholder? Who is to say what is and what is not art?
 
It's simple, really. Art is in the eye of the beholder, so don't take away
National Endowment for the Arts funding for stuff you don't understand. BUT
it is well known among the cognoscenti of True Art that cars are not art.
The Art Nazis have spoken. Next question.
 
<g>
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 30 Mar 95 19:27:30 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Porsche art?

OK, OK, I'll look it up...(grumblegrumble page page page)
 
Automobile Quarterly, VIII/2, p. 133;
"The Cisitalia Pinin Farina Coupe' received its supreme accolade in 1951
when New York's Museum of Modern Art chose it for its excellence as a work
of art. With seven other cars it was exhibited in the museum and the
catalogue for this exhibit eloquently described the Cisitalia:..."
 
there follow a few hundred words describing and analyzing the car from a
design standpoint.
 
I'm not sure what MoMA has on permanent display, but I think the Porsche 904
was or still is displayed there. Not the 911 though.
 
Why not call them and tell us what you find out?
 
More MoMA stuff:
AQ XIV/2 p. 202, re Lincoln Zephyr (1941ish): "Later the New York Museum of
Modern Art cited the Zephyr as 'the first successfully designed streamlined
car made in America,' a notable affront to Chrysler which was, most agreed,
well earned."
 
AQ I/3 p. 302, "[The 1937 Cord] took the gold medal for design beauty in
Paris in 1935; the Museum of Modern Art selected it as one of the ten
outstanding automobile designs in 1949; ..."
 
There are other issues that refer to MoMA shows in 1951, 1953 and 1966.
 
The 1947-76 Automotive Literature Index has about 11 column inches of
references to automotive art. 1977-81 has 10 column inches. 20 inches in
82-86. If you want to pursue this, I can photocopy the references but you'll
have to do the digging in back issues of Road & Track, Car and Driver, Motor
Trend, etc. yourself.
 
If Leroy Neiman is art, then isn't Walter Gotschke art too?
 
Duh, would "Cadillac Ranch" by Ant Farm be considered art? And then there's
"Long Term Parking" somewhere in Paris, I think -- a block of concrete with
embedded cars. And wouldn't the creations of Phil Garner, sometimes seen in
old Road & Tracks, be considered "performance art"? How else would you
describe a 1959 Biscayne body set on its chassis backwards, and seen driving
down the Golden Gate Bridge? This will almost certainly result in an "art
reaction." Possibly a violent one on the part of those who suddenly become
aware of those headlights apparently coming AT them in their lane.
 
Hey, I don't know what I like, but I know about art.
 
Pete

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 19:49:12 -0500 (EST)
From: Richard Hollander <ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us>
Subject: Re: question re polish & wax

The best polish/"wax" is by far...Klasse. It's a German product, and it's 
quite expensive. I've used them all: Zymol, Auto Glym (second best), 
etc.--nothing is as good as Klasse. They also make a "protective glaze". 
For all other applications, like rubber/vinyl, Auto Glym (complete with 
Prince Charles coat of arms, no less) is tops.


RickSH
ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 19:59:39 EST

Subject: Re: 911 Parking Brake Adjustment

          Derek Cahill wondered how to adjust his parking brake:

          For a great description of how to adjust a 911 parking
          brake, see Up-Fixin Volume VII, page 164.  This is a reprint
          of an Allan Caldwell article from the January 1985 Pano.

          When I bought by 1979 911SC, the parking brake barely
          worked, but this article was enough to get things straight.

          If you can't find a copy, email me directly and I can fax it
          to you.

          Good luck!

          Mark_Salvetti@ABBSMTP.ABB.COM

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 17:06:23 PST
From: Ehab Aljandali <ehab@cisco.com>
Subject: Re: 911: Adjustable spring plates

>
	I have installed the adj sp on my 84 targa. They are NOT meant for ride
height adjustment. they are for weight balancing the car. 
I had no problem installing them. They are excellent and worth the money I spent
(got them on a sale). They do however make adjusting the height via the torsion
 bars easier becuase it is easy to remove and rotate the plates, something that
takes a lot of time and effort to do with the stock plates.
You will have to grind the bushings they give you to match YOUR 911. it took me
a while but was very easy having a belt sander. Use the Automotion white grease
for this application for squeek free ride (mine has been quiet for 5 months).
Also, changing torsion bars is almost a snap if you want to.
I buy from them when they have a sale.

I am NOT promoting these products, just giving you MY experience.

	Good luck,

	 Ehab.


 
> Phellow Philes,
>   What's the wisdom on those Weinimeister (sp?) adjustable
> spring plates ?  I thought someone on the list mentioned having trouble
> installing them.  Other than that, all I have to go on is
> the glowing praise Automotion* heaps on a product made by their
> own sister company.  If it really works, it looks like it
> would make adjusting the rear ride height a _lot_ easier.
>  vrooom,
>    Chris
>  '86 Carrera
> 
> * Who buys from these guys anyway ? I purchased name brand
> products (Sachs clutch and Bilstein shocks) at places in Pano
> for a savings of around $600.

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 95 20:14:39 EST
From: mark_salvetti@ABBSMTP.abb.com (mark salvetti)
Subject: Re: Surgical Gloves

          Bill D. was looking for a more durable alternative to
          surgical gloves:

          I recommend N-DEX nitrile gloves made by a company called
          Best.  These are commonly used in the haz waste field.  They
          fit tightly like surgical gloves, but they are more
          resistant to contaminants and they are also much harder to
          tear.  They cost about $15 for a box of 100. Try a local
          environmental equipment supply house, or call Lab Safety
          Supply at (800) 356-0783.

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 20:38:54 -0500 (EST)
From: "Derek Cahill" <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: OPTIMA Batteries (was Re: battery for 914)

In message Thu, 30 Mar 1995 11:28:51 -0800 (PST),
  steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)  writes:

> I'd recommend the Optima battery, which eliminates the problem of acid
> forever.  It also has a good warranty (2 years' replacement, 7 years
> pro-rate).  I put one in my 911 after restoring a ruined trunk.  It
> also holds a charge very well, which is important if your car is
> seldom used.

I haven't used the Optima battery, however, I believe it is good enough to
mail-order it. There is an article in the current Hot VW's called Bug Juice
about the Optima batteries (for you 6v 356ers too!)

If you know the exact size etc. you can call Crown Battery in Ohio at
800-487-2879 and ask for Rex. If you're not sure about the size, Rex isn't
either, but he will point you to Chatnam Motors in Vancouver, WA at
206-693-6720 and the owner will help you out with your favorite "imported
exotic". BTW, they run $117.50 plus UPS charge (Ohio->NJ is $10)

Side note: They are heavier than standard lead-acid batteries, though I'm
not sure how much.
 -Derek Cahill

tantly said no and went on about cars not being art.  I thought this was extrem

certainly different. I mean, how much fun can you have trying to oversteer a 
Picasso or a Munsch? :)

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 21:24:20 -0500
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Re: Brake rebuilding

Boy, do I ever agree with Kevin Gross on eye protection, and covering the
caliper with a large shop towel before blowing out the pistons.  I did both
of these, and still "misted" the top of my driveway with brake fluid when
blowing out "a"(only ever got one out!)piston.  Didn't protect the piston
with my finger, as Kevin suggested, but used paint stir sticks, per Jon Lowe.

Sure glad I decided to take the work outside, away from the Porsches - if I'd
misted them with brake fluid, my SO would never let me forget it!

Pat Garvey

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 21:48:31 -0500
From: Russ930@aol.com
Subject: Re: K-Mart Quality (gasoline)

Bob said,

 However, you can
be sure that ALL branded gasolines meet the specifications for that brand,
whatever that may be, whatever their grade, and from wherever they may come.
 The point, however, is that gasolines sold at the discount stations and
convenient marts almost always meet the same standards and come from the very
same refineries that supply the big boys (yes, even Amoco's refinery...see
Stan's "Business 301" lesson).  You just don't know which of the big boys'

  I owned a Mobil station a few years ago and 80% of my loads came out of the
Citgo terminal even though I would place my order with Mobil.  I then bought
a Gulf station, now half my loads came from Gulf and half from Mobil.  When I
switch to Citgo most of my loads came from Gulf with a few from Mobil.  I am
now unbranded (discount) and 95% of my loads come from Citgo, with the bal
coming from either Sunoco, Gulf, or Mobil.  I was at a party this past winter
and met a guy who works for Sunoco of NJ on one of there barges.  He told me
that Citgo (in Boston) had been buying their gas from Sunoco of NJ for most
of the winter, which means that I have been selling Sunoco but thought that
it was Citgo.
     I think that the bad rep that is associated with unbranded fuels comes
from the fact that if an unbranded dealer wants to cheat his customers it is
a lot easier for him to do so, then it would if he was committed to a major
brand, since they tend to keep a certain amount of control over the station,
and how loads are dropped.

Russell
930  runs fine on unbranded including track events.

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 22:36:41 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: Adjustable spring plates

>What's the wisdom on those Weinimeister (sp?) adjustable
>spring plates ?  I thought someone on the list mentioned having trouble
>installing them.  Other than that, all I have to go on is
>the glowing praise Automotion* heaps on a product made by their
>own sister company.  If it really works, it looks like it
>would make adjusting the rear ride height a _lot_ easier.

Chris,

I put them on my car a little over a year ago.  I think they are great.
Saves alot of time getting the car levelled after replacing the 
torsion bars.  I used mine to adjust my ride height, too.  Works beautifully.
I also had to file the bushings down to get them to fit my car (I think 
someone else mentioned this).  I used some of the stuff called "Formula 5
Prelube" and after about 14 months, have no squeaks at all.  BTW, I 
bought my adj spring plates from Troutman $210.  Lots cheaper than
Automotion, etc.  Another BTW - mine were made be Sway-A-Way, not
Weltmeister.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 1995 00:35:58 -0500
From: JonesWFla@aol.com
Subject: Re: Brain box #? for 84 911

	What does a brain box belonging to a 911 84 and having the number
	
	911.618.111.09  mean please? is it euro?


	Thx in advance.

I have checked my microfiche for part # 911.618.111.09 . I did not find it
listed in the index. According to the fiche, you should have a #
911.618.111.05 . I am assumeing that you are efering to the "Control Unit"
 -DME- that is located under the driver seat. I will check with my Porsche
supplier to see if this is a supersession part number. I will also check with
Bosch North America and Germany to see if they know anything about the part
number you have. The original unit was manufactured by Bosch. Please check to
see if there is another number on the unit. It should be 10 digits in length.
exe: " 1 234 567 890". Please send reply directly to me so as not to get lost
with all the rest of the mail!

                                                          seeya,
                                                                        Bill

Date: Sun, 29 Jan 95 20:54:40 PST
From: Robert M Zampardi <us000812@interramp.com>
Subject: Greatest stuff on earth...!

I dunno if any one else out there has tried this stuff before but
if your still using WD-40 I suggest you find it.
Its called PB, its shaped like a wd-40 can except lots of writing
on the can, sorta like those old shampoo/toothpaste/odor remover/
 potions you see in health food stores.  It boasts Capillary Drilling!?
I dont know what the hell is in it, but i sprayed some on a 20 year
old dry brake line covered with crud and couldve unscrewed it by 
hand!

Date: 31 Mar 95 01:08:22 EST
From: Richard Kovach <76253.1567@compuserve.com>
Subject: 944 (1984) Engine questions

Now that I can get in and out of my "baby", I'd better get at the engine
maintenance.

Over Easter weekend I plan to replace the Cam belt.  I'm just assuming it's
required, as I just got the car several weeks ago, and all I know is it hasn't
been replaced or checked in the last 5 years/12K miles.  I've heard it's wise to
sometimes replace some other parts (guides? rollers?) at the same time.  But I
don't know specifically what all I should replace.  Since I definitely have to
mail-order parts, and will be doing the work out of town at my Dad's shop, I'd
rather spend a few extra bucks to make sure I have ALL the likely parts BEFORE I
start.  Anyone's advice would be much appreciated.  So far list only includes
Cam & B.Shaft belts, P9201 tool, engine mounts.

Also, there seems to be a strange (to me anyhow) noise coming from intake side
of the engine, near the fuel injectors & plugs on the back two cylinders.  It's
kind of a loud clicking, but sounds more like noise a Ford V8 makes when it's
got a loose exhaust header.  Sounds like it's only coming from one cylinder to
me.  But the engine seems to me to run fine and smooth.  I have trouble
isolating it to the exact spot, but it's definitely more towards the back 2
cylinders.  Could it be one injector making more noise than the others?  I used
my cheapie mechanic's stethoscope to listen to the injectors, all over the valve
gear cover, head, balance shaft cover, etc. and nothing seemed strange or noisy.

There does seem to be a slight exhaust leak lower down, around by the driver's
knees or so (judging from bending down beside the car).  But it doesn't seem to
be audible from under the hood.  Maybe it's the same noise, cleverly
disguised???  The sound under the hood seems to be localized near the top and
back of the head though. ???  It couldn't possibly be a leaky head gasket, could
it (without having any other noticeable symptoms)?

Or is this just the way it should sound?  I don't recall noticing it when I
bought it, but maybe it was the Platinum-colored glasses effect...  I suspect
I'll figure it out eventually, but I thought I should ask in case it's a known
sign of an impending-yet-avoidable catastrophe...

Thanks!

Richard Kovach
1984 944
1976 Ford Econoline (Red with lic. plates:CTR 512, but hard to mistake for a
Ferrari...)
1964 Maserati Quattroporte puzzle (25-year project, to resume after house
renovations)


------------------------------

Date: 31 Mar 95 01:08:28 EST
From: Richard Kovach <76253.1567@compuserve.com>
Subject: 944 Door Trigger FIXED!

Many thanks to all who replied to my earlier request(s)...
This will be fairly length, as I'll try to address some of the additional
questions
people sent me directly...

Not having been given an easy way out, I finally made some time to work up a 
cure for one of my extremely stubborn door triggers.  I had read reports in a
British 
mag about these things breaking easily, so I was getting pretty worried...

The only real way to do this is to take off the interior door panel (speaker,
pocket 
and handle first) to unhook the lock and latch linkages.  Then you can take off
the 
handle, and see "wassup".  The Haynes manual has a pretty clear disassembly 
procedure, as do the factory manuals.

In my case, there was so much CRAP built up around the lock and linkages, it was
no wonder I could barely open the door with both hands...  At first this seemed
VERY 
odd, coming out of a pretty pristine car (albeit 11 years old).  But it's a
perfect example
of why it's a BAD idea to use grease on parts like this.  Besides lubricating,
the grease
does 2 things over time: (1) dry out and harden, and (2) collect LOTS of dirt!
I'm not 
sure if the whitish grease was a factory thing or not -- the plastic film behind
the door 
panel didn't look like it'd been removed before (??)

None of the parts themselves were damaged or badly worn, although you have to be
fairly 
careful undoing the latch linkage -- there's one plastic snap-on piece that
takes a 
lot of cunning AND force to unhook, and it's in a slightly awkward place.
And as many people thought, the handle (at least) indeed appears to be a VW Audi
part (that's what's stamped on it).  There's no part #, but the little plastic
things that 
go between the handle and the door have part #s on them (if anyone wants, I can 
get them when I do the other one).  The one trouble you may have if trying to
replace
with an Audi part is that I'd bet the latch linkage wouldn't be right, and it's
riveted onto
the handle parts -- so you may have some tricky work there.

To make a long story short, the entire process took about 2 hours, including
cleaning
even the "tumblers" and springs in the lock, and using plenty of graphite on
everything.
The passenger side should take only an hour now, knowing what to do.
The end result is a door I can open with my thumb and my pinkie!  The neighbors
must
be worrying again, what with me standing outside for 10 minutes straight,
opening and 
closing the door and giggling like a mad fool on ether...

To sum up:  get manual+take time+follow steps+clean well+use graphite=VERY
HAPPY!

Happy fiddlings!  Now for the engine mounts, cam&balance shaft belts, power
steering pump...

Richard Kovach
1984 944
1976 Ford Econoline (cost less than a 944 water pump)
1964 Maserati Quattroporte (1/3 in the garage, 1/3 in my basement, 1/3
upstairs...)
P.S.  Anyone know where to get cheap early-60's Girling brake parts??


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 1995 01:24:18 -0500 (EST)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: Correct mix for paint?

First off, forget the Lucite.  DuPont Chromabase has always given
me a better match.  It's better paint to boot.  They get the mix formula
off fiche (old way) or the DuPont computer.  There are always certain
vagarities due to the skill level of the person using the mix machine
but they are usually not significant.  One possibility you haven't
mentioned is that your "original" paint may have been an incorrect
color, bad mix, or just faded.  (did you try rubbing out the adjacent
panel to see how it comes up?).  Some of the better paint stores have
a paint matching gun that gives them a baseline mix that can be
tinted to the correct color.   I haven't tried it yet but the guys are telling
me it's "pretty accurate, at least 90% of the time".  'Course this is 
coming from people that use calculators to make change.  A REALLY 
GOOD "mixmaster"  (and I worked with one, Lill) can match ANYTHING,
including the color of your shirt.  Check around and find someone that
will work with you when "good" is not good enough.  Have them shoot
a test card.  These are standard paper cards made to mimic an autobody 
finish.  Be aware that mixers usually shoot these with a little compressed
gas cartridge "touch up" rig.  When you shoot the door, your pressure
and feed will be quite different.  This is usually not much of a problem with
solid colors (like yours) but it can be a bitch on metallics.

Excuse the wordiness but I worked in a paint store one summer.
(Did I put enough qualifiers in this message or do I need to add "IMHO"?)

Let me know how it goes.


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 1995 01:24:32 -0500 (EST)
From: MKUEFEL@delphi.com
Subject: Sound Pad Adhesive

A personal note:

Only use Super Trim Adhesive (3M part no. 08090) if you won't
ever have to remove the part.  General Trim Adhesive
(3M part no. 08080) sticks about as well and you can take
things back off without a crowbar.

The stuff *we* used to call bull snot is Weatherstrip Adhesive
(3M part no. 08011) available in yellow (bull snot) and black
(what I like to use).  Also available is Super Weatherstrip
Adhesive (3M part no. 08001), yellow only.  Careful, this is also
a "don't screw it up the first time" product.   Great stuff.

(Am I confusing everyone yet?)


Mark W Kuefel
mkuefel@delphi.com


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 22:24:37 -0800 (PST)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: Re: Try this with your fiche manuals...

On Thu, 30 Mar 1995, David Kelly wrote:

> Ahh. But its easy to Xerox the the expensive paper manual in the 3 ring
> binders, make notes all over, get greasy, and file away for future reference
> with working notes of just what was done.

Ahhh, but its just as easy to Xerox the fiche at your local public 
library on printing fiche viewers. If you're going to copy them anyways, 
why not buy the cheaper source at $15 for fiche, $200+ for paper. The 
fiche viewer was $10.
 
Worst case scenario you copy all the fiche onto paper at 25 cents a page. 
$200/0.25=800 pages. I think there are far fewer than 800 pages in the 
manual. The result is you get fiche + paper at a much lower cost.

Joe '86 944

Date: Thu, 30 Mar 1995 22:03:26 -0800 (PST)
From: jbsussna@netcom.com (Jeff and Brenda Sussna)
Subject: 944 Turbo S performance (fwd)

> Also, now that spring is arriving I realy need to clean up the wheeels.=
>  The fronts have lots of break dust on them. What is best to clea=
>  them up ?
> 
> Thanks in advance,=20
> 
> Stephen Davies
> 1988 944 Turbo S
> 
> 
> 

I have a Ducati motorcycle with white wheels that get a lot of brake dust
on them. After trying various expensive cleaners, including things like
S100, I discovered a secret, cheap solution. Armor All makes something called
General Purpose Cleaner. It comes in a spray bottle, costs about $3, and does
a great job removing brake dust, grease, etc.

 -Jeff Sussna

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 1995 01:16:35 -0500 (EST)
From: "Naresh H. Singh" <nhs1681@is2.NYU.EDU>
Subject: Re: is this a serious problem?

On Fri, 31 Mar 1995, Armagan Ozkaya wrote:

> My 85.5 944 just developed a problem. The steering wheel does 
> not always work smoothly. When I steer to the left at about 30
> degrees steering becomes harder at one specific point. It is not
> very much harder, but noticable. Then I hear a single tick after
> which it is smooth again. I do not think it happens on all left
> turns though. It is like something becomes stuck at that point
> which is quite short. It looks like a problem with power steering,
> but what is it? Is it serious or can I continue to live with it?
> 
> Armagan.


Hi Armagan,

I am no Porsche expert, I don't even have a 944 yet, I'm still looking 
for a good used one. However, I did experience a similar problem on my 
non P-car. The steering would be extremely hard to turn to the left 
especially when it was cold. As time went on the stiffness became worse. The 
problem was a bad rack and pinion. It was changed and voila... problem solved.
I later found out that rack and pinion life on my particular make was about
50k miles (failed at 55k). I am sure Porsche life is a lot longer.

This may, or may not, be the source of your problem. Any other opinions??

Hope this helps and Good Luck!

Naresh

Sean writes: Is the Porsche 911 a work of art?

I would suggest that the *history of art criticism* is essentially
the debate of what constitutes "art". Given that your instructor
suggests that a Porsche 911 in not "art", while presumably he
does agree with most art historians that a signed urinal, a pile of
bricks in the Tate gallery and picture of a pipe, labeled "C'est ne
pas un pipe" is art, then to argue that a 911 is not art would be
strongly indicative of a serious recto-cranial inversion of a chronically
petard foisting nature.

Regards

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 07:46:30 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Belt Cover Vent Plug Tech Bulletin

> 
> Just got my Euroselect catalog (an excellent parts reference) and noticed 
> tech bulletin 10 about plugging the vent hole on the belt cover.
>  
> 1. Does this apply to all 944's?

Yep, all that have the hose from the upper belt cover to the air filter
housing.

>  
> 2. Is it just a matter of capping the holes at the cover and at the air 
> box and throwing away the hose?

Yep.

>  
> 3. What was the original intent of the vent and why was it's function 
> terminated?

Looking at the original design, I surmise that the intent was to vacuum up
all the belt dust into the air cleaner.  (P.S, If you see belt teeth there,
time to do the timing belt...)  I surmise that its function was terminated
because it wasn't worth the trouble to do it...
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 07:53:26 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Removing 944 camshaft sprocket

> 
> I've got an oil leak where the camshaft sprocket cover meets the cylinder 
> head. The factory manuals and Haynes lack detail intructions on replacing 
> the seal.
>  
> 1. How difficult is it to remove the camshaft sprocket? Is the allen bolt 
> a pain to get off usually? Will I need a puller?

The allen bolt (actually a 12-point triple square) is one of the most
difficult bolts on the engine to remove.  I would suggest that you have a
new one on hand before you attempt this.

My advice: 1) do this before you disturb the belts (that way, if you slip,
you don't bend valves). 2) remove the distributor cap, rotor, and sprocket
cover. 3) Remove the mount for the rotor. 4) Hold the camshaft sprocket in
place with a big six-point offset box end wrench and attempt to loosen the
12 point bolt with the good tool. 4) After stripping out the head of the
bolt, get out a 3/8 inch drill and drill the head out. 5) Once the tension
is taken off the bolt, you can spin it out with your finger.

>  
> 2. There are two O-rings in the Euroselect catalog: 999 701 602 40 (big) 
> and 944 105 321 00 (small). Which one do I need? Both?

Yep you need both.

>  
> Any other trick I should be aware of before replacing the seals? BTW, 
> I'm doing the belts at the same time.
> 
Good luck,

- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 08:30:11 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Ride Height and Safety

Thanks to all of the Porschephiles who responded to the survey 
of 944 Ride Height.

The results are as follows:

Total Number of Responses: 24

From 14 inches to 13 3/4 inches   - 12
From 13 11/16 - 13 1/2 inches     -  5
From 13 7/16 - 13 1/4 inches      -  4
From 13 3/16 - 13 inches          -  2
Less than 13 inches               -  1  (Had been Lowered)

The following announcement is provided as information for those 
who might be considering attending the Zone 1 48 Hours of 
Watkins Glen Driver Education, to be held July 1-2, 1995

- ----------------------------------------------------------------
944/968 Ball Joint Failure

Vehicles Affected: 944 Series II cars (1985/2 or later or 944s 
of the earlier years (1983-1985/1) that have retrofitted cast 
front lower suspensions. This problem is seen on 944s that have 
been lowered and driven aggressively.

In the interest of maximizing the safety of all entrants at the 
Zone 1 48 Hours of Watkins Glen, cars that have been lowered 
should be set at stock factory ride height. Ball joints and 
control arms should be checked and replaced if necessary.

If a 944/968 has been lowered below factory specifications, it
causes undue forces to be applied to the ball joint and the
lower suspension member, leaving the balljoint and the lower
suspension area prone to failure. Installation of shorter or
aftermarket springs with lower profiles also lend themselves to
contributing to the failure of the baljDate: Fri, 31 Mar 1995 00:19 EST
From: MWAXMAN@vax.clarku.edu
Subject: unsubscribe

please unsubscribe from this list and put me on the digest list

unsubscribe

We plan on arriving in Seattle, drive down along the coast to Vegas and
from there go to L.A.

Please respond directly to me (joker@diku.dk) to avoid this thread from
spreading on Porschephiles...

Now the questions I have are the following:

(1) What kind of car should we rent. I'm (obviously) a car-nut, driving
    two 911's daily. But I wanted to try something really american - like
    a T-Bird or something like that. What I want is a V8 that not too
    conspicuous - we don't want to be attacked because of the car.
    (Sorry, typical european fear having heard manu bad things about USA)

    Would a Corvette cab. be too obvious in the Californian traffic? How
    about in L.A. or Vegas?

(2) How much does plane-tickets from - say L.A. - to Hawaii cost?

(3) Are there any Porsche Club events along the East Coast during august?

(4) How much does a 993 cost to rent in california per day/week?

Thanks in advance...

Please mail me directly - don't want to waste too much bandwidth on this.

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 07:46:30 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Belt Cover Vent Plug Tech Bulletin

> 
> Just got my Euroselect catalog (an excellent parts reference) and noticed 
> tech bulletin 10 about plugging the vent hole on the belt cover.
>  
> 1. Does this apply to all 944's?

Yep, all that have the hose from the upper belt cover to the air filter
housing.

>  
> 2. Is it just a matter of capping the holes at the cover and at the air 
> box and throwing away the hose?

Yep.

>  
> 3. What was the original intent of the vent and why was it's function 
> terminated?

Looking at the original design, I surmise that the intent was to vacuum up
all the belt dust into the air cleaner.  (P.S, If you see belt teeth there,
time to do the timing belt...)  I surmise that its function was terminated
because it wasn't worth the trouble to do it...
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 07:53:26 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Removing 944 camshaft sprocket

> 
> I've got an oil leak where the camshaft sprocket cover meets the cylinder 
> head. The factory manuals and Haynes lack detail intructions on replacing 
> the seal.
>  
> 1. How difficult is it to remove the camshaft sprocket? Is the allen bolt 
> a pain to get off usually? Will I need a puller?

The allen bolt (actually a 12-point triple square) is one of the most
difficult bolts on the engine to remove.  I would suggest that you have a
new one on hand before you attempt this.

My advice: 1) do this before you disturb the belts (that way, if you slip,
you don't bend valves). 2) remove the distributor cap, rotor, and sprocket
cover. 3) Remove the mount for the rotor. 4) Hold the camshaft sprocket in
place with a big six-point offset box end wrench and attempt to loosen the
12 point bolt with the good tool. 4) After stripping out the head of the
bolt, get out a 3/8 inch drill and drill the head out. 5) Once the tension
is taken off the bolt, you can spin it out with your finger.

>  
> 2. There are two O-rings in the Euroselect catalog: 999 701 602 40 (big) 
> and 944 105 321 00 (small). Which one do I need? Both?

Yep you need both.

>  
> Any other trick I should be aware of before replacing the seals? BTW, 
> I'm doing the belts at the same time.
> 
Good luck,

- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road
Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 08:30:11 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Ride Height and Safety

Thanks to all of the Porschephiles who responded to the survey 
of 944 Ride Height.

The results are as follows:

Total Number of Responses: 24

From 14 inches to 13 3/4 inches   - 12
From 13 11/16 - 13 1/2 inches     -  5
From 13 7/16 - 13 1/4 inches      -  4
From 13 3/16 - 13 inches          -  2
Less than 13 inches               -  1  (Had been Lowered)

The following announcement is provided as information for those 
who might be considering attending the Zone 1 48 Hours of 
Watkins Glen Driver Education, to be held July 1-2, 1995

- ----------------------------------------------------------------
944/968 Ball Joint Failure

Vehicles Affected: 944 Series II cars (1985/2 or later or 944s 
of the earlier years (1983-1985/1) that have retrofitted cast 
front lower suspensions. This problem is seen on 944s that have 
been lowered and driven aggressively.

In the interest of maximizing the safety of all entrants at the 
Zone 1 48 Hours of Watkins Glen, cars that have been lowered 
should be set at stock factory ride height. Ball joints and 
control arms should be checked and replaced if necessary.

If a 944/968 has been lowered below factory specifications, it
causes undue forces to be applied to the ball joint and the
lower suspension member, leaving the balljoint and the lower
suspension area prone to failure. Installation of shorter or
aftermarket springs with lower profiles also lend themselves to
contributing to the failure of the baljoint and suspension.

No endorsement of any changes or suppliers is made by PCA, Zone 
1 or its respective members or officials.

Technical inspection for the Zone 1 event will include a check 
for conformation to stock ride height as depicted in the 
attached diagram. Vehicles which do not meet the illustrated 
specification of 13 inches or 33.5 centimeters will not be 
permitted to participate in the Zone 1 48 Hours.

Ride height is to be measured from the fender lip directly
above the wheel to the center of the wheel hub.

(Terrible ASCII art follows) The points are the center of the
wheel (marked with X) and the bottom of the fender lip directly
above the wheel center (marked with Y)

- -------------------------------------------------------

|  Front of Car
|

                   /           \            \
                  |             |            |
                  |      X      |            |
                  \             /            |
                   \           /             |________
                    \___   ___/

George Beuselinck, Registrar
Zone 1 48 Hours of Watkins Glen

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 1995 09:12:30 -0500
From: cmxi@tiac.net (R.Warren)
Subject: Chipped paint/dent on hood

>What is the general wisdom on fixing rock chips in paint on the hood?  Anybody
>have any miracle cures for fixing these good as new without major expense? 

I just ran a "does anybody" request on "Paintless Dent Removal" and got many
responses.  All respondents were favorable and very impressed with the results. 
As long as the paint isn't cracked and the operator is good at his craft
(some referred to it as vodoo), it is a reasonable alternative to the
bodyshop repair.     Costs about $100 +/- per panel. 

There are a number of companies/individuals out there all going by the name
"Dent Whatever" (DentWizard, Dentworks, Dentman, Dentpro...) Trick is to
find a good one local to you.  The Dentworks here in Boston is no longer in
business but others around the country have used a Dentworks and liked their
work.  I found an individual who does work for the local Mercedes & Porsche
dealers.  They use him repeatedly.  

Good Luck.
Roger Warren
aka_rgrrw

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 09:54:00 PST
From: "Golden, Arthur" <agolden@pepsi.com>
Subject: Re: Porsches Art?


SEAN WHATEVER YOU DO DON'T REFER TO THE FERRARI EXHIBIT AT MOMA AS ART!!!

Stan wrote:
>  I'd argue that if MoMA says it's art, then it's art. So there.

I wrote:
>  Just because an art "authority" says it's art doesn't make it art.

Stan replied:
>  The debate in the performance and conceptual art circles
>   is this: if it causes an "art event" to happen for the viewer,
>   then it's art. Period.

Through all this debate, most of us said if MoMA has a Ferrrari exhibit than 
MoMA is saying thier art.

Well, I spoke briefly with my sister last night (Associate Curator at the 
Whitney Museum of Modern Art) and she said Stan and I were right. (It's 
interesting, Stan's always right. I don't know why I disagreed with him in 
the first place)

The problem is, the Ferrari exhibit. According to my sister, MoMA shows art 
and design and the Ferrari exhibit is a _design_ exhibit.

She did say that if Sean intends to represent a Porsche as art then he can. 
It was a short conversation and not being an art expert I may have missed a 
few important points so I CC'ed her and I'm sure if a butchered her comments 
she'll let me know.

Let the debate continue.


Arthur E. Golden
AGolden@Pepsi.com
(and yes, I'm working on getting you a pair of Rollerblades Thel!!!)

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 1995 10:09:32 -0500
From: Ebnah@aol.com
Subject: Odds & Ends

I've been a faithful reader of Porschephiles for some time now, and have been
saving up many questions I have concerning my late 1985 944.  I'm hoping all
you knowledgeable 944 owners will be able to help.
1) I just replaced the entire sunroof cable assembly, made necessary since a
cable on one of the arms broke and Porsche does not make individual
replacement parts.  Now when the arms retract into the roof housing, the
motor does not shut off when they are fully in, until you take your hand off
the switch.  The original cable functioned properly.  I have adjusted the
microswitch on the end of the motor assembly, but this has no affect.
2) The fasten seat belt light on the dash randomly pops on when driving, then
goes off again.  No one and nothing is on the passenger seat.
3) The cruise control will hold the speed for a while, then surge faster.  I
have seen and saved the posting about the repair place in Tennessee, but was
wondering if possibly there is a sensor that I should replace first before I
remove the brain controller.
4) The idle sometimes bouces up and down from about 900 rpm to 1200 rpm, and
eventually settles down.  the idle controller valve has been replaced, and
tuneups have had no effect.
5) When upshifting from first to second the gears grind if shifted rapidly,
but no problem on downshifting, and no problem if not shifted rapidly.  The
clutch has been previously replaced .
FYI, the car now has 145,000 miles (I've owned since new) and has had almost
everything replaced at least twice!
Thanks in advance for everyone's assistance.
Jeff
'85.5 black 944

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 10:13:00 PST
From: Franklin Fasano <FFASANO@VASALES.LEGENT.COM>
Subject: Insurance Hassles


Sorry if this is old news, I just joined the list this week.  The reason I 
joined is that I looked at an '88 928 that I was hoping to purchase 
tomorrow.  In any case, I called my insurance company for a rate quote.  I 
should've known something was wrong when the agent who answered the phone 
said to me, "Oh, a Porsche.  I'll have to get a supervisor to call you." 
 When I asked why, she replied "Porsche's arent in my computer because they 
are evaluated on a case by case basis."  I left my name and # and waited for 
a call back.  Finally, I get a call from a supervisor.  First she says, 
"Yeah, we'll insure that car" like she's doing me some kind of favor.  Then 
she quotes me a RIDICULOUS rate.  I asked why it was so high since I'm 28, 
married, 2 other cars on the policy, no tickets, etc... She gives me this 
whole "sports car, goes real fast, blah blah blah" spiel.  So I told her my 
other car was newer, worth more, driven more and also goes pretty fast 
(although that still doesn't mean I speed).  Evenutally, I realized it was 
pointless to argue.  Have the rest of you guys had to put up with this kind 
of stuff?  Is reasonably priced insurance for a Porsche possible?  At this 
point I'm thinking of not buying the car, because I've heard of people 
getting dropped just because they bought a Porsche.

Thanks.

====================
Frank Fasano,
<FFASANO@VASALES.LEGENT.COM>

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 16:36:26 BST
From: kevin@mailserver.aixssc.uk.ibm.com
Subject: Electrical fire (fwd)

>
>A friend of mine had an electrical fire shortly after having his 87 944T
>repainted.  On driving home from the shop he had to turned on his
>headlights and within minutes he had a cockpit full of smoke.  
>
>John A. Wise                                    Tel: (+1) (904) 226-6384
>

John,
      I had a wiring problem with my 944S a few weeks ago. One of
my headlamps suddenly went out while in use. On investigation
I found that the fuse had blown. The replacement fuse also blew.
An hour spent with an multimeter traced the fault to the three wires
leading to the connector behind the headlamp unit.
All three cables are covered in a sleave and after stripping back the 
sleaving I found that the insulation had been worn from two of them
causing a short, and one of those (the earth) had actually broken. 

I think the problem was caused by the wiring not being adequately 
secured and therefore susceptible to vibration. It's now tie-wrapped
just as securely as the other side which checked OK.

- -- 
Regards,        IBM IPnet: kevin@aixssc.uk.ibm.com   Voice: +44-256-343000
Kevin Murrell       UKnet: kevin@aixssc.ibm.co.uk     VNET: NHBVM7(MURREK)

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 1995 11:25:14 -0500
From: X400459@aol.com
Subject: Non Porsche cruzin' story

One night (in 54, I guess) myself and 2 buddys decided to go out cruzin.
Well, we hit all the drive-in resturants and came up with nothing to do. One
of us knew a girl who took tickets at the local drive in movie theatre--he
was sure she would let us in--so we headed for the drive in. Well we got
there and she wasn't working. We drove right up to the ticket sale booth,
looked at the sales person and backed out again. Wellllll one of us said it
was a shame to go home after driving all the way out and that our plan should
be to BACK INTO THE EXIT, in this fashion we could gain entry to the drive in
and no one would be the wiser because they would see tail lights--the
customary view of people leaving. So we drove around the the exit lane,
turned the car around (nobody thought about back up lights being somewhat
tell tale that something was amiss near their exit) and proceeded to back
into the drivein. Well, we got pretty far into the drivein but we seemed to
be drawing the attention of a bunch of ushers with flashlights. We decided to
turn the car around with one of those racecar like manuvers, where you back
up--change direction,downshift and leave the opposition watching--and we
manuvered right into a parked car. We hit him pretty good--he was minding his
own business and being intimate with his girl friend. He didn't know what hit
him. Naturally, the crash sort of attracted attention in the drivein.
Actually, the movie went off and the house lights came on. The ushers
escorted us to the owner of the drive-in and he decided not to  press charges
against us for entering without paying. The guy we hit wanted no part of
reporting the accident--he was driving without a liscense. My buddy,
Thurston's car incurred considerable damage and the owner of the drivein
muttered something about serves us right and called a tow truck. CAN YOU
IMAGINE THE  EMBARRASEMENT OF BEING TOWED OUT OF A DRIVEIN MOVIE WITH A TOW
TRUCK AND YELLOW LIGHTS FLASHING AND EVERYTHING. We didn't try to back into
the drivein again.

Rich Brown x400459@aol.com

We have put our entire parts catalog online for you to browse and order 
from via e-mail. We invite you to visit our site and send us your comments 
and suggestions (and, of course, orders). We have also posted a few 
technical articles on engine building, and we invite your review.

Be sure to join or E-mail mailing list so that we can send you infrequent
notices of our bargains du jour. Don't forget to indicate what model of
Porsche you own. 

Plans for future improvements include a page of specials for those of you
with other models of Porsche, posting of *your* technical articles, and
pictures and notes from my current rustoration. 

I look forward to hearing from you. 

- --------
Walter Piescik, 356parts@cais.com, 703/528-2661
"Klasse 356" New & used parts for your Porsche 356
Visit our web site: http://www.cais.com/356parts/

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 09:54:00 PST
From: "Golden, Arthur" <agolden@pepsi.com>
Subject: Re: Porsches Art?


SEAN WHATEVER YOU DO DON'T REFER TO THE FERRARI EXHIBIT AT MOMA AS ART!!!

Stan wrote:
>  I'd argue that if MoMA says it's art, then it's art. So there.

I wrote:
>  Just because an art "authority" says it's art doesn't make it art.

Stan replied:
>  The debate in the performance and conceptual art circles
>   is this: if it causes an "art event" to happen for the viewer,
>   then it's art. Period.

Through all this debate, most of us said if MoMA has a Ferrrari exhibit than 
MoMA is saying thier art.

Well, I spoke briefly with my sister last night (Associate Curator at the 
Whitney Museum of Modern Art) and she said Stan and I were right. (It's 
interesting, Stan's always right. I don't know why I disagreed with him in 
the first place)

The problem is, the Ferrari exhibit. According to my sister, MoMA shows art 
and design and the Ferrari exhibit is a _design_ exhibit.

She did say that if Sean intends to represent a Porsche as art then he can. 
It was a short conversation and not being an art expert I may have missed a 
few important points so I CC'ed her and I'm sure if a butchered her comments 
she'll let me know.

Let the debate continue.


Arthur E. Golden
AGolden@Pepsi.com

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 1995 10:09:32 -0500
From: Ebnah@aol.com
Subject: Odds & Ends

I've been a faithful reader of Porschephiles for some time now, and have been
saving up many questions I have concerning my late 1985 944.  I'm hoping all
you knowledgeable 944 owners will be able to help.
1) I just replaced the entire sunroof cable assembly, made necessary since a
cable on one of the arms broke and Porsche does not make individual
replacement parts.  Now when the arms retract into the roof housing, the
motor does not shut off when they are fully in, until you take your hand off
the switch.  The original cable functioned properly.  I have adjusted the
microswitch on the end of the motor assembly, but this has no affect.
2) The fasten seat belt light on the dash randomly pops on when driving, then
goes off again.  No one and nothing is on the passenger seat.
3) The cruiuch harder, but noticable.
> 

Armagan, 

  Does this only happen on low speed. If so, then I had a similar
problem with the same tick noise. It turned out that the outer wheel 
bearing on my 944 were loose to the point where turning the steering
wheel would tilt the front wheels to an angle (sort of like toe-out,
only bigger).

It could be something else on you car but do check out the front wheel
bearing and make sure they are properly tighten.  If there is no play
in both of the front wheels then proceed to steering rack trouble
shooting.

Good Luck!
Afsar

- -- 
e-mail: husain@zeus1.issc.com

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 8:41:26 PST
From: Ehab Aljandali <ehab@cisco.com>
Subject: Re: Adjustable spring plates

>
	Hi Mike and P-nuts:

I would like to recommend that you do not use the adj sp for height adjustment
as I mentioned in my previous email. You should use the teeth on the torsion
bars and get the height almost perfect with the adjusting plate screw in the
middle of its travel. Then use the screws to fine tweak the height and weight
balance the corners.
I am just trying to tell you that these plates are advertised for height
adj. but in fact they are not designed for that reason. 
BTW, mine too are built by Sway-A-way.
Do not forget to have a pro align and balance the four corners! makes the car
track and slide the same right or left.


Good luck, Ehab.

 
> >What's the wisdom on those Weinimeister (sp?) adjustable
> >spring plates ?  I thought someone on the list mentioned having trouble
> >installing them.  Other than that, all I have to go on is
> >the glowing praise Automotion* heaps on a product made by their
> >own sister company.  If it really works, it looks like it
> >would make adjusting the rear ride height a _lot_ easier.
> 
> Chris,
> 
> I put them on my car a little over a year ago.  I think they are great.
> Saves alot of time getting the car levelled after replacing the 
> torsion bars.  I used mine to adjust my ride height, too.  Works beautifully.
> I also had to file the bushings down to get them to fit my car (I think 
> someone else mentioned this).  I used some of the stuff called "Formula 5
> Prelube" and after about 14 months, have no squeaks at all.  BTW, I 
> bought my adj spring plates from Troutman $210.  Lots cheaper than
> Automotion, etc.  Another BTW - mine were made be Sway-A-Way, not
> Weltmeister.
> 
> Mike Dayton
> '76 Euro 911
> 


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 1995 08:47:07 -0800
From: dem@best.com (DEM)
Subject: 914 hunting

Hi 'philes.

(First, if you're in a hurry, you might just want to skip to "Now, some
questions:" down below. :)

Recently I decided I needed another car that wasn't such a fan of vandalism
that my nice 944S is (a few weeks ago, I was in a parking lot less than 5
minutes and returned to a car decorated with permenant marker - took a few
hours to polish out.) so that I could breathe a little easier driving to
certain Unfamiliar places.

Since I'm no fan of mid eighties econoboxes, I thought a BMW 2002 would be
pretty neat.  Unfortunately the "nice" ones (pre-smog) were out of my
price range.  I'm looking in the $3Kish area.  I did find a very nice
original '76 2002 with all records since new and very stock, I gave it a try
and was underwhelmed.

So, I was unhappy.  Was I headed to mid-eighties econobox land? No!
I found myself thinking thusly: "What could be better than TWO Porsches!"

I recalled that while looking in the paper there seemed to be a fair
amount of 914's in my required price range.  The idea of a mid-engine
two seater targa has always appealed to me, so I circled the ad "1976 914
2.0 excellent xxx-xxxx" and was off.

First, my driving impressions:  wheeeeeeeeeeeeeeeOoooooo!!!!

Fun, nimble, very zippy, wonderfully noisey!  Totally, utterly impractical.
I want one.

My girlfriend thinks I'm insane, but what's wrong with a bit of
insanity to go along with your Porsche(s)?

Now, some questions:

The car in question (76 2.0) seemed...well...  bad.  No records, the seller
knew almost nothing about the car, etc etc.

To me it looked like someone started to restore it, and ran out of money.
New seats, targa top, springs/struts/etc.

The car had also been resprayed a year or so ago (judging by the fade).
It was not a good job.  The trim pieces were left on and masked around,
etc.  There were 2 or 3 small visible rust bubbles in both storage 
compartments.  The battery tray was also rusted with all the paint flaking
off.

A question about rust:  How much is too much?  Reading the 914 FAQ,
the battery tray is a very common rust point.  In my $3K price range,
I expect I may be seeing a bit more of this.  Is there a point
where the rust can be amputated fairly easily?  Obviously if the
battery tray is rusted there is going to be some on on the chassis
there too.  Or should I hold out for an utterly rust free car?

The transmission was also pretty much shot.  1st, 2nd, and 3rd
gear synchro's were non-existant.  How much does a tranny rebuild
run on the 73 or later 914's?  This car also had the Euro gear
shift pattern.  How common was this?

The gas pedal seemed to require far more pressure than seems
correct (as much or more than the clutch).  I assume this isn't
normal?

Am I expecting too much from a car marked "Excellent!" for
$3600?  I'd like a car that's reliable, rust free, and well
maintained and preferably stock.  It doesn't have to be beautiful,
I even wouldn't mind "dogged" and "ugly", as long as it isn't 
rusty.  Doesn't have to be a 2.0 either.  I'd prefer a 73 or later,
but again, not a requirement.

Any other helpful 914 tidbits would be much appreciated.

Dennis Mitsch (dem@best.com)
1988 944S
1973+ 914 maybe :)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 11:53:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 fuel tank vacuum


Eric,

>At any rate, I am looking at page 20-8 of the service manual that
>is labeled "Active Carbon Tank for Pollutant-Free Fuel Tank
>Venting (Layout)". I am wondering if it is likely that the carbon tank
>itself has become clogged or is it more likely that the valve between
>the expansion tank and the carbon tank (labeled: 4 - Safety valve)
>has become non-functional.

This was a problem in particular for the 944S.  A service bulletin
recommended removing a long vent line which ran from the can
along the drive side rocker.  Apparently they had a number of
cars whose fuel tanks collapsed in the winter months.

I don't know whether this is your problem.  I would check the vent
and I would also check the fuel return line for damage (kinking).
In fact, just go over all the lines to and from the tank, expansion
tank (in RHS C pillar) and filler neck.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 11:36:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re: Removing 944 camshaft sprocket


>4) After stripping out the head of the bolt, get out a 3/8 inch drill and
>drill the head out.

If you get to this step, you might want to first try the following.  Get a
pair of vice-grip pliers and clamp them on the bolt head *real* hard.
I mean *real* hard.  This has, I blush to confess, saved my butt on
both CV and flywheel bolts; never had to try it on a cam bolt (knock
wood).

Welding is also an option.  Never done it myself, though.

As a rule, you have to be really careful to get full engagement when
turning an allen head or triple square head bolt.  The allens just want
to munge.  The triple squares are quite a bit better, no doubt because
their design puts torque on flat faces in the spline head, where an allen
basically puts most of the torque along the face.

So clean out the bolt head with carb cleaner, a brush, or whatever
before sticking the bit in it.  Esp. important for the CV bolts, which
are invariably crud-laden.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 11:47:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re: is this a serious problem?


> My 85.5 944 just developed a problem. The steering wheel does
> not always work smoothly. When I steer to the left at about 30
> degrees steering becomes harder at one specific point. It is not
> very much harder, but noticable. Then I hear a single tick after
> which it is smooth again. I do not think it happens on all left
> turns though. It is like something becomes stuck at that point
> which is quite short. It looks like a problem with power steering,
> but what is it? Is it serious or can I continue to live with it?

It sounds like this is a problem with the power steering.  Its design
is quite clever, being basically torque sensitive.  I am not sure
what will fix things for you.  I would begin by draining your PS
fluid, replacing the reservoir with a new one, and replenishing
with fresh ATF.

You have to replace the reservoir because it contains a non-
servicable filter at its base (I am told).  You will drain the system
by opening a union bolt at the rack or at the PS pump; you will
need new seal rings when you put it back together.

Of course, start by making sure your PS reservoir is topped off.
If you're dry, it cannot do its work.

Kevin

------------------------------

se control will hold the speed for a while, then surge faster.  I
have seen and saved the posting about the repair place in Tennessee, but was
wondering if possibly there is a sensor that I should replace first before I
remove the brain controller.
4) The idle sometimes bouces up and down from about 900 rpm to 1200 rpm, and
eventually settles down.  the idle controller valve has been replaced, and
tuneups have had no effect.
5) When upshifting from first to second the gears grind if shifted rapidly,
but no problem on downshifting, and no problem if not shifted rapidly.  The
clutch has been previously replaced .
FYI, the car now has 145,000 miles (I've owned since new) and has had almost
everything replaced at least twice!
Thanks in advance for everyone's assistance.
Jeff
'85.5 black 944

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 10:13:00 PST

Subject: Insurance Hassles


Sorry if this is old news, I just joined the list this week.  The reason I 
joined is that I looked at an '88 928 that I was hoping to purchase 
tomorrow.  In any case, I called my insurance company for a rate quote.  I 
should've known something was wrong when the agent who answered the phone 
said to me, "Oh, a Porsche.  I'll have to get a supervisor to call you." 
 When I asked why, she replied "Porsche's arent in my computer because they 
are evaluated on a case by case basis."  I left my name and # and waited for 
a call back.  Finally, I get a call from a supervisor.  First she says, 
"Yeah, we'll insure that car" like she's doing me some kind of favor.  Then 
she quotes me a RIDICULOUS rate.  I asked why it was so high since I'm 28, 
married, 2 other cars on the policy, no tickets, etc... She gives me this 
whole "sports car, goes real fast, blah blah blah" spiel.  So I told her my 
other car was newer, worth more, driven more and also goes pretty fast 
(although that still doesn't mean I speed).  Evenutally, I realized it was 
pointless to argue.  Have the rest of you guys had to put up with this kind 
of stuff?  Is reasonably priced insurance for a Porsche possible?  At this 
point I'm thinking of not buying the car, because I've heard of people 
getting dropped just because they bought a Porsche.

Thanks.

Date: Fri, 31 Mar 95 16:36:26 BST
From: kevin@mailserver.aixssc.uk.ibm.com
Subject: Electrical fire (fwd)

>
>A friend of mine had an electrical fire shortly after having his 87 944T
>repainted.  On driving home from the shop he had to turned on his
>headlights and within minutes he had a cockpit full of smoke.  
>
>John A. Wise                                    Tel: (+1) (904) 226-6384
>

John,
      I had a wiring problem with my 944S a few weeks ago. One of
my headlamps suddenly went out while in use. On investigation
I found that the fuse had blown. The replacement fuse also blew.
An hour spent with an multimeter traced the fault to the three wires
leading to the connector behind the headlamp unit.
All three cables are covered in a sleave and after stripping back the 
sleaving I found that the insulation had been worn from two of them
causing a short, and one of those (the earth) had actually broken. 

I think the problem was caused by the wiring not being adequately 
secured and therefore susceptible to vibration. It's now tie-wrapped
just as securely as the other side which checked OK.

- -- 
Regards,        IBM IPnet: kevin@aixssc.uk.ibm.com   Voice: +44-256-343000
Kevin Murrell       UKnet: kevin@aixssc.ibm.co.uk     VNET: NHBVM7(MURREK)
